1 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 24, 1995


Nigeria;
Interview With Lagbaja (bisade Ologunde)


BYLINE: Glendora International


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 6791 words


 

<i>Lagbaja is not only the theme for the music album of Bisade Ologunde's team. It is a theme but more than a theme. It is a concept. A concept of a masked musician. An anonymous man, an unknown instrumentalist striking the keyboard notes or blasting away on the bass guitar. Bisade would not confirm this, but Lagbaja, that is the concept of an unknown man rings a strident bell with both a musical and political resonance. Can we expect not to recall that Fela Anikulapo-Kuti in the 70s released an album titled Unknown Soldier? Which itself echoed the summed up verdict of a judicial commission that investigated a raid of uniformed soldiers on his erstwhile residential compound in Lagos - the Kalakuta Republic. As Bisade confesses to us, influences fly from mind to mind purely at the stream of the subconscious: Nobody can hold on to it.</i>

<strong> Q: Can you give us a brief introduction to your person?</strong> 

A: Well, I call Bisade a musician. I'm also a producer. We have a band, we've been together now for about five or six years; sorry, this is the fifth year; in another one month, it will be five years we've been together. The band is called Colours. We play basically African music. It's like all my work is based around that band for now. Studio production for now are limited to experimental projects. That's the summary of what I'm all about.

<strong> Q: Is there any relationship between Bisade Ologunde and the invisible man, the masquerade you called 'Lagbaja'? </strong>

A: Bisade is the producer for Lagbaja. I also conceived the idea. But there has been so much unnecessary focus on the person behind Lagbaja. The more important thing is the message of Lagbaja and the total concept. Anybody could be Lagbaja. It's just the significance of using a mask. And the main importance of that mask is that the mask is like a symbol of the facelessness of the so-called common main in Africa. So, we have different people perform the role of Lagbaja, being masked performers. But Bisade is Bisade. I'm not Lagbaja. If I wish too, I could wear the mask and perform Lagbaja also. But somehow, I think it's probably due to some press misconception that led people to thinking of Lagbaja as Bisade or whatever. We've had several people play the role of Lagbaja as a matter of fact.

<strong> Q: Looking at the music trend in Nigeria, would you say there is anything called Nigerian Jazz?</strong>

A: Em Classification of music is basically for communication. If you wish to call something Nigerian Jazz, that would be your classification. Generally, I understand jazz to be a universal style. It's equally a universal tag. Music is a language that is universal. So, when we talk about Jazz, it's got to be the same Jazz all over the world. "Nigerian Jazz" could only mean an English phrase to talk about the Nigerian scene.

<strong>Q: Richard Smith was talking about this classification and how they relate to the Nigerian environment. Like reggae, that we have only one or two reggae musicians in Nigeria playing the kind of reggae that you find in the West Indies and all that - Can we have a general apart from Jazz, may be reggae and calypso Do you think it is possible to have any of these forms? </strong>

A: This is possible. But we have some problems I will say, of knowledge, know-how. When you talk about Jazz, basically, even in America where Jazz is probably at its peak form, there are all kinds of controversies on what is Jazz and what is not Jazz. So, when you talk about Jazz, basically people, purists think in terms of the original art form that was the popular music of the world at some point in time and that has styles like swing, bebop, blues. They tend to consider that more like Jazz than what generally people call Jazz here which is classified as fusion in their own terms. So when you talk about Nigerian Jazz, it's like you are now beginning to add another dimension to the confusion of classification. Lots of what we might call Nigerian Jazz might end up just being another type of fusion which is basically like taking instruments of standard Jazz forms and having the instruments of African or Nigerian forms and adding those things. If you put percussion in Jazz it's no news. It's been done even since the days of Coltrane - all kinds of amalgamation, mixtures of Jazz and other forms. So, the sub-division can go on endlessly. I prefer to just keep to the international standard of what they believe is Jazz and how they classify the other forms, the ones they call music of avant-garde or the ones they call fusion. Or indeed Jazz of the more recent hip-hop adventures.

<strong> Q: So, it's not possible to recognise any local trend that can really be?</strong>

A: We can talk about the efforts of Nigerians and their ideas of Jazz but they are not many, they are not sufficient to have a movement. When we talk about new ideas and movements, you must have an active scene. You must have musicians coming together in workshops, exchanging ideas; when these guys, the M-Base guys take up the saxophone, they just come together, Greg Osby, Steve Coleman, they come together, they play, they discuss, they rub minds together. And then ideas come out over a period of time. It's an active, dynamic thing. That's what I'm saying, that it's not a very active movement. One or two people. Really, they are just making individual efforts.

<strong>Q: Is it possible to make the same comment about reggae? </strong>

A: Now, reggae in a way, yes. But I' II say what really made reggae popular in Nigeria was the media and Bob Marley and all the Virgin Record guys - I-Roy and co. It took a long time before authentic Jamaica -like reggae came out. The youths that were listening then grew up until they were able to play. It was easier for them to tend to reggae because, one, the technical facilities they needed weren't that complicated. Most of reggae is based around the two, three chord progression. Much like you find in highlife, basic primary chords most of the time. A few adventurous pieces have more than three, four chords. But it's easier to learn some basic chords and play reggae. Also, there is a particular rhythm which you play when you play those forms. As opposed to Jazz where a piece could have probably some nine, ten chords with some different arrangements per section. But aside from blues that also uses basic primary chords and extensions of them like seventh, ninth, in reggae there are basically the primary chords, the one, four, five major and a few minors. So I think that is what aided the growth of reggae. Also the general culture, again through the media, aided the growth of reggae. And I think it is through practice that a style develops. Eventually, it got to the point where people were able to play in a style that could almost be called a Nigerian style of reggae. Also, Nigerian could be a wide classification. If you play an instrumental piece of reggae, it would sound very much like an instrumental piece of reggae from Jamaica. But then, when you start singing, the accent will give you away and then you see a difference. But they got to the point of aping so much, talking the patois, "I 'n I" and "gimme likkle sugar' and stuff like that.

<strong>Q: Can we go back a bit? Give us brief over view of your musical backgrounds? </strong>

A: Musically, I've been playing in bands from school. First of all, it was Government College, Ibadan. Later, Obafemi Awolowo University, Ile Ife. I was lucky to have friends that were active in music too. So, together we kind of taught ourselves through reading books and discussing and arguing, sometimes ignorantly, until over time our interests grew and our skills too on some instruments. There were many influences, Nigerian and foreign. I will say the very first artiste that I got into was Carlos Santana. And rock. But you see, there were some instrumental rock pieces like Samba Patti. And as a matter of fact, it was from that style, that instrumental rock thing, that I got to recognise that there were other pieces called jazz. So, it was from Carlos Santana I got into Bob James and Earl Klugh. And it was my surprise about a year later I found out that there were even more exciting forms - swing, big band, bebop.

<strong>Q: You were reading most of the time? </strong>

A: It was more of listening then. More like you just get to a place by chance and you hear that someone has a record and he's playing it and something sounds interesting.

<strong>Q: What about the Nigerian Scene? </strong>

A: The Nigerian scene? It was mainly Fela.

<strong>Q: What did you study?</strong>

A: I did first degree in Education Biology. Then I did an M.B.A.

<strong>Q: About which time were you focused on Fela?</strong>

A: Fela has been from secondary school. Well, not only Fela. There was Fela and Baba L'Egba - that's Yussuf Olatunji- and Haruna Ishola. It was much later, during my Masters years that I got into fuji, I was more excited about apala and sakara, especially Baba L'Egba.

<strong>Q: What is it about Yussuf?</strong>

A: There is this smooth oh not blues in the scene of America blues as such, but the feel; blues in the scene of the feel. In fact when he attempted to sing the fast songs in the fashion of that time, they were usually in his funny drawl that if you aren't careful, listening to the music, you'll probably sleep off. But there are very exciting ways in which he would say things. Despite the fact that I am Yoruba, it took me a long time to even understand some Yoruba things he was saying because of the way in which they were said. Not following the usual phonetic patterns of Yoruba, "do-re-mi-re-do"; the basic things; turning things around. And also the poetry of his compositions. The way he would start in the middle, stop in the middle and repeat parts of it, then the guys in the band would probably just join like they had forgotten they were supposed to join and end the piece. But I found out it was actually a style - not that they forgot or anything, it was just the style. Apala came into my consciousness more because somehow it was popular around with some DJs. So you got to hear them on the radio. But again it was the composition of Haruna Ishola. I remember clearly "Ina ran/O k' omo to o't owo b'eeru;" "On my way to London. Ko s'ewu rara." Quite exciting pieces at that time. I think it was the sheer pleasure of listening to all those During my Masters years, I had a friend who had discovered fuji before me. So, he just brought a couple of records and I got to hear them. Then it was Barrister

<strong>Q: What hit you about fuji? Was there also a feel?</strong>

A: I really can't place my finger. It was a gradual thing. I would say that as a matter of fact, I initially looked down on fuji. It didn't strike me as anything exciting. It sounded like they were even stealing pieces from apala and sakara. But gradually, I got to find that they had their original style. It took a long time to even differentiate between Barrister and Kollington. They even looked alike to me at that time, sounded alike and so on. So, it was after a while you find they had totally different styles. Then came Wasiu with his Talazo Disco

<strong>Q: Barrister and Kollington are probably in the old school now with the Wasuis coming out. What are the differences? It seems their works have not been able to go beyond Nigerian shores. Is there something about it that is unable to aspire to world standard?</strong>

A: I think it's difficult to find a reason for its not going international. Of course they play abroad and stuff like that. But when it comes down to individual creativity, the personality of the man behind the music, Sunny Ade taking juju beyond these mighty boundaries has to do more with Sunny Ade as a person. Because music nowadays is seen from the perspective of the individual, of the solo act, and how he puts the package together; what he looks like, sounds like and everything. In spite of the language barrier, Sunny was able to do something. I think in fuji, there hasn't been a person with that personality yet; you know, who is dynamic enough to have the so-called star quality. It's not a thing you can hold on to, but he has them. Now, having said that I think, it's also still developing. I think it had a very big break about seven years ago. Then it actually almost took over all parties from juju. And I think it was basically because of the fact that it was easier to buy equipment to play fuji. So even today, you have thousands of fuji musicians around. At that time, it would cost you about N125.00 to buy the total fuji equipment. But because it was mainly sekere (maracas) and sakara. In fact, not even gangan (talking drum) that was so expensive. A single flat-faced sakara then was about N15.00; two sakaras, about four omele, then sekere, agogo (gong) and you are fine. And, of course, guys went there. As opposed to juju that you needed to buy a bass guitar and about four guitars and a synthesizer and a drum set- and these are foreign things. So it was quite expensive. Fuji players/musicians even went so far as offering to play for free, hoping that they would be sprayed at the party.

<strong>Q: You had a project. Can you talk about it - with one of the fuji artistes?</strong>

A: I found out then that fuji was a growing style, I was quite excited. It was an active like an active Yoruba popular music. Or let's say metropolitan, urban - In Lagos, they had what you call jumps everyday of the week in different places. Again, it came down to being able to afford the instruments to play with. Also, the instruments are there, being as a Yoruba thing. In addition, they already had people they could look up to, people who were technically versatile already. So they had heroes to worship and, learn from percussion wise. Therefore, it was growing. This is very much unlike the saxophone. I mean. I had to learn the sax myself, more or less. Those I thought I could look up to were themselves not so good, just about average. You couldn't find people to tell you about tones, and to correct you. They would think that's good already when you know you are not even sounding like what you know you should sound like they can't even tell the difference. Those you thought were the heroes, you get close to them and found they were out of tune. They could hardly play in more than one or two keys. But in fuji then, it's like you have these people who are entirely in the music business. It was possible to go ahead and learn from those - ask questions, watch them, so they were playing. I got excited about this, going round and watching them. Then I decided to invest in it and record an artiste. Although apart from creative reasons, I had commercial motives at that time too. You see I found out that it was actually the cheapest thing I could release. Now, pop music, if you really want to sound good, you have to have the right equipment and you have to have the know-how to operate the equipment well. Then, more of the time, you took many more sessions to have something done in the studio. Now, for fuji, the guys play together. This is more like the jazz of those days. You go to the studio, the guys come together and they just play. And they record about two or three tapes. That's the music. Not that you go to the studio, you record the drums, you record the bass guitar and the keyboard, you overdub this and that; it takes a long time. And then it is not their own music. Really, people were still learning the technology involved. You sometimes had the synthesizer and you couldn't programme it, you use whatever thing is in the synthesizer, stuff like that. But in fuji, it is different, where the music is around you, and they could play together as a band. So, in three sessions, I could finish a programme. So, I decided to look all over town to find the kind of guy that I thought could do the kind of thing I wanted him to do. I had my ideas too like an A and R (artiste and repertoire) person. So I was looking for a young person who believed in himself, and who could compose. Because I found then that you heard the same songs everywhere. Obviously only a few people were really composing. Most of the others, even the established acts were like stealing or borrowing ideas and concepts from the others who hadn't the chance to record. So it's difficult to track down a person with these qualities. Especially one who was able to compose. Also who looks good - had the so-called star quality you can really put your hands on. And of course who was sensible enough to want to work. I almost gave up after about six months. Then, by chance, I saw a guy playing at Ketu (area of Lagos). And his voice was good. He was sounding very good. But he looked very sheepish kind of in his performance - stand on one side, cock his head to one side. He didn't even have the aura that was captivating. But his voice was great. So, I spoke to his manager who then said I should come back the next day to watch somebody else perform at the same place. I saw that one perform. He was vibrant. But he didn't sound good, he didn't sound creative. So, I told the manager I couldn't work with that too and that was the guy called Hajji Top. So, he said there was a third guy who was performing else where-somewhere else in Ojota. That if I could fix a time with him over the weekend, we could go and watch that guy. That's how I got to see Sandoka. He kind of had much of what I wanted - you know, he was young, he was good looking and he had his own way of singing; slightly aggressive, but he was unique. I also thought at that time that he was composing most of the pieces. That was more like '84, '84/'85. I found eventually that he too was actually borrowing from places I hadn't been. So, When I thought he was composing, he wasn't composing. And I found out that the best of the composers then was a guy called Shaura- that was his nickname. I've forgotten his real name now. His base was Idumota area of Lagos. And he was at constant loggerheads with Wasiu, the Talazo king of the time. So, many of these acts were actually stealing or borrowing or adapting. They go to watch themselves. Like when I'm not playing, I go watch you plat at a jump, I hear something, I pick it up. Because the jump is free- I mean no gate fee, just come in. But they expected you to spray and buy food and stuff like that. So, it's like they hang out together. In fact when you see another star, you'll probably spend about ten minutes praising him and making him dance or whatever. The only real culture then that was really out and developed from the roots. And that was also contemporary, you have moved a little away from apala to what was happening that was entirely ours. It was a real culture. And it was real, it was happening. As opposed to the so-called Nigerian jazz or even pop, it was really happening. One, you had so many people doing it so you could have others to learn from. Also it was from the roots of the Yorubas. It was easy to develop; it was growing. And also it was in a language that they could understand. It came to a time that it was like a colloquial - even mixing words of English into it just like is normal everyday life. So it was more like the authentic contemporary urban style of the Yoruba at that point- even up to now.

<strong>Q: Do you want to link it to ghetto rap or stuff like that?</strong>

A: Yeah. I think as a matter of fact it's like our own answer to that because that's their real music.

<strong>Q: Were you looking at that as an artiste or? </strong>

A: Just an independent thing.

<strong>Q: When you look at the coming of people like Adewale Ayuba, Abass Akande Obesere and Sandoka who seem to have taken over from the older Kollington, Barrister era, would you say the jump culture has produced them? Again do you see any of these guys having the potential of achieving the kind of thing Bob Marley achieved for reggae and Sunny Ade achieved for juju music in future?</strong>

A: I think it's possible. Not immediately but I think it will develop. There is no doubt it will get to that point. But unfortunately, because of our enslavement to foreign culture and the way people look at foreign things as better, they are already beginning to dilute or should we say commercialise from the point of what they think is commercial by adding synthesizers. They are not even played properly. In a way, one could say that may be even the way it is played is also real. It's not like they play in a particular way like when you have Baba L'Egba then playing his goje. Goje is like violin. But even the instrument itself, he knows about it. He knows about the tuning, he knows about the way it sounds, he knows about how the way it sounds, he knows about how it blends with his voice and style of playing. So, when you just carry a thing and you just start playing, sometimes the guy even sings on a different key from what the guy who is backing him is trying to do. If the guy who was backing him knew about his instrument, he could as well listen and learn from the lead vocalist's style of doing things. And after, decide to accompany him, learn a different style of accompanying. Not come and install a two, three chord pop style behind the guy who is changing keys.

<strong>Q: Is it the norm now?</strong>

A: Yeah, that's what's happening now.

<strong>Q: Is it going to obliterate the originality of the whole thing?</strong>

A: I think it would take a few, probably more serious people. Maybe somebody will come up with a style among them and develop something. But then it comes down to awareness. One, you have to believe in your own thing. Two, you have to respect yourself, know that you are a worthy human being. And that something that is yours coming from you is as authentic as of anywhere else.

<strong>Q: How does the man on the street, who just wants to make a million dollars, how does he have that kind of orientation?</strong>

A: Well (laughter). Well, we can only hope. By the way too, we are working on something similar. It's like em..I've been fascinated by that kind of music from time. So, it's like we came up with this style of music that was highly percussive but not just percussive. We use the talking drum as an instrument of rhythm in backing. Not just talking, but singing. Normally, when you get a talking drummer to play, he plays, he talks, not that he sings. Now you try to now understand his own way of thinking when it comes to melody. He doesn't have to play in what you consider to be the standard Western classification of notes into keys and notes. It's like 'play, play'. Get about seven guys to play, all different styles, and try to find what is the link between them, the way they think. I mean, like if you ask my talking drummer now to do for you the tonic solfa, I mean the guy, he would probably do about four, five out of seven notes. And that's how he understands that. But he has an authentic musical style in him. He is going to be a master of his drum. So, can I now learn from him? How is he thinking? What is he even thinking about? How can I use that for my own music in the so-called popular genre? And that's the thinking. So we kind of produce things that had the talking drum combined with drums to play rhythms. That gives us the beats. And the beats are not the standard four-four beats or the popular disco beats or the hip-hop beats. They are more like, well, they are slightly jerky, probably more related to where the guy was coming from - the drummer. His own personality, his own history of understanding, his own understanding of music, his own free thought. But again, he's also a product of several influences. He's also heard M.C. Hammer and Michael Jackson. So, in a way, he's been influenced too. But his own interpretation of those forms, of his own instrument is different from my own interpretation. Because I am thinking already in almost the Western key forms. He is still thinking in his own mode. And you can hear it, he is not thinking in terms of how I am thinking, so, he is authentic. And he moves people; and you don't really know what is moving them. You can't say I mean like ask them 'what exactly is exciting about ? They just tell you 'Men, I mean it's nice. It sounds good.' So, there is something about what he is doing that's authentic.

<strong>Q: It's an evolution of this decadent style of music where someone like you that is sound and is out of the same urban crowd here but is taking a bunch of talking drummers that are ingrained in the background of the tradition and now is directing them. Is this what you are trying to do? You are taking your own culture among your own class of people and holding on to it too and then with different vibrations?</strong>

A: Yes, the only difference is that may be now I am putting in editing language. May be now I'm doing a little of English. That's the only attempt to communicate to the wide population of English speakers.

<strong>Q: Is that not modernising?</strong>

A: No. O.K., now, I won't call it modernising. It comes back again to being honest with myself. Now, initially, I looked down again upon foreign culture because I felt it's doing a bad thing for us here. But then I found that I had to find myself. The fact is that as a young African, I've passed through several experiences. I went to a primary school that was put on the form of British education. Next, I went to secondary school that was even one of the best in the country, a government school that had white teachers initially who established the school. And then I got to a point where you had to learn the proper way, the proper grammar for English. If you said something wrong, I mean grammatically, they say you misfired; I mean they would make fun of you. So, you had to learn some things, some forms. And then it got to the point where you prefer to wear a shirt and a trouser and you wouldn't want to wear your own thing. It took a long time before you got to where you are. So, as a person, I'm also a product of many influences. Some, traditional, some foreign. All of them affect the psyche. Even things that had nothing to do with music. The politics of the nation, the madness, the ignorance of the people at the top. They affect things that affect you ultimately: your growth is limited to their perception, their lack of vision. So, you are an individual that is a product of many influences. So, I found out that I had to discover myself first of all and be. I mean, I said 'You have to be yourself.' I am not really traditional. Even fuji music if you really want to hear the authentic music of the Yorubas, you have to go to the villages and go to the festivals. The same talking drum I use in a different style. Our talking drummer is ayan, Ayangbola. He was born into the family of talking drummers. So, he grew up as he went with them from ceremony to ceremony and so on. But he came to Lagos to join juju bands and stuff like that. So, he is a product of many influences. Juju bands were aspiring to add foreign things to their music. In fact, they even quarrelled on who first introduced the trap drum set, who first introduced the bass guitar, who first introduced something exciting. And again as a nation, even as a continent, we are under regular slavery economically, culturally. And the audience you are trying to talk to, people generally, they live under the same condition that you live in, even worse; the listeners. I am not excited about creating art for art's sake. As far as I am concerned, it's a communication thing. Also, I have a message. And I think it's a message I have need to carry across. I cannot sing fuji. As a matter of fact, it would be pretentious because it wouldn't really be real. I cannot play apala per se, that's not me. Now I cannot play jazz like Lee Morgan would, or like John Coltrane would. More or less, I am inspired more by the singing of Miles Davis. It's not a matter of selling out. I' ll never buy ignorance. It's a dynamic thing. And it has to do with your culture at that point in time and the people. Miles was a part of jazz O.K., may be they had a commercial interest too, to make money and stuff like that. But if you look at other great jazz artistes like Sonny Rollins, or like Pharoah Sanders, you find them constantly learning, experimenting. It's a continuous process. And they keep learning and they keep imbibing all kinds of ideas into their stuff. It's not rigid. A style goes for a while. If you play all the time, you really get bored with something. Like Fela would never play live a song he's recorded. I think it has to do with some form of gaining style of his own. I mean, it would be tough for him to go on stage now and start playing Palaver and Lady He would be bored. And then it wouldn't be challenging to him creatively. I would want to create something new all the time, be on the edge of it. As a matter of fact, now we have a problem with Lagbaja because at this point in time I am almost tired of the music already. And it's not a year old in the market. It's more to do with being creative and having a new ideas that makes those old things very outdated more or less. Not outdated per se but outdated somehow to me. People still want them. It's like OK., let's play it for them, they are asking for it. But there are new things

<strong>Q: Don't you think you need to give it time to evolve before you switch to another thing?</strong>

A: I think it's more because I have grown in awareness over the last eighteen months. And my growth had nothing to do with music. Again it came back to the political situation in Nigeria. The June 12 madness, it's like I understood other things about life. And I got to a point where I found that I had to do other things apart from what I was doing. So, what we are doing now is nearer what I think we are going for. It's not a deliberate attempt to go one way or the other. But I'm just trying to follow my natural inclination; the thing I feel good doing, I enjoy doing and that's giving me some creative vibes. And that's why the new direction is coming up. So, I was saying that it's difficult to just hang on to one style if you don't think about the importance of course of being dynamic. And nothing is static. Things keep changing all the time. It should be same for art and for music. And there was no way that jazz itself could ever have been developed if people did not strive for something new. The Africans who were taken as slaves then could have been playing white music of playing their home stuff. Nothing new would have come out. Jazz would never have been developed. It's a matter of dynamism. I'm not an American anyway, I'm not a custodian of traditional jazz or whatever. I want to make music and communicate my art to the best of my ability and to keep learning from other forms. So, I came up with this new thing now. And I don't think that is the end point yet. I think I will have to see people's response to it. I try to ask questions from people that: 'What really moves you about music? Can you tell me what exactly excites you? I read a couple of books, well, not really read. I kind of glanced through them trying to they talk about the function of music or whatever. In fact, I wrote a thesis, my thesis of my M.B.A. was on marketing music in Nigeria. So, I had to go through some books; there was a book on functions of music. It gave me a little bit of an insight into what moves people about music. But I'm still not satisfied. People really can't hold on to what they think moves them. And it seems to be what, I mean, there must be a norm to determine what is good music or bad music. It's very very subjective from person to person. And so, it's like I keep wondering whether it's not like a spiritual thing. Something you really can't hold on to, that it's a subconscious thing. That's why people have hits once in their lifetimes and never have another hit. They try their best to find what exactly moved people the first time around and they can't find it again. It's a subconscious mixture of so many things. From the timing of release to the lyrics, to the beats, to the mood of the society. I mean, so many things at that point in time. So I find out that it was just good to be me with all my conflicting influences. Before we talk about other types of music in Nigeria, this new thing, is it going to have 'Every man's name like Lagbaja or what is the name? What are you calling it? Answer: Well, Lagbaja again. The concept was developed with the idea of mass communication in mind. An image that could be powerful - a masked musician. Somebody you don't know who is behind the mask. At this point in time, I am actually considering whether or not to pack up totally the Lagbaja thing. We have a problem of communication with the people artistically. People want to see the face of the artiste, see your expressions when you are sad, when you are smiling, everything coming to the people. The mask kind of makes the image static; all they can see are the eyes. They can't see his cheeks or his mouth curl up or curl down. So, there is this static thing about it. We've tried to develop all kinds of masks and reduce this. I even saw some photographs in your shop (Glendora Bookshop/Jazz Hole) of some women from is it Tunisia or from Djibouti, they had this purdah kind of mask which I would say are friendly masks. But still those things have a connotation of religion which I wanted to move away from. Also the mask connoted masquerades in Yoruba culture. Now, I am a Christian. And I really believe in what I believe in. And it's like I didn't feel happy with the mix-up; people take you at times to be a masquerade- Nothing to do with the egungun. This is more like contemporary music. And also communicating the essence of an image. Also we were trying to build an image that could be powerful in terms of recollection. It's difficult to see ten saxophonists play and not remember the guy who was masked. But then that took away from the music because what interests people was who was behind the mask. As opposed to the music itself. So, right now, as a matter of fact, we have serious arguments, discussions, the band, about what to do Lagbaja has already built something. So, it's like how can you decide to just break it down and move on to something else? So, we can't make up our minds what to do. The new thing might still be Lagbaja in the very end. But the image of Lagbaja might be different. Now, also Lagbaja had a political connotation which was deliberate. And which is like the most powerful part of the whole image. 'Lagbaja' in Yoruba means 'So-And So.' 'Somebody', the anonymous person; it's like Tom of Tom, Dick and Harry. So, Lagbaja was chosen as a word to stand for the faceless common man. What really happens when something affects, I mean, like in this country (Nigeria), it happens to a so-called big man, then things move fast. Like when they shot one (army) colonel at the check-point, they threw out police check-points immediately. I tell you there are hundreds of Lagosians who've been shot before and even since then at check-points and nothing ever came out of it. So, it's like they are faceless. They are not known. Except you are in a powerful position or like the son of somebody powerful, you are nobody. So you are faceless. How do we now build an icon, a symbol that would represent the facelessness of the so-called common man - me too I hate that word 'common man'. How do you now represent them? So, we chose to use a mask to represent that. Two, they are supposed to be common. A connotation which ultimately comes down to cheap, of little substance. So, it was like, o.k., let's use the word 'Lagbaja' to represent that and then try and build the image as a voice of the so-called common people. So that was why we came up with, 'Let him be faceless.' There is a third reason why we came up with the masked face. It has to do with wanting to be private. Because initially I was going to perform as Lagbaja myself before I came up with the idea of steering my original band, Colours as a party band and have somebody perform Lagbaja as a different person. So, I wanted to be a private person. I wanted to be successful at my work and yet be devoid of the co-called glamour attached to show business. Like on Sunday, I just walk from my house, I stroll to the Shrine to go and watch Femi (Anikulapo-Kuti) or walk down Allen Avenue in Ikeja area of Lagos), nobody knows me. Last week, I was at Tejuoso Market to buy some things. Last Saturday I was at Wasiu Ayinde's show at Yaba Tech. Things like that you couldn't do if your face were known all over by everybody. They would harass you, I mean, in a friendly manner. But you don't have the freedom. So, it was a reason why that image came up.

<strong>Q: What do you think of other music forms in Nigeria like our own pop and reggae, highlife and also the folk music of people like Dan Maraya Jos, Mamman Shata?</strong>

A: Again, I believe that, like I said, we are unique as Nigerians with so many influences. Some years ago, I believed that it was impossible to play pop music like the originators of pop music. 'Pop' itself came from 'popular music' anyway. But I mean the popular African-American style. I was also amazed why Nigerians were so excited about soul music. Why they looked down on Nigerians music. Why it was foreigners that would come here and show us how to appreciate our own music forms. And then, I found that really it is a complex issue like I was telling you the last time, I think there is what I call ' it's a Black thing happening. Basically, if you look at what people love, Nigerians, it is mainly African-American culture, African-American music. People don't know about AD/DC or U2, or know about Bruce Springsteen here or Mick Jagger or Pete Townsend. Who knows them here? Nobody, more or less. But even the rap guy who is a small success in his state is known here. There is something about the rhythm, there is something about the music, there is something about African-American culture. To me, I think it's a Black thing. So we find that it comes down to the essence of the music. And the same thing applies, I think, to reggae. Because it's a Black thing from Jamaica. Bob Marley, Peter Tosh and the younger ones that came after them, Shaba Ranks and so on. It is the Black thing.

<strong>Q: Is it really conscious?</strong>

A: I am even saying it is subconscious. It is not conscious. It is not like they are going out to listen for who is Black. They just love a piece of music and I am saying ninety per cent of it is a Black thing.

<strong>Q: Do you think it is the rhythm?</strong>

A: I think it's not just the rhythm. It is a total culture. The hipness of being Black. Look at movies, people like Black movies like nothing else. People love Bill Cosby, Oprah Winfrey on television. I am talking of things that I believe. They love them as much as they love white movies. Then you see our young people trying to ape the Blacks they saw in the movies, they don't try to sound like the white they saw there; the way they talk, the way they walk, they can relate to that. The same thing with sports. Like Mike Jordan, Carl Lewis, they are popular among the youths here, they love them. Tyson, when Tyson came out, everybody wore his hairstyle. And, see the DJs are playing for the people what they perceive that people love. So, I found that this Black thing, there is no point throwing it overboard because in a way it is positive. It's not like they are just crazy for anything foreign. I was also happy that they are not as popular as just anything white. I mean, country music is not as popular as Black music in this country. You still find them in the east (eastern part of Nigeria), especially Don Williams and Kenny Rogers and so on, but just a few of them. Most of the time it is the Black thing that is really hot and really happening, even those Black artistes who are not national successes in the US., they are big here. When Lakeside, came to Nigeria then, Lakeside, Shalamar and so on, they weren't as big as many of the white pop and rock musicians. But here, they were mighty heroes. So, there is a Black thing happening. So, I think that, one day you will find a Nigerian who will come up with a concoction, out of Nigeria, not that he would go out and borrow something from abroad o. Something Nigerian. Some Nigerian that would really hit and I mean, hit it. (GR). 7 .


LOAD-DATE: May 21, 2001


LANGUAGE: English

January, 1995


Education


LENGTH: 2334 words


 

PARTS Fellowships

The Africa Bureau's Division of Productive Sector Growth and Environment (PSGE) has announced the third round of African fellowships. These fellowships are funded under USAID'a Policy, Analysis, Research, and Technical Support (PARTS) project in Washington.

African nationals are annually invited to apply for a fellowship to participate in research and analysis in agriculture and natural resources management. The purpose of the fellowship program is to: ensure African participation in research and analysis on African issues being conducted by U.S.-based organizations; provide fellowship holders with opportunities for professional growth; foster and maintain links among U.S. and African scientists and decision makers in order to adddress development issues.

The PARTS project is designed to increase the use and influence of information and analysis for agricultural and natural resources policies and programs in sub-Saharan Africa. Project activities are organized around a research-analysis-dissemination process that includes issues identification and priority setting, implementation of research and analysis, dissemination of findings, and evaluation. 

Five to ten fellowships are offered annually based on available resources. Usually, at least one fellowship is offered in each of the following five analytic areas: Agricultural Marketing/Agribusiness/Private Sector Development; Food Security and Productivity; Technology Development and Transfer; Natural Resources Management; Environment. The research and analysis in these areas is aimed at sustainable development and economic growth as related to agricultural development and natural resources management. Fellowships include travel, food, lodging, and other allowances according to USAID regulations but do not include salary.

Each fellowship involves working as a collaborator with American researchers. Participants spend approximately one to six months in the United States. Upon returning home, each fellowship holder is expected to maintain contact with staff in order to disseminate new research findings throughout their home country. Participants must be certified as physically able to undertake the fellowship and must demonstrate English proficiency adequate to interact effectively with English speaking researchers and to write a short report on their fellowship experiences. Strong consideration is given to individuals who have extensive linkages with public and private sector decision makers as well as research institutions and universities in their home country. The program is open to Africans from sub-Saharan countries regardless of sex, race, color, religion, marital status, or political affiliation.

An Africn Fellowship application form must be completed along with a one to two page essay and two attachments. The completed form, the essay and the two attachments are all to be sent to the PARTS project in Washington, D.C., by fax addressed to: PARTS African Fellowship, Fax number (703) 235-3805. Deadline on or before January 31, 1995. Applicants will be notified by fax when their application has been received. Those selected and not selected for fellowships are expected to be notified by fax on or before March 30, 1995. A symposium, Essential Health Research -- Lessons From African Successes will convene on saturday, february 18, 199 in Atlanta, Georgia.

Essential national health research (ENHR) is a relatively new concept, stemming from the pioneering Commission on Health Research for Development, formed in late 1987, an independent international effort, underwritten by some 20 private and public agencies, aimed at improving the health of people in developing countries, and focused on the enormous, yet generally neglected, power of research to accomplish that goal. A major report, based on a worldwide review of health conditions, was issued three years later, at the conclusion of the Commission's tenure, Health Research: Essential Link to Equity in Developent, stressing social justice in its pronouncements.

The Commission's successor, the Task Force on Health Research for Development, also supported by multiple donors, further advanced and operationalized the concept of ENHR, as an integrated strategy to facilitate the attainment of these goals, and involving communities, researchers, and policymakers in the process. Established in 1993, the nongovernmental Council on Health Research for Development (COHRED), sited in Geneva, now constitutes the long-term mechanism that is coordinating and further encouraging the implementation in developing countries of recommendations and deliberations resulting from the prior two initiatives. In theory and practice, the ENHR approach is quite in contrast to the classical donor-driven modality, organized vertically, for it entails a national consultative process, deals directly with priority setting, and identifies actors/organizations to implement decisions that were reached consensually.

ENHR strategies are now well underway in a number of countries, with some particularly positive developments reported from sub-Saharan Africa, the region where the twin goals of health for all and socioeconomic development have generally proved elusive heretofore. This two-session, day-long Symposium, organized as part of the AAAS Sub-Saharan Africa Program's Science in Africa series of meetings and publications, will illustrate the unique elements of the ENHR approach, as it is being adapted to circumstances in several African countries.

The morning will open with a brief overview of ENHR and the work of COHRED, to provide background and context. Country-specific examples of ENHR-in-action, each summarized by a principal African participant in the process, will follow. The first topic covered is the setting of ENHR priorities, utilizing two national cases to document the process whereby broad consensus is attained on principal goals and on appropriate resource allocation. The second section concerns the implementation of ENHR, including effective institutional structures, capacity-building efforts, and networking mechanisms. Here the experiences of three countries will be featured. In the third part the crucial question is asked, "What Difference Does ENHR Make?" Ministerial-level representatives from two countries have been invited, as decisionmakers, to assess the impact of ENHR. The final wrap-up, organized as a panel discussion, will evaluate these ENHR efforts broadly, in terms of sustainability and transferability. The discussion will also probe future directions for ENHR, not only further developments in Africa but global prospects, including implications for North America. Joining the African presenters in this panel discussion will be two internationally well-known experts on health research and development.

Organizers include Dr. Amy Auerbacher Gimbel, Director, Sub-Saharan Africa Program, American Association for the Advancement of Science, Washington, DC, and Dr. Yvo Nuyens, Coordinator, Council on Health Research for Development, Geneva.

Contact: Ms. Monique Ntawiha, Project Coordinator, AAAS Sub-Saharan Africa Program, 1333 H Street, NW, Washington DC 20005. Tel: (202)326-6730; Fax: (202)289-4958; E-mail: mntawiha@aaas.org

The Sub-Saharan Africa Program of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) announces a new Science in Africa award, sponsoring ten sub-Saharan African graduate students to attend the February 1995 AAAS Annual Meeting, including a special day-long Symposium on Essential National Health

Research: Lessons from African Successes. The symposium is the latest in a series of Science in Africa meetings organized by the Sub-Saharan Africa Program.The presenters from Africa who have agreed to take part in the symposium on Saturday, February 18, are on the front line in their respective countries, harnessing research to meet the pressing health needs of all their fellow citizens.

This special AAAS award will cover the meeting registration fee directly ($45 student fee, $100 postdoc fee) as well as provide modest local transportation costs ($30), and includes participation in: the Symposium on

Essential National Health Research: Lessons from African Successes; a special luncheon with Symposium presenters and AAAS staff; the International Directorate reception honoring foreign guests; and all other AAAS Annual Meeting Symposia and open events.

The 1995 AAAS Annual Meeting will take place at the Atlanta Marriott Marquis Hotel and Hyatt Regency Atlanta, February 16 through 21.

Sub-Saharan African students interested in applying for a Science in Africa award to attend must meet the following criteria: be enrolled full time in a graduate program or postdoctoral fellowship program at a U.S. institution (preferably in the Atlanta are, since long-distance travel and hotel costs cannot be covered) be pursuing an advanced degree (master's or doctoral level) or postdoctoral training in a field of science or engineering (including the social sciences)

Contact: Ms. Monique Ntawiha, Project Coordinator, AAAS Sub-Saharan Africa Program, 1333 H Street, NW, Washington DC 20005. Tel: (202)326-6730; Fax: (202)289-4958; E-mail: mntawiha@aaas.org

Social Science Research Council, American Council of Learned Societies, Joint Committee on the Near and Middle East--"Call for Applications"--The SSRC/ACLS Joint Committee on the Near and Middle East invites applications from graduate students interested in participating in a dissertation workshop on approaches and methods in cultural history cultural studies of the Near and Middle East.

The workshop is designed to provide an opportunity for graduate students planning or conducting research on the Middle East past or present to make more effective use of the methods and paradigms suggested by the "new cultural history" and cultural studies. The Committee wishes to solicit applications from graduate students in Ph.D. programs who have a well developed dissertation research proposal as well as from students who have a well developed dissertation research proposal as well as from students who have already begun to research or write their dissertations. The workshop is tentatively scheduled for May 27-30, 1995 and will be held at a location in the Middle East.

Funding for the workshop has been provided by the U.s. Information Agency's Near and Middle East Research and Training Act.The SSRC will cover expenses associated with participation in the workshop.

The workshop will consist of approximately 12 students and 4 faculty members. It will include presentations and discussions of draft dissertation chapters, proposals and/or relevant seminar papers by the students, as well as faculty led seminars. Student participants will be selected by the Joint Committee. Please note: You must be a U.S. citizen or permanent legal resident in order to be eligible for this competition. Those interested in applying are requessted to send: (1) a letter of application and statement of qualifications; (2) a curriculum vitae; (3) three letters of reference; and (4) a five page analytical summary of the dissertation research or intended dissertation research to: The Joint Committee on the Near and Middle East, Workshop on Cultural History/Cultural Studies, Social Science Research Council, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158, Tel: (212) 661-0280.

The Alan Shawn Feinstein World Hunger Program at Brown University invites applications for a two year (renewable, pending funding) resident appointment at the level of Assistant/Associate Professor (Research). Duties involve some undergraduate and graduate teaching combined with research, policy, and public service- related activities. Candidates should have a Ph.D. in a social science and a strong commitment to interdisciplinary work. Research and teaching should address current Program priorities: the linkages between hunger and other global issues (population, conflict, environment, poverty): the future of diets in particular national settings; human rights to food; and hunger and development policy. Appointments begin July 1,1995. Applications will be accepted through February 15, 1995.

Applicants are invited to submit a description of background and research interests, a curriculum vitae and names of three references for Assistant Professor and five references for Associate Professor position to: Ellen Messer, Director, Alan Shawn Feinstein World Hunger Program, Brown University, Box 1831, Providence, RI 02912. 

The World Hunger Program is an affiliate of the Watson Institute for International Studies. Brown University is an equal opportunity/affirmative action employer.

The Ford Foundation is seeking a staff member in Nairobi to develop, monitor and evaluate program activities in reproductive health and gender relations in Kenya, Tanzania and Zimbabwe. The program focuses on research on the social and behavioral aspects of sexuality and gender, community initiatives for change and advocacy of sexual and reproductive rights. The staff member will work closely with African professionals on research and training issues. The ideal candidate will have a demonstrated understanding of reproductive health and gender issues; a broad perspective on development and substantial field experience in developing countries, preferably in Africa; a Ph.D. in a health-related social science field; strong conceptual and writing skills' ability to work effectively with persons of diverse backgrounds and fluency in Kiswhaili or Portuguese. Interested candidates should send a C.V. and a brief writing sample for Position #672 to Joan C. Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 East 43rd Street, New York, NY.10017. The Ford Foundation is an Equal Opportunity Employer.

International Medical Corps, a non-profit emergency medical relief and training organization, seeks the following for its Emergency Response Trauma and Casualty program in Rwanda:

PRIMARY HEALTH CARE

TRAINERS (2 positions): teach and train local health care providers in basic public health issues; basic sanitation, theory of disease causation and treatment and prevention; community nutrition; teach techniques for the identification of the malnourished child treatment and growth monitoring; child immunization theory and rationale and EPI support; identification of complications in pregnancy. 3 years public health nursing experience in lower income, disadvantage setting or developing country; teaching tropical medicine experience desirable. Must be fluent in Swahili or French.

FAMILY PRACTICE PHYSICIAN: provide some hands on care for the local population. Provide some hands on care for the local population. Provide training and monitoring to the local health care providers, teaching experience helpful. Assist and support Rwandan medical and nursing staff. Enhance the clinical skills and theoretical knowledge of counterpart staff by education through collaborative practice; formulate practice guidelines, standards of care and quality assurance guidelines. 2 years of development research desired; knowledge of tropical medicine; French fluency. Six month commitment.

SOMALIA: Midwife-Registered Nurse with a degree or certificate in Midwifery: one year experience in maternal or primary health care programs in a developing country; prior Traditional Birth Attendant (TBA) training experience; ability to manage and motivate the local staff; excellent decision-making skills; work with local health authorities; must be able to work independently under very difficult conditions. Six month commitment.

Site Manager/Coordinator, Belet Weyne: coordinate the transition of the IMC sponsored PHC program into an independent Primary Health Care Provider agency while facilitating this agency's integration into the regional Health Union. Duties to include: monitor the PHC program activities to ensure compliance with identified program objectives and funding agency program guidelines; outline managerial and administrative training goals and objectives for national PHC coordinator and program manager management development; implement formal administration/management training program activities for national administrative staff; ensure local accountability in utilization of program funds and donor agency.

ANGOLA: Program Coordinator-equirements include Ministry of Health liaison experience, excellent interpersonal skills, grant writing experience, Masters of Public Health and Portuguese or Spanish FS13+. Five years developing country health programming experience in progressively responsible positions desirable. Anticipated start date January, 1995.

Country Director- (Luanda based): requirements include seven years overseas experience managing emergency/relief programs with increasing levels of responsibility; bachelor's degree in project management, international development or international health care; strong management, interpersonal and donor-relations skills; strong awareness of local culture and political setting. Health program experience for one year. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided. Anticipated start date January 1. 1995.

Logistician- (Luanda based). Requirements include: Three years experience with logistics in infrastructure poor environments required. Relief emergency program support experience preferred. Portuguese or Spanish FS13+ preferred. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided. Submit resume or letter of interest to: IMC,Dept. 94-036, 12233 W. Olympic Blvd. #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064; fax: 310-442-6622.

American Refugee Committee seeks a LOGISTICS OFFICER for Zaire to assist with scheduling of cars and drivers and other aspects of vehicle operations; establish, expand and refine ARC camp sites; supervise labor and material resources; oversee work of storehouse manager; assist logistical and operations manager with any of the logistical aspects of security planning. Africa News


January, 1995


Announcements


LENGTH: 3654 words


 

Preparations for the Fourth World Conference on Women, Beijing, 1995, are moving into the middle phase at the UN, the U.S. Department of State and the NGO world. On the UN scene, the five regional preparatory meetings are over. Each prepared a Regional Platform for Action from which the UN Secretariat is now preparing the next draft of the global Platform for Action. This draft will be negotiating document for the second preparatory committee meeting (prepcom) for the Conference, March 15-April 5, 1995 at the UN in New York.

The US government and NGOs participated in the Economic Commission for Europe Regional Preparatory Meeting, which focused on issues of survival, equity and human rights that women face in the region.

Both the official meeting and the NGO Forum produced a Platform for Action: write Conference Secretariat, US Dept. of State, G.CS 1318, Washington,D.C. 20520-7250. Phone 202 647 3129. 

The planning committee, NGO Forum on Women, Beijing '95 is now accepting registration forms from anyone planning to attend the NGO Forum in Beijing, August 30 to September 8, 1995. The NGO planning committee is also preparing a full agenda of activities during the March prepcom meeting in New York. The NGO meetings will be held on March 13. For information on Forum '95, contact NGO Forum on Women '95, 211 E. 43rd

Street, Suite 1500, New York, NY 10017, USA;212-922 9269; e-mail: ngoforum95@igc.apc.org.

The Panos Institute, an international information organization committed to raising public understanding and development worldwide, is pleased to offer resources for teaching about crucial transitional issues.

Working with partners in developing countries, the Panos Institute has produced a series of educational modules designed to stimulate critical thinking and problem-solving and to amplify voices from the global South on a variety of development concerns that are too often overlooked in international affairs.

Entitled "From Information to Education", the project seeks to engage Northern audiences in exploring the process and consequences of development by highlighting the research and analysis of journalists and NGO leaders from developing countries.

Of particular interest is the module "Conflict and Development." The module examines the causes and effects of armed conflict, highlights ways in which war impedes development, and describes current approaches to conflict resolution and prevention. Included are case studies of the conflicts in Rwanda and Chiapas, Mexico, and indicators of the social, economic, and environmental consequences with which all countries affected by conflict must grapple. The module concludes with discussion questions and exercises which engage participants in identifying priorities for action in several hypothetical regions.

Contact The Panos Institute, 1717 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Suite 301, Washington DC 20036 U.S.A. Phone 202-483-0044; Fax 202-483-3059.

TRANSITIONS ABROAD, Traveling Responsibly: A Directory of Opportunities

Since 1977, TRANSITIONS ABROAD, the first magazine devoted to specialty travel, has detailed the rewards of travel with a purpose. Each issue is a directory of information on all the ways to combine international travel with activities of special interest to the individual traveler.

The November/December issue focuses on ecotourism or environmentally responsible travel. Responsible tours try to choose locally owned lodging, local restaurants, and employ local counterparts to keep as much of the tourist dollar as possible in the host country. Responsible tours are in-depth learning experiences with the local hosts as teachers.

Organized by region and country, the possibilities in the current directory include: village-based bicycle tours to all parts of Africa; East African safaris focusing on marine ecology, art, beadwork, language/literature, archaeology, and wildlife conservation; living with village families in Kenya; orangutan research in Indonesia; trekking and elephant safaris in the Himalayas; economic development in Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia; snorkeling on the barrier reef of Belize; sailing seminars in the Caribbean; hiking in Patagonia; Spanish immersion and rain forest treks in Costa Rica; yachting in the Galapagos islands; watercolor and drawing in Greece; endangered species tour in Russia; photography workshop in Siberia; traveling seminars in all tropics throughout the world.

Along with the directory of special interest tours, this issue contains its usual mix of columns and

departments emphasizing low-cost independent alternatives to packaged tours: hiking across the Alps, overlanding through Africa, and folk dancing around the world...

A one-year, six-issue subscription to the magazine costs $19.95 from: TRANSITIONS ABROAD, Dept. TRA,P.O. Box 3000, Denville,NJ 07834. New subscribers receive a free 56-page "Guide to Opportunities Overseas", a selection of the most useful features from the magazine's first 17 years of publication. A free catalogue of dozens of separately printed resource guides on work, travel, and study abroad is available from TRANSITIONS ABROAD, P.O. Box 1300, Amherst, MA 01004-1300

The Carter Center's African Governance Program has recently published a set of working papers from a Seminar on Democratization in Africa held at the Center, May 13-14, 1994. Faced with the urgent need to review the many political transitions that had occurred in Africa since 1990, more than 30 scholars and practitioners took part in the seminar and 23 papers have been revised for publication.

The volume, entitled "The Democratic Challenge in Africa", provides valuable insights into some of the pressing concerns of the democratic movement in contemporary Africa. This is the Center's fourth publication to address issues affecting governance and democratization in Africa. "Beyond Autocracy in Africa", "Perestroika Without Glastnost in Africa" and "African Governance in the 1990s" were published in 1989 and 1990.

Copies of "The Democratic Challenge in Africa" can be obtained for $15 (individuals) and $24 (institutions). Make checks payable to: The Carter Center. Sender orders to the Office of Public Information, One Copenhill, Atlanta, GA 30307.

The Twenty-first annual conference of the African Literature Association will be held at Columbus, Ohio, from the 15th to the 19th of March, 1995 (both dates inclusive). The conference will be hosted by the Center for African Studies, in association with the College of Humanities, The Ohio State University.

The theme chosen for the conference, "The Postcolonial Condition" reflects our sense of the need not only for a critical interrogation of the term "postcolonial" which, in its application to non-Western, has gained wide currency, but also for placing the term itself in relation to the issues raised by the concept of post modernism and to the debates concerning its relevance, either in existential or theoretical terms, to African literature.

Arrangements are being made for a prominent literary figure to feature as keynote speaker at the conference, and for the presence of writers and literary scholars from Africa.

Proposals for panels and roundtables are now invited, and should be addressed to: Ms. Najat Elhag, Centre for African Studies, The Ohio State University, 314 Oxley Hall, Columbus, OH 43210; Tel. 614-292-4273.

Please note that proposals can only be accepted from paid-up members of the Association. The deadline for submission of proposals is October 15, 1994, and for abstracts to confirmed panel chairs January 31, 1995.

The Shirley and Lester Porter School of Cultural Studies at Tel Aviv University is organizing an

international conference, from June 18-23, 1995, entitled: "Breaking Boundaries: Beyond the Land of Cush. New Critical Encounters with Languages and Literatures of Sub-Saharan Africa."

The aims of this conference are: to further understanding and awareness of African literatures and languages in Israel; to provide scholars of African Studies with an opportunity to present new findings analyses; to promote research projects between Israeli and African scholars; to experience African art-literature, film, theatre- through visiting artists.

The conference will be the first of its kind in Israel; the conference languages will be English and French. Papers will be of 30 minutes duration and will be followed by a 15 minute discussion period. Scholars who do not receive any financial support from their universities to cover travel and/or accommodation expenses can apply for a grant from the organizing committee. Registration fee: $80 (US), students and companions: $50 (US)), payable at

registration in Tel Aviv. Registration deadline is February 28, 1995. Conference address: Joachim Warmbold,

"1995 Africa", Foreign Languages, Sharette Bldg., Tel Aviv University, IL-69 978 Ramat Aviv, Israel; Tel: +972-3- 6409466.

The Africa News and Information Service -- AFRICA-N is an electronic mailing list (listserv) that provides news, information, analysis, and articles about Africa. It is produced by Faraz Rabani at the University of Toronto. To subscribe send an e-mail message to "lstserv@utoronto.bitnet". Leave the subject blank and type "subscribe AFRICA-N" followed by your full name. You will get a notification that you are on the list and begin to receive messages.

A total of 226 exhibitors took part in the 1994 Zimbabwe International Book Fair held in Harare, Zimbabwe last August, representing publishers in 39 countries and 25 international organizations and UN agencies. Aside from local Zimbabwean companies, the South Africans comprised by far the largest national group. Eighteen other East, West and southern African countries were represented in Harare, confirming the ZIBF's position as sub- Saharan Africa's most important book trade event and the main pan-African gathering of indigenous publishers. The British Publishers' Association sent a 27 person trade delegation from leading educational and academic publishers. Special group and national exhibits were mounted from Germany, Italy, Spain, India and Australia. The first two, trade-only days of the Fair attracted 1,100 booksellers, librarians and other specialist visitors, with 30,000 members of the public on the remaining three open days. Overall $2 million-worth of business is estimated to have been transacted.

The First African Rights Indaba, held immediately before ZIBF94, raised important policy issues of rights trading and protection for African publishers. Other special events included a Young Scientist Exhibition and a regional Writers' Workshop on Communicating science and Technology, the Houses of Stone international music festival and, at the other end of the multimedia spectrum, a display of state-of-the-art electronic publishing and technology. The organisers of the 1994 Commonwealth Writers Prize also chose Harare and ZIBF94 as the setting for the announcement of its African regional winners.

ZIBF95 will be held from 8-12 August 1995 in Harare on the theme of Human Rights and Justice. Further details and application forms are available from the ZIBF's regional office, ZIBF(UK), 25 Endymion Road, London N4 1EE, UK (Tel:+44-81-348 8463; Fax: +44-81-348 4403). For further information contact Margaret Ling, ZIBF(UK) Limited, is the agent in Europe and North America for the Zimbabwe International Book Fair. The ZIBF can be contacted in Zimbabwe at PO Box CY 1179, Causeway, Harare, Zimbabwe; Tel: +263-4-750282;

Fax:+263-4-751202

Eighth Annual Hunger Research Briefing and Exchange, Brown University, April 5-7,1995

The eighth annual Hunger Research Briefing and Exchange, sponsored by InterAction, the American Council for Voluntary International Action and Brown University will be held April 5-7, 1995 at Brown University in Providence, Rhode Island.

The 1995 Briefing focuses on the interplay of resource and policy factors that link vulnerability to hunger and capacities for sustained development in people's lives. Hunger usually is linked to resource scarcity, but are key intervening variables population growth or policy failure? In view of changing relationships of people to land, and peoples to states, how can government, intergovernment, and non-government (including community, field- based, and academic) programs collaborate to make overcoming hunger part of the broader sustainable development goals of economic growth, positive political change, environmental protection, public health, and education?

Key topics to be addressed in the Briefing include the conflicting evidence regarding the impact of economic liberalization and GATT on food security; hunger in development education, and changing hunger scenarios in the United States.

As in the past, the Briefing will offer an extensive exhibit of books and other publications and will be held in conjunction with the annual awards ceremony for the Alan Shawn Feinstein World Hunger Awards. More than 175 individuals from government and academic institutions and private voluntary organizations around the world typically attend the Briefing. Contact: Brown University, Box 1831, Providence, Rhode Island 02912, USA. Tel. (401) 863-2700 Fax (401) 863-2192. E-mail whp@brounvm.brown.edu

The Reverend Leon Howard Sullivan announced that reservations are now being taken for the Third African-African American Summit. The summit will convene in Dakar, Senegal, West Africa from May 1-5, 1995 and will be hosted by President Abdou Diouf and the Senegalese Government.

The historic Summit is being convened and chaired by Reverend Sullivan and will focus on finding practical ways to assist in the improvement of the quality of life in Sub-Saharan African countries in areas such as economic development, debt relief, industrialization, educaton, agriculture, medicine and others. At the upcoming Summit, there will be a special emphasis placed on democracy and ethnic and tribal cooperation. Expected to join Reverend Sullivan in these critical discussions are Heads of State from over 24 African countries, including President Nelson Mandela of The Republic of South Africa. Also expected are Chiefs and Leaders of most of the critical nations and tribes involved in conflict on the Continent today. With such an emphasis being placed on one of the more perplexing issues of our time, the deliberations at the Third Africa-African American Summit promise to be significant not only in their timeliness but also in the results that will unquestionably result.

It is expected that the next African-African American Summit will attract over 5000 delegates, participants and observers from the United States, Africa, Europe and other parts of the world. The African delegation will be led by Heads of State, senior members of government, officials, and experts. In addition, high level representatives will participate from such international bodies as the United Nations Development Program, World Bank, International Monetary Fund, World Health Organization, the Food and Agriculture Organization and many others.

Reverend Sullivan cited some follow up activities which have been successfully implemented since the last two Summits. Some of the msot significant results include the following: a substantial debt relief program for sub-Saharan Africa in America and France; a legal support council organized to assist the large numbers of Americans who are interested in the new dual citizenship program; a "Thousand Teachers for Africa" Program; a "Best and Brightest" African bankers training program is underway that has already trained 150 African bankers throughout Sub-Saharan Africa; factories have been initiated; skills training centers have been expanded; a partnership with the World Bank is making possible the construction of 50,000 wells; poly-technical schools have been opened; and extensive health programs and other projects have been launched. Also, large scaled river- blindness projects are underway, and plans have been made for the initiation of AIDS containment programs designed to help entire nations. At the upcoming Summit, there will be ways for everyone attending to participate: workshops, seminars, special group meetings and other ways. There will be programs for Physicians, Lawyers, Ministers, Business people, Health Management Professionals, Students, Environmentalists, Engineers, Educators, and Human Rights Activists.

Those interested in attending the Third African-African American Summit may call 1-800-835-3530 for more information. (Travel and accomodations are being handled by the American Express Group Travel Management Services.) "The International Free Press" (IFP) is a free service on the internet. IFP focuses on stories, interviews and editorials that deal with Black groups and individuals on a global basis. Writers and editors are from Africa, Asia, Europe and North America. To subscribe send an e-mail message to: dhosten@freenet.scri,fsu.edu with the word SUBSCRIBE in the body of your letter.

Kwaplah International Inc. is an African-based organization interested in compiling bio-data on African and African-American Experts in different fields of study as well as subject specialists. The purpose is to help connect such individuals with international organizations that engage in development work in Africa and other developing nations. Those interested should contact: Kwaplah International Inc. Office of Procurement and International Consultant Service. E-mail : yakubut@csos.orst.edu or mahns@ucs.orst.edu

The African Crop Science Journal is seeking unpublished research papers for inclusion in the next edition. This edition will focus on Women and Agriculture and is scheduled for March 1995. While most papers are expected to be about crop science, socioeconomic and rural development topics will also be welcomed. Contact: Dr. Adipala Ekwamu,Editor, The African Crop Science Journal.Faculty of Agriculture and Forestry, Makerere University: PO Box 7062, Kampala, Uganda. Telephone: 256-41-542277. Fax: 256-41-531641
