Africa News


January, 1995


Calls for Papers


LENGTH: 1334 words


 

Hofstra Cultural Center announces a call for papers for Africa 2000, an interdisciplinary conference examining the situation of Africa in the year 2000 and the decade thereafter. Papers should focus on or emphasize the immediate future faced by the continent. Any discussion that increases an understanding of Africa's next decade and a half are welcome. Papers are invited on such diverse topics as African Americans and Africa; the African Diaspora; ethnic relations; medical geography; multinational corporations; public health; popular culture; single and multiparty states; urbanization; and women in Africa. Previously presented or published material should not be submitted. The conference will feature keynote speaker Chinua Achebe. DEADLINE:

MARCH 15, 1995, for final papers (in duplicate), one-page abstract, and curriculum vitae. Contact: Athelene A. Collins, Hofstra University, Hampstead, NY 11550-1090, phone 516/ 564-4306.

"African Entrepreneurship" is the theme of The Carter Lecture Series to be held November 1-2, 1995 at the University of Florida, Gainesville. Contact Dr.Anita Spring, Department of Anthropology, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611. Tel:(904) 392-4691. 

February 17-18, 1995 "Education in Africa: Relevance of Democratic Reform" is the theme of a symposium organized by Ohio University and the Ohio State University to be held February 17-18. ABSTRACTS OF NO MORE THAN 550 WORDS MUST BE SUBMITTED BY JANUARY 10. For details contact Professor Sally Navin, Ohio University, 203 McCracken Hall, Athens Ohio 45701. Tel: (614) 593-4444.

March 15-19, 1995 The Twenty-first annual conference of the African Literature Association will be held at Ohio State University in Columbus, Ohio. The conference will be hosted by the Center for African Studies, in association with the College of Humanities, The Ohio State University.

The theme chosen for the conference, "The Postcolonial Condition" reflects our sense of the need not only for a critical interrogation of the term "postcolonial" which, in its application to non-Western, has gained wide currency, but also for placing the term itself in relation to the issues raised by the concept of post modernism and to the debates concerning its relevance, either in existential or theoretical terms, to African literature. Arrangements are being made for a prominent literary figure to feature as keynote speaker at the conference, and for the presence of writers and literary scholars from Africa.

Proposals for panels and roundtables are now invited, and should be addressed to: Ms. Najat Elhag, Centre for African Studies, The Ohio State University, 314 Oxley Hall, Columbus, OH 43210; Tel. 614-292-4273. Please note that proposals can only be accepted from paid-up members of the Association. THE DEADLINE FOR ABSTRACTS TO CONFIRMED PANEL CHAIRS JANUARY 31, 1995.

April 13-15, 1995 Michigan State University's Comparative Black History program will host the COMPARATIVE HISTORY OF BLACKS IN THE DIASPORA SYMPOSIUM. The symposium will focus on new developments in the fields of African American, Latin American, Caribbean, U.S. Southern, and African history.

The themes for the symposium are: Comparative Methods and Perspectives and the Black Diaspora; Comparative Slavery and Slave Society; and Freedom and Inequality in Comparative Perspective. Contact: Dr. Darlene Hine, History Department, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, phone 517/ 432-4933, or Dr. David Barry Gaspar, History Department, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, phone 919/684-2109.

Papers on all topics from all disciplines will be considered; especially welcomed are those dealing with the direction for Africa as the 21st century is approached. a 600 word abstract is requested for papers. 11 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Document: Has Mandela's Call Been Answered? Investment in Post-Apartheid South Africa


LENGTH: 1920 words


 

The Corporate Examiner

November 1994

The Calvert Group

In October 1982 the Calvert Group launched the Calvert Social Investment Fund, the "first mutual fund in the U.S. to oppose apartheid by deliberately refusing to invest in companies doing business in South Africa." Shortly after Nelson Mandela made his historic call for new international investment in South Africa, Calvert reversed its longstanding policy. One year after Mr. Mandela's call, they released this report, commenting: "We feel strongly that the eyes of the world should remain focused on South Africa." Calvert has also invested in several community development projects in South Africa. Presented here are excerpts from Calvert's report. For more information or a complete copy of the report, contact: Calvert Group, 4550 Montgomery Ave., Bethesda, MD 20814; (301) 951-4800 "The new South Africa is open for business."-Wall Street Journal, May 1994

How has the world responded to the calls made one year ago by Nelson Mandela for new investment in South Africa? While new investments have started to flow into post-apartheid South Africa, considerably more outside capital and non-equity infusions (licensing deals, technology transfers, etc.) will have to reach the nation if it is to achieve President Mandela's broad agenda for change and redress. 

"New Investment Edges Up." The ranks of U.S. companies with employees or investments in South Africa has increased almost 20 percent (26 firms) since September 1993, according to the Investor Responsibility Research Center (IRCC). Up from 119 U.S.-controlled companies present in 1991 to 165 companies at the end of August 1994, it is clear that U.S. investors are beginning to respond to Mandela's call. (Growth in new investment by non-U.S. companies is also being registered, though at somewhat more modest levels.) The expansion in U.S. companies doing business in South Africa are taken into consideration, the interest in the nation is even more evident, with the number of these non-equity ties surging from 184 to 475, according to IRRC.

"Interest builds in South African stocks." The demise of apartheid has provided a major boost to the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (JSE). The JSE has performed strongly over most of the past eighteen months, providing attractive returns to international investors. From January 1, 1992 through August 31, 1994, volume on the JSE rose by 80 percent. The exchange's recent inclusion on several major global market, increasing its appeal to international fund managers.

"Socially responsible investing takes root in South Africa." With the fall of apartheid, U.S. mutual funds that screen for socially responsible corporate behavior are now investing in the best of the companies (such as Kellog and Schering Plough) that once were off limits because of their presence in South Africa under apartheid. Of more direct significance to change in South Africa is the flowering of "homegrown" socially responsible investments. Calvert Group, a U.S. leader in the social investment category, is now making a committment to emerging South Africa-based enterprises, such as the trade-union run Community Growth Fund (CGF), South Africa's only socially screened unit investment trust (the South African version of an open-end mutual fund), and the South Africa Private Investment Fund, which is working to create jobs through the promotion of black middle class entrepreneurship. CGF was launched in 1992 by a collection of South African trade unions.

In addition to these initial efforts to nurture the fledgling socially responsible investment in South Africa, Calvert encourages multinational corporations doing business in South Africa to adopt socially responsible business practices. In particular, companies present in South Africa to adopt socially responsible business practices. In particular, companies present in South Africa are encouraged to support the high ethical standards of the Code of Conduct, which was established in July 1993 by the South African Council of Churches in collaboration with a wide range of labor, political and business leaders in the nation. The Corporate Examiner is published by the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility, 475 Riverside Drive, Room 566, New York, NY 10155 (he SOUTH AFRICA Pyramid Structures Must Stay, Says Motlana (tx

Weekly Mail and Guardian

January 20, 1995

by Jacques Magliolo

Black business cannot bid for the Anglo-controlled JCI if proposed changes to present Johannesburg Stock Exchange regulations relating to pyramids go ahead this year.

New Africa Investment Limited's chairman, Dr Nthato Motlana, one of South Africa's most prominent black businessmen, says: "We will oppose the Johannesburg Stock Exchange's forthcoming changes to regulations, particularly those affecting pyramid structures.

"Now that we are becoming more established in big business, the JSE and white conglomerates want to change the rules," he says, asserting that "we want, we desire and it is necessary for conglomerates stay in place.

" It would be unfair for blacks to follow different rules, when the old ones have proven to be successful for the Oppenheimers, the Ackermans and the Wieses."

Says another black businessman: "We want to be part of conglomerates and, if rules regulating these companies have been good enough for whites, surely its good enough for us."

Motlana believes that "to change the playing fields now would be race discrimination"

One stockbroker, head of research, says: "All new black businesses are pyramids, but it is only in being a part of such a conglomerate that they can get access to massive funds to take on the Anglos or bid for the restructured JCI."

Motlana agrees: "Pyramids enable companies with small shareholder stakes to control larger companies. If this type of structure is abolished it will make it impossible for blacks to own companies or to help transfer wealth to the disadvantaged people.

"In this manner, Motlana confirms that his group will be making a bid for "a stake in JCI's industrial division". Although a number of "informal meetings have taken place with Anglo and JCI, no firm plan will be formulated before April", says Motlana.

JSE proposals will prohibit second tiered pyramids by the end of this year, which means a holding company which is listed can have only one listed subsidiary. In turn, that holding company cannot have a major shareholder that is listed.

Nail fits the description of a multi-tiered structure. While it controls listed institution Metlife, its shareholder is recently listed Corporate Africa. In addition, another of its shareholders, Sanlam, may seek a listing in the future, which would force them to sell their shares in Nail.

Experts say that it is doubtful whether Nail would be able to acquire Sanlam's shareholding. Although Nail's pre- listing statement indicates that it bought 30 percent of Metlife from Sanlam, Nail actually controls only 10 percent. The company wishes to acquire an additional 20 percent.

Like a number of black businesses, Nail finds itself in a predicament. While it intends to continue to grow by taking advantage of a breakup of white pyramid structures, it wants to be in control of its own conglomerates which would contravene new pyramid requirements.

"This is a complete contradiction," says the head of research. "You cannot have it both ways; either you are for a breakup of all pyramid structures, or against it."

According to a corporate financier: "Most businessmen don't understand or even know that changes are in the pipeline. If they did, they wouldn't be listing companies in pyramid form."

To highlight his point, he mentions the quick succession of listings of Nail and its major shareholder Corporate Africa. "Despite having a host of corporate experts, stockbrokers and merchant banks involved in these listings, the directors of Nail did not seem to know that the JSE changes would take place in 1995," he says.

However, Motlana is determined that his group and other black organisations will continue to grow in pyramid form. He believes that this will enable them to turn Metlife's two million policyholders into shareholders.

"Our plan is to take annual actuarial surplus (profit made on policy funds which are paid out to policyholders only on maturity) and to buy shares in the company," says Motlana."

"We would do this only at the policyholders' request." While plans are in progress to obtain a share in JCI, Motlana intimates that the group is in the process of conducting negotiations for other takeovers.

"If you don't grow, you die," says Motlana.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein,

Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.For e-mail subscriptions, send enquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


12 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


NIGERIA: Pandora's Box


LENGTH: 3507 words


 

Newswatch

January 16, 1995

by Wale Akin Aina

How was $571.78 million (N12.58 billion) additional revenue from crude oil sales during the nine month Gulf war/ crisis spent? Last week sources told Newswatch that unraveling the details of how the money was spent is "like peeling an onion. Tears well up in your eyes but you don't want to stop."

The windfall was as a result of a surge in prices of crude oil (an average of $23 per barrel during the crisis) following the scarcity of supplies in the international market (a shortfall of four million barrels per day). The money was also part of the $12.4 billion (N272.8 billion) which the country earned in oil sales between September 1988 and June 1994 and which was placed in special accounts. Most of it was earned during the administration of Ibrahim Babangida, former president and a retired general. 

In June 1991, William Keeling, the Lagos correspondent for the London Financial Times, was deported for reporting that Nigeria had spent more than half of an estimated $3 billion it earned during the crisis. Government said then that the report was false. Alex Akinyele, former information minister in the Babangida administration, said the money was used to create a foreign currency stabilisation account. He added that as at the end of June 1991, $1.7 billion remained as balance in the account.

Last October, Pius Okigbo, an economist, who headed a panel to reorganise the Central Bank of Nigeria, CBN, revealed that $12.2 billion of the $12.4 billion has been spent. He said that only $206 million was left but added that most of the money was "spent on what could neither be adjudged genuine high priority projects or truly regenerative investment." In simple English, the money was squandered.

Weeks of investigations in Abuja and Lagos by Newswatch confirmed the observations of the Okigbo panel and revealed questionable and often unexplained expenses by the Babangida administration, Records available to the magazine indicated that the Nigerian High Commission in London was allocated $18.2 million or 3.2 percent of the $571.78 million of the oil windfall. Other embassies also benefited from the former president's largesse, although there were no papers to show how they spent the money. Among the beneficiaries are the Nigerian Embassy in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, which collected $14.99 million; Nigerian embassies in Teheran, Iran; Niamey, Niger; And Islamabad, Pakistan, which got $2.76 million, $3.80 million and $3.80 million, respectively.

However, the Nigerian Embassy in Israel got $13.07 million. Newswatch also found out that $1 million and $0.50 million were given to Liberia and Ghana respectively as gifts. The former president's travels abroad gulped $8.95 million from the windfall money, while those of his wife, Maryam Babangida, cost $0.99 million.

That is not all. Newswatch sources have confirmed that welfare expenses at Dodan Barracks, Lagos, and Aso Rock, Abuja, cost $23.98 million, while $18.30 million was expended on television and video equipment for the presidency. A documentary film on Nigeria titled: Nigeria: Journey to Nationhood, detailing the country's history from the colonial times to the administration of Babangida was produced in 1991 for $2.92 million. Sources also disclosed that television and video equipment for the Ahmadu Bello University, ABU, cost $17.90 million, while medical equipment for Aso Rock Clinic cost $27.25 million. The Army, the sources added received $3.85 million for ceremonial uniforms, while another $323.35 million was given the ministry of defence. Money from the windfalls that was spent on security was $59.72 million, while defence attaches in the embassies of Nigeria abroad got $25.49 million. Newswatch also learnt that $1.04 million was spent on the General Staff Headquarters, GHQ.

How the money was used by the different government agencies were at best not specific and at worst, obscure. A presidency source said that the defence ministry which got 56.55 percent of the money did not state any specific project it used it for, although it was speculated that part of the money was used for the car gift to military officers. Also, it was not clear why the embassies normally funded by the ministry of foreign affairs, needed a total of $56.64 million or why defence attaches got $25.49 million. All the money - $12.4 billion - was kept in dedication, stabilisation or other special accounts which were hardly applied for the purpose for which they were originally designed. The dedication and other special accounts in particular, were applied beyond their original scope, clearly undermining their fiscal objectives. For example, the dedication account was extended to a lot of non-priority projects and the stabilisation account was used to cover up expenditure of excess revenues which surpassed projected earnings. Newswatch was told that funds in special accounts were spent as fast they were accumulated. Okigbo while presenting his report to General Sani Abacha, last year, said "these disbursements were clandestinely undertaken while the country was openly reeling with crushing external debt overhang - these represent, no matter the initial justification for creating the accounts, a gross abuse of public trust." (Newswatch October 24,1994.)

The dedication account was created in 1986 by former President Babangida with 20,000 barrels per day to fund the Liquefied Natural Gas, LNG, project. Earnings from the allocation were paid into a special account with the Midland Bank of London. In 1988 other special accounts were created to fund specific developmental projects. According to CBN sources the receipts for the dedication account between 1988 and June 30 1994, totaled $6.195 billion but $6.109 billion was disbursed leaving a balance of about $85.9 million. Sales of mining rights by the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, NNPC, which was also placed in a special account recorded $1.745 billion was spent leaving a balance of $1.66 million. The Signature Bonus account had $101.06 million. Only $1.06 million was kept after $99 million was disbursed. Similarly, only $117.3 million was left in the Stabilisation account which had $4.398 billion.

On the whole, receipts from the various accounts were $12.441 billion out of which $12.235 billion was disbursed. That left a balance of only $206.03 million. Sources at the CBN also gave a breakdown of the expenditure from the dedication account on projects between 1988 and 1994. These are the Federal Capital Territory, Abuja which got $1.518 billion and the Ajaokuta Steel Plant which received $1.473. The Aluminium Smelter Plant in Ikot Abasi, Akwa Ibom State, also received $765.45 million; Itakpe Iron Ore project got $804.81 million; Shiroro Electricity project received $91 million while other projects received $651 million.

From the dedication accounts alone, the projects received a total of $5.304 billion between 1988 and 1994. The presidency got $262 million, Defence received $401.2 million, while $130.7 million was disbursed on security. Other projects which CBN sources were not specific about $10.5 million. Many of the projects, however, especially Ajaokuta and the Aluminium Smelter, plant are either of doubtful viability or misplaced priority. World Bank reports on the two projects have described them as expensive and unviable. The dedication and special accounts were indeed, according to the sources, parallel budgets for the presidency and the decision of what projects to be financed was by Babangida alone, depending on pressures brought to bear on him by sponsors of specific items.

How were the accounts operated? According to sources in Lagos and Abuja, request for money from the accounts were, in the instance of security and defense matters, made by the then director-general of the National Intelligence Agency, NIA, Halilu Akilu, a retired brigadier-general or by the former governor of the CBN, Abdulkadir Ahmed. In some cases, the governor may approve money from the accounts and simultaneously send a request to the former President Babangida for approval. At other times Akilu would go directly to the director of foreign operations without his request which is later referred to Ahmed for approval. At no time, according to CBN sources, was there any document in which Babangida directed the way the accounts should be operated. In fact, the sources added, at no time were the accounts operated when Ahmed was away. He was the only one who, as governor, had the authority to effect payment on the authority of the president. Payment was made when Ahmed sent a minute to the bank's director of foreign operations through the deputy governor, international relations. But both officials, according to the resources, only acted on the authority of the governor.

Presidency sources told Newswatch that if money from the dedicated account was needed for any undertaking, a note was sent by Ahmed to the CBN's director of foreign operations stating that he should release so many million dollars for such project. It would then be stated that the note should stand as a directive and a receipt for such money. In all cases, the accounts were debited accordingly. CBN sources said that the bank did not request, demand or was it given any documentary evidence of the services or projects paid for because these were deemed classified.

In the case of payment of contractors, only certificate of performances were lodged with the bank and at no time were the original contract documents made available to the CBN. Ahmed, the sources say, would from time to time review the performance certificates and as governor of the bank direct that money from any one of the special accounts be used to pay the contractors. It was, therefore, not possible, the bank sources complained to check requests for payment against the total value of the contract so as to guard against double payment or inaccurate claims. The bank only effected payment once it confirmed that signatures were genuine. It had no authority to verify the authenticity of any claim. Newswatch learnt that in a number of cases there were variations between amounts approved for payments and the actual amount disbursed.

Furthermore, the way the accounts were operated and the manner in which money was withdrawn from them made it unclear which particular account should be debited for a particular project - whether Dedication, Sale of Mining Rights, Signature Bonus or Stabilisation accounts. Said a source, "it was like the governor (Ahmed) had a buffet. You could pick from any dish you liked." The sources said further that at no time did the former governor recommend and try to utilise the monies in the special accounts to build up the country's external reserves.

This was to be one of the sorry effects of the manner in which the special accounts were operated. Okigbo last October said: "Had these resources of $12.4 billion, or even a significant portion been paid into the external reserves, the impact on the naira/ dollar exchange rate today; on the attitude of our external creditors; on the credibility of Nigeria and on the environment for foreign investment, etc. would have been incalculable."

A CBN source explained last week that if the money had been used to build up the external reserves, the impact on the exchange rate would had been so strong that by last year, N1 would have exchanged for $1.004 or even less. More importantly, at $4 billion in debt servicing payment per annum, the country would have been able to clear its interest for three years and would have received generous reschedualing arrangements from the London and Paris Clubs. Both held 7.16 percent and 63.24 percent respectively of the country debts by 1993. But in the period between 1988 and 1993, Nigeria's external debt continued to grow. In 1988 it was $30.69 billion. It rose to $33.99 billion in 1990, but dropped slightly to $28.718 billion in 1993. In 1988, the external debt was $17.34 billion.

The World Bank had long criticised the operation of the special accounts by the Nigerian government. Last October, at its annual general meeting in Washington, the bank said that Nigeria should close down the accounts as they were drain pipes and conduits for corruption. The bank observed that with the operation of dedication and other special accounts, actual revenue figures earned by Nigeria is difficult to ascertain and therefore it was difficult for it to assist in reschedualing the nation's external debts or granting it concessionary arrangements with major creditors. The World Bank observed that through Nigeria for instance, said it earned N63.55 billion in 1992, its actual revenue from oil was more than that. It also said government should stop extra- budgetary spending.

CBN officials think the World Bank is right. According to them the receipts of earnings into the dedication and other special accounts were never reflected in the budget. Also, the receipts and balances in these accounts, they said, were not included in the federation account. The implication is that by not placing receipts in the federation account, the federal government had forcibly acquired what would have legitimately gone to the state and local governments, thereby disrespecting the revenue allocation formula.

In all these, the NNPC cannot be completely absolved. It is the NNPC which directs crude oil buyers on which of the accounts to make payments, although the monies in the special accounts do not form part of the corporation's oil sales. Last October, Emmanuel Abisoye, a retired major-general, who headed a panel that looked into the activities of the corporation, discovered that N71.39 billion the country earned in oil revenue and lodged in several accounts of the NNPC between 1991 and 1993 had been misappropriated. The money was said to have been paid out by the corporation on the orders of government.

Last December 15, the National Economic Intelligence Committee, NEIC, lamented the fact that the NNPC and CBN budgets, which together amount to 70 percent of the federal government budget are a threat to fiscal stability and monetary management. The NEIC observed: "Added to this is the fact that dedicated accounts which are projected at about 40 percent of federal government budget are controlled by the two vital and seemingly independent agents of government." Abisoye found the manner in which NNPC managed its accounts distressing. He observed in his report to government: "NNPC does not respect its own budget. NNPC does not respect its own plans. NNPC does not respect constituted authorities."

This appears reflected in the events following the change of pump head prices of petrol from 70 kobo to N3.25 in November 1993. In canvassing for the hike, the NNPC promised to pay the government N20 billion, pointing out that out of the amount, government would be able to ameliorate the consequences of the increase on workers and the cost of living. But as at last December 15, the NNPC had only paid government N1.8 billion leaving a debt balance of N18.2 billion. Even then the payment of N1.8 billion was made after great pressures from the federal ministry of finance and NEIC.

Sources at the presidency told Newswatch that it was because NNPC didn't pay that government decided all payments for the purchase of fuel from NNPC depots should be made to government's account in the CBN. From this, an agreed ratio of sharing would be reached between government and NNPC.

Last week, however, NNPC officials offered an explanation on why they were unable to pay the arrears. According to them, government has not paid the corporation a kobo since the prices were raised to N11 per litre. They told Newswatch that NNPC was to get N1.75 out of the N11. That explanation did not clear the confusion or answer the question why the corporation is still unable to keep its own side of the original bargain. According to sources, the problem facing the NNPC is one of executive interference. Although government withdraws money from the corporation by fiat, it sometimes struggles to pay its joint -venture partners. This is why the NNPC struggles for increment in domestic petroleum products, the last was the 339 percent increase in fuel prices last October. This is exactly why the Abisoye panel recommended that the NNPC be freed from the ministry of petroleum resources and be allowed to operate as a purely commercial organisation. The Abisoye panel was also said to have advised government to withdraw from the oil industry and allow NNPC a free hand. This was the same recommendation that had been made much earlier by the defunct Technical Committee on Privatisation and Commercialisation, TCPC.

Newswatch learnt that the Okigbo panel recommended that all further disbursements from the CBN special accounts, including the dedication account, be discontinued while the remaining funds in them be transferred to the external reserves. The Okigbo panel also directed that receipts from sales of dedicated crude oil be paid into the external reserves. From the beginning of this year, it said, there should be no more dedication of crude oil. And that if there is to be a dedication account, a full disclosure of both expected revenue and projects of expenditure should be announced in the budget. The Okigbo panel, according to sources, also said that the GHQ special account should be transferred to the Federal budget.

Last year, the Abacha administration in responding to international pressure, pledged to discontinue the dedication of crude oil. It said specific projects would be funded through direct budgetary allocation. In fact, it allocated $279 million as special treasury allocation to finance certain projects. Only the dedication of oil from the funding of the LNG project was to continue. Curiously, however, the government increased the amount of dedicated oil from 105,000 barrels per day to 150,000 per day by last June, It is not clear whether government will continue with this pattern when it announces its 1995 budget.

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH. NEWSWATCH is published at P.M.B. 21499 Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950 Fax: 962887 Telex: 27874


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


13 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


NIGERIA: Gains and Losses


SECTION: FINANCE AND BUSINESS


LENGTH: 3560 words


 

Newswatch

December 12, 1994

by Utibe Ukim

Nigeria made significant progress on the road to economic recovery in the six years of the Structural Adjustment Programme, SAP. However, distortions in implementing the reform package, and the final repudiation of the programme by the Abacha government have combined to push the country further down the road to that recovery, says a report by the World Bank.

In the report which catalogued the performance in Nigeria and other sub-Saharan countries, the World Bank said SAP made it possible for Nigeria to reverse its economic decline and achieve reasonable growth. But it said these would have been more impressive and sustainable if the progress of the reforms were consistent and uniform. It gave the major gains of SAP as the reversal of the negative growth rate of gross domestic product, GDP, which averaged - two percent in 1980-86. Between 1986-92, the bank said Nigeria's GDP growth averaged 5.8 percent with the real sector - agriculture and manufacturing - recording significant growth in output. "Nigeria's adjustment programme, however incomplete, has produced clear positive results," the report said. It noted further: "The decline in GDP growth has been reversed: from - two percent annually during the 1980-86 to more than five percent during 1986-91. The ratio of investment to GDP, although, still lower than 1981-83, has improved since the crisis years. Non-oil export grew in the early years of the adjustment programme. Agricultural production responded more than manufacturing." 

Growth in agricultural output averaged four percent for the first five years of SAP. Before then, output remained stagnate, the report said. The bank said both food and export crop production, rose sharply following the introduction of SAP. For instance, between 1986 and 1990, production of export crops went up by nearly 45 percent while food crops productions grew by 60 percent.

In the manufacturing sector, output increased by 5.1 percent in 1987 and 12.9 percent in 1988 against a decline of 3.9 percent in 1986. Although , these growth rates declined subsequently, the report noted that subsectors such as textiles, rubber, minerals, wood furniture and certain food products which depended on domestic sources for a large percentage of input continued to record impressive growths, both in output and capacity utilisation.

In 'Adjustments in Africa: Lessons from Country Case Studies', the bank attributed the overall growth in the GDP to three factors. "First, oil production and exports are not effected by public sector inefficiency and other policy distortions," said the report. The other reasons are that the private sector, especially the agricultural sector, performed well partly because of some improvements in the incentive structure brought about by the reforms and the efficiency in the deployment of capital.

Despite these growths, the report said that overall, the economic reform package produced largely unsatisfactory results. Matched against the objectives, it noted that the reforms left much to be desired as it failed to meet the laudable goals of the programme. However, it conceded that even the haphazard implementation was better than the total abandonment of the programme. This view is supported by Christopher Ezeh, managing director of John Holt Plc. He told Newswatch that "even the half-hearted prosecution of the structural adjustment programme was a lot better than what we are doing now."

Ezeh said that SAP effectively abolished economic regulation. "It became easier for people to trade, the naira was a bit stable for sometime. It was easier to get foreign exchange if you wanted it."

But that did not last for long. The political will, needed to effectively execute the programme was lacking. "The growth in money supply was too high. Budget deficit was still there too," Ezeh said. These combined to render the reform programme ineffective after the second year.

When the Babangida administration introduced SAP in 19486 as the cornerstone of its economic reforms programme, the objectives were to reform the exchange rate mechanism, liberalise trade, abolish commodity boards, and put in place a market-oriented economy where government would concentrate efforts in creating a conducive environment for private enterprise to flourish. The main elements of SAP were the adoption of tight fiscal and monetary policies to reduce inflation and cut down on government expenditures and bring deficits to four percent of GDP. Others were the dismantling of exchange control to pave way for the emergence of a market- determined exchange rate policy, the liberalisation of trade through review, of customs tariffs and excise duties and the abolition of price controls.

The programme also included the reform of the financial sector which was hitherto heavily regulated, as well as the privitisation and commercialisation of public enterprises and abolition of commodity boards.

These objectives were designed to tackle the problems which the government inherited on assumption of office. The Buhari/Idiagbon regime had rejected a loan facility from the International Monetary Fund, IMF, and instead opted for policies such as import licensing, counter-trade and the allocation of 34 percent of export earnings for debt servicing. These policies were rejected by both the IMF and the World Bank and credit lines to Nigeria from international lending institutions were withdrawn. By 1984, inflation stood at 40 percent. Imports declined by 22.7 percent in 1984 against the 1983 level. Non-oil exports also declined by 44.2 percent, disrupting government's plan to develop reliable alternative revenue source to oil. With the drop in earnings from oil sales, the Babangida government needed to win the confidence of international creditors to secure debt reschedualing reliefs.

Once the regime opened discussions with the IMF, it initiated a national debate on whether Nigeria should accept or reject the IMF loan and its conditions. Nigeria opted to reject the loan. In its place, the government drew up the reform package of SAP largely with inputs from the IMF. SAP was introduced in July 1986 and planned to last two years. The take-off of the programme coincided with the introduction of similar programme in many sub-Saharan African countries, desperately in need of economic recovery and injection of new capital. The countries included Burundi, Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Kenya, Senegal and Tanzania.

The report noted that in Nigeria and nearly all the countries that adopted reforms - Cote d'Ivoire is an exception- GDP grew. But these gains were directly linked with the effectiveness of implementation. The report noted that while the objectives for reforms in Nigeria was "comprehensive", the implementation left rooms for distortions. "Although, implementation started well, it soon slackened, and even regressed." It blamed this on "political factors, interacting with fluctuating oil revenue." It noted that it was only during the first fifteen months of the programme, July 1986 - December 1987, that the implementation was effective.

"During the initial period, crucial reforms were implemented fairly effectively. In one stroke, the naira was devalued, the import licensing system was eliminated, and the commodity boards were abolished," it said. Thereafter, distortions were introduced into the programme as the government began to yield to political interests. This greatly marred the effectiveness of the entire programme.

The derailment of SAP began with the 1988, N27.102 billion reflationary budget of the government. Said the report: "In January 1988, the programme stalled and in some areas, such as controls on the budget deficit and the growth of money supply, it even regressed." It blamed this on the policy thrust of the budget which Babangida said would put the country "on the threshold of a new era of a healthier, sustained development process." That budget adopted moderate inflation as a way of stimulating growth in the economy, and providing the human face and milk of human kindness, which Olusegun Obasanjo, a general and former head of state, said it lacked. The report said this sowed the seed for the abandonment of the programme.

The report listed other factors as the growing unrest in the labour and students circles, rising food prices, fiscal and monetary in discipline, lowering of interest rates and the failure of government to adjust petroleum prices upwards. "Not only was the reflationary budget of 1988, the first major policy backslide, but it also undermined progress in other areas of reforms," the report said.

Once the momentum was lost, the bank said government was largely unable to steady the reforms on course. Political considerations gave way to sound economic reasoning. Extra-budgetary spending increased the budgetary deficit. This in turn affected the value of the local currency and raised the level of inflation in the economy. Once it deviated from the path of the reform, the gains began to diminish. By mid-1989, the report said government had shifted attention from economic to political reforms, which resulted in a decline in "the quality and consistency of economic policy making." The windfall from oil earnings during the Gulf War only accelerated the pace of abandonment of the reforms.

Between mid 1989 and 1992, the report noted that "government totally yielded to political pressures, and despite repeated official pronouncements that it would continue with reforms, it could not sustain the original objectives of the structural adjustment programme and instead, implemented ad-hoc policies to meet short-term expenditures. The most serious issues were unrestrained public spending and irresponsible fiscal behaviour." Since 1990, the World Bank noted that "the government has fallen even further behind in implementing the reform programme."

The report in a way admitted the failure of its standardised prescriptions to effectively tackle the economic ills of a society. In the Nigerian example, the bank admitted its failure to appreciate the complexity of implementing structural reforms alongside fundamental political reforms as well as the need for a consistent political will that will see the reforms through. "This political context of reforms in Nigeria," the report noted, "proved to be more complex than either the World Bank or the government expected."

It noted for instance, that in the design and implementation of the programme, the government "had a short-run outlook that foreclosed thinking about benefits in the medium and long run." The effect of this is that policies and programmes were adopted and implemented more as interim strategies than permanent solutions.

The absence of transparency, especially in the administration of oil revenue and the emphasis placed on expensive capital projects such as the Aluminium Smelter projects at Ikot Abasi, the Ajaokuta Steel Complex and the petrochemical project phase two projects, which the bank described as unviable projects, were seen as major pitfalls in the implementations process. Whereas the government had anticipated the SAP would encourage large inflow of new investment, the report said new investment in the economy remained low. It blamed this on the lack of accountability and poorly informed investments by government. Manufacturing investments by the private sector too remains low.

Achievements in such other areas as fiscal and monetary controls were unspectacular. Inflation was on the rise, from 5.7 percent in 1986 to 11.4 percent in 1987 and nearly 54.5 percent by 1988. It fell to 50.4 percent in 1989 and by 1991, stood at 13 percent. It blamed this on the huge budget deficit. Central Bank of Nigeria, CBN, figures released recently, however, differ slightly. It said that inflation between 1986 and 1987 averaged 7.8 percent, a year. It went up to 30.8 percent between 1988-92 and by November 1993, stood at 56.2 percent. Fiscal deficits also grew during the period, the CBN said. Between 1988-91, it was 10.5 percent of GDP, moving up to 12.4 percent in 1992 and may have exceeded 15 percent by the end of 1993.

The World Bank said SAP made the greatest gain in the area of exchange rate reforms. "What has been most remarkable is the sustained devaluation of the naira's external value between 1985 and 1992, from 1988 to 1992, the quarterly average of the naira exchange rate per US dollar depreciated by 27 percent, 58 percent, 61 percent, 67 percent and 83 percent over the 1987 period."

But according to Paul Ogwuma, governor of CBN, this depreciation still left the country without a realistic exchange rate. Said he: "The objective of reasonable exchange rate stability was not achieved. Although the relatively large depreciation of the naira exchange rate in 1986 and 19487 were to some extent expected, (given the evident overvaluation of the currency before then), the subsequent sizeable downward movements could not be attributed to pre-SAP overvaluation but largely to increased demand relative to supply of foreign exchange."

Accordingly, the CBN notes that the central rate depreciated by 12.6 and 38 percents in 1988 and 1989 but was much less unstable in 1990 and 1991. It dropped by 48 and 20.6 percent in 1992 and 1993. The goals of devaluation were to discourage imports by making them more expensive, encourage domestic production and the in-flow of foreign capital. The bank's position has remained that devaluation will create new wealth for the Nigerian economy. However, this has not been the case. Devaluation, according to experts, does not often create the prosperity its proponents claim. Recently, Bill Clinton, the United States president had declared that no "country can devalue its way to prosperity," nor can they systematic devaluation of the naira which SAP brought about help to strengthen the local currency.

Ogwuma, said this much when he reviewed the performance of the monetary sector under SAP. "Despite the reforms so far, the naira exchange rate has remained unstable and, therefore, not conducive to planning." The World Bank did not, however, say whether the depreciation resulted in a realistic value of the naira. Rather, it said that excess money in the system fueled demand for foreign exchange, thus widening the gap between demand and supply, "from a mere $360 million in the first 10 months of the second-tier foreign exchange market to $15 billion in 1987 and $17.5 billion in 1990." it noted that what could have been a great success for the reform programme was again stunted by inconsistencies in implementation as well as contradictory movement in related policies like fiscal deficits and interest rate regulation. "Overall, progress in foreign exchange reform was good, but lack of reforms in fiscal policies and monetary control nullified the progress to some extent. Excess liquidity, weak implementation capacity and interest group pressure were cases of the government's failure to stabalise the exchange rate and domestic inflation."

The CBN agrees largely with the verdict of the World Bank on the performance of SAP. Said Ogwuma late last year. "In spite of some gains made through CBN's role in Nigeria's recent economic reforms, the designed objectives, such as stability and rapid growth with minimal unemployment, are still elusive." It said that the successes, especially in the critical reform areas such as monetary as fiscal reforms have been constrained by a number of factors. This, it said, included the rapid growth in liquidity with attendant effect on the naira exchange rate and domestic price levels, high interest rates, government deficit financing through direct borrowing from the CBN, inadequate inflow of foreign exchange and exchange rate depreciation.

The lessons from the Nigerian experience, the report said, are quite instructive. The implementation of SAP created a lot of pains and severe deterioration in the quality of social services. For instance, it noted that drugs could no longer be imported for hospitals. Fees were introduced in schools and hospitals while school enrollment doubled. It noted that while SAP was designed to increase the share of public expenditure on the social sector. This led to deductions in government allocations to these sectors and accelerated the level of deterioration.

But the bank noted that the real food prices declined during the adjustment years and the position of the poor improved during the SAP period. However, increases in prices of petroleum products resulted in increase in transportation costs and cost of other services. Although, the government introduced some palliatives, they were inadequate to ameliorate the pains. Under SAP, the objective was to increase the share of public expenditure for human resources, but this proved difficult. For instance, allocation to the sector declined by 21 percent in 1981 to 13 percent in 1988. The report dismissed government's SAP relief packages such as transport subsidies, public employment programmes through the National Directorate of Employment, NDE, and allowances for government workers as "wasteful," because they were ad hoc and not well-designed.

SAP betrayed the hope of Nigerians for a glorious future. In supporting the programme, the bank said Nigerians wanted to endure the "interim hardship from the austerity programme, in the hope that broadly based political reforms would create a more equitable distribution of growth benefits at the end of the interim austerity." Instead, Nigerians now have to live with that, hope betrayed. The lesson from Nigerian and other countries covered in the study is "that whenever adjustment programmes have been pursued vigourously, results have been clearly positive with respect to both growth and alleviation of poverty... Too frequent, abrupt and unpredictable changes and reversals of policies erode the credibility of the programmes, intensify uncertainties and weaken investors confidence."

"The stability, continuity and predictability of policies play an important role in the success of reforms," said the report. These, Nigeria lacked. And they helped to render the reforms ineffective.

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH. NEWSWATCH is published at P.M.B. 21499 Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950 Fax: 962887 Telex: 27874


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


14 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


USA: "Crowning Achievements: African Arts of Dressing the Head"


LENGTH: 1294 words


 

UCLA News Bureau

January, 1995

by Christine Sellin

"Crowning Achievements: African Arts of Dressing the Head" features traditional and contemporary hats, headdresses and hairstyles from Africa, exploring their aesthetic richness, keen artistry and symbolic ingenuity. In recognition of Black History Month, "Crowning Achievements" opens Feb. 5 and continues through July 16, 1995 at UCLA's Fowler Museum of Cultural History.

Composed of a staggering array of shapes and an enormous range of materials, the exhibition represents a cross-cultural survey of Africa's dynamic arts of personal adornment. Dating from the early 1800s to present-day, more than 150 objects examine the significance of headwear across Africa and the African Diaspora. 

"These works of art illustrate how people use hats to construct social identities, and to enhance and transform their lives," said Mary Jo Arnoldi, curator of African ethnology at the National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, who served as the project's visiting co-curator with colleague Christine Mullen Kreamer, visiting curator at the Museum of Natural History. "Headwear is one of the most inventive art forms to come out of Africa, or any other part of the world."

In Africa, as in many cultures, hats and hair can define social status, age or gender and transmit important messages about the attitudes, values and beliefs that shape the human experience. The exhibition interprets headwear with an emphasis on individual identity, exploring the material artistry, spiritual value, historical origins and stylistic influences of the objects. Related clothing and appurtenances, lively, painted African headressing signs and photographic blow-ups embellish the presentation.

Following an introductory section, the exhibition commences with an in-depth view of 12 provocative hats that represent a wide geographic range of cultural styles, employ a diversity of materials and exhibit spectacular technical expertise. These include a Yoruba beaded crown, a Gola fiber hat, a Sudanese chain mail helmet, an Ethiopian silver crown and a Herero women's leather headdress.

Like hats, hairstyles are excellent vehicles for visual expression as examined in the next section, "Head and Hair." Some 55 distinctive objects, including elaborate wigs, hairpieces, hairpins, combs, headrests and painted barber shop and salon signs, comprise this portion of the exhibition.

The fourth and fifth sections present two groupings of headwear: informal or everyday wear and special- occasion wear. Aesthetically and regionally diverse, these hats speak to issues of style and symbolism, purpose and personhood. Though beautiful in form and technique, everyday wear tends toward durable, affordable solutions, such as hats made from calabashes incised with curvilinear designs; or those miraculously transformed from reeds, grasses and tree fibers, such as the tightly-woven basketry cap from Madagascar. Conversely, dress for special occasions involves the use of precious or exotic materials, with a high degree of decorative embellishment that convey power, wealth and prestige. Whether intended for kings, brides or diviners, hats may fulfill a multitude of social and religious functions. For example, headwear can serve as a visual metaphor for political power associated with leadership, such as the exuberantly beaded bicorn chief's headdress made by the Pende people of Zaire. Alluding to the strength of the buffalo, the headdress has horns on each side.

The sculptural art of wrapping the head, featuring men's and women's head ties and turbans that highlight the elegant, volumnic expressions of this widespread custom in Africa, comprises the sixth section of the exhibition. The Yoruba of southern Nigeria are recognized throughout West Africa for the beautiful head ties worn included in the exhibition illustrate the artistic splendor of this custom and reflect how the practice of wrapping the head relates to Yoruba philosophical notions about the sacredness of the head.

Headwear can serve as important material symbols of rank and title. Issues of status are investigated in the seventh segment of the exhibition, which compares the full range of headgear used by two societies in Zaire, the Kuba and the Lega. Among the Kuba, title-taking is central to social life. An initiated adult man has the right to wear a small conical cap, laket, but more elaborated versions of this cap are reserved for those with additional titles. For example, the version of the laket worn by titled soldiers is embellished with large tufts of raffia fiber. Among the Lega, high-ranking men and women in the Bwami association-- a social organization of which nearly all Lega adults are members--wear distinctive hats as markers of their elevated status. Men who have achieved the highest level of status call themselves "Elephant Tail Folks," and wear an elaborate hat made of fiber, shells and cowries surmounted by an elephant tail.

The exhibition concludes with a look at the significant impact that African styles have had on the Western fashion world, tracing contemporary trans-Atlantic connections between Africa and America. Hats made of Ghanaian kente cloth or Bamana mud-cloth from Mali, and the Islamic-inspired cloth skullcap have hit the urban fashion scene both within and outside the continent. A selection of hats from the African marketplace in Los Angeles offers an excellent case study of the range of African-influenced headwear available for sale in a major American city. These hats reveal affinities with Egypt, African Islam, Senegal and Jamaican Rastafarianism, among others.

Accompanied by a 185-page catalogue, the exhibition was organized by the Fowler Museum and includes objects selected from the museum's holdings as well as from several private collections. "Crowning

Achievements" is held in conjunction with its companion presentation,"Coiffure Moderne: A Gallery of African Hairstyles, 1970-1990" which features hand-painted, African headressing signs from Gabon, Ghana and Cote d'Ivoire. "Coiffure Moderne" opens on March 5 and continues through July 16, 1995.

The Fowler Museum's hours are Wednesday through Sunday, noon to 5 p.m.; Thursday until 8 p.m. Admission is free. For general information call (310) 825-4361.

UCLA News Bureau, Public Information Office, James West Center, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA

90024-1431. Tel. 310 825-2585 Fax: 310 206-3455


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

15 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


THE GAMBIA: What is African Arts?


SECTION: ARTS, MUSIC & CULTURE


LENGTH: 1627 words


 

Daily Observer

December 8, 1994

by Suelle Nachif

All art can be said to have two sweeping characteristics; it embodies a message within an idiom of communication, and it appears to the intellect.

"Good" art is that which, no matter what its cultural origins or uses, can arouse the sense of mystery in many persons, from many cultures.

Africa has an extensive "good" art; its ineffable quality can be widely perceived, and it has taken its place in museums and in collections of many art lovers.

Art bears a "message" from artist to viewer.

The message is carried out within an idiom that, like language, can be broken down into a sort of grammar- the parts of a sculpture, or the parts of music, analogous to the parts of speech. Art then may be valued either as a message-bearing comment or as a mystery. It may in fact be valued for both of these things at once. 

The mystery of good art cuts across cultural barriers, the message probably does not.

In order to appreciate the art fully, something of the cultural background must be known to make the message clear.

Art is of essence in analysing culture, because it supplies the media in which some of the most perceptive and original thinkers in any society communicate their experience.

Art includes communication, comments, and criticism. The critics translate for the people who may have less perceptive vision, what it is that the artist is saying- the postulate that lies behind his message.

African art can be understood on three levels: it can be studied as form and technique. In the second place, the purpose and the meaning-the aesthetics. And thirdly, African art can be evaluated for its impact on western (or some other) art, an impact on western (or some other) art, an impact that was, earliest and strongest, that of the mystery rather than that of message.

Forms of African Art-The main forms of African art that have been widely known are limited to sculpture and music.

African music is coming into its own and has several specific contributions to make.

The most dramatic of the special attributes is its polyrhythmic structure. Polyrhythms are complex combinations of fairly simple but different rhythms, all played concurrently.

African dancing has been for a long time one of the favourite sights of the tourist in Africa, for its quality and artistic achievement.

Each part of the dancer's body accompanying one of the rhythms in the orchestra is reproduced by the dancer's body. The head moves in one rhythm; the shoulders in another; the arms in the third; the trunk in another; and the feet still in another.

Once the viewers learn to see and feel the polyrhythms in the dance as it reflects the music, they can appreciate that African dancing demands both precision and allows freedom of expression to the dancers.

African painting has a very long history. The earliest cave paintings go back several thousand years, but have not been dated with any great precision.

Some of the earliest are huge representations of human beings; 11 feet high and animals as much as 26 feet lone. Rock paintings are still done today, but the figures are miniature rather than the gigantic murals.

"African Sculpture" The best known of African arts is its sculpture. Most African sculpture, except that done in Terra Cotta, is produced by a subtractive process material taken away from a core instead of added to a core.

Soap stone carvings are found in areas of Sierre Leone, iron sculpture in several places in Africa.

Ivory was a favourite medium in Benin and the Congo. However the major media for African sculptures are wood and various alloys of copper, tin, zinc, bronze and brass. Wood working is done with an adze and is finished with a knife. Bronzes are all cast by the lost wax method. In this method, the technique is fundamentally additive, rather than subtractive, as it is in a carving. The earliest sculpture that we know to be unequivocally African comes from the Nok culture. The distribution of Nok is a fairly narrow area between Katsina and Katsina Ala in northern Nigeria. Nok art as it is known, is almost entirely pottery or Terra Cotta art. Origins and histories of individual art styles and forms can, of course, be usefully made; but "the origin" is too amorphous a question, as art is a form of communication, and therefore grows with culture and develops; it has always been so and it will always be so.

Various Expressions-African art is interwoven with daily life, religious beliefs and cultural ideals which are expressed, and created artistical figures primarily for ceremonial purposes, and also in the practical objects of day- to-day existence, and in the role of art as an agent for social and economic development. A historical examination of traditional art, a recognition that it is more dynamic than we formerly thought and a close look at the changes of recent decades, lead us to recast our image of traditional art in a less romantic and idealised light, and to see it as perhaps more profoundly different from recent art of the West than we have thus far recognised. Viewing the traditional arts of African historical perspective throws into relief certain qualities that are not usually emphasised, in so far as one can generalise about so vast a field.

A consistent and important feature of seems always to have appreciated and rewarded unusual new interpretations of their inherited art forms whether on the level of relatively minor innovations in form and in iconography or occasionally in the wholesale exportation of new art forms from neighbouring people often substantially adapted. It now appears that many entertainment masquerade- the characters, names, songs and dance were invented by young men and women to comment upon current events. They remained in use as long as their generation performed them and then were replaced by the next generation's inventions in a similar mode. When successor generations decline to produce a new version, the genre becomes extinct. The National Council for Arts and Culture demonstrates that traditional art continues to be re-created, thanks to its capacity to change, and to absorb new ideas and situations- the flexibility apparent in traditional art today sheds new light on the traditional artists of the past.

The National Council for Arts and Culture proposes that the traditional arts and cultural activities past, present and near future be defined as those in which the community views the artists essentially as transmitters of received forms; and that though those artists are and were rarely anonymous in the true sense, their identity is and was usually of little interest. Their personal contribution to the creation of a work art was seen as subordinate to the role played by the commissioner of the work or by subsequent owners. The traditional artists often collaborate with clients and others, including other artists in the production of art works, therefore it is the role of the National Council for Arts and Culture to make sure the preservation, promotions and developments are well implemented and monitored.

Uncorrupted African Art-African art today cannot be seen as corrupted, for it was never pure, never homogeneous and never isolated, rather in The Gambia as elsewhere in time of change, individuals and societies have taken charge of their artistic expressions- they have selected artistic forms and ideas from the multitude available to them and have changed and changed their artistic repertoire. As the twentieth century reaches a close, African artists like forebears before us, have chosen to renew useful old forms to take on new ones and to cast off others in an ongoing (process of organic decay and renewal.

Reprinted from the Daily Observer, P.M.B. 131,.Banjul, The Gambia Tel. (220) 490608 Fax: (220) 496878


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


16 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


SUDAN: The Logical Alternative


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

Sudanow

December 1994

By Alfred Logune Taban

The "peace from within" option is a consequence of the absence of a peace agreement with the SPLA on the one hand, and the military successes scored by government forces in the field on the other. Many of the Sudanese displaced by fighting in Southern Kordofan, the Blue Nile region and southern states have become convinced that if they are to wait until an agreement is signed before returning to their homes, they may stay displaced indefinitely. Besides, life hasn't been at all easy in the area where most of them have been displaced. Those in Khartoum, for example, have complained of among other things a lack of employment, transport difficulties, poor housing and the high cost of living. 

This has resulted in an influx of the displaced back to their areas of origin. Their return has been made easier by the relative state of law and order which has been restored to several parts of Southern Sudan and Southern Kordofan. Since March 1992, government forces have recaptured about 16 towns and villages from the SPLA, and although fighting is still going on, it is confined to much fewer areas.

In cooperation with the Commission for the Displaced (COD), the Sudan Council of Churches (SCC) has repatriated over 20,000 Southern Sudanese since 1990. It has sent 4,000 persons to Juba alone since the middle of last year, and was planning in late October to organise at least four more trips to repatriate at least another 2,000. Besides Juba, destinations of the displaced include Renk, Bentiu, Wad-Dakona, Meriam, Abyei and Safa.

The SCC normally provides each returnee with 2 pots, plates and water cups, one washbasin, five pieces of soap and a number of food items. Additionally, a sum of Ls. 3,000 is given to each of them on arrival. Initially there was fear that some of the displaced would quickly rush back to Khartoum on discovering that life is not that much easier in their areas of origin. SCC officials say however that no-one has returned, and almost all those repatriated went straight back to their villages and homes or joined relatives and friends, and are not dependent upon relief. Some are now busily engaged in reconstruction work.

In late October, President Al-Bashir described the repatriation as a success, telling senior figures in the national media that some of those who had returned to Wad-Dakona in Northern Upper Nile State have been earning yearly incomes averaging Ls. 600,000 for the cultivation and collection of gum arabic. The president added that those who returned to Bahr Al-Jebel have also been positively engaged in cultivation and rehabilitation of their villages, but stressed that the government has now to provide the returnees with essential services such as schools and medical centres in order to bring stability, development and trade-internal and cross-border-to areas that were once the scene of fierce fighting. Peace villages have been established in parts of Southern Sudan and Southern Kordofan- those in Southern Kordofan in particular have been provided with almost al essential services and can even boast tractors. It is hoped that services such as these will attract those still resident in rebel-held areas to the peace villages, where they can expect to live a life of near-normality.

Another component of the "peace from within" option, say government officials, is the negotiations with SPLA commanders in the field with the aim of striking regional peace agreements that would also help to bring stability to parts, if not all, of Southern Sudan. For this reason, all ten southern states have an additional minister for peace and reconstruction. Part of the brief of these ministers is establishing the contacts necessary to initiate this internal dialogue.

The consolidation of federal rule is also seen by many as being crucial for the realisation of "peace from within". Since 1947, southerners have been calling for a federal system of government to enable them to rule themselves. This has now been granted to them. The argument goes that if southerners living inside Sudan are content, then peace is guaranteed; if not, stability cannot be assured, even if a settlement were reached with the SPLA. The success of federal rule and the popular desire for the return of stability to rebuild broken lives is also expected to put pressure on the SPLA to make amends at the negotiating table.

The formation in late September of a 88-member Select Council for Peace, under the tutelage of President Al-Bashir, is also being seen as another measure to support the "peace from within" option.

While appealing to many people inside the country, the "peace from within" option is however unlikely to bring lasting peace to the country. The SPLA is still armed, and has the capacity to create instability in many parts of Southern Sudan and Southern Kordofan. What's more, it still takes orders for the most part from leaders who are based outside the country. Therefore, the "peace from within" option must go hand-in-hand with negotiations with the SPLA until such time as a comprehensive and lasting peace agreement is reached.

Reprinted from SUDANOW December 1994. SUDANOW is published at 7 Jamhouriyya Avenue P.O. Box 2651 Khartoum, Sudan Tel: 249-11-84936 Fax: 249-11-77915


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


17 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


SUDAN: SPLA And UMMA Give Unity, Democracy and Freedom a Chance


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Sudan Democratic Gazette

January, 1995

By Bona Malwal

In what must be regarded as a milestone achievement, the SPLA and the Umma Party signed a formal agreement on 12 December, committing themselves to political cooperation, working for the restoration of freedom and democracy, and recognising the right of the South to Self-determination.

This is the most important agreement for many years concerning relations between the North and the South in Sudan. It has come at an opportune moment when the debate over Self-determination is at the forefront of any political discussion.

Without doubt, the Umma Party has shown great courage in breaking away from the more traditional view held by Northern political parties. The agreement confirms that the party is committed to finding a peaceful solution to the conflict in Sudan, and is no longer prepared to use force to maintain the unity of the country. 

The "Gazette" strongly endorses this agreement and urges all those who wish Sudan well to do likewise. However, we hasten to add that the agreement on its own will not cure all of the country's ills. The problems are both chronic and complex. The agreement is a highly significant first step towards getting to the root cause of the problems, which is why it is important to rally the support of other political groupings to the basic text.

Already the agreement has been criticised by groupings in both North and South. The Umma Party has been attacked by traditional and conservative elements in the North who have always viewed southern Sudanese as a people to be controlled rather than won as partners.

Both the SPLA and the Umma Party have called on the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) to join them in the agreement and to show leadership at this crucial time. Although the NDA has not in the past shown a great deal of leadership for the opposition in the struggle to overthrow the Khartoum regime, it should now respond positively to bring all the opposition groupings behind the agreement.

Negotiations behind the agreement were never easy because there are a number of areas on which the two parties disagree. Foremost among these is the question of Self-determination for the Ngok Dinka people of Abyei, the Nuba Mountains and the Ingessina Hills. Colonial administrators placed these areas in the geographical North of Sudan, and so the Umma Party is reluctant to grant them such a right. The SPLA argues that these areas have become so marginalised in the North that they have earned the right by taking up arms against their oppressors.

Disagreement on this point is understandable, yet the "Gazette" must add its weight to the SPLA position. The North has done very little over the past forty years to merit the continuing attachment of these areas to it without first giving the people a say in their own future.

The two parties have set up a technical committee to work out the details of future constitutional and administrative arrangements on which they disagree. Much work has already been carried out on these matters but much more remains to be worked out, to avoid controversy at a later date.

It now remains for the Southerners outside of the SPLA to endorse the agreement. The sooner this is done then the sooner the debate over separation or the confederation of the South with the North can begin in earnest. Without such a healthy debate, it will be difficult to arrive at a correct decision.

At the individual level, it has to be noted that the agreement would not have been possible without the personal courage displayed by the two Umma Party leaders, Dr. Omer Nur El Dayem and Mubarak El Fadil El Mahdi. Both men broke the Northern establishment mould by traveling to Southern Sudan to finalise and sign the agreement there with the SPLA leaders. They not only put their reputations on the line but also their lives when they entered the war zone. They have greatly contributed to the search for a just solution to Sudan's problems by showing the way forward to others in the Northern political establishment.

Finally I wish to thank the leadership of the SPLA for granting Aldo Adjou Deng and myself the honour and privilege of participating in their team during the negotiation process.

Reprinted from: Sudan Democratic Gazette, PO Box 2295, London w14 ond, U.K.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

18 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


UGANDA: Museveni Moves To Speed Up Privatisation


LENGTH: 720 words


 

The Monitor

January 4-6, 1995

President Yoweri Museveni has announced a major overhead of the organisation and procedures for divestiture of parastatals.

A press release issued by State House yesterday says the new measures, among others, shall see greater transparency, line ministries ceding authority over parastatals under them, the scrapping of the Public Enterprises Reform and Divestiture Secretariat (PERD) and, a new target of full transfer to the private sector of at least 85 percent of all parastatals by 1997.

The changes take immediate effect. 

The State House release says that the measure aim at increasing investment in key sectors and reducing the burden of inefficient public enterprises on the economy. It says there is a need to streamline the procedures for divestiture which are unnecessarily cumbersome and are a deterrent to potential investors. They also aim at "imposing financial controls on parastatals, which still represent a substantial drain on the budget."

The Minister of State for Finance & Economic Planning Matthew Rukikaire, will now be in charge of the divestiture and privatisation programme, in addition to performing other duties already assigned to him in the Ministry.

The Presidential also directed that the Divestiture Reform Implementation Committee (DRIC) will not be involved in any negotiations with investors or bid review, for which the Minister of State will be responsible. DRIC will, however, continue to approve the final transfer of an enterprise or shares to bidders as required by the Statue.

The Minister of Finance and Economic Planning has also been directed to transfer to the Ministry of Finance all shares of parastatals slated for divestiture, with the temporary exception of statutory corporations for which amendment of Acts of Parliament is needed. Line ministries, therefore, will cease to have any authority with respect to those parastatals.

The Public Enterprise Reform and Divestiture Secretariat (PERD) and the Policy Review Working Group (PRWG) will be dismantled and replaced by a Parastatal Monitoring Unit headed by the Secretary to the Treasury to monitor financial policy with respect to parastatals, and a Privatisation Unit will handle all matters relating to divestiture, with transparent criteria for bid evaluation.

The President has further directed the Minister of Finance and Economic Planning to increase transparency and objectivity in all divestiture procedures. All parastatals shall be submitted to a full legal and financial audit conducted by independent auditors and lawyers before they are advertised for sale. The current level of debt and the cost of possible retrenchment should be estimated in addition to the value of the company as a going concern. The information will then be used to determine the divestiture method to be followed (i.e. liquidation when debts are larger than assets; sale of shares through the outright sale; pre-emption rights etc.)

Advertisements shall follow a standard format.

The release concludes by stating that the target of the divestiture programme has been revised to achieve full transfer to the private sector of at least 85 percent of all parastatals by the end of 1997.

Reprinted from THE MONITOR Jan. 04-06 1995 THE MONITOR is published at P.O. Box 12141 Kampala, Uganda Tel: 251353 Fax: 251352


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.
