Africa News


January, 1995


KENYA: First Round in Goldenburg Case


LENGTH: 680 words


 

Daily Nation

January 25, 1995

by Vincent Mwangi

The Nairobi Chief Magistrate's court will start hearing preliminary objections in the Sh18 billion Goldenburg case filed by the Law Society of Kenya against former CBK Governor Eric Kotut and five others.

The move followed consensus yesterday by all counsel, who included Deputy Public Prosecutor Bernard Chunga, appearing for the Attorney-General.

Mr. Paul Muite, leading the prosecution team applied for the adjournment in the suit against Mr. Kotut former Treasury Permanent Secretary C.S. Mbindyo and W.K. Koinanga, Commissioner for Mines, C.O. Owayu, Commissioner for Customs A.K. Cheruiyot and businessman Kamlesh Pattni . 

He said counsel wanted to get out of the way preliminary issues before embarking on full hearing.

The six accused were present during the brief morning session. The court was packed to capacity by relatives, friends and sympathisers.

The LSK is seeking to institute criminal proceedings against the six men in connection with a Sh18 billion theft from the Central Bank of Kenya on different dates between October 1990 and December 1992.

Goldenberg International Limited has also been enjoined in the suit.

In another development, Mr. Ishan Kapila, for Mr. Owayo, has filed an affidavit notifying the LSK that his client would oppose the society's application for permission to conduct the private prosecution.

Mr. Kapila joins the Attorney General in questioning the LSK's legal right to institute the private criminal prosecution. He filed the notice on Monday citing three (reasons) for the objection.

The lawyer says the LSK has not established that the AG has expertly, or by conduct, declined, neglected or refused to institute criminal proceedings against the suspects.

It has also not established that it has "locus standi" (right to sue) in that the scope of its functions are provided in the LSK Act (Cap 18 Laws of Kenya) does not include the institution and conduct of criminal proceedings on behalf of the public.

But Dr. Willy Mutunga, the LSK chairman, has filed an affidavit maintaining the society has a "locus standi" in the matter on behalf of Kenyans.

The LSK, adds Dr. Mutunga, has the right to prosecute because it's a major taxpayer, having remitted S10 million to the public offers between 19991 and 1994.

Mr. Kapila, in his notice, claims that the LSK has not established that it has suffered any injury or damage or it has sufficient (funds) to enable it to institute the proceedings.

The matter is being heard by Chief Magistrate Uniter Panella Kidullah.

The defence team includes Mr. Salim Dhanji, Mr. A.R. Kapila, Mr. Mohamed Nyaoga, Mr.Byron Georgiadis, Mr. M.G. Sharna and Mr. Moses Kurgat.

Mr. Muite is teaming up with Mr. Pheroze Mowrojee, Mr. Mbuthi Gathanji and Mr. Muangi Mbuthia.

Mr. Chunga is assisted by Principal State Counsel Horace Olumu.

Reprinted from: Daily Nation, Nation House, Kimathi Street, PO Box 49010, Nairobi, Kenya. Tel:(254-2) 221222, Fax (254-2)214047


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


20 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


NIGERIA: The Terminal Date


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

Newswatch

December 19, 1994

By Dan Agbese

All military rulers are grandly devoid of political ambition. But they find, poor people, the burden of political leadership forced on them by politicians who have problems with getting their acts right. As military men, sworn to the defence of the fatherland and its constitution, they can't shirk this great responsibility in their nation's hours of need. So, they accept the challenge and take on the burden. Patriotism demands nothing less from the patriotic. 

No one can objectively accuse a military ruler of plans to stay in power indefinitely. In case anyone is so inclined, military rulers make it a point of honour, if not duty, to reassure the people they (the rulers, that is) do not intend to stay in office a day longer than necessary. Meaning, they appreciate that people on a rescue mission don't like to hang around when the mission has been accomplished. That requires some explanation. Days are necessary to right the wrongs, to solve the mountain of problems left by the politicians and chart a new course for the nation. One of these days is accepted as the last day necessary to accomplish the aforesaid task. If a military ruler stays beyond it, then those who accuse him of ambition to do what comes to politicians by right of being politicians, are right. In our national experience, no military ruler in this country has breached this code of honour. They all strove to stay within the days necessary. Those who came after them still do.

So, how come there are problems with the days necessary? Part of the problem arises from the fact that there is no constitutional provision stipulating the tenure of a military ruler. How long he stays in power is, to reiterate, dictated by the problems he met and which he must, for love of country, tackle. As you very well know (at least, you should) problems of a country come in various sizes. Small problems as such as fixing the value of the naira, take only a few days. Medium-sized problems such as writing a new constitution (the social contract no modern country, except Britain, wants to be without) take many more days. A ginormous (gigantic and enormous) problem such as returning a country to democratic rule, takes the largest number of days. That is why there is always a dress rehearsal on the way to those final days. Now, if you add all these days together, you will see what a Herculean task it is to find the days necessary days within which every military ruler wants to meet the enormous challenges.

Some help from external sources does become both inevitable and desirable. The fact that the late General Murtala Muhammed worked out his own tenure and his successor, General Olusegun Obasanjo, stuck to it, does not invalidate this fact. It only means that some military men are better at working out necessary days than others.

President Ibrahim Babangida, whose regime was not an offshoot of the Murtala/Obsanjo regime, needed external assistance. He set up a political bureau to lend him such a hand. The bureau, in the course of finding an untried and untested political system suitable for a country whose political peculiarities made both the Westminster and the American-type executive presidential system unsuitable, was asked to attach to its finding just how many days were necessary for the military to stay in power. Ambivalence over military rule divided members of the bureau. And the majority did not carry the vote. The minority report of the political bureau stretched the necessary days by a couple of years. Government went along with the wisdom inherent in that recommendation. The rest, as they say, is now history. Indeed so.

When Sani Abacha, a general, stepped in November 17 last year, he too appreciated the enormity of the challenges he had to face and the burden he had to carry. It was, therefore, wise of him to decide, as he did, that he needed a little help from our representatives in the constitutional conference to tell him how many days are necessary for him to accomplish this task. He took some flak for this. Critics, as uninformed as they usually are, did not appreciate the rationale for his action. They said how could the constitutional conference which was not a party to the decision to take over be the right and appropriate organ to determine the number of days necessary for the general to fix the problems of the country. They said the general was merely passing the buck. The general said they were wrong. He said fixing the problems of the nations was the challenge he had accepted but that how long it would take him to do that can best be determined through, well, a 'vox populi', as in constitutional conference.

Last week, a committee of the constitutional conference which studied the enormity of our economic, political and other problems, carefully calculated that Abacha needs the days stretching between November 17, 1993 and December 31, 1997 to fix our national problems. Any days after those would be days longer than necessary. But in this case, the majority refused to accord the minority the right of being right. So it was that the recommendation was thrown out. In their collective wisdom, the delegates to the conference determined that the days necessary for the general should be between November 17, 1993 and December 31, 1995. Any more days would be days unnecessary.

Have the people spoken? The next few days will tell what the government makes of it. But you must remember that politics is not about being right or wrong. It is about being knowing what to make of the question at any given point in time. As someone said, the answer to two plus two depends on either what you are calculating or the circumstances of your calculation. In other words, who you agree with on how long or short necessary days should be for military rule, may depend as much on how many hours make one day as in what you make of the ends of power - that ultimate desire of all men and women.

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH. NEWSWATCH is published at P.M.B. 21499 Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel:4960950 Fax:962887 Telex:27874


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


21 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


NIGERIA: Abiola, a Tragic Hero


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Newswatch

January 9, 1995

by Ray Ekpu

Moshood Kashimawo Olawale Abiola, better known as M.K.O., is the stuff of which heroes are made. His life is a study in perseverance and that is why a man born and bred in poverty was able to scale the daunting hurdles that separate rags from riches and to get to the very pinnacle of prosperity.

Born August 24, 1937, in Abeokuta, Ogun State, to a man who had (almost) lost faith in life, having lost twenty-one (21) children to the icy hands of death, and a woman who had (almost) lost faith in marriage, having lost two husbands earlier, Abiola went through the tough school of life with a single-minded dedication to a reversal of his indigent status. He hewed and sold firewood to raise money for his school fees and when this didn't take him far he formed a brass band. 

As you'd expect, the Kashimambo Orchestra didn't always receive a standing ovation for you did not expect a stammerer to be a great musician. But Abiola, croaky voice or not, managed to rake up a few coins as a captain of this rag-tag orchestra. The orchestra, you need not be told, did not put out any chartbuster. And Abiola's mother died December 10, 1956, "because the family was too poor to afford fifty-five (55) kobo that the doctor demanded for her treatment." If the lady had waited a few years longer, and witnessed her son's phenomenal wealth, her ailment, whatever it was, would have been treated by the best doctors in the best hospitals in the world.

The man who had a good head for figures got a government scholarship to study Accountancy at the University of Glasglow, Scotland, and returned home to work at LUTH and Pfizer before destiny wheeled him to ITT in 1968, where with the deft deployment of blackmail, bravado and business acumen he made a stupendous fortune. It was then that he struck a lucrative symbiotic relationship with the military establishment. It is a cruel irony that that institution has made and unmade him. In the last two decades, Abiola has served as a useful ally to military big-wigs in their inordinate power seizures and manipulations. They made him rich. He made them powerful. And rich too. Abiola's bastion of strength, namely the military, has paradoxically become his Achilles heel, the pin-point source of his vulnerability. They knew him at close range to be a man of ambition. But men of power are usually suspicious of men of ambition.

In the Second Republic, the NPN, the party to which Abiola belonged, admired his electrifying energy at campaigns, his wise-cracks, his willingness to throw money around like confetti, his ability to break the bones of the party's enemies in his newspapers but there's one thing they did not admire in him; his political ambition. They'd be happy to grant him more contracts if he wanted, or add to his paraphernalia of titles or grant him other indulgences provided he'd amputate his political ambition. When in 1980 he desired to overthrow Adisa Akinloye, the NPN chairman, the campaign slogan was that they didn't want to have two presidents in one country so Abiola had to lose. A few years later when Abiola wanted to challenge Shehu Shagari for the NPN presidential nomination, Umara Dikko was to tell Abiola that the presidency was not for sale to the highest bidder, so Abiola had to lose.

If civilians bruised him out of the power orbit, he had reason to believe that his friends, the military, may thrust him into it, particularly since he had in times past done a few dirty jobs for them. But power is a charming maiden. No man surrenders it to another except he has to.

That lesson, Abiola had to learn June 12, 1993, as he was coasting home victorious in the presidential election and the talking drums were talking, then the military brought the march past of jubilating voters to a stop by wiping off the election. Nigerians may have thought they had found their hero, albeit an imperfect hero, a man full of the milk of human kindness. They reasoned: if he gave out his private wealth to the poor and the needy, he would do much more with Nigeria's wealth. A Santa Claus was about to come to power and all the year round it would be Christmas.

But Abiola became an amputated hero the moment he fled the land in the night, the moment he came up with the fatalistic lamentation that Allah gives power to those He wants to, the moment he hid under the Fabian philosophy of avoiding the battle. He forgot the other philosophy, "Who dares wins," or its companion, "Nothing venture, nothing win." A year later, he throws his lethargy aside, he wears the toga of a bull-fighter, he challenges the lion to a duel, he says he wants his due, the presidency, and they say to themselves: "Hei, this guy is a loose cannon." So, they put him away in prison, put the key somewhere and play cards.

Abiola is a desperate man. Desperate men are products of confusion. Juxtapose these: Abiola writes love letters to Ibrahim Babangida, the architect of his predicament. Abiola lavishes praise on Sani Abacha and tells the man to take over the government; he tells his compatriots they could serve the military government that is sitting where he should have been sitting. Then he swings round; he fights for his freedom; he'd accept no conditions for bail, he'd rather die in prison, a striving to regain his lost heroism.

Abiola is not Nelson Mandela. He cannot be, his is too rich, too cowardly, too fickle, to be a Mandela. But he is, in a sense, a hero, a hero of Nigeria's political revolution, albeit a tragic, reluctant hero.

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH. NEWSWATCH is published at P.M.B. 21499 Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel:4960950 Fax:962887 Telex:27874


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


22 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


ERITREA: Document: Address by H.E. Mr. Isalas Afwerki to International Development Conference January 16, 1995


LENGTH: 4254 words


 

Mr. Chairman,

Honorable Delegates,

I would like to address these themes in my remarks: 1. The domestic challenges to bring about peace and security at home, 2. The challenges for bringing about peace and security in the region, 3. The way to development, 4. International cooperation 5. Marginalization Domestic Peace and Security

The challenges that a new country face to lay the foundations for enduring peace and security and the prospects for achieving them cannot, I believe, be addressed and gauged in isolation. Inexorable trends towards regional and continental integration that pervade contemporary thinking and the underlying international setting towards increased global interdependence militate against such conventional, linear approaches. A cursory view of the causes, incidence and intensity of conflicts at the continental level will thus be necessary in order to provide a broader picture of the challenges that have been surmounted.

Africa's past and present record in this regard is however perplexing. Africa has witnessed no less than 47 intensive and low intensity conflicts over the past thirty years after the first wave of political independence from European colonial rule in the 1960s. A disproportionate number of them, 89%, happen to be civil conflicts within the post-colonial independent African state. And, so as not to have a lapse in our collective memories, we also have the Rwandan, Somali, Liberian and Angolan tragedies that are still raging at this very hour. What are the causes of these conflicts? 

Deep-rooted historical factors, legacies of colonialism, underdevelopment and political mismanagement have all contributed with varying degrees and intensity, to over heat Africa's political caldron and breed a situation of perennial tension and civil strife. Modern African states have not been allowed to evolve in accordance with the internal dynamics of nation-building. In the Berlin Conference's scramble for Africa, the powers that drew arbitrary borders, sometimes dispersing ethnic units across several contiguous new states, thereby sowing the seeds of future conflict.

The colonial powers often pursued divisive policies of uneven development both for reasons of short- term economic exploitation and with the willful desire to keep their subjects divided and at loggerheads with each other. The local elite who acceded to power after independence were less interested in addressing these imbalances, wedded as they were to the values, aspirations and perceptions of their colonial mentors. As it happened, internal cleavages along ethnic lines, nepotism ands exclusiveness became more pronounced in independent Africa. Moreover, post-colonial Africa almost invariably suffered from the malaise of poor governance. For many leaders and their close ethnic associates, political power was the short-cut for amassing wealth. As the national pie grew smaller and smaller due to Africa's failure to compete in the international market, those in power took the lion's share of dwindling natural resources through corruption and outright official theft. Public dissension could only be silenced by repression and brute force. At the other extreme, coup d'etat became the accepted norms for those who could wield a measure of support in the army but to whom the system appeared impregnable.

Cold War realities and geopolitical considerations compounded this state of affairs as the major Western powers and the former Soviet Union supported and abetted notorious tyrants to promote broader strategic interests. How can we reverse these realities to ensure continued peace and security?

The cardinal principle that we have to respect is, it seems to me, commitment to participatory politics and the cultivation of democratic traditions in all their variations. Participatory politics may lend itself to different interpretations. There are those who equate participatory politics with Western democratic values and institutions and who advocate for their wholesale and immediate transplantation.

This approach is fundamentally flawed. Nor will it offer the panacea to Africa's profound problem of bad governance. Indeed, while we should acknowledge the barriers to development, stability and social well-being that tyrannies and autocracies pose, we must be flexible and imaginative in the solutions we seek to redress them. After all, we must bear in mind that Western democracies have matured through a prolonged process.

I was often amused by the simplicity and equanimity of knowledgeable friends and partners who were probing us about our democratization process after the referendum and the formal independence of Eritrea. A constitution-drafting process of two years and a transition period of four years to prepare the ground for parliamentary democracy seemed unduly long for many of them, including seasoned politicians.

Many also felt that regulating party politics within the confines of our realities was tantamount to tampering with universal rights. And yet, this is precisely the most reliable and viable approach that we have to follow if we perceive, indeed as we should, the democratization process as a long-term engagement that must be realized over time without violent reversals and hiccups.

We must realize that we are starting with fragile and fragmented societies. The democratic process must therefore pass through pass through a controlled phase if these societies are not to break apart at the seams in mid-stream.

Pluralism must be gauged against its centrifugal potential of fragmentation along ethnic, clan and religious lines. Thus, while we should cultivate serious political differences on tangible, contentious economic and social programmes, we cannot and should not tolerate party politics that revolve around and aim to appeal to primordial sentiments of ethnic and/or religious exclusiveness. At the end of the day, this can only degenerate into the politics of hatred.

To emphasize this point, for societies such as ours, the buzzword must be democratization and pluralism through a controlled process. With this caveat, however the government must be constitutional, elected and accountable. Codes of conduct to ensure transparency and stamp out corruption have to be strictly adhered to and rigorously enforced.

In the economic field, the government must pursue sound economic policies and management practices in as much as it continues to play a supplementary and catalytic role to the private sector. Institution and capacity building must be given top priority both in order to cultivate democratic values and traditions and reasons of administrative efficiency. Human resource development, through wide access to primary and secondary education and improved health services, must be vigorously sought. These will not only ensure social mobility but concretely demonstrate to the population that they have a stake in maintaining peace and security. Participatory politics as interpreted by constructive pluralism, regional balance and human resource development is, I believe, the path we have to refine and pursue to create a conducive climate for continued economic progress and political peace and security. Regional Peace and Security

Earlier I touched on the indivisibility of peace and security. Indeed, it would be unrealistic to speak of an Island or oasis of peace if turmoil and mayhem abound everywhere.

Growing ,militarization, barriers to increased trade, refugee outflows, etc. will sooner or later disturb relative peace in a neighboring country if civil strife is raging across its borders. Traditional concepts of non-interference in internal conflicts are accordingly becoming increasingly tenuous, requiring timely and appropriate qualifications.

Regional peace and stability is moreover threatened by ambitious tyrants who crave territorial conquest under suitable labels. Irredentism, historical myths and legends, and fundamentalism have in fact been invoked at various times and by different tyrants to ignite and fuel expansionist wars in our region in the last forty years alone. External influence and prodding - Cold War exigencies, its hangover, subtle manipulation by major powers - have again played a significant part in exacerbating these wars. How can we contain and prevent future regional wars?

Gradual regional economic cooperation leading to full integration is perhaps one of the realistic goals that we can pursue to create a stable regional climate. This is not a mere political imperative. Indeed, current global economic trends are rendering regional cooperation a matter of survival.

One glaring problem that needs quick remedy is that factors such as low complimentary, weak regional and continental trade, and the virtual absence of infrastructural networks connecting different countries and regions have resulted in attributing a political rather than an economic tinge to the whole concept of economic cooperation. We thus sometimes end up with unrealistic goals such as continental economic unity - the Abuja Treaty - within the life span of this generation.

It is essential that we pursue approaches that are both modest and realistic. At this stage, I do not think we can envisage economic cooperation other than through a modular approach. The constituent parts of these building blocks for eventual continental unity cannot follow similar or stereotyped patterns. Issues of harmonization and uniformity of pace are, I believe, secondary matters that can be addressed in due time.

For the moment, such regional and sub-regional blocs can be easily formed and regrouped. IGADD, the Greater Horn of Africa Region, and COMESA can be cited in our region. They can work on concrete economic cooperation programmes which can be expanded with time. Above all, they can serve as a vehicle for political consultation and as forums for regional conflict prevention and resolution.

The latter function is particularly vital. The tragedies in Somalia and Rwanda have demonstrated the inadequacy of reactive conflict resolution by the United Nations, the OAU or other international organizations physically removed from the scene. What is needed is a reliable mechanism for proactive conflict prevention and resolution. This task will require some form of early warning system to identify in advance hotbeds of potential conflict and astute diplomacy to defuse potential time bombs. (IGADD's role in seeking a solution to the problem of South Sudan is a fitting example.) Forceful intervention should only be the last recourse. There are compelling reasons to establish that most of these tasks are better carried out by regional actors and partners. "The Way to Development"

The controversy here is not on variants of market economy: whether Third World countries at the lowest rung should focus on import substitution, aim towards an export led economy or a combination of both to be able to compete in an increasingly tough global market. I believe that these are issues of detail which may obtain satisfactory answers for specific realities.

The key parameters that have common relevance to our realities can, it seems to me, be summed up by the following:

ii) The first prerequisite for all-rounded development is peace and security both in its domestic sense and in its regional dimension. I have tried to elaborate this theme with sufficient detail previously. Hence, I shall spare you extra boredom by unnecessary repetition.

ii) The second factor is reliance on correct and rational management of domestic resources. This factor is important for several reasons: it helps societies to live within their national means; it reduces dependency; and, more importantly, it fosters local ingenuity and industriousness.

iii) The third factor is effective use of foreign aid. There is much that can be said in this regard. Perhaps in absolute terms, the amount of external finance-- in the form of grants and soft loans-- that has been injected into Africa has not been negligible. Whether it has been used effectively or not is, of course, another matter. But this is a double-edged sword. There are indeed serious errors that must be remedied on the part of donors which I shall try to briefly deal with in the section on international cooperation.

iv) The fourth and last factor is a broader regional and international approach to development. This involves increased regional cooperation to widen economic complimentarity, better exploitation of comparative advantage, and a bigger market for economies of scale as well as wide scope for joint ventures.

"International Cooperation"

At the risk of over repetition, I wish to emphasize that international cooperation is indispensable in an interdependent world which is getting smaller every day under the pervasive power of communications. The weak and powerful, the small and the big, the poor and the rich have to interact, willy nilly, as none of them can go it alone. The main issues in the post Cold War period and the 21st century-- environment, population growth, international terrorism, etc.-- are in fact global in nature and will require increased international consensus and cooperation.

The issue of relevance and controversy will thus be the nature of this cooperation, particularly as it relates to the weak and small.

For us, symmetry should be the linchpin of this relationship. International cooperation will be essential and catalytic to our development in forms of the transfer of technology: external finance in the form of aid, trade and investment; technical assistance for capacity building; as well as meaningful cooperation to ward off threats to peace and security.

But this will only be true if international cooperation is perceived as and upgraded to evolve into true partnership. Donor-recipient relationships based on prescription and dictation of unsuitable antidotes will not do.

Our independence of decision should not be encroached by conditionalities of aid. Recipient countries are better place to determine and identify the policies, priorities and objectives they wish to pursue. Moreover, this is a fundamental question of dignity which cannot be compromised by temporary necessity.

New concepts in the donors lexicon such as programme ownership and national execution need to be expanded and familiarized to help cement this desired symmetry. We must be cautious about programmes of technical assistance and donor intervention that perpetuate themselves replacing the original purpose of grooming local experts, and activities that increasingly tend to substitute local actors and governments. On the other hand, donors should insist on mechanisms of transparency and rigorous monitoring of end use of funds to ensure that they are not abused or pocketed by unscrupulous bureaucrats.

A word regarding the international organizations might also be in place here. There is a growing consensus among Third World countries that representation in the major international-- bodies the Security Council, the Bretton Woods institutions, etc.-- needs radical reviewing in order to reflect a more democratic presence of the constituencies. I believe that this issue will have to be addressed in greater detail in the years to come.

"Marginalization of Africa"

Africa is marginalized as manifested by its failure to close the gap-- which is actually widening--with the developed and newly industrializing countries: by its huge indebtedness, by its failure to attract foreign investment; by the poor status and impoverishment of its inhabitants; and by other conventional economic indicators. Apart from unfair terms of trade and related international economic interactions which have worded to the disadvantage of Africa, the main reasons for its miserable performance in the post-colonial era are those which I mentioned at the beginning of my speech: namely, perennial conflicts and civil strife, bad governance, corruption and nepotism.

Indeed, although the colonial legacy has contributed to arrest Africa's expected progress, it has not been the major cause. On the other hand, we cannot downplay the continued and subtle manipulation of Africa's politics and economy by external actors who do not always have Africa's welfare as their priority.

Yet Africa has the inner potential to break from this cycle of despair and marginalization. It has abundant natural resources, a population of around 600 million, vibrant economies which can spring to life if correct policies are embarked on even at this late hour, and a sizable educated class. This decisive leap can be made if the anomalies cited earlier are corrected and Africans take their future into their own hands. Above all, the resigned attitude, the lack of confidence perhaps inculcated by decades of dehumanizing experience must be shattered and Africa encouraged to look inwards with a sense of purpose and pride.

The solution to Africa's myriad problems, the answer to its marginalization will thus depend on Africans themselves. Naturally, support from the international community will be vital.

Mr. Chairman

Honorable Delegates

For us, the precepts that I have described with some detail do not constitute mere platitudes or long-term ideals. The political will and requisite commitment to translate them into concrete tangible programs must indeed be in place in order to engender hope, confidence and collective action by all those concerned. This is, in fact, the only yardstick for measuring the seriousness and validity of these values and ideals.

In this regard, Eritrea did not opt for a unilateral declaration of independence when it won the war in 1991 after thirty years of bitter armed struggle that exacted heavy sacrifices. Committed as it was to secure, lasting regional and internal peace, it chose instead to assert its independence through international legality and the consultation of its population. Thus, it conducted an internationally supervised referendum, keeping on hold its hard-won sovereignty for an interim period of two years. It declared formal independence only when the Eritrean people gave their verdict with a resounding yes vote of 99.9%.

Eritrea has further managed to cultivate and forge an exemplary relationship of solid cooperation with Ethiopia, its arch-enemy for the last half century. The warm ties of friendship that characterize the fledgling cooperation between both countries, unblighted by feelings of vindictiveness and bitterness, must offer reassuring relief for many of us, especially when we see the havoc wrought and the cycles of violence engendered by these attitudes in many problem areas-- Somalia, Rwanda, Liberia, etc.-- in our continent and elsewhere in the world.

The Eritrean government has not, moreover, been complacent in sparing efforts to consolidate the prevailing peace and stability. To ensure the rule of law and to build as well as strengthen the institutions of democracy, it is vigorously pursuing a measured and prudent democratic path. It has thus formed a Commission to draft a constitution that will be ratified through a constituent assembly within the coming two years. This will pave the way for democratic elections and the formation of a constitutional government with the interim period of four years.

Here again, the government has been careful to ensure and encourage grassroots participation and involvement in the constitution drafting process. Gender issues, cultural diversity and multiplicity, and traditional values of the society were taken into account when the commission was formed. The fifty member Commission brings together legal experts, elders and other eminent personalities from a cross-section of the population.

As mentioned before, peace and security will be sustainable only when they are accompanied by sound economic policies that lead towards a tangible progress. Aware of this truth, the government has done its homeward in the past three years and has now formulated a clear macro-policy and sectoral strategies of development.

The efforts that the government has exerted with its partners to promote regional peace and security are perhaps too well-known to merit repetition here. Eritrea has, moreover, been able to foster bilateral relationships as a sovereign state within the wider community of nations. These ties are proving useful in promoting the collective interests and aspirations of our region in its interactions with the wider world.

Finally, I wish to underline that although we have no illusions on the complexity and intensity of the burdens we are shouldering to promote regional peace and security and the well-being of our people, we are confident that we shall be able to realize these aims through patience, hard word and the indispensable assistance of friends and partners who share with us these common ideals.

Thank you.

The International Development Conference, 1875 Connecticut Ave., NW, Suite 1020, Washington, DC 20009

5728 Tel: (202) 884-8580 Fax: (202) 884-8499


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


23 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


THE GAMBIA: Foreign Aid: Poor People in Rich Countries Helping Rich People in Poor Countries


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

Daily Observer - (Editorial

December 12, 1994

By Sir Alieu

Africa, the continent that abounds in rich natural resources, continues to amaze the world with its incapacity to provide for itself. We Africans seem to have lost our way and we are not even sure whether to produce for ourselves or continue to rely heavily on western foreign aid for our development.

When the modern panoply of official aid institutions grew up after the Second World War, the intention was not to relieve poverty as such but to promote economic growth in poor countries. Aid was seen as a transitional device to help countries reach a point from which their economies would take off of their own accord. Its use was to remove shortages of capital and foreign exchange, boosting investment to a point at which growth could become self sustaining. 

Since 1960, about $1.4 trillion has been transferred in aid from rich countries to poor ones. Yet little is known about what the process has achieved. Has it relieved poverty? Has it stimulated growth in the recipient countries including The Gambia? Has it helped the donor countries to achieve their official goals by using aid to buy third world adherence to their pet ideas? "The Gambian Case"

Such questions become more pertinent as we start to stand on our own feet in light of the decision to spend aid from our traditional aid providers. Proponents of aid will argue that the abrupt cessation of aid to The Gambia will cause severe economic dislocation and diminish the supply of much needed foreign capital and investments, which will adversely affect the standard of living of the majority in our society.

Critics, on the other hand, argue that with dwindling aid budgets around the world and the ominous reluctance of taxpayers in rich countries, who view aid as an unnecessary evil and want their money to be spent on the growing number of poor and homeless people in their backyards, ponder on the effectiveness of aid to alleviate poverty whether directly or indirectly, and believe that recipient countries like The Gambia, failed to make the most out of aid.

The belief that aid is a critical factor in our country's development and that some have even rated it above foreign trade is a popular fallacy that requires careful analysis. Killing the goose that lays the golden egg is one way of depriving us the continuous supply of the egg. The other way is for the goose of its own volition, to cease producing the golden egg. This is an unfortunate characteristic of aid. Unlike other forms of foreign finance, aid does not carry with it the notion of "shared commitment", an important factor if aid is to be referred to as "an engine of growth".

Aid in the 1980s was frequently used as a prod to encourage African countries to begin "structural adjustment" programmes in support of the World Bank's recommendations, and since that time many donors have come to believe that the quality of a country's economic management will do most to determine whether aid will do some good. This is inconsistent with the original goals of giving out aid to alleviate poverty and foster economic growth in developing countries.

"Uneven Growth"Some third-world countries have enjoyed fast economic growth with relatively little aid per head. In particular, China and Vietnam had little or no aid at a time when donors were pouring money into Africa with strings of SAP conditions. If some countries can achieve economic growth with little aid, while other countries can get a great deal of aid do not grow at all, what is aid good for?

According to a recent World Bank report, the richest 40 of the developing countries get about twice as much as the poorest as the poorest 40 percent, and that 50 percent of the available aid for third world counties goes to big military spenders like Egypt and Israel instead of the less belligerent countries who need it most.

A study of America's aid programme conducted by the Overseas Development Council (ODC) based in Washington, D.C., found that more than $250 per person went to relatively big-income countries like Egypt and El Salvador, but less than $1 per person to very low-income countries such as The Gambia and Bangladesh.

The report further disclosed that roughly 25 per cent of the United States $21 billion foreign-aid budget takes the form of military assistance, and roughly a quarter of the total budget goes to Israel and Egypt alone. "The United States has spent more money on advancing political and military goals in the third world than on development says John Sewell of the ODC.

Evidently, this statement partly conflicts with some of the reasons given for the cessation of crucial US development assistance to the people of The Gambia. If neighbouring countries in the region continue to receive US military assistance in the form of "national security", why is it that the development assistance meant to benefit the majority of the Gambian people is to cease for the simple reason that the law in the US with regards to military regimes will be violated?

"Security" The pursuit of national security is also now being used as an argument for giving more weight to all sorts of other goals in the drawing-up of aid budgets in the rich countries. Not surprisingly the motives in giving out aid to poor countries often override the goal of poverty relief, where on earth do we want peace to prevail?

Within poor countries aid is rarely concentrated on the services that benefit the poorest, at a time when aid budgets around the world are ceasing to frow at all and most countries are attaching strings of conditions to their deveilopment assistance. Hapan's aid goes mainly to countries that are most likely to become its future customers.

All DAC (OECD's Development Assistance Committee) countries tie soemaid to the purchase of thier own gods and services. Some kinds of ODA are given in the sure knowledge that the money will be spent mainly in the donor country, but without explicitly tying the kind of aid given.

It is estimated that about 90 per cent of the ODA which goes each year to buy advice, training and project design, is spent on foreign consultants. Half of all technical assistance goes to Africa which, observes an UNDP expert, "has received more bad advice per capital than any other continent". Most thoughtful people in the aid business regard technical assistnce as one of the lest effective ways to foster develoment.

Nonetheless, there have been significant improvements in our standard of living that can be related to the foreign we received. Nobody will deny the importance of aid, but the real issue now is that a lot of real economists have picked holes int he original idea that aid will boost investment; why should it, some ask, when governments may simply use income from aid as an excuse to spend tax revenues in other, less productive ways?

Others worry about the tendency of aid to compensate for failure rather than to reward success. Bilateral donors have increasingly found that much of the aid they give to some countries goes towards paying back borrowed money from international financial institutions that were unwisely spent.

Given the various transfers that count as "aid" the many conditions that donors attach, the differing importance of aid to different countries and the complexity of economic growht, there are simply too many variables to say that aid is useful and that we cannot do without it.

Foreign trade, especially the re-export trade, has been the mainstay of our economy that overly relies on aid for economic growht will surely fail one day. We should be in total control of the variables that will help our economy grow. Aid should be seen as something beyond our control and not a factor of production.

The old jibe about aid-poor people in rich countries helping rich people in poor countries to grow- has plenty of truth in it.

Reprinted from the Daily Observer, P.M.B. 131, Banjul, The Gambia Tel. (220) 4900608 Fax: (220) 49678


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


24 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


ZIMBABWE: Church's Africa University Graduates 27 in First Class


LENGTH: 654 words


 

United Methodist News Service

January, 1995

by M. Garlinda Burton

As families, friends, professors and other supporters cheered, the 27 young men and women of Africa University's first graduating class also heard a charge to the weighty task of "shining like stars" as leaders of a "new Africa."

Zimbabwe's first private university, founded by the United Methodist Church, marked its first graduation exercises Dec. 17 with dancing, singing, prayers, and tears.

Excitement ran high among the 19 agriculture students and eight theological students who now return to communities around Africa to use their skills for the betterment of the continent. 

Attending the exercises were more than 900 persons, including retired United Methodist Bishop Leotine T.C. Kelly of San Mateo, Calif., who led the opening procession, and United Methodist Bishops Emilio deCarvalho of Angola and Arthur Kulah of Liberia, who received honorary degrees.

The two African bishops issued the first challenge in 1980 that the United Methodist Church open a university in Africa. Both the trustees of the school, deCarvalho is also chancellor (chairman of the board).

The emotions of the graduates ranged from elation to reluctance to say goodbye to the close-knit university community. Tsitsi Moyo, a mother of four from Zimbabwe who received a bachelor of divinity degree, admitted her pride and joy were mixed with sorrow.

"I know I'm ready to go, but it is hard to leave," said Moyo, now an ordained United Methodist minister who will work as co-pastor with he husband.

Commencement speaker was the Rev. Randolph Nugent, mission executive for the 9 million-member, global United Methodist Church. Nugent compared the nurture and "birthing" of Africa University's graduates to the birth of Christ, expressing hope that the young leaders will bring a "great light" to an often troubled continent.

Vice Chancellor John Kurewa lauded the graduates as brave visionaries, who came to the university when it was little more than renovated farm houses and a dream.

Thanks to the faith and outstanding performance by students and supporters, the graduates' continued high performance, the United Methodist Church, and private donors, Kurewa said, Africa University's influence on the continent will be far-reaching.

Africa University opened in March 1992 with 40 students in two colleges--theology and agriculture, and natural resources. More than 6,000 people from around the world attended the formal opening of the university held in April 1994.

With continuing support of the denomination the school has grown to 85 students, and a school management and administration (business) will open in March 1995 . Future plans call for schools of education, medicine, science and social sciences.

United Methodist News Service, PO Box 320,Nashville, TN 37202 Tel. (615) 742-5470 Fax: (615) 742-5469

January, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: The Poet With A Politician's Instincts


LENGTH: 1854 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

January 20, 1995

by Mark Gevisser

Sankie Mthembi-Nkondo is a poet and writer and the new minister of housing, succeeding the late Joe Slovo.

Dear Comrade Wife," wrote ANC poet and diplomat Zinjiva Nkondo to his wife, Sankie, during their years of separation in exile, "I know you are not afraid/ of spears/ your thighs and breasts of humanhood/ have outgrown these pests."

They are divorced now, and he lives in Zambia. But they were, in the 1980s, one of the ANC's preWhile working in Lusaka, she wrote a story under her nom de guerre, Rebecca Matlou, entitled One Never Knows, eminent literary couples: both had volumes of poetry published by the Congress of South African Writers in 1990. which won special mention in a contentinental women's writing competition and was published in a Swedish anthology.

Like her protagonist in this story, who becomes unwittingly involved in the ANC underground in the 1970s, Mthembi- Nkondo gives the impression of being rock-solid, a pillar of the struggle, "not afraid of spears". But the story, as its title suggests, is about the impossibility of understanding the present and determining the future. This, up against the formidable revolutionary rationalism of the ANC. There's a subtext to Mthembiaround her, the reader understands her alienation and insecurity. 

Nkondo's genial strength, one which is found in her fiction: while her female hero radiates silent courage to those

In an interview this week, she returned repeatedly to the difficulties of exile and separation; and to the refuge that the movement provided. There is something quite incongruous about her willingness to spool randomly through her consciousness: "When I began to receive multiparty South African delegations in Bonn (where she was ANC chief representative until late 1993), I began to understand that it was possible to return home, really to return home. And my mind wandered back to my childhood, to my friends and school and family, and I began to imagine how we all would function as a liberated people." This is a poet's way of being, one thinks. Not a politician's.

And yet she likes to portray herself as tough: "You must remember," she twinkles, "that I come from Soweto. The ghetto, the jungle. You learn to survive there. If you allow yourself to be bullied, you'll spend the rest of your days paying off protection fees. And so you toughen up; you become a product of your environment." One of the things she learnt in other parts of Africa, she says, "is that you don't have to fight. You can disagree with someone, and argue for hours, like the Nigerians do. You don't have to pull a knife out."Poet-intellectual she might be. But she must have the instincts of a politician to have become one of the very few women to have made it to the upper echelons of ANC power. Early on in her exile, as a journalist on Radio Freedom, she came to the attention of Thabo Mbeki, then head of ANC information. She later worked under him in the international affairs department -- first in Lagos and then in Bonn.

Several sources in the ANC believe her appointment to be a direct result of her relationship with Mbeki: after her return to South Africa in 1993, she ran the department of international affairs for him. Others counter, however, that Mbeki frequently overlooked her -- placing Aziz Pahad above her in the transitional executive committee's foreign affairs subcommittee, for example. And that she caught Nelson Mandela's eye in Bonn where she took over a particularly difficult and troublesome terrain -- relations between the ANC and the German government were not good -- and transformed it into one of the more effective missions of the movement.

Indeed, Mandela -- along with Mbeki and Jacob Zuma -- is believed to have supported her in the election for deputy secretary general at last month's ANC congress, a battle she lost decisively to the far higher profile --and more leftwing -- Cheryl Carolus.

Cabinet insiders suggest that her appointment was a combination of two key factors: Mandela's desire to keep the housing ministry powered by Joe Slovo's legacy -- which would require a lower-profile minister both efficient and humble -- and his wish to develop new, and particularly female, political leadership.

"I feel terribly uncomfortable here," she says, on her second day in an office whose generic Pretoria drabness allows for no remembrance of its former occupant. "I kept on moving about this afternoon, looking for a different chair. I didn't want to sit where Comrade Joe sat."

She is of the 1976 generation -- her classmates at Turfloop included Cyril Ramaphosa and Matthews Phosa, and she was to begin teaching in Soweto in the very year of the uprising. For her, Slovo was of the generation that "took responsibility for bringing us up, both politically and literally, for we were little more than children when we left the country."

It would be "dishonest", she says, "to attempt to imitate him". But running the ministry will be about "upholding his principles and making sure that what he has created is not destroyed.

There is something radically new she will bring to the housing sector: the sheer fact that she is a woman. She has a characteristically lyrical response to the suggestion that she has moved from the female realm of welfare to the male realm of housing: "It might be macho to see people building houses, putting brick on top of brick. But there's another way of looking at it. Let's look at households rather than empty houses. More than two thirds of all South African households are headed by women and the strength and the power of those households are dependent on women. The household is central to the sanity and harmony of society, and there's a woman at the centre of that household."

Mthembi-Nkondo did feel particularly judged as a woman in her last post, as deputy minister of welfare: "If you're a woman, you're expected to deliver, sometimes unfairly, in a very short space of time." Her record as deputy minister of welfare was not wildly impressive: according to those in the welfare sector, very little happened at the ministry, but they blame this on the fact that the minister, Abe Williams, is a National Party appointment, who had little interest in transforming the department and who allowed his deputy very little room to maneuver.

Despite the fact that she was trained as a diplomat, she feels very comfortable in the field of service provision; welfare or housing. She articulates a dedication that is utterly credible. Listen, for example, to a story she relates, off the cuff:

"When I first started coming back to South Africa, whenever I'd go home to Meadowlands, I'd ask someone to come with me, because I couldn't take the face of suffering that would confront me. There were twins across the road from us, who were born when I was about 12, and I used to look after them, I brought them up. Now, when I see them, I look at faces that look older than me, because of poverty, because of drink. When I first went home, I tried to find out what had happened to Ma Julia, to Ntati Simon, to Cookies. And the tape would unwind: he was stabbed when crossing from Dube station, she got shot outside the hostel, he's a hobo now. I might be a cabinet minister now, but because the rest of them in Meadowlands didn't have my opportunities, my achievement belongs to them."

Her poetry, like her fiction, deals with the themes of commitment and trust. While she lionises the heroes of the struggle --from Ruth First, an early mentor, to Oliver Tambo-- she agonises over the work expected of her as a "soldier-poet": On the one hand, "I do not have the leisure/to wander along aimless paths/ to wallow in literary art creations"; on the other, "I cannot shelve my creative instincts/until peace time ..."

Her anthology, Flames of Fury, has both the compelling rhythms and the overwrought imagery of South African struggle poetry, influenced in equal measure by the black consciousness movement of the 1970s and the Lusophone poet- revolutionaries; lines like "Flames fume fury and vengeance/ the falcon souls burn in haste" and "I know who I am/ I die in detention everyday/.../ I am my people/ my country.

There is evidence in her verse of serious talent: she implores a mother, for example, to "show scorn ... with the swoop of your backside". Perhaps, in another place and another time, Mthembi-Nkondo might have gone down in history as a competent and respected poet; a minor literary celebrity on the world beat. But she is, so quintessentially, a product of this place and this time: out of the country in 1977; into power in 1994. She might yet go down in history as a major political figure: the woman who filled Joe Slovo's shoes.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media. Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.For e-mail subscriptions, send enquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Africa News


January, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Squaring Up For The Supreme Law


LENGTH: 987 words


 

The Weekly Mail and Guardian

January 27, 1995

by Gaye Davis in Parliament

The huge task of writing the country's new constitution began in earnest this week as political parties squared up against each other in sometimes acrimonious debate, spelling out their vision for the document which will become the supreme law of the land.

Deputy President Thabo Mbeki rejected the notion of continued power-sharing entrenched in the constitution, saying the party which won the majority of votes in 1999 should form the government. Support for the ANC's position that coalitions be voluntary came from the Pan Africanist Congress' Richard Sizani.

National Party member Andre Fourie accused Mbeki of "closing the door on negotiations". In addition to entrenched power-sharing, the NP wants enshrined the principles of subsidiarity -- power devolving to the lowest level of government capable of carrying it out -- and asymmetry, where not every province gets the same powers and functions. 

The ANC wants regional and local powers subjected to what Mbeki described as "the need for national uniformity". While traditional leadership would be recognised and protected, in a democracy their demands could not take precedence. He warned against "the Balkanisation and fragmentation of the country when we discuss the devolution of powers to lower levels of government".

Consitutional Affairs Minister Roelf Meyer said continued multiparty participation at all levels and in all structures of government would prevent any abuse of power and serve the best interests of the nation as a whole.

Accusing the NP of hypocrisy, the PAC's Patricia de Lille said: "They are the very same people who used a unitary state very effectively to oppress us all these years."

The ANC wants proportional representation maintained, but has left the door open for constituencies to help close the gap between people and elected representatives.

The Freedom Front's Corne Mulder argued for Afrikaner self-determination within an area or areas where they formed the majority -- what FF leader General Constand Viljoen has called "an engine room" of Afrikaner culture with its own radio stations, schools and universities and where Afrikaans is the official language. Members of "other nations" could also live there if they chose.

An attempt by the IFP to insist that international mediation settle its regional demands -- promised to it in terms of a pre-election agreement -- and take place as part of the constitution-making process was given short shrift by the ANC's Johnny de Lange.

A committee comprising Meyer, his deputy and senior ANC negotiator, Valli Moosa, and Correctional Services Minister Sipho Mzimela has been appointed to negotiate with the IFP. De Lange said on reaching agreement they would report back to parliament, but "under no circumstances" would this process be allowed to hold up parliament or the constitutional assembly.

African Christian Democratic Party leader the Reverend Kenneth Meshoe said the constitutional principle forbidding discrimination on grounds of sexual orientation should be scrapped as it promoted homosexuality and was against family values, African culture and biblical teachings. "To build a family, Adam needed Eve, not Steve," he said.

As the parties skirmished, a huge campaign to involve the public in the process geared up. Constitutional assembly chairman Cyril Ramaphosa told the plenary session that tentative agreement had been reached with banks on printing information on bank-machine slips and supermarkets had agreed to do the same on till slips. Weekends will see constitutional assembly members addressing forums in townships, villages, informal settlements and farms. Internet surfers will also be able to dip into the constitutional debate.

Six 30-member theme committees started work this week and will hear submissions on the character of the democratic state, the structure of government, the relationship between levels of government, fundamental rights, the judiciary and specialised structures of government. Members were this week already doubting that they would meet their deadlines.

The new constitution has to be written by May 1996. Any extension would need all seven parties in the constitutional assembly agreeing to amend the interim constitution, which lays down two years for creating a new one.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media. Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.For e-mail subscriptions, send enquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Ex-spy Williamson Clashes with Pil


LENGTH: 707 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

January 27, 1995

by Stefaans Brummer

Former superspy Craig Williamson -- the one former agent that knows more than most about the "dirty tricks" of his apartheid bosses -- this week was at loggerheads with Mineral and Energy Affairs Minister Pik Botha and other National Party politicians over their handling of the police indemnities saga.

Williams warned NP politicians "not to think we have forgotten who gave us the orders". It drew a sharp response from Botha, who said Williamson was a "clown you have to be careful of". 

The former spy accused NP politicians, and in particular Botha, of betraying the security forces "which kept the Nats in power for so long".

Williamson said he was ready to take his own "sins" to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. He said he had rebuffed an approach by a police brigadier to join the 3500 policemen who applied for indemnity before April's elections as "I thought it would do more harm than good".

He said both sides to the conflict had committed crimes but charged that the difference, as illustrated by the NP's "incompetent" handling of the indemnities issue, was that the ANC "stood by its people" while NP politicians did not.

Williamson said Botha's statement before last week's cabinet meeting that no amnesty had been granted to the 3500 had left him confused. "If anybody who is in cabinet now knew what was happening then (in the apartheid years), it is Pik."

Botha said his statement had been misinterpreted; that he had never said the amnesties were invalid -- only that the courts would have to decide, which was the accepted legal "consensus" anyway.

But to Williamson's charge that he had known of "dirty tricks", Botha shot back: "He is talking nonsense." He said he had been a member of the State Security Council -- the body which co-ordinated the apartheid government's response to the "total onslaught" -- but he had "tried to stop wrong things from happening so that we would not get further sanctions against us".

Asked if that did not imply he knew about "dirty tricks", Botha said: "I did not know of 'dirty tricks'. I knew what was on the agenda of the State Security Council, but I never served on the sub-committees which had to put broad directives into action ...

Sue de Villiers, publicity officer for Justice Minister Dullah Omar, said this week that high-ranking delegations from the army and police had met Amnesty Office officials before the April elections to discuss whether their applications would be successful.

The Amnesty Office officials told them their formula, which asked for indemnity for "all actions" rather than specifying the individual applicant's offence, would not lead to automatic indemnity. De Villiers said the Defence Force delegation then announced it would not submit indemnity applications en masse.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media. Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.For e-mail subscriptions, send enquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Africa News


January, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Angola Doesn't Want SA Peacekeepers Troops South African troops are not welcome in Angolan peacekeeping operations


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

January 27, 1995

by Stefaans Brummer

South Africa will not be part of the United Nations peacekeeping operation in Angola because Angolan President Eduardo dos Santos won't play host to countries previously involved in his country's war. Zimbabwe Defence Minister Moven Mahachi this week attacked South Africa for its apparent failure to respond to requests for troops to participate in an envisaged 7 500-strong UN force to monitor Angola's tenuous peace.

At a regional peacekeeping seminar in Harare, attended by army officers of 19 African states including South Africa, Mahachi said that if South Africa failed to respond to UN requests for troops, it would cast "serious doubt on its commitment to peace". 

Zimbabwe -- whose President Robert Mugabe is reportedly keen to regain the initiative as top regional peacemaker from President Nelson Mandela -- has already promised a battalion of troops to join the UN Angola Verification Mission (Unavem) force.

South Africa has indeed been churlish, to an extent, in responding to the UN request for assistance, made by the world body when Dos Santos' Frelimo government and Jonas Savimbi's Unita rebels agreed to a ceasefire in November.

The South African position, decided by the cabinet in early December, boiled down to an agreement to be part of Unavem, but without troops in a combat role. South Africa would provide only logistic support, such as air transport and engineers, the cabinet decided.

Explained Defence Ministry publicity officer Major Muff Andersson: "It would have led to tensions in the new integrated force ... People in the South African National Defence Force used to be on different sides in Angola."

But even the engineers and the aviators, it seems, will now have to stay at home.

Andersson said: "The cabinet accepted that we cannot turn our backs on Angola. But when we got as far as drawing up plans on when we could send people and where, that's when we heard we would be unwelcome." Despite Zimbabwe's criticism, South Africa could do nothing but wait, she said. "The guests want us to go but the hosts are ambivalent. If Angola decides we are an important country to have there, we will be there. But for now, we will just stand and wait politely."

A Department of Foreign Affairs official this week said Dos Santos' stance, contained in a letter dated December 5 to UN secretary general Boutros Boutros-Gali, came to South Africa's attention only about a week later, after the cabinet had approved the limited involvement.

The official said he interpreted the letter -- which stated that countries which previously were "directly or indirectly involved in the conflict in Angola" would not be welcome as part of the Unavem force -- as meaning that a country such as Zaire, whose President Mobutu Sese Seko has backed Unita, would also not be welcome. Other countries affected by Dos Santos' exclusion may be the United States, Cuba and Russia.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media. Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.For e-mail subscriptions, send enquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English
