29 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


BURUNDI: Responding to Crisis in Burundi


LENGTH: 3054 words


 

Search for Common Ground

by John Marks

January, 1995

Summary--Sometimes a situation -- such as the prospect of genocide -- is so compelling that it demands action. In our view, this is the case in Burundi, where thousands of people have been massacred but where the killing has not reached the scale of neighboring Rwanda.

Under the terms of this program, Search for Common Ground (SCG) will work under the direction of the Bujumbura Office of the Special Representative of the UN Secretary General (UNSRSG) and in collaboration with the Council on Foreign Relations, the African American Institute, and Refugees International to carry out an integrated, multi-faceted initiative to try to prevent ethnic warfare from escalating in Burundi and to promote the process of reconciliation. The overall aim will be to work with Burundian partners in establishing a culture of negotiation and peaceful conflict resolution in Burundi.

The basic premise of the proposal is that: If Burundi cannot develop ways to resolve conflict without violence, democracy cannot possibly take hold. 

This initiative, which is similar conceptually to a comprehensive prevention project which Search for

Common Ground is currently carrying out in Macedonia, will include the following package of preventive measures: 1. Radio Reconciliation; 2. Negotiation training for high level political leaders; 3. Conflict resolution training for parliamentary leaders; 4. Conflict resolution training for the clergy; 5. Joint Hutu-Tutsi Leadership Trips to South Africa; 6. Conflict Resolution in the Schools; 7. Support for University Conflict Resolution Center; 8. Support for a Buyoya Foundation conference on reconciliation ; 9. Burundi Policy Forum

Background--Burundi is a country which has a long history of ethnic enmity and warfare between Hutus (about 85% of the population) and the long dominant Tutsis (roughly 15%). The cycle of violence persists, and numerous members of both ethnic groups have considerable blood on their hands. In the last year, tens of thousands of Burundians are estimated to have been slaughtered by members of the other ethnic group. However, despite the fact that the killing continues, the country has managed to avoid the outright holocaust that has taken place in neighboring Rwanda, a country with similar ethnic make-up, history, and geography.

In November a delegation co-sponsored by Refugees International (RI) and Search for Common Ground (SCG) visited Burundi to explore opportunities for conflict resolution and reconciliation. RI initiated the trip in order to catalyze concrete steps to help prevent future ethnic warfare -- in effect, a preventive campaign similar to SCG's current initiative in Macedonia.

Delegation members included RI President Lionel Rosenblatt, RI European representative Yvette Pierpaoli, Conflict Resolution Consultant Susan Collin Marks, a veteran of the South African peace process and presently a Fellow at the US Institute of Peace, and SCG President John Marks. Superb support for the trip was provided by the Bujumbura Office of the Special Representative of the UN Secretary General.

The delegation met with a former President, a former Prime Minister, the widow of an assassinated President, four Cabinet ministers, Parliamentary leaders, heads of Burundian and expatriate NGOs, the US Ambassador and key members of the embassy staff, USAID, USIA, OAU, National Democratic Institute (NDI) personnel, the Papal Nuncio, clergy, academics, and the two principal representatives of the UN Secretary General.

The delegation listened carefully to suggestions from Burundians and expatriates on how to advance the prospects for reconciliation and peaceful resolution of conflict and looked at each suggestion in view of experience gained in other countries. The idea was to assess which initiatives were feasible and for SCG to determine which were within its capacity to implement. The delegation made every effort to coordinate its inquiry with other NGOs, governments, and international organizations so as to avoid duplication of existing efforts. Indeed, it found that there were already in place a series of reconciliation programs with the support of the UN Secretary-General's Office, UNDP, UNESCO, UNHCR, USAID, USIA, and NDI.

Nevertheless, a series of requests for assistance were made by Burundian and expatriate groups in areas that SCG felt it could make a unique contribution. This will require sending at least one representative to Bujumbura and bringing in Francophone conflict resolution trainers and other relevant specialists as appropriate. The office of the UN Secretary-General's Special Representative has tentatively agreed to work in collaboration with the SCG project. In addition, the Center for Preventive Diplomacy of the Council on Foreign Relations and the African American Institutes will be partners in the work. Together, there will be developed a program for policy advocacy, which will include a Burundi Policy Forum which will meet monthly in Washington for NGO representatives, government officials, and international organization officials.

SCG has decided to move forward with full awareness of the tremendous complexity involved in carrying out conflict resolution and reconciliation work in Burundi. As a high international official said, "Everyone is afraid" - of domination and extermination. "I've never been in a place where fear is so rampant," added a top US official, "where people tend to blame others, and where no one takes personal responsibility." Said a Western aid worker, "There has been so much pain and suffering, they just don't deal with it. People keep it all inside and suppressed." He noted that the "conflict resolution process is foreign."

A Hutu human rights activist said that he felt the violence was abating, but "first we need justice." He stressed that individuals cannot mete out justice; "otherwise it's the law of the jungle." He noted that the legal structure was controlled by Tutsis and that there was no system for punishing the military (95% Tutsi). In the same vein, a Tutsi Cabinet Minister talked of how Hutus had in the last months murdered several close family members, and he also called for justice. It was not difficult to see how one side's justice could be the other's retribution and how there is tension between justice and reconciliation.

When asked what needed to be done to promote reconciliation, an international official said, in all seriousness, that Burundi needed "continuous brainwashing over three years through communications and media." In answer to the same question, a Burundian professor called for a strategy that convened Tutsis and Hutus for meetings and "especially doing things together." He advocated starting slowly, concentrating on the education system, and encouraging self-reliance and self-sufficiency. A Burundian woman replied that what was needed was for Burundians to learn to accept each other with all their differences. The way to do this, she said, is to push people to meet. She and several other people stressed working particularly with women because they are "sick of the fighting," they are much less likely to have participated in the fighting, and they have much less resistance to reconciliation than men. The widow of an assassinated president said that at a certain point people must say this is enough.

A former Prime Minister called for "changing the mentality" of Burundi's military so that "it is seen by the population that they play a necessary role." To help do this, she called for bringing in foreign military to share their experiences with the Burundian military. A Parliamentarian noted that "even people of good faith do not have the tools to negotiate." He noted that a role of foreigners could be "to help us to meet each other."

The delegation left Burundi with the belief that while activities aimed at promoting conflict resolution and reconciliation are important and necessary, they are only one component in a larger mosaic of measures that need to be taken to assure peace in Burundi. Burundians called for economic development, implementation of the rule of law to create a working justice system, military reform, and increased international and domestic support for the fledgling government coalition. Project Objectives--to reduce the level of ethnic tensions in Burundi and thereby reduce the likelihood of violent conflict; to build a culture of negotiation and peaceful conflict resolution in Burundi; to create and provide support to mechanisms and institutions that contribute to reconciliation and the building of democracy in Burundi.

Project Activities--1. Radio Reconciliation -- Burundi National Radio, the Minister of Communications, the UN office, and USIA offered to cooperate in producing a regular radio program -- probably an hour per day -- dedicated to promoting peace and reconciliation. The broadcasts will aim to counter "hate radios" and will be structured along the lines of South Africa's Peace Radio 2000, which SCG co-produced and which promoted values of peace, reconciliation, and an end to violence. Burundi radio will provide facilities, personnel, and broadcast time. USIS has expressed interest in making available technical assistance and programming and in organizing seminars to train rural Burundians to prepare taped reports on events in the countryside. SCG will furnish an American co-producer and experience in program content and project management.

2. Negotiation training for high level political leaders. The Office of the Special Representative of the UN Secretary General asked SCG to design and lead a three- day training program in negotiation skills for 30 Burundian political and civic leaders selected from the major political and ethnic groupings.

3. Conflict Resolution Training for Parliamentary leaders. Leaders of the two parliamentary parties, the predominantly Tutsi UPRONA and the Hutu FRODEBU, in separate meetings, asked for training in conflict resolution skills. Both agreed that they will share in joint training programs with the other. Indeed, one parliamentarian noted that the skill-building sessions will provide a "pretext" for coming together.

4. Conflict Resolution Training for Clergy. The International Bible Society requested mediation training for Protestant, Catholic, and Evangelical clergy. The purpose will be to provide these natural peace-makers with hands-on, conflict resolution skills that could be applied at the grassroots, parish level. Clergy will also be trained as trainers, so that they could further extend the outreach of the program.

5. Joint Hutu-Tutsi Leadership Trips to South Africa. The parliamentary leaders expressed interest in being able to travel to South Africa in a delegation with their opposite numbers in order to explore the South African success in transcending racial and ethnic divisions. The Office of the Special Representative of the UN Secretary General expressed interest in supporting this program and suggested that it also include military leaders. (Note: Virtually every Burundian with whom the delegation spoke expressed great interest in the South African model and provided support for the working assumption that South Africa's experience in conflict resolution and reconciliation is probably the one most applicable to Burundi.)

6. Conflict Resolution in the School. A Burundian educator requested through USIS support for curriculum development and training that will make possible the introduction of conflict resolution and peace education in Burundian schools. The UN would be interested in providing and distributing materials in Burundi.

7. Support for a University Conflict Resolution Center. A professor at Burundi University requested support for the development of a Center for Conflict Resolution which would be under joint Hutu-Tutsi leadership. Such a center would provide an academic base for training and research in conflict resolution.

8. Support for a Buyoya Foundation Conference on Reconciliation. Former President Pierre Buyoya and NDI requested assistance in designing and facilitating a conference early in 1995 entitled "The Process of Reconciliation." SCG will also assist in identifying appropriate southern African participants who will be asked to communicate their experiences in conciliation and nation-building.

9. Burundi Policy Forum. Under the direction of Barnett Rubin, Director of the Council on Foreign Relations' Center for Preventive Diplomacy, the Burundi Policy Forum will be convened once a month in Washington. Present will be representatives of government agencies, international organizations, and NGOs working on Burundi. The purpose will be to exchange information, promote cooperation, coordinate programs, and catalyze policy initiatives which might contribute to conflict resolution and reconciliation in Burundi.

Evaluation Plan--The project's impact on Burundi will be felt through increased dialogue and cooperation between the country's ethnic communities and gradual resolution of the controversies that divide them. SCG staff and partner organizations will regularly confer with their local partners to gauge the efficacy of our methods and approaches. Specific means of evaluation will include: participants in all workshops and training sessions will be requested to complete a questionnaire designed to assess the relevance of the materials presented and the effectiveness of the presentation. The responses will be analyzed and used to improve future programs. Follow- up interviews of selected workshop participants will be conducted to identify specific examples in which the skills learned were successfully applied to conflict situations.

Organizational Background--Search for Common Ground is an independent, non-profit organization dedicated to finding workable solutions to divisive national and international problems. Established in 1982, SCG applies the most advanced techniques of conflict resolution, negotiation, facilitation, and collaborative problemThe Initiative for Peace and Cooperation in the Middle East, initiated in 1991 to encourage comprehensive solving to a broad range of disputes. The organization's current international programs include: approaches to Middle East peace and security; Search for Common Ground in Macedonia, a comprehensive project to help prevent ethnic warfare in Macedonia; Common Ground Productions, SCG's television division, Common Ground Productions, whose series and programs have been broadcast in Russia, South Africa, Macedonia and the United States Search for Common Ground in Russia, which works to adapt Western experiences in conflict management and collaborative problem-solving to Russian society, especially labor- management relations. John Marks, who is President of Search for Common Ground, will provide overall direction to the project. Bryan Rich, who has worked for Common Ground Productions for the last two years in Russia and Macedonia, will direct SCG operations in Burundi. David Shorr, Washington Director of SCG's Ethnic Conflict Resolution Project, will oversee the project's Washington activities. Susan Collin Marks, currently a Peace Fellow at the US Institute of Peace and a veteran of five years in the South African Peace Process, will serve as an unpaid consultant. Dr. Barnett Rubin, Director of Center for Preventive Diplomacy of the Council on Foreign Relations, will direct his organization's

Contact: Search for Common Ground, 1601 Connecticut Avenue, NW, Suite 200, Washington, DC 20009. Tel.

(202) 265-4300 Fax: (202) 232-6718


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

by the Africa Policy Information Center

* On the Foreign Affairs Commitee in the last Congress, but not on the Africa Subcommittee

** On the Africa Subcommittee in the last Congress

Note and Request: A high proportion of the Subcommitee members, in both the Senate and the House, are new to African issues. Many, particularly on the Republican side in the House, are also new to Congress this year. In addition, all members of Congress face serious time pressures to deal with a multitude of issues. How much attention the Subcommittee members devote to Africa, and what views they advocate, will be highly influenced not only by their personal sympathies and ideological perspectives, but also by what they are hearing from relevant constituencies.

Priority states for building constituencies to educate Africa Subcommitee members and pressure them to take African concerns seriously are thus Kansas (1 Senator, 1 Representative), Wisconsin (1 Senator, 1 Representative), Florida (3 Representatives), New York (2 Representatives) and Maine, Missouri, and California (1 Senator each). Priority Congressional districts are indicated above for each Representative.

Among actions that would be appropriate for anyone concerned about a U.S. Africa policy responsive to African concerns:

(1) Pass on this update, particularly to Africa- concerned individuals and groups in the relevant states and Congressional districts.

(2) If you know of individuals or groups, again particularly in the relevant states and Congressional districts, who would be interested in receiving occasional short material on Africa policy and advocacy via email, please send, or ask them to send, their email addresses to woa@igc.apc.org.

Thanks to the Association of Concerned Africa Scholars (ACAS) for assistance in quickly compiling this list.

This material is made available by the Washington Office on Africa (WOA) and the Africa Policy Information Center (APIC). WOA is a not-for-profit church, trade union and civil rights group supported organization that works with Congress on Africa-related legislation. APIC is WOA's educational affiliate.

To receive basic information with a list of publications send a blank email message to woawoa@igc.apc.org. The address for an automatic response is *not* the same as for other substantive messages, info@igc.apc.org. (Note: Do *not* use the "reply" function in your mail program, which will send your message to which should be sent to woa@igc.apc.org. Please be patient on responses to other queries.)

For additional information: Washington Office on Africa 110 Maryland Ave. NE, #112 Washington, DC

20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. Email: woa@igc.apc.org.

31 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


U.S./AFRICA: Document: Memorandum to President Bill Clinton


LENGTH: 2800 words


 

by The Joint Ministry in Africa of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) and the United Church of Christ

January 10, 1995

We are sending you this memorandum as concerned citizens and people of faith. The reason for our correspondence is to request that you reconsider the current direction of your administration's foreign policy toward Africa.

Two years ago you became the first post Cold War President of the United States. We congratulated you on your election. For millions of people, 1992 represented a time of hope and anticipation, a chance to break out of the shackles of history and a bi-polar world. Your election to the highest and most powerful public office in the United States represented a grand historic moment- one which offered an opportunity to transform US foreign aid programs, human rights policy, the United Nations and international economic priorities. 

It was in this context, a time of genuine excitement about a new beginning, that the Joint Ministry in Africa sent you a twelve page memorandum on November 20, 1992 (SEE attached addendum).

The Joint Ministry in Africa represents the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) and the United Church of Christ to more than 40 African partner churches, secular bodies of Christian councils. Our two denominations have a combined membership of over 2.5 million people.

In 1992 you "called for a new strategy of American engagement to encourage the spread and consolidation of democracy abroad." You said that this meant "opposing political oppression across Africa as firmly as we oppose political oppression in Asia and the Middle East. And it means providing support to the victims of war in Liberia and Somalia...In Africa, as elsewhere, the Bush administration has been tepid- when it should have been decisive- in ending aid to dictators, such as Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire." You also proposed that "Our top priority must be to foster democracy...ensure that the assistance we provide truly benefits Africans...(and) support measures to strengthen UN peacekeeping capabilities."

According to our partner churches and friends in Africa your encouraging words promised a break from a past of "politics as usual" and gave a breath of fresh air to democrats and proponents of justice throughout the continent.

When Secretary of State Warren Christopher declared that the future of Africa lies "not with corrupt dictators like Mobutu, but with courageous democrats", our hopes, and those of many others, seemed to be moving toward reality.

Our 1992 memorandum urged your new administration to vigorously pursue a democratic and human rights agenda across Africa. Surveying the past two years, we acknowledge that your administration has taken some positive steps. We commend you for; recognizing the elected government of Angola; supporting democratization in Mozambique and South Africa; signing into law the Conflict Resolution Act; providing humanitarian assistance to African nations; sending a high level diplomat to investigate the human rights situation in Sudan; criticizing the Nigerian dictatorship; and holding the first ever Presidential conference on Africa.

But there are many areas where we are frustrated and disappointed. Your administration seems to be operating without a coherent Africa policy and, perhaps worse, without any convictions of creativity. The U.S. currently seems to meander from one crisis to another; neither learning from the past, nor seeking out new fresh voices that look to the future. With embassies, consulates and AID offices closing in several places, development funds subject to severe cuts, and diminished concerns about human rights, malign neglect seems to be the U.S.'s main policy toward the poorest continent in the world. This policy appears, from our standpoint, to be motivated by a desire to ensure commercial and political interests over human ones.

In Zaire, we are distressed that, against the wishes of the democratic Sovereign National Conference, you applauded the appointment of long-time Mobutu ally Kengo wa Dondo as Prime Minister. In Rwanda, although he U.S. has been supplying important humanitarian aid, it was a policy of omission by your administration and others that allowed ethnic tensions to escalate to genocide.

In Western Sahara, the democratic aspirations of the Sahrawi people have been ignored. Instead, the U.S. continues to work with the occupying Moroccan state.

Unfortunately, it is not only in specific countries that a historic opportunity for reform has been lost. Africa continues to suffer from the effects of structural adjustment programs (SAPs), which, according to UNICEF, OXFAM, UK, the UN Africa Recovery, African churches and grassroots organizations are gutting social services, stagnating economies, and worsening the debt burden of the poor. These programs, designed in part to secure debt payments, are implemented under pressure from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank- two institutions that the U.S. has great influence over. SAPs are leading, according to friends, churches and people of faith on the ground, to declining school attendance and health care, malnutrition and unemployment. What we most often hear is that average people have little say in the policies that are so terribly affecting them.

Moreover, many people ask: what validity do elections have if the platforms many governments are elected on are subject to vetoes by the IMF and World Bank?

Africa's debt now stands at almost $300 billion a year, more than its gross domestic product (GDP). Every year, according to the United Nations(UN), billions of dollars flow out of the continent in debt payments. This money could, if redirected, go to infrastructure, health care, education, eradication of diseases, and jobs. Since the U.S. remains the major actor in the United Nations, the IMF and World Bank, there is much constructive leadership that could still be provided on your part.

We believed that your election opened the door to this kink of leadership and to the possibility of significant reforms in the U.S. government, and international bodies, less secretive and dependent on Cold War legacies and ideologies, and more committed to grassroots organizations, participation, and public input. Given your many campaign statements on TV about remaking government and its institutions, we expected that you might advocate for the transformation of the IMF and the World Bank into democratic and accountable institutions. We also hoped that similar reforms might take place in the U.S.'s various foreign aid programs (particularly within the U.S. Agency for International Development)- beset by many of the same problems regarding accountability and lack of participation found in the large international multi-lateral institutions.

Instead your administration appears to be operating in a vacuum- providing almost no creative, innovative or new ideas on how to deal with Africa's challenges or general foreign policy direction. Consequently, the hopes of millions of people for working with the U.S. and other countries on positive alternatives to debt and structural adjustment have turned to despair. Many Africans say that their world is worse than it was two years ago, on the eve of your inauguration. This situation is partially a result of the U.S.'s abdication from providing practical and moral international leadership.

The financial hemorrhage that is afflicting Africa leads to unemployment, disaffection and eventually to conflict. It will be much more costly to deal with these problems later (e.g. Rwanda) rather than if the U.S., the UN, and others play a preventive role that deals with the root causes of problems. One of your top aides recently acknowledged this thesis when he said, "Nations are being challenged to look beyond crises to the underlying causes of (problems). Unemployed, sick and angry populations can, and often do, lead to conflict, dictators and demagogues.

In 1992, one of the strongest premises of your campaign was to focus on jobs and growth. Many factors could obviously go into making this happen. However, weak foreign markets (diminished by debt and declining standards of living brought on by SAPs), such as Africa's, work against jobs for Americans. One study estimates that 20,000 US jobs are being lost yearly as a result of IMF and World Bank loans and SAPs. We are reminded by what another one of your key policy advisors said in 1992: "foreign policy and domestic policy can no longer be divorced."

In a related matter, we recall that during your campaign you repeatedly said that you would seek fair trade agreements that would benefit labor and the environment. Yet, by your administration's support for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade(GATT), without significant changes from your predecessor, Africans, labor and environmentalists will have little say in the new and secretive World Trade Organization (WTO). In economic terms, the Organization for Economic Cooperation(OECD) estimates that by the year 2002 Africa will be losing $2.6 billion a year as a result of GATT.

A trade agreement that included at least a minimum base of environmental, social and economic standards might help everyone. Such an agreement could begin with the European Community's Social Charter as a possible model. Your election represented an opportunity to mold a bold new vision, together with citizen movements around the world, for fair and just trade. With Congress just beginning it's work on implementing GATT, your administration still has time to reconsider how the treaty is carried out or, even under its current guise, whether it is implemented at all.

Foreign aid is another area where positive reform seemed within reach in 1992. Unfortunately, what you started now appears mired in special interest politics, far away from the lofty goals you once professed for moving foreign aid toward sustainable, participatory development- and for remaking government in the interests of greater popular participation.

What disappoints us most about your administration to date is its lack of vision and ideas. Without these there can be no hope, and certainly little reform. By failing in these areas, a leadership vacuum has been created which is increasingly being filled by conservative and anti-aid, anti-democratic, and anti-international actors. What concerns us even more is that in place of convictions we are witnessing political expediency-whereby human rights, democracy and economic justice are sacrificed on the alter of compromise with the very forces who opposed much of what you stood for in your campaign.

More than two years into your administration, we hear human rights people telling us that things were better under President Bush. In Kenya, where the U.S. embassy played a constructive role in 1990 and 1991, an opposition party member recently said that our embassy is now irrelevant to the democratization struggle here." Grassroots people and church folk inform us that for them they see little difference, in economic or political terms, now than during the Cold War- even that things may have gotten worse. We regularly speak with Africanists and Africans who tell us that all they see today from the U.S. is continuity and Cold War holdovers in the State Department. Instead of global economic opportunity, participation and new directions, we see in Africa declining living standards, more debt and SAPs.

Obviously the U.S. cannot solve all the world's problems by itself but as the major global superpower it can play a critical role in mobilizing resources, providing programmatic leadership and supporting a positive moral climate. Unfortunately, today many people say that with your administration hope for these things has been lost.

The question for us is: what distinguishes your administration from its predecessors?

When we sent you our memorandum in 1992, we did so because you were elected on a broad platform of change, one that appeared to separate you from the past and laid out a positive, democratic vision for the future. The United States, we thought, help might bring in a new era for a new time. Your platform talked of jobs, democracy, reform, and human rights. It is these basic, decent things that you stood for that we are now challenging you to return to.

We imagine that you might use your good offices as an educational pulpit where you can take stands for:

-equitable, sustainable and democratic multi-lateral institutions;

-foreign aid that is participatory, supportive of people at the base, democratic and de-linked from Cold War legacies.

-debt write-offs for low income nations (especially in Africa where bilateral and multi-lateral loans prevail);

-a GATT that involves fair trade practices and that seeks to raise environmental standards and working and living conditions;

-a stronger UN that is able to better respond to international humanitarian/conflict crises;

-moral and financial support for African peacekeeping initiatives; and

-a human rights policy that is consistent, and that places democracy and justice above commerce.

Finally, we would like to encourage you to seek out non-official and alternative voices and sources for information on Africa. There are a lot of creative, democratic people in the world who are hot heard but who offer many ideas for the challenges we have raised here. It would be our pleasure to facilitate any such contacts or to send you resources. We pray that in these next months, you will see that there is still time to act on behalf of Africa, and regain the foreign policy initiative that you so promisingly began two years ago.

Thank you.

Prepared by the Joint Ministry in Africa of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) and the United Church of Christ, 475 Riverside Drive, 16th Floor, New York, NY 10115-0109. Tel: 212 870-2834 Fax: 212 932-1236


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


32 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


U.S./AFRICA: Document: House Africa Subcommittee


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 374 words


 

by Congresswoman Ileana Ros-Lehtinen

January 11, 1995

The following is a prepared statement by the new chairwoman of the Africa subcommittee of the International Relations Committee in the U.S. House of Representatives, Ileana Ros-Lehtinen. The Republican Congresswoman from Florida assumed the post from Harry Johnston, a Florida Democract, following the Republican takeover of Congress which gives that party all committee and subcommittee chairmanships. 

Born in Cuba in 1951, Ros-Lehtinen came to the United States with her parents after Fidel Castro took power. A former school administrator, she she won her seat representing Miami in Congress in 1988.

"We plan to determine what are the U.S. priorities in Africa as they relate to the U.S. national interest, and to monitor to what extent the Clinton Administration and U.S. agencies are pursuing them.

"The subcommittee will also review the role of U.S. intervention in internal domestic conflicts, and their resolution, as well as review what role if any, the U.S. should play in relief operations. Moreover, the subcommittee will look at U.S. trade and investment opportunities in Africa by working with the different agencies and business organisations both in the U.S. and Africa.Africa, like much of the world, is undergoing great changes.

"The U.S. must do all it can to assure that these changes lead to the expansion of democracy and free markets in the region. Human rights has been a long-standing concern for me and we hope to focus on problem areas in order to improve the situation.

"There are some shining lights in Africa -- countries that are firmly on the road to democratic reform, human rights, and free markets -- but many countries, unfortunately, are still far from getting on that road."


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


33 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January, 1995


Music Is My Mission: An Interview with Joseph Shabalala


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 2120 words


 

Ladysmith Black Mambazo, the South African acappella singers, are on a winter tour of the United States before beginning rehearsals for an original play by the group's lead singer, Joseph Shabalala, that will open in Chicago this spring. Ladysmith is a friends and family group, which includes brothers and cousins and fathers and sons performing and traveling together. Africa News Service caught up with them at the beginning of the tour in Washington, D.C., where they appeared on National Public Radio's call-in show "Talk of the Nation." Tamela Hultman of Africa News spoke with Joseph Shabalala.

AN: Being on tour sounds to many people as though it would be a glamorous affair, but I know it is extremely hard work. How do you cope with the pressures?

Shabalala: Because we are a group, we are always together and we practice together; it's not as tough as for other people because we are full time in music -- we always practice. But it is different than home, you miss home. 

AN: You travel a lot, though, so you're missing home much of the time.

Shabalala: You do but you feel like you must go (perform), because you are just like a preacher, like a teacher. You must go, because we have something for the people that we call our gift from God. That's why we love people to come and see us!

AN: So you're saying your music is a kind of mission?

Shabalala: Exactly. A mission. In fact, this type of music -- the nature of this group Lady Smith Black Mambazo -- is to spread our culture and its tradition, to encourage our musicians and composers that their music should remain as close as possible to their roots. Many times they think maybe they must be imitating other people instead of sharing their own gifts. Ladysmith Black Mambazo are like teachers, to share this culture that is our gift all over the world.

AN: How much time do you spend performing at home in South Africa?

Shabalala: Since 1986, the time when we started to tour with Paul Simon, it looks like the demand in other places was more than at home. At that time people at home were angry and they have no time to do things to promote this type of music. Working together with Paul Simon we met a lot of people who love our harmony, and it means that now we work more outside than home. Now everything is settling at home; we can go back home and spend more time with our people there.

AN: How do you answer the people who say Paul Simon took your music and exploited it for his own benefit?

Shabalala: Paul Simon used our music, yes. This kind of music is meant to be used by many people. Paul Simon used our music, but he helped us in so many ways, he became our friend. Because of him our music is known in this country, all over the world.

AN: Many people see Africa as a continent where everyone is hopeless and everything is hopeless, because so much of the news coming from Africa seems to be bad. Yet many Africans feel that this is a very hopeful time. How do you feel about the future in South Africa?

Shabalala: Everybody has to have hope. I'm a person who has hope all the time. Even from the beginning, people were asking me questions about South Africa and I told them that South Africa would be an example to the world. As the leader of my group, I had to show my trust. If I am angry or if I hate, I will spread anger and hate. But if I love, the group will spread love.

What happened to South Africa was unbelievable. It was just like a miracle. Now it is easier than before to have hope. We know we must come together and work together and conquer difficulties together. We forget about hate. That is why we have a song mentioning all the South African (political) organizations, to tell them that the way to conqueror is to come together, especially when you are a leader of a group. If the leaders are angry, everything will be destroyed.

AN: Can music be a healing force?

Shabalala: Exactly! That's exactly what my people used to say. They said we have a healing voice. And I agree with them because, from the beginning, I feel like God was asking me to send this harmony to the people to heal them. It healed me first, and then I went to the people.

AN: I know that in Natal, your home area in South Africa, everybody sings for every occasion -- or for no occasion! So it's not unusual for a person like yourself to sing. But did you know very early in your life that you had a special musical gift, even among a people who are always singing?

Shabalala: No. Because, you see, according to our tradition, when you sing, you are just singing for the people, just to entertain yourselves. You are not thinking about singing all over the world. We used to have song competitions, and maybe you would be standing for your region, or maybe for your father and mother, to make them proud. But finally we know that this is something different than tradition, that this is a voice of healing for all the people.

AN: And you say that now you see opportunities growing for you within South Africa?

Shabalala: Yes, exactly, you are exactly right. This is the time to go back home and talk to my people with my music. We have so many dreams. I feel like we must establish something, we must build something to keep the music alive, to preserve the music.

AN: You mentioned before we began the interview that you dream of establishing an academy to preserve South African music.

Shabalala: I think this is my last dream! I was thinking that my dream is over now, because I've taken this music all over the world.

But then it came to me that we need a school. That's why we found somebody to be a fund raiser for us here in America. There are trustees at home. We are trying to raise funds to build this academy to teach traditional music, not only for Zulus, not only for Xhosas or Ndebeles but for every tradition, for every culture in our country.

That is the only way to conquer this hatred: to be proud to follow the footsteps of your ancestors and the wisdom of the ancient cultures. Instead of fighting each other, we will learn from each other!

AN: As South Africa has become more urban, has some of the tradition of inter-weaving music through daily life been lost? Is that already happening?

Shabalala: Exactly. People used to say we have the music called "township jive," that this is our music. But that type of music is influenced by the western music, and we have many things like that. This is why people in South Africa are happy about Ladysmith Black Mambazo, happy we have young guys in the group, because we go deep down to water the roots of the indigenous music. Otherwise the music of our tradition will vanish, and eventually we will end up in a vacuum. It's better to build the school and make our children to be proud of what they are.

AN: How have black South Africans been able to maintain such a strong culture through all the years of difficulty?

Shabalala: It's because South Africans respect traditional wisdom; it's a pillar of life. To respect it doesn't mean that you are stupid, that you always do things in old ways. But South African people keep the culture, because they respect their grandmother, mother, father, uncle, who have preserved the culture. Otherwise it would be something gone long time ago.

AN: So the strong family structure is a part of the source of the culture's strength?

Shabalala: Exactly.

AN: Talk a little bit about your own family.

Shabalala: My father was a herbalist and my mother was a diviner. Those are the people who are working with spirits all the time. They depend on and trust their dreams. And from that time up until now, I dreamed of music. I was very happy when my children grew up and finished at school and they liked to come and join the group. From their childhood I was teaching them the music, but I knew that I was just teaching them because they are young. So I was very happy when they decide to come and join Black Mambazo. Even myself, with the music I was respecting my father, working with him when he was grinding his medicine and singing there. Because that is the way he believed, that when he sings beautiful songs and he is grinding that medicine, that medicine would do what he wants it to do.

AN: So you don't just grind the medicine; you have to do it in the proper spirit?

Shabalala: Yes, exactly, you're right. I'm afraid of medicine -- it's a little bit bitter -- but my music is sweet.

**************************************************************************

Ladysmith Black Mambazo is appearing in the following cities during the rest of their winter tour in the United States.

FEBRUARY45 1- Boulder, Colorado
3- Santa Fe, New Mexico
4- Scottsdale, Arizona
7- San Fransisco, California
8- Fresno, California

21- Princeton New Jersey
22- West Chester, Pennsylvania
23- New York City, New York
24- Meadville, Pennsylvania
25- Worcester, Massachussetts
26- Cambridge, Massachussetts
28- Lawrence, Kansas

In March, the group goes to Chicago to begin rehearsal for a play that will open on April 9.

EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 2754 words


 

Position Opening: African Studies. Applications are invited for Director of the University of Florida's Center for African Studies. The Center is a flourishing, multidisciplinary, nationally and internationally recognized center of excellence. The Director provides intellectual leadership and direction in sustaining, organizing, and further developing a dynamic program. Applicants must have international standing as a senior Africanist scholar, established contacts with relevant institutions, active research interests in Africa, administrative experience, and demonstrated fundraising skills. Salary negotiable. Discipline open. Applications should be received by March 31,1995. Send letter of intent, CV, and names of three references to: Professor Azim Nanji, Center for African Studies, 427 Grinter Hall, University of Florida, Gainesville FL 32611-5560. E-mail: nanji@africa.ufl.edu. The University is an EEO/AA/ADA employer.

Vacancy Announcement: Associate Director for Legislative Affairs. The Washington Office on Africa(WOA), a lobbying organization, works on issues affecting grassroots African interest throughout the continent. The WOA Educational Fund has been transformed into the Africa Policy Information Center (APIC), also with a continent-wide mandate.

WOA seeks an Associate Director for Legislative Affairs. Responsibilities include:

developing, in consultation with the Executive Director, staff and Board of Directors, the organization's annual legislative priorities; developing the organization's overall legislative strategy and representing the organization as spokesperson. 

Duties include contacts and confers with Members of Congress and other holders of public office to persuade them to support appropriate legislation by the organization by performing the following duties;contacts individuals and groups, including members of the broad Africa advocacy community, churches, trade unions, community groups and others having similar interests, both at the national and local levels, in order to encourage them also to contact legislators and present views; prepares news releases and informational pamphlets and conducts news conferences to state organizational views and to inform the public of proposed legislation considered desirable or undesirable; plans and coordinates meetings between members and elected officials to discuss legislative issues and proposals; contacts various governmental agencies and testifies at public hearings to enlist support for legislative interests; and attends and represents the organization at various meeting, hearings and other public gatherings.

Supervisory responsibilities includes managing interns and is responsible for the overall direction, coordination, and evaluation of the legislative unit. Educational Requirements: Either advanced degree (M. A.) with some Capitol Hill experience or four to ten years experience in grassroots organizing, citizen advocacy training, or campaign organizing. Candidates should have a strong background in Africa-related issues.

Salary Range: $27,000 to $35,000, depending upon experience. Closing Date: February 28, 1995. Interested Candidates should submit a resume, writing sample and reference list, by mail or fax, to: The Washington Office on Africa, 110 Maryland Avenue, N.E., Suite 112, Washington, D.C. 20002 Fax: (202) 546-1545. Each applicant will be provided background material on the Washington Office on Africa. No inquiries on the position by telephone or email will be accepted.

This announcement is distributed by the Washington Office on Africa (WOA). WOA is a not-for-profit church, trade union and civil rights group supported organization that works with Congress on Africa-related legislation. To receive basic information on WOA and its educational affiliate, the Africa Policy Information Center (APIC), with a list of publications, send a blank email message to woawhich will send info@igc.apc.org. (Note: Do *not* use the "reply" function in your mail program, your message to woa@igc.apc.org. The address for an automatic response is *not* the same as for other substantive messages, which should be sent to woa@igc.apc.org. Please be patient on responses to other queries.)

International Medical Corps (IMC), provides emergency medical relief and healthcare services in regions devastated by war and catastrophe where health services are scarce. IMC combines training with relief assistance, and effectively rehabilitates healthcare systems and restores them to self-sufficiency. IMC is currently seeking the following: Primary Health Care Trainer. Will teach and train local health care providers in basic public health issues; basic sanitation, theory of disease causation and treatment and prevention; community nutrition; teach techniques for the identification of the malnourished child treatment and growth monitoring; child immunization theory and rational and EPI support; identification of complications in pregnancy. Three years public health nursing experience, preferably with at least one year of experience in lower income, disadvantage setting or developing country experience. Teaching and tropical medicine experience very desirable. Six month commitment.

Field Coordinator - (April 1, 1995) To design future activities in Southern Sudan; must have administrative and some financial skills; able to provide leadership to the staff in Tambura; manage and coordinate all projects activities to include recruitment of local staff, procurement, accounting and all other functions of the projects; prepare monthly and quarterly reports for headquarters; responsible for all security issues for the site; two years of developing country experience; excellent interpersonal and decision making skills; clinical background along with public health experience desirable. Six month commitment.

Physician - (opening April 1,1995) Will be a team member who will address the continuing education of the medical assistant and assists with the OPD department and specialty clinics. Prepare and present education programs and materials for the local staff. Two years developing country experience desired; knowledge of tropical medicine; Six month commitment. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided.

IMC is currently seeking the following for its Emergency Response Trauma and Casualty program in Rwanda: Family Practice Physician - To provide some hands on care for the local population. Provide training and mentoring to the local health care providers, teaching experience helpful. Assist and support the Rwandan medical and nursing staff in their provision of health care, prepare and present education programs and materials for medical and nursing staff. Enhance the clinical skills and theoretical knowledge of counterpart staff by education through collaborative practice; formulate practice guidelines, standards of care and quality assurance guidelines. Two years of developing experience desired; knowledge of tropical medicine; must be fluent French speaker; six month commitment.

Site Managers - Kibungo & Butare: Must have administrative and some financial skills. Able to provide leadership to team members assigned to the site. Provide and monitor appropriate security for IMC personnel and property; acts as principle radio contact for site; acts as IMC representative to local government authorities; submit procurement requests; maintain inventory controls; submits monthly financial, inventory and narrative reports on administrative operations; two to three years experience in management, administrative and logistic experience in a developing or distressed country; health program experience is preferred; excellent interpersonal and representational skills a must; demonstrated ability to build a cohesive team and achieve goals through team work; able to work independently under stress. Six to nine month commitment. Fluent French desirable.

*EPI Coordinator - (opening April 1,1995) Manage administrative functions of the EPI Program in Baidoa Somalia. Design, set-up and conduct EPI coverage survey; maintain statistical data; assist EPI program local staff with the developing of training materials; design and conduct EPI coverage; knowledge of EPI in a developing country; experience working under adverse working conditions with limited resources; assist in the selection and training of qualified local program field staff; supervise the field activities of the program participants and provide overall direction, motivation and guidance for staff; two years developing country experience. Twelve month commitment.

Midwife - Registered Nurse with a degree or certificate in Midwifery; one year experience in maternal or primary health care programs in a developing country; prior Traditional Birth Attendant (TBA) training experience; ability to manage and motivate the local staff; excellent decision-making skills; work with local health authorities; must be able to work independently under very difficult conditions. Six month commitment.

Director, International Programs, New York, NY. Population Communications International seeks individual to work closely with President and Executive Vice President and PCI's overseas associates in the development, implementation and monitoring of PCI's mass media communications programs. Entertainment-education serial dramas on radio and television are on the air or under development in: Mexico, Brazil, Kenya, Tanzania, South Africa, India, Pakistan, the Philippines and China. Applicants should be available to travel extensively, have knowledge and experience in overseas population development work, and in mass media communications, preferably in overseas settings. Also required: excellent writing skills; ability to work with wide variety of people from various cultures and at high levels in government and non-governmental settings; ability to be persuasive and to secure agreements and acceptance of cooperative action; and ability to preserve in the face of frequent inefficiencies and setbacks expected in less developed situations. Salary up to $90,000, depending on experience. Resume and cover letter to: David O. Poindexter, President, PCI, 777 United Nations Plaza, New York, NY 10017.

Micro Enterprise Specialist, Philadelphia, PA. OIC International, an American PVO based in Philadelphia, PA, seeks a Micro Enterprise Specialist. The position will require at least 1 extended trip per quarter to affiliate programs in several African countries and to other locations where there are OIC programs. Individual must have a Masters Degree in Business Administration with emphasis in Accounting. 5+ years experience in community development work and knowledge of various Micro Credit Systems required. Individual must also be bilingual in English and French. Competitive salary and benefits plan is offered. Send resume with salary requirements to the Human Resources Officer of OIC International, 240 West Tulpehocken Street, Philadelphia, PA 19144, USA.

Regional Specialist Africa, Davis, CA. Freedom from Hunger, a non-profit international development organization working in Africa and Latin America, seeks Regional Specialist, Africa. Responsibilities include: management assistance and administrative support the programs in Burkina Faso, Ghana, Mali, and Uganda, and possibly other countries in Africa; respond to daily administrative needs; assist in preparation of plans and budgets; write, review and manage proposals, reports, and communication with institutional partners for field programs. Requires: Master's degree (MPH, international administration, or related field) or equivalent relevant experience: 2 years of administrative experience; excellent oral and written skills in English and French. Development experience in Africa is highly desirable. Willingness to travel 40% to Africa is required. Salary range $24K-32K. Start April 1995. Resume by March 15: Manager, Human Resources, FFH, PO Box 2000, Davis, CA 95617; fax 916/758-6241.

Resident Financial Advisor, Uganda. The Foundation for International Community Assistance (FINCA), which promotes self-sufficiency through credit programs for women in developing countries, seeks a Resident Financial Advisor for a 3 year assignment to Uganda. Duties: project implementation to include the development of Accounting, MIS and Human Resource Management systems. Requires: MBA; 5-10 years executive experience with successful financial institutions; experience in institution building; and working experience with USAID contracts. PREFERS: experience in microcredit programs. Send resume to FINCA, Attn: International Programs Director, 901 King Street, 4th floor, Alexandria, VA 22314; fax: 703/836- 5366.

Program Director, New York, NY. Lutheran World Relief seeks Program Director for Africa based in New York. Responsible for project monitoring and documentation, supervision of regional offices, partner relationships. MA or equivalent in related field, 5+ years work in Africa, fluency in French, good communication skills travel required. Application deadline February 28. Send resume and relevant writing sample to: Manager, Human resources, Lutheran World relief, 390 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10016; fax: 212/213-6081.

Africa News


February, 1995


RESOURCES


LENGTH: 1520 words


 

The Reebok Human Rights Programs Invites Nominations for a candidate for the 1995 Reebok Human Rights Award. In addition to a $25, 000 grant, the Reebok Human Rights Award brings national and international attention to the recipient's work, giving moral support and personal encouragement to the recipient as well.

Past Reebok Human Rights Award recipients have worked on manyu different issues includding violence, immigration, torture, hunger, abancioned street children, indentured servitude, racism, and indigenous rights. For example: A 29- year -old advocate for the rights of battered women in the U.S. created awareness of the human rights aspect of domestic vioolence by documenting the severity of the violence and creating a network of volunteers. A 25-year-old activist working with bonded laborers in agriculture received an honor from the King of Nepal and gained government recognition for is organization and for the issue of bonded labor. A 30- year-old former migrant workers first hand, became a legal aide workding for the rights of migrant farmers in Florida. A 24-year-old children's rights activist protected Guatemala's street children from police brutality and the dangers of life on the streets. Award candidates must be 30 years of age or younger, must not advocate violence or belong to an organization that advocates violence, and must be working n a human rights issue as defined by the United Nations Universal Declaraton of Human Rights. Write for a nomination packet which detaild the Award criteria and the nomination requirements. They will also accept nominations submitted on the internet. The deadline for applications is March 31, 1995. Send to : The Reebok Human Rights award, 100 Technology Center Drive, Stoughton, MA 02072, Internet: human.rights@reebok.com

The Fourth Annual U.S. African Sister Cities Conference will be held in kDakar, Senegal June 19-26, 1995. The D.C.-Dakar Capital Cities Friencship Council, Inc. (D.C.-Dakar) is coordinating the confernece. This will mark the first time that the annual conference will be ocnvened on African soil. The 1992 and 1993 conferences were held in Washington, D. C. and the 1994 conference was held in Mansfield, Ohio.

Initial responses from counterpart councils across the U.S. have indicated that approximately 300 American participants will attend, along with approximately another 300 from the African Sister Cities. The participants will represent African Sister Cities Councils, Federal, State and Local Governments, Non-Governments Organisations(NGO's), Businesses, National and International Health and Environment Organizations, and University Health and Environment Organizations, and University Health and Environment students and professionals.

Sister Cities International is a national, non-profit volunteer membership organization of U.S. communities linked globally to promote lasting friendship throough a variety of programs. Since inception as a people-to-people project lauched by President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1956, the organization has assisted more than 1,034 U.S. cities, representing more than 125 million Americans, linked with 1,743 foreign cities in 114 nations. Seventy-six (76) U.S. cities have linked with 84 cities in 29 African countries.

The theme of the Conference is "Business Opportunities in Africa: Focus on Health and Environment." The objectives of the conferenc is to exchange information between U.S. and African Sister Cities; to focus attention on health needs in Africa and initiate a plan for reduction of environmental factors that create health hazards and diseases; to foster relationships between our health and environment professionals and organizations; to promote business and trade opportunities and to encourage tourism.

Conference resoruce persons will discuss issues such as: advances in research and technology, programs for training and daily proctice, strategies for invloving youth in development projects, trade opportunities in providing supplies in equipment which support research , development and practical applications.

Key health areas will include malaria, clean water, pre-natal and child care, AIDS, African pharmacopeia, rural health, river blindness, and holistic approaches which focus on traditional African perspectives.

Key environmental issues on the agenda will be techniques for recycling or destroying materials, disposal of used medical supplies, alternaltive energy sources for rural clinical facilities, and strategies for controlling desertification.

Key business topics will highlight export/import regulations, investment incentives, industrial enterprise zones, project financing, and discussions with senior officials and potential joint venture partners.

Other events in the framework of the Conference will feature cultural activities, a visit to Goree Island and the "Slave House", European and American destinations. We will share the saga of Africans, the civil rights fight in America anf the struggle for independence from the colonists in Africa. A free musical concert which bridges cultures will be held. The performers will feature African- American musicians (Jazz, Blues and Rap) and African musicians (Traditional, Jazz and Contemporary).

For further information, contact: Shirley Rivens Smith, D.C. -Dakar Council, 817 Longfellow St., N.W., Washington, D.C. 20011; phone (202) 829-1118 or fax (202) 829-1406.

The Center for Global Education is seeking a volunteer for its study center in Windhoek, Namibia. Responsibilities include assisting in the coordination of the study and travel programs carried out by the Center for Global Education. This is a thirteen month position with room, board, health insurance, round-trip airfare, and small stipend provided. For a job description and application, contact the Center for Global Education, Augsburg College, 2211 Riverside Avenue, Minneapolis, MN 55454-612/330-1159. Starting date: June 1, 1995. Application deadline: March 25, 1995

Visions in Action is a nonprofit organization offering one-year volunteer position in 8 African & Caribbean countries. Positions are available with nonprofit development organizations, research institutes, health clinics, community groups and news organizations. The program features a month-long orientation, including intensive language study, followed by an 11-month volunteer placement. French is required for Burkina Faso, English for the other programs. Program areas are: community development, health care, housing, small business, youth and children, women's issues, environment, scientific research, social science research, journalism, human rights & democratization. Volunteers are required to cover their own costs for airfare, housing and living expenses; community and individual sponsorships are encouraged. Costs range from US $4500-6000. Partial scholarships are available for nationals of developing countries.

For programs in Nairobi, Kenya; Tanzania, Somaliland the deadline is April 15, starts July 1. For Johannesburg & Durban, South Africa the deadline is April 15, starts July 1. For Kampala, Uganda the deadline is June 1, starts September 1. For Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso the deadline is July 1, starts October 1. For Harare, Zimbabwe the deadline is October 1, starts January 10. For Johannesburg & Durban, South Africa the deadline is October 1, starts January 10.

For applications contact: Visions In Action * 3637 Fulton St. NW * Washington, DC 20007 Tel: 202-625-7403.

Africa News


February, 1995


Calls for Papers


SECTION: OPPORTUNITES


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Hofstra Cultural Center announces a call for papers for Africa 2000, an interdisciplinary conference examining the situation of Africa in the year 2000 and the decade thereafter. Papers should focus on or emphasize the immediate future faced by the continent. Any discussion that increases an understanding of Africa's next decade and a half are welcome. Papers are invited on such diverse topics as African Americans and Africa; the African Diaspora; ethnic relations; medical geography; multinational corporations; public health; popular culture; single and multiparty states; urbanization; and women in Africa. Previously presented or published material should not be submitted. The conference will feature keynote speaker Chinua Achebe. DEADLINE: MARCH 15, 1995, for final papers (in duplicate), one-page abstract, and curriculum vitae. Contact: Athelene A. Collins, Hofstra University, Hampstead, NY 11550-1090, phone 516/ 564-4306.

March 24-26, 1995 SUNY Buffalo African Student Association will be hosting a Pan-African conference focusing on economic development in Africa and its links, dependencies and relationships to the social and political climate, as well as the relevance of U.S. Foreign Policy in Africa. Send outlines to asaorg@ubvms.cc.buffalo.edu Fax outlines to Guy Kayembe, the President of the association, at (716) 645-2112 Tel: (716) 645-2950 

April 13-15, 1995 Michigan State University's Comparative Black History program will host the COMPARATIVE HISTORY OF BLACKS IN THE DIASPORA SYMPOSIUM. The symposium will focus on new developments in the fields of African American, Latin American, Caribbean, U.S. Southern, and African history. The themes for the symposium are: Comparative Methods and Perspectives and the Black Diaspora; Comparative Slavery and Slave Society; and Freedom and Inequality in Comparative Perspective. Contact: Dr. Darlene Hine, History Department, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, phone 517/ 432-4933, or Dr. David Barry Gaspar, History Department, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, phone 919/684-2109.

April 29, 1995 SPRING CONFERENCE OF THE BERKELEY-STANFORD JOINT CENTER FOR AFRICAN STUDIES "Whither Africa's Liberation? Economic, Political, Cultural and Social Perspectives" is the theme of the 1995 spring conference.Send abstracts to Marianne Villanueva, Joint Center for African Studies, Littlefield Center, Room 14, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305-5013. Tel:(415) 723-0295. DEADLINE IS FEBRUARY 1, 1995,

May 4-5, 1995 SUDAN STUDIES ASSOCIATION FOURTEENTH ANNUAL MEETING The theme for the annual meeting of the Sudan Studies Association is "Conflict and Conflict Resolution," the meeting will be held at Villanova University. Papers are welcome from any relevant discipline and may also consider other countries in the Horn of Africa. Send paper or panel abstracts to: Ann Lewsch, Center for Arab and Islamic Studies, Villanova University, 800 Lancaster Ave., Villanova, PA 19085. TEL: (610) 519-7712. FAX: (610) 519-7249. June 21-25, 1995

May 10-13,1994 ANNUAL MEETING OF THE CANADIAN ASSOCIATION OF AFRICAN STUDIES "The Environment and Population in the 1990s" is the theme of the meeting to be held at Trent University, Peterbourough, Ontario. COMPLETED PAPERS FOR PRESENTATION MAY BE SUBMITTED UP TO APRIL 14. Contact Dr.Michael Lambek, Anthropology Department, 100 St. George, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario. M5S 1A1. Tel:(416) 978-7787. Fax:(416) 287-7283

May 19-20, 1995 SPRING MEETING OF THE BERKELEY-STANFORD JOINT CETNER FOR AFRICAN STUDIES, UCLA AND STANFORD HUMANITIES CENTER entitled "Law, Colonicalism and Property in Africa. Organizers are interestedi in exploringi the range of ways the study of law regarding ownership of resources can provide new insights into change in Colonial Africa. ABSTRACTS ARE DUE APRIL 1, 1995. COntact: Richard Roberts, African Studies, Stanford, University, Stanford, CA 94305-5013. E-mail: rroberts@leland.stanford.edu

November 1-2. 1995 CARTER LECTURE SERIES "African Entrepreneurship" is the theme of The Carter Lecture Series to be held at the University of Florida, Gainesville. Contact Dr.Anita Spring, Department of Anthropology, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611. Tel:(904) 392-4691.

February, 1995


Exhibitions & Programs


LENGTH: 587 words


 

February 5 - July 16, 1995 Los Angeles, CA UCLA Fowler Museum of Cultual History CROWNING ACHIEVEMENTS: AFRICAN ARTS OF DRESSING THE HEAD. Traditional and contemporary hats, headresses and hairstyles dating from the early 1800s to the present. Contact: UCLA Fowler Musseum of Cultural History, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90095 Tel: (310) 825-4361

March 5 - July 6, 1995 Los Angeles, CA UCLA Fowler Museum of Cultural History. COIFFURE MODERNE: A GALLERY OF AFRICAN HAIRSTYLES 1970-1990. 50 contemporary, painted African hairdressing signs from Gabon, Ghana and Cote d'Ivoire vibrantly express how hair may serve as a vehicle for artistic and cultural expression. Contact: UCLA Fowler Musseum of Cultural History, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90095 Tel: (310) 825-4361 

March 31 - August 31, 1995 New York, NY Museum for African Art ANIMALS IN AFRICAN ART. Contact: The Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, New York, NY 10012. Tel: (212) 966-1313.

Through February 26,1995 Washington, DC MOHAMMED OMER DHALIS, PRINTMAKER/AMIR I.M. NOUR SCULPTOR. This exhibition is devoted to works by two Sudanese artists, Mohammed Omer Khalil ,printmaker and painter and Amir Nour that recall their environment and life experiences Contact: National Museum of African Art, 950 Independence Ave. S.W. Washington, D.C. 20560, Tel:(202) 357-4600

Through March 5, 1995 New York, NY "EXHIBITION-ism: Museums and African Art." Contact: The Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, New York, NY 10012. Tel: (212) 966-1313, Fax: (212) 966-1432.

Through March 5, 1995 Los Angeles, CA SPIRITS AS PEOPLE: FIGURATIVE SCULPTURE OF THE BAULE PEOPLES, COTE D'IVOIRE, WEST AFRICA. Contact: UCLA Fowler Musseum of Cultural History, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90095 Tel: (310) 825-4361.

Through March 27,1995 Washington, DC GRACE K SCULPTURE; AN ARTIST'S BOOK BY ATTAWA KWAMI. In 1993, Attawa Kwami, A Ghanaian artist, created a book that explores the artwork of his mother, Grace Salome Kwami. The book itself is a work of art that consists of 48 unnumbered, folded pages that open like the legs of spider(ananse) In Ghanaian Culture, the Character Ananse is the custodian of wisdom and a symbol of ingenuity. Contact: National Museum of African Art, 950 Independence Ave. S.W., Washington, D.C. 205060, Tel: (202) 357-4600

Through April 30, 1995 Richmond, VA. Virginia Museum of Fine Arts SPIRIT OF THE MOTHERLAND. Contact: Suzanne Hall or Don Dale, Office of Public Affairs,

Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, 2800 Grove Avenue, Richmond, VA. 23221, Tel: (804)367-0878 Fax: (804)367-9393."

April 30-May 2, 1995 Kansas City, MO -- Conference "A Global Conversation About Information Transfer", the 5th conference of Librarians in International Development. Contact: Herbert K. Achleitner, School of Library Information Management, Emporia State University, Emporia, KS 66801; Phone: (316) 341-5329; Email: achleith@esuvm.bitnet.

May 4-6. 1995 Villanova, PA -- Annual Meeting, the 14th annual meeting of the Sudan Studies Association to be held at Villanova University. Contact: Center for Arab and Islamic Studies, Villanova University,m 800 Lancaster Ave., Villanova, PA 19085; Tel: (610) 519-7712; Fax: (610) 519-7249

May 21-28, 1995 Havanna Cuba -- Conference ,The International Yoruba Conference will bring together practitioners, professionals, and students from many nations of Africa. For details write The Elleggua Project, c/o CCS&F, 7171 Tobram Road, Suite 51, Mississauga, Ontario, Canada,L4T 3W4.

For registration materials write D.C.- Dakar Council, 817 Longfellow Street, NW, Washington, DC 20011.
