Africa News


February, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Financial Rand's End Rumoured


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Is Chris Stals about to scrap the financial rand?

Weekly Mail and Guardian

February 24, 1995

By Jacques Magliolo

A statement by Reserve Bank governor Chris Stals this week fuelled rumours that the financial rand would be scrapped within weeks. However, according to a number of economists and analysts, the speculation seems optimistic. 

The finrand was introduced by the Reserve Bank to discourage foreigners from removing funds from South Africa. In effect, a company wanting to operate here would obtain finrands at a better rate than commerical rands for their currency. But if they wanted to disinvest the exchange rate used would be at the less favourable commercial rand rate.

Stals was reported as saying the Reserve Bank had secured foreign credit of close to R12-billion to support the exchange rate once the dual currency system was abolished. He added that the underlying conditions for the scrapping of the finrand were improving all the time.

The pre-conditions are: the discount rate, which is the percentage difference between the commercial and financial rands, has to remain at 10 percent for a reasonable period of time.

"Massive buying by foreign banks of finrands in anticipation of the scrapping of the unit (before Stal's speech) is driving down the discount rate," says Southern Life economist Sandra Gordon. The discount rate fell to 10 percent last week and had maintained this level by Wednesday.

Says another economist: "The low discount rate has, in turn, fueled these rumours. However, the rate is merely one of three pre-conditions which has to be fulfilled before Stals can recommend to the cabinet that the units be unified."

Gordon adds: "Stals has said that the discount rate has to remain at a rate of at most 10 percent for a reasonable period of time.What that time is, is anyone's guess."

Non-resident holders of South African assets should not dispose of these assets after the two currencies have been combined. In other words, the pool of finrands must decrease over time. But no time frame has been provided by the Bank.

This would be best achieved by a continuing increase in foreign investor confidence in the country. This should, in turn, be reflected in a sustained reduction in the finrand discount.

However, political turbulence such as the Inkatha Freedom Party's walkout from parliament is likely to decrease foreign investor confidence.

The actual pool of finrand deposits (on an annual basis) increased at

the end of 1994 to R6,4-billion from 1993's R4,4-billion. Speculation of the scrapping was further supported by Stals revealing this week that finrand balances had fallen to about R5,5-billion.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone: (011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


42 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


NIGERIA: BUSINESS AND FINANCE


LENGTH: 4040 words


 

The Unanswered Questions

Newswatch

January 30, 1995

by Utibe Ukim

Anthony Ani, acting finance minister, was mid-way into the budget briefing session January 17, when a note arrived his desk from the presidency. Government was reversing its decision to remove rice from the list of prohibited goods and impose a duty of 150 percent on its importation. For 1995, rice will stay banned. Ani was asked to reflect this change in his budget breakdown. He did. Later, he told the audience at the Abuja Sheraton Hotel and Towers that the decision by the head of state to continue with the outright ban of the commodity was a way to encourage its local production.

Government's explanation failed to impress many. Rather, it added to the unanswered questions that have greeted Sani Abacha's budget of renewal announced January 14. In business circles the decision was seen as a pointer to the lack of political will within the government to implement some tough policy measures in the budget that may be unpopular with certain interest groups. 

Rice importers constitute one such interest groups. Their operation is very profitable when the commodity comes into the country illegally. Sources say that rice destined for Nigeria account forms at least 75 percent of the total cargo handled by the seaport at Cotonou, Benin Republic. NEWSWATCH sources say that over the years, the rice lobby has successfully convinced government on the need to ban the commodity outrightly ostensibly to encourage local production. As a result of the ban, rice arrives the country at a more expensive rate than it would have been if it came in legally and a high duty was imposed on it.

Last week, importers said that with a duty of 150 percent, it would still have been possible for the Nigerians to buy a 50 kilogramme bag of rice for about N900. Whether this is true or not, the sudden reversal has not helped the image of the government which like all previous governments appears voluble on goals but short on their execution. Nor has its decision to crerate two new minitstries- those of solid mineral development and women and social wielfare when there are ministries of mines and power and petroleum and mineral resources to take care of solid mineral developments and health and human resources and the National Women Commission to take care of women affairs. Last week, analyst saw this as a sign of unseriousness from a government that talks of downsizing and rationalising government operations.

The 1995 budget is part of the 1995-97 national rolling plan. For 1995, government expects a total revenue of N350.66 billion. Out of this, earnings from crude oil sales are expected to account for N200.64 billion, showing an increase of N7.04 billion over the N193.6 billion project for 1994. Government's revenue projection is based on the sales of 2.04 million barrels of oil per day including 175 million barrels of condensate from the Oso Condensate plan in Eket, Akwa Ibom State. Non-oil sources will account for N150.02 billion, an increase of 218.85 percent over the N47.05 billion earned in 1994.

The increase in oil revenues is accounted for largely by government's decision to discontinue the operation of dedicated accounts and pay all oil receipts into the Central Bank of Nigeria, CBN. Out of this amount, N185.08 billion will finance the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, NNPC,join venture cash calls, national priority projects like the liquefied natural gas project and other capital projects in the oil sector, external debt servicing and the projects to be undertaken by the newoly created petroleum trust fund.

Government says it expects to stimulate the non-oil sector to become a key revenue source for it as part of efforts to break the overdependence on oil. Duties are expected to yield N34.4 billion, while N15 billion is expected from the value added tax. Also, government expects to earn N97.618 billion from the adjustment of prices of petroleum products effected in October.

Federal government's expenditure of profile shows a total expenditure of N155.02 billion. Out of this N53.7 billion will go for recurrent expenditure against the N38 billion spent in 1994. ani said the increase of 41.32 percent is attributed to recent revisions in personal allowances. Capital projects will gulp N44.5 up from N19.38 billion provided for in 1994, while another N57 billion has been set aside for the servicing of public debt. Government said the sharp increase in the allocation for capital projects was because of government's decision to incorportate all capital projects previously funded from dedicated accounts into the budget process.

Government says the budget is intended to restore the dignity of the naira, stimulate growth in the productive sectors of agriculture and manufacturing, create new jobs, boost exports and reduce inflation within the economy. It appears as an attempt by government to satisfy the demands for a drastic review of the policies introduced with the 1994 budget. The creation of an autonomous market for foreign exchange, suspension of the official foreign exchange, suspension of the official foreign exchange market and the abrogation of the foreign exchange act of 1962 were seen as moves towards deregulation. Abacha, said in his budget broadcast january 14 that the economic strategy of this administration "draws inspiration from the recognition that free enterprise is the bedrock of a democratic political system."

To achieve these goals, the government announced the introduction of guided deregulation for interest and exchange rates. Under the new interest policy will induce growth in the productive sector as it will serve as incentive for the investment in this critical area. It said that government will use a number of policy instruments, especially "fiscal and monetary austerity and supply side initiatives to drastically reduce thte rate of inflation." It directed anks not to demand more than N50 initial deposits for opening new saving accounts in rural areas and N100 in urban areas.

The most significant changes are in the foreign exchange area. Although the government said it was maintaining the official exchange rate of N22 to $1, it officially devalued the naira in a process which many Nigerians are yet to fully appreciate. Government announced the re-introduction of the autonomous market for foreign exchange and said individual can now open and maintain domiciliary accounts. The official foreign exchange market, FEM has been scrapped and henceforth, all foreign exchange users will be reuired to source their foreign exchange independently. However, government will continue to but the foreign exchane earning from official sources at the official rate and keep same for its own needs and for the occasional intervention in the autonomous market that it has empowered the CBN to establish in order to stabilise the market. The government further strenghtened the national Economic Intelligence Committee Decree Number 17 when it said that in the foreign exchange guidelines that the parallel market remains illegal.

Government also abrogated the 1962 exchange control act which restricted the flow of foreign exchage into and out of the country, a move which Gbenga Akinnawo, managing director of African Paints, praised as a key to opening up the economy to outside investments. It also cancelled the Nigerian Enterprise Promotions Decree which restricted foreigners to certain areas and announced the establishmentof a consumer protection council to check unwholesome practices by manufacturers, middlemen and traders' regulation by another name.

Abacha's budget of renewal and incentives, is another experiment which he hopes will return Nigeria to economic prosperity. He said that the budget is premised on government's belief that the country must not be afraid of experimenting. "This budget of renewal embraces the principle that we should not be afraid to experiment nor should we experience out of fear," he said in the broadcast.

Nigerians are familiar with the various economic experiments which the country has undergone since its economy began its downward spin in the late 1970s. The Obasanjo government introduced economic austerity programme which was abandoned by the Shagari regime. The Buhari government reintroduced austerity measures and strict regulation of the economy but the government was shortlived. The Babangida government introduced the structural adjustment programme in 1986 to champion an economic reconstruction programme based on a free market approach. Under the structural adjustment programme, SAP, the government decided to float the exchange rate of the naira and open it to market forces. It promised other key reforms including the privatisation of key government parastatals, reform of the financial sector and the deregulation of the economy. The programme worked for a while but it suffered from abuse and haphazard implementation while at the same time exacting enormous cost from Nigerians.

Last year, Abacha's first budget halted the reforms and introduced stringent controls. Interest and exchange rates were fixed in a move which the government said will enhance growht in the productive sector.Abacha admitted last week that his first economic experiment failed. Negative growth within the economy continued throughout 1994. Said Abacha in his broadcast: "The negative growth rate of the preceeding year was not reversed because of the constraint of the unconducive macroeconomic environment." Ani said that the objectives of 1994 budget were largely unment. "Some of the policy objectives in the 1994 budget, especially stemming the high rate of inflation, stabilising the exchange and interest rates and achieving a higher level of economic growth could not be fully attained." He said that the national economy did not record any growth in 1994. From 2.3 percent growth rate in the manufacturing sector, Ani said there was a decline of five percent within the sector which the government projected would grow at 3.3 percent. Inflation was put at 70 percent at the end of 1994 against 57.2 percent in 1993 while fiscal deficit stood at N81 billion for 1994. The government had presented a balanced budget which had no built in deficit.

Budget 95 is a marriage of economic liberalisation with government control. Abacha and his officials call it guided deregulation, one in which government plays the role of umpire and frequently intervenes when market forces try to make a mess of its polcy objectives. With the budget, the government has gone back completely on its initial rejection of market forces as the key determinant of the exchange rate of the naira, reflecting perhaps, the victory of the CBN over the National Economic Intelligence Committee, whose chairman, Samuel Aluko, a seasoned economist, has always advocated strict economic regulation.

NEWSWATCH sources say that the budget was packaged with the intention to please most people, especially the international financial institutions like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, IMF, which have maintained their opposition to the reintroduction of government controls. That way, the government hopes to be able to win over the support of the IMF for approval for its Medium Term Economic Programme which Nigeria applied for since 1993 and for which negotiations have been stalled. In its half year report for 1994, the CBN had asked the government to immediately adopt a MTEP as a strategy towards reversing the negative trends within the economy. In October, the CBN followed this up with a memorandum to government which asked for higher rates of exchange for the naira saying that the going rate of N22 to $1 was low and uneconomic and that government was being forced to subsidize the market heavily. It is believed that one of the key contributions of the NEIC to the budget was its advice to government that it was time to end the "festival of foreign exchange" which the official market had been turned into. It was learnt that the committee argued that in most countries where the national currency is convertible, the monetary authority does not announce the rates at which it plans to sell the national currency against a basket of currencies. The committee said asking importers to source for their foreign exchange will reduce the pressure on the government as well as the government.

NEWSWATCH sources said further the move is commendable because the demand for the currency at the official market over time was unrealistic. An industrialist said that for most of 1994, manufacturers demanded more than they need because they "knew that they will never get enough allocation."

So far, reactions to the budget have been mixed. Olusegun Oshunkeye, managing director of Nestle Foods said the principle of the budget was good but the implementation will require a lot of discipline from the monetary authority and government. Akinnawo sees the budget as "the most responsive to the enlightened opinion in recent years." He said that the budget has ensured complete deregulation of the foreign exchange system, especially with the abrogation of the foreign exchange act of 1962. Gerald Flood, resident representative of the World Bank in Nigeria, said there were encouraging signs in the current budget and pointed to efforts at budget transparency and the move towards deregulation. He doubts, however, how the CBN will intervene in the autonomous market as government has said.

Flood is not alone. The administration of the new exchange system will demand a lot of discipline and sincerity from the government and the CBN. Already, there are fears that the government has effectively devalued the naira without saying so. This is not his problem, however. His concern is that while the rate at the autonomous market is bound to exceed N22 to $1, "why is the government keeping the N22 to $1 rate? How will this be handled without abuses as we witnessed during the Babangida days?" He recalled that during the days of SAP, there were at least four different rates of exchange, namely, the first tier rates at about N1 to $1, the second tier rate, the autonomous market rates and the parallel market rates. The first tier rates became a source of government patronage for interest groups and friends. Some airline operators, even those without aircraft, were allocated foreign exchage at the first tier rates.

NEWSWATCH learnt that these fears are genuine. Just as the budget was being read, there was instruction from the presidency for the CBN to sell foreign exchange to some highly placed traditional rulers at N22 to $1. The CBN allegedly saying that the traditional rulers should be asked to pay the autonomous market price.It took some time before the presidency agreed to this, a source said. Once it did, however, the problem was how to arrive at the autonomous market rate. The CBN, the source said, could not figure out the rate.

Said Akinnawo: "I have my fears that the foreign proceeds of the feral government may indeed be used as settlement for friends and supporters of government. What this means is that if someone is friendly with government, he may be sold foreign exchange through the back door at the CBN at N22 to $1 while authentic manufactureers and users of foreign exchange will have to go and buy their foreign exchange from the autonomous mardet at perhaps N60 per dollar."

The second fear which many people have is that the government is likely to earn more than what its budget shows and that such extra earnings has not been provided for in the budget. Budget 95 is based on the official rate of exchange. Government says it would buy off monies from the oil companies, and embassies at the autonomous rates and occasionally inject the money including its official receipts into the market to stabilize the naira exchange rate. CBN will sell to the autonomous market at the prevailing rate. "What government has not said is how it intends to spend the extra money it will make from this as this is not accounted for in the budget," a finance industry chief said last week. "Will it sterilize the money to guard against inflation or will it spend it on frivolous projects?" Government, he said, needs to address this question to restore the confidence of Nigerians in the budget.

Said another manufacturer in Lagos: "Except government comes out to state clearly what it intends to do with its own foreign exchange earnings, we are back to square one." But the CBN seems to have prepared for this question. The foreign exchange policy guidelines for the year says that the new policy is to build-up the nation's external reserve. "A major policy goal for 1995 is the deliberate build-up and strengthening of external reserves to enhance confidence in the Nigerian economy, strengthening the naira and pave the way for its ultimate convertibility.

These are not the only complaints against the new policy. The private sector is beginning to look at government as being greedy. That may be true. Government is the net receiver of most of the foreign exchange that comes into the country. Apart from the official receipt, all oil companies, embassies and parastatals which earn foreign exchange will sell their earnings to the government. With this, there will be only a few sources left for operators of the autonomous market. "What kind of depth will the market have when the government has hijacked the supply side?" asked a banker last week.

Perhaps, this may not be a major problem. Many believe there is plenty of autonomous funds coming into the country and that a well developed market can tap these independent sources. Besides, there is the belief that once the market takes off, the black market will be threatened as banks will compete freely for all available funds. What this means is that foreign exchange will be available at rates higher than N22 and this is with government approval. On the positive side, it is expected to grant open access to people to do business in Nigeria, knowing that they can easily repatriate their progit. For instance, government will no longer be under any obligation to provide foreign exchange for foreign airlines to repatriate theri ticket sales revenue. That has been a contentious issue. With the autonomous market, the airlines will be able to buy and remit their profits to their bases with ease. But this means that air fares for instance will go up. The current air fares are dollar based although they are denominated in naira. As the rates at the market fluctuate, the fares would be expected to respond to these changes.

Manufacturers are expecting higher operating cost as the cost of foreign exchange goes up. Some are expecting that with the rates at the autonomous market reaching N80, their production cost will rise significantly and that these additional cost will be passed on to the consumers by way of higher prices. In addition to the above, the plan by government to lease out some of its firms including the four refineries, the petrochemical plants, the Nigeria Airways and the Sugar companies also means that the products of these companies. In the case of the refineries for instance to companies and organisations, both local and foreign, with known expertise in these areas. Government will share in the profit of these companies. In the case of the refineries for instance, crude oil for refining will be sold to the managers at the commercial rate and in order to recover cost, the pump price of petrol will expectedly go up.

Tola Mobulurin, managing director of Capital Bancorp, said the decision to lease these firms was not proper. "If you want to privatise. Leasing is a far more complex thing to look at it is subject to abuses." He raised the question of effective management of the facility in a wat that depreciation is taken care of. He said a better option would have been a lease purchase arrangement where the managers has the option of buying the plant after a certain period of time.

"If we want to privatise, we should privatise. Let them (lessors) take commercial risk. Let them take ownership risk. For now, who bears the obsolence risk? We can sell these things off for dollars and we will be better off, he added. He said that no serious entrepreneur will want to lease these strategic plants from a government that is supposed to be on its way out." Still, as most analysts said last week the succes or failure of the budget depends on how committed government is to its implementation. From past experiences, success is not guaranteed.

Reported by: Soji Akinriade, Wale Akin Aina, Moffat Ekoriko, and Jonah Achema.

Published by Newswatch Communications Limited, No.3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria. Telephone: 4960950. Fax: 962887


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


43 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


UGANDA: Sports-Cancer Eating African Soccer


LENGTH: 1214 words


 

The Monitor

February 06-08, 1995

by Rashid Mudin

Soccer on the African continent, is riding rough seas despite the fact that FIFA recently recognised its rise, and allotted it two more slots in the final rounds of the 1998 World Cup in France.

Not a single nation on the African continent can say "we are having it smooth". save for South Africa that is awakening to the demand of international football after 30 years of isolation due to apartheid.

The cancer eating deep into African football scene is nothing but politics and money. These two factors have had incredible influence on the direction of the game; its success or failure. 

From Cairo to Cape Town and from Dakar to Mogadishu, the story is the same. It is only a difference in magnitude.

Let us begin with our eastern neighbor, Kenya. For years Kenya was the envy of neighboring countries. Not that the Kenyans were highly talented but because the KANU government cared and pumped a lot of assistance both morally and financially into soccer.

The regular presence of president Daniel arap Moi at matches would motivate the teams to success. For example during the 1987 All Africa Games when president Moi attended virtually every event that involved Kenyans and at the end of the day, Kenya walked away with most of the Gold medals.

The same year, Moi was at every match that Gor-Mahia played in Nairobi in the Cup Winners Cup. Gor Mahia ended up winning the title after beating Esperance of Tunisia in the finals.

In the early 90s, Kenyans formed opposition parties to unseat president Moi, and most opposition was from western Kenya which is the country's cradle of soccer. Moi knows that too well, so he also chose to ignore soccer. The result? Soccer in Kenya is now just struggling.

Kenya should have hosted the 1996 Africa Cup of Nations, but because the current leaders in the Kenya Football Federation (KFF) belong to opposition parties, the KANU government felt it would be a political capital for the opposition if KFF succeeded in hosting the biggest soccer tournament on the continent.

The KANU government felt it was better for them to forfeit the hosting right and pay a huge fine, than sponsor the Africa Cup of Nations. That is how far politics can destroy the game.

Egypt is a known soccer force on the continent. The Government pumps in a lot of money, but they too are facing financial problems. Some of the premier division clubs can no longer sustain the foreign coaches and players. Has anyone ever bothered to find out why Egypt is never represented in the CAF (Abiola) Cup?

One time Arab Contractors of Egypt was a powerful team with players from all over the continent. But because of politics, the club failed to get home support. Ahmed Osman Ahmed, the sponsor of the team, would at times even hire fans, especially soldiers to cheer his team in international matches. Egyptians disgusted by Osman's schemes, introduced stringent rules against foreigners and Arab Contractors which had no political backing waned into the oblivion.

Cameroon has as a nation participated at the highest level of football, the World Cup three times. And it was because of their quarter final appearance in Italia '90 World Cup that Africa got a third slot. But just see what has now become of soccer in Cameroon. Because of civil strife in the country, the game has hit its lowest ebb.

Cameroon is struggling in their Cup of Nations Group One qualifying pool with just three points from four matches. Recently they were in Zimbabwe and lost 4-1. As if that was not bad enough, the team spent two days in transit, starving. The national team players had traveled without any allowances.

In 1994 Zaire traveled to the Africa Cup of Nations finals in Tunisia with two warring factions of the football federation, supported by the government, and the other by clubs. CAF had to intervene before Zaire could be allowed to participate in the African Cup of Nations.

In Tunisia, last year, when the national team lost the first match to Mali there was a national outcry. The coach was immediately sacked when the team failed to qualify altogether, the fans boycotted all the matches. The Tunisian government had to come to the rescue of the tournament. Hmmn! Some fans even asked for the resignation of the government.

Where does all this leave us? With one conclusion.

That in Africa, it is the politics of the day and money that make the game tick. Countries that pay its players well usually get the results. When Nigeria won the Africa Cup, each player was handsomely rewarded by the Abacha government in cash and other awards.

Poor countries unable to properly finance their teams in terms of training and winning bonuses, will forever lag behind.

Soccer has turned out to be a big money business, and in soccer success means money. In Uganda the story is well known, the government withdrew financial support three years ago, and what we have on the ground is chaos.

The national team is just struggling, the clubs are unsure of participation in the continental competitions.

Compared to the so called dark days (of Idi Amin)- and it sounds terrible. In the 70s when Uganda was one of the top soccer nations on the continent, the government of the day used to money in sports. And the NRM government cannot continue pretending about this. Money must be found and put in sports.

Unless this cancer is eradicated, African soccer shall never catch up with the advanced nations of the world.

The Monitor is published at P.O. Box 12141 Kampala, Uganda Tel: 251353 Fax: 251352


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


44 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


UGANDA: Somewhere In The Bush, An Idea Becomes Real


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

The Monitor

January 18-20, 1995

by Hamis Kaheru

First a man called Bernard Onyango left Makerere and took refuge in a remote place called Nkozi.

Then in October 1993, the Uganda Martyrs' University, Nkozi, located 80 kms west of Kampala, opened shop with two major courses.

Since then, short courses have been introduced. Last Saturday Onyango spent the whole afternoon seeing off a group of students who had just completed a course in "Computerised Human Resources Management." 

The Co-ordinator of the course, Valerious Bebangamba, explained at the graduation ceremony that the course is the first of its kind in an East African university. Most computer programmes centre on data-based fields like accounting, he said, but as we enter the "age of information" it is necessary to modernise our Human Resource Management (HRM) systems.

The graduates were not young men and women. They were senior officers in parastatals and multi-nationals who are in charge of human resources in their particular companies.

Ajiku Cyprian, Head of Administration in Uganda Airlines Corporation, who spoke on behalf of the graduates, said that he has never used computers in his twenty years in the field of personnel management. Now, with the skills he has gained from Nkozi, management processes will be easy for him, he said.

John Kategaya, Principal Personnel Officer in the Uganda Posts and Telecommunications Corporation, said "We liked the course - except it was short."

The computer programme, "Manage pro 2.0", took six days and forms the basic level for which the participants were given certificates. They are expected to return to complete their intermediate and advanced levels.

The Saturday graduates whom Mr. Onyango said are among the "pioneers" of the University were given certificates in computer-based human resource management.

In a speech read on behalf of Vice Chancellor Prof. Dr. Michel Lejueune, Onyango said the institution intends to develop many courses in institutional management. The general area of management involves managing hotels, schools and hospitals and that all require specialised training. "We hope to go into that soon," he said.

It is just over a year since Martyrs University started. Academic Registrar Onyango looks back with more than satisfaction.

When he announced that he was retiring from his post as Makerere University's Academic Registrar in January 1992, a number of the varsity's alumni burst into tears.

Almost everyone who knew Onyango, and even those who had only heard about him, felt it was not the appropriate time to lose the services of one of the country's most dedicated civil servants. They felt that now the university was opening its gates to allow in more students, he ought to postpone his retirement.

What was his reaction towards this general sense of loss among the public? "I was very happy. It means I had done the job," Onyango told The Monitor over the week-end.

"I had served for 30 years and others had to come in," he explained. Thirty years in the same place-excluding the years I spent there as a student-is not something small."

As Academic Registrar, Onyango had impressed almost everybody-particularly for his determination to catch anybody who attempted to sneak into Makerere using forged academic testimonials. He expelled many students in this category - including children of ministers and other "big" people.

When he left, people feared that the only government-owned University was going to become a haven for those who could afford to buy their way into it. It would be difficult, many thought, to get a good enough replacement.

But Onyango does not except this idea: "There is nothing like failing to get a replacement." Any new person will come and see what is in place and start from there."

At Uganda Martyrs University, Nkozi, where he has taken on the same job of Academic Registrar, Onyango is as untiring as ever.

Currently, the University has two academic years, with a total of 120 students, and it hopes to admit the third intake in October this year. It offers two

courses: Bachelor of Business Administration &Management (BBA&M) and, Bachelor of Ethics and Development Studies (BE&DS).

The major problem Onyango is facing in his new job is lack of room to accommodate staff, students and administration. There are only five student hostels, each with a capacity of 30. If they decide to use double deckers the maximum will be 60 beds each.

But the Academic Registrar says that even when the new buildings (currently under construction) are completed, he will not have more than 1,000 students.

"We don't want to make it very big," he explained, from his one-room office.

The accommodation problems means that Onyango is mainly using lecturers from Kampala, most of whom come, stay overnight, teach the following day and then return to Kampala. "It is not satisfactory but we are determined to push on," said Onyango in his usual undaunted tone.

THE MONITOR is published at P.O. Box 12141, Kampala, Uganda Tel: 251353 Fax: 251352


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


45 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


SUDAN: Khartoum Finds The Going Tough On The Battlefields Of The South


LENGTH: 2987 words


 

February 1995

As recently as six months ago, any suggestion that a military solution to the war in the South was an impossibility and a mere pipe dream would have been greeted with scorn by the Islamic Fundamentalists military regime. The regime was not the only one to be fooled by its own propaganda barrage against the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA). Even many Southern Sudanese were taken in by the stories of the SPLA's demise, not to speak of would be credible media sources like Africa Confidential. Reports were rife that Colonel John Garang's security could no longer be guaranteed in the South, and that he was going into exile.

However, times change and so do people's perceptions of the war in the South. Today, the supposedly won conflict that Khartoum so often boasted about, has returned to the political agenda amid calls for a political rather than a military solution. The Southern people are far from defeated and the SPLA is still a force to be reckoned with. Khartoum is beginning to take a more sober look at developments in the South. 

The Fronts

The main fronts of the past three years have centred around Nimule, Kajokeji, Morobo and the routes from Bahr El Ghazal into Western Equatoria. The regime has been poised on many an occasion to evict the SPLA from the border areas. Troit and Kapoeta in Eastern Equatoria had become the stablest towns occupied by the regime's forces. All of this has started to change in these areas as the regime's forces have been pressed by a revitalized SPLA. Some elements controlled by Khartoum have even resorted to banditry because of the lack of official supplies reaching their outposts.

In early January, there were several news reports about incidents involving the regime's forces in the Uganda border areas. Apparently, a unit stationed at Kajokeji or Morobo, facing starvation through lack of supplies, slipped through the SPLA siege and regrouped inside Uganda. They brought along some members of the Uganda dissident group, the Lords Resistance Army, to help them negotiate their way through the villages which they intended to plunder for food. Some members of the renegade SPLA commander William Nyuon's forces also went along, presumably to make it seem there these were activities of the SPLA, if anything went wrong.

The alarm was soon raised after the mixed force entered a few villages, and Ugandan army units nearby were sent to investigate. The force was largely destroyed or captured when it attempted to raze one village too many. Then the story of what it was up to finally came out. The Sudanese readily identified themselves, perhaps thinking that this would be a safer option than being labeled Ugandan dissidents. They stated that they had lost their way and crossed into Uganda whilst in hot pursuit of some SPLA rebels. The members of the Lords Resistance Army appeared to have been forewarned of the ambush and most of them evaded capture.

Some of the stories told by the captured Sudanese indicate that they had really entered Uganda to scavenge for food. That is somewhat different from the official version now being circulated by Khartoum.

Uganda's Version of Events

Uganda Radio broadcast the stories told by members of William Nyuon's group. They said they were being used by both the regime and the Lords Resistance Army to carry arms and ammunition. Their stories were given in full, no doubt in a bid to maximise Khartoum's embarrassment and discomfort.

As was to be expected, the leader of the Lords Resistance Army, with prompting from his supporters in the regime, claimed all responsibility for the incident. He said that Khartoum bore no responsibility at all. Through the actions in Uganda his forces had launched in earnest the war against President Yoweri Museveni's government in Kampala.

The official Ugandan position blamed Khartoum for infiltrating the border area and accused the Islamic Fundamentalist regime of using the forces of the renegade SPLA commander William Nyuon to supply arms to the Lords Resistance Army. Uncharacteristically, Khartoum did not directly respond to these accusations.

Limitation of the Renegades

Khartoum's ability to make use of the various renegade factions in the South has seriously diminished in the present dry season. This has limited the regime's ability to launch any offensives, as it has come to rely these groups to harass the mainstream SPLA since the major schism in the movement in August 1991. Except for the cattle rustling raid in the Agar Dinka area of Akot last October, forces loyal to Commander Riek Machar have not recently been active. There are even doubts about whether the commander had any real control over the forces which raided Akot, with some observers suggesting that he claimed their loyalty in order to impress external agencies that he is still in command of a force to be reckoned with. There are signs that his own support among the Nuer tribe is dwindling due to his lack of vision and strong leadership. Conflict and division has escalated among Nuer communities since Riek Machar aspired to leadership.

Elsewhere, Commander Lam Akol announced last month that he has reorganised his own faction under the SPLA United banner. He has set himself a limited agenda of making peace with the regime in Khartoum. He has accused his rivals of incompetence in the field of leadership. It is not exactly clear what size of force Lam Akol could offer Khartoum as part of any peace agreement.

Inter-reliance

In a strange case of inter-reliance and dependency, the renegade commanders have turned to Khartoum for deliverance now that their attempts to destroy the leadership of the mainstream SPLA have failed. In turn, Khartoum has increasingly turned to these commanders for deliverance too, because of the logistical difficulties involved in continuing the war in the South.

Commander William Nyuon once appeared to be a real catch for Khartoum. Now he has discovered that the regime is in no position to help him achieve his ambition of defeating Colonel Garang. He is fast realising that his forces are being used as canon fodder by the regime, in order to clear the way for their own forces. This ought not to have been too surprising for Commander Nyuon because ultimately the regime never had any intention of sharing the spoils of victory with him. Khartoum had scores to settle with him from his days as a bona fide nationalist fighter. Commander Nyuon's forces have been reduced to porters for the other groups, in the wake of their defeat by the SPLA outside Troit in December.

A fourth renegade commander, Kerubino Kuanyin Bol, remains marooned outside of Gogrial town in Bahr El Ghazal. He is still waiting for the regime to re supply his forces so that he can establish a firm foothold against the SPLA in the area. He dearly wants some territory that he can lay claim to, but his forces have only succeeded in engendering hostility in the local population.

Bombing Relief Centres

In December, just before Christmas, the regime began to bomb Akon, some twenty-nine miles northwest of Gogrial. Akon has been a relief centre for more than four years. It is a United Nations negotiated relief centre in an area under SPLA control. It was established as part of an agreement between the SPLA, the UN and the Khartoum regime whereby the belligerents each provided the UN with an equal number of relief centres. These centres are supposed to be protected and free from military operations. Khartoum has routinely violated these agreements, seemingly with impunity.

Targeting Civilians

The objective of bombing Akon appears to have been to drive away the civilian population, along with a small SPLA unit stationed there, so that Commander Kuanyin could take control of the village and make it his headquarters. This was also the intention behind the failed attempts to control Mayan Abun, which is equidistant from Abyei to the north and Gogrial to the south. Akon would be a far easier outposts to maintain and supply from Gogrial and also from Aweil, a larger regime garrison town some thirty-four miles to the west.

For some reason, Commander Kuanyin's forces did not move from Gogrial towards Akon. It later transpired that for the takeover of Akon to succeed, three important steps needed to be carried out. Firstly, the regime's forces in Gogrial would supply Kerubino with arms and ammunition as well as transport vehicles. The regime's troops would follow behind. Secondly, the aerial bombardment would begin on the morning that Kerubino's forces moved out of Gogrial. Thirdly, they would be in place to begin a ground offensive at Akon when the bombardment ceased. In reality, the co- ordinated attack never got started. Whilst the bombers were ready at zero hour, the ground forces were not. Kerubino had received no arms or ammunition. The Gogrial garrison had none to offer, they had expected that the army headquarters in Wau would supply them in good time. Wau itself was short of supplies and so the plans faltered.

Attack on Kuac

Last month, in the face of the failure of the Akon plan, the regime's militia, also known as the Popular Defense Force (PDF), attacked the Kuac Dinka population and of southern Gogrial and devastated an entire community. The force arrived from the north by train on their way to Wau. Half way between Aweil and Wau the train stopped, troops disembarked and spread out to the East. The Kuac Dinka population was taken by complete surprise. Many villages were razed to the ground and more than 8,000 head of cattle were rustled and driven towards the railway line, no doubt to boost food supplies. Large numbers of the Kuac Dinka were killed and wounded. Women and children are reported to have been carried off into captivity and sold on as slaves.

The objective behind the militia attack appears to have been to distress the SPLA. Guerrilla soldiers from the area might be tempted to desert and return to defend their tribal homelands when they hear reports of atrocities. This would have a knock on effect on the SPLA's capacity to wage war in the South. So far, the plan appears to have failed, largely due to the SPLA's high level of motivation and discipline amongst its forces. The defense of the local population has to be part of an integrated SPLA strategy.

Western Equatoria

The main centres for Khartoum's offensives are still the border areas of Eastern and Western Equatoria. The Western Equatoria front is always co-ordinated at Wau in Bahr El Ghazal, with some planning undertaken at Juba for a push from the East. However, the reverses suffered at Troit and Kapoeta in December have concentrated the regime's Juba efforts on maintaining those fronts.

Since early 1994, the regime has ferried troops into Wau by rail air. The town is now saturated with soldiers and the logistical problems are immense. The railway stops at Wau and the troops will have to head for Western Equatoria by ground routes. The terrain between Wau and Tomnura is ideal country for waging a guerrilla war and it will be by no means a straightforward process to get these troops beyond Wau.

Troops have been transported to the northern bank of the River Bo, a point where the regime has been repeatedly defeated in the past. The SPLA is in control of the southern bank of river and so a successful crossing will not be easy. The regime has repeatedly attempted to use this direct route towards Western Equatoria over the past four years presumably because the alternatives hold out even less chance of success.

Alternative Routes

There are a number of alternative routes. The first is from Juba through Yei, and the second also from Juba through Rokon and Mundri. The Yei route has been all but abandoned because the manpower is no longer available to push forward, as most of the allocated troops have been re-designated to the battles for Troit and Kapoeta. For the route through Rokon, there is a large force assembled at Tarekeka on the Nile just north of Juba. This force has failed for many months now to advance due to lack of supplies.

The other possibility is to make use of French assistance and attack Western Equatoria from inside the central African Republic of Zaire. So far the attempts to infiltrate troops across the border have failed dismally. Soldiers easily lose their bearings in the thickly forested border areas and those who make it though have been easily dealt with by the SPLA. Khartoum still refuses to acknowledge that it is trying to infiltrate soldiers in from the two neighbouring countries, which is little recompense to the families of any soldiers killed in action. The regime has a policy of not informing families of the details of any details.

Eastern Equatoria

The regime once believed that if it could defeat the SPLA along the borders with Kenya and Uganda, then it would be sounding the guerrilla army's death knell. Most resources in the South have been deployed in this area.

The SPLA has defended these areas determinedly because they have been their diplomatic outlet to the outside world. Kenya and Uganda have also acted as hosts to the many Southern Sudanese refugees fleeing the conflict, and have helped the relief agencies to carry out their tasks. Whoever controls the border area also controls the hearts and minds of the local Southern population, who depend upon outside relief. It is for this reason that Khartoum speaks about border villages such as Nimule as though they were some of the world's most strategically important cities.

Troit and Kapoeta

The regime's forces are fighting a real rearguard battle to hold on to both Troit and Kapoeta. For the third month the SPLA occupies and controls half of Kapoeta, with the trench lines being two to three hundred yards apart. The SPLA has the town under siege so its troops are far more mobile and can bring in fresh supplies. On the other hand, the regime's forces are well dug in and have all kinds of heavy artillery at their disposal. They are proving difficult to dislodge, but as long as circumstances stay the same Kapoeta will eventually fall to the SPLA.

Attempts to relieve Kapoeta from Troit failed in December and now Troit itself is under siege. The supply route between Juba and Troit has become almost unusable for the regime, so it has been examining alternative routes for re supplying and reinforcing both Kapoeta and Troit. One suggestion has been to use the route from Pibor on the Ethiopian border, which was originally used to launch a surprise attack on the SPLA at Kapoeta in 1992. Unfortunately, the logistical problems involved in transporting a large force to Pibor are likely to prove insurmountable.

Nineteen ninety-five is already proving to be a difficult year militarily for the regime. If the SPLA can bolster its position in the South, then the chances are that the regime will feel pressured into returning to the IGADD peace process.

Sudan Democratic Gazette is published at PO Box 2295, London w14 ond, U.K.

February, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Women--Rural Women Speak Out Against Power of Chiefs


LENGTH: 467 words


 

New Nation

February 10, 1995

by Pule Molebeledi

Traditional chiefs should not be given automatic ex-officio status on Local Government but should rather contest the coming October elections along with other ordinary candidates.

This was said by rural women from all around the country at the speak-out day organised by the National Land Committee (NLC).

The rural women were mainly speaking about their exclusion from the local government transition process, where they demanded to be centrally involved in decision-making processes around the country. 

"This will ensure that women have access to land and a role in land management, which we are currently denied," they said.

The women, from rural communities in six provinces, reported that nothing had changed with regard to the gender composition of local government and that many traditional authorities were hostile to women.

Initiatives: They criticised the civic movement by saying that it is mostly controlled by men and tends to block initiatives suggested by women.

They further called on the civic structure to be constituted with equal representation for men and women. "Bodies claiming to be progressive should give substance to those claims," the women said.

"Over the past months, President Nelson Mandela has indicated his concern about the lack of women representatives in national government.

"We ask that he take note of the appalling situation in local authorities across the country and take active steps to remedy the problem," they said.

Around 20 women delegates reiterated one of the last year's demands in the Land Charter by calling on all Transitional Local Councils (TLCs) to be constituted with equal representation by men and women. The Land Charter was adopted by over 300 rural communities at the Community Land Conference last year.

The New Nation is published at Darragh House 13 Wanders St. Johannesburg. Tel:(011)333-2711 or (011)333-2721/2/3/4 Telex: 482226 Fax: (011)889-0630

SOUTH AFRICA: Nuclear Waste Ship To Pass South Africa


LENGTH: 454 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian

February 24, 1995

by Inge Ruigrok

A ship loaded with deadly nuclear waste, including weapons-grade plutonium, may sail through South African waters on its way from France to Japan within the next two weeks.

The Cape Town-base Environment Monitoring Group has urgently appealed to the government to notify the Japanese government of South Africa's formal opposition to these shipments and to support international calls for all such cargoes to be banned.

This follows appeals by Greenpeace International, in conjunction with other environmental organisations, for the governments of France, Japan and the United States to conduct a detailed environmental assessment of the risks and dangers of the shipment. 

Greenpeace claims the cargo is the most concentrated, radioactive waste ever transported and the release of even a small fraction of this material could result in an environmental and public health disaster.

After receiving a briefing from Greenpeace International, the Cape Town- based Environment Monitoring Group has called on the government to make public information received about the forthcoming shipment, and to describe any contingency plans it has to deal with the impending shipment.

Until now the exact route of the ship has been kept secret.

The shipment is the result of an international agreement by the French and British governments to send back to Japan nuclear waste that has been generated by reprocessing Japanese spent nuclear fuel in Europe.

In the period between November 1992 to January 1993 a shipment containing hundreds of kilograms of weapons-usable plutonium passed the Cape Coast on board the vessel "Akatsuki Maru".

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone: (011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


48 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Spy Drama: The Show's Not Over Till The Fat Man Sings


LENGTH: 4400 words


 

Weekly Mail

February 24, 1995

by Stefaans Brummer

ONE-TIME spy Craig Williamson's revelations about the March 1982 bombing of the ANC offices in London do not go farenough, former police Security Branch colleagues say. They charged this week that former Law and Order Minister Louis le Grange approved the plan after an approach by then security branch head General Johan Coetzee.

Two top-ranking former members of the Branch pointed out that Le Grange's advance knowledge of the bombing raid, carried out by seven security policemen including Williamson, virtually assured that the State Security Council and other cabinet members would have known.

Their claims corroborated a statement made this week by outgoing police commissioner General Johan van der Merwe that the Security Branch would not have engaged in operations of the kind without the approval of the State Security Council, the cabinet committee that managed the apartheid state's security interests.

Confessions about the London bomb, as well as two parcel bombs that killed Ruth First, Jeanette Schoon and Schoon's young daughter, Katryn, in Angola and Mozambique, this week drew hefty denials from politicians, who said if the claims were true they had nothing to do with it. 

But a former security police officer -- he asked not to be named but was at the time part of the "Sanhedrin", the executive management of the security branch -- said he had seen a memo before the raid from General Coetzee (who later became commissioner of police, and is now head of the police academy at Graaff Reinet) to Le Grange, in which the plans for the London raid were discussed.

He said Le Grange rejected the first version of the plan on the grounds that it was "too risky"; it was likely to be traced back to South Africa. But Coetzee proposed new plans, which included each member of the raid party being issued with more than one false passport to facilitate escape, and gave Le Grange an assurance that the bomb would be detonated at a time when lives were not likely to be lost. Le Grange then approved the plan.

The former officer said the correspondence made it clear that diplomatic channels would be used to send the explosives to London, and that the South African embassy there would be used in the plan.

Williamson said in his "confession" to The Observer newspaper in London on Sunday that the parts for the bomb had been transported by diplomatic bag, and that it had been assembled at the South African embassy in London.

The Observer article quoted Williamson as saying the raid, as well as the parcel bombs that killed First and Schoon, had been ordered or commanded by Colonel Piet Goosen, who died some years ago. Williamson disputed assertions independently made to The Observer that Coetzee -- who was his mentor and is still thought to be a good friend -- had given the orders.

The former officer said the extra passports were issued by police Brigadier Andre Beukes, then a captain in the Security Branch, and that the explosives had been stashed in a cake tin in the diplomatic bag, and addressed to an employee of the London embassy who co-operated with the security branch.

He said it appeared then-ambassador Marais Steyn had not known about the assembly of the bomb under his nose, but that "it was the way it was" that Le Grange would have cleared the project with the State Security Council and cabinet colleagues.

Another former top Security Branch officer agreed, saying Goosen -- who was group head of a number of Security Branch units that included the intelligence unit which Williamson commanded -- could not have "started a war on his own". For a project of that nature, a "commissioner-minister memo" was necessary.

He said the plan would probably have been thought up by the intelligence section and Williamson, but that it would have had to be approved, in sequence, by Goosen, by Coetzee as Security Branch chief, by the commissioner of police, and by the minister. He said the fact that all seven had been awarded medals for bravery by Le Grange in September that year corroborated other evidence that Le Grange had approved the project.

Both charged that Williamson, by naming Goosen as the most senior person involved, was "protecting" Coetzee. Neither Coetzee nor Williamson could be contacted for comment. Williamson was said to be in Mozambique, while Coetzee was on leave from the police academy this week.

Goosen, who died about two years ago, first gained notoriety as the man in charge of the interrogation in which black consciousness leader Steve Biko was beaten to death in 1977.

Others named by Williamson as having been involved in the London bombing, apart from himself, were Eugene de Kock, the former Vlakplaas unit commander who this week went on trial on 121 Third Force-related and other charges, then-Warrant- Officer Jerry Raven (who now runs a shop in Pretoria and was named by Williamson to have set the London bomb and fitted the parcel bombs), Jimmy Taylor, John Adam and Vic McPherson, a serving police colonel.

Williamson first made his "confession" to the ANC intelligence wing late last year, saying the new governing party had "a right to know". This confession was leaked to The Observer correspondent Phillip van Niekerk, who confronted Williamson with it.

Williamson then agreed to talk, saying of the London bomb: "Jerry Raven and one of the others actually positioned the bomb."

Williamson said there had been a special regional interception unit at Jan Smuts airport that sorted all the mail in Southern Africa, putting aside letters whose addresses included certain names, acronyms or organisations."Everything went through Jan Smuts," he said.

A parcel from a United Nations agency in Lesotho addressed to Slovo in Maputo was intercepted. It was taken to Wachthuis, the police headquarters in Pretoria, where a small explosive device was fitted. "Some weeks later, a device went off in Maputo and killed her (First). The logical conclusion was that it was that device."

Williamson told The Observer that the killing of activist Schoon and her six- year-old daughter, blown up by a parcel bomb in the Angolan city of Lubango in June 1984, was, like the First killing, aimed at her husband.

He said a parcel from Gaborone to Angola, addressed to Marius Schoon, had been brought to his unit. "They said, right, here is this parcel from the ANC in Gaborone to Marius Schoon in Lubango. Doctor it. We doctored it and gave it back to them, and that was that."

Williamson said the death of Schoon and her daughter disillusioned him with police work. "That was the end of my career." He subsequently joined Military Intelligence, where he hoped to do "proper intelligence work".

Williamson said that after the First killing a "stratcom" (a "strategic communication", or propaganda project) to plant the story that Slovo had killed his wife was devised. It was claimed that First had been "causing all sorts of trouble in the Communist Party central committee".

The story was published in the Johannesburg daily The Star in 1984. Later Slovo successfully sued the newspaper.

Former Sunday Times reporter Stephan Terblanche this week confirmed Williamson had told journalists after First's death that Slovo had been responsible.

While not reported in the Observer article, Williamson has said that the First killing was not done by the police alone; a specialist unit of the Defence Force had helped transport the parcel to Mozambique.

Spy Drama II: The web of 'stratcoms'

by Stefaans Brummer

THE all-pervasive influence of South Africa's securocrat chiefs in the mid- 1980s -- through an intricate web of covert propaganda projects -- has been revealed in a classified State Security Council document released by former spy Craig Williamson.

The 1984 document audits "strategic communication" (stratcom) projects run by the police, the military and the Department of Foreign Affairs under the supervision of the State Security Council.

The police oversaw projects such as The Aida Parker Newsletter. The rightwing newsletter was not started by the police, but the document says police "are currently using it and much success is being achieved with propaganda against the ANC".

The Department of Foreign Affairs ran a number of overseas projects, including a West German news service aimed at "countering ... negative reporting on South Africa".

Among the South African Defence Force projects were:

* Project Guano, intended "to build the image of the security services among all population groups";

* Project Elevate, to give support to Malawi's President Kamuzu Banda;

* Project Santa, which co-ordinated military help to the government of Swaziland;

* Project Seeppot (soap pot), intended to influence the media and create front organisations to boost security aims;

* Project Whale, which tried to build the image of Unita leader Jonas Savimbi;

* Project Drama, to build the image of the Zipra opposition in Zimbabwe;

* Project Balalaika, to harm the morale of Cuban troops in Angola.

* Project Lake, to raise suspicion in Zimbabwe about the government of Robert Mugabe and "inculcate dissatisfaction with the system of government".

* Project Zodiac, to "use the reverend Ndabaninge Sithole and his party to sow dissatisfaction with the Zimbabwe government".

* Project Bisen, to raise suspicion internationally about the Lesotho government of Chief Leabua Jonathan and damage his authority among the people of Lesotho.

* A large number of "church and cultural" projects, aimed at countering the influence of liberation theology, discrediting cultural enemies of the apartheid state or building "moderate" values. "Africa" churches were, for example, "influenced by means of front organisations such as Geopende Deure (Opened Doors)" in an operation called Project Anvil, while "revolutionary theology" in the Catholic Church was countered by a front organisation called Total Family Planning.

These propaganda projects -- known in security parlance as "stratcoms" -- were aimed to influence attitudes and events in all spheres of South African life, influence international opinion, and damage the "enemies" of South Africa. Almost 2 000 SADF members, in addition to numerous employees of other government departments, were at the time working on stratcom projects, and the budget ran into tens of millions of rands.

Front organisations, covert propaganda and the media were extensively used, and years after the "Infogate" scandal, covert support was still being given to publications to influence opinion, the document reveals.

Authored by South Africa's top 12 security brokers - including then-chief of the SADF General Constand Viljoen, National Intelligence head Dr Niel Barnard, Foreign Affairs director-general J van Dalsen and police commissioner General Johan Coetzee - the document was the result of a study which aimed to improve inter- departmental co-operation in the implementation of stratcom projects.

The authors call strategic communication "one of the state's mightiest weapons in recent years".

The document says the police were "currently involved on covert territory in a wide range of stategic communication actions intended to fight the enemies of the RSA on all terrains". Police projects included:

* The Security Forces Support Committee: It was started to counter the Detainees' Parents Support Committee and the Black Sash and was "run" by the police in co-operation with the SADF.

* The Aida Parker Newsletter: The document says although the right-wing newsletter was not started by police, police "are currently using it and much success is being achieved with propaganda against the ANC". The SADF, according to the document, also gave "inputs".

* Industry International: This was a newsletter, about to be launched at the time, which would have been run from London.

* SABC - Target Terrorism: The document says this was a programme initiated by the police and police played "a leading role in providing information to the SABC".

* A range of covert projects against the United Democratic Front, the student bodies Nusas and Cosas, the Azanian Peoples' Organisation, the SA Council of Churches, trade unions and community organisations, "mainly with the aim of ... impeding their organisational capacity".

The Department of Foreign Affairs ran a number of projects to "improve" South Africa's image abroad. They included:

* Radar: This was a Paris-based organisation headed by one Leon Delbecque, "mainly focused, by means of psychological warfare, to boost South Africa's case in Europe and the European Parliament, and to counter propaganda actions originating from the United Nations and the Organisation of African Unity".

* A West-German news service, headed by one Jo(umlaut)rg Wilhelmy, aimed at "nautralising or countering the extremely negative reporting on South Africa" in the German-speaking countries of Western Europe.

* Projects to invite and sponsor opinion formers, decision makers and experts to South Africa. While Foreign Affairs sponsored the trips, the guests often did not know the true origin of the invitation or sponsorship, as these were chanelled through other organisations.

* Three projects on the sponsoring, acquisition and distribution of "expert" publications, locally and overseas, "on subjects that can boost the case of South Africa, without the state being linked" to the publications.

* Agreements with the German PR firm Hennenhoffer to invite top foreigners to South Africa and the French PR firm Aderi to "improve South Africa's image overseas".

* A yearly contribution to the Institute for Strategic Studies to "boost issues affecting South Africa internationally" by means of conferences and publications.

* Financial help to the Southern African Forum.

The SADF made by far the greatest contribution to stratcom projects, and was allocated hard propaganda - "the co-ordinated management of propaganda, counter- propaganda and information supply, aiming to influence opinions, feelings, attitudes and actions of neutrals, allies and enemies" - inside South Africa.

Significantly, other government departments and "institutions such as the SABC" could be "tasked to give the necessary support to the SADF in terms of, for example, personnel, technical support, etc".

SADF projects were divided into the categories of "information operations", "motivation" and "psychological operations". Information operations included:

* Projects with codenames like Alborak, Tadpole, Girasol and Becket, all intended to "create climate" for defined purposes such as military co-operation with homeland governments, or to start a Southern African Military Treaty Organisation. Project Guano's - perhaps appropriately-named - aim was "to build the image of the security services among all population groups".

Motivational operations included:

* Overt projects named Harmonic, Dipole, Honey Ant, Weefspoel, Watent and Bates, with the aim of influencing categories of people like school headmasters, youth and womens' groups.

* Project Elevate, which gave support to Malawi's President H Kamuzu Banda.

* Project Tsafoon, which had to influence whites in the old South West Africa positively as regarded their future there.

* Project Canteen, which was aimed at hiding South Africa's involvement in building a military base in Gabon.

* Project Santa, which co-ordinated military help to the government of Swaziland.

* Project Arianne, which used a Moroccan newspaper to build South Africa's image as an African power".

* Project Flask, intended to boost South Africa's image as "reliable negotiator" in Iraq.

* Project Layer, which co-ordinated and propagated military co-operation between South Africa and Israel.

Psychological operations included:

* Project Seeppot (soap pot), intended to influence the media and create front organisations to boost security aims by means of newsletters, magazines etc.

* Project Diver, which intended to influence television and film organisations.

* Project Babushka, which used student front organisations to counter Nusas, the Black Students Society and "other radical organisations such as the UDF".

* Project Weiveld, which aimed, nationally and internationally, to "psychologically disrupt" the ANC and organisations including SACOS, the UDF, Cosas and Azapo.

* Project Breakwater, which aimed to "psychologically disrupt" Swapo.

* Project Destitute/Yam, which tried to boost the image of Angolan rebel movement Unita.

* Project Whale, which tried to build the image of Unita leader Jonas Savimbi.

* Project Capsize, which aimed to boost the image of the BCP-opposition in Lesotho.

* Project Drama, to build the image of the ZPRA-opposition in Zimbabwe.

* Project Detach, to sow dissatisfaction with the MPLA-government in Angola.

* Project Balalaika, to harm the morale of Cuban troops in Angola.

* Project Lake, to raise suspicion in Zimbabwe about the government of Robert Mugabe and "inculcate dissatisfaction with the system of government".

* Project Zodiac, to "use the reverend Ndabaninge Sithole and his party to sow dissatisfaction with the Zimbabwe government".

* Project Bisen, to raise suspicion internationally about the Lesotho government of Chief Leabua Jonathan and damage his authority among the people of Lesotho.

* A large number of "church and cultural" projects, aimed at countering the influence of liberation theology, discrediting cultural enemies of the apartheid state or building "moderate" values. "Africa" churches were, for example, "influenced by means of front organisations such as Geopende Deure (Opened Doors)" in an operation called Project Anvil, while "revolutionary theology" in the Catholic Church was countered by a front organisation called Total Family Planning.

Project Serato tried to discredit Bishop Desmond Tutu and Alan Boesak nationally and internationally and "counter their influence", while Project Wanmeul's aim was "to use the Zion Christian Church for anti-revolutionary activities".

Project Wolga's aim was to "use an inter-denominational organisation" to boost the "moderate theological ethical views that exist in the Reformed Churches".

A number of "supporting service" projects were also run by the SADF, with aims like training selected members of all government departments in propaganda techniques, to train leaders of resistance movements in neighbouring states and selected politicians and others in "public administration of a state founded on democracy and a free market economic system", or to "train and place" selected leaders in specifically targeted communities.

Supporting services also included the management of high-powered radio transmitters to transmit propaganda and block "enemy propaganda".

The 12-man committee, in its findings, suggested that greater co-ordination could be achieved by establishing a committee, chaired by the Prime Minister (then PW Botha) and including the ministers of Foreign Affairs, Law and Order and Defence, as well as the head of National Intelligence, the commissioner of police, the director-general of Foreign Affairs, the chief of the SADF and the secretary of the State Security Council, to meet at least twice a year to evaluate terrains of strategic communication.

A working group, consisting of the security bosses but excluding their political bosses, were to meet more often to evaluate projects and propose new projects.

The scale of Strategic Communication becomes apparent in the large numbers of government employees who were involved in it. It appears from the document that a State Security Council directive of 1980 envisaged a Strategic Communication personnel complement of 2 651, of which the SADF in 1984 was providing 1 931.

A budgetary addendum to the document shows that the costs of a planned expansion of the programme alone would be R53-million.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone: (011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.
