Africa News


February, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: When Thabo Came To Winnie's Rescue


LENGTH: 1574 words


 

The Weekly Mail & Guardian

February 17, 1995

by Mark Gevisser

President Nelson Mandela was so "fed up" with the ill- discipline and unaccountability of his estranged wife, Winnie Mandela, that he was resolved to drop her from the cabinet until persuaded otherwise by several ANC leaders, including Thabo Mbeki, the deputy president.

At his Sunday meeting with the 11 senior ANC women who resigned their positions on the Women's League national executive committee (NEC) in protest against Winnie Mandela's leadership, the president said that, following her remarks at the funeral of Warrant Officer Jabulani Xaba, he was absolutely firm about firing her.

He told the women he had consulted with the seven ANC regional premiers, and all but one of them had agreed that the move was long overdue. He would have relieved her of her duties immediately, he said, were it not for "comrades" having "restrained" him.

The result was a meeting, last Thursday, of all ANC ministers and senior officials, and the "retract, resign or be fired" ultimatum that was given to Winnie Mandela the next day. 

A senior source in the ANC alleges that Deputy- President Thabo Mbeki played a critical behind-the-scenes role in convincing Mandela not to act rashly and to consult more widely before taking any action. Mbeki was then responsible for drafting the letter of apology that Winnie Mandela finally signed.

Mbeki's director of communications, Thami Ntintile, counters, however, that "no such role" was played by Mbeki. The decision to offer Winnie Mandela a choice was "made at a meeting called by President Mandela last Thursday. It was on the basis of the inputs made by several people at that meeting that the president made his decision."

The debate over her future cuts to the heart of a core ANC dilemma: how to keep troublesome ANC members in line without alienating vital constituencies and encouraging factionalism. While there are those in the ANC who believe that people like Winnie Mandela, Allan Boesak and Peter Mokaba need to be jettisoned once and for all, "so that they stop coming back to haunt us", in the words of one NEC member, there are others who believe that unity must be kept at all costs.

Negotiating between these two seemingly exclusive prerogatives, Mbeki spent his week shuttling between the Mandelas, and attempting to temper both the irascibility of the president and the exasperation of the 11 resigned Women's League NEC members.

Perhaps his mediatory role was appropriate, given that he is the ANC's political manager. But he too encompasses a dilemma: on the one hand, the shoot- from-the-hip antics of Winnie Mandela, Bantu Holomisa and Mokaba cannot but work against his primary appeal as the man who will bring international capital to South Africa; on the other, he has risen to the position of Mandela's successor in no small part because of the support of the Women's League and the Youth League; support delivered either directly by Winnie Mandela or by her lieutenants.

At the meeting at which the 11 executive members resigned from the Women's League, held last Saturday, Mbeki -- who was called in to troubleshoot -- urged them to consider party unity above all else.

Said one of the women: "It felt as if we were being rapped over the knuckles; as if we were being condemned for being divisive. He seemed to be saying that we should not cause trouble and just go quietly, by not standing for office. It was as if we were being condemned for being good comrades, and raising important issues ..."

When Mandela met them the next day, the message was altogether different: "He seemed much more willing to listen to our concerns, and gave the impression that the wrong people were leaving the Women's League." The result is a meeting of the entire league executive, along with the ANC's national leadership, to take place tomorrow.

What upsets those who have resigned, says another of the women, is that "our battle is being denigrated as a cat fight in the Women's League, and we are being accused of resigning because we are 'anti-Winnie'. It's just not true. We resigned because we felt we needed to make a vital and urgent point about cleanness and accountability in leadership."

The rift within the Women's League goes back to 1992, when the then-NEC suspended the entire PWV regional executive, of which Winnie Mandela was chair. This action was taken after it was proved that she had used the league to mount a demonstration against the ANC after being suspended from her post as social welfare head. Shortly thereafter, she resigned all her positions in the ANC.

On the NEC that suspended her were Baleka Kgositsile, then secretary general, and Nosiviwe Mapisa, current secretary general. Mandela saw them as part of a "cabal" plotting to destroy her. The next year, she had begun her stunning political rehabilitation by winning the presidency of the very Women's League that had suspended her.

Winnie Mandela opened the very first NEC meeting she chaired, in early 1994, by accusing colleagues of disloyalty, claiming that she had in her possession a report from ANC security "proving" that a group from the previous NEC had met in Welkom to plot her downfall. "It was the first any of us had heard of this," says one of the women. "But it set the tone of paranoia and back-biting from the start."

Indeed, the Women's League has turned, under her stewardship, from being a powerful lobby for gender issues to being a moribund and ineffective body that has failed to represent women's issues either in parliament or to the government.

From 1991 to 1993, when Kgositsile was secretary general, the league lobbied successfully for a 30 percent quota of elected female officials and for gender parity in negotiating teams at the World Trade Centre. Two of those who resigned last weekend -- Kgositsile and Mavivi Manzini -- were the ANC's female negotiators. Furthermore, the league generated reams of policy -- on subjects ranging from reproductive rights to land issues -- that assisted the ANC in drafting its gender provisions of the reconstruction and development programme.

Most importantly, the Women's League launched the National Women's Coalition -- a powerful national non-partisan women's lobby that was disbanded last year, largely due to the fact that the league, under its new political leadership of Winnie Mandela and Thandi Modise, decided to withdraw its support for it.

At the conference at which Mandela was elected in 1993, the NEC was mandated to come up with a programme of action. The work, however, has yet to be done. "The tragedy," says one of those who resigned, "is that all this strife has rendered us stagnant. Instead of having a positive input on the RDP and being a strong lobby for gender rights in government, what have we been doing? Talking about setting up casinos for foreign tourists!"

The woman does not believe that she or any of her colleagues will rejoin the league executive for as long as Mandela is president: "I suppose we have come to see that our work in the league is not the only way to advance the cause of women. We are ministers and MPs; we'll continue to do our work outside the league."

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone: (011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Africa News


February, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Countdown to a New Constitution


LENGTH: 3134 words


 

New Nation (Johannesburg)

January 20, 1995

A little over 14 months ago, 19 weary leaders at the World Trade Centre ushered South Africa into a new political era with a ceremonial nod, which signaled their acceptance of the interim Constitution.

In just three days from now, the Constitutional Assembly (CA), made up of representatives elected in terms of that interim constitution, will initiate yet another process and set in motion the writing of the country's final constitution.

They have less than 18 months to complete their task.

And, contrary to what many South Africans might believe, the task will be much more formidable than simply effecting a few amendments to the Interim Constitution.

Almost every aspect addressed by the Interim Constitution will be thoroughly interrogated during the next 18 months by the six theme committees set up by the CA. 

They will for example debate issues related to the character of the state, the structure of the state, the relationship between national, provincial and local government and even fundamental rights.

Deputy chairperson on Constitutional Assembly and National Party member, Leon Wessels, says the search for the constitutional formula which will ensure the most representative and workable democracy will no doubt focus the CA's attention most acutely.

"The challenge is how to ensure proper representation in a democratic state of all its people."

Wessels pointed to what he describes as the "adversarial nature" of a democratic system in which a party winning 51 percent of the vote exercises 100 percent of the power.

"These are the rough edges of democracy that we will have to smooth over through debate," he says.

This debate will have a crucial bearing on the concept of power sharing on which the principle of government of national unity (GNU) currently rests.

And it will, no doubt, be a lively debate because there is clearly no consensus among the country's major parties on whether to continue with the government of national unity or not.

Eastern Transvaal premier and ANC constitutional expert Matthew Phosa agrees that one of the most fundamental debates that will occupy the CA will be around the structure of the executive. "This relates to whether we still continue with the concept of the government of national unity-do we abandon it or do we find a way of accommodating it," Phosa says.

"We (the ANC) want to stress that democracy should mean democracy and it should not be stifled by all sorts of frills - government should unambiguously reflect the principle of majority rule."

But he adds that the ANC "would be prepared to make the necessary compromises as dictated by the objective situation in the country."

Phosa says he would favour a situation where minorities are accommodated in the executive but not in the rigid way that it is currently done "because that tends to stifle the democratic process."

One possible way to achieve this is to limit the obligation on the part of majority parties to reach consensus at executive level on governance broadly.

"But we should take them (minorities) on board and be inclusive and consultative in the our practice of governance," Phosa explains.

He adds that the majority party, which he is convinced will continue to be the ANC, should be sensitive to the objective fears of other people and therefore be inclusive in its style of governance.

Although the National Party has yet to debate the issue formally at its federal congress this week, there is some support within its ranks for a system of coalition government.

The NP's Fanus Schoeman says the NP has not yet taken a final decision on whether the GNU should continue to be a feature of the final constitution.

He reportedly said that it was too early to take a position because the GNU was working well at the moment.

Inkatha Freedom Party negotiator Walter Felgate says his party would certainly not want the principle of the GNU to be carried over into the final constitution.

He argues that the GNU is a farce and a reflection of a weak democracy.

Another debate that will certainly exercise the minds of constitution makers, according to Phosa, will be around finding a way to introduce fundamental transformation at administrative level.

"The whole question was debated at (the ANC) conference and some of us said that the only way of addressing it is to remove the protection on the civil service and people should be employed on merit," says Phosa.

"We should also ensure that the civil service unequivocally represents the nation. At the moment, we are having to endure a very painful and unjust distortion in the composition of the civil service," he says.

Phosa adds that the third important issue that will come up for debate is the arrangement of powers and functions between the national government, the provinces and local administrations.

"I think we should more or less retain the powers of the provinces as they are but take the issue a step further and create a facilitating or liaison mechanism in provinces to ensure effective governance and implementation of central government policy."

Phosa says some in central government have recognised the importance of liaison structures in areas where provincial governments do not have powers and have already started forming these structures.

Foreign minister Alfred Nzo has already initiated the formation of foreign affairs liaison structures at provincial level. His land affairs counterpart Derek Hanekom has initiated a similar process for the formation of land liaison structures.

Phosa says the constitutional debate will also have to focus on whether the country needs the senate or not.

If the CA decides that the country does in fact need a senate, it will have to define its purpose more clearly.

The senate in its current role is no more than a structure that rubber stamps decisions of the National Assembly.

A key question that will have to be answered in the course of this debate is whether senators represent the province or their political parties.

In the Australian system, senators represent their respective parties. In South Africa, senators come from the provinces but at a national level they represent political parties.

This seemingly contradictory character of the senate will have to addressed in formulating the final constitution.

The NP would certainly favour a situation where senators represent the provinces, rather than their political parties.

While the debate on the senate is far from over, a considerable body of opinion believes that the senate should be retained.

It is important to the extent that all areas of the country should be guaranteed representation in the national legislature. It is improbable that the national legislature would be able to draw representatives from all parts of the country if the senate is abolished.

If however, the senate is retained, its functions will have to be very clearly spelt out if it is to have any relevance in the national legislature.

Senators will have to be given specific powers and functions that go beyond rubber stamping decisions of the executive and National Assembly.

This does not suggest that senators should have uniform powers across the board. It is possible, for example, that senators could be given less powers in areas of fiscal policy and legislation and more powers on questions of social welfare or science and technology.

Another question that is likely to arise is whether the new constitution should redefine the size of the parliament, currently made up of 400 members of the National Assembly and 90 senators.

It has in the past been suggested that parliament is far too big.

On the issue of fundamental rights, Wessels says that, while the chapter on fundamental rights in the constitution already addresses many issues relating to the rights of individuals, these have yet to be tested in practice.

At the same time, the final constitution will have to accommodate a complete Bill of Rights rather than just a chapter.

One example, he says, relates to the question of voluntary association of individuals. The question that will have to be answered is whether this right allows for Afrikaners, for example, to gather themselves into an exclusive group or not and whether such voluntary association would not promote racism.

An area which will also focus the minds of the constitution makers is defining second and third generation rights.

Second generation rights would include socio-economic rights such as the right to work.

Wessels says if this right is entrenched in the constitution through the Bill of Rights, the question that will have to be answered is: who provides the work.

An example of a third generation right is an individual's right to live and work in an unpolluted environment.

While all of this suggests that the final constitution could differ radically from the interim document, members of the CA will need to conduct their debates within the confines of the constitutional principles finalised by the multi-party talks on November 17, 1993.

Phosa says, while this is true, parties should be mature enough to amend principles if the need arises and should not allow their efforts to be hamstrung by limitations that the principles could place on the constitution-making process.

But problems may well arise if parties in the CA disagree on amendments to principles they believe are "cast in stone". However, according to Phosa, the principles are defined in broad enough terms and may not need to be amended.

Wessels agrees, saying the principles are not narrowly defined and will allow considerable scope for debate. Citing the example of the principle which demands that the final constitution allows for democratically elected government at national, provincial and local level, Wessels says it is not prescriptive at all and allows for considerable amount of debate on the relationship between the three levels of government.

Phosa nevertheless cautions that, in the event there is disagreement on amendments, the constitution-making process could experience serious delays, especially if the issue becomes the subject of court action.

At the same time, he says, we should not exclude the possibility of differences in the interpretation of the constitutional principles ending up in court.

With the conclusion of these debates, South Africa will emerge with a final constitution. If all goes according to plan, this could happen in 18 months from now.

But there is insufficient clarity on whether the new constitution will immediately come into effect or not.

In terms of the current consensus, the interim constitution will remain in force for only two years.

This could confront the current government of national unity with a serious constitutional crisis, especially if the new constitution jettisons the principle of power sharing.

Phosa agrees, saying if the final constitution is completed before the five year term of he current government expires, it could precipitate problems for the GNU.

"We could have problems if you cut short the mandate of politicians to less than five years for which they have been elected. It could even create instability and potential for conflict," Phosa argues.

Ways will have to be found, if the new constitution rejects the principle of government of national unity, to facilitate the co-existence of old and new principles until 1999 when the next round of elections are due.

However, Phosa says that provincial governments could be sacrificed and earlier elections, costs permitting, could be held at a regional level, possibly by 1998.

Phosa argues that an early provincial election could also allow national government the opportunity to better prepare for the provinces. "One of the problems after the 1994 April elections was the national government was totally unprepared for the provincial governments and we each had to use our common sense to get the work done. That is why there is uneven development at the moment."

While it is at the level of the theme committees that much of the debates will take place, constitution makers are determined to give tangible meaning to past rhetoric of public participation in the process.

Lack of public participation in the drafting of the Interim Constitution was severely criticised as one of the most important shortcomings of the previous process.

University of Cape Town political scientist David Welsh said at the time of the adoption of the Interim Constitution that despite the critical importance of the document, there was no opportunity for wide-ranging public debate.

"What scares me is that this might be a kind of harbinger of the style of government that we can expect in the future. I hope I'm wrong about that. But I do have an uneasy feeling that this kind of contemptuous attitude towards the public may just become part of our political culture," he warned at the time.

The CA seems to have come up with the perfect answer to Welsh's concerns and have built in to the process its "Public Participation Programme".

It is envisaged that every weekend, members of the CA will travel to townships, villages, squatter camps and suburbs to canvass the views of all sectors of the population.

It is through these forums that ordinary people will be able to make their contribution to the constitution making proves.

While the plan certainly appears noble in character, there are concerns about its practical merits.

Past experiences have shown that the tendency at leadership level during policy formulating exercises is to move away from popular participation, not because of a lack of commitment to democracy and transparency, but because of the technical nature of the process and time constraints.

A serious obstacle that will confront the CA in the implementation of its programme for popular participation is the lack of adequate mass based structures at almost every level.

Organs of civil society will no doubt keep a close watch to see to what extent the concerns of their respective constituencies will find expression in the final constitution.

NEW NATION is published at Darragh House 13 Wanders St. Johannesburg Tel: (011) 333-2711 Telex: 482226 Fax: (011) 889-0630


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.
