Africa News


February, 1995


RWANDA: Security Council Decides Arusha To Be Seat of Tribunal For Rwanda; Council Unanimously Adoppts Resolution 977


LENGTH: 614 words


 

Reposted by Africa Policy Information Center

February 22, 1995

The Security Council this morning decided that Arusha, United Republic of Tanzania, will be the seat of the International Tribunal for Rwanda, subject to the conclusion of appropriate arrangements between the Tanzanian Government and the United Nations.

The Council, by unanimously adopting resolution 977 (1995),acted on the recommendation of the Secretary-General, who had based his determination on the criteria of justice and fairness, and administrative efficiency and economy. The Council also noted the willingness of the Government of Rwanda to cooperate with the Tribunal. 

Speaking before the resolution was adopted, Rwanda's Representative Manzi Bakuramutsa, said that he did not share the view expressed in the Secretary- General's report that the requirements of justice and fairness meant that the Tribunal should be seated outside Rwanda. However, despite its misgivings on the issue, his Government would cooperate with the Tribunal to help ensure that those who had committed genocide in the country were brought to justice.

The International Tribunal for Rwanda was established by Security Council resolution 955 of 8 November 1994 to prosecute persons responsible for genocide and other violations of international humanitarian law committed in Rwanda and Rwandese citizens responsible for such acts in neighbouring States between 1 January 1994 and 31 December 1994. The Tribunal, according to its statute, shall consist of: two Trial Chambers, each made up of three judges elected by the General Assembly to four-year terms, and a five-judge Appeals Chamber appointed by the President of the Tribunal;the Prosecutor, who will be responsible for investigating and prosecuting violations of international humanitarian law; and a Registry which will be responsible for administering and servicing the Tribunal.

According to the Secretary-General's report on the Tribunal's seat, today's action signals the beginning of the second phase in its operations, meaning that the process of electing the six trial judges could begin. The Appeals Chamber, which it shares with the International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, is already in place.

The Tribunal's first stage of operations began with last year's creation of the Investigative/Prosecutorial Unit in Kigali. A Deputy Prosecutor, Honore Rakotomanana (Madagascar),has been appointed. The office of the Prosecutor will be filled by the Prosecutor of the International Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, Richard J. Goldstone.

Security Council SC/5998 3502nd Meeting 22 February 1995.

This material is reposted for wider distribution by the Africa Policy Information Center (APIC), affiliated with the Washington Office on Africa (WOA). Contact: 110 Maryland Ave. NE, #112, Washington, DC 20002 Tel: (202) 546-7961 Fax: (202) 546-1545 Email: woa@igc.apc.org


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


52 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


RWANDA: Rwanda: Many Faces Of The Aftermath of Genocide


LENGTH: 2374 words


 

All Africa Conference of Chruches

February 16, 1995

One has to look carefully to see signs of the hellish killing fields that were Rwanda six months ago. Kigali's streets are smooth, the bomb-craters nowhere to be seen as speeding aid vehicles, flags and stickers waving their humanitarian greetings, rush madly from one meeting to another. Buildings pock-marked and windowless once again exude the sleek self-confidence and optimism that once made Kigali the darling of development agencies.

There is water and electricity in greater supply than neighbouring countries. Phones work most of the time. Streets are well lit and safe. More than 250,000 people live here now, more than half the population of pre-1994 days. 

Out in the rural areas, the fertile valleys and hills are green, ready for the planting season that is just beginning. Enormous herds of long-horned cattle have returned to clog the undulating hills near Tanzania. Once-deserted villages and roads are filled with people bartering, smoking their pipes, drinking beer in breaks between renovating their homes. Women, valleys and terraced green hillsides.

A first-time visitor from America asks "Where was the was? "And so, one points out the shell-shattered roof of the Presbyterian Church, the few unrepaired buildings with windows blown out and the severely damaged former National Assembly buildings. That is the only material evidence. In the hills if one looks closely, rubble-filled gaps in the rows of mudhouses can be seen where once Tutsi peasants eked out a precarious living with their Hutu neighbours in land-hungry Rwanda before the genocide that killed a million people last year.

There are still a few church compounds left where the skeletons of those murdered in Africa's worst genocide in history are evident. Most have been unceremoniously buried in anonymous mass graves, soon to be symbolically buried by churches still in the agony of their own divisions and failures.

One church compound at Nyarubuye still has some 600 or more remains of people hacked to death by matches and hoes, their bones slashed and broken in pieces. Grass hides the remains, the stench of death has gone away, flowers push through the corpses. The new government says it will preserve Nyarubuyeas a memorial to the genocide, which traumatized a country half the size of Switzerland.

There is, however, more than one face to Rwanda. Across the borders with Zaire, Tanzania and Burundi in muddy, fetid refugee camps more than a million Hutu refugees live in smoldering rage, unable or unwilling to reclaim the land they would normally be planting. Most of them arrived last year --although a few still trickle in along the porous frontiers --in two convulsive waves convinced they would be slaughtered in revenge by the victorious rebel Rwanda Patriotic Front (RPF)which drove the extremist interim government from power and established a Hutu-Tutsi administration in Kigali in July, 1994.

These are the "new refugees" in government parlance, those who are innocent victims, those who were implicated in the genocide and those whom the murderous militias and former army and government control through a variety of means including control of food distribution, coercion and outright terrorism. "We cannot go home, we will be killed if we do," one ragged woman in Eastern Zaire complains, as she rests from carrying a yellow jerry-can filled with dubious water. Another claims he tried to go back to his village from Cyanika, a camp in southwest Rwanda which the UN is trying to empty through Operation Return, and was threatened by soldiers of the Rwanda army.

These kinds of unsubstantiated stories are spread through the camps inside and outside Rwanda by the Hutu extremists who control the camps. UNAMIR (United Nations Assistance Mission in Rwanda) soldiers, mainly from Africa, offer the refugees and internally displaced a free ride home under military escort, enough rations for a month and some basic farm tools, but few are taking up the offer.

Then, there are the old refugees, Tutsis, who fled to Burundi and Uganda as far back as 1959 to escape the periodic massacres at the hands of successive Hutu dictatorships. The new government says some 600,000 of these have come home and that another 600,000 Hutus have returned. The UN simply says these figures are vastly inflated, probably more like 300,000. These two faces of Rwanda -- the optimistic, rebuilding, rehabilitating Tutsis and moderate Hutus who escaped the killings and the sullen, potentially explosive residents of the camps -- are both images of Rwanda today. The one has erased most of the surface scars of the brutal genocide and war which lasted for 10 murderous weeks from April to July last year. The other shields the hard core of killers (same say as few as 250, others as many as 30,000) who planned and executed the genocide and who are desperately trying to avoid the war crimes trials planned by the new government and a disorganized and faction- riddled UN.

"The leaders of the camps, unwittingly aided and abetted by the UN and the international humanitarian aid agencies hope that if they stall long enough, they will not have to pay for their actions. They also want to rebuild their army and militias to invade our country or destabilize it further, "says Christine Umutoni, the articulate young deputy minister of rehabilitation and reconstruction in the RFP-dominated government who, herself, lost more than 40 members of her immediate family during the genocide.

There is still another face to Rwanda, the 151 international humanitarian aid agencies which have swarmed into the tiny Central African country -- including the ecumenical Church World Action-Rwanda (CWA-R) an initiative of the Geneva-based Lutheran World Federation and the World Council of Churches. Most are donor-driven, others are extremely dubious including a number of U.S.-based fundamentalist sects blatantly exploiting a situation designed to raise easy funds from congregations in Europe and North America.

The more legitimate of these agencies, all coordinated in some way by the UNHCR (United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees), are caught in the middle, knowing they are helping killers in the camps but clinging to an outmoded or irrelevant humanitarianism which insists it is unfair to expect Hutus to return home until they are confident they will be safe from reprisals and that their land will still be theirs to till.

The government argues, and UNAMIR commanders seem to agree, that the refugees should be told the days of free food and water are soon to be over. If assistance were offered in the hills of Rwanda, rather than in the camps of Tanzania and Zaire, this argument goes, the people would follow it home.

"The fear of violence and revenge is nothing more than an excuse used by the old extremist government -- which says its only mistake was that it failed to finish off all the Tutsis-- to deny the reality of a new government or national unity, "says Umutoni from her spartan office devoid of the trappings of power seen in the agency compounds filled with vehicle, satellite phones, faxes and well-paid emergency professionals.

The agencies, some of whom simply do not register with Umotoni's ministry, generally reject this idea, claiming aid is neutral and people must be fed. Some also believe that the government in Kigali is prepared to use force to close camps through pre-emptive strikes, a position the new government denies. However, it reserves the right to engage in "hot pursuit" if militias launch guerrilla attacks from Zaire which has occurred near the border of the Great Lakes region.

The UNHCR's special representative in Rwanda, Canadian Carol Flaubert, is quoted as saying "Our job is to listen and support rather than thinking we can direct their movements. The level of aid in the camps, contrary to popular wisdom, is not really a factor in whether people return home or not."

Umutoni is less optimistic "The world forgot us too fast and now expects us to do too much, too soon, with too little support. Our biggest achievement to date is that we stopped the genocide and returned the country to some level of stability. You lose sight of this achievement in the North in your daily round of problems.

"We in government are convinced that the militias and members of the old genocidal regime must be separated from the refugees. We want them to come home. We welcome them and tell them they are secure. It is important that the old and new refugees return and are resettled. But the UN is unwilling to take the steps necessary, through a special police force, to keep the killers away from the refugees."

As Rwanda drifts away from the world's attention, with almost no functioning justice system, the demands for peace and reconciliation and healing of trauma are extremely difficult. "Everyone wants it but no one is sure how to do about it,: says a Tutsi priest asking for anonymity in fear that neglect by the international community for Rwanda's plight could result in further, even unintentional, violence. "We a reliving on top of a bomb and even one mistake could cause the explosion."

The government insists there can be no reconciliation without justice. Most of its supporters, including the main Catholic and Protestant churches, agree but they also accuse the international community of taking too long to set up the machinery needed to investigate the allegations and prepare for the international tribunal which may be set up in Arusha, Tanzania this year.

There are some 9,000 prisoners living in terrible conditions in Kigali's prison built for 2,000, many of them -- including two Catholic sisters and two priests -- arrested on hearsay evidence who cannot be tried because there are no magistrates or judges.

"Genocide is the whole world's problem. We could do this justice ourselves, but we think the world, which has a convention against genocide requiring governments to act against it, must make certain the whole world judged the criminals who planned this atrocity," says Umutoni.

If the tribunal is not launched properly and urgently, Rwandese fear that the old notion of impunity from crime will never be purged from Rwandese political culture. Amnesty is not an option for the government. It would only encourage acts of rough justice in the villages and individual acts of revenge, officials say.

A tribunal would also accomplish the task of separating the planners of the genocide from the innocent. Surviving Hutus, many of whom also lost family members, feel they all stand accused of genocide. "It is very painful to be a Hutu Tuesdays. The mass media paints us all as killers and rapists, but many of us tried very hard to saves lives," says Anglican Bishop Norman Kayumba, acting dean of the country's Episcopal bishops.

The tribunal could also serve as a deterrent to other countries in the world who see genocide as the "final solution" to their problems.

Meanwhile Rwanda's neighbours are fearful of further destabilization in Central and East Africa. Burundi, with a similar ethnic mix teeters on a knife edge as the government stumbles from crisis to crisis. Zaire is a scene of chaos and Tanzanian refugees seem settled in their Ngara camps for along time.

The international humanitarian community is divided and unfocused about what to do. The government is badly underesourced and needs help especially in resuscitating the justice system. The international community must lift its vision beyond aid to less glamourous but more essential development assistance if peace is to be assured and reconciliation effected. ends.

All Africa Conference of Churches, PO Box 14205, Nairobi, Kenya Tel: 254 2 44 3581 Fax: 254 2 44-3241 Ecunet: AACC Internet: AACC.PARTI@ecunet.org.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


53 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


NIGERIA: Drama in Port Harcourt


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

Newswatch

February 20, 1995

by Sam Olukoya

The Ogoni Anthem, "Aaboo Aaboo pa Ogoni"...(Rise up, Rise up, Ogoni...) rent the air as hundreds of people converged outside the Rivers State House of Assembly, Port Harcourt last Monday. The crowd which was there to witness the beginning of the trial of those alleged to have killed four Ogoni citizens also chanted such slogans as: "Ogoni must survive" and "Ken Saro-Wiwa must be free," to protest the trial.

In a moment of frenzy, the crowd defied security men and "seized" Gani Fawehinmi, a Lagos radical lawyer, carried him shoulder high and danced around with him, apparently to add colour to the protest. Though, security men had blocked the Boro-Port Harcourt highway early that morning to prevent the Ogonis from coming to demostrate at the trial venue, hundreds of them managed to reach Port Harcourt anyway. In fact, the crowd had stared gathering outside the trial venue as early as 6.00 a.m. 

As expectations grew, a black maria, escorted by policemen and soldiers, drove to the venue and made for a hidden part of the premises to discharge its human cargo. Only a photographer and a video camera man, both of them from Government House, Port Harcourt, were allowed to see Ken Saro-Wiwa, a playwright and leader of the Ogonis, alight from the black maria. "It was necessary to prevent something similar to the mistake they made in Abuja where they allowed Moshood Abiola, acclaimed winner of the June 12 1993 presidential election, to alight from a black maria in the full glare of everybody," a security man confided to "Newswatch".

Saro-Wiwa and four others -- Ledum Mittee, a legal practicioner and deputy president of MOSOP;Barinem Nubari Kiobel, a former commissioner in Rivers State; John Kpuinien, deputy president of National Youth Council of Ogoni, NYCOP, and Bambor Bera, a youth from Bera village, are facing a four count charge of murder under item 13 Schedule I Cap. 53 of Section 316 of the criminal code. They are accused of the murder of Albert Badey, a former secretary to the Rivers State government, Edward Kobani, Samuel Orage and Theophilus Orage.

Saro-Wiwa, who is first accused person, Mittee and Kiobel, second and third accused persons respectively, are alleged to have counselled and procured Kpuinien and Bera the fourth and fifth accused persons respectively, in company of others who are at large, to inflict grievous harm on participants at the council of chiefs meeting at Giokoo in Gokana, Rivers State, on May 21, last year. As a result of their action, the prosecution alleges, Badey, Kobani, and the Orage brothers were killed.

Philip Umeadi led three other lawyers for the prosecution, while Fawehinmi led 16 lawyers including Olisah Agbakoba and Femi Falana, two human rights activists, for the first, second, and fourth accused persons. The third accused person was represented by S.A. Arorogun. The fifth accused person was not represented.

Ibrahim Auta, a high court judge, and head of a three-man tribunal set up by the federal government to try the accused persons, left no one in doubt that the case must be quickly heard. He said it will continue daily until it ends. "Counsels should do sway with objections and motions that will affect the conduct of the case," he said.

But the proceedings ran into an early hitch with the non-representation of the fifth accused person by a counsel. Auta had persuaded Fawehinmi to represent him or get any of the human rights lawyers in his team to do the job. But Fawehinmi said it would be unprofessional to do so, since the accused person is also working for the prosecution as a witness. As a result Auta said the case will have to be adjourned for a day to enable the fifth accused person to get legal counsel. But the case ended up being adjourned for two weeks when Fawehinmi said he had not made any contacts with his clients. "Every person charged with a criminal offence is entitled to adequate time and facility to defend himself," he said. He observed that the prosecution had spent the past eight months preparing its case. But Fawehinimi's attempt to get bail for the accused persons failed. The tribunal ruled that he should defer his arguments for bail until the case resumes February 21.

The session was not without some embarrassing moments. For example, when Umeadi denied that the fifth accused person was working as a witness for prosecution, Fawehinmi showd him documents in which the prosecution had listed him as a witness. An embarrassed Umeadi then formally asked the tribunal to allow him to drop the accused as one of the witnesses.

But the prosecution was embarrassed even further when Fawehinmi pointed out another mistake. The prosecution had wrongly charged the accused persons under the (Special Tribunal) Act Cap 53, which is no longer in existance, rather than the (Special Tribunal) Decree Cap 53. This was promptly corrected. But Fawehinmi threw the tribunal into laughter when he obsered that the mistake was made by very senior lawyers: Umeadi and M.A. Agbamuche, federal attorney-general and minister of justice.

Emotions rose when Fawehinmi attacked the military for keeping some of the accused persons in a military barracks. "What is the business of the army in this matter?" he asked. He said in the history of the judiciary never had an accused person been kept with the army. He argued that they should be kept in prison custody and not with the army. Umeadi, however, countered the argument saying that it was better to keep them with the army since the prison is not as safe as the miliary barracks. He argue further that there was no suggestion of torture or ill-treatment of the accused persons while in the custody of the military.

An angry Fawehinmi observed that Saro-Wiwa, was put in chains fo r54 days and slo beaten up during the period. As a vetern of 15 prisons, Fawehinmi said the prison is safer than the barracks. He siad it had never happened before that persons charged for murder are kept in army barracks. He challenged Umeadi to cite just one case whre such had happened before. Umeadi remained seated and stared helplessly at Fawehinmi. The tribunal, however, ruled that the status quo be maintained pending the resumption of the trial on February 21.

Paul Okuntimo, a lieutenant colonel, in whose custody the accused persons are kept took on Fawehinmi after the adjournment. Farwehinmi had attempted to talk to Saro-Wiwa as he made for the black maria when Okuntimo roughly stopped him. An angry Fawehinmi pointed at the army officer and addressed him as Mister Okuntimo. "Don't point your fingers at an army officer and don't address me as mister, I am a lieutenant colonel" Okuntimo shouted ar Fawehinmi. "I don't care who you are," Fawehinmi shouted back. For a few minutes both men exchanged harsh words.

The trial has generated interest even outside Rivers State. An organisation which calls itself Niger Delta Liberation Movement, observed last week that justice for Saro-Wiwa is justice for all oil producing communities. Foreign journalists and foreign observers were also at teh venue to observe the proceedings. One of the observers is from the British High Commission while amother is a representative of the European Union.

Even with the commencement of the trial last Monday, the Rivers State Internal Security Task Force, which since May, last year has been arresting the Ogonis in connection with the Giokoo murder, raided K-Dere, home town of Mitee in the night. A number of people were arrested including Mittee's sister and her son.

Newswatch is published at P.M.B. 21499 Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel:4960950 Fax:962887 Telex:27874


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


54 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


Statement by Franklin Kennedy, President and CEO of Equator Bank Limited


LENGTH: 3867 words


 

Senate Subcommittee Hearing on Trade and Investment

February 16, 1995

Subject: U.S. Trade and Investment in Sub-Saharan Africa

Good afternoon, Madame Chairman and Members of the committee. My name is Franklin Kennedy and I am President and CEO of Equator Bank Limited. I am also a director of the Corporate Council on Africa and the African Business Roundtable, whose memberships are highly committed to increasing U.S. trade and investment in Africa. Equator and General Motors, who is also testifying today, were among the CCA's founding members. Thank you for the opportunity to share with you some views on U.S. business activity in Africa and on the continued development of this market. 

Introduction

For the past 20 years, Equator has operated exclusively in Sub-Saharan Africa, founded with the belief that Africa presented an under-served market with tremendous potential for a specialized financial institution. We have worked in the majority of countries in the region and have offices in Ghana, Kenya, Zambia, Angola, Mozambique and South Africa as well as in London, Nassau, Washington, and Glastonbury Connecticut. Our major shareholders are the Hongkong Group and, since early 1994, Nedbank of South Africa. Equator has 100 employees, including American, European and African professionals.

I will briefly introduce Equator's 3 lines of business: merchant banking, import-export trading and investment banking. If I may, I will also mention some examples that illustrate the potential to increase American business in Africa.

Equator has provided trade financing, short-and-medium-term lending and correspondent banking services in Africa since start-up in 1975. We have provided roughly $5 billion in financing to African public and private clients. Equator like many other lenders undertook its own "structural adjustment program" during the debt crisis of the late 1980s, but some of us continued on and many more are back in the African market now, so that competition in banking has heated up considerably. Equator has worked closely with OPIC, USAID, Eximbank and the multilateral institutions the U.S. supports, such as UNDP, the African Development Bank, the World Bank, IFC and the IMF, and we have close ties with African central and new African Export-Import Bank, along with Citibank and others.

Equator Bank Limited

Equator's trading company supports commercial activity and capital investment in Africa in sectors such as transport, communications, power, mining and housing. It acts in a number of capacities, such as representing U.S. companies or serving as procurement agent for African buyers. Much of the business has involved U.S. suppliers. Some are big exporters, such as Motorola, GM, Chrysler, Mack, Caterpillar, Kohler, McDonnell Douglas and Beechcraft. But many of our trading partners had not done business in Africa before, such as Bluebird Buses from Macon, Georgia. Bluebird has now sold several hundred buses in several African countries, with Equator assistance and financial support from the U.S. government's Commodity Import Program, among other sources. A major selling point was Bluebird's flexibility to modify the buses in ways that were highly suitable for local conditions. Surprisingly, Africa is already one of the largest markets for some of the smaller firms Equator works with, and for some of the newer exporters to the region it's been a real eye-opener. I would be happy to provide other examples to the committee.

Equator also helps arrange financing for existing private companies, privatization and new ventures in Africa, as financial advisor and as manager of direct investment funds. For example, the $25 million Africa Growth Fund was launched in 1989 as the first initiative of its kind by the Overseas Private Investment Corporation and U.S. corporate investors. The AGF has invested in both start-up joint ventures between U.S. and private African partners, and in expansion of competitive firms. It has already recovered 140% of its partners' original investment. Most of its portfolio is still intact, with businesses growing and appreciating in value in 8 African countries. The AGF invested companies employ about 1,500 people altogether, who in turn may be supporting 10 or more members of their extended families.

A larger follow-on fund, AGF II, is being established this year with continued US corporate and OPIC participation. Equator also manages the Kenya Equity Fund, which has benefited from strong USAID support. It has invested in tourism, manufacturing, agribusiness and other fields and can also be expanded. There are many more high-quality investment and investment banking opportunities in Africa today, owing to a much more receptive environment in many countries.

Business Climate in Africa: I would now like to comment on this improving business climate and the potential for increased U.S. business involvement.

Although aggregate GDP increased by only 1.4% in 1993, net of population growth, many African countries have been achieving strong real growth for several years, such as Ghana, Uganda, Zambia and Botswana. Higher prices for some of Africa's commodity exports have contributed to the expansion, but they are no longer the main driving force that they used to be.

Credit must go to the deep reforms undertaken by many African countries, backed by coordinate international support. The extensive liberalization of trade, foreign exchange, investment, labor and other policies, along with more fiscal discipline, have reduced the risks and costs of doing business and investing in many countries. There are fewer distortions, such as overvalued exchange rates, protective barriers and subsidies. This makes it much easier to identify and pursue business activities that should remain competitive aver the long term.

Of particular importance to foreign investors and lenders, many African countries have built up adequate foreign exchange reserves while reducing their debt burdens. As a result, country creditworthiness has improved and local companies and their banks can meet their obligations on a timely basis. In many cases inflation and local currency depreciation rates have reached historic lows, after years of painful adjustment towards competitive market rates. The historic devaluation of the CFA franc shared by 13 francophone countries in January 1994 was a major step towards restoring their competitiveness and attractiveness to private investors.

Financial support from the U.S. and other major donors is still an essential ingredient needed by the reforming countries to achieve and maintain basic economic stability. However, in response to these efforts, private capital inflows are generating more of the resources Africa needs for its development. Recent landmark transactions totaling over $1 billion included Ashanti Goldfields' stock offering, PTA Bank's regional pre-export credit facility in southern Africa, and the raising of three Wall Street funds focusing especially on the South African stock market, which has the 10th largest capitalization of all the emerging markets.

For all of the achievements, a number of African countries still suffer from civil strife and/or hostile policy environments. The stunning policy reversals in Nigeria following the coup do nothing to improve Africa's image among those who do not necessarily differentiate among the region's 54 countries. While having to provide massive humanitarian and peace-keeping assistance, the U.S. government has also closed aid missions and discontinued its support in some of the non-reforming countries. I can safely say that the business community supports tougher standards for U.S. assistance, as it focuses on its own tough standard on where to do business: the returns to the bottom line.

Even in actively reforming countries, there are still constraints to U.S. trade and investment and overall private sector development. These include the relative scarcity of domestic capital and local credit, especially medium-term loans for investment purposes. On the policy front, privatization is still moving fairly slowly in many countries, with valuable assets and infrastructure waiting to be rehabilitated and/or expanded. The African Growth Fund recently spent many months working with Cocaq saw in that case and others elsewhere indicate how important it is for governments to fine-tune their privatization efforts with the technical support available to them. We are all learning from experience, while opportunities keep growing.

Tax and customs policy and administration also need more work in many African countries. It's not just a matter of providing adequate business incentives, but also of reducing unfair competition and revenues lost to smuggling and tax avoidance. The U.S. Treasury Department and USAID are among those who are helping with tax reform and using U.S. expertise to do it. Some of these and other challenges are being tackled at the regional level. Organizations such as Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) and the West African Monetary and Economic Union (UMOEA) are working to harmonize tax and trade policies, to promote regional market integration, including capital markets, to modernize corporate and commercial laws, and to carry out regional infrastructure projects.

Opportunities for US Business: In terms of the opportunities for U.S. business, African imports increased about 7% per year during the 1990s, to about $70 billion last year. U.S. exports have doubled since 1990 to about $7 billion, although still only 1% of U.S. exports. U.S. private direct investment in the region, measured at its original cost going in and not at its present value, is estimated by one survey at about $4 billion. It is worth mentioning that South Africa accounted for only roughly 25% of these flows. Its share is sure to increase, but its successful political transition and re-entry into the market have boosted U.S. business interest in the rest of the region as well.

Export agriculture, light industry, mining, infrastructure development, financial and management services are some of the sectors of opportunity. Based on Equator's experience in managing the Africa Growth Fund and Kenya Equity Fund, I can assure you that there is no lack of opportunity for investors to earn the kinds of returns they would expect in an admittedly riskier environment than the United States. The trickle of investment is turning into a flow in places like Ghana, Uganda and South Africa as African, American and other entrepreneurs recognize that they can control more of these risks through their own sound management, free from government interference.

American businesses do not necessarily have to be on the ground in Africa day in and day out to sell their products. While many U.S. multinationalists have representative offices in major capitals, African buyers and their advisors ranging from U.S. Embassy commercial officers to private trading forms are taking the initiative to search the U.S. market for the best solutions for any given situation. Some of the products from smaller U.S. firms that have been very well received on the market are low-cost, low-maintenance oxygen production units built by Airsep Corporation in New York state, portable solar panels from United Solar Systems in Michigan, and mobile telecommunications equipment from Transworld Communications Corporation in California.

In Angola and Eastern Africa, Equator has helped introduce a machine produced by a small firm in Reston Virginia, MIC Industries, that allows a small team to construct free-standing buildings made of interlocking steel arches in a matter of days. Our clients have used this machine to build everything from warehouses and factory spaces to residential units.

The potential is not just for newly manufactured goods or capital equipment. For example, Equator has shipped over 2,000 secondhand utility vehicles from the U.S. to Africa over the past 5 or 6 years, such as freight, fire and garbage trucks. While these projects raised cash to help U.S. leasing and trucking companies renew their fleets, they also provided a cost-effective alternative for our African clients.

Whether the subject is trade or investment, the secret to success for the U.S. business person is to identify the high priority sectors in any given country and the serious entrepreneurs within them. They are the ones who are creating the demand for profitable involvement of U.S. partners, and as such they are a priceless commodity. They will have more choices of financial, procurement, management and other resources from the U.S. as their governments stay firmly on the path of private sector-led development.

U.S. Government Support: With each passing year of increasing stability, U.S. direct investors and exporters can devote less attention to political and currency transfer risks, and can fully concentrate on evaluating opportunities in African growth markets on their commercial merits. Business is becoming more competitive in many sectors, with more players involved and more financing available, including bilateral export credits and concessional financing from Europe and Asia. As this Sub-Committee, the Congress and the Administration review the priorities for U.S. government support, you can do so with greater confidence that efforts to leverage taxpayer resources with U.S. private capital and to provide a direct return in terms of U.S. employment and sales will be rewarded.

I would just like to mention some of the existing or potential programs that can promote additional complementary between U.S. foreign assistance and U.S. commercial and investment interest in Africa.

First and foremost, adequate balance-of-payments assistance, including continued participation in official debt reduction efforts, must be maintained for countries that have made a serious commitment to reform and still require such support to maintain macro-economic stability. In parallel, the U.S. should continue to provide strong support and send clear signals regarding Africa's policy reform agenda, with due regard for issue areas of importance to business, including privatization and tax policy.

There has been a significant increase in private short-term trade financing activity in Africa in the past 2 and 3 years, reducing the need for official balance-of-payments support. Eximbank can accelerate this trend by covering more countries, as well as considering new products that fit into the pattern of present- day international banking activity in Africa. For example, it could encourage further commercial lending to the region to both public and private sector borrowers by guaranteeing some of the risks of African export bills being used as security to raise financing for African imports.

The African environment is also more receptive now for Eximbank to widen its support of U.S. capital goods exports to Africa. While the biggest transactions might still involve infrastructure projects undertaken by African governments, or big oil and mining projects undertaken by African governments, or big oil and mining projects, much of the demand for term credits is starting to come from well-managed private sector projects in other sectors that make good commercial sense. Building on its experience elsewhere, Eximbank can start taking on this type of private project risk in Africa on a sound commercial basis, in collaboration with U.S. and African banks and other private sources of financing. This would be a very welcome development.

Besides expanded export financing, the U.S. government can help U.S. firms invest and compete in Africa in many other ways. Seed money provided on a cost- sharing basis for market research and project preparation, of the kind provided by the U.S. Trade and Development Agency, have generated more business in Africa in recent years, However, there are very few places to turn to for this kind of support, or else they are not well known. It can be particularly valuable to smaller American entrepreneurial firms developing investment projects or long-term trading relationships in Africa.

With respect to project financing, the second Africa Growth Fund leveraged by OPIC-guaranteed notes will be providing equity financing and value-added management support to private ventures, and the Southern Africa Enterprise Fund will do so as well with a particular focus on smaller businesses and with the capability of providing technical assistance to African entrepreneurs.

OPIC itself has worked successfully to develop direct lending, guarantee and insurance products for U.S. investors seeking to mitigate risks and to complete their financing packages. With its track record of innovation, OPIC can keep leading the way in addressing some of the remaining gaps. For example, given the steady currency devaluation that have accompanied African adjustment programs and are still of concern to investors, especially in projects geared towards the African domestic markets, it may be feasible to develop products that help investors hedge against exchange rate fluctuations. Such products may only be suitable for use in countries whose exchange rates have already reached a solid plateau.

The fact that President Clinton has been meeting with many more African heads of state than other President is also very encouraging. Indeed, promotional efforts play an important in building U.S. business interest and confidence in Africa, and in matching up African entrepreneurs with suitable partners here. They have included Secretary Brown's visit to South Africa last year, the White House conference on Africa, USIA's conference in Atlanta, and the trade and investment missions that OPIC has led to various African countries. At the same time, private non-profit organizations such as the Corporate Council on Africa, the U.S. South Africa Leadership Exchange Program and Africare are also building the networks and helping to make the African business environment more user-friendly.

Finally, to keep building the market, USAID and other agencies can continue to support local business and financial sector development in Africa, through initiatives like its loan guarantee programs for small enterprise lending by local banks, and start-up support for business development and training centres, local investment funds and a new generation of capital market institutions. Multilateral agencies have also developed a good track record with programs that support the African entrepreneur, such as the Africa Project Development Facility and the African Management Services Company managed by IFC and funded by several other agencies, and the work UNDP has been doing with African business associations, among other initiatives. The U.S. business community should also play its part in helping African entrepreneurs and managers locate suitable products, partners and training opportunities, not only managers locate suitable products, partners and training opportunities, not only on a commercial basis but also through outreach programs that can be organized by individual corporations, associations and non-profit organizations.

Conclusion: Africa is on the right track and can rightly be considered a growth market for U.S. investors and exporters. Rather than reduce its support at this critical juncture, the U.S. government should seek to build on the successes. Coordinated efforts must continue to strengthen economic stability, deepen policy reforms and accelerate growth of Africa's market economies. Many African countries seem to be well on the road to long-term growth. They are different stages, but what really counts is the major change in attitudes towards private business activity. This increases the scope to leverage U.S. taxpayer investment in African development by stimulating U.S. trade, investment and financing. I would be happy to discuss some of these opportunities in more detail and to answer any questions. Thank you.

Statement by Franklin Kennedy, President and CEO, Equator Bank Limited, Senate Hearing on Trade and Investment, February 16, 1995


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


55 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


Testimony of George E. Moose Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs


LENGTH: 2840 words


 

Encouraging Trade and Investment: An Integral Part of U.S. Policy Towards Africa

Senate Committee on Foreign Relations

Subcommittee on Africa

February 16, 1995

Madam Chairman and members of the Committee,

It is fitting that the first formal hearing on Africa by the 104th Congress should be on trade and investment. Those who see only news headlines that portray Africa as a continent of famine and crisis may be surprised by this focus. But those who have lived and worked in Sub-Saharan Africa or who have closely watched recent developments on the continent will recognize that trade and investment are indeed becoming a fundamental aspect of U.S.-Africa relations. I welcome the opportunity to focus on this theme as we intimate formally our dialogue on African issues. 

Africa is Undergoing a Transformation: A major transformation is underway in Africa, comparable to what Latin America experienced over the past decade. The clearest indicators of this transformation are the growth and expansion of democratic governments and institutions, paralleled by significant economic reform and liberalization. Nearly two-thirds of African countries are now are at the same stage of democratic transition, compared to only four in 1989. Many African nations have taken difficult and courageous steps to keep budget deficits down, maintain realistic exchange rates, and increase competition through domestic deregulation, trade reform, and privatization of public enterprises. The aim of these reforms has been to create an enabling environment in which the private sector can act as the engine of development.

U.S. leadership and support are critical to that transformation. Our diplomatic efforts and bilateral aid programs have given significant impetus to democracy-building and economic development. Our contributions -- leveraged with those of other donors -- to the programs of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund in Africa have reinforced economic policy reforms and infrastructure development.

The transformation of Sub-Saharan Africa has significant implications for U.S. interests. First, the progress realize to date has stimulated growing interest and opportunities for U.S. business. Second, the emergence of more stable, more democratic governments has given us responsible partners with whom we can address the full range of regional and international issues; settling or preventing conflicts; combating crime, narcotics, terrorism, and weapons proliferation; protecting and managing the global environment; expanding the global economy.

Although the results thus far have been encouraging, we must recognize that Africa's transformation is ongoing, incomplete, and still tenuous in many places. It would be extremely shortsighted not to persist in the effort to consolidate and protect the investment already made. The problems that would arise if the transformation falters -- failed states, political instability, human tragedy -- would pose direct threats to U.S. interests and security.

U.S. Involvement in Africa is paying Off: Nowhere are the benefits of active U.S. involvement and investment more evident than in "Southern Africa". Our efforts at conflict resolution and democratic institution building have paid -- and will continue to pay -- significant dividends.

With the establishment of a non-racial democracy in South Africa, U.S. business can contribute to the country's economic disparities that are the legacy of apartheid. South Africa already accounts for $2.2 billion in trade -- nearly half of the U.S. exports to Sub-Saharan Africa. Ford and Pepsi recently made multimillion- dollar investments, and over 300 U.S. firms have returned since mid-1991. AT&T, Citibank, IBM, Kodak,Sara Lee, and Proctor & Gamble are becoming household names. South Africa is the cornerstone of a much larger market, one that encompassed the 11 nations of Southern Africa and their 130 million inhabitants, and extraordinary minerals, wildlife, and resources. The potential of the Southern African sub-region is what has led the Commerce Department to declare it one of the world's ten major reemerging markets for U.S. exports.

In West Africa, "Ghana" provides another example of how U.S. involvement and support -- including USAID's Trade and Investment Program -- have yielded impressive results. Our leadership in promoting democratic institutions and economic reforms have turned Ghana into one of our most promising African export markets. Between 1992 and 1993, U.S. exports to Ghana expand by 73 percent. Figures for 1994 trail that performance, but U.S. businesses have found profitable opportunities, and their products and investments are reinforcing Ghana's development goals.

Events in "Sierra Leone" offer a cautionary lesson. The recent eruption of civil unrest in this coastal nation illustrates the fragility of some regimes and underscores the need for us to maintain knowledgeable, experienced diplomats in the field who can work to prevent developing conflicts where possible, or help work out solutions. In the particular case of Sierra Leone, the economic stakes are high as well. An attack in January shut down Sierra Rutile, a 50-percent U.S.-owned mine that is the world's largest single producer of rutile, a strategic titanium ore used in aircraft manufacture and paints.

Support for Africa is an Investment in out Future: The African market, with over one-half billion potential consumers, is already significant. There is great potential in sectors such as telecommunications, finance, agriculture, and natural resources, although obstacles to trade and investment remain in a number of countries. The U.S. direct investment position approaches $3.5 billion. In 1993, U.S. firms exported nearly $4.8 billion in goods and services to Sub-Saharan Africa. This is 20 percent greater that our exports to the Commonwealth of Independent States of the former Soviet Union.

These exports represent tangible benefits to American families. By some estimates, every extra $1 billion in exports adds 19,000 new jobs in the United States. Doubling our exports to Africa could create an additional increase, provided that the political and economic transformation currently underway is sustained. Given the potential gains to the United States, our current development aid to Africa -- about one-half of one-tenth of one percent of the federal budget -- represents a minuscule investment with the possibility of a tremendous pay-off.

In a recent speech, AID administrator Brian Atwood offered a quick, back-of- the-envelope calculation to illustrate this point. Using simple, but not implausible, assumptions about African demand for foreign goods, U.S. market share, and U.S. population growth, he came to the following conclusion: The average $3 per year that each American family contributes to African development assistance, if sustained over 30 years, could generate an annual $600 in exports per U.S. family by the year 2025. As Brian points out, these are not trivial amounts; they represent millions of jobs for out children, and financial interest to remain engaged in Africa and to support real, but fragile, economic and political transformation that has begun.

Other Policy Initiatives Will Spur Trade with Africa: This Administration has also vigorously pursued global trade, investment, and debt policy initiatives that will boost U.S.-Africa business and commercial ties and help integrate Africa into the world economy:

Trade: The successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round negotiations and the creation of the World Trade Organization will enhance trade opportunities with African countries. The U.S. Trade Representative is chairing a working group to formulate and implement a comprehensive trade and development policy to ensure that these countries are able to take full advantage of the opportunities to compete successfully in growing regional and global markets as trade barriers come down.

Investment: On multiple fronts we are pursuing our goals of open markets, non- discriminatory treatment, and basic fairness for U.S. investors doing business abroad -- be it in Europe, East Asia,or Africa. Where appropriate, we negotiate Bilateral Investment Treaties that protect investors from expropriations and assure the right to transfer funds and access to fair dispute resolution mechanisms. Debt

Relief: The United States and other creditor nations have established a mechanism in the Paris Club to offer debt reduction on a selective, case-by-case basis to countries that are undertaking economic reforms, but that are still saddled with heavy debt burdens that inhibit private investment and growth. Some two dozen low- income African countries have benefited from debt reschedulings or reductions over the past several years.

We Provide Direct Support for U.S. business in Africa: I have outlined how our policies and programs that promote democracy, peace, and sustainable development in Africa reinforce U.S. economic interests and provide significant indirect benefits and opportunities for the U.S. private sector. But we are also actively involved in providing direct support services and assistance to the business community. Deputy Assistant Secretary Walker is providing a detailed overview. Let me just provide a few recent examples of the role our embassies are playing: In Ethiopia, our embassy helped Louisiana-based Schaffer and Associates in a hard-fought and successful bid for an $84 million sugar project, with prospects for an additional $50 million in sales of related U.S. goods and services. In Botswana, the U.S. Ambassador's intervention resulted in removal of discriminatory tender requirements that hampered an Owens-Corning bid on a $180 million contract to supply pipes for a major water pipeline. In Kenya, Zimbabwe, Malawi and Mauritius, our embassies actively supported the Kellogg Company's effort to reduce import duties on breakfast cereal. In Madagascar, our Ambassador's efforts to ensure a level playing field for all bidders resulted in the signing of a lease/purchase agreement for a Boeing 737 aircraft. In Cameroon and Chad, our embassies supported negotiations leading to a recent $3-4 billion agreement relating to the building of a proposed oil pipeline from land- locked Chad, through Cameroon, to an offshore terminal. The consortium which is to build the pipeline is led by an affiliate of Exxon. In Zimbabwe, the tender offer for the country's first cellular phone system was canceled after our Ambassador protested that the specifications were biased in favor of European suppliers. Several U.S. firms were able to submit bids after the tender was rewritten. In Senegal, the U.S. envoy successfully persuaded the authorities to replace outdated health legislation that prevented Colgate from making or selling fluoride toothpaste.

We are Creating New Government-Business Partnerships: Providing information on economic trends, local business practices, and financing options; ensuring a level playing field; removing discriminatory regulations -- this is the kind of work that our embassies in Africa and our personnel in Washington do every day to help U.S. businesses, large and small, to find opportunities in Africa. In an increasingly tight budget environment, we need to find ways to be more efficient and more effective in our business facilitation efforts.

We have ongoing contacts with a variety of Africa-related business groups, such as the U.S.-Angola Chamber of Commerce, the U.S.-South Africa Business Council, and the African Business Roundtable. We also have frequent exchanges with the Corporate Council on Africa. These are the kinds of partnerships between business and government that we value and wish to strengthen.

A few months ago, the Corporate Council on Africa, the Department of State, the other federal agencies held a series of roundtable discussions, and found many of the recommendations that ensued to be useful and timely. Some of the issues the Corporate Council raised -- the need to remain engaged throughout Africa, the need to support regional economic integration, the need to secure broader international adherence to the principles of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, the need to re- invent the role of our embassy economic officers -- are issues we are already in the process of addressing.

Other Corporate Council recommendations touched on complex issues that require careful analysis. The availability of government-supported export financing, for example, is a central concern; but it is a difficult issue, given that current practice is rooted in the provisions of the Credit Reform Act and the charter legislation for eximbank and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. I have asked Regina C. Brown, our Deputy Assistant Secretary for Economic and Business Affairs, to chair an informal interagency review of the Council's recommendations, with the aim of identifying concrete, feasible steps the Administration can take to address the concerns that have been raised.

The U.S. Needs to Remain Engaged: To recapitulate, Madam Chairman, Sub-Saharan Africa is undergoing a sweeping political and economic transformation. Democratic institutions are being developed or strengthened in numerous countries, and fledgling governments are taking important steps to liberalize their economies and create an enabling environment for private sector-led growth.

U.S. leadership and support have been critical to this transformation. Already, our active engagement in this process is starting to show results. Our assistance programs fostering democratization and economic reform have created opportunities for U.S. business. U.S. exporters and investors, in turn, have reinforced development goals in African nations. All Americans potentially stand to gain from the expansion of African markets.

We must recognize, however, that Africa's new governments are fragile and their transformation remains incomplete. We need to continue supporting their efforts. Our initiatives to strengthen democracy, resolve conflicts, and foster sustainable development in Africa representing a low-cost investment. If we as a nation remain engaged, American businesses -- and indeed all of us -- can expect to reap significant returns.

Statement by George E. Moose, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Senate Hearing on Trade and Investment, February 16, 1995


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


56 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


Statement of Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Hearing on Trade and Investment in Africa

February 16,1995

Just a few weeks ago, a constituent of mine, Mr. Owen Williams of Durham, traveled to Uganda. His trip came as a result of a meeting last year with a visiting Ugandan trade delegation to the United States. During his trip, Mr. Williams met with several Ugandan ministries and private business people on behalf of furniture and building material firms in North Carolina. He said that the trip went very well, and he looks forward to pursuing the mutual interests he found in Uganda. 

Owen Williams is just one small example of the kind of private sector initiative that, over the long haul, yields the foundation for mature economic relations between nations.

Ten or fifteen years ago, I guarantee you that Owen Williams would not have been looking for business in Uganda. It wouldn't have occurred to him. Uganda and a few other African countries have made tremendous strides in recent years in opening up their economies, taking down barriers to trade, reducing corruption and generally bringing their countries into the mainstream of international commerce.

They should be commended, and the United States should support their efforts. It is those efforts that will allow a growing relationship between our countries, one based on respect and mutual benefit, to emerge. A relationship based on one party giving financial assistance to another is neither sustainable nor respectful.

I commend Senators Kassebaum and Feingold for holding the first Africa Subcommittee hearing of the 104th Congress--indeed, it is the first subcommittee hearing of any kind--on trade and investment. It sends a clear signal to the business community that some parts of the government, at least, care about their concerns. It also sends a signal to the governments of the countries of Africa, where some progress is being made but much more needs doing, that good and active relations with the United States will depend much upon their policies. And finally, it sends a signal to the people of Africa, who deserve to find their governments what we too often take for granted: accountability, rational policies, and adherence to the rule of law.

Statement of Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, Hearing on Trade and Investment, February 16, 1995


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

57 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


U.S./AFRICA: Senate Subcommittee on African Affairs Hearing, U.S. Policy on Trade and Investment in Africa


LENGTH: 160 words


 

February 16, 1995

Washington, D.C. -- The Senate Africa subcommittee's first meeting since Republicans took control of the U.S. Congress drew an unusual number of Senators, including the controversial chairman, Jesse Helms of North Carolina. The session focused on U.S. business opportunities, an area where there is bipartisan support for expanded ties.

The subcommittee chair, Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas, was joined throughout the nearly three hours of testimony by the ranking Democrat on the panel, Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin. Two prominent Democrats made opening statements, Dianne Feinstein of California and Paul Simon of Illinois, who held the chairmanship for the past four years.


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English
