58 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


Aid to Africa is an Asset to America's Self-Interest


LENGTH: 547 words


 

by Dr. Dorothy I. Height

As the President of the National Council of Negro Women, Incorporated, (NCNW), I, Dorothy Height, am pleased to join my dear friends and fellow colleagues, Ambassador Andrew Young, Congressman Donald Payne, C. Payne Lucas, President and CEO of Africare and the hundreds of organizations and interested parties that have come together today to speak up and speak out about the immediate need to defend U.S. AID to Africa.

AID to Africa is and must be advocated as a viable investment made by America to ensure the continuance of the spread of global democratization, and the strengthening of social and economic development on the continent of Africa.

Founded in 1935, The National Council of Negro Women has worked diligently to foster programs, technical and educational support to women of color domestically and internationally. As a non-governmental organization, we have worked in partnership with the U.S. Government to help African women and men develop programs and initiatives in Africa to improve the overall quality of life and to build viable relationships between Africans and Americans. 

For over 60 years we have learned first-hand and have worked day-to-day with African women and children which has resulted in the development of strong global leadership establishing the international agenda for women in such issues as maternal and child health; nutrition; maintaining the institution of family; and creating business opportunities to achieve self-sufficiency.

Through the decades, African women have provided leadership to people throughout the world in an effort to uplift the conditions of the poor. Enhanced global communications between Africa and America allows us to see the relatedness of global concerns of everyday life. We know that the problem of poverty are not only serious in the developing world but are problems that are equally faced domestically in the U.S.

As America in a bi-partisan spirit, evaluates and explores viable business markets, it is in the enlightened self-interest of the United States to cultivate and increase support for Africa. African-Americans have an historical and moral obligation to champion this issue. Representing four million African-American women and women of color today, I call upon President Clinton, the Republican and Democratic leadership of the U.S. Congress, to renew the confidence and commitment of America to providing equitable levels of AID and support to Africa.

Prepared by the National Council of Negro Women, 1001 G Street, NW, Suite 800, Washington, DC 20001. TEL: (202) 628-0015 FAX: (202) 628-0233


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


59 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


Speech to Summit on Africa Aid


LENGTH: 2667 words


 

by Brian Atwood

Washington, DC

I am pleased to be with you today as President Clinton's representative. I understand that the president has issued a statement that was shared with you. As you heard, it underscores the abiding commitment of this Administration to Africa.

From time to time American ballot boxes produce what we called revolutions. We know about the revolution sparked by the Voting Rights Act. Franklin Roosevelt's election created a revolution. So did Ronald Reagan's

We are in the early stages of a revolution in Washington today. And, as in every other time in our history, good can emerge from the changes their revolution brings. 

Congressional reform -- the streamlining of the institution, the increased transparency, open rules -- this is all long overdue. A Gore-Gingrich collaboration to reinvent government is something the American people welcome. This is not politics-as-usual, and it can produce positive change.

But in the fervor that accompanies the early stages of a revolution, incautious positions are often asserted. At the least, before such positions become the accepted wisdom, someone must challenge them, civilly, but forcefully. That is the only way we can keep revolution on a healthy course. Indeed, that is the way mandates for change are interpreted and given real meaning.

A case in point is the assertion that we have no national interests in Africa. That we must reduce or eliminate development assistance to that continent, That Africa has neither geopolitical importance for the United States nor economic value.

With all the force we can muster, we say: That is just plain wrong.

Let's examine the question objectively. For just a moment, let's leave out America's humanitarian values. Let's put aside our historic ties to Africa. Let's forget sentimentality. Instead, let's talk about hard economic facts and markets and sales. Let's ask ourselves: is Africa worth the investment? Is a continent of half a billion people worth one-half of one-tenth of one percent of the federal budget, which is what we now spend on it? Is the three dollars and change that each American family pays each year to help several dozen sub-Saharan nations a burden worth the price?

Of course it is. It's a good deal for America. It's a good investment for Americans. Our aid to Africa is not welfare, nor is it charity. It is an investment we make in other people for our own self-interest.

How we do build markets? The answer is simple: we do it by making investments for the future. That is what vision is all about. That is what practical reality teaches us too. If we want to talk economic rationales, then we must look at Africa as the last great developing market. We must look at it the way we looked at Latin America and Asia a generation ago.

Consider Latin America; today it is fastest growing market for American goods. This is a huge new middle class market of 350 million people. It got that way because of investments made during the last forty years -- $30.7 billion in economic assistance from the United States between 1949 and 1993. Yet our exports to all of Latin American in 1993 alone were more than two-and-a-half times that amount -- $78 billion. Quite a payoff in jobs and income, and that was just one year. And the Latin American market is likely to grow three times larger in the next decade.

Where would we be if John F. Kennedy, Lyndon Johnson and Richard Nixon had not committed themselves to the Alliance for Progress and the education programs that helped create a generation of economists and technicians who now lead South America's impressive growth? What kind of customers would we have if we had not supported health and education programs that invested in the human capital of Latin America, an investment that now is producing an educated, healthy workforce that can afford to buy our goods and services? What kind of stability would we have in this market if we had not supported democracy-building programs that have made military juntas and coups a thing of the past?

It is an interesting exercise to compare sub-Saharan Africa today to three of the newest "Asian Tigers" -- Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand -- as they were in 1960: African per capita income is today 80% of what it was in Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand 35 years ago. But Africa today has four times the number of people Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand had in 1960. Think of the potential of this African market, even at its current stage of development.

The bottom line is that Africa today is not significantly behind where the "Asian Tigers" were in 1960. In the three decades since, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand substantially reduced poverty, their rates of population growth, infant mortality, and illiteracy. These countries are now major players in the world economy. We believe Africa can do as well.

The doubters should look not just at Africa's potential; the market is already significant, and like other developing markets, it is growing far faster than our markets in Europe. In 1992, sub-Saharan Africa imported $63 billion worth of merchandise from the world. African imports have risen by around 7.0% per year for the past decade. At this rate, the African market would amount to $480 billion by the year 2025. That is approximately $267 billion in today's dollars.

The U.S. currently accounts for nearly 10% of the African market. Do the arithmetic. Each American family now spends about $3 annually on aid to Africa. At current growth rates, that will produce something like $50 billion worth of American exports to Africa each year in 30 years. In 2025, the U.S. is projected to have a population of 320 million. Again, do the arithmetic. $50 billion worth of exports would work out to about $600 worth of exports per family, annually, in 2025. And that is if Africa's growth remains at its current level; if we make the investments Africa needs, and if African nations implement the kind of policies that have benefited Asia and Latin America, the return for each American family in thirty years could be as much as $2000 per year.

These are not trivial amounts. They represent millions of jobs for our children, financial health for our nation.

Isn't Africa worth the investment now that we made in Asia and Latin America? Those who argue against such investments are shortchanging the next generation of Americans. There is, of course, no guarantee that our investments will pay dividends, but it is as good a bet as most mutual funds, Moreover, the cost of not acting could overwhelm our treasury, and, I fear, our consciences.

Those who say we have no strategic interest in Africa should understand that if African nations fail to make progress, if they descend into chaos and decay, the tragedy will not take place in a vacuum. Chaos there will affect our interests here. As long as we remain true to our values -- and there is a strong bipartisan consensus that suggests we will (even Pat Buchanan supports disaster relief) -- the costs of humanitarian operations will continue to be borne in part by the United States. If more African nations fail, we will share the costs of caring for the millions of refugees. We will shoulder the burdens of dealing with endless famine. And we will have to confront the spreading political disorder, the environmental damage, and the consequent loss of markets for our goods.

Parts of Africa are living on the edge. Many African nations face adverse climatic and soil conditions. Each day, people in these countries face problems of poor health and malnutrition and illiteracy that few other peoples confront.

Yet lost in the apocalyptic descriptions of an Africa seemingly falling apart is genuine reason for encouragement. The headlines rarely report the many positive developments and success stories in Africa. Yet in a number of African nations, democratically-elected, enlightened leaders, committed to broadening participation and undertaking reforms necessary for development, are creating an environment for success. This, too, is the reality of Africa:.

USAID today is working in 35 African nations that, in our judgment, are in various phases of consolidating their democracies, creating free markets, and implementing serious economic reforms. Conversely, we have ended our involvement in several nations where the governments refuse to commit themselves to reform or to a development partnership with their own citizens.

A new generation of African leaders is pursuing extensive economic restructuring programs, including privatization of state-owned enterprise, reducing government functions and budgets, stabilizing the economy, and implementing policy change that help the private sector expand.

New crops and market liberalization are expanding food production, raising farmer income and reducing food prices for consumers.

More children, especially girls, are attending school so that they can become more productive members of society. And we know from our own experience that more than any other factor, improving the education of girls and the status of women enhances the economy, the environment, and the prospects of democracy.

Programs to expand immunization and use of oral rehydration therapy are saving an estimated 800,000 African children each year.

Fertility is starting to fall as more and more parents use family planning services.

I am proud that USAID has played a role in one of these achievements.

For every Rwanda there is a Ghana -- a nation that has begun revitalizing its economy and is intent on being part of the worldwide economic expansions.

For every Somalia, there is a South Africa or a Namibia -- nations that have successfully implemented democracy and peaceful change.

For every Angola, there is a Mozambique, emerging now from civil conflict.

For every tragedy, there are a half dozen islands of hope. Progress is still tentative, often fragile. Which is precisely why we must not hesitate now. But this continent is no write-off. It is a good investment.

We have learned from the mistakes we made during the Cold War. We now are concentrating our aid in countries that are implementing sound economic policies, promoting an open and democratic society, and investing their own resources in broad-based development. That is exactly what the Congress wanted to accomplish with the Development Fund for Africa. And that is why this Administration strongly supports the Development Fund for Africa. Under this fund, we have taken a longer- term approach to Africa's development, systematically addressing the root causes -- economic, social, and political -- of underdevelopment.

In those countries stricken with disaster or famine, we are treating emergency relief as more than an end in itself. Rather, we are structuring it to help nations make the difficult transition from crisis to the path of sustainable development.

President Clinton's Initiative for the Greater Horn of Africa is designed to apply the lessons we learned in the Sahel and Southern Africa to a troubled region that now consumes nearly half of all African relief. By emphasizing regional cooperation and planning, by helping nations acquire the ability to respond to food crises early on, we can prevent droughts from becoming famines. This Initiative, we believe, will save lives and resources. The partnerships it builds will enable the donor community to save billions of dollars in relief assistance over the next fifteen years and focus resources instead on recovery efforts and long-term development.

To prevent more failed nations, the United States must strengthen our efforts to prevent crisis and to encourage others to do so as well. While we only provide five percent of the development assistance that Africa receives, we provide 30 percent of the relief assistance directed at the continent's emergencies. It is a lot less expensive to lead the way on prevention than it is to pay the costs of failure.

I am able to make the case for assistance to Africa today because USAID has reorganized itself to be an effective instrument of development. Many of our reforms were pioneered by the Development Fund for Africa. The DFA forced us to measure results and now we are going to do this everywhere. Our work in Africa has been an essential part of our identity, and must remain so.

So now we have a fight on our hands. We welcome it. If the revolution has indeed begun, then each of us must do everything we can to ensure that the well- being of our children -- and the children of Africa -- is advanced by the vision today's revolution produces. We cannot be silent. We cannot wring our hands. The case for Africa gives us the opportunity to be the champions of common sense. This is a battle well worth waging. Not for African Americans, not for historical reasons, not even for our humanitarian values, though we must never forget them. This is a battle worth waging for America's national interests and the future of our children. We will wage it. And I am confident that, in end, common sense will prevail.

Contact: USAID Press Office, Washington, DC (202) 4274


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


60 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


Stay the Course on Aid in Africa


LENGTH: 1947 words


 

Speech to Summit on Africa Aid

by Donald M. Payne

Good afternoon, I want to commend the Constituency for Africa (CFA) for initiating this meeting at this crucial time for Africa. There have been three periods in recent Africa history that have bearing on changing the course of events for Africa. First, the independence era in the early 1960's when the continent was freed of their colonial masters, and leaving them without adequate resources and preparation for their new freedom.

Second, during the cold war, when Africa was used and abused. Used by both the Soviet Union and the United States to fight hot wars on African soil. The most symbolic were in Angola, Ethiopia, Eritrea and Somalia, and you know there were others. 

Abused, because we ignored humanitarian principles, and turned our eyes away from corruption and human rights abuses when it seemed in the interest of winning.

It also was obvious that preferential rehabilitation assistance was needed to right wrongs, but our voices were not heard.

In fact, indexes or the quality of life in the continent have spiraled down in the last two decades, at the some time going up in other parts of the developing world. Many, like Vice President Gore, who read the Kaplan Article in Atlantic Monthly were appalled at the condition of Africa, and determined to assist the continent. Unfortunately, others doubted Africa was even salvageable.

We really were not very good teachers in preparing Africa for out grand plans of multi-party democracies and free markets economies to be operated free of corruption.

We are now a few years into the Third Period, which I would call the post cold war period. Armed conflict continues to afflict sub-Saharan Africa where fighting persists in Sudan, Liberia, and Sierra Leon --- and we have our fingers crossed on Angola, despite the cease fire agreement. The potential for renewed outbreaks in Rwanda, Burundi, and Somalia is high, and other countries like Zaire and Nigeria are at risk.

Human rights problems have been accelerated due to overpopulation and lack of sustainable development.

However, all is not gloom and doom. There have been historic advances.

In South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Ghana, and other countries we could name.

The respected Africanist, Ambassador Elliot Skinner at a recent meeting hosted by Carnegie, "we need to note and promote Africa's rich natural resources and our economic interest."

My esteemed former congressional colleague, the Honorable Mervyn Dymally, also said at the same meeting that economic advances in Africa should have preceded the emphasis on democracy.

These are thoughtful statements and deserve more consideration, as I know Andy Young will provide will today.

But, as I understand my job today, is to provide with some insights on what's happening on capital hill, how serious it is and what's being done about it.

We are all aware of Republican Senator McConnel initiative to eliminate the ear mark on Development Funds for Africa. This smacks right at the core of the historic Congressional Black Caucus efforts to reverse the inequalities of the past contribution of Ron Dellums in sponsoring the Anti-Apartheid Act which mobilized American against racial discrimination in South Africa.

Remember the late Mickey Leland, who gave his very life in pursuit of increasing the awareness of all Americans to the plights of our African brothers and sisters.

We have a proud heritage, and in no way are we going to go backward. We will use every resource at our disposal to win this fight!

Some of you know that for the last two terms the leadership, both Democrat and Republican, have tried to abolish the Subcommittee on Africa. Our present Congressional Black Caucus leadership has been successful, with your help, in preserving this important committee.

The Republicans were faced with reducing seven subcommittees to 5, verses the Democrats mandate to reduce from 8 to 6 in the last term of congress. Speaker Gingrich was most sympathetic to our cause, as was the new International Relations Committee Chairman Gilman.

Hanry Hyde the powerful conservative Republican leader also helped to make the case for our continuation. Actually, we had an easier time with the Republicans this term that with the Democrats last term.

This leads me to emphasize that we should not make aid to Africa a partisan issue.

There are many Republicans on the Senate side like Nancy Kassebaum, Chair of the Senate Africa Affairs Committee, James Jeffords and Paul Coverdell (former Peace Corps Director) who I personally know have Africa's interest in their heart. Sen. Jesse Helms also has not been too impress with the McConnell initiative and may help pass the first authorizing bill on foreign aid in years.

I have been further informed by top leaders in the Jewish Community that they stand ready to fight for the preservation of out earmark.

Let us not forget the close relationship we have had over many years with our Jewish friends on a grass root community level in fighting for social justice. We feel this same partnership could be positively expressed on the international level, and not have this issue create division. An important specific announcement on this will be forthcoming in the next few weeks.

Another action by Caucus members was our quick response in fighting for the autonomy of the Agency for the International Development. As if we did not have enough problems, the Administration started to tinker with the idea of merging it into the State Department. Especially, after we finally have a strong enough leader in

Brian Atwood, and right on the tail of his own efforts to fine tune his new reorganization.

Our letter to the White House Chief of Staff, Leon Panetta, with a copy to Vice President Gore, said in effect "the merging with the State Department would further put DFA funds in jeopardy and would directly feed into the McConnell Bill and thereby alienate the African Americans. Further, this continues to cast our foreign policy in disarray, and indicates to the public that the Administration has doubts about its own method of operation. We implore you to ask the President to speak out on this matter at once."

He did -- through Vice President Gore's statement a few days later where he ruled against the merger.

Also, indirectly at risk were the African Development Foundation and the National Endowment for Democracy, which are doing effective work with small grass root development and human rights groups in Africa.

In addition to our efforts to preserve the 802 million dollar FY 1995 earmark for Africa in light of an estimated 20% total foreign aid cut, we need to be aware of larger sums appropriated for IDA (International Development Association), the soft loan window of the World Bank.

Approximately 45% of IDA lending is targeted to sub-Saharan Africa. This year the Administration will request an appropriation to IDA of $1.250 billion. Since $617 million of last year's money has not yet been expended, and if one adds the possibility of a recession, we are talking about the vulnerability of loosing $1.867 billion of which about half would have gone to Africa. Since these funds are matched 4 to 1 by other nations these potential actions could encourage them to also cut back causing a loss of billions of dollars for Africa. We must give more attention to the World Bank and other multi-lateral institutions like the African Development Bank.

It seems to me that the Constituency for Africa's role is to broaden the public's understanding of what is at stake. Congress will not pass legislation where there is not a constituent support. Calls and letters need to be directed to each constituents local Representative and Senator. If all the calls come to the CBC, we dilute the effect of our movement. There is too much effort inside the Beltway and not outside the Beltway. Reach out to local chapters of NAACP, Black Churches -- all Churches, Temples and Mosques.

By the way, I think it is great, the support CFA is receiving from our Muslim brothers and sisters to finance this meeting today. Their attendance is also evidence that we are united together for Africa.

Also, there are influential members of congress who have close ties with the NGO community like I have had with the YMCA, U.S. Committee for UNICEF and UNA. Senator Hatfield with World Vision, one of America's largest Non Governmental Organizations in overseas development and relief.

In closing I would like to read from a letter I recently received from Robert A. Seiple, President of World Vision, one of America's largest Non-Governmental Organizations in overseas development and relief.

Mr. Seiple writes, "Our national net worth, like an individual's, will ultimately be determined not by what we selfishly keep but rather what we compassionately and responsibly give away. No global power can truly be great whose national interest excludes human dignity and the sanctity of every human life. Not to be an impact player in a world of desperation is nothing short of a betrayal of our Christian ethics. This world and its people matter to God, and we turn away from them at our peril."

Thank you, and stay the course on aid to Africa.

Speech to the Summit on African Aid by Congressman Donald M. Payne (D-NJ)


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


61 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


Letter from President Clinton to the Summit on Africa Aid


LENGTH: 560 words


 

The White House

Washington

February 3,1995

I welcome the initiative of so many distinguished Americans and organization who have come together today in Washington to send a simple message: Africa matters to the United States.

Africa matters because of the huge potential of its people and its economies, potential that already creates jobs and exports for our nation. It matters because of the historic ties that bind our peoples, including the roots of 25 million African Americans. And it matters because the great global challenges of tomorrow -- promoting sustainable development, protecting human rights, stopping environmental decline, ensuring reasonable population growth, preemption ethnic tensions, and integrating the rich spiritual heritage of Islam into the demands of modern states -- can be seen in the challenges facing Africa today. 

My Administration has acted to promote these important national interests. we have worked to advance the remarkable transition to democracy, and economic development throughout southern Africa. We have helped resolve conflicts throughout the continent, such as efforts to bring an end to two decades of terrible civil war in Mozambique and Angola. Under the innovative leadership of USAID Administrator Brian Atwood, we have launched a new initiative in the greater Horn of Africa to anticipate and address the causes of potential famine that threatens 25 million people. We have helped relieve the crushing burden of debt for many African nations. And we have responded to humanitarian crises in Rwanda, Liberia, Angola, Sudan, and elsewhere.

There is a new spirit of democracy and self-reliance throughout Africa. I have felt it in the meetings I have held with eight African Heads of State in the past year. And the Vice President, U.N. Ambassador Madeline Albright, National Security Advisor Anthony Lake, and Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott have all felt it as well during their recent trips crisscrossing the continent.

We all know that we are facing a tough new budget environment, and we are going through a healthy process of assigning clear priorities and demanding efficiency for government resources. Let me assure you that in the budget I am submitting to Congress, I am committed to ensuring adequate resources for meeting the challenges and seizing the opportunities we face in Africa. Thank you again for your efforts.

Bill Clinton

Letter from President William J. Clinton read to Summit on Africa Aid, Washington, DC, February 3, 1995


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

62 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


Why Africa Matters: The Case for Continued U. S. Assistance to Africa


LENGTH: 2320 words


 

by the Constituency for Africa

February 3, 1995

Foreign Aid in Context

The debate over the utility and effectiveness of American foreign aid has been a mainstay of American politics for the last fifty years. The foreign aid program began in 1946 when President Truman offered assistance to post World War II Europe in conjunction with the Marshall Plan European reconstruction.

During the Cold War, foreign aid, though unpopular was seen as a necessary tool to promote America's national interest and foreign policy goals. Foreign assistance was directly related to the overarching policy objective of containing Soviet influence and the expansion of Communism throughout the world, particularly in Third World or developing countries. Those countries that fit into this strategic and geopolitical scheme became America's new allies and were rewarded with military and development aid. Of the $436 billion spent on foreign aid since 1946, two-thirds has been in military assistance, with the balance spent on humanitarian, development, and emergency relief programs. 

With the end of the Cold War, American policy-makers began to re-examine the underlying foundation and rationale for foreign aid program no longer applied to an American foreign policy, and world, in flux. Although developing countries in Asia, Latin America, and United States, their development, humanitarian, and emergency relief needs continued to grow.

The breakup of the Soviet Union ushered in a "new world order" comprised of post-Soviet successor states in Central and Eastern Europe seeking new political and economic systems. American policy-makers have supported the acceptance of democracy and capitalism in these states by providing massive amounts of foreign aid. Thus, the Newly-Independent (NIS) and Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS)(in addition to the Middle East) are the regions in which American resources and priorities increasingly have been focused.

The New Foreign Aid Regime: Immediately after the November 1994 Congressional elections brought both the House and Senate under Republican majorities, leaders in Congress began discussions on reducing foreign aid. Senator Jesse Helms (R-NC), Chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, is a documented critic of the present foreign aid system. Helms has called foreign aid an ineffective giveaway and has promised to intrude a foreign aid bill that not only will reduce foreign aid, but will impose tougher standards on foreign aid recipients.

To date, the Helms foreign aid bill has not been introduced. Upon its introduction, the Helms bill likely will become the primary legislative vehicle for the debate on foreign aid reform. Because it is authorizing legislation, the Helms bill would be considered first.

Senator Mitch McConnell (R-KY), Chairman of the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, announced that he would introduce legislation to revise America's foreign aid system. Calling the current foreign aid process outdated and inefficient McConnell's proposal establishes three goals for American foreign aid: 1) Foreign aid must protect American security interests; 2) Foreign aid must promote American economic interests; 3) Foreign aid must preserve political and regional stability.

Among other things, the McConnell proposal would increase foreign aid to the former Soviet republics, increase foreign aid to the Camp David countries (Israel and Egypt), and reduce or eliminate altogether several government agencies currently responsible for foreign aid.

The McConnell bill has not yet been introduced. As an appropriations bill, the McConnell legislation would be limited by the authorizations and policies contained in the Helms legislation.

Assault on Aid to Africa: Both Senator Helms and Senator McConnell are on record opposing the existing levels of foreign aid for Africa. Both have promised to scale back bilateral aid to Africa considerably, perhaps by as much as 20%.

Most troubling, the McConnell proposal would abolish protected funding (or earmarking) for the Development Fund for Africa (DFA) along with earmarks for the African Development Bank and the African Development Foundation. McConnell's proposal would reduce overall foreign aid to Africa by as much as 30%.

McConnell has stated: "(T)he continent of Africa has had a sort of perpetual earmark of about $800 million. I don't think there ought to be an earmark for them or for any other part of the world where we do not have a clear national security interest. There would be a residual pool of funds, up to $3 billion unearmarked, that countries in Africa and countries outside of Africa that have basically made no progress could still compete for, but I would want to target that assistance in a way that guaranteed some results. And we know we're going to get results when we try to encourage the spread of capitalism."

If Helms and McConnell pursue their plans, new foreign aid legislation would substantially isolate Africa the bulk of available foreign aid funds in the federal budget and force African countries that receive foreign aid to compete with other regions of the world for a diminished share of foreign assistance. Such a system establishes a road map for failure.

Protecting the Development Fund for Africa: The Development Fund for Africa (DFA) was proposed in 1987 following Congressional recognition that Africa was consistently left to survive from the crumbs of the larger foreign aid loaf while aid to other regions was insulated or protected by earmarks. Prior to the establishment of the DFA, foreign aid appropriations for Africa were vulnerable to plunder from any Member of Congress who could make a plausible or persuasive case for any other region or purpose. Owing to the leadership of the Congressional Black Caucus, this practice was stopped when the DFA was initiated.

Originally appropriated at $500 million, the DFA provided the Agency for International Development (AID) with a consistent way to meet long-term development and foreign policy objectives and an assured and stable source of funding for Africa.

The DFA emphasized the following policies in the American foreign aid program to Africa: (1) Concentrating DFA resources in selected African countries that demonstrated a willingness to undertake economic policy reforms and structural adjustment; (2) Focusing on critical sectors within those countries; (3) Encouraging African governmental reform while continuing to provide assistance for needed projects; (4) Addressing the social and environmental effects of development; (5) Integrating food aid with development assistance; and (6) Cooperating with host government agencies, bilateral and multilateral donors, and non governmental organizations involved in development assistance.

The DFA Has Been Successful:By almost every account, the Development Fund for Africa has been successful in providing bilateral development assistance to Africa. In a 1991 Report to the House Appropriation Committee (GAO Report), the Government Accounting Office (GAO) found that the DFA was being implemented consistent with congressional guidance.

The GAO Report made the following conclusions: (1) The DFA was concentrating its resources (appropriately) in countries that had adopted policy reforms to support economic growth. (2) DFA resources were concentrated in specific sectors that were determined to be essential to the recipient country's development success. (3) The DFA allowed recipient countries to maximize the utilization of other bilateral and multilateral assistance, particularly with respect to food aid, agricultural development and micro-enterprise development.

How Much Foreign Aid Does Africa Receive: There is a prevailing and erroneous perception that Africa receives an enormous amount of American foreign aid. This misperception has been exacerbated by a number of factors, including the following: (1) Abuse of American foreign aid by some African governments; (2) Africa's continued economic and political problems; and (3) American foreign aid to address natural disasters, emergencies, and large humanitarian relief efforts.

American interventions in Somalia and relief assistance to Rwanda have been costly, but together, this aid does not measure up to the assistance the U.S. has provided to the former Soviet Republics, or to the Camp David countries in any one year.

In 19941995, U.S. aid to Africa breaks down as follows: (1) Development Fund for Africa will be $802 million; (2) African Development Fund/Bank will be $124 million; (3) African Development Foundation will be $16 million.

African Aid Context: (1) American foreign aid totaled $13.8 billion in 1994. This represents less than 1 percent of the total United States budget of $1.5 trillion. (2) Aid to Africa represents 6 percent of the foreign aid budget and a meager .053 percent of the total United States budget. (3) America's contribution to foreign aid, as measured in percentage of GDP, is very little. Among Western countries, for example, the U.S. contributes only 0.20% of its GDP. This ranks far behind Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, Scandinavia countries and the United Kingdom, in some cases by as much as 100 per cent.

Why Africa Should Matter to the United States:There are many who argue that with the end of the Cold War, Africa no longer has strategic importance to the United States. Others seek to marginalize Africa's importance to America in terms of its fledgling economies and burdensome debt.

These views reflect an incomplete appreciation of the range of issues vital to the long-term economic and security interests of the United States, however defined.

In summary form, they are: Trade: Although the volume of trade between the United States and Africa is modest, much of it consists of commodities of vital importance to U.S. security -- high grade petroleum, platinum, titanium, chromium and other minerals, to which continued access is vital. Africa is also increasing its share of American exports, providing jobs and income for American taxpayers. Democracy: Democracy and market-oriented economies are on the rise in Africa. Without foreign assistance, fragile economies will be unable to develop democratically. Societies mired in perpetual poverty are highly susceptible to seeking growth and development through authoritarian leadership with a high probability of such states becoming hostile to U.S. interests.

Conclusion: Despite the many known failures of the foreign aid system, bilateral foreign aid and contributions to multilateral assistance efforts serve a valuable function, particularly in Africa. These programs constitute an infinitesimal portion of the total U.S. budget. Aid to Africa is slightly more than 1/2 of 1 percent of the U.S. budget and only 6 percent of American foreign aid.

Scaling back American aid to Africa sends the wrong signal to African governments and economies struggling to recover from the effects of colonialism and Cold War. If the United States acknowledges any leadership role in the world, it is in its interest as sole superpower to support African successes and, correctly, look critically on the failures.

Constituency for Africa, 1030 15th Street, NW, Suite 340, Washington, DC 20005. TEL: (202) 371-0588 FAX: (202) 371-9017


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

LENGTH: 480 words

64 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February, 1995


Special Report: Summit Called to Defend Africa Aid


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Summit on Africa Aid

Washington, DC

February 3, 1995

by Constituency for Africa

Washington, D.C. -- In what is clearly intended as a show of force, two African-American leaders, Andy Young and Donald Payne, have orchestrated a massive coalition of organizations to meet on Capitol Hill, Washington, D.C. on Friday, February 3. Their objective is to fight what they see as ominous moves in the 104th Republican-led Congress to eliminate U.S. economic assistance to Africa

Young -- who was a top aide to Martin Luther King, served as Jimmy Carter's unusually influential Ambassador to the UN, and ran Atlanta for two terms as Mayor -- currently plays two formal roles in U.S. policy toward Africa. First in October he was appointed by President Clinton to manage a $100 million fund dedicated to reconstructing post-apartheid South Africa and its neighbors. Second, he now heads the Board of the Constituency for Africa, CFA, a network of organizations and individuals whose aim is to generate support for better US policy toward Africa. CFA is doing the organizing legwork needed to pull off the February 3 meeting on Capitol Hill 

Don Payne, who represents Newark, is the first African-American from New Jersey to be elected to the House of Representatives. He was recently selected by his peers to head the Congressional Black Caucus, CBC. One of the longest serving members on the Africa subcommittee of the House panel that oversees America's international relations, Payne is considered a leading House lawmaker on Africa issues.

Dubbing their effort, "Summit on Africa Aid," Young and Payne have invited a virtual who-is-who of American civic organizations as well as some major businesses.

Included are: The Carter Center; US-South Africa Airways; NAACP; International Republican Institute; General Motors Corporation; Global Coalition for Africa; TransAfrica; the African-American Institute; the Aspen Institute; AT & T; and Coca Cola.

In their joint invitation letter, Payne and Young took particular issue with selected provisions in a bill announced on December 12 by Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky who recently took over leadership of the foreign operations subcommittee of the Senate's Appropriations Committee. In that position, McConnell will wield enormous influence over levels of foreign aid approved by the Senate.

For organizers of the Feb. 3 meeting, two pieces in the McConnell bill are particularly vexing. The first would abolish ADF, the African Development Foundation. This independent federal agency is tiny: the most money it ever has ever been allocated for a whole year is $16.9 million -- far less than the $31.7 million that the Pentagon spent each hour of 1994. ADF operates by circumventing African governments and by directly helping the poorest of poor Africans to build wells, to build schools, and to start small businesses. The second threat is McConnell's provision to remove earmarks (read, protection) from the Development Fund for Africa, DFA. The inevitable result, all objective analysts agree, would be to end U.S. aid to Africa as we know it.

In sharp contrast to squeezing Africa, McConnell would open the floodgates of US aid to Ukraine, Poland, Estonia, Georgia, Azerbaijan, Latvia, Lithuania, Slovakia, the Czech Republic, and Hungary. Critics point out that these are mostly European countries and all used to be behind the iron curtain -- meaning a few short years ago, they were America's communist archenemies.

Those in the know expect the Young-Payne group to use two complementary

arguments to make its case: the first will attempt to show the concrete ways in which foreign aid benefits America. The second argument will reason that zeroing sub-Saharan Africa out American foreign aid would be both unfair and shortsighted.

To most observers, the Young-Payne group has set itself a formidable task -- particularly in the current Congressional climate of budget slashing in which programs that benefit even the most vulnerable American citizens (e.g. welfare for single mothers, public broadcasting programs or children, etc.) are under attack.

The betting is that in such an atmosphere, foreign aid does not have a prayer of escaping the budget ax. Even in the best of times in U.S. domestic politics, foreign assistance has long remained an unloved stepchild among federal budgetary programs. Few politicians defend it, even in private. And those who reluctantly vote for it are never anxious to advertise that fact. Probably, for good political reason polls show that the American public thinks that 20 cents out of every federal dollar goes to foreign aid (the truth is less than one cent!).

Finally, there is the question dreaded by foreign aid proponents: Why should we Americans give our scarce dollars to foreigners when we have so many problems at home and are tightening our own belts?

Aid proponents find this situation frustrating. In their view, the truth surrounding foreign assistance is very different. First, the proportion of the federal budget that goes to foreign aid is tiny. Second and more important, they assert that foreign aid is a bargain and is an efficient tool for promoting the American interest abroad -- more efficient they assert, than such alternative as covert action or military force.

In addition, Africa's friends argue that other criteria besides McConnell's -- e.g. aid recipients' need; elimination of poverty; humanitarian concerns; and the desires of 40 million African-Americans -- should be considered in dividing the American aid pie. Clearly, use of such criteria would put Africa in a strong position to continue receiving American aid.

The skeptics doubt that these arguments will be effective enough to turn the Congressional tide in favor of both foreign aid in general, and assistance to Africa in particular. Still, Young, Payne, and the other organizers of the "Summit" express confidence.

Press Release of January 26, 1995 by the Constituency for Africa, 1030 15th Street, NW, Suite 340, Washington, DC 20005. TEL: (202) 371-0588 FAX: (202) 371-9017


LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1995


Education


LENGTH: 242 words


 

The University of Westminster offers Postgraduate courses in Francophone African Studies. Students of this program will earn either a Master of Arts degree, a Postgraduate Diploma or Postgraduate Certificate. For further information and an application form, please contact: Nikki Roberts, School of Languages, University of Westminister, 9-18 Euston Centre, London NW1 3ET. Tel: 0171911 5000 ext, 4364. Fax: 0171 911 5001

Drew University offers a summer study program in Cote D'Ivoire, West Africa. Program dates are July 18 to August 17, 1995. Particular attention is given to local art and its relationship to the culture producing it. Interested student have the opportunity to work with artists who are vital links in a tradition of apprenticeship. Jerome Vogel was the first American professor at the University of Abidjan in 1964-65 and is the program director. The program is open to undergraduate and graduate students, artists and crafts people, teachers, and others interested in learning about Africa. The application deadline is April 1, 1995. For further information and an application from contact: Office or Off-Campus Programs, Drew University, Madison, NJ 07940 Tel: (201) 408-3438

66 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


Resources


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

The US Committee for UNICEF and UNICEF will join the Organization for African Unity for the fifth consecutive year to commemorate the Day of the African Child. This worldwide advocacy campaign is held in memory of the Soweto massacre on June 16, 1976 and is an important platform for focusing greater public attention and resources for Africa. The Day of the African Child also present an opportunity to celebrate child survival and development achievements in Africa, while at the same time recognizing challenges that still must be addressed. The theme this year is children in armed conflict. In the past decade, approximately two million children have been killed in armed conflicts, about 12 million have been left homeless and more than one million have been orphaned. For more information on how you can participate, contact the US Committee for UNICEF, 333 East 38th Street, New York, NY 10016. Tel: (800) FOR-KIDS or (212) 686-5522. 

Volunteers for Peace is a non-profit membership organization promoting International Workcamps in 50 coutries. The 1995 International Workcamp Directory is now available for $12, which includes first class postage. The annual booklet, 120 pages, lists over 800 opportunities for creative travel throughout North and West Africa and The Americas among other places. Workcapms are inexpensive ways that Americans of all ages can promote international goodwill through community service projects in 50 countries. 2 - 3 week programs are $150. Please call or write for the 1995 directory (Visa and MasterCard are accepted) or for a free copy of the newsletter. Contact: VFP International Workcamps, 43 Tiffany Road, Belmont, VT 05730. Tel: (802) 259-2759.

Award Nomination Deadline Extended: The Reebok Human Rights Award recognizes young people (age 30 and younger) who have made a significant contribution to the cause of human rights. The nomination deadline for the 1995 Reebok Human Rights Award has been extended to April 30, 1995. For more information on how to make a nomination for the Award, contact Reebok Human Rights Program, Reebok International Ltd., 100 Technology Center Drive, Stoughton, MA 02072. Tel: (617) 341-7321. Fax: (617) 297-4806. E-mail: human.rights@reebok.com

The Fourth World Conference on Women will be held in Beijing, China in September, 1995. Already, millions of women around the world are mobilizing to guarantee that their voices are heard. The Conference will produce a Platform for Action that is expected to guide international and national policies on women's issues into the next century. An NGO Forum is also being planned just prior to the official Conference and it is hoped that women will use that experience to network and to share resources and strategies for lobbying the official delegates.

The Secretary-General of the Conference is Ms. Gertrude Mongella of Tanzania, who is in charge of organizing the Conference and preparing the documentation. Her office is located at 2 UN Plaza, Room DC-2-1220, New York, NY 10017, USA. Tel: 212/963-5068; Fax: 212/963-3463.

The NGO Forum is being convened by Ms. Supatra Masdit of Thailand. Ms. Irene Santiago is the Executive Director of the NGO Forum '95. Her office is located at 211 East 43rd Street, Suite 1500, New York, NY 10017 USA. Tel: 212/922-9267; Fax 212/922-9269. The deadline to register for the NGO Forum is 30 April, 1995.

National groups have been formed in most countries to provide input, oversight and information on this major world conference, and NGOs may still be accredited to the official process by contacting the Secretariat of the UN Fourth World Conference on Women, NGO Accreditation Office, 2 UN Plaza, 12th Floor, Room GC2, New York, NY 10017 USA. Tel: 212/963-8034; Fax 212/963-3463.

Development through Self-Reliance, Inc. (DSR) is pleased to announce that it is now distributing "Developing Strategies," a 56-minute video on educational training projects in Africa. "Developing Strategies," produced by the African Forum for Children's Literacy in Science and Technology, an activity of the Rockefeller Foundation, is available for all countries on VHS PAL video in English.

"Developing Strategies" looks at three educational projects in science and technology that have succeeded in Africa despite a lack of textbooks and interesting scientific materials. The first, Minds Across in Uganda, encourages children to write booklets and reading materials to each other. The second, Action Magazine in Zimbabwe, is a project that distributes comic-strip magazines on health and the environment to all schools in the country. The third, Kagera Writers Cooperative Union in Tanzania, publishes a newsletter for local farmers and textbooks in science and technology for the local school system. Lastly, "Developing Strategies" describes how these projects are also working on AIDS education.

"Developing Strategies" is available for $19.95 plus shipping through DSR at 9111 Guilford Road, Columbia, MD 21046, USA; fax 301-490-4146, e-mail dsr@us.net, or call 800-875-0037. It is also available locally in Kenya, Namibia, Senegal, Sierra Leone, South Africa, Tanzania, and Zimbabwe. Please contact DSR for their addresses.

The Overseas Development Network publishes catalogs, guides and information packets useful to those seeking internships, study and work opportunities in international development. Guides include contact information and suggestions for applying to international organizations in the United States and abroad. Write or call for the ODN publications order form by contacting: Overseas Development Network, 333 Valencia St., Suite 330 San Francisco, CA 94103. Tel: (415) 431-4204. Fax: (415) 431-5953. E-Mail: odn@igc.org.

Media for Development (MFD), a Zimbabwean registered charity, is seeking donations to expand it collection of development-related videos for use in it resource center. The center has over 200 video and 16 mm titles that Zimbabwean organizations can borrow and use in educational and outreach programs. MFD would like to acquire more titles in the following categories: agriculture, environment, health, culture/arts, politics and gender issues. Contact: Ben Zulu, MFD, PO Box 6755, 135 Union Avenue, Harare, Zimbabwe. Telephone: (263-4) 733364/5. FAX (263-4) 729066; or, Christine Schlegel, Media for Development International, 9111 Guilford Road, Columbia, MD 21046. Tel: (301) 490-4465.

Visions in Action is an international nonprofit organization offering volunteer opportunities working with development organizations in Africa and Latin America. Placement for volunteers is available in Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Zimbabwe, Burkina Faso, Dominican Republic and South Africa. Program areas include community development, health care, housing, youth coordination, the environment, human rights, democratization, research, journalism and others. The program is open to persons of any nationality. For more information contact: Visions in Action, 3637 Fulton St., NW, Washington, D.C. 20007. Tel: (202) 625-7402. Fax (202) 625-2353. E-mail: africajob@aol.com.


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


67 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


Announcements


LENGTH: 907 words


 

Hofstra Cultural Center announces a call for papers for Africa 2000, an interdisciplinary conference examining the situation of Africa in the year 2000 and the decade thereafter. Papers should focus on or emphasize the immediate future faced by the continent. Any discussion that increases an understanding of Africa's next decade and a half are welcome. Papers are invited on such diverse topics as African Americans and Africa; the African Diaspora; ethnic relations; medical geography; multinational corporations; public health; popular culture; single and multiparty states; urbanization; and women in Africa. Previously presented or published material should not be submitted. The conference will feature keynote speaker Chinua Achebe. DEADLINE: MARCH 15, 1995, for final papers (in duplicate), one-page abstract, and curriculum vitae. Contact: Athelene A. Collins, Hofstra University, Hampstead, NY 11550-1090, phone 516/ 564-4306.

March 24-26, 1995 SUNY Buffalo African Student Association will be hosting a Pan-African conference focusing on economic development in Africa and its links, dependencies and relationships to the social and political climate, as well as the relevance of U.S. Foreign Policy in Africa. Africa News


March, 1995


River Blindness Causes A Maddening Itch, A Newly Recognized Burden Broadened Campaign Could Eliminate The Disease From Africa


SECTION: SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND MEDICINE


LENGTH: 1587 words


 

World Health Organization (Geneva)

March 27, 1995

International organizations are preparing to launch a new campaign in Africa against a strain of river blindness (Onchocerciasis) recently shown by a new study to cause a widespread, maddening itch that often incapacitates its victims.

"We never realized that this 'forest' strain could be so seriously debilitating," says Tore Godal, M.D., director of the UNDP (United Nations Development Programme)/ World Bank/ WHO (World Health Organization) Special Programme for Research and Training in Tropical Diseases (TDR). "The disease also causes scars, disfigurement and serious psycho-social problems."

Victims cannot sleep, find it difficult to work and fear that the disease might kill them; they also feel like social outcasts, uprooted from their communities; some even contemplate suicide.

"Affected people are stereotyped as weak, emotionally dull and cold," the TDR study says. "They are considered as dangerous, dirty and are avoided for fear that they might pass on their disease to others. The person who suffers from onchocercal skin disease is likened to an animal on the basis of his or her skin and behavior." 

The skin disease caused by the "forest" strain affects all age groups but especially people 20-40 years old, the most productive members of society. In contrast, the blindness caused by the "savanna" strain of the disease affects mostly those over 40.

Onchocerciasis is caused by an infection by the nematode worm Onchocerca volvulus for which man is the only known reservoir. The adult worms are usually found in subcutaneous (beneath the skin) nodules. The adult female worm produces millions of microfilariae (early larval forms of worms) that migrate to the skin and the eyes of the human host. The parasite is transmitted by a blackfly of the genus Simulium, which ingests microfilariae while taking blood from humans and then passes it on to non-infected humans when it takes their blood.

Onchocerciasis Control Program in West Africa (OCP), financed by an international consortium of donor countries and the World Bank, brought the disease under control in the savanna belt of the West African countries of Benin, Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Guinea Bissau, Guinea, Mali, Niger, Senegal, Sierra Leone and Togo. Control was achieved with a combination of spraying programs to kill the larvae of the blackfly and utilization of the drug invermectin, first begun in 1987, that prevents blindness in the infected by killing newly hatched worms. All doses of ivermectin are given at no cost by its manufacturer, Merck.

Outside of the OCP, there are 16 nations where either form of the disease is endemic--Angola, Burundi, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Congo, Equatorial Guinea, Ethiopia, Gabon, Liberia, Malawi, Nigeria, Sudan, Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire. However, for these countries, there is as yet no coordinated international program to fight onchocerciasis.

A recent WHO review shows that some 18 million people have either form of the disease, and that 15 million live outside the OCP. Of those, almost 9 million are infected with the "forest" strains, which cause a heavy burden of skin disease, according to the new study. The "forest" strains are widespread in the forest belt of West, Central and East Africa; the blinding variety is prevalent in the West African savanna.

The World Bank and WHO, in collaboration with other sponsoring international agencies and a cadre of non-governmental development organizations, are preparing to fight the disease in the other 16 countries in a campaign called the African Programme for Onchocerciasis Control (APOC). The program is scheduled to take 10 years. Estimates show that the program will cost a maximum of $100 million. Funding will be mobilized by the World Bank from basically the same coalition of bilateral and multilateral donors which currently support the OCP.

TDR's study was carried out in eight collaborative centers in severely infected onchocerciasis areas in West, Central and East Africa. Four centers were Nigeria and the others were in Tanzania and Uganda in East Africa, Cameroon in Central Africa and Ghana in West Africa.

The study used onchocerciasis affected villages and non-onchocerciasis affected villages as controls to provide a basis for comparison.

This study utilized an innovative approach that was based on extensive psycho-social interviews with sufferers of onchocerciasis to learn how the disease affects their lives, as well as on new methods for the clinical classification of the skin disease itself.

The New Program: The new effort aims to control both strains of river blindness outside the OCP area. To raise the necessary $100 million, The World Bank is asking aid from the donor countries, and the program is scheduled to begin operations in 1996.

"If successful, the disease would be brought under full control in 10 years in all endemic countries, as long as none experience political instability," says Dr. Godal.

TDR has been requested by the Bank to help solve key epidemiological, mapping, treatment, distribution and monitoring programs, and the feasibility of local blackfly eradication in isolated areas in the 16 non-OCP endemic countries. It may be possible, for example, to eradicate the fly vector completely from some parts of East Africa, where it seems the species can be eradicated with a matter of weeks or months.

TDR has already resolved some of the questions. One of these was to devise a "rapid mapping" methods for onchocerciasis. "Rapid epidemiological mapping allows us to find out where the hot spots of the disease are," says Dr. Godal.

Nigeria is already fully mapped, and Cameroon will be done by June. The survey will be completed in the remaining countries within one year. All of the information will be used to create a computer data base that will be available to everyone working on onchocerciasis control.

Currently, TDR is studying to see what ivermectin will do for the skin disease variety. To prevent blindness, just one dose of ivermectin per year is needed for those infected, but it is not yet known what dosage is required for the skin disease, though TDR scientists believe more than one dose per year will be necessary.

TDR is also conducting a multi-nation research study as to how best bring a sustainable delivery of ivermectin over an indefinite period to all affected areas. It will be based upon a village-based delivery treatment system, called Community Self-Treatment. The study will compare the method of health specialists developing community plans to other methods developed by the communities themselves.

Experience to date indicates that ivermectin treatment is very popular among endemic populations and that communities can effectively take responsibility for their own treatments.

It should be possible to control onchocerciasis at very low cost with active community involvement and with the support of a coalition of non-governmental development organizations in the non-OCP countries.

"Community self-treatment with ivermectin may also provide an important entry point for other community-based health interventions and thus help to develop a practical basis for strengthening primary health care in some of the poorest and most under-served communities in the world," says Dr. Godal.

"Recent research findings clearly show that the people of highly endemic communities consider onchocerciasis, especially the grave and unrelenting itching, to be one of their main health problems and the cause of much misery," the report says.

World Health Organization, CH-1211 Geneva 27, Switzerland. In US, contact Marshall Hoffman, (703) 820-2244.


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


72 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Ravan Renews The Best Of The Past

Weekly Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)

March 31, 1995

Ravan, one of the stalwart anti-apartheid publishers of the dark years of South Africa's history, have started a new series of titles called the Ravan Writers Series.

It was Ravan that first published JM Coetzee; that published Mongane Wally Serote's first (and thus far only) novel. Many of their books were banned by the white Nationalist government -- and its founder Peter Randall was restricted. 

But, like so many other of the smaller local publishers, Ravan had a hard time of it even when the threat of repression had been lifted. While it continued to produce important titles, their appearance was often irregular -- and finances were no rosier than they had been in the Emergency years.

Recent manoeuvres have given Ravan a new lease on life and the opportunity to capitalise on a backlist that includes some of South African literature's most interesting and important works.

The Ravan Writers Series will also aim to attract and encourage a range of new and established writers, drawing them into the series.

The series has been launched with nine titles. They are:

* Yvonne Burgess' Say a Little Mantra for Me, a humorous picture of life in the confines of a South African family.

* Waiting for Leila by Achmat Dangor, which won the 1979 Mofolo-Plomer Prize in conjunction with Mzala by Mbulelo Mzamane, also in the Ravan Writers series. The former tells the story of a man frantically searching for a woman amid the destruction of District Six. The latter is a version of the Jim-Comes-to-Jo'burg tale, a humourous and penetrating view of township life.

* David Muller's Whitey is a bleakly affecting novel focusing on one weekend in the life of a footloose, alcoholic sailor who finds himself in the depths of District Six.

* Ahmed Essop's novella The Emperor is a satire about a egotistical and authoritarian headmaster.

* The Schoolmaster by Rose Moss presents the dilemmas of a man who defies an oppressive system.

* The World of Nat Nakasa, edited by Essop Patel, collects the work of one of South Africa's key black writers of the Fifties, showing off the "loud and thunderous voice" with which he challenged inequality.

* Noni Jabavu's The Ochre People is a delightfully warm-hearted memoir of a return to South Africa in 1955 by a woman who had grown up in this country but left for schooling in England at the age of 13.

* Native Life in South Africa is a great classic of South African literature, a vital work by Sol T Plaatje, one of the ANC's founders and the first black person to publish a novel in English. It details the horrible results of the 1913 Land Act on the dispossessed people of South Africa.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


73 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Benin's High Priest Of Urban Waste


LENGTH: 1334 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)

March 31, 1995

by Tony Karon

Beninoise artist Romuald Hazoume makes traditional religious masks -- out of discarded objects. 'I'm just sending back the rubbish sent from Europe to Africa,' he said. Hazoume probably turned more heads than any other artist visiting the Johannesburg Biennale.

The young Beninoise exhibited a series of traditional religious masks crafted from plastic oil cans, old radios and other urban waste. On the opposite wall, he hung a series of complex paintings attempting a graphic representation of the oracle of divination used by the high priests of the Fa, the traditional Yoruba religion practised throughout West Africa (and, in adapted forms born of slavery, throughout the Americas). 

The exhibit commented with wry wit on Africa's relationship with the West, at the same time as expressing the artist's deep roots in Yoruba tradition -- and captivated most visitors to the Biennale.

Even those who overlooked the masks would not have failed to notice Hazoume's powerful physical presence, as he presided regally in his magnificent blue bubu alongside his work or at Biennale openings.

Wearing traditional clothing is a reflection of his overall strategy as an African artist operating abroad (primarily in Europe): "We never forget where we are from, and we maintain our tradition. We wear our traditional clothes to show that people from Benin are here. It's our way, our culture. If we don't do that, people here would think we are South African."

At the same time, he refuses to be categorised as a folk artist. On one occasion he travelled to Hamburg at the invitation of a German gallery owner, only to discover that he was to exhibit at an ethnological museum. He turned down the show. "I am not an 'African artist'; I am an artist," he explains.

His work is located at an intersection between Yoruba tradition and a post-industrial international art market -- Hazoume carries his portfolio on CD Rom. His route to art was almost accidental. As an undergraduate student in Benin, with plans to go into either medicine or architecture, the university lost his exam papers. He left in disgust, and in the seething anger and depression which followed, he began to create collages on the bark of banana trees, and sell them to expatriate Europeans in Benin. From the proceeds, he bought a house and started making batik prints. That earned more money, and created a secure financial base for Hazoume to develop his own art works.

Initially, he concentrated on making masks, and was soon invited to exhibit all over Europe: "In Africa, it is very sad that we don't have our sacred masks any more; they (Europeans) steal all. What I am doing with my masks is sending back the rubbish sent from Europe to Africa -- if I can get money for that, it's even better."

He also sees himself as a recycler: "Many Africans use this material and throw it away. If they can get it again in their house and pay me for it, it's wonderful. People don't realise that these materials can have two lives."

Hazoume's masks, he stresses, have no ritual value: "They are simply art." Nonetheless, they are firmly grounded in tradition: "In our country we have a tradition of making sacred masks from wood. I cannot make masks without this tradition. Before I opened the exhibition in Johannesburg, we (he and his Beninoise curator) made a voudon ceremony here. There are many secret societies here in South Africa, of the animist religion. We needed to make a conversation with these people here in this ceremony, to ask permission to show our masks. If we don't have permission, nobody can see these masks." The ceremony was private, and the Biennale organisers were unaware of it. "It is our problem, it is not a show."

A South African gallery owner interrupts our interview to offer Hazoume a show. "Call me, let's talk," the owner urges. "Why not?" Hazoume sighs, a little warily. He doesn't like galleries, and is fiercely resisting the pressures of the European art market on African artists to produce work to order. "I don't like to work with galleries or have an agent. An agent tells you what to do -- you work to get money from the agent. But money is not my problem. I just want to show something. If I have success, it's good. If I don't, it doesn't matter.

Part of the problem is the almost total absence of an African art market: "African people have no interest in buying art," Hazoume sighs. "People in Benin cannot buy art, they have no money. And they don't understand this art. They don't understand how people can pay me money to buy these masks. To them it's crazy."

Although he has sold some work in Cote d'Ivoire and Senegal, his ability to survive as an artist depends almost exclusively on sales to Europeans. "European galleries want to show African work now because European work now is static, and less interesting. They want to see new work, new material." While this is cause for optimism, "at the same time I am anxious. Many African people like money too much, and have no dignity. I want to show our culture, not sell our culture."

He urges caution for South African artists dealing with Western markets: "Today many museums and galleries want to show the work of African artists. But be careful! They will eat you so fast, and spit you out. Like Cheri Samba. It's so sad." He proceeds to relate how the celebrated Zairean artist has signed a contract with a European gallery which requires such a high volume of output that it has drastically reduced the value of his paintings: "It's like a factory."

To negotiate the treacherous international art market, Hazoume believes the artist needs a strong sense of identity: "Your best chance is to stay with your traditions," he advises South African artists. "Think about your tradition -- each country has its own traditions."

It took Hazoume five years to complete his divination paintings now hanging opposite his masks in the Electric Workshop in Newtown. But he was in no hurry, for they represent an exploration of the very core of his identity. That exploration brought him and his inspired work to Johannesburg, which suggests that the Yoruba gods smiled (at least momentarily) on the much-maligned Johannesburg Biennale.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.
