Africa News


March, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Spreading The Jazz Gospel


LENGTH: 1867 words


 

New Nation (Johannesburg)

February 3, 1995

by Mfundo Ndeble

Mfundo Ndebele: It must be great to be the son of an immortal jazz legend?

Thelonius Monk Jr.: Well yes, as you can imagine. I am absolutely privileged and honoured to be the son of a man who bequeathed such a rich heritage to jazz.

I love and admire my father for his great achievement and fame. He was certainly among the jazz giants of the likes of Duke Ellington, Johnny Hodges, Louis Armstrong and John Coltrane. From time to time my father hosted these maestros and many others at home. 

Sometimes he took me along to his shows. One thing is sure-- my father laid a strong foundation for my musical inclination.

I dabbled with the trumpet at the age of two, with Miles Davis as my role model. My father never said a word about it. Mesmerised by the great jazz drummer Max Roach's playing, I then tried drums. Still my father said nothing to me about music. When I turned 15, I finally made up my mind to settle for drums as a means of expressing my artistic feelings.

I broke my father's silence by telling him that I wanted to take up music as a career. Predictably, he gave me his blessing, but stressed that learning to read music was of paramount importance.

He asked the greats, Max Roach and Art Blakely, to teach me how to play drums. My father also sent me to college. His reticence about music with me, though, still remained.

When I turned 20, something very funny happened. My father called me and asked: "Are you ready to play?" Two days later, there I was playing alongside my father in his band. The show, which turned out to be a sensation, was screened on national TV and broadcast on radio. That's how I was baptised into jazz.

MN: Can you define jazz?

TM: Like love, jazz defies a single definition. To me, jazz is an instrument of liberation- physical, spiritual and mental liberation. It activates freedom of thought. It is the mouthpiece of the oppressed. Jazz has played a significant role in the emancipation of the oppressed.

When jazz began to flourish in the 30s, it was in demand. Black musicians traveled around the world where they witnessed democracy in practice. These roving ambassadors of jazz spread the message of democracy and what it meant. They began to see America from outside. This broadened their national and universal perspectives. Their ideas contributed to the civil rights movement. Their ideas also lent a clear understanding to the earlier liberatory writings of Frederick Douglas, W.E.B. DuBois and other who had led the struggle for freedom.

Jazz brought together Black Revolutionaries , white intellectual and liberals, particularly Jews. Jazz gave an impetus to the process of integration in the United States. Bringing people together was a priority of jazz. It was incumbent on it to forge a universal brotherhood.

What made jazz unique in America was that it was born of the oppressed human spirit in search of freedom.

MN: How do you view current jazz trends?

TM: Compared to the 50s, 60s and 70s, the standard of jazz today is low. The reason for this is not hard to find. Within the last 20 years we have lost jazz legends who are not easy to replace. These include Charlie Parker, John Coltrane, Louis Armstrong, Duke Ellington and Miles Davis. This artistic holocaust, in which our leaders died so close to each other, left a huge gap in the world of jazz.

There are two chief characteristics of jazz which to a large extent make it a unique musical form- it has an intellectual impact on the masses while it simultaneously inculcates self-identity and pride. And this runs against the grain of the oppressor.

MN: Does "fusion", which to some people is an ultra-modern form of jazz, perhaps give us a glimpse of jazz in the 21st century?

TM: No. "Fusion" is not futuristic, it's the product of experimenting. It was created when rock-and-roll became popular in the 60s. Jazz record companies feared that rock-and-roll was robbing jazz of popularity. So they instilled elements of rock-and-roll into jazz. The result was fusion.

Behind fusion is a desire to get a broader audience. But the die-hard jazz fans greeted "fusion" with utter contempt. To them, it was not natural. It was a commercial vehicle.

MN: Tell us about the Thelonius Monk Institute of Jazz?

TM: It was founded in 1986 and we are expanding all the time. We want to establish a musical conservatory primarily for jazz. In almost all the world's musical institutes, classical music reigns supreme. We say jazz is supreme and rightfully so because jazz is the most influential music in the history of the world.

We mold and enhance the talent of young people. We enlist the help of great musicians such as Herbie Hancock and Ramsey Lewis, among others, to teach the kids everything there is to learn about theory and jazz instruments.

MN: How does it feel to be on African soil for the first time?

TM: I feel very new. It is as if I have been reborn. I feel like a native and foreigner all at once. I have a "deja vu" feel. I love and adore President Mandela. I count him among our great freedom fighters Marcus Garvey, Malcolm X, Kwame Nkrumah and many others. Mandela has restored the dignity of Black People all over the world. He is now at the helm of South Africa which was the last bastion of white supremacy.

But there is a lot that still needs to be done in the reconstruction of your country. That is why the Jazz Ambassadors and I will be coming back to South Africa to help in whatever way we can.

ARTISTS of South Africa unite! This is the message that rang out loud and clear during last week's jazz workshops conducted by two top American jazz musicians, Thelonius Monk junior and Thomas Carter, at the United States Information Service in Johannesburg.

The two roving jazz ambassadors shared their 18 year experience of fund-raising for arts projects with representatives of local arts bodies during a fund -raising workshop.

The Thelonius Monk Institute of Jazz, which was founded by the two artists, is a living symbol of the success of their fundraising techniques.

When it was founded in 1986, it had a mere 100 dollars in its coffers. Within 9 years, the Institute's bank account had swollen by hundreds of thousands of dollars.

Both men urged local arts bodies to amalgamate into a single powerful organisation as the first step towards raising the funds on which their survival depends.

Carter said there were two vital aspects to be considered. The first was the size of the organisation's membership. The other was the donors' preference for funding one large organisation rather than advancing money to many small organisations.

At present there are several dozen arts organisations in South Africa, characterised by a lack of interaction and joint effort. Instead they continually compete for overseas donations.

The public image and credibility of the organisations in search of funds are of vital importance. According to Carter, one way of acquiring the right image is to co-opt enthusiastic and respectable public figures.

The Thelonius Monk Institute of Jazz is a case in point. Carter pointed out that the co-chairpersons on the institute's board of directors were the famous comedian, Bill Cosby, and the popular Black actor, Billy Dee Williams, who co-stars in the classic film "Lady Sings the Blues".

"Their association with the Institute gives it a positive image and credibility in the eyes of potential donors," he said.

Monk stressed the need for influential contacts across a broad social spectrum. "Contacts are an essential aspect of fundraising. Make acquaintance with those in influential positions like politicians, journalists, wealthy business people, lawyers and others. They can be your mouthpiece in debates on the arts," Monk said.

When an organisaton sets out in search of funds, it must be clear about its goals, policies and strategies. Its mission statement must be explicit.

"For you to win the favour of a potential donor, you must be eloquent and convincing," he said.

"In the brochure or journal of organisation you must acknowledge the company's donation and promote the sales of its products. Expose, isolate and boycott the commodities of those companies which turn down requests for donations," said Carter.

If these strategies have worked and turned Thelonious Monk Institute Jazz Ambassadors into a prestigious music body in the USA, how can our financially struggling arts bodies fail to rise to the challenge?

New Nation Publishing Co., 1st Floor Darragh House, 13 Wanderers Street, Johannesburg. PO Box 10674 Johannesburg 2000. Tel:(011) 333-2711 or (011) 333-2721. Fax: (011) 333-2733. Telex: 482226


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


75 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


NIGERIA: Here Comes Dikko Again


LENGTH: 1934 words


 

Newswatch (Lagos)

February 13, 1995

by Godwin Agbroko

Book Review

Title: "Diplomatic Baggage-MOSSAD and Nigeria: The Dikko Story

Author: Kayode Soyinka

Publishers: Newswatch Books Ltd.

Even as a practising Muslim, Umaru Dikko as a politician could do with Christ's admonition that it is not what goes into the mouth that defiles a man, but what comes out of it. At a time the citizenry was being pauperised by his ruling National Party of Nigeria, NPN, Dikko chose to make his now infamous rebuttal that there was no hunger in the land. His evidence: Nigerians had not started to eat from the dustbins!

As a senior minister in government and the man charged with procuring rice for Nigerians, Dikko's choice of logic was not impolitic, it was insensitive. Nigerians at the time may not have been scavenging the dustbins for food, not because they had a choice in the matter, but most certainly because there were no leftovers in the dustbins. 

Add to that his haughty carriage, his air of omnipotence, his peculiar ability to arouse suspicion of corruption to himself even as he tried to cut the picture of a man more sinned against than sinning, then Dikko was clearly a throw-back to the era of the divine right of kings, where the monarch could do no wrong; and a bad king was a reproach for a people for their sinful ways. For Nigerians, Dikko was the symbol of all that was vile in the Shagari administration.

Of course, the military in their self-righteousness refused to see the Shagari "monarchy" as a reproach. They struck on December 31, 1983 and sent Dikko and his NPN colleagues scurrying abroad for safety. In Britain to where he fled, Dikko, that rare politician who would not chew his words before uttering began a verbal "jihad" to mobilise his fellow countrymen to chase away the interlopers.

It was in furtherance of this mission that Dikko set out that morning of July 5, 1984, from his Porchester Terrace residence in London, for an interview appointment with a Ghanaian journalist. A few meters away from his home, he was forcibly abducted, anaesthetised, crated as diplomatic baggage, and taken to Sanstead Airport to be air freighted home. The attempt, though botched, resonated throughout the world. Overnight, Nigeria had joined the league of international brigands.

Ten years after, Kayode Soyinka, "Newswatch's" London bureau chief, has returned to the subject with a book, "Diplomatic Baggage-Mossad and Nigeria: The Dikko Story".

With Soyinka's help, the "why" and "how" of the Dikko saga can now be stitched together reasonably firmly. In the author's hand, the tale acquires a fresh life, taking on new meanings in the telling. For sure, he is a journalist, not a historian, and when he tells of an episode, he does not so much reproduce it as reconstruct it. In that reconstruction, "Diplomatic Baggage" takes the reader on a cinematic, breezy journey of discovery, the eloquence finding expression in the literary technique of narration and explanation.

Revelation for the reader begins with the question, why Dikko alone? Why not Augustus Akinloye, the chairman of the NPN reputed by the military, though untrue, to own a vineyard abroad for making his own choice champagne? Why not Bello Maitama Yusuf, the Czar of the import license regime? As the author shows quite early and rather persuasively, Dikko was a victim of the fabulous myth of his own life, a man condemned in the eyes of the military and Nigerians by his own mouth.

The same persuasive argument connects the government of Muhammad Buhari to the kidnap attempt. Calling in evidence the role of Nigerian diplomats and military intelligence officers; the behaviour of the Nigerian government and its high commissioner to the court of St. James before and after the event; and Dikko's own activities as minister of exile in Britain. "Diplomatic Baggage" provides strong clues to which other researchers may have to turn to unravel the answers. The most compelling of the clues is the theory that the National Security Organisation, NSO, may have planned and executed the kidnap, neither with the knowledge of the ministry of external affairs, nor with the imprimatur of the head of state.

That could have been made possible by the structural jumble that defined, rather ambivalently, the relationship between the NSO and the external affairs ministry on the one hand, and the personalities of the heads of the two organs on the other. Mohammed Lawal Rafindadi, newly-appointed director-general of the NSO, was an envoy of long-standing who had capped his foreign service career as Nigeria's ambassador to Bonn. Obviously, he knew more about the internal workings of the ministry than Ibrahim Gambari, who, prior to his appointment as minister was director-general of the Nigerian Institute of International Affairs, NIIA. To confound the situation, the ministry's research department by the decree establishing the NSO, was brought under the intelligence organisation as its external wing and renamed the Directorate of External Intelligence. As if that was not bad enough, Rafindadi, as chief intelligence officer, was a member of the supreme military council, the highest ruling body, while the external affairs minister was not. Of course, it would be less than human given the situation if the NSO director-general did not feel superior to the minister. As Gambari himself put it, "he (Rafindadi) appeared to have seen himself as a member of the supreme military council with the supervisory role over this ministry -- a view I did not accept. Worse still, some senior officers in our ministry were fond on currying favour whit the NSO boss and attempted to involve him in personal or policy decisions."

In such a situation, anyone, particularly the NSO director-general, was capable of taking advantage of the confusion where the ministry of external affairs exercised administrative supervision over the staff of the department of external intelligence while operational control was with the mother agency, the NSO. Given the criminal zeal of the NSO at the time, was it not possible, as the author suggests, that Rafindadi may have suborned Peter Oyedele and Okon Edet, the two Nigerian diplomats involved in the abduction, in order to shore up his credentials as a crack intelligence manager in a regime that was already pre-disposed toward arbitrariness? Unfortunately, the answer must await the fullness of time.

As to this, there is no doubt. Even if Rafindadi were to have acted on his own, the Buhari regime, in providing the enabling environment by its own arbitrariness, was vicariously guilty of the crime. So too must Nigerians share in the blame. By their vengeful spirit and condemnation of the political class without proven guilt, they unwittingly encouraged the wholesale abridgment of fundamental human rights and the subsequent brigandage abroad.

When we come to the MOSSAD connection, we are on a less firmer ground. Of the four men arrested and tried for Dikko's forcible abduction, only one, Mohammed Yusuf, a military intelligence officer was a Nigerian, the other, Israelis. They were the ring leader -Alexander Barak, a diamond dealer and MOSSAD operative; Felix Abithol, a clothing importer; and Lev-Arie Shapiro, the anaesthetist who drugged Dikko. Although Shapiro may have though that he was working for Israel through the MOSSAD, probably because of the intelligence connections of Barak, the man who recruited him, there is no hard evidence to suggest that this was so. Barak himself testified on trial that he carried out the plot on behalf of certain businessmen who wanted Dikko back on trial.

Denial is not, however, a refutation. The fact that the abductors entered a guilty plea foreclosed inquiry on many fronts. and in a failed enterprise of this nature, Barak's denial and that of Israel is to be expected. But given the pervasive presence of the MOSSAD later in Nigeria, its role in the Dikko affair, and subsequently in Nigeria's intelligence outfits the issue merits more critical attention.

"Diplomatic Baggage" is not all about Dikko. In a way it is a miniaturised history of the Shagari era, its 286 pages running a wide gamut. Its sweep covers the background to what the author refers to as a madness' the kidnap attempt itself and the ensuing diplomatic face-off; the expensive extradition process and why it failed; and the debauchery of the time tagged the Fourgerolle affair. It ends on a poignant note in the reversal of fortunes that saw to Dikko's home coming. Hear Dikko in 1991 as an exile: "I appreciate more the value and quality of law. The law saved me here, so I have a greater respect for law. These years of exile have assisted me to see the beauty of democracy, to see the value of liberty to understand more the value of freedom. Here, they render their business based on the rule of law. That is what is called a refined society. that is what I want my society to become." Dikko on his way home in 1994: "Tell him (Buhari) some people are already calling my arrival in Nigeria the latest political coup."

That is the kind of repartee that makes the reader look balefully into nothingness, stamp his feet repeatedly on the ground, and mutter to himself, "There goes Dikko again." In a way, Dikko symbolises Nigeria's political class who like the Bourbons have learnt nothing and forgotten nothing.

All in all, "Diplomatic Baggage" is a bold attempt at reconstructing the events of the time, and putting them in perspective for the records.

Newswatch Communications Limited, No.3 Billings Way (off Secretariat Road), Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 214299, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria. Telephone: 4960590 Fax:962887


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


76 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


USA/AFRICA: No Man-Eating Lions!


LENGTH: 560 words


 

March 1995

The Museum for African Art

Animals in African Art, a major exhibition of approximately 100 works which runs March 31 through August 31, 1995 at the Museum for African Art in SoHo, holds surprises for people of all ages. Visitors will discover that the animals they usually associate with Africa-such as zebras, giraffes, and lions- are almost never depicted in traditional African art. Instead, artists render animals which are unusual because of how they look or act. Frequently, the more remarkable the animal, the more commonly it is depicted. These animals, which are associated with healing, hunting, and spirit possession, include antelopes, bats, buffaloes, spiders, and chameleons, among others. 

"Animals in African Art" proceeds from the familiar to the marvelous. The exhibit begins with images of village animals, such as dogs, chickens, and oxen. It continues with images of wild animals of the land, air, and water. Next, many animals which cross categories-such as fish that climb trees (pangolins) and snakes that swim (pythons)- are presented. Following this, the exhibition devotes itself to art that represents felines, then magical creatures that combine human and animal traits, and finally humans and animals interacting.

The exhibit also challenges conventions in exhibition design. conceived to be enjoyed simultaneously by people of all ages, "Animals" will contain an exhibition-within-an-exhibition just for children. Many objects will be displayed at a height and in a manner engaging to children, and accompanying wall texts and labels will be user-friendly for young visitors.

This exhibition is a key part of a city-wide collaborative organized by the New School for Social Research to explore the relationship between humans and animals. Animal-related exhibitions and public programs will also be held at the Jewish Museum and The Asia Society. A national conference, "In the Company of Animals," will be hosted by the New School from April 6 to 8.

Curators for "Animals in African Art" are Allen F. Roberts (Guest Curator), Associate Professor of Anthropology and African-American World Studies and Co-Director of the Project for Advanced Study of Art and Life in Africa (PASALA) at the University of Iowa, and Carol Thompson, Associate Curator, Museum for African Art.

Where: The Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, between Houston and Prince

Admission: General $4 and $2 for children, students and seniors

Hours: Tuesday-Friday, 10:30-5:30 p.m., Saturday & Sunday, 12-6 p.m., closed Monday

The Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, New York, NY 10012. Tel: (212) 966-1313.


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


77 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


U.S./AFRICA: Museum For African Art Names Grace C. Stanislaus New Executive Director


SECTION: ARTS, MUSIC, CULTURE


LENGTH: 1214 words


 

New York-- Grace C. Stanislaus, formerly director of the Bronx Museum of the Arts, has been named executive director of the Museum for African Art, the Trustees of the Museum announced recently. She assumes her position on February 13, 1995, replacing Susan Vogel, the Museum's founder and former director.

Ms. Stanislaus, who is 36 years old, has a national reputation as a dynamic museum professional with a fresh approach to the issues that confront museums and proven experience as an institution builder. As director of The Bronx Museum for the Arts, from 1992 to 1994, she provided the managerial and intellectual leadership that brought in new audiences, doubled the size of the permanent collection, and increased the budget, while she initiated a collections management program and revitalized the museum's curatorial and educational programming. 

Shortly after she receive her Master's in Art History form Columbia University, she joined The Studio Museum in Harlem as a curator, and from 1983 to 1992, developed groundbreaking exhibitions, oversaw the development of the permanent collection, supervised the Artists-in-Residence Program and published a number of well-received articles. While there, she organized a traveling exhibition of contemporary African art, "Contemporary African Artists: Changing Tradition," and curated the first exhibition of contemporary African art at the 1990 Venice Biennale. Ms. Stanislaus has also authored many fine catalogue essays about contemporary African-American, African and immigrant artists. She is a much sought-after speaker nationally and internationally, lecturing on African-American art, multiculturalism, African art, museums and public education in a pluralistic society, and she has traveled extensively in West, Central, Southern and East Africa.

Ms. Stanislaus' other professional activities include serving as a panelist for the NEA and New York State Council on the Arts (NYSCA), and a reviewer for the College Art Association and the Institute of Museum Services (IMS). She is also a member of the Association of Art Museum Directors, and Secretary of the Board of ArtTable, an organization of women in leadership positions in the visual arts. She participated in the Museum Management Institute Training Program, which is sponsored by the J. Paul Getty Trust.

"While we interviewed many fine candidates over the last three months, Ms. Stanislaus was our hands-down, first choice," said Board Trustee Jason Wright, Senior VP at RJR Nabisco and head of the Search Committee at the Museum for African Art. "We can think of no better person to lead this museum into the next century. Grace is a talented institution builder - a creative, responsive leader who knows how to raise money, attract new audiences and nurture the next generation of African art enthusiasts and collectors. She will make a critical contribution to the Museum's future."

"After a decade of first-rate exhibitions and scholarly publications, the Museum for African Art is today one of the most important centers for the presentation of African art worldwide," said Ms. Stanislaus. "The Museum's exhibitions have enhanced our appreciation of African art and deepened our understanding about issues of context and the methodologies of display. As Executive Director, I look forward to the challenge of building on these past successes and strengthening our institutional foundation for future growth. With a dedicated Board and staff, and with the support of the Museum's many friends, the next decade and the new millennium promise renewed excitement as we work together to expand the institution's resources and public outreach."

The Museum also announced that Frank Herreman joins the staff as Director of Exhibitions reporting to Ms. Stanislaus. Mr. Herreman, an Africanist of international reputation is currently associate director of the Historical Museums of the City of Antwerp, and head of the Antwerp Museum of Ethnography in Belgium. His reputation as a scholar, his knowledge of African artworks, and his aesthetic judgment are considered outstanding by those in the field. Most recently he curated "Face of the Spirits" an exhibition of Zairean masks that was featured at the National Museum of African Art, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C.

Dr. Herreman, who formally joins the Museum on July 1, 1995, will work closely with the Executive Director to plan future exhibitions and related educational programs, and oversee museum installations and publications. He will select and collaborate with guest curators, supervise the curatorial staff and play a critical role in shaping the intellectual and artistic component of all exhibitions.

"We're delighted to have someone of Frank's stature willing to relocate from Belgium to join the Museum. His considerable expertise in the field of African art will be a valued asset as we move forward," said Mr. Wright.

The Museum for African Art is the only independent museum in the country devoted exclusively to presenting historical African art. Over the past ten years, the Museum has developed an international reputation for offering insights into Sub-Saharan art and culture through its exhibitions, educational and travel programs. It is well-known among public and private collectors, as well as the general public, for providing an educative context for appreciating African art. Since its inception in 1984, the Museum has circulated its exhibitions, curated with exceptional depth and expertise, to 46 national and international museums, giving broad access to African artworks.

The Museum moved into its current space in New York's SoHo district in February 1993. The Museum's interior, designed by award-winning architect Maya Lin, creator of the Viet Nam Veteran's Memorial in Washington, encompasses some 17,000 square feet-- tripling the size of its original home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

Ms. Stanislaus and Mr. Herreman will have a chance to meet the entire Board and Museum members, supporters and friends when "Animals in African Art" (March 31- December 31, 1995) opens in March.

The Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, New York, NY 10012. Tel: (212) 966-1313.


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


78 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Financial Rand's End Rumoured : Is Chris Stals About To Scrap The Financial Rand?


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)

February 24, 1995

By Jacques Magliolo

A statement by Reserve Bank governor Chris Stals (in January) fuelled rumours that the financial rand would be scrapped within weeks. However, according to a number of economists and analysts, the speculation seems optimistic.

The finrand was introduced by the Reserve Bank to discourage foreigners from removing funds from South Africa. In effect, a company wanting to operate here would obtain finrands at a better rate than commerical rands for their currency. But if they wanted to disinvest the exchange rate used would be at the less favourable commercial rand rate. 

Stals was reported as saying the Reserve Bank had secured foreign credit of close to R12-billion to support the exchange rate once the dual currency system was abolished. He added that the underlying conditions for the scrapping of the finrand were improving all the time.

The pre-conditions are: the discount rate, which is the percentage difference between the commercial and financial rands, has to remain at 10 percent for a reasonable period of time.

"Massive buying by foreign banks of finrands in anticipation of the scrapping of the unit (before Stal's speech) is driving down the discount rate," says Southern Life economist Sandra Gordon. The discount rate fell to 10 percent last week and had maintained this level by Wednesday.

Says another economist: "The low discount rate has, in turn, fueled these rumours. However, the rate is merely one of three pre-conditions which has to be fulfilled before Stals can recommend to the cabinet that the units be unified."

Gordon adds: "Stals has said that the discount rate has to remain at a rate of at most 10 percent for a reasonable period of time.What that time is, is anyone's guess."

Non-resident holders of South African assets should not dispose of these assets after the two currencies have been combined. In other words, the pool of finrands must decrease over time. But no time frame has been provided by the Bank.

This would be best achieved by a continuing increase in foreign investor confidence in the country. This should, in turn, be reflected in a sustained reduction in the finrand discount.

However, political turbulence such as the Inkatha Freedom Party's walkout from parliament is likely to decrease foreign investor confidence.

The actual pool of finrand deposits (on an annual basis) increased at

the end of 1994 to R6,4-billion from 1993's R4,4-billion. Speculation of the scrapping was further supported by Stals revealing this week that finrand balances had fallen to about R5,5-billion.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

LANGUAGE: English

79 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


NIGERIA: How Will They Work?


SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCE


LENGTH: 2360 words


 

Newswatch (Lagos)

February 20, 1995

by Joseph Ode

The uncertainty which had pervaded the financial sector over the operation of the new foreign exchange system introduced as part of the 1995 federal budget was cleared last week. The Central Bank of Nigeria, CBN, said in a press statement signed by Tony Ede, manager, corporate affairs, that commercial and merchant banks were free to sell and buy foreign exchange from any source at any rate. Further directives on the market's operation, the CBN said, would be issued when necessary.

According to the bank, there was no basis for the uncertainty and low level of foreign exchange in the first place since the guidelines it issued on January 17 had spelt out the mode of operation of the market. 

The main features of the new system according to the guidelines, are the return of the autonomous inter bank foreign exchange market, IFEM, where individuals and organisations are free to buy and sell foreign exchange at market-determined rates, and the cancellation of regular bidding and allocation of foreign exchange to dealer-banks by the Central Bank of Nigeria, CBN. In the new dispensation, all foreign exchange earned by government parastatals, government companies, agencies and companies in which government has majority share holding; oil exploration, producing and service companies as well as loans and grants are to be channeled to the domiciliary accounts with the CBN at prevailing autonomous rates. Such funds are to be used by the CBN to intervene in and influence the autonomous market in order to ensure reasonable stability in the market. However, priority government foreign exchange obligations will continue to be funded by the CBN at the official exchange rate of N22 to US$1.

But Newswatch learnt that no bank really complied with the ban on the autonomous market last year, except that transactions in that respect were carried out below the counter at rates close to the black market's. The official return of the autonomous market this year has merely intensified such transactions. A treasury manager with a merchant bank in Lagos explained to Newswatch that his bank, like many others, was reluctant to come out openly to engage in autonomous forex transactions for fear that it might incur the wrath of the CBN if its documentation now is at variance with CBN requirements when the guidelines are eventually released.

Other banks, however, commenced official transactions ahead of last week's clarification by the CBN. Among them are Citizens International Bank, Wema Bank, Nigeria Merchant Bank and Eco Bank. Yemi Cardoso, executive director and head of treasury And financial institutions group of Citizens Bank said his bank commenced autonomous forex transactions immediately after the budget without hesitation because the CBN had come out clearly to say that the market was free subject to certain guidelines and some existing foreign exchange decrees. Moreover, he said, the philosophy of the CBN on the new foreign exchange system is very clear, and similar to what operates in other countries.

Since the commencement of the new system, autonomous exchange rate, on the average, has been close to the black market rate. From about N83 to the dollar about a fortnight ago, the rate has fallen to between N70 and N76 to the dollar. A treasury manager with one of the banks who requested anonymity attributed the trend to expectations that the Central Bank might intervene to narrow the margin between the autonomous and the official exchange rates.

Cardoso said the mopping up of N10 billion from the banking system in January through the issuance of stabilisation securities by the CBN must have also aided the appreciation of the naira. But how long the trend will last, according to Cardoso, will depend, to a large extent, on the consistency and volume of CBN intervention and the rate at which it is done. J.O. Ekundayo, president of the Chartered Institute of Bankers of Nigeria, CIBN, however, foresees a situation where the naira would depreciate as a result of a possible lag in implementation of the new forex system. But he advised government not to allow itself to be stampeded into taking a reverse measure. "The naira will afterwards recover with strict adherence to the new policy," he predicts.

Generally, reactions to the foreign exchange and other policies enunciated in the 1995 budget have been mixed. Although most of the policies are said by analysts to be in the right direction, many are skeptical about their realisation based on government's poor track record on budget implementation and certain signals so far in the new year.

For instance, the re-introduction of the autonomous market is widely hailed as a measure capable of reopening the channels of foreign exchange inflow, especially from non-oil sources. This agrees largely with the call by the Manufactures Association of Nigeria, MAN, for a move away from a fixed exchange rate regime to a market-oriented managed floating system spiced with CBN intervention to ensure firmness and stability of the rate. But MAN, in its reaction to the budget has stressed the need for an effective and efficient implementation of the system. "Otherwise," the association warned, "there is the danger of a cycle of unremitting depreciation of the exchange rate and instability if the policy is mismanaged and forex is available only to the highest bidder. Under such a grim scenario, the main casualty is the manufacturing sector which has the scales loaded against it in any competition for forex and bank credit with finished goods importers."

The manufacturers want the government to compel the banks to ensure that 60 percent of the available foreign exchange goes to the manufacturing industry. They also want import duty payments to be made at the official rate to avoid abnormal cost burden on manufacturers which will make the prices of goods unaffordable. But, on the other hand, MAN would want all government transactions to be carried out at the autonomous rate. "In the national interest, there is no reason why such transactions should have priority over manufacturing and agriculture."

Generally financial experts are not too critical of the new interest policy for 1995. Unlike last year when both lending and deposit rates were fixed, only a maximum spread of 7.5 percent between the lending and deposit rates has been prescribed for this year, subject to a maximum lending rate of 21 percent. The only question being raised by commentators on the budget is whether government can bring inflation down to a level that would make the prescribed interest rates positive. "Given the conservative estimate of inflation currently at over 70 percent, real savings rate is highly negative," said Erastus Akingbola, managing director of Intercontinental Merchant Bank. According to Femi Adekanye, chairman and chief executive of Commerce Bank, "If the government loses the battle against inflation, there would be no economic justification to keep running a controlled interest rate policy."

There are conflicting signals however, over the ability of the government to win the war on inflation. Last year, prices moved on the back of the exchange rate in the parallel market despite the existence of a much lower statutory rate. As Akingbola put it, "virtually everything, including local vegetables and tomatoes, was priced on this basis." Some analysts believe that the return of the autonomous market will push the parallel market rate down, as is already happening, and with it the level of inflation. Akingbola believes that inflation can be brought down substantially within the broad framework of the budget. However, given the present level of liquidity in the system and the potential source of excess liquidity during the year - World Youth Soccer championships, political activities, etc., - he believes that the authorities would need to rely on more monetary policies to put inflation in check.

The manufacturers feel that some of the fiscal measures of government this year like the proposed lease/commercialisation of some of its enterprises, and the new tariff structure may deny government victory in its declared war on inflation. "Experience in the last nine years," says MAN. "shows that in all cases, commercialisation so far implemented has taken on the nature of arbitrary increases in tariffs and charges without corresponding improvement in services provided. The snowballing effect on the cost of operation of industries has inevitably affected the prices of consumer goods adversely." MAN also believe that high levels and range of excise duty as well as the widened base of VAT can exacerbate the inflationary level.

Indeed, Akinola Owosekun, director, research and policy analysis, department of the national planning commission, who carried out a study on various aspects of the economy has predicted that inflation would be the most serious economic problem in 1995. "This high rate of inflation will result from the fuller impact of the increases in the prices of petroleum products and from the further depreciation of the naira in the autonomous markets. The forecast is for a weighted overall rate of inflation of 233.62 percent. Every component of the consumer price index will be advesarely affected."

Like the monetary policies, government's fiscal policies for 1995 have generally been hailed. They include the broadening of the revenue base especially the value-added tax. VAT; reduction in personal income tax and increase in tax relief and tax incentives for manufactures and exporters. What bothers most analysts is whether government will keep faith with its proposals, when it comes to implementation. For instance, despite a provision for zero deficit in the 1994 budget, government deficit spending amounted to N81 billion. "Judging by this performance, which again is consistent with past performances," says Adekanye, we may have to prepare ourselves for budget deficits in excess of N150 billion in 1995 when a budget deficit of N12 billion is projected."

Another example of inconsistency in policy implementation which analysts are pointing to is the recourse to stabilisation securities last month to reduce excess liquidity in the banking system. The use of the instrument was suspended in 1993 with the introduction of the Open Market Operation, OMO as an alternative, indirect instrument of monetary control. "The emerging signal from this sudden change in policy is that fiscal 1995 could be another year of destabilising official intervention... If stabilisation debits would be the major instruments of monetary management in 1995, we should warm up for a major financial crisis," according to Adekanye.

M. O. Ojo, director of research at CBN, said last week that the apex bank itself was not very comfortable with the use of stabilisation securities. "However, it should be made known that many central banks, including those of developed countries apply the same instrument in various guises or at least reserve its use for emergency purposes." The emergency, in this case, was the need" to start off the fiscal year without further increasing inflationary expectations and particularly to support the new foreign exchange market mechanism." According to the CBN monetary guidelines, "stabilisation securities are to be retained as an instrument of monetary control in 1995. However, their use will be phased out in the course of the year if prevailing monetary conditions so permit." For Lateef Owoyemi, president of the Nigerian Association of Management Consultants, NAMCON, merely highlighting the merits and demerits of the budget, as has been the case since independence has not led the country anywhere. His advice is for Nigerians to focus post-budget attention on what each group should do to enhance effective implementation and a happier year for Nigerians. "Any budget needs a moral underpinning to succeed. It needs more than the CBN to make the outlined interest rate and foreign exchange regimes work successfully and the policies cannot achieve much unless businessmen and bankers resolve to play fairly in 1995."

Newswatch is published at P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Nigeria Tel: 4960950 Fax: 962887 Telex: 27874


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

80 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


CONTINENT: Weekly Press Summary From The Pan African News Agency (Dakar), March 24, 1995


LENGTH: 1814 words


 

DAKAR, SENEGAL (PANA) - THE DECISION OF THE INTERNATIONAL FOOTBALL FEDERATION (FIFA) TO CANCEL THE WORLD YOUTH SOCCER CHAMPIONSHIP IN NIGERIA WAS AMONG SOME OF THE TOPICAL ISSUES DISCUSSED IN AFRICAN NEWSPAPERS THIS WEEK.

SENEGALESE NATIONAL DAILY, "LE SOLEIL," EXPRESSED DISAPPOINTMENT WITH AFRICA SPORTS OFFICIALS WHO, IT SAID, WERE MUM ON THE AFFAIR.

THESE OFFICIALS SHOULD HAVE "DENOUNCED THE UNFAIR DECISION WHICH FIFA HAS JUST TAKEN BY WITHDRAWING FROM NIGERIA THE RIGHTS TO HOST THE WORLD YOUTH CHAMPIONSHIP," IT IS SAID IN A COMMENT ENTITLED "NO TO FIFA," PUBLISHED IN ITS SPORTS COLUMN.

THE SEMI-OFFICIAL DAILY SAID THE SECURITY AND HEALTH REASONS ADDUCED BY FIFA FOR THE CANCELLATION CANNOT STAND THE TEST OF REASON.

"AFRICA IS ONCE AGAIN BEING TRAMPLED UPON," THE PAPER SAID, SMACKS OF INJUSTICE AND INTRODUCTION OF POLITICS INTO SPORTS. FIFA, IT ADDED WAS TOYING WITH A NATIONS SOVEREIGNTY AND AFRICA'S DIGNITY. 

THE SOLEIL (SUN) URGED ALL AFRICAN SPORTING BODIES TO CONDEMN THE ACTIONS INDIVIDUALLY AND SEVERALLY SAYING, "IT ISTECHNICALLY DISPUTABLE, SPORTINGLY BLAMABLE AND POLITICALLY INDEFENSIBLE."

"WE WILL BE RIGHT OVER FIFA," WAS THE HEADER OF THE LAGOS-BASED "DAILY TIMES" EDITORIAL ON THE MATTER, WHICH SAID FIFA'S HIDDEN MOTIVE FOR TAKING THE DECISION WOULD BE UNVEILED WITH TIME.

"IT WAS CLEAR, RIGHT FROM THE START, THAT THE WORLD SOCCER GOVERNING BODY WAS PREPARED TO GO TO GREAT LENGTHS TO PREVENT NIGERIA FROM HOSTING THE COMPETITION," IT SAID.

"THE TRUTH IS THAT FIFA HAS NEVER WANTED NIGERIA TO ORGANIZE THE CHAMPIONSHIP, FOR ITS OWN REASONS." THE SECURITY NECESSARY FOR THE HOSTING OF AN EVENT OF THE MAGNITUDE OF THE WORLD YOUTH SOCCER CHAMPIONSHIP WAS NOT LACKING IN NIGERIA. YET, WE KNOW WHAT VIOLENT CRIME RATES ARE IN THE SO-CALLED DEVELOPED COUNTRIES," IT POINTED OUT.

THE NEWSPAPER TURNED TO THE FUTURE: "WE HAVE REACHED A JUNCTURE WHERE WE MUST PROVE TO THE WORLD THAT FIFA IS WRONG AND HAS BEEN UNFAIR TO US. AT THIS STAGE, WE MUST NOT DEVELOP A SYNDROME OF WITHDRAWING INTO OUR SHELLS," THE PAPER SAID.

IT URGED NIGERIANS TO PUT THE INCIDENT BEHIND THEM STRESSING THAT "THE FUTURE OF NIGERIAN FOOTBALL IS NOT AND CANNOT BE DEPENDENT ON FIFA'S WHIMS AND CAPRICES."

THE "DAILY SKETCH," ANOTHER PAPER BASED IN WESTERN NIGERIA ALSO COMMENTED ON THE PROBLEM SAYING THE FIFA ACTIONS "...IS AN INSULT NOT JUST TO THE AFRICAN CONTINENT BUT TO THE ENTIRE BLACK RACE."

THE NEWSPAPER SAID IT HOPES THIS ISSUE WILL BE BROUGHT UP AT THE MEETINGS OF WIDER INTERNATIONAL BODIES THAN FIFA: THE COMMONWEALTH, THE UNITED NATIONS, THE NON-ALIGNED MOVEMENT AND THE ORGANISATION OF AFRICAN UNITY (OAU).

IN THE MEANTIME, THE "DAILY SKETCH" URGED THE NIGERIAN YOUTH SOCCER TEAM "TO BRING SHAME ON FIFA. THEY SHOULD STORM QATAR AND STUN THE WORLD," IT WROTE. OTHER AFRICAN PAPERS FOCUSED ON INTERNAL PROBLEMS.

Pan African News Agency, PO Box 4056, Dakar, Senegal. Tel: 221 24 13 95. Fax: 221 24 13 90. E-mail: pana.pana.sn

DAKAR, SENEGAL - IN NIAMEY, TWO WEEKLIES DISCUSSED THE VIOLENT INTER-ETHNIC CLASHES IN THE GADIRA REGION (FAR-EASTERN REGION NEAR LAKE CHAD) AT A TIME WHEN A UN MISSION ON THE PROLIFERATION OF WEAPONS IN WEST AFRICA WAS VISITING IN NIGER. "IN A REGION WHERE IT IS EASIER TO FIND A KALACHNIKOV THAN A FEW TABLETS OF NIVAQUININE, THE DEATH TOLL CANNOT BE ACCURATELY ESTABLISHED,", "LE REPUBLICAIN" NOTED.

THE WEEKLY WAS REFERRING TO THE DIVERGING FIGURES ABOUTTHE NUMBER OF PERSONS WHO DIED IN THE MAYHEM. THIRTY, ACCORDING TO THE INTERIOR MINISTRY, 25, LOCAL AUTHORITIES SAID WHILE INDEPENDENT SOURCES SAID AT LEAST 100 PEOPLE WERE KILLED.

"LE DEMOCRATE" TRACED THE ORIGIN OF THE CONFLICT TO ATTACKS ON PEULS, A PASTORAL PEOPLE WHO OFTEN FALL VICTIMS TO ROBBERIES THEY BELIEVED ARE COMMITTED BY PEOPLE OF THE TOUBOU ETHNIC GROUP.

"TO AVENGE THEIR KINSMEN, THEY IN TURN ORGANIZE PUNITIVE EXPEDITIONS AGAINST THE COMMUNITIES OF THE PRESUMED AUTHORS," IT EMPHASISED.

THE PAPER SAID THE BEST SOLUTION TO THE PROBLEM IS TO CONFISCATE ILLEGAL WEAPONS IN CIRCULATION IN THE REGION.

ARMS TRAFFICKING IS ALSO THE FOCUS OF ATTENTION IN "LE JOUR" AND "LA VOIE," BOTH PUBLISHED IN ABIDJAN, CITING ACCUSATIONS MADE BY LIBERIA'S PRESIDENT OF THE STATE COUNCIL, DAVID KPORMAKPOR, WHO DECLARED IN GHANA THAT COTE D'IVOIRE WAS SUPPORTING CHARLES TAYLOR BY SUPPLYING WEAPONS TO THE NATIONAL PATRIOTIC FRONT OF LIBERIA (NPFL).

"CHARLES TAYLOR'S SOLDIERS ARE FULLY AT EASE IN COTE D'IVOIRE WHERE THEY DO AS THEY THINK FIT. OF COURSE WITH THE COMPLICITY OF THE IVORIAN ARMY," "LE JOUR" QUOTED KPORMAKPOR AS SAYING.

"LA VOIE," CLOSE TO THE OPPOSITION, NOTED HOWEVER THAT SUCCESSIVE LIBERIAN RULERS HAD OFTEN BLAMED THEIR PROBLEMS ON COTE D'IVOIRE.

"AFTER SAMUEL DOE, AMOS SAWYER AND ULIMO, IT IS NOW KPORMAKPOR'S TURN TO ACCUSE COTE D'IVOIRE, AND OUR COUNTRY HAS SO FAR NOT BEEN ABLE TO DISSIPATE THESE SUSPICIONS BY ADOPTING TOWARDS CHARLES TAYLOR AN ATTITUDE WHICH DOES NOT BLEMISH THE COUNTRY'S IMAGE."

"IF THE ACCUSATIONS MADE BY THE LIBERIANS ARE WELL-FOUNDED, THEN THE LIBERIAN CONFLICT IS GOING TO ENDLESSLY CONTINUE IN THIS VICIOUS CIRCLE WHEREBY THE FIRE BRIGADE IS TURNING FOR HELP TO THE ARSONIST WHO IS FANNING THE FIRE," THE NEWSPAPER WENT ON.

THE CONSEQUENCE OF ALL THIS FOR COTE D'IVOIRE, IT ADDED, "IS THE RISE OF CRIME RATE THANKS TO THE WEAPONS WE ARE SUPPLYING TO LIBERIAN REBELS, AND WHICH ARE IN TURN SOLD ON THE IVORIAN BLACK MARKET BY THESE VERY SAME LIBERIANS TO GET THE MONEY TO BUY FOOD."

PANA, PO Box 4056, Dakar, Senegal. Tel: 221 24 13 95. Fax: 221 24 13 90. E-mail: pana.pana.sn

DAKAR, SENEGAL - TALKING ABOUT CRIME IN COTE D'IVOIRE, THE PEOPLE SEEM TO SUPPORT THE GOVERNMENT WHICH RECENTLY APPROVED A BILL PROVIDING FOR CAPITAL PUNISHMENT AND PUBLIC EXECUTIVE OF CULPRITS OF ARMED ROBBERY.

"IT WAS HIGH TIME...THIS IS A SALUTORY MEASURE WHICH LIVES UP TO THE EXPECTATIONS OF THE OVERWHELMING MAJORITY OF IVORIANS," A LAWYER WROTE, IN AN ARTICLE PUBLISHED IN "FRATERNITE MATIN."

ANOTHER LAWYER POINTED OUT THAT NEIGHBOURING GHANA, ADOPTED A SIMILAR MEASURE WHICH HAS VASTLY REDUCED THE SPATE OF ARMED ROBBERY IN THE WEST AFRICAN STATE. "THOSE WHO KILL MUST BE KILLED," HE ADDED.

THE INDEPENDENT DAILY, "LE JOUR," SUPPORTED RELIGIOUS LEADERS WHO MAINLY FAVOUR OTHER SOLUTIONS, CITING A CLERGYMAN AT THE BAPTIST CHURCH WHO ADVISED: "DO NOT OPPOSE THE DECISION LEADING TO THE IMPOSITION OF THE DEATH PENALTY, SIMPLY CHANGE

YOUR BEHAVIOUR, AND BECOME AN HONEST MAN AND THE PROBLEM IS RESOLVED."

ANOTHER ABIDJAN-BASED CLERIC SUGGESTED THAT A LASTING SOLUTIONS WOULD BE FOUND IN THE CREATION OF JOBS. TO RESPOND TO VIOLENCE BY VIOLENCE WILL NOT PROBLEM, HE SAID.

IN A DECLARATION HE MADE TO A NEWSPAPER, AN IMAN IN ABIDJAN AND INFLUENTIAL MEMBER OF THE ISLAMIC NATIONAL COUNCIL (CNI), WARNS AGAINST THE RISK OF EXCESSES. "BANDITRY SHOULD NOT BE USED AS A PRETEXT TO RESOLVE OTHER PROBLEMS," HE WARNED.

PANA, PO Box 4056, Dakar, Senegal. Tel: 221 24 13 95. Fax: 221 24 13 90. E-mail: pana.pana.sn

DAKAR, SENEGAL - ELSEWHERE, BURKINA FASO'S "LE PAYS" NEWSPAPER WROTE ON HOW TO AVOID A BLOOD BATH IN BURUNDI.

TODAY "MORE THAN EVER," THE GHOST OF A THIRD CIVIL WAR IS THREATENING THE AFRICAN COUNTRY, ITS SAID.

ACCORDING TO "LE PAYS," EFFORTS BY THE INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY TO STOP THE MADNESS ARE "COMMENDABLE BUT INSUFFICIENT." IT ADDED THAT PEACE IN BURUNDI DEPENDS FIRST ON

BURUNDIAN THEMSELVES. IT IS DOUBTFUL THAT "BLUE HELMETS" COULD BRING HUTU AND TUTSI TO CONSIDER THEMSELVES AS ONE PEOPLE," THE PAPER SAID.

UNDER THE LEAD "A SECOND RWANDA IN ZAIREAN BORDER," "FORUM DES AS," A KINSHASA INDEPENDENT WEEKLY ALSO ALLUDES TO THE INCREASE OF VIOLENCE IN BURUNDI. "WHAT HAPPENED TO THE BURUNDIANS? DID THEY NOT LEARN A LESSON FROM THE RWANDESE TRAGEDY? APPARENTLY NOT," WROTE THE LEAD WRITER.

THE SITUATION IN BURUNDI "CANNOT BE UNDERSTOOD IF ONE CONSIDERS THE RELATIVE QUIETNESS WHICH PREVAILED IN THE COUNTRY AFTER PRESIDENT NTARYAMIRA'S DEATH, WHILE THE GENOCIDE BEGAN IN RWANDA" SAID THE ZAIREAN WEEKLY.

IN TRIPOLI, "AL-ZAHF AL AKHDAR" DENOUNCED WHAT IT DESCRIBED AS "A WESTERN PLOT AGAINST ALGERIA." IT SAID THE DECISION BY PARIS AND WASHINGTON TO EVACUATE THEIR CITIZENS FROM ALGERIA WAS PART OF A PLOT DESIGNED TO DESTABILIZE THE COUNTRY.

PANA, PO Box 4056, Dakar, Senegal. Tel: 221 24 13 95. Fax: 221 24 13 90. E-mail: pana.pana.sn

Africa News


March, 1995


NRA to Withdraw From Liberian Mess


LENGTH: 387 words


 

The Monitor (Kampala)

March 15-17, 1995

by Robert Mugagga

Uganda is to withdraw National Resistance Army (NRA) battalion from the ECOMOG peace-keeping force now in Monrovia, according to a top ECOMOG commander.

During an interview on Radio Channel Africa, the external service of the South African Broadcasting Corporation Tuesday, Major General Olapade said that financial considerations and frustrations with the slow pace of the peace process in Liberia were the main reasons behind Uganda's decision. 

The Major General also said Tanzania, the only other East African country contributing peace keeping forces in the war-ravaged West African nation of Liberia has also decided to pull out its battalion of 800 soldiers citing financial constraints back home.

According to the commander, authorities in Dar-es-Salaam say Monrovia was hurting the Tanzanian economy.

He also attributed Tanzania's withdrawal to the complexity of the Liberian case. "The Tanzanians say their forces were told that they had a duty that would last for only six months but now are fed up with a conflict that seems very far from ending, "the Major General said.

"The Monitor's" efforts to contact the NRA Public Relations Officer Major Ronald Katunguka yesterday were futile.

In 1993 several African countries contributed troops to help observe peace and order in Liberia.

Up to now, a disagreement among the war-lords over who should sit on the governing council has delayed the proposed peace process.

The Monitor is published at P.O. Box 12141 Kampala, Uganda. Tel: 251353. Fax: 251352


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


82 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


UGANDA: Hutu, Tutsi Working Well For Uganda Government


LENGTH: 707 words


 

The Monitor (Kampala)

February 8, 1995

by Ahmed Musoga

In an unusual revelation, President Yoweri Museveni during a speech marking the 14th anniversary of the National Resistance Army (NRA) at Kakyeka Stadium in Mbara, February 6, named two senior Uganda government officials as Banyarwanda.

The President was contrasting the failure of neighboring countries like Rwanda and Sudan to solve their problems, with the NRM's accommodative approach. "We have Ruzidana (IGG and CAD Ruhaama) a Tutsi and Justice Ntabgoba a Hutu and they both support us. So how can they fail to work together in Rwanda to work together in Rwanda while they speak the same language?", Museveni wondered. 

The President warned Constituent Assembly delegates against "playing about with the constitution".

"We fought to enfranchise Uganda, so for and one to play monkey tricks with the Constitution he must be hanged," said Museveni.

He said that although he had for the time being spared some people destined for the gallows, those who play about with the new Constitution "will be finished".

"If NRA has accepted to do away with its name which many people don't know how it was reached upon and be called Uganda Armed Forces (UAF) then who are those who cannot abide by what the constitution decides?" he asked amidst clapping from the soldiers.

He warned the delegates against playing cheap politics in the process implanting sensitive provision in the constitution which might turn out to be time bombs and explode.

The President criticised those delegates agitating for districts to retain all the revenue from industries within their localities, calling such an idea ridiculous.

That aside, the celebrations had other interesting episodes.

First, retired Bishop, Amos Betungura who arrived while the President was inspecting the guard of honour was nearly thrown out. He was only saved by the NRA Chief of Protocol, Major Bwende. This did not go down well with the junior officers who said that not even Jesus is allowed in after the President.

Then came the NPC, Eriya Kategaya who arrived 30 minutes after his boss, but nobody complained as he wriggled himself through the soldiers before being asked to proceed straight to his VIP seat.

Minister of State for Security, Col. Kahinda Otafire arrived an hour and a half later and headed straight to his seat without a hitch.

Strangely, the people of Mbarara who braved a morning drizzle were locked out of the stadium. It was only after the Commander in Chief had inspected the guard of honour that he intervened and the masses were let in.

The master of ceremonies, Lt. Col. Sserwanga Lwanga had something exciting in stock for the people. Among several name mix-ups, he introduced the Inspector General of Police (Cossy Odomel) as Cosmas Adyebo. He at one time referred to Major Bwende as Major General.

Almost all army top brass with the notable exception of Maj. Gen. David Tinyefuza, attended the function.

The Monitor is published at P.O. Box 12141 Kampala, Uganda. Tel: 251353. Fax: 251352


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


83 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


SUDAN: CSI Mission Witnesses Grim Conditions in the South and the Nuba Mountains


LENGTH: 2574 words


 

Sudan Democratic Gazette (London)

March 1995

A four person delegation from Christian Solidarity International (CSI) made the organisation's fifth visit to Sudan between 19 and 25 January. CSI is a non-denominational Christian human rights and humanitarian organisation organisation which champions the cause of persecuted people around the world. CSI has been involved in monitoring the persecution of Moslems and non-Moslems in Sudan for several years now. The conditions the delegation witnessed were as bad as any that had been seen on CSI's earlier visits to Sudan.

The delegation had hoped to visit the Nuba Mountains but logistics prevented this. However, a delegation from that area traveled by foot to Pariang, in northwestern Upper Nile, in order to tell stories of atrocities committed against them by the Islamic Fundamentalist regime to the CSI delegation. 

As with the previous three visits by CSI, the delegation comprised of Baroness Caroline Cox of the British House of Lords, John Eibner of CSI and the Bishop of El Obeid, Macram Max Gassis. The bishop is an outspoken critic of the regime who was forced into exile and who has taken every opportunity offered to get close to his diocese and hear the complaints of his flock. His diocese covers the whole of Western Sudan and includes the Nuba Mountains area as well as that of the Ngok Dinka of Abyei. A large number of his diocesans have been displaced by the regime's activities and have fled into areas held by the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA), such as Pariang in Upper Nile and Mayen Akun in Bahr El Ghazal. Bishop Gassis has tried to regularly visit these otherwise uncared for people.

The CSI delegation was accompanied by a media team from the Associated Press and Television, and also by a member of the German Evangelical Church of Westphalia, Ernst Albert von Renesse.

"On Regime's Invitation"

When the CSI first visited Sudan five years ago, they did so at the invitation of the Khartoum regime, which tried to manage their visit and only take the delegation to sanitised areas under Khartoum's control. Even so, the CSI delegation produced a highly critical report based on what they saw and heard, and as a result Khartoum has never invited the organisation back. The CSI is now limited to visiting only those areas controlled by the SPLA in Southern Sudan and the Nuba Mountains; "- assessing aspects of the need for humanitarian aid and delivering a consignment of medical supplies, especially in areas officially denied access by the regime, where problems could be expected to be particularly acute; and "- showing concern for, and solidarity with victims of repression."

Apart from Pariang in Upper Nile, which was known to be facing problems with people displaced from the Nuba Mountains, the CSI mission visited: Marial in Bahr El Ghazal, which as known to be facing many problems such as acute shortages of food and water, many people dying of starvation and treatable diseases, and a lack of medicines, clothing and blankets; and Kapoeta in Eastern Equatoria, to investigate reports of heavy fighting in the area and to assess the implications."

Conditions in all the areas visited were harsh and difficult, but perhaps two areas stand out from all the rest. These were Pariang and Kapoeta The CSI mission wrote of Pariang in their report: "The situation of the people in SPLA- controlled parts of the Nuba Mountains is desperate. Enormous suffering is caused by the lack of medicine and medical professionals, and the dearth of adequate water supplies. The intensity of military action in the Nuba Mountains was generally low during the rainy season, which ended last autumn. However, Government of Sudan (GOS) offensives from its garrison at Burnam resulted in the burning of at least eleven villages: Kordofan, Masakin, Gisar, Zuwal, El Ganaya, Angolo, Demadrajo, Kodel, Kacham and Umsrdeba. In the previous dry season the villages of Tore, including its large Christian church, and Sarf Gamius were razed. Ghound Abrahim, Ibrahim Tilmz and Osman El Murad were murdered by GOS forces in the latter."

In Kapoeta the CSI mission visited Kapoeta Catholic Church in the company of SPLA Commander Thomas Cirillo and Bishop Paride Taban and wrote about it in their report: "Cdr. Cirillo is directing the siege of Kapoeta. He served as an officer in the GOS artillery corps in Juba until June 1993 when he and his troops mutinied and joined the SPLA who were then besieging Juba The siege of Kapoeta began last October. Approximately 2,000 government troops, including a recently arrived relief convoy from Bor, are now trapped in the town's underground bunkers, according to the Commander. Virtually all of the local civilian population is believed to have left Kapoeta before the SPLA sealed off the town. As we spoke with Cdr. Cirillo, a GOS Antonov repeatedly circled overhead forcing us to take cover in bunkers, and the sound of gunfire and exploding artillery shells filled the air. Eight civilians died and three were wounded as a result of a GOS Antonov bombing raid in the vicinity of Kapoeta on January 23. During our visit to Sudan, scores of wounded civilians and SPLA soldiers have been reportedly arriving in northern Kenya from the scene of the battle. Cdr. Cirillo said that the GOS forces kill all SPLA soldiers who fall into their hands, while the SPLA takes prisoners and treats them according to the Geneva Convention. He said that he now had about 200 POWs from the battle of Kapoeta. Bishop Paride confirmed that he has been allowed to visit them and that they have been treated humanely.

"Cdr. Cirillo is a former altar boy and remains a practising Catholic. He views the GOS's war against the South as a war to Islamise Sudan. He said: Before battle the Mujahadeen and other Islamic fundamentalist zealots customarily shout and chant: 'We will force you to become Muslim whether you want to or not.'

"'The Muslim fundamentalists cannot defeat us. We are firm as Christians, and we will die for our faith. Our struggle is not against Islam or against Muslims, but is against a fundamentalist regime that wants to destroy our African heritage and faith. It is discouraging to see the Islamic fundamentalist government in Khartoum receive material and moral support from other Islamic countries, while we receive no support from the Christian world. But we will continue our struggle for freedom even if we are forsaken by Christendom... We will die for our faith and we will die Christians.'"

The report makes several findings and recommendations.

Findings

"(1) The GOS continues to try to transform by force the ethnically and religiously diverse country into an Arab, Islamic state, against the wishes of the vast majority of its black African population. The devastating effects of this policy are tantamount to attempted genocide.

"(2) The mass displacement of the population of the South and of the Nuba Mountains by means of terror, war and the manipulations of aid, is the main outcome of this policy.

"(3) Civil war has created a catastrophe of enormous proportions in Southern Sudan and the Nuba Mountains; an estimated 1.5 million have now died of starvation and disease and over 5 million have been displaced since the outbreak of the latest phase of the war in 1983.

"(4) The war has devastated the infrastructure of these regions, destroying the economic, health, education and communication systems and seriously affecting food production. The civil authorities continue to make valiant efforts to maintain essential services, but repeated mass displacement of millions of people, lack of resources, and problems of access for aid organisations, pose insuperable problems.

"(5) Offensives by GOS forces during last year's dry season inflicted great suffering on hundreds of thousands of people in and around Nimule, Kajokeji, Thiet, the Southern Blue Nile and the Nuba Mountains. The GOS-supplied militias of Commanders Kerubino and William Nyuon have also inflicted great suffering on the peoples of Bahr El Ghazal and Eastern Equatoria, respectively.

"(6) Unless this conflict is resolved as a matter of great urgency, the cost to both the people of Sudan and to the international community will be incalculable. For example, there will be even greater demands on the international agencies; growing numbers of refugees will pose even greater problems for neighboring countries; and disease will spread beyond the borders of Sudan, including new health problems with resistant pathogens.

"(7) The imbalance of military power in favour of the GOS perpetuates the war and decreases the prospect of a successful outcome of the IGADD peace intiative.

"(8) Indiscriminate bombing of civilian targets (for example, the areas of Kapoeta an Nimule, January 1995) continues to increase the number of civilians who are killed, wounded and displaced. There are recent reports of large numbers of people leaving camps around Nimule (Labone and Mughale) and migrating eastwards. Many of these people had previously been displaced from their homes in the region of Bor and were resettled in the 'Triple A' camps near Nimule; they had to move again last year when these camps were over-run by GOS forces. They are therefore now suffering their third forced migration in two years. The SPLA has no adequate defence against the aerial bombardment.

"(9) Humanitarian aid fails to reach hundreds of thousands of victims of war and famine. The GOS continues to refuse to give access to the UN and the NGOs to SPLA-administered areas in the Nuba Mountains and to other areas such as Pariang, Nimule, Chukudum, Ikatos, Mundri, and the Southern Blue Nile Region. Denial of access means that thousands of people are dying from lack of food and medicines.

"(10) Many people in Sudan still suffer from gross violations of human rights. For example, there are reports of recent destruction of villages and of crops, together with the perpetration of murder and other atrocities by GOS forces in the Nuba Mountains, and many black Africans, especially women and children, are still subject to enslavement by Arabs from the North.

Recommendations: "The time is overdue for the international community to take a firm stand against the GOS's policy of attempted genocide, with the destruction of liege, culture, language, community, religion, ethnic identity and political opposition. This policy continues to create misery of unimaginable proportions and to give rise to dangerous political instability in Sudan and throughout the wider international arena. It also creating a bottomless pit of need for humanitarian aid.

"CSI therefore again calls in the international community, can in particular the member states of the United Nations Security Council, to prevail upon the GOS to cease hostilities against the people of the South and of the Nuba Mountains; and the honour its voluntarily accepted human rights obligations to all citizens, by:

"(1) Imposing an arms and oil embargo upon the GOS until it desists from trying to impose a military solution on the people of the South and the Nuba Mountains;

"(2) Establishing air exclusion zones for the protection of the civilian population from aerial bombardment;

"(3) Continuing to support the IGADD peace initiative, and ensuring that tangible outcomes are imminently forthcoming to prevent the GOS from using these peace talks as a means of buying time to perpetuate its war attrition;

"(4) Engaging in discussions with the banned democratic Opposition groups, in both the North and the South which represent over 90% of the Sudanese people;

"(5) Enabling the people of the South and the Nuba Mountains to have the opportunity to determine their own future;

"(6) Ensuring access by the UN's Operation Life-line Sudan (OLS) and other humanitarian aid organisations to all areas, including the Nuba Mountains. Permission to reach all areas should be permanent, as the current 'stop-go' policy adopted by the GOS results in many thousands of displaced people moving to an area which they hear is receiving supplies of food and/or medicines. If access is then denied, they become stranded, often dying of starvation of treatable disease;

"(7) Providing teams of human rights monitors in the North, the Nuba Mountains and the South, under the direction of the UN Special Rapporteur for Human Rights in Sudan;

"(8) Enabling the civil authorities in the South and the Nuba Mountains to develop local initiatives, such as co-operative farms, craft industries, and education/training schemes for both civilians and soldiers. This would provide the basis for substance and an infrastructure for independence, rehabilitation and reconstruction."

Sudan Democratic Gazette is published at PO Box 2295, London w14 ond, U.K.

Africa News


March, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Changing Voices of Radio South Africa


LENGTH: 1307 words


 

New Nation (Johannesburg)

February 17, 1995

by Joyce Ozynski

Once upon a time there were two radio stations -- Springbok Radio, and the English Station.

Springbok Radio was riddled with advertisements and catered to the narrow, shallow tastes of white South Africa.

It was Springbok Radio that, as a kid, I listened to Superman at 5 o'clock in the afternoons -- "Up, up and away!" and in the evenings, the spooky "Creaking Door" and "Consider Your Verdict", a courtroom drama series in which the listener was told, "You be the judge!". During the long pause filed with commercials, the listener had to decide who was the guilty party. Only then did the judge announce his verdict. 

The English Stations was the only on which you could hear, without any interruptions from advertisements, classical music, poetry, and other coloniclism, only an ossified remnant of colonialism commercial radio and theAfrikaans station.

Not so many years ago, the SABC effected a fusion of Springbok radio with the English station. Springbok radio with in fifties went off the air and the English station wagon (renamed Radio South Africa) was now obliged to carry advertisements.

It looks as it the advertisements are here to stay, but in other respect, SABC Chief of Radio, Govin Reddy, is bent on transforming Radio South Africa into a station what will reflect on life, recognising of out last that we are part of the African continent.

You can switch on tour radios on March 1 to check out the changes yourself. Judging by what Reddy says, this could be the station that will come to the rescue of all those who want more from radio than endless pop music and endless talk shows with hosts who are often as arrogantly opinionated as the people who phone in.

The news and current affairs section of SAfm, as it is to be known, sounds as if it is going to be excellent

Considering the state of the newspaper industry, with its diminishing diversity of views, radio news could be a life saver -- especially as there is no good quality national morning paper.

Reddy said that RSA had relied on prepackaged new programmes. This will change as the news is given greater immediacy by the inclusion of live interviews with people in the news. "The news will be read by people who write the news. We won't be using presenters anymore."

Instead of the very brief on-the-hour news broadcasts, there will be "lengthy news bulletins at 7 am, 8 am, 1 o'clock, 6 pm and 10 pm. The on-the-hour news broadcasts will continue but they will be longer and last for 3 to 5 minutes.

Taking South Africa out of the isolation of apartheid years, SAfm will carry much more African news.

Channel Africa, the external service, already has a structure in place with eight other African countries, and Reddy says this is to be used to supply news materials to SAfm and the African language stations. There will be exchanges with radio in other African countries as well.

But it is not merely a question of broadening the scope. Reddy emphasises the implications for creating a well-informed public that will be able to play its part in a democracy.

"We are a member of the Southern African Development Community and are involved in constructive engagement with the region. South Africa is the wealthiest country in the region and you can only do that if people are informed. For example, if South Africa gives assistance to Malawi, people must know why, must know that Malawi is one of the 10 poorest countries in the world."

Coverage of the other African countries will not confine itself to elections, assassinations and coups, Reddy said, but will include human interest stories as well.

"We are gong to increase the coverage not only of the whole of Africa but of the world." There will be fresh young correspondents to replace the older voices, some of whom have been doing the job "since the seventies, if not the sixties."

The approach to current affairs will change. Radio Today will be called Newsbreak. "We have a new term being trained to handle it and it will be much more lively and topical."

For in-depth reporting and analysis of the week's issues, there will be a long programme on Sunday morning and a programme of interviews and analysis by Allister Sparks.

SAfm will play a least 50 per cent local music, but will also continue to play classical music.

Its aim is to introduce younger voices people of all colours and both sexes -- ending the domination of the older, white male structure. So the audience it will attack will similarly be a representative mix of the South African population.

Documentaries, which have been a very weak area on RSA, will be given the attention they deserve. "Radio documentaries cost a fraction of what they do on television, and I believe that social documentaries are highly relevant to the new South Africa. But we need to train people to make them."

Sadly, SAfm will have to continue to carry advertisements unless the government decides to step in and fund the station. "We have advertising out of necessity, not choice. At the moment we get 35 per cent of out income from licenses. If the government gives us funding we will drop our advertisements. The principle will be decided by the IBA."

Surely the IBA will have the wisdom to look beyond immediate financial considerations and giver its support to the crucial principle that there should be at least one are of our culture which is free of the subtle stranglehold of advertising.

The demands of advertising do undoubtedly limit freedom of speech. Add to that the pain they cause listeners by their nagging repetition of inane messages and bad music, and there is a very good case for giving South African relief from this tyranny.

New Nation Publishing Co., 1st Floor Darragh House, 13 Wanderers Street, Johannesburg. PO Box 10674 Johannesburg 2000. Tel:(011) 333-2711 or (011) 333-2721. Fax: (011) 333-2733. Telex: 482226


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English
