Africa News


March, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA-Document: Speech of the Deputy President of the Republic of South Africa, Thabo Mbeki, at the G-7 Conference on the Information Society, Brussels


LENGTH: 2507 words


 

February 24, 1995

President Jacques Santer, Your Excellencies, Ladies and Gentlemen:

First of all, I would like to express our profound appreciation to you Mr. President, to the European Commission and to the G-7 ministers present here for inviting us to address the opening session of this important Conference.

We also bring to the Conference the greetings of our President Nelson Mandela who, similarly, asked us to convey both the best wishes of the people of South Africa to the Conference and our gratitude that you selected our country to sit in on your discussions.

We believe that by this act you sought to make the critical point that entry into the information society is not reserved for the G-7 members and other developed countries- that the debate about the information society is of relevance to all humanity and therefore cannot ignore the position, the needs and role of the developing world.

The truth of this proposition is self-evident. We are sincerely moved that you, Mr President, by inviting me to address the opening session of this Conference, began in a practical way to bring the developing world into the global debate on the information society. 

With regard to information and communication, we are all witnesses to an extraordinary technological revolution which offers ever more powerful and astonishing capabilities, affecting, primarily in the developed world, traditional patterns of work, public opinion, entertainment, education and so on.

These technological developments once more serve to highlight, emphasise and further enhance the disparities between the developed and the developing countries.

All of us present in this room know that, for instance, access to basic telephony is far from being a reality in many parts of the world.

More than half of humanity has never made a telephone call. There are more telephone lines in Manhattan than in all of sub-Saharan Africa.

We also see similar disparities within our own country- between the developed and the underdeveloped parts of our society. In the city of Durban, for instance, telephone penetration among white households stands at 75 per cent. In contrast it stands at 2 per cent as far as the Black households are concerned.

Given these disparities, it is clear that bringing the developing world on to the Information Super-Highway constitutes a colossal challenge.

We have to address this challenge nevertheless, if we are to promote economic growth and development world wide, consolidate democracy and human rights, increase the capacity of ordinary people to participate in governance, encourage resolution of conflicts by negotiation rather than war and do what has to be done to enable all to gain access to the best in human civilisation, within the common neighbourhood in which we all live.

In our own country, having recognised the critical importance and role of information and communication, we began, before our elections last year, to take an intensive look at this whole area, including the question of further building our information and communication infrastructure.

As a result of these early studies and discussions among the various stockholders in our country, the construction of this infrastructure has been determined as one of the important policy objectives of our Reconstruction and Development Programme, which aims to achieve the fundamental and all-round renewal of our society.

It is of course very true that the new democratic government has a whole range of pressing problems to attend to. These include such issues as job creation, housing, provision of clean water and adequate sanitation, education and health care.

It is however also clear that we need a vastly expanded and modern information and communication infrastructure to help us address these concerns, which helps to emphasise the urgency of attending to what, at first glance, might seem to be something to which we should give less priority.

Let me therefore state five principles which guide our own approach to these matters of communication and information which this Conference is discussing.

First- the information infrastructure must serve as a means to support our goals of reconstruction and development. In this context we are convinced that information and communication technologies constitute an engine for economic development.

As such, these technologies will, among other things, encourage growth within our boundaries and facilitate the further insertion of our economy into the global economy.

It is obviously on the basis of a growing and dynamic economy that we will be able to address, on a sustainable basis, the pressing needs I have mentioned.

The second principle I would like to mention concerns the region of Southern Africa.

We strongly believe that any initiative the purpose of which is to build and modernise our information and communication infrastructure must be situated within the context of the needs of the Southern African region as a whole.

Regional integration is key to our approach and is an objective which all the peoples of our region have seized upon because it is both possible and necessary. This must also encompass the area of information and communication.

The third principle I would like to mention is that we must adopt a global approach. It seems clear to us that building our information and communication infrastructure is a multi-faceted proposition in the sense that it encompasses economic, financial, technological, social, cultural and moral aspects.

Consequently, the solution to these problems must itself be global in nature, cutting across the traditional segments of the information and communication industry and bringing within its scope social and cultural concerns.

The fourth principle concerns the issue of content. Like all developing countries, we are very keen to acquire and grasp the technologies which enable people and institutions to access astronomical processing, storage, retrieval and delivery capacities.

But we are also extremely interested to ensure that we are not mere importers and consumers of a predetermined content. Rather, we also want to be producers and exporters and therefore active and significant participants in the creation, production and formulation of content, including news, educational and cultural programmes, games, movies, songs, etc.

To give an indication of what we can by all this- we believe that the modern communication technology we are all talking about must help us educate our children, particularly in the rural and other underdeveloped areas of our country, teach our medical workers and parents how to care for babies, train our youth and eliminate distance and infrastructure imbalances which act as a barrier in providing these social services.

The fifth principle we would like to mention concerns the issue of international co-operation. It is again quite clear that the building of our information and communication infrastructure offers a unique opportunity to enhance international co-operation.

As we have said, we believe that this initiative must be global in nature and involve a great variety of actors, from investors, financiers and manufacturers to operators, educators, artists and so on, drawing into the global project both the domestic and the international, both South Africans and the peoples of the world, both ourselves and the participants at this Conference.

Our late entry into the democratic world order has given us the opportunity to take on board exciting new concepts about governance. I refer here in particular to what is described as the participation of civil society in such governance.

As we draft our new constitution and establish new institutions of government, our eyes are focused on the concept of what we have described as a people-centered society. This requires that the people themselves must be empowered to intervene in the decision-making process.

For this to become a reality, the masses must be able to read, write and to count and be informed on a global basis, that is to say, not only about the plans of government but at the same time about the situation in their immediate neighbourhood.

The people must not only be the recipients of communication from the rulers but should also be able to make their voices heard within the committees in which the rulers sit.

We believe that this radical expansion of the frontiers of democratic participation cannot but enhance the legitimacy of the democratic state, tap the initiative and intellect of millions of citizens, limit any tendency towards arbitrary rule and reinforce social stability and peace.

None of this can be achieved without recourse to the information and communication infrastructure we have been talking about - hence our keenness to move in practical ways towards joining the Information Super-Highway.

Without, in any way, overestimating our own capabilities, and in the context of what we have said about the integration of the region of Southern Africa, we believe that South Africa can act as one of the bridging societies with regard to the realisation of the common objective of bringing together, in a mutually benefical way, the interests, the assets and the aspirations of the developing world and the technological and financial capacities that reside in the developed world.

In this context, I would like to say that our government is already considering various concrete proposals relating to the information and communication infrastructure.

These proposals include the possibility to lay a fibre optic cable encompassing the whole continent of Africa, the extension of the telephone network to rural and underdeveloped areas of South Africa, and a project sponsored by an international consortium which addresses our information and communication needs on a global, rather than a piecemeal basis.

In all these instances, we would look forward to the participation, on the basis of partnership, of the private sector represented at this Conference.

Among other things, adequate regulatory frameworks would have to address the all-important issue of ensuring that the developing world does not enter the Information Super-Highway as a second-class road user.

For instance, where the flow of information and cultural products on the information super-highway will originate mostly from the developed North, this naturally becomes a cause of concern to relatively less media-intensive cultures.

I strongly believe that censorship and control are not an appropriate way to deal with these worries.

The best insurance against the swamping of people's cultures is the re-invigoration of their creative spirit and universal appeal.

We, in the developing world, have much to contribute and the super-highway should usher in an era where this contribution ultimately binds human kind closer together and enables all to shape our common destiny.

This leads me to the last point I would like to make. We believe that this initiative, which has brought us to Brussels, needs to be followed by another one, bringing together a cross section of the developing world together with the G-7 Group and the European Union, in recognition of the global information and communication challenge, to exchange views on such questions as strategy, finance and international m-ordination.

We trust that the distinguished President of the European Union, our host on this occasion, will find time to consider this proposal and perhaps agree to sponsor what we believe would be an important and necessary encounter.

I am certain that our own country, if called upon, would seriously consider the possibility of hosting such a Conference.

Please accept our best wishes for the success of this Conference and our thanks for you attention.

Thank you.


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


91 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Healing Health Care


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

New Nation (Johannesburg)

JAnuary 27, 1995

South Africa has in the past prided itself on the fact that it spends as much as anyone else in the world on health care - about two percent of the total wealth produced.

It also boasts some of the best equipped hospitals in the Southern Hemisphere and, for some, state of the art health care.

What it cannot boast, however, is equal access to health care for all its citizens.

Only 19 percent of the country's estimated 40 million citizens have ready access to quality primary health care - largely thanks to funding through private medical schemes. 

On average, most medical aid members belong to an above average income group, earning about R40 000 a year or around R3 000 a month.

The remaining 81 percent or 32 million people are not covered by medical aid because they are unemployed or simply because they do not earn enough to afford exorbitant premiums.

They depend entirely on state hospitals and clinics for primary health care.

The picture gets more depressing when one considers that these 32 million depend almost entirely on only 5 000 general practitioners employed by state-funded health facilities.

In contrast, the seven to eight million medical aid members have access to 8 000 GPs operating in the private sector.

This is a ratio of doctors to patients in the private affluent sector of 1:1 000 compared to 1:6 400 in the publicly-funded sector.

This imbalance translates into a back-breaking burden for overcrowded state-funded hospitals, which have been driven close to collapse with the quality of specialist medical services deteriorating at an alarming rate.

What is amply apparent is that the country's health care system needs dramatic restructuring. But consensus on how to achieve this continues to elude interest groups in the health sector.

Zuma is adamant that a solution must be found. She is convinced that the focus must be on developing a system that removes the responsibility of providing primary health care from hospitals and makes it universally accessible and affordable.

"The core of any successful health care system is strong primary care - ie, a basic health service for all," she says.

The immediate spin-off will be an improvement in the quality of specialist care at hospitals while the cost of providing primary health care would be reduced.

What seems obvious though, is that accessibility will not increase unless government is able to make the services offered by the 8 000 GPs available to all and not just those who can afford it through private medical aid and insurance schemes.

Health economist Jonathan Deeble says in a proposal prepared for the health ministry that this could be achieved by involving these GPs in a national scheme.

This would immediately increase the number of GPs available to the estimated 32 million dependent on state facilities from the current 5 000 to 13 000 and spread the ratio of one doctor for every 64 000 to one doctor for every 3 000 citizens.

However, one of the most serious obstacles in the way of drawing GPs into a national scheme is limited financial resources.

It seems highly unlikely that government will in the short term be able to find additional funds to pay the 8 000 doctors who currently have 70 percent of their services financed through private medical aid schemes.

Pointing to an added difficulty, Deeble says, "There would be little chance of attracting GPs into a national programme at affordable prices as long as their present practices are well supported by medical aid."

Proposals for a NHI scheme have come in for criticism from free marketeers who have slammed the proposal as an attempt to smuggle in a socialist health care scheme that is bound to fail.

They point to Britain, where market reforms were introduced into a national health scheme which had been operating for more than 40 years.

It has been pointed out that the introduction of o system similar to that proposed by Deeble also sparked off an exodus of GPs.

But Zuma says the British system continues to work very well and has done so for 40 years. "Yes, right at the beginning some doctors left, but the scheme worked and they soon came back," she adds.

Commenting on the market reforms recently introduced in Britain, Zuma says: "Any scheme that has been operating for such a length of time as in Britain has to be re-evaluated from time to time as conditions change."

"What needs to be said, however, is that almost all developed countries are introducing some national health scheme in one form or another - including Switzerland, which recently held a referendum and people voted for a national health insurance.

"Taiwan, also for the first time this year, is implementing a national health insurance scheme."

What is certain from recent criticism of a national health plan controlled exclusively by government and which bars medical aid funds from collecting premiums for primary health care, is that its implementation could generate a great deal of conflict.

It is possible that when government finalises its plans for a NHI, it will provide for a gradual move from a hybrid scheme offering both government and private sector involvement, to eventually developing a completely state-run primary health service.

New Nation is published at Darragh House 13 Wanders St. Johannesburg Tel: (011) 333-2711 or (011) 333-2721/2/3/4 Telex: 482226 Fax: (011) 889-0630


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


92 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


RWANDA-Commentary: Gender and the Rwanda Genocide


LENGTH: 1854 words


 

February 1995

(This is a piece submitted by David Newbury of the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill. He notes these thoughts will be expanded in the future.)

The dramas in Central Africa continue unabated, though off the TV screens. In Rwanda, while the "international community" and the aid agencies focus on the "two" sides, the RPF (the Rwandan Patriotic Front, the leading party in the current government of Kigali) and the FAR ("Les Forces Armees Rwandaises," the former Rwandan Army under the Habyarimana regime). However, the vast majority of people -- the Third Force -- are partisan of neither political faction at this point. But despite the focus of outside observers, the multiple crises will not diminish until the re-invention of Rwandan society has begun anew -- from the bottom up. One facet to that process is seen in an exploration of the relation of gender and genocide.

There are many ways in which the two--gender and genocide--are inter-related. But three dimension seem worthy of note. In the immediate wake of genocide both the FAR and the RPF rounded up young women and kept them as incubators of a new generation, in what amounted to a race to propagate -- with both sides feeling their political clout (and eventually military potential) depended directly on their demographic weight. 

In a sense this amounts to a new dimension of an earlier social strategy. In the past in Rwanda demographic weight was valued because it allowed the potential of multiple alliances through various types of client ties. Now demographic weight is used as a means to build up the potential of the factional group precisely to be independent of the kind of intricate social networks and broadly-ramifying client ties that characterized earlier social relations. The ethnicity of the women so captured was apparently no obstacle to this strategy, since in the eyes of the ideologues on both sides -- who have increasingly adopted an essentialist view of culture and ethnicity -- ethnicity is determined by paternity alone. But where during the genocidal atrocities, many Tutsi women were raped to humiliate and harm them (and they were often killed afterward), in this later phase after the atrocities, the preference was for women of the same ethnic group as the perpetrators, both Hutu and Tutsis, this time to reproduce the group. For example, stories from reliable sources -- independently confirmed -- tell of young Tutsi women being held in Kigali and other towns by RPF forces (composed mostly of Tutsi) as walking wombs, where the yearnings of youth mix with the strategies of statesmen to capture women of reproductive age -- especially women of one's own ethnicity. So rather than fighting to "protect" women of the same ethnicity as the soldiers, to recall the paternalistic/patriarchal cliche about war, in this case the fighting has ended up by conquering women of the same group as the soldiers, often explicitly referred to as "le repos du guerrier" -- spoils of the victor.

A second dimension to the role of gender in the current conditions relates to legal, as well as personal security. Both in the refugee camps outside the country and in the camps of displaced peoples within Rwanda, a very large number of women -- of diverse ages -- are now heads of families. But this presents grave difficulties for them in gaining access to land or property within a patriarchal legal system -- and, as in the wake of many wars, a chauvinistic social context.

The legal situation pertaining to women and property, and specifically to the right of women to inherit and own land is ambiguous, for the Legal Code of Rwanda was in the process of revision when the war broke out. Recently there have been efforts by some in the Kigali administration to clarify such rights; it is estimated that currently 65-75% of the adult population in Rwanda are female, and a significant proportion of households are headed by women. But in the aftermath of genocide where so many of those currently in power lost close family members to horrible deaths, and without any semblance of a credible judicial system in place in Rwanda, to enforce the law, such legal guarantees are often without merit. Instead, with the influx of many people (and many cattle), with the spirit of vengeance running high, and with a climate of accumulation reigning supreme during this "window of opportunity" where power and patronage have supplanted legal claims to ownership and property, there is very little security offered to an independent female head of household.

What this means is that many families in the refugee camps outside Rwanda virtually cannot return to Rwanda, absent either male protection or effective legal rights in a social situation characterized in many instances by simple propriety predation. How are a woman and her children to claim land in the hills? Or housing in the towns? Even people who remained in the countryside have had to cede property and housing to incoming arrivals with powerful patrons. So vast numbers of female-headed families, in the refugee camps and elsewhere, wait in limbo for some effective policy to be implemented within Rwanda. It has been a long time coming, and there is no sign that the situation will change soon.

For many, it is not a question of "guilt" or "propaganda" that keeps them in the refugee camps outside Rwanda, as the outside world is constantly told. Intimidation and propaganda are intense, to be sure. But such propaganda gains credibility by the fact that it contains a partial truth: that security, both over the person and the land, is not yet assured. And among these several million refugees, there are many who reject the propaganda, who see it for what it is: these are not "dumb peasants," puppets, as some would have us believe, but shrewd actors, who have heard their share of promises and can judge for themselves where there interests lie. Their reluctance to return -- something many desperately want to be able to do -- is simply a realistic assessment on the part of the participants, and in large number they are women.

But -- and this is the third dimension to gender and genocide -- they have been largely indivisible. While currently UNHCR personnel are actively involved in encouraging women's organizations, for example, it took a long time coming, time that was critical for the emerging political culture of the camps. Neither the new powers in Kigali nor the UN -- at least in their higher levels -- were very sensitive to gender realities in the early stages. For example, four months after the establishment of the principle refugee camp in Tanzania, the UN authorities and AID organizations were apparently unaware that there had existed formal women's organization's in every Commune, in nearly every Secteur, in Rwanda before the genocide. They were unaware too that these "foyers sociaux" had often been reconstituted by the women in the refugee camps; yet these women were moving ahead on women's projects where they could -- collective childcare, firewood collection, health issues, care for the aged or the wounded -- not just through informal friendship networks alone, but as organized collectives.

There would have been many ways a small assistance from the NGOs could have helped, yet by August 1994, at the time my wife and I visited Benaco, little had been done; the camp authorities, though extremely dedicated aid workers, were totally unaware of such activities among the refugee community, being fixated instead on issues of personal security and the "politics" of the refugees; these are crucially important issues, of that there is no question, but not the universe of what makes a life, let alone a community. The neglect of such local-level initiatives as the women showed was particularly disappointing if one's goal is a functioning society and a peaceful one.

One example shows how a little aid could have helped. In one camp, the women sought to harvest reeds for mats to protect their compounds during the dry season -- and as an income generator for female headed households; these delicate mats keep the dust down, provide shade, and bring beauty to what is otherwise the drab decor of a refugee camp. But when the women sought to harvest such reeds on their own, they had been chased away by the local population, who feared the loss of yet another resource to the huge influx of refugees. Discreet help with outside mediation could have made a significant difference for both the women entrepreneurs and the local population, both reducing tension and perhaps providing some compensation to the local population. There are many ways this could have been accomplished: by paying for harvest rights for refugee women; by having the local population harvest the reeds and sell them in the refugee camps, or by simply providing the reeds through UN/NGO funds. (The first alternative would have been best, for the women who weave the mats prefer to cut and dry the reeds themselves as part of the work process.) It wouldn't have taken much; nothing was done.

The important point is that the UN/NGOs could have helped in the negotiations with local people to allow some form of access to marsh reeds, and thus both ease tensions and provide a valuable resource and activity validating women's grass-roots initiatives and organization through remunerative work. This is only one small example of many. But it is from such small beginnings that other initiatives flow.

Today the situation is much different. Current activities on these issues seem to recognize that to neglect women's initiatives and to deny the chance for independent production or organization is to discount an extremely important element of this "Third Force," on which any resolution ultimately depends. It is an encouraging start, but there is a long way yet to go.


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


93 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


NIGERIA: Auta says Nyet


LENGTH: 854 words


 

Newswatch (Lagos)

)March 13, 1995

by Sam Olukoya

Ken Saro-Wiwa, president of the Movement for the Survival of Ogoni People, MOSOP, and four others standing trial for the murder of four prominent Ogoni citizens, have lost their battle for bail. Ibrahim Auta, chairman of the three-man tribunal trying them, ruled last Monday in Port Harcourt that the accused persons were not entitled to bail because there was no guarantee that they would not abscond.

In their application for bail late last month, two of the accused persons, Saro-Wiwa and Ledun Mitee, deputy president of MOSOP, argued that they were responsible people unlikely to jump bail or interfere with police investigations. In an affidavit to support his application for bail, Saro-Wiwa had said his health would deteriorate as long as he remained in detention. He said his heart disease is a serious ailment which can only be treated in a teaching hospital. 

Mitee had also cited his poor health as one of the grounds for bail. His health, he said, had worsened while the life of his pregnant wife was in danger because of the anxiety caused by his continued detention.

Also last Monday, the tribunal ruled on the contentious issue of where the accused persons are to be detained in the absence of bail. Auta turned down prayers by defense lawyers that the accused persons be transferred from the custody of the military where they are currently being kept to the Port Harcourt prison. In his ruling, Auta said MOSOP members might raid the prison and release the detainees if they were kept there.

Gani Fawehinmi, one of the defence lawyers, had objected to the detention of the accused persons in a military barracks when he raised the issue before the tribunal early last month. "What is the business of the army in this matter?" he queried, insisting that in the history of the judiciary, never had an accused person been kept in the custody of the army. He also spoke of the maltreatment meted out to the accused persons in the barracks. Citing the case of Saro-Wiwa as an example, he said the MOSOP president was put in chains for 64 days and beaten up during the period. Another key complaint against their detention in the barracks was that they were denied access to their doctors, lawyers and relations.

Last week, Fawehinmi raised fresh issues before the tribunal. He said the prosecution has been taking its witnesses to the witness box without allowing the defence lawyers to see their statements to the police. Such a procedure, he said, was of section 236 of the Criminal; Procedure Act, but also against the rule of natural justice. Fawehinmi threatened to hands off the case if the prosecution does not change its strategy. The decision of the tribunal, he said, would determine whether he should continue as a defence lawyer in the case or not. J.B, Dawodu, the prosecutor, however, appeared unwilling to change his stance. He said to make the statements of the witnesses available to the defence following Fawehinmi's threat would mean that "the prosecution has succumbed to the blackmail of the defence counsels." The prosecution has so far presented two of its witnesses before the tribunal. Their testimonies centered on MOSOP's activities especially its campaign against environmental degradation caused by oil exploration in Ogoniland.

Garrick Leton, one time minister of education, was one of the two witnesses who have testified against the MOSOP. Incidentally, Leton was the first president of MOSOP when it was formed on August 26, 1990 after the Ogonis launched the Ogoni Bill of Rights. Leton described MOSOP as anon-violent organisation which adopted a philosophy of passive resistance and persuasion rather than violence. He said he resigned his position as president following Saro-Wiwa's adamant posture of not allowing the Ogonis to take a part in the June 12, 1993 presidential election. He said Saro-Wiwa resorted to unorthodox activities shortly after he succeeded him as MOSOP president.

Newswatch Communications Limited, No.3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria. Telephone: 496093. Fax: 962887.


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


94 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


In the Net


LENGTH: 4894 words


 

Newswatch (Lagos)

March 27,1995

by Nats Agbo

At 11.00 A.M. March 13, four police officers drove into the Ota home of Olusegun Obasanjo, a general and former head of state. The four-man team was led by an assistant inspector-general of police. They met Obsanjo in his brick house and introduced themselves to him. They told the general he was wanted for questioning at the State Intelligence and Investigation Bureau, SIIB, in Lagos.

Obasanjo spoke briefly with one of his aides and was driven out in a Mercedes Benz car. Outside the gate, more security men waited in an unmarked Peugeot J5 bus. As soon as the Mercedes Benz car conveying him was out of the compound, the bus followed it. About one kilometre away, there was a lorry-load of anti-riot policemen who joined the convoy. Obasanjo was taken to the SIIB offices where he was kept until midnight. He was then transferred, according to sources, to a guest house in Ikeja. 

Defence headquarters feigned ignorance of Obasanjo's arrest. Fred Chijuka, a brigadier-general and defense spokesman, said that since he was arrested by the police the military could not explain why or where he was being held. He told reporters: "I have not been officially informed about Obasanjo's arrest. I read it in the papers like everyone of you." He directed journalists to the police for information on the arrest of the former head of state.

"Newswatch" has learnt that Obasanjo's arrest did not surprise him and some of his close associates. According to dependable "Newswatch" sources, information had leaked from security circles indicating that he was to be arrested on his return from Copenhagen, Denmark, where he was attending a United Nations conference on the elimination of poverty from the world.

An aide of the general told "Newswatch" that Walter Carrington, the United States ambassador in Nigeria, who heard of the plan to arrest Obasanjo phoned him in Copenhagen. He reportedly told him of a rumour circulating in Nigeria that he escaped from the country through the Seme border because of a coup plot that had just been uncovered. The ambassador reportedly pleaded with him to postpone his return to Nigeria.

Obasanjo is said to have told Carrington that he would return to Nigeria because he had no hand in any coup plot. As soon as the conference ended, Obasanjo headed home through London on a British Airways flight. On arrival at the Murtala Mohammed International Airport, Lagos, March 13, his international passport was seized by security men. He was, however, allowed to go home.

The seizure of his passport gave Obasanjo the first real hint that trouble was awaiting his return from Denmark. Later in the morning, he went for a meeting with the Ooni of Ife, Oba Okunade Sijuade, at the Ooni's house in Ikeja. David Jemibewon, a retired major-general, and one other person were in attendence. The meeting, "Newswatch" learnt, discussed mainly national issues, including the rumour of Obasanjo's imminent arrest and his experience at the airport the previous night. After the meeting which lasted more than two hours, he returned to his Ota farm home. And trouble came to the general.

There has been no love lost between Obasanjo and the Abacha administration. His detention, according to sources, climaxed the love-hate relationship. When Abacha took over November 17, 1993, he invited Obasanjo to Defense House, Lagos, to seek his cooperation and for Obasanjo to nominate candidates for cabinet and other positions. Shehu Musa Yar'Adua, a retired general and Obasanjo's former deputy, was equally invited. As reported by "Newswatch" at the time, both Obasanjo and Yar'Adua, who did not even know that the two of them were invited to Defence House for the same purpose, told Abacha separately that they could not give him their support unless he was ready to announce his political transition programme for the country, stating his handing over date. The stance of the two generals was said to have so angered the head of state he decided to shut them out of Aso Rock when he eventually moved to Abuja.

"Newswatch" learnt that Abacha appealed to close friends of Obasanjo to get him to change his mind. One of such dignitaries is President Nicephore Soglo of the Republic of Benin. A few weeks before Obasanjo left for Copenhagen, he was in Cotonou for a world conference on corruption. There, Soglo told him of Abacha's complaints that he did not support the head of state. Obasanjo told Soglo he had nothing against Abacha but that unless Abacha comes up with a clear programme to move Nigeria forward and announce a hand over date, he would not support him.

Yar'Adua too has campaigned openly for an early return to civil rule. He is a member of the constitutional conference. He and some other members of the conference spearheaded the decision that Abacha must hand over by January 1996. During the long break of the conference this year, government put pressure on conference delegates to change the decision. Agents of the government were said to have distributed money and plots of land to some of the delegates. Yar'Adua was believed to have also stepped up his campaign to ensure that the conference decision was not changed. This, Aso Rock sources say, angered senior government officials who started spreading rumour that Yar'Adua was planning to topple the government. Late in February, a delegate, however, pleaded with Kaita not to tell Yar'Adua. The general is Kaita's cousin. Kaita said he was aware of the implications of the allegation being made against Yar'Adua and that he could not keep it from him. The retired general made desperate efforts to meet Abacha on the allegation. That meeting did not take place before Yar'Adua was picked up.

Even when the two generals were arrested, no one suspected that it had anything to do with the alleged coup plot. The military had said that Obasanjo's arrest was a police affair, ruling out any involvement of him in any coup plot. As for Yar'Adua, his detention order by Ibrahim Coomassie, the inspector-general of police, accused him of "acts prejudicial to state security" and of contributing to "the economic adversity of the state."

The two generals were arrested by policemen not soldiers. Usually, suspected coup plotters, whether they are soldiers or civilians are arrested by soldiers because coup plotting is a purely military affair. Also, their detention in civil establishments was also an indication that they were not held in connection with he coup plot.

But all these look like wrong signals. Late last weekend, military intelligence sources said the arrests were indeed linked to the coup plot. Two of the senior officers arrested in connection with he coup plot were said to have made conflicting statements on the involvement of Obasanjo and Yar'Adua. According to the sources, while one of them said the two retired generals knew of the plot and were indeed ready to finance it, the other officer said it was false. The second officer was said to have claimed responsibility for the coup plot saying it was ridiculous to accuse any retired army officer of complicity in it.

Still, according to a military source, "most of the revelations confirmed what we have suspected all along, that the generals were up to some mischief." "Newswatch" learnt that since 1993 when the two retired officers refused to support the government they had been placed under close security surveillance. Obasanjo, for instance, was said to have been closely monitored by security agents because of his utterances and political activities which are said to be "inimical to the interest of the state." During their brief meeting in November 1993, Obasanjo told Abacha that the administration should have a brief tenure, not exceeding 18 months. He also suggested that the cabinet both at the federal and state levels, should be made of civilians. His argument was that this would mollify the civil society.

Not quite a week after, Obasanjo openly chastised the administration at the launching of a collection of his speeches at the Ota Forum lectures in Lagos, November 24, 1993. Apparently referring to the government's claim that Ernest Shonekan resigned as head of the interim national government, ING, he asked the military to be honest in dealing with those whom they lead. He said any resignation "procured at gun point is different from normal voluntary resignation," adding, "it would have enhanced the credibility and honesty of purpose of our new military leaders to inform us that the resignation on which their existence is based is at least an induced resignation. Openness, honesty and accountability should be in an open inventory of Nigeria's stocks, what is sold, to whom, and at what price."

His role in the formation of the National Unity Organisation of Nigeria, NUON, and the planned alliance between the Yoruba and the Igbo were viewed along the same line. Defence sources also claimed last week that the coup suspect who linked the former head of state to the coup plot said he had pledged full to the coup plotters and was presented with two options, if the coup succeeded. The first option was for him to head an interim national government for a period of two years. He would use the period to conduct elections and hand over power to an elected civilian government.

A second option was the installation of Moshood Abiola, who is believed to have won the annulled June 12, 1993, presidential election, as president. He too would be in office for two years. Under the second option, all the sacked civilian governors and legislators at both the national and state levels would have been recalled.

Military sources also claim that Yar'Adua preferred the Abiola one because it would have been easier for him to realise his ambition of becoming president. A two-year one-term tenure for Abiola would have meant that the south would have taken the first slot in the rotational presidency proposed by the constitutional conference. He would have been free to contest election after the expiration of Abiola's tenure because it would have been the turn of the northern states to produce a president.

Yar'Adua was also said to have exhibited so much contempt for the present military government that he often assured political associates that it would not last beyond February this year. Intelligence sources said that even in detention, Yar'Adua continued to berate the military regime, asking Abacha to leave office and hand-over power to an elected government. So far, only Yar'Adua is said to have made any statement to the police. Obasanjo, the sources said, is yet to be interviewed.

Our intelligence sources also claimed that the coup plotters had the support of the United States embassy in Lagos. An economic blueprint was said to have been prepared for the coup plotters by the embassy. The sources said the economic blueprint was to be used by the interim government to revive the economy.

But an embassy official who requested not to be named described it as "fabrication and cheap propaganda." He said: "no official of the US embassy prepared any economic blueprint for any succeeding government in Nigeria. There is no truth whatsoever to it and we had no knowledge whatsoever about plans to overthrow the government."

A close associate of Obasanjo also faulted the allegations made against him, saying if the former head of state was connected with the plot, "he would not have returned from his trip to Denmark since he was informed of government's plans to arrest him." The associate also described as false the claim that he had accepted to serve as head of state for an interim period of two years. "Those making that wild allegation seem to have forgotten that when attempts were made to persuade him to head the interim national government, ING, in the dying days of the Babangida regime, he refused. How do they expect him to accept the same position now and under criminal circumstances?"

Also, contrary to claims by intelligence sources that Yar'Adua was making inflammatory statements about the government at the Kirikiri maximum prison where he is being held, his political associates who visited him said "anybody who links him to a coup plot is out to cause mischief." He is said to see his arrest as a price for his political conviction, and told those who visited him that every one knows that he has the ambition to become president of Nigeria in a democratic set-up. He reportedly said he could not support any military coup d'etat because it negates the political ideals for which he had stood since 1979. His political allies say that his arrest was to remove him from the constitutional conference in order to diminish his influence there and create an enabling environment for the extension of the tenure of the constitutional conference.

Whether such postulations are right or not, the arrests of Obasanjo and Yar'Adua have sparked off angry reactions from the international community and some organisations within Nigeria. The US department of state March 14 warned that government should avoid actions "that could be construed as outside the bounds of international norms." The statement also appealed for "freedom for citizens to exchange views freely both in public and without fear of reprisal or retribution for the opinions expressed." It said the fresh wave of arrests and the continued incarceration of Abiola showed the extension of "the unwise practice of silencing critics of military rule."

Shridath Ramphal, former secretary-general of the Commonwealth, told a News Agency of Nigeria, NAN, correspondent that the arrest of serving and retired officers was alarming and resentful. He said just as the lives of those arrested were at stake, "so is Nigeria's standing in the world as well as that of Africa of which Nigeria is so much a leader."

Some European nations are said to be considering the imposition of stiff sanctions against Nigeria. Last week's cancellation by FIFA of Nigeria's hosting rights for the eighth youth soccer championship was a direct result of the current political development. The arrests also attracted very angry comments on the floor of the British House of Commons.

Trans-Africa, a Washington-based lobbying group which concerns itself with African and Caribbean issues, wrote a letter to Abacha in which it regretted the "unfounded treason charges" against Abiola. It called on Abacha to "expedite the restoration of democracy to Nigeria's 100 million people who yearn for it. To do less will result in incalculable damage to Africa's most populous nation and the eventual global economic and political isolation of your regime."

The letter was signed by 56 prominent African-Americans. Randall Robinson, executive director of TransAfrica, told the BBC last Thursday that his organisation was ready to do battle with the Abacha regime, saying it would not relent until military rule was terminated in Nigeria.

Strangely, attempts to have the detention of especially Yar'Adua discussed at the constitutional conference last week was thrown out. It was not clear if the delegates were intimidated by the presence of soldiers at the conference venue. Eight conference delegates from Katsina State had issued a two-paragraph statement demanding Yar'Adua's release. But when Anselem Eyo, a delegate from Akwa Ibom State, moved that the conference should intercede on behalf of their detained colleague, some of the delegates kicked against the motion, saying they were in Abuja to draft a constitution. Mohmud Attah, a conference delegate from Kogi State, said the delegates could not intercede because it was "clearly a security matter." He argued that when other prominent Nigerians were detained in the past, nobody pleaded for them: "I believe we have got other important issues to discuss. Who does not know that Yar'Adua is being suspected for? He should go and clear himself."

Adolphus Karibi-Whyte, chairman of the conference, later ruled that the arrest of Yar'Adua was outside the purview of the conference.

The National Democratic Coalition, NADECO, the Civil Liberties Organisation, CLO and the National Conscience Party, NCP, also reacted to the arrests of the retired generals, and the suspected coup plotters. NADECO described the arrests of "such important personalities as a former head of state and his deputy" as "disgraceful and alarming." The statement which was signed by Bolaji Akinyemi, former external affairs minister and NADECO spokesman in London, chided the military for entrenching "a cycle of coups, arrests and executions" which "will never solve the political problems of Nigeria."

CLO is worried that Yar'Adua is detained under very "strict and harsh conditions." He is said to be denied access to radio, television, telephone, newspapers or magazines.

The NCP, in its statement, said the mere fact that some of those arrested in connection with the alleged coup plot are noted opponents of the regime makes the motive for their arrests suspect. The statement, signed by Femi Aborisade, the director of organisation and strategies, called for "a free and fair trial for the alleged coup plotters...in the normal open court and (they) should be allowed access to counsel of their choice."

Jimmy Carter, former US president who was one of the international leaders to plead for the release of Obasanjo and the others in detention, is planning a peace mission to Nigeria. He is expected to meet senior government officials to further appeal for national reconciliation through he release of those arrested in connection with the coup plot. It was learnt that traditional rulers who visited Abacha last week had the same message: that Obasanjo and other politicians arrested should be freed.

Although Ibrahim Dasuki, the Sultan of Sokoto who led the 14 traditional rulers, said thier visit to Aso Rock was to express their loyalty, shock and sympathy over the alleged coup plot, the motive was to douse dwhat government sources described as "the fear of the unknown." The traditional rulers were said to have expressed the fear that if the matter was not resolved amicably, it could lead the country into more crisis.

Other world leaders are said to be putting pressures on Abacha not to put Obasanjo and some of the detained politicians and soldiers on trial. The northern elders' forum, a loose association of political elites from the northern states, is to send a delegation to Aso Rock this week. Kaita told "Newswatch" that they were still discussing the issue but added that they, like other Nigerians, were concerned about the coup plot.

Abba Kyari, a retired brigadier-general also confirmed to "Newswatch" that the Northern elders were holding meetings concerning the detention of Yar'Adua. But he said that government was yet to tell them the real reason for Yar'Adua's detention. "It is when we are told formally, not on pages of newspapers, that we will know how to approach the issue," he said.

Whether such appeals will influence Abacha's decision on the issue remains to be seen. Even when he received the traditional rulers last week, he said when investigations are concluded, they "would leave no one in doubt" about the individual roles played by some of those arrested in connection with the coup plot. Describing the suspected coup plotters as "misguided elements," the head of state said "the objectives and negative intentions of the perpetrators of this act" would be made public.

Since the coup plot was uncovere, several groups have been sending delegations to the federal government to express their support. "Newswatch" also learnt all the solidarity messages being sent to Abacha from the states may harden his position on the fate of all those arrested by security agents as a result of the plot. "What the so-called solidarity messages and visits will do is to create the false impression that the people are in support of military rule and that is dangerous because it will encourage the leaders to kill these suspects," a defence source said.

What has been confusing analysts of the unfolding situation in Nigeria is the secrecy surrounding the identity of those involved in the alleged coup plot. In a statement on Friday, March 10, Abdulsalam Abubakar, a major-general and chief of defence staff, had explained why names of the suspects were being kept secret. Said he: "It will be premature and prejudicial to justice to mention names because of the damage that can be done to the psyche of those who may be cleared in the long run."

This has led to speculations in the press about those involved in the coup plot and what their intentions were. But as the picture of the coup plot became clearer last week, "Newswatch" learnt that some of the officers listed as having been involved in the coup plot had nothing to do with it. In its story of March 20, for instance, "Newswatch" had mentioned Cyril Iweze, a major-general and army's director of logistics, as one of the senior officers arrested in connection with the coup plot. It was discovered that he was not involved in the plot and was never arrested. Several other retired and serving military officers linked with the alleged plot in some other publications are raising objections to such linkages.

Defence sources also said Mike Torey, the military administrator of Enugu State was mentioned only because the conference from which some officers were alleged to have been recruited for the coup plot was held in Enugu.

Ike Nwachukwu, a retired major-general and former minister of external affairs, issued a sttement saying he was "aggrieved by the concern generated and impression created in the minds of my family and friends" by a magazine story linking him with the coup plot. He had been mentioned by a weekly journal as one of those arrested. He said that after serving the military and Nigeria for 30 years, the insinuation that he was involved in the coup plot was a calculated attempt "to question my honour, integrity and loyalty to Nigeria." He added: "I am not, have not been and shall not engage in any plan to disrupt the process of government in Nigeria."

Defence sources also told "Newswatch" last week that although Babangida had not been linked to the coup plot," the ring leaders are people who enjoyed protection under him." Early in 1985, some of them were said to have been implicated in a plot to overthrow former head of state Mohammed Budhari. As punishment, they were only sent on overseas courses, intelligence sources claimed.

It was also claimed that the coup plot was initially hatched early in 1994 and had been supported and encouraged by civilians, including some who later became ministers in Abacha's cabinet. "Their appointments as ministers," said a military source, "weakened the plan to overthrow the government last year."

Defence sources also confirmed "Newswatch" story of March 20 concerning the alleged plan by the suspected coup plotters to eliminate some prominent Nigerians, including military officers and civilians. They were alleged to have argued that Nigeria's development was being hampered by those listed for elimination because they, through the domination of the military, the economy and politics had retarded Nigeria's growth. As for the military, officers from the rank of brigadier-general were to be either killed or retired, the sources claimed.

Full investigations into the coup plot began last Friday. Despite assurances that the case would be speedily disposed of, the pressures being mounted on the government may delay the final judgement. Abacha himself has promised that investigations would be very thorough. But not all the detainees have faith in the outcome of such investigations.

Yar'Adua, for instance, has gone to court to challenge his arrest and detention. On March 14, his counsel, Chike Ohigbue, asked the federal high court, Lagos, to declare that Yar'Adua's arrest and detention without any formal charge were unlawful, unconstitutional, null and void. He also wanted the court to declare that his arrest and detention violated his immunity from arrests as a result of his roles at the constitutional conference.

Babatunde Belgore, the chief judge of the federal high court, however, threw out the case saying Yar'Adua could not claim in one breath that he was not told the reason for his arrest and detention and claim against that it was because of his utterances on the floor of the constitutional conference. By last Thursday, Alfred Kasumu, a professor of law and senior advocate of Nigeria, SAN, had taken over the case. He filed a fresh suit in which he amended the statements in the first suit to read: "Although Yar'Adua was not informed of any reason to warrant his detention, he has cause to believe that it may not be unconnected width speeches he made on the floor of the constitutional conference with respect to the governance of this country including the complete and total disengagement of the military from politics.

Yar'Adua's lawyers, however, vowed last week to "fight for Yar'Adua's release, using all constitutional means available in Nigeria." It may be a tough fight.

Reported by Soji Akinrinade, Mike Akpan, Joseph Ode, Wale Akin Aina and Janet Mba-Afolabi.

Newswatch Communications Limited, No.3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria. Telephone: 496093. Fax: 962887.


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


95 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


NIGERIA: See Lagos and Die


LENGTH: 3014 words


 

Newswatch (Lagos)

March 6, 1995

by Niyi Osundare

Eko Akete, Ile Ogbon: Lagos, House of Wisdom. Arodede maa ja o: The one that hangs precariously without dropping. A romi sa legbe: Running infinity of water.

The above snippet from an old popular song provides a poignant ontological geography of Lagos, the commercial and social nerve centre of Nigeria, and, until recently, the country's administrative capital. Lagos is an uncanny combination of myth and reality, of esoteric indigeneity and imported alienation; a city where zinc-walled, paper-windowed shacks tremble in the concrete shadows of ultra-modern skyscrapers; where tears and laughter erupt and wrestle before seeking a fitful truce in the belly of the sea. 

For the sea is Lagos. Lagos is the sea. The Atlantic it was which eased in the first flotilla of boats; in its Adamic proclamation the name 'Lagos' was born. But like everything African, the city has learnt to bear the burden of a double nomenclature, handling it, where possible, with peculiar ambidexterity; 'Lagos' being offspring of its foreign baptism, while 'Eko' remains its rooted, authentic identity. 'Lagos' dominates map of politics and high commerce; 'Eko' rules the lore of a deep uncharitable nativity; 'Lagos' measures the waters by the circumference of the coastline, 'Eko' issues forth from the vortex of a fluid abyss. Thus, while Lagos may oftentimes appear anonymous even by virtue of that naming, another metro-pole of screeching automobiles and restless elevators, a riot of roofs in endless battle with the skyline, Eko is the product of a pointed, almost religious specificity of visceral methods and cerebral sympathies, that narrow lane of consciousness where science collides with sensibility and memory is born midwifed by nostalgia. In many ways, these two names are equidistant from the Nigerian experience. In other ways they arrive at a certain confluence, some indescribable co-terminality. An argument may, indeed, be raised as to whether these two names refer to one and the same place. For one person's 'Lagos' is another's 'Eko'. It is often possible to hate 'Lagos' while helplessly bound by 'Eko's' charm.

In its two names, which are also its two destinies, the city casts a gigantic shadow over the Nigerian hinterland. See Lagos and die, screams a legend on one of those brave lorries which ply the long, hazardous road between Lagos and the interior, trucking in the upland farm's yams and plantains for the insatiable comfort of the city stomach, and returning later with glittering brands of imported merchandise. That legend itself is child to a legendary chronicle. In the past, in those imperial days of the ocean liner and the BOAC (British Overseas Airways Corporation), it used to be See London and die. Proud... and thoroughly enviable... been-to's (humorous label for returnees from overseas) regaled open-mouthed stay-at-homes with tales of London's grandeur: the underground train which burrows through the earth like fabulous rodents; the motley drama of Trafalgar Square where care-free pigeons defecate on human heads with imperial disdain (to be sure, Lagos fountain ran dry with post-independence euphoria, the pigeons vanished without trace!); the sheer architectural awe of Westminster; the royal splendour of Buckingham Palace wherein lived the Crown that ruled the empire; Elephant and Castle which had a castle but no elephant...

But then the number of travellers multiplied, and increasing familiarity put a dent London's magic. Then the locus of wonder changed: See Paris and die. City of scrubbed streets and wine-draped boulevards. City of modes and manners where the French language tumbles out of sophisticated mouths with the liquid impeccability of champagne cascading into a civil tumbler. City which spies the world from the lofty pinnacle of Eiffel Tower...

Somewhat aware of the imperial grandeur of London and the methodical sophistication of Paris, Lagos thought herself capable of similar wonders. However, 'See Lagos and die' is both affirmatively celebratory and chillingly apocalyptic. It is at the same time an invitation to the marvellous possibilities of a complex city and premonition about its dark and deadly shadows. Many do see Lagos... and die!

There is always something about this gateway city to arouse the visitor's wonder: its breathless bridges and flyovers (old people still talk about the spectacular miracle of Carter Bridge, the first steel and mortar link between Lagos Island and its mainland); the thronged, dappled commerce on the Marina where virtually every trans-national company in the world possesses a jealously and Oyingbo whose awesome fame is enshrined in folksongs and proverbs, Eyo festival masquerade and the Nordic beard of Santa Claus... Complementing all this is the unique cosmopolitan prowess of Lagos, its ethnic, racial, and cultural heterogeneity, the pidginised, sometimes creolised discourse of its daily commerce.

Lagos may be no one's city because it is everyone's city, but it is far from being a melting pot. Ethnic and class tensions simmer under the blanket of cosmopolitan uniformity. There are golf clubs and social clubs where the privileged open sesame is still the colour of one's skin or one's money. In Lagos's vertical mosaic, the studied serenity of Ikoyi shares borders with the futuristic architecture of Victoria Island, both of which are several centuries and many bank accounts from Ajegunle, Mushin, and other slums where life is cheap and tortuous, where there is no practical alternative to violent criminality. Despite these jostling boulders, Lagos flows on like the infinity of its waters.

Those waters are, indeed, the core of its magic..., and might. We all know (only the uninitiated may pretend to a modicum of ignorance) that mermaids trade their fishy tails for legs upon merely stepping on beach sands, then saunter into the streets, charming, miraculously seductive. Young men stare in petrifying admiration, while their mothers apply the rein, ever so aware of the dangers of having fishes as daughter-in-laws. There are also sea spirits which spiral up from the depths at night, secure themselves in the saddle of waves, galloping beachwards, their bodies bathed in the silvery intensity of the half-moon. If you see them in the streets, clothed in white calico and crocodile skin slippers, their gait leisurely, their consonants more liquid than their vowels, do not wait to be told that the demons of the blessings! Sometimes Olokun, the sea goddess, herself plays games with fishermen, teases their nets with eels and water scorpions, then pats the bottom of their little boats. At the first light she romps to the beach, her hair sequinned in shells and shingles, her eyes like new-laid eggs, her breasts two magnificent mountains, her voice a shade between serene whisper and fishy echo. Lagosians know this by uncanny instinct: whoever catches Olokun's glimpse at this divine hour will live the rest of his or her life in boundless fortune. Which is why at dawn the beach never lacks throng of callers. Lagos is, indeed, the sea. The sea is Lagos. When Lagos recently lost its status as Nigeria's administrative capital, Lagosians were quick to ask: "If they take the capital from Lagos, can they take the sea?"

Without a regular nurture by fiction, fact soon pales out and dies. Lagos knows this though it is never so sure where fact ends and fiction takes over. In like manner, in the eyes and minds of rural dwellers Lagos's fact is as prodigious as its fiction. For them Lagos is both a dreamland and a radix malorum. Rural tales, songs, and proverbs are replete with the ambiguous possibilities of this city. It is a city whose streets are literally paved with gold (a myth whose embers were fanned into a blaze in the prodigal years of the oil boom): a city where everything happens, where anything can be found (if it is not available in Lagos, then you can't find it anywhere else in Nigeria).

This miracle city is also the home of fads and fashions, the barometer of social taste, sounding board for imported etiquettes. The weirdest, most extravagant manners exact a certain measure of toleration, even acceptability once people know that 'that is how they do it in Lagos'. Tailors, seamstresses, hair-dressers, brick-layers, carpenters, barbers, musicians, and suchlike sure that their bill-boards include the magic words: Trained in Lagos, or simply, Lagos-trained (two, three decades ago, the attention winner was Trained in London).

There is something constantly perplexing about Lagos to the sober consciousness of those far from its madding crowd. It is that city where people perpetually move in the fast lane, a place where fortunes are as rapidly made as marred, where a millionaire in the morning maybe swiftly done out of his wealth at noon, crawling, finally, into an ignoble grave with the setting sun. In the frugal thinking of rural folks, Lagos is the hell-hole of profligacy, where money earned by the left hand soon evaporates from the right. Hence Lagos is a-jo-mo-so-wo-ma-jo-mo-mo-wo-wa-le (a place which lets you make all your profits without allowing you to take any of them home). Hence the late highlife musician, Adeolu Akinsanya, exclaims in one of his songs: Inawo Eko le ju! (Lagos expenses are killing!). And it is a truism widely acknowledged that Owo Eko Eko lo ngbe (Money made in Lagos never leaves Lagos).

If Lagos is a fortune-wrecking, money-grobbling monster with a thousand mouths, the most ruthless, most insatiable of those mouths is Sisi Eko (Lagos Lady), that alluring, bewitched loafer whose job is the progressive dispossession of men. Heavily lipsticked, long-fingernailed, scantily clad, wig-headed, and stiletto-heeled, she is a practiced schemer with eyes buried deep in men's pockets. A highlife song in the early seventies drew inspiration from this pervasively negative representation of the Lagos woman: Sisi Eko: Lagos Lady Sisi Eko: Lagos Lady Oko fun e lowo o: Husband gave you money O fi je'ja dindin: You squandered it on fried fish (a delicacy) lwa yi o dara: This is abominable lwa yi o sunwon o: This is improper Ma se the ra re:

In this supremely patriarchal perspective, the woman is reduced to a part of Lagos problems. Sisi Eko is the ultimate in prodigal venality, a callous, calculating Jezebel with unmistakable affinities with the acquisitive amorality of Cyprian Ekwensi's Jagua Nana or the cash-and-carry cupidity of Ken Saro Wiwa's Madam de Madam.

Lagos is ready-made theatre complete with a largely motley cast, a highly flexible stage, a script constantly re-writing itself, with the Atlantic Ocean as cyclorama. The actors and actresses often constitute their own audience, laughing at their own jokes, crying over their own sorrows. To people not really familiar with its logic, the city might look like some nightmare in which people and things are constantly, listlessly rushing-to-mowhere. Although "ultra modern" supermarkets have sprung up in every street, we all know that in Lagoon City, everywhere is a market. At least the itinerant traders know this, jumping, shouting from car to car, thrusting their assorted wares at motorists glumly immobilised by the city's legendary "go slow" (traffic hold-up).

In one of her superbly engaging stories, Karen King-Aribisala has described this curious commerce as "a moving supermarket of concentrated chaos", but who doesn't know that to remove this chaos is to eliminate one of the most gripping scenes in Lagos's drama? In a land which recently discovered the mad logic of "marketforces", how else can the "parallel economy" sustain itself except through the trickle-down traffic of legislated anarchy?

Whether as a place or metaphor, dream or nightmare, Lagos has remained the source and catalyst of literacy imagination. Hardly is there any contemporary Nigerian literary work of note in which Lagos is not mentioned - or kept within a discernible connotative circumference. Odia Ofeimun laments the seamless agony of "Lagosed" souls; Gabriel Okara captures the frenzied supplication of the Aladura one significant night on Victoria Beach; while jagua Nana is Ekwensi's sexual-political exploration of Nigeria through Lagos. In The Interpreters, Wole Soyinka's iconoclastic young men negotiate their ways through the flare and flood of a baffling city; in end Lagos becomes a parable, a text which persistently interpretes its own interpreters.

Where Lagos is not the major setting, it often plays the role of a king maker whose power is in rivalry with that of the king. For example, in both Ake and Isara, Lagos looms inevitably large from the background: spawning ideas, dictating the pace of events, marshalling people, re-arranging places, making sure it is a lexical presence in the syntax of the political idiom. It is no narrative or historical surprise that both Daodu and the horse which bears him to the throne of Isara are "shipped" in from Lagos.

But there are works in which Lagos's centrality is more ambivalent. For instance, although Lagos provides the actual setting for No longer at Ease, the psychological and cultural centre of the narrative swings between there and Umuofia, the famous village where the protagonist's grandfather lived out the tragic drama of Things Fall Apart. Indeed, to members of the place to whose hazards and insecurities the union provides a strong communal antidote. There is that dream of the return home after a long sojourn in the city. Thus Lagos gives, but also takes. Its brittle, anonymous canvas is dotted with passionate rural mores.

Now let us pursue this exploration beyond the Nigerian borders. Generally, the city has always held a profound fascination for writers: Freetown for Syl Cheney-Coker Dakar for Ousmane Sembene; Soweto for Mbulelo Nzamane; Paris for Baudelaire; Berlin for Brecht; Madras for Narayan; Dublin for Joyce; Chicago for Richard Wright; Munich and Venice for Thomas Mann... In some cases the same city may spawn different, even contrasting images and modes of representation: compare, for instance, the satiric, excoriative exploration of London in Dicken's Bleak House with the sedate, stream-of-consciousness navigation of the same city in Virginia Woolf's Mrs Dalloway. Or let us go back to the early Romantic period and join William Blake's journey through London's "charter'd street", with all their "marks of weakness, marks of woe". In all these instances, far from being a mere backdrop, the city is an active strand in the narrative fabric, an indispensable trope in a gigantic text.

Lagos is suchlike text, only more baffling, more amorphous. Where else in the world would you find the beggar's song wafting so naturally into a soiree of juju, highlife, chachacha, reggae, calypso, etc. blaring forth from 1000-watt loudspeakers even in a business district street? Where else would you encounter the inventive ribaldry of the agbero (motor park tout), the chilling rat-a-tat of the robber's gun, the shoeless army of the jobless waving thumb-stained diplomas like expired tailsmans? And to make it divinely clear, this is a city where God goes by many names, though a deep nativist impulse sometimes tames the jealousy of imported gods. And yet the boundless energy of this city, its rugged vitality, its polyglot culture, its acres and acres of possibility. This city where everything happens sometimes without happening, where crowded roads terminate in Atlantic cul-de-sac, where the sojourner finds his fate by losing it. This city so sweet, so severely sour.

Newswatch is published at P.M.B. 21499 Ikeja, Nigeria Tel: 4960950 Fax: 962887 Telex: 27874


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995
