Africa News


March, 1995


GHANA - Document: Address by H.E. Flt. Lt. J. J. Rawlings (RTD), President of the Republic of Ghana, on the Occassion of a Dinner Hosted by the Corporate Councikl on Africa, Washington, DC


LENGTH: 2934 words


 

March 8, 1995

Mr. Chairman, Members of the Corporate Council on Africa, Distinguished Business Executives and Friends of Ghana, Ladies and Gentlemen,

It is indeed a pleasure to be here today. We bring you warm and fraternal greetings from the Government and people of Ghana. (We hope the warmth will begin to dispel the cold front!) I must thank the staff of the corporate C council on Africa and the many corporate sponsors of this event for this invitation. I would also like to express my gratitude to officials of the U.S. government for the warm reception accorded us and the excellent arrangements made for our stay here in Washington.

The very presence here of so many corporate executives demonstrate the confidence you have in the continent of Africa and specifically in our country, Ghana. This confidence is very well-placed because our continent has no other direction to go but forward. 

Africa, we all know, is a continent with the richest array of resources in the world; yet it remains the most underdeveloped and currently accounts for only two percent of world trade. We need to ask ourselves, why this is so. No continent has been as battered as the African continent - in the colonial era, in the struggle for independence, during the period of Cold War, and now post-Cold-War. Africa has often been assailed by external forces who have been attracted by its resources but only for their own one-sided interests. Africa was victimized during the colonial period by her raw materials and her human resources being exploited to build up value for other continents. More recently, during the period of Cold War, Africa has been victimized by super power rivalry which posed false choices for our leaders between competing political and economic poles without any specific reference to our circumstances on the continent.

Much of the condemnation of Africa, or the dismissiveness with which Africa is treated in certain quarters is unfair and unjust. The native American saying that you need to walk in my shoes to understand my existence is very appropriate for understanding Africa's situation.

We do accept responsibility for our own failures, and we in Ghana have decided firmly that we will not be a failure; we will uphold the image of Africa, we will show the world what is positive ad successful, what is noble and elevating from our continent. This giant of a continent is stirring itself up and I am confident that you put your faith, your commitments, you investments in Africa will not be disappointed!

In recent years, astute business people, for very good reasons, have been looking to the continent as a dynamic region to make sound new investments. There has come a realization that the continent not only has natural resources but also has a huge population whose tastes and demands can stimulate new phases of industrial development and economic boom in the world. Mining, for example, has always been big business in Africa, but now investors are looking to shift to more value-added production on the continent taking advantage of the lower labor costs. Agribusiness, utilities, the energy sector, manufacturing, financial and tourism services offer other opportunities. In the telecommunications field, the giants of the industry, from the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain and France are all making investments in a continent that is ripe for major new initiatives.

I acknowledge the fact that political stability and security of investment is of paramount importance to investors. And in this respect, the history of conflicts in certain regions and countries of Africa gives some investors pause. But as we get to the roots of these conflicts, we can clearly see that the economic development of the continent will contribute immensely to resolving many of these situations of conflict. Today, we in Ghana are proud that amidst the ocean of well-reported conflicts, there are islands of peace and political stability that offer themselves as havens for foreign investment. "One of such countries in Africa is Ghana." Those of you who have not visited Ghana recently, - or those who have not visited at all, do not know what you are missing!

Our many favourable attributes include: a stable political and social environment in which the safety of your persons, property and investment is assured; a determined and consistent government following a prudent and disciplined economic reconstruction program; a liberalized trade policy and exchange rate regime that has enabled a complete transformation of access to foreign exchange in the economy. With the number of for ex bureaus doing brisk business in the city of Accra, for instance, I understand it is easier to deal in foreign currency, especially travelers cheques, in Accra than it is here in Washington!

We also have a very well-endowed natural resource base that includes gold, diamonds, manganese, bauxite and other minerals, large tracts of arable land and climate that together create a good basis for agriculture and still under exploited sea resources; an environment of relatively cordial relations between labour and management; we seek to establish regular and close consultation between government, employers and labour unions under a tripartite negotiation mechanism. The workforce itself is relatively better educated than many places in the world, and quite skilled.

I should point our further that Ghana offers ready access to other regional and international markets, such as the 16-member 200 million people Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS), as well as access to the over half a billion people in the European Community Caribbean and Pacific, Lome Convention trading area, based on our most favoured nation status.

Most significant of all, Ghana boasts a warm, friendly, intelligent and honest people who are a delight to do business with.

We have made considerable efforts over the last decade to become, in the eyes of objective observers a role model for good performance and successful economic recovery.

Most of you here must have heard of the economic turn around that has occurred in Ghana since 1982. This was achieved through the design and implementation of an Economic Recovery Programme that enabled us to achieve steady growth of about 5 per cent per annum from the early 1980's, a period some refer to as Africa's "lost decade". Our key objective has been to stimulate productivity and encourage both foreign and local private investment, and ensure a prudent and effective harnessing of public resources.

Among the important priorities have been the restoration and maintenance of fiscal and monetary discipline, and the control of inflation. We succeeded in bringing inflation from nearly 130% per annum in the early 1980s to less than 30% per annum today. Meanwhile, domestic savings and investments have increased by 12% and 14% per annum respectively in recent years. We are by no means satisfied with these figures. Inflation has to go down much further so as to make life more comfortable for the man and woman in the street, and we are currently focusing on how to ensure this.

Other priorities of our economic recovery program include the rationalization of the public sector by way of divestiture of over 300 state-owned enterprises (SOEs) and the trimming down of the over-bloated civil service by about 60%.

The government has concentrated public investment expenditure on infrastructure rehabilitation, which has brought many urban and feeder roads up to acceptable modern standards. Similarly, transport and communications infrastructure - our telephone systems which are so important for business people, our ports and harbours, - have all undergone a transformation in recent years. The National Electrification Scheme to extend electricity to all parts of the country is very much on course. The extent of commitment of communities throughout the country to contribute to bringing this important benefit to themselves has been remarkable. To meet the rapidly growing demand for electricity that our economic recovery programme has stimulated we are now encouraging independent power producers to get involved in energy production.

All of the above reform measures have had the effect of making both the rural and urban areas of Ghana good sites for a wide variety of investments.

Ladies and Gentlemen,

Ghana's economic progress has been reinforced by the successful political transition to multiparty democracy and constitutional rule. We established a new constitutional order from January 1993 after Presidential and Parliamentary elections. There has been quite an exuberant testing of the new Constitutional order. Some have even tried to provoke situations of anarchy under the guise of freedom, but as a Government we have not been unduly prickly about even some excesses, though we will not countenance a reversal of the gains we have made. The Judiciary has been eager to assert its independence and operates unrestrained. All this is an eloquent pointer to the tolerance, degree of understanding, and the willingness and determination of the government and people to succeed in fulfilling our national aspiration of prosperity in freedom and with justice.

Our efforts at establishing democratic institutions included a conscious policy of decentralizing political power and public administration. This has led to the establishment of 110 District Assemblies through which the local communities now have the authority to initiate and implement development programs that meet their own defined material and cultural needs.

Ladies and Gentlemen, I recently signed into law a new Ghana Investment Promotion Centre Act 1994 that was passed by Parliament. This Law, unlike the old Code, mandates the Ghana Investment Promotion Centre to promote, rather than regulate, investment. Copies of the Law, setting out the incentives and concessions to both domestic and foreign investors, can be obtained through our Embassy here.

The new Law obviates the need for new enterprises to go through long bureaucratic approval processes. An investor only need register or incorporate the enterprise in accordance with the Ghana Companies Code 1963 (Act 179). Incentives and concessions are triggered automatically and do not require separate application and approval. Incentives under the new Law include: full exemption from Customs import duties on plant machinery and equipment required for the setting up of the enterprise; accelerated depreciation; guaranteed transferability of profits, dividends, royalties, director's fees and capital in the event of liquidation of an enterprise; guarantees against expropriation of the enterprise; guarantees against being forced to cede any part of an investor's interest in the enterprise and a framework for settlement of investment disputes.

Ghana, as most of you know, is a member of the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) of the World Bank Group. As such, investors can benefit from the insurance and guarantee services provided for projects in member countries of the World Bank. The Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) of the United States is also very willing to provide investment guarantees for American investors going to Ghana.

Ladies and Gentlemen, Friends of Ghana,

I am happy to see so many faces in this audience who represent U.S. companies that are already contributing to Ghana's economy. We applaud you. But I will be even happier if by the end of my visit, we have an even greater number of companies heading for Ghana and more investments flowing in.

It should not surprise to hear that The Ghana Stock Exchange has recently been marked amongst the best of emerging stock markets in terms of performance and capital appreciation. When the New York Times in April 1994 recommended five major African Stock Exchanges on which American investors might invest, the newspaper placed the Ghana Stock Exchange at the top of the list. With more than 70 percent in annual average stock appreciation in 1993 and also in 1994, the stock market in Ghana, though young, is already providing an attractive framework for foreign investors to participate in Ghana's economic transformation. With a current market capitalisation of US $1.8 billion, it also the 3rd largest sub-Saharan Stock Exchange.

It was on this Stock Exchange as well as on the London Stock Exchange that last year some of Government's shares in a major national asset, the Ashanti Goldfields Corporation, were floated. The success of that floatation is still being talked about and I am happy to have in my delegation here the Chief Executive of Ashanti Goldfields, Mr. Sam Jonah. It was also on the Ghana Stock Exchange that the Government sold its shares in some multinational companies to foreign partners like Unilever. I am also happy to have in my delegation the Chairman of Unilever Ghana, Mr. Ishmael Yamson.

The involvement of such stalwarts of the private sector in my team here is a manifestation of the close relations we are forging between Government and the private sector in Ghana. Our Chambers of Commerce and Mines, the Association of Ghana Industries, the Ghana Employers Association, Private Enterprise Foundation are all key players in our march towards a better future.

Ladies and Gentlemen,

I deemed it important to find time to address you during my rather short stay here in deference to the statement attributed to President Calvin Coolidge that : "The business in an increasingly competitive global market place requires you to be open to new opportunities, to seek, in the best American tradition, new frontiers to conquer. Africa, we are told, is the last unconquered frontier for business, and we hope many of you here will participate in this challenge of African economic development, specifically in Ghana.

Ghana has a bright future. That future depends not only on sound and stable government policy in a peaceful environment but also on a larger role for the creativity of the private sector. That future must involve the foreign business community, particularly the American business community, particularly the American business community. I may add that there are important links between the activities of U.S. governmental agencies and private business. The aid programmes of USAID for instance create opportunities for U.S. trade and investment to follow up on. We have been very satisfied with the assistance USAID is providing us, among other things to help our export drive. We are also hopeful that U.S. governmental initiatives such as the Shipbuilding Initiative under the Maritime Administration of the Department of Transportation, the opening up of new markets by the Commerce Department and the availability of export credit lines of US Eximbank will all contribute to strengthening economic relations between the U.S. and Ghana. We, the Government of Ghana, are keeping our side of the bargain. We call on you, the American business community, to rise up to your part.

Thank you


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March, 1995


THE GAMBIA: I Am Disappointed: As International Community Fails to Come to His Rescue, Sir Dawda Blames U. S. For Its Lukewarm Attitude


LENGTH: 840 words


 

The Daily Observer (Banjul)

February 21, 1995

by Cherno Baba Jallow

In an exclusive interview with Ron Mcgullagh and Elizabeth Ground, who were recently in The Gambia to do a BBC sponsored documentary on The Gambia's current political situation, Sir Dawda singled out the U.S. Administration for its posture towards the "lack of strong defense and human rights in The Gambia."

Sir Dawda contended that the United States, which really believes in democracy and human rights, and now the sole super power leading the new international order "should study the Gambian situation and do something about it."

On allegations that The Gambia under his leadership saw unbridled corruption in government circles, Sir Dawda vehemently denied that corruption was ever rampant during his tenure of office. 

"I mean, for me to say that no one was corrupt or that no corruption had been perpetrated in The Gambia would be wrong or foolish," Sir Dawda said.

However, he argued that no country remains free of corruption, but maintained that The Gambia is one of those countries that knows little or no corruption at all.

"The Gambia, " Sir Dawda said, "has very few resources; but because of good management, financial and fiscal discipline in my government, we were able to make a success where most other countries have failed."

He said that corruption has often been one of the often repeated justification for the military in Africa to seize power from civilian governments.

"But invariably, they immediately embark upon corrupt practices, and this has happened in The Gambia within this short space of military rule," Sir Dawda alleged.

On the British travel advice against British tourists visiting The Gambia for its 'political instability', Sir Dawda believed that is 'quite reasonable'.

"Few months after the July 22nd coup," he said, "there had been a counter coup resulting in the loss of lives of 50 to 60 people." He added that in a situation like this, "it would be foolhardy to think that the situation in The Gambia is stable. "

Commenting on the economy and general welfare of Gambians under the military regime, Sir Dawda lamented that The Gambia's economy is "on the verge of disaster" because business activity, vis-a vis importation and re-exportation of goods that had been the country's good source of revenue, were being strangled under choking circumstances. He also said the tourist industry had been dealt a devastating blow.

"Because of mismanagement of this present military regime," Sir Dawda alleged, "the economy has started to suffer, and the living conditions of Gambians are becoming much more deplorable."

He argued, with some pride, that The Gambia under his leadership, had performed plausibly well in the economic sector. "We had undergone one of the most successful structural adjustment programmes with the IMF and World Bank," he said.

He added that his government had achieved an average of four per cent growth per annum; and "we were going to double this in the Gateway Project beginning in 1994."

On any clandestine motives to engineer a counter coup against the AFPRC Government, Sir Dawda replied that he wouldn't, but would "encourage Gambians to stand up and say they do not accept the overthrow of a democratic government by unaccountable military people who have no experience..."

He called on the Gambian people as well as the international community to denounce the military Government. "Having taken power, they would now perpetuate themselves in power and manipulate the people and the country," Sir Dawda bitterly complained.

Daily Observer is published at P.M.B. 131 Banjul The Gambia Tel: (220) 496608. Fax: (220) 496878


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


98 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


THE GAMBIA: Dr. Nyang Speaks On The Political Situation In The Gambia


LENGTH: 2080 words


 

The Observer (Banjul)

March 21, 1995

by Fatou Jahumpa Ceesay

Recently, the deposed Gambian president, Sir Dawda Jawara, visited the United States, where he held series of meetings with U.S. government officials and the Gambian community, in a bid to drum up their support for his restoration to the presidency. Among the groups Sir Dawda approached for support was the Pro-Democracy Movement which is a Gambian-initiated democracy movement based in Washington.

Our reporter, Fatou Jahumpa Ceesay, who was on a working visit to the U.S. at the time, had an exclusive interview with Dr. Sulayman Nyang, the convener of the movement and a top professor at Howard University. Below are the excerpts of the interview.

FJC: To begin with, what is your opinion about the current political situation in The Gambia? 

NYANG: Well, when you observed the situation in The Gambia you have to g back to the prelude of what had happened. The situation deteriorated so badly that the only corrective was possibly only through military intervention. Personally, I don't like military intervention. I would prefer to have a civilian democratic society. Actually, the situation as it exists now involves the need to a democratic order as soon as possible. Of course there is the need to set up a commission of inquiry to look into the deeds of the past. A democratic order cannot be restored with all the defects of the past. As a matter of fact I am proudly concerned about the current political trend in The Gambia which compelled me to convene at Howard University a meeting for a group of Gambian intellectuals and professionals to study the situation in the country. They are, for one, emotionally attached to The Gambia and they have the intellectual gadgets to help them analyse critically the goings-on in The Gambia.

I expect them to be able to heat the Gambian issue with candour and without any feeling of bias. We did not agree with all the points raised but I would say all the points raised but I would say we had a fruitful discussion since we raised critical questions. The National Consultative Committee have, nonetheless, come up with a finding which is relieving for anybody with serious concern for The Gambia.

FJC: Have you current knowledge about economic situation in The Gambia especially after the dawn of sanctions by Britain, the EU and the United States?

NYANG: Well, the British and American authorities who decided to sever economic relations with The Gambia were merely enacting a policy guideline. For example, the United States Department was instructed not to deal with governments of militaristic nature. The figures I have on the Gambian economy are from sources here in the city and they reflect the performance for 1995 which is expected to be minus four which would be very bad. Now we hope things would reverse half way through the next year. Another thing is the reserve and the figures I receive to this effect are not bad but it would be problematic if the trying trend continues. Once The Gambia can attract the British, Americans and the EU back with economic assistance through genuine projects of development, we may see a trend suggesting otherwise. It would be bad if they refuse to come forward and the current Government may be forced to dip into the reserves and this would certainly be unfavourable for the country. Based on information available to me, the military Government have been able to finance five to six months of import but if this continues uncomplicated by donors, there could be national bankruptcy.

We hope that the donors will be sufficiently impressed by the performance of the transition Government now headed by Captain Jammeh. I think the Government has the responsibility in allaying the fears of the average Gambian about the issue of restoring democracy. They must also make it clear to donors that they are concerned about relationship between economic performance and political stability.

FJC: How would you asses former party leaders (opposition) operating in their capacities as private individuals on holidays?

NYANG: Nothing should prevent them from using their pen to write in the media expressing their views. Some of the weaknesses of the former regime are familiar with them so they have every reason to make themselves heard. I even think people were linked with the PPP and are sincere enough should contribute to this political change since they are in a better position to decry the weaknesses of the former regime.

FJC: I learnt that the deposed President Sir Dawda Jawara was here in the U.S. and visited Atlanta, Georgia and Washington DC, can you tell me if you indeed met him?

NYANG: No I didn't, I was contacted by him (Jawara) before he came here through the telephone three times from London, apparently he had the news that a group of Gambians had met and decided to address some of the problems facing the country. I told him during our dialogue that the old regime under him did not do any serious intellectual defense of democracy. That was an important point Jawara will even remember. He was entertaining hopes that when he comes here he will get the chance of meeting us but unfortunately it didn't happen and there were a number of reasons why that didn't happen. Nonetheless, he met with the Gambian community in Atlanta but he didn't meet with the Gambian community in Washington DC.

FJC: Do you know if he was able to see officials at the State Department or any American authority?

NYANG: Yes,... I mean that is what the Washington Times article I referred to earlier brought to our attention.

FJC: Whom did he meet at the State Department?

NYANG: We were informed by the paper (Washington Times) that he met the assistant secretary of state for African Affairs, George Moose, and of course based on the article, Mr. Moose felt that Jawara deserved support. I think that article must have been reproduced in one of the Gambian newspapers, (N.B. The American embassy in Banjul said the article under reference misquoted George Moose).

FJC: Do you think Jawara should be campaigning to restore himself?

NYANG: Well one of the reasons why I wanted to have a direct meeting with Sir Dawda was to raise this issue with him. It is really correct to say what Jawara has been in the helm of state affairs for 30 years; in fact he was there for 33 in view of his pre-independence position as prime minister.

I give him credit for the good he has done the state, but in light of present revelations by the commissions of inquiry his overall record in office is quite unimpressive and undeserving to the state. The only sensible approach he can make if he wants to be recalled somewhat favourably by historians and posterity is to push for restoration of democratic rule without him. This may build upon his past image as a democrat. Though I don't know the extent, but I know that people are bitter about his misdeeds from what I could gather in telephone conversations with people in The Gambia. Certainly people are not happy with the administration of the former regime which he headed for so long.

FJC: How would you describe the result of this trip to America?

NYANG: I am not in a position to make any kind of evaluation on his trip, but based on the Washington Times Jawara left U.S. with the hope that somehow the U.S. government is going to pressurise the military government in Banjul through sanctions to step down unconditionally. Of course, in an article, Jawara tried to strike a compassion between his case and Aristides'. Now whether he will go to The Gambia I am not in a position to tell. His return to The Gambia is sure to exact a high prize in human lives. This would be reminiscent of Senegal's Intervention in 1998 in order to quash Kukoi Samba Sanyang and his supporters.

FJC: I understand that there is an AFPRC delegation in the US. They have in fact attended social functions organised by the Gambian community here in Washington. Can you comment on whether they are here to meet your committee?

NYANG: The group (committee) is supposed to meet them later this evening but I am not in a position now to ascertain their concerns and aims since we have to listen to them first to know what they need. We may want to know, however, how far they can work with our movement and how they would react to certain suggestions a pro-democracy movement is willing to put forward to them. There are some points, though, which I think are very critical in terms of dialogue. These rather young military officers should set precedence not for Africa but for The Gambia by recognising the need to return to barracks and prevent the Gambian nation from retrogressing.

FJC: Captain Yahya Jammeh, most people believe, is very popular following the failure of an attempted counter coup by Sana Sabally and Sadibou Hydara. He has been urging Gambians like you abroad to go back home and take part in the process of national rectification and development. Do you think you would ever answer to his call?

NYANG: Yeah, well, I have realised that a lot of Gambians have been putting pressure on me to return and offer services to the people but I think there is a lot of Gambians who are really competent and available at home to contribute effectively to the national effort. Some of them are doing fairly well there so there is no pressing reason to go back now. In fact we can help them from here.

FJC: Recently I came across an obituary you wrote for the late Garba Jahumpa in the West Africa magazine. Can you expatiate on that?

NYANG: I decided to write the obituary for a number of reasons one of which was that I.M. Garba Jahumpa was one of the few consistent personalities of our time who have contributed healthily to socio-economic and political development in The Gambia. In fact he deserves a book of tribute to recognise his contribution to The Gambia's development for over 50 years. He was a considerate and forthright man that we sadly miss. I hope his children will continue his impressive traits... so that what we need, continuity, that is the problem in Gambian families. Yeah, Jawara was the president, but he didn't contribute as much effectively to civic society as Jahumpa. That's a fact.

The Daily Observer is published at P.M.B. 131,.Banjul, The Gambia Tel. (220) 490608 Fax: (220) 496878


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

99 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


THE GAMBIA: CAF Talks Government Association Relationship


LENGTH: 454 words


 

The Daily Observer (Banjul)

February 14, 1995

The Confederation of African Football (CAF), the continent's football governing body, has issued a statement to all national football associations affiliated to it on the issue of "Interference of governments in the life of the national associations."

According to the release by CAF, the world football governing body FIFA had both at its 1992 congress in Zurich and 1994 in Chicago, took a decision prohibiting governments from mixing with the activities of national football associations.

As a logical consequence of this provision, FIFA will only recognise the national associations which are democratically elected. According to Article 7 of the FIFA statutes, the executive body of an association shall be appointed only by means of election within that association. The statutes of an association shall provide for an election procedure that guarantees the complete independence of the electorate. 

It also states that FIFA will not recognise all the executive body of an association, even on an interim basis, if it has not been appointed in accordance with the stipulated rule.

Also, any decision taken by an outside body to suspend an association's executive body shall not be binding on the Federation.

The FIFA statues also said that leagues or any other groups of clubs at association level shall be permitted with the association's express consent and shall define the powers appointed to any group as well as its right and obligations. The regulations of any such group shall be subject to the approval of the association.

The statement from CAF concluded by calling on national associations wishing to clarify their relationship with the public power and to preserve their autonomy, to amend their statutes to cope with the new situation as these statutes will be the only document which governs football in the national association.

The Daily Observer is published at P.M.B. 131,.Banjul, The Gambia Tel. (220) 490608 Fax: (220) 496878


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


100 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


SECTION: BURUNDI Up to 50,000 Refugees Flee Burundi


LENGTH: 574 words


 

RI Bulletin (Washington, DC)

March 31, 1995

As many as 50,000 Rwandan refugees are fleeing towards the Tanzanian border form camps where they were housed in Burundi. Relief officials estimate that potentially 100,000 people may head towards Tanzania in the next few days. Fear among refugees has resulted from an attack on one of several Rwanda camps in northern Burundi in which 12 Rwandan refugees were killed and 22 wounded. These migrations have occurred following violence in several quarters in Bujumbura over the pasty days by armed militias which led to the deaths of at least 150 people, left some homes burned and provoked the departure of several thousand people from their homes, some dispersing in Burundi and some seeking refuge in Zaire. 

Currently, there are approximately 500 refugees waiting to be allowed to cross into Tanzania near the Kobero Bridge. The United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) is monitoring the border situation and distributing water to the refugees who have carried some food supplies with them. A few hundred are said to have decided now to remain in Burundi. The High Commissioner for Refugees, Sadako Ogata, has called on governments to honor their international commitments to allow refugees to seek asylum. Because the journey takes two to three days, the vast majority of refugees have not yet reached the border.

The departure of the dependents of U. S. and European nationals has added to the level of fear. Staff of international relief agencies in Burundi are sending a clear message that they are not planning to depart. The UNHCR is reportedly increasing its presence in Burundi to reassure the population.

Refugees International urges the following:

UNHCR and international donors must "insist" that the governments of Tanzania and Zaire continue to uphold the internationally accepted right to asylum

In turn, the donor community should be actively engaged in identifying ways to meet the needs of this emergency, assisting the already heavily burdened asylum countries to cope with these additional demands.

Contingency planning must include the provision of adequate water and food.

Donors must insure that the World Food Program receives pledges for future months to insure that minimum requirements are met.

Ration levels should be equalized to prevent food inequalities form contributing to the insecurity in the region.

The UN Security Council should remain ready to promptly respond to requests from the Government of Burundi.

Refugees International, 21 DuPont Circle,. NW, Washington, DC 20036. Tel: (202) 828-0110. Fax: (202) 828-0819


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


101 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


BURUNDI: $100 Million Pledged for Food -- Much More Needed


LENGTH: 440 words


 

RI Bulletin (Washington, DC)

March 31, 1995

Refugees International commends the prompt and generous support of the United States to the potentially tragic and destabilizing shortage of food available for refugees and displaced persons in Central Africa.

An emergency fundraising campaign by the World Food Program (WFP) and the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), vigorously supported by Refugees International, resulted in approximately $100 million in new contributions to fight hunger among refugees and internally displaced persons from Rwanda and Burundi, including those in camps in Zaire and Tanzania. 

Refugees International appreciates the rapid response of donor countries to the fundraising campaign. According to the UN agencies, ten countries have contributed an additional 100.5 million dollars for the emergency program. The U.S. contributed $47 million. European contributions account for the balance.

"The prompt and generous response of the United States was the essential catalyst of the response of other donors," said Refugees International President Lionel Rosenblatt..

"Unfortunately," he added, "the job is only half-done. This additional $100 million will only last until October or November 1995. Without more food in the pipeline by then, millions of refugees and displaced persons from Rwanda and Burundi will face cuts in food aid that will be fatal to both their long-term survival and to the fragile efforts to stabilize the region."

"Next steps include a continued appeal to potential donors, including countries which have not yet contributed to the emergency fund. The United States can now speak forcefully and authoritatively to such potential contributors because we have acted so forcefully ourselves."

WFP, for its part, is reducing operational costs for the delivery and distribution of the food. These include making improvements in infrastructure and transportation.

Refugees International, 21 DuPont Circle,. NW, Washington, DC 20036. Tel: (202) 828-0110. Fax: (202) 828-0819


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

102 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March, 1995


Letter to HIs Excellency General Sani Abacha


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 960 words


 

March 13, 1995

His Excellency General Sani Abacha

Head of State of Nigeria

Abuja, Nigeria

Dear General Abacha:

In the months since the Nigerian military's annulment of the democratic presidential election of June f1993, the Nigerian government has become an absolute military dictatorship. Unfounded treason charges have been brought against the presumed winner of the election. Critics of the military regime have been killed. Hundreds more have been arbitrarily detained. the national and state legislatures have been disbanded. Labor unions have been dissolved. Elected civilian governors have been removed from office. All political activity have been banned. The country's once free press has been shut down. And owing to gross mismanagement and corruption, Nigeria's economy now borders on collapse. lamentably, Nigerian courts have lost any authority to review military decrees. 

As the world struggles in the general direction of democratic reform and reconciliation, Nigeria, to determine of its people and indeed to all of Africa, is moving painfully on an opposite course. We are deeply saddened. We beseech you to expedite the restoration of democracy to Nigeria's 100 million people who yearn for it. To do less will result in incalculable damage to Africa's most populous nation and eventual global economic and political isolation of your regime.

Sincerely,

John Hurst Adams, Senior Bishop African Methodist Episcopal Church; Maya Angelou, Author; The Hon. Richard Arrington, Jr., Mayor of Birmingham, Alabama; Willie L. Baker, Jr. International Vice President United Food and Commercial Workers' Union; Dr. Mary Frances Berry, Chairperson, US Commission on Civil Rights; The Hon. Sanford Bishop, US House of Representatives; The Hon. Corrine Brown, US House of Representatives; The Hon. Willie L. Brown, Jr., Speaker of the Assembly, State of California; The Hon. William L. John Conyers, Jr. US House of Representatives; Ossie Davis, Actor; Ruby Dee, Actress; The Hon. Julian C.Dixon, US House of Representatives; Vivian Lowery-Derryck, President, African American Institute; The Hon. Chaka Fattah, US House of Representatives; The Hon. Cleo Fields, US House of Representatives; Roberta Flack, Singer and Songwriter; Henry Louis Gates, Professor, Harvard University; Danny Glover, Actor; Donna B. Guillaume, Television Producer; Robert Guillaume, Actor; Bryant Gumbel, Host of The NBC Today Show; The Hon. Alec Hastings, US House of Representatives; The Hon. Richard Gordon Hatcher, Law Professor, Indiana University; Ulrich Haynes, Former Ambassador to Algeria; The Hon. A. 103 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


Education


LENGTH: 870 words


 

The Centre for Indigenous Plant Use Research at the University of Natal in Durban, South Africa is launching a research program to establish a management plan for indigenous plant use within the Biosphere Reserve in the Maputaland Region of KawZulu-Natal. A post-graduate scholarship funded by the Foundation for Research Development is available for students to be undertaken at the doctoral level, but prospective students interested in masters study will also be considered. Accommodations and transportation as well as living expenses will be provided. Contact Bruce Page at the Centre for Indigenous Plant Use Research, Department of Biology, University of Natal, Private Bag X10, Dalbridge, Durban, South Africa. E-mail: page@biology.und.ac.za.

The Visiting Scholar Program of the Institute for Research on Women in New Jersey is accepting applications for its Spring 1996 schedule. The program is open to postdoctoral scholars in any discipline. Visiting scholars have the following privileges: access to libraries and recreational facilities, office space, and participation in the Institute's fortnightly seminar, "Towards 2000." Interested parties should send the following requirements: letter of intent, curriculum vitae, a description of project to be done (five pages maximum), two letters of reference. Mail to Institute for Research on Women, Douglas Campus, 27 Clifton Avenue, PO Box 270, New Brunswick, NJ 08903-0270. Phone: (908) 932-9072. Fax: (908) 932-1180.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


104 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


Resources


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

On April 8, 1995, in Montreal, Canada, Mr. Amadou Diop, Director of The Rodale Institute Senegal received the Grand Prize of Excellence for the Senegal program's contribution to the African Cause in the Category of Development Aid. There were 2500 organizations nominated all throughout Africa.

This was the first year for the International Center of the African Cause in Montreal to hold this event.

This award comes at an appropriate time as the Rodale Institute Senegal Team is working very hard to become its own independent organization. 

The U.S. Committee for UNICEF, the United Nations Children's Fund, will join UNICEF and the Organization for African Unity in commemorating the fifth annual Day of the African Child on June 16 to advocate for greater resources and public attention for Africa. As violence poses one of the greatest threats to African children, this year's Day of the African Child campaign will explore the theme of children in armed conflict.

"The 1995 Day of the African Child commemoration gives us the opportunity to draw attention to extraordinary challenges facing African children," stated Dr. Gwendolyn Calvert Baker, president and chief executive officer of the U.S. Committee for UNICEF. "The U.S. Committee for UNICEF will work vigorously in its education, advocacy, and fundraising initiatives to ensure the survival, protection, and development of Africa's children and for children worldwide."

"Children in Armed Conflict"

The tragedy in Rwanda can be used as a benchmark from which to measure the impact of armed conflict on children. A study commissioned by UNICEF found that even a month after Rwandan children witnessed the bloody coup in their country, they were severely traumatized by what they experienced. Seventy-five percent of the children interviewed in the UNICEF study had seen firsthand someone being killed, over half had seen a family member killed, and most had witnessed mass killings in schools, churches, and other areas. Eighty percent of the children at some point had also feared for their own lives.

Overall, there has been a rise in the number of conflict situations around the world. UNICEF finds that 80 percent of casualties from armed conflicts are civilians, mostly women and children. In the past decade, approximately two million children have been killed in armed conflicts, about 12 million have been left homeless, and more than one million have been orphaned.

In many cases, children are not only victims as civilians, but also as soldiers. In Liberia, Somalia, and the Sudan, children as young as 10 years old are said to be familiar with the use of weapons. IN some areas 11-year-old boys have been conscripted or coerced into military training.

"The Fifth Year of Advocacy and Celebration"

As in previous years, the U.S. Committee for UNICEF and UNICEF-- with the support of religious and civic groups and non-governmental organizations-- will coordinate a variety of week-long cultural and educational programs culminating in United Nations reception on the evening of June 16. Many of the activities are open to the public and target children as well as adults.

Among the activities planned for this year's Day of the African Child are a children's event at the United Nations to help educate U.S. schoolchildren about Africa's rich cultural heritage; an interfaith service on the morning of June 16; and a gala event where the U.S. Committee for UNICEF will present the Africa's Future Award to a prominent individual who has demonstrated a strong commitment to African and African-American children.

"How to Get Involved"

Individuals, groups, and business are encouraged to support the Day of the African Child by contributing to the U.S. Committee for UNICEF's Day of the African Child fund, currently supporting emergency and long-term development programs throughout the continent. The U.S. Committee is also accepting donations earmarked for relief efforts in Rwanda, Somalia, Zambia, Mozambique, Namibia, Nigeria, Liberia, and Angola.

In addition, the Audrey Hepburn Fund, established in honor of the late actress and beloved UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador, promotes education initiatives for children in Somalia, Ethiopia, and Sudan. For more information on how to participate in the Day of the African Child or to make a contribution, call 1-800-For-KIDS, or contact the U.S. Committee for UNICEF at 333 East 38th St., New York, NY 10016, (212) 686-5522.

Hofstra Cultural Center announces a call for papers for Africa 2000, an interdisciplinary conference examining the situation of Africa in the year 2000 and the decade thereafter. Papers should focus on or emphasize the immediate future faced by the continent. Any discussion that increases an understanding of Africa's next decade and a half are welcome. Papers are invited on such diverse topics as African Americans and Africa; the African Diaspora; ethnic relations; medical geography; multinational corporations; public health; popular culture; single and multiparty states; urbanization; and women in Africa. Previously presented or published material should not be submitted. The conference will feature keynote speaker Chinua Achebe. DEADLINE: MARCH 15, 1995, for final papers (in duplicate), one-page abstract, and curriculum vitae. Contact: Athelene A. Collins, Hofstra University, Hampstead, NY 11550-1090, phone 516/ 564-4306.

Helen Suzman, longtime anti-apartheid campaigner has been awarded the 1994 Notre Dame Award for international humanitarian service. The $10,000 award is presented annually by the University of Notre Dame to persons who exhibit uncommon virtue in the fight for justice.

The CSSALL Newsletter, from the Centre for the Study of Southern African Literature and Languages, University of Durban-Westville, is distributed in bother printed form and on the Internet, under the Usenet newsgroups: za.events and soc.cultures.south-africa, starting with No. 1/1 (1994). Contact: Johannes Smit, CSSALL Newsletter, University of Durban-Westville, Pvt. Bag X54001, Durban 4000. E-mail: jasmit@pixie.udw.ac.za

April, 1995


Announcements


LENGTH: 760 words


 

April 13-15, 1995 Michigan State University's Comparative Black History program will host the COMPARATIVE HISTORY OF BLACKS IN THE DIASPORA SYMPOSIUM. The symposium will focus on new developments in the fields of African American, Latin American, Caribbean, U.S. Southern, and African history. The themes for the symposium are: Comparative Methods and Perspectives and the Black Diaspora; Comparative Slavery and Slave Society; and Freedom and Inequality in Comparative Perspective. Contact: Dr. Darlene Hine, History Department, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, phone 517/ 432-4933, or Dr. David Barry Gaspar, History Department, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, phone 919/684-2109.

Proceedings will be published in print, audio and video. The Center for African Studies at the University of Florida is soliciting presenters for the annual teachers' workshop. Prsentations are sought which relate to teaching about Africa in K-12 classrooms, including curriculum development, classroom activities, resource selection, innovative ways of teaching about Africa, adn other topics which may be informative and interesting to teachers. Contact: Agnes Leslie, Outreach Director, Center for African Studies, 427 Grinter Hall, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611. Phone: (904) 392-2187. Fax: (904) 392-2435.

108 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


Upcoming Events


SECTION: CALENDAR


LENGTH: 600 words


 

April 2-5, 1995 Durham, NC -- Conference, U.S.-Africa Trade and Investments Promotion Conference/Exhibits Contact: Secretary/Treasurer, US/Africa Trade Alliance, Box 51636, Durham, NC 27717. Tel: (919) 560-6020 or (919) 493-8935

Contact: World Hunger Program, Box 1831, Brown University, Providence, RI 02912, Attn: Hunger Briefing. Fax: (401) 863-2191. 

April 6-8. 1995 Pittsburgh, PA - Conference, "Black Popular Culture in Africa, USA and the Caribbean," an international conference at the University of Pittsburgh. Contact: Joseph Adjaye, Africana Studies Department, University of Pittsburgh, 3T01 Forbes Quadrangle, Pittsburgh, PA 15260. Tel: (412) 648-7544. Fac: (412) 648-7214.

April 6-9, 1995 New York, NY -- Conference, "Silver & Gold: Bridges to the Future," sponsored by the American Forum for Global Education, the United Nations Association of the USA and the Greater New York Chapter of the Fulbright Alumni Association. Contact: American Forum for Global Education, 120 Wall Street, Suite 2600, New York, NY 10005 Tel: (212) 742-8232, Fax: (212) 742-8752; E-mail: globed@IGC.ORG

April 7-8. 1995 New York, NY -- Conference, "Women and Change in South Africa." Contact: Office of Continuing Professional Education, Teachers College, Columbia University, Box 132, 525 West 120th Street, New York, NY 10026. Tel: (212) 678-3987. Fax: (212) 678-4048.

Contact: CBH Symposium Office, MSU History Department, East Lansing, MI 48824, Tel: (517) 432-4933 or 2382

109 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


UCLA Fowler Museum of Cultural History Presents Exhibition, "Coiffure Moderne: A Gallery of African Hairstyles, 1970-1990"


LENGTH: 1307 words


 

UCLA Public Information Office (Los Angeles)

March, 1995

Lively, contemporary, painted African hairdressing signs from Gabon, Ghana, Kenya and Cote d'Ivoire comprise the exhibition, "Coiffure Moderne: A Gallery of African Hairstyles, 1970-1990," at the UCLA Fowler Museum of Cultural History in The William Goldenberg Galleria which continues through July 16.

Approximately 50 painted, wooden signs vibrantly depict the latest hair fashions for men and women, combining concepts of art, culture and advertising in exuberant, eye-catching compositions. On one level, this selection of signs offers a varied study in the elegant, and often elaborate, arts of African hairstyling. In addition, the signs are themselves visually compelling works of art. Designed to attract patrons, the signs express contemporary ideals of fashion and status and reflect cultural aspirations and global influences. 

The works were created by artists from four major cities-- Liberville, Gabon; Kumase, Ghana; Nairobi, Kenya; and Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire-- for display outside barber shops, hair salons o haircutting stands. Painted in bright colors and varying greatly in style, the signs often feature several distinctly coiffured heads accompanied by catchy names such as "Top Style," "Zoulou Boy (Zulu)," "American Coiffure," or "Diplomatic Haircut." Many of these signs are rendered in a playful, quirky manner; others are realized with straightforward, simple strokes; still others are painted with a graceful, almost tender, kind of realism.

Aesthetic value aside, these hairdressing signs are not just works of art-- this is art at work. For example, the dignified "Mandela" haircut, a reference to South African leader Nelson Mandela, appears on a sign painted by the acclaimed Abidjan-based artist Joel. Progressive, urban women are recognized as an economic force; one sign features the "Student Cut," a no-nonsense hairstyle worn by a serious-looking young woman. The sleek "Boeing 707" haircut depicted on a sign from an artists' workshop in Kumase, Alpha and Omega Art Works, refers to a newer, a foreign culture of high-speed travel. Several other signs suggest faraway destinations and international enterprise with haircuts called "Paris Dakar," "Italian Draft" or the "Cincinnati Zip."

The exhibition also demonstrates just how global style and media have become and how current trends--mainly American--are integrated by these urban artists. Several signs identify styles using famous or terms, such as "Grace Jonnes (Jones)," "RFK" and "House Party," among others. In these works, there is a strong emphasis on African and African-American cultural heroes or entertainment figures, including mentions of a sports idol, "Mode Pele," and the rap group "Kid'n Play." One sign features a likeness of actor Eddy Murphy sporting a suave haircut, titled "Murphy Modelle Currency."

Most importantly, the hairstyles on the signs point out profound cultural links between African and African-American cultures and the dynamic nature of contemporary transcultural exchanges. Men's shaped cuts, popular among young adults in African-American communities in the late '80s were quickly embraced by African urban youth. Similarly, the elaborately braided women's hairstyle of the '80s and '90s were worn simultaneously by women in Africa and in America.

Hairdressing signs and other forms of commercial art have been part of the urban landscape in Africa since the 1930s. Many commercial signs are painted by self-trained artists, and the prices for hairdressing signs continue to be based on the number and size of the painted heads. Self-taught artist Joseph Bertiers of Nairobi began painting signs for beauty shops and other businesses in the early 1960s. In addition to presenting hairstyles, Bertiers' signs often depict the bustling activity of hairdressing salons, accompanied by humorous, often satirical quips. Over the years, he began producing works for the contemporary international art market as well. The reverse also occurs; in recent years, academically trained artists in Abidjan occasionally produce signs to supplement their incomes.

In the late 1960s, Bishok T. Pierre came to Liberville as a young sign painter. Today, there is hardly a barber shop or hairdressing salon in the city that does not display multiple paintings by the renowned artist. Like sign painters in other parts of Africa, Pierre now regularly copies photographs from a variety of fashion magazines and other publications in order to keep current with the latest styles.

Working directly from photographs has changed how he renders his images. From the relatively flat profiles of earlier work, Pierre has moved to three-quarter poses, as well as paintings of full figures, which he renders more realistically.

Sign-painting ateliers have been established in many urban centers in Africa. Often the painters sign their name or a nickname, or they use the name of the atelier on the paintings, such as "Unity Best Art," "Double-Do Art," "Almighty God Art" and "Heavenly Father Cuts." One sign, bearing the "Heavenly Father Cuts" imprint in the corner, titles one particular haircut "God's Gift."

Curated by Fowler Museum Deputy Director Doran H. Ross, an African-art historian and curator of the museum's African collections, the exhibition was organized by the UCLA Fowler Museum and includes objects selected from the museum's holdings, as well as from several private collections.

"Coiffure Moderne" is presented in conjunction with its companion exhibition, "Crowning Achievements: African Arts of Dressing the Head," which features traditional and contemporary hats, headdresses and hairstyles. Like hair, hats are excellent vehicles for visual expression that can be used to construct one's social identity, and to enhance and transform one's life.

The UCLA Fowler Museum has planned extensive public programming to complement both "Coiffure Moderne" and "Crowning Achievements," including lectures, African hair braiding demonstrations, children's storytelling, gallery talks and teachers' workshops, among other events.

The UCLA Fowler Museum's hours are Wednesday through Sunday, noon to 5 p.m., Thursday until 8 p.m. Admission is free. For general information, the public should call (310) 825-4361.

Public Information Office, James West Center, UCLA, 405 Hilgard Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90024-1431. Tel: (310) 825-2585. Fax: (310) 206-3455.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April, 1995


KENYA: KENYA WILDLIFE SERVICE TO LAY OFF 1000


LENGTH: 360 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (NAIROBI)

APRIL, 1995

KENYA'S WILDLIFE SERVICES IS UNDER WORLD BANK PRESSURE TO LAY OFF 1,000 OF ITS EMPLOYEES.

IT IS STILL UNCLEAR OVER WHAT PERIOD THE 26 PER CENT STAFF REDUCTION IS TO BE DONE BUT A HIGHLY PLACED SOURCE HERE SAID THE RETRECHMENT PROCESS WOULD TAKE PLACE WITHIN THE NEXT ONE YEAR. 

THE SERVICES DIRECTOR DR DAVID WESTERN CONCEDED LAST WEEK THAT HIS ORGANISATION WAS UNDER PRESSURE FROM DONORS TO REDUCE STAFF FROM 4,100 WORKERS TO 3000.

BUT HE SAID A REVIEW OF TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF STAFF, JOB DESCRIPTIONS AND STRUCTURE OF THE WILDLIFE BODY WAS UNDERWAY TO ESTABLISH WHETHER THE PROPOSED STAFF REDUCTION WAS "REALISTIC WITH OUR NATIONAL PLAN."

"WE WANT TO SEE WHETHER WE CAN OPERATE WITH ONLY 3,000 EMPLOYEES AS DEMANDED BY OUR DONORS," HE SAID, ADDING THAT HIS ORGANISATION HAD AT ONE TIME REDUCED MANPOWER TO 3,000 BUT THE FIGURE SHOT UP LATER "IN UNKNOWN CIRCUMSTANCES".

WESTERN SAID HE WOULD BE IN A POSITION TO GIVE MORE DETAILS ONCE THE REVIEW REPORT WAS READY, PROBABLY IN SIX MONTHS.

HE SAID HIS ORGANISATION WAS NOT IN A POSITION TO DICTATE TERMS TO DONORS. "YOU KNOW THEY FUND US, SO WE HAVE TO ACCEPT WHAT THEY SAY," HE QUIPPED.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


111 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


KENYA: SESSION SAYS GENDER EQUALITY REQUIRED FOR DEVELOPMENT


LENGTH: 494 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (NAIROBI)

APRIL 18, 1995

PARTICIPANTS AT RECENT INTERNATIONAL SEMINAR ON GENDER AND ENVIRONMENT HERE URGED GOVERNMENTS TO ADOPT POLICIES AND PROGRAMMES THAT REFLECT GENDER EQUALITY AND EMPOWERMENT AS MEANS AND THE GOALS OF ACHIEVING SUSTAINABLE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT.

THE FOUR-DAY SEMINAR, ATTENDED BY OVER 50 PARTICIPATNS - BOTH MEN AND WOMEN -- WELL VERSED IN GENDER ISSUES FORM AFRICA, ASIA, EUROPE, LATIN AMERICA AND THE CARIBBEAN, NORTH AMERICA AND WEST ASIA, ENDED ON FRIDAY.

THE SEMINAR OFFERED AN EXCELLENT OPPORTUNITY TO SHARE EXPERIENCES ON GENDER FOR THE PROMOTION AND EMPOWERMENT OF WOMEN IN THE MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES AND SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT. 

IN A NEWS RELEASE, THE ORGANISERS- UNITED NATIONS ENVIRONMENT PROGRAMME- SAID THE MEETING SOUGHT TO EXPAND PARTNERSHIP ON GENDER AND ENVIRONMENT IN COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS AND PROGRAMMES WITH GOVERNMENTS, INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS, UN AGENCIES AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS.

PARTICIPANTS POINTED OUT THAT AS THE EARTH WAS THE COMMON HERITAGE FOR ALL, ITS FUTURE DEPENDED UPON THE SHARED RESPONSIBILITY BETWEEN MEN AMDN WOMEN AS EQUAL PARTNERS.

IN THEIR MESSAGE, DELEGATES CALLED FOR SOCIAL JUSTICE AND PEACE AND SAID DEVELOPMENT SHOULD NOT BE DONE AT THE EXPENSE OF OTHER GROUPS OR COMMUNITIES.

THEY SAID SAFEGUARDING THE ENVIRONMENT HAD TO GO TOGETHER WITH CHANGES IN THE GLOBAL ECONOMIC SYSTEM, ADDING THAT STRATEGIC ACTIONS NEEDED FOR SOUND ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT REQUIRED A HOLISTIC, MULTIDISCIPLINARY AND INTERSECTORAL APPROACH.

THE SEMINAR INSISTED THAT BOTH MEN AND WOMEN WERE KEY PLAYERS TOWARDS THE WISE STEWARDSHIP OF PLANET EARTH. IT ALSO MADE A NUMBER OF RECOMMENDATIONS ON UNEP'S FUTURE ACTIVITIES ON GENDER AND ENVIRONMENT.

THE SEMINAR'S RCOMMENDATIONS WILL FORM PART OF UNEP'S CONTRIBUTION TO THE FOURTH WORLD CONFERENCE ON WOMEN TO BE HELD IN BEIJING IN SEPTEMBER 1995.

PANA PBM 17APRIL95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


April, 1995


ZAMBIA: ZAMBIA TO KEEP OPEN MARKET FOR FARMERS


LENGTH: 440 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY/ZANA (LUSAKA)

APRIL 18, 1995

THE ZAMBIAN GOVERNMENT WILL NOT CONTROL MEALIE-MEAL AND MAIZE IMPORTS FROM SOUTH AFRICA AND ZIMBABWE AS DEMANDED BY SOME LOCAL PRODUCERS, HENRY KABIKA, COMMERCE, TRADE AND INDUSTRY DEPUTY MINISTER, SAID IN AN INTERVIEW.

HE SAID ZAMBIA'S ECONOMY HAD BEEN LIBERALISED AND THAT NATIONALS NOW HAVE TO COMPETE WITH FOREIGN PRODUCERS FOR THE MARKET.

KABIKA WAS REACTING TO COMPLAINTS FROM SOME FARMERS IN MKUSHI, CENTRAL ZAMBIA, THAT THIS YEAR'S LOCAL PROUDCE MAY NOT FIND A READY MARKET BECAUSE PRICES WOULD BE PUSHED DOWN BY IMPORTS. 

HE SAID GOVERNMENT INDIRECTLY ENCOURAGED THE IMPORTATION OF MEALIE-MEAL, THE NATIONAL STAPLE, TO ENABLE CONSUMERS HAVE A WIDE CHOICE OF LOCAL AND FOREIGN BRANDS OF MEALIE MEAL.

THE DEPUTY MINISTER CONDENMED SOME BUSINESSMEN WHO WERE OUT TO MAKE HUGE PROFITS FROM POOR PEOPLE AND WONDERED WHY LOCAL GRAINS SHOULD BE MORE EXPENSIVE THAN THOSE IMPORTED.

HE SAID GOVERNMENT WILL STOP THE IMPORTATION OF MAIZE ONLY AFTER MAKING SURE THAT ZAMBIA HAS ENOUGH GRAINS.

ON THE COPPERBELT, A 25KG BAG OF BREAKFAST MEALIE-MEAL FROM SOUTH AFRICA IS BEING SOLD AT 7,000 KWACHA (840 KWACHA = ONE US DOLLAR) AND 20KG OF SUPER WHITE MEAL FROM ZIMBABWE AT K6,500.

THE LOCAL MILLERS HAVE FIXED A 25KG BAG OF BREAKFAST MEALIE-MEAL AT NOT LESS THAN K8,000 MAKING THE FOREIGN BRAND VERY POPULAR.

MKUSHI FARMERS, SOME OF THE BIGGEST IN THE COUNTRY, HAVE COMPLAINED ABOUT THE CONTINUED IMPORTATION OF THE GRAIN AND MEALIE- MEAL AND SAID THEY WOULD HOLD A MEETING WITH THE ZAMBIA NATIONAL FARMERS' UNION (ZNUF) OFFICIALS AT THE END OF THE WEEK TO DISCUSS THE MATTER.

PANA-ZANA CM/KL/DS 18APRIL95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995

113 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


ALGERIA: ALGERIA MOVES TOWARDS A MARKET ECONOMY


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (DAKAR)

APRIL 18, 1995

BY ALY COULIBALY, PANA CORRESPONDENT

THE ALGERIAN GOVERNMENT IS DETERMINED TO MOVE TOWARDS A MARKET ECONOMY WITHOUT DESTROYING THE STATE-OWNED PRODUCTION SECTOR, ACCORDING TO A PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION CURRENTLY VISITING THE SENEGALESE CAPITAL.

"THE BID IS BOLD INDEED, ESPECIALLY IN VIEW OF THE CYCLE OF VIOLENCE WHICH HAS BEEN CONVULSED THE COUNTRY FOR OVER TWO YEARS," SAID BEN YACOUB, CHAIRMAN OF THE BUDGET AND FINANCE COMMITTEE OF ALGERIA'S TRANSITIONAL NATIONAL COUNCIL (CNT) AT A PRESS CONFERENCE MONDAY IN DAKAR.

YACOUB SAID "THE GOVERNMENT WILL DEFINE, BY MAY, THE MAJOR TRENDS OF THE ALGERIAN ECONOMY WHICH NEED SOME RESTRUCTURING".

WHERE PRIVITAIZATION TAKES PLACE, SHARES WILL BE SOLD TO TO BOTH NATIONALS AND FOREIGNERS. 

SEVERAL STATE-OWNED HOTELS AND MARKETING SERVICES WILL BE CERTAINLY BE SOLD OFF.

PUBLIC UTILITIES SUCH AS WATER AND ELECTRICITY WILL, HOWEVER, NOT FALL INTO PRIVATE HANDS FOR THE MOMENT.

YACOUB DID NOT RULE OUT THAT THE STATE MAY GRADUALLY DISENGAGE FROM THESE SECTORS IN THE FUTURE.

"ALGERIA'S GOAL IS TO REACH A 3 PER CENT GROWTH RATE IN 1995," HE SAID, ADDING THAT THE TARGET HAD NOT BEEN POSSIBLE TO ACHIEVE IN 1993 BECAUSE OF VIOLENCE.

THE VIOLENCE HAS COST ALGERIA SOME 2.5 BILLION DOLLARS, YACOUB SAID, ADDING THAT HE WAS CONFIDENT THERE WOULD BE AN ECONOMIC RECOVERY IN SPITE THE TURMOIL.

A MEMBER OF THE DELEGATION SAID BASIC INDUSTRY AND OIL WERE THE PILLARS OF THE ALGERIAN ECONOMY.

"INDUSTRY OPERATES AT SOME 50 PER CENT OF CAPACITY," GUERID ABDUL KADR, THE CNT DIRECTOR OF PROTOCOL SAID.

THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR, A MAJOR CONTRIBUTOR TO THE NATIONAL ECONOMY, HE SAID, WAS GOING TROUGH SERIOUS TRANSFORMATION WITH THE INTRODUCTION OF NEW FARMING TECHNIQUES.

THE MOVE IS AIMED AT PUTTING AN END TO FOOD IMPORTS, ESTIMATED TO HAVE COST 2.5 BILLION DOLLARS IN 1994.

"OIL PROCEEDS WILL SERVE FOR THE REPAYMENT OF A DEBT OF 26 BILLION DOLLARS AND FAVOUR THE SEARCH FOR A SOLUTION TO HOUSING, TRANSPORT AND EDUCATION PROBLEMS," ABDELHAMID BOUZAHER, THE ALGERIAN AMBASSADOR IN SENEGAL INDICATED.

MEANWHILE, PUBLIC FINANCES HAVE BEEN UNSTABLE. THE CURRENT FINANCIAL YEAR HAS SEEN A DEFICIT BUDGET. WHILE 20 BILLION DOLLARS IS PROJECTED IN EXPENDITURE, ONLY 12 BILLION DOLLARS IS EXPECTED TO BE COLLECTED IN REVENUE.

BORROWING FROM THE INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND (IMF) SHOULD MAKE IT POSSIBLE TO FINANCE THE 8 BILLION DOLLAR DEFICIT, ALGERIAN SOURCES IN DAKAR SAID.

FROM 1990 TO 1994, ALGIERS BORROWED BETWEEN 7.2 AND 7.9 BILLION DOLLARS PER YEAR. NOW, IT HAS REPAIED BETWEEN 3 AND 4 BILLION DOLLARS WITHIN THE FRAMEWORK OF THE 'LONDON CLUB' WHICH COMPRISES PRIVATE CREDITORS.

HEAVY DEBT REPAYMENT SCHEDULES HAVE BEEN A FACTOR IN SLOWING DOWN JOB CREATION AND INCREASED FRUSTRATION AND VIOLENCE.

SOME 25 PER CENT OF ALAGERIAN YOUTH ARE STIL UNEMPLOYED, YACOUB SAID, ADDING THAT THE CREATION OF JOBS HAD BECOME A MAJOR PREOCCUPATION FOR THE ALGERIAN GOVERNMENT.

ALGERIAN AUTHORITIES HOPE TO CREATE 125,000 JOBS IN 1995 ALONE AND SOME 2 MILLION OVER THE NEXT FIVE YEARS.

PANA AC/KIB/PAP/DS 18APRIL95

ECONEWS: ALGERIA-MARKETS ALGERIA MOVES TOWARDS A MARKET ECONOMY BY ALY COULIBALY PANA CORRESPONDENT

DAKAR, SENEGAL (PANA) - THE ALGERIAN GOVERNMENT IS DETERMINED TO MOVE TOWARDS A MARKET ECONOMY WITHOUT DESTROYING THE STATE-OWNED PRODUCTION SECTOR, ACCORDING TO A PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION CURRENTLY VISITING THE SENEGALESE CAPITAL.

"THE BID IS BOLD INDEED, ESPECIALLY IN VIEW OF THE CYCLE OF VIOLENCE WHICH HAS BEEN CONVULSED THE COUNTRY FOR OVER TWO YEARS," SAID BEN YACOUB, CHAIRMAN OF THE BUDGET AND FINANCE COMMITTEE OF ALGERIA'S TRANSITIONAL NATIONAL COUNCIL (CNT) AT A PRESS CONFERENCE MONDAY IN DAKAR.

YACOUB SAID "THE GOVERNMENT WILL DEFINE, BY MAY, THE MAJOR TRENDS OF THE ALGERIAN ECONOMY WHICH NEED SOME RESTRUCTURING".

WHERE PRIVITAIZATION TAKES PLACE, SHARES WILL BE SOLD TO TO BOTH NATIONALS AND FOREIGNERS.

SEVERAL STATE-OWNED HOTELS AND MARKETING SERVICES WILL BE CERTAINLY BE SOLD OFF.

PUBLIC UTILITIES SUCH AS WATER AND ELECTRICITY WILL, HOWEVER, NOT FALL INTO PRIVATE HANDS FOR THE MOMENT.

YACOUB DID NOT RULE OUT THAT THE STATE MAY GRADUALLY DISENGAGE FROM THESE SECTORS IN THE FUTURE.

"ALGERIA'S GOAL IS TO REACH A 3 PER CENT GROWTH RATE IN 1995," HE SAID, ADDING THAT THE TARGET HAD NOT BEEN POSSIBLE TO ACHIEVE IN 1993 BECAUSE OF VIOLENCE.

THE VIOLENCE HAS COST ALGERIA SOME 2.5 BILLION DOLLARS, YACOUB SAID, ADDING THAT HE WAS CONFIDENT THERE WOULD BE AN ECONOMIC RECOVERY IN SPITE THE TURMOIL.

A MEMBER OF THE DELEGATION SAID BASIC INDUSTRY AND OIL WERE THE PILLARS OF THE ALGERIAN ECONOMY.

"INDUSTRY OPERATES AT SOME 50 PER CENT OF CAPACITY," GUERID ABDUL KADR, THE CNT DIRECTOR OF PROTOCOL SAID.

THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR, A MAJOR CONTRIBUTOR TO THE NATIONAL ECONOMY, HE SAID, WAS GOING TROUGH SERIOUS TRANSFORMATION WITH THE INTRODUCTION OF NEW FARMING TECHNIQUES.

THE MOVE IS AIMED AT PUTTING AN END TO FOOD IMPORTS, ESTIMATED TO HAVE COST 2.5 BILLION DOLLARS IN 1994.

"OIL PROCEEDS WILL SERVE FOR THE REPAYMENT OF A DEBT OF 26 BILLION DOLLARS AND FAVOUR THE SEARCH FOR A SOLUTION TO HOUSING, TRANSPORT AND EDUCATION PROBLEMS," ABDELHAMID BOUZAHER, THE ALGERIAN AMBASSADOR IN SENEGAL INDICATED.

MEANWHILE, PUBLIC FINANCES HAVE BEEN UNSTABLE. THE CURRENT FINANCIAL YEAR HAS SEEN A DEFICIT BUDGET. WHILE 20 BILLION DOLLARS IS PROJECTED IN EXPENDITURE, ONLY 12 BILLION DOLLARS IS EXPECTED TO BE COLLECTED IN REVENUE.

BORROWING FROM THE INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND (IMF) SHOULD MAKE IT POSSIBLE TO FINANCE THE 8 BILLION DOLLAR DEFICIT, ALGERIAN SOURCES IN DAKAR SAID.

FROM 1990 TO 1994, ALGIERS BORROWED BETWEEN 7.2 AND 7.9 BILLION DOLLARS PER YEAR. NOW, IT HAS REPAIED BETWEEN 3 AND 4 BILLION DOLLARS WITHIN THE FRAMEWORK OF THE 'LONDON CLUB' WHICH COMPRISES PRIVATE CREDITORS.

HEAVY DEBT REPAYMENT SCHEDULES HAVE BEEN A FACTOR IN SLOWING DOWN JOB CREATION AND INCREASED FRUSTRATION AND VIOLENCE.

SOME 25 PER CENT OF ALAGERIAN YOUTH ARE STIL UNEMPLOYED, YACOUB SAID, ADDING THAT THE CREATION OF JOBS HAD BECOME A MAJOR PREOCCUPATION FOR THE ALGERIAN GOVERNMENT.

ALGERIAN AUTHORITIES HOPE TO CREATE 125,000 JOBS IN 1995 ALONE AND SOME 2 MILLION OVER THE NEXT FIVE YEARS.

PANA AC/KIB/PAP/DS 18APRIL95

Africa News


April, 1995


ZAMBIA: EAST-CENTRAL COMMON MARKET MEMBERS MEET IN ZAMBIA


LENGTH: 387 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY(LUSAKA)

APRIL 18, 1995

BY MILDRED MULENGA, PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

MEMBER STATES OF THE COMMON MARKET FOR EASTERN AND SOUTHERN AFRICA (COMESA) WILL BE MEETING IN SIAVONGA, SOUTHERN ZAMBIA, FROM 24-27 APRIL TO APPRAISE THE BUSINESS COMMUNITY ON VARIOUS CREDIT FACILITIES EXISTING IN THE REGION.

AMONG THE CREDIT FACILITIES TO BE DISCUSSED ARE THE COMESA DISCOUNT HOUSE AND LINE OF CREDIT, AFRICA DEVELOPMENT BANK - PRIVATE SECTOR WINDOW FACILITY, AFRICA DEVELOPMENT FUND - POVERTY ALLEVIATION FUNDING PROGRAM AND EUROPEAN INVESTMENT BANK - EQUITY CAPITAL AND LOAN FACILITY. 

ACCORDING TO A STATEMENT RELEASED TUESDAY TO PANA IN LUSAKA, BY THE ORGANISERS, FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT CONSULTANTS, OTHER IMPORTANT TOPICS TO BE DISCUSSED INCLUDE PRIVATISATION PROGRAMMES IN MEMBER-STATES WITH A SPECIAL FOCUS ON MANAGEMENT BUY-OUTS.

PARTICIPANTS WILL ALSO CONSIDER THE POSSIBILITY OF THE FORMATION OF A REGIONAL STOCK EXCHANGE.

TARGET GROUPS FOR THE SEMINAR INCLUDE ALL MERCHANT BANKS WITHIN THE AFRICAN REGION, FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS AND STOCK BROKERS, THE ENTIRE BUSINESS COMMUNITY IN THE REGION AND CENTRAL BANKS, INCLUDING MINISTRIES OF FINANCE FROM COMESA MEMBER-STATES.

THE MEETING IS BEING ORGANISED JOINTLY WITH THE ZAMBIAN MINISTRY OF FINANCE.

PANA MM/MK/DS 18APRIL95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


115 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


WORLD ECONOMIC INTEGRATION ON COURSE, SAYS WORLD BANK


LENGTH: 507 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (LUSAKA)

APRIL 18, 1995

BY MUSENGWA KAYAYA, PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

THE WORLD BANK HAS SAID THE INTEGRATION OF THE DEVELOPING COUNTRIES' INTO THE WORLD ECONOMY IS PROCEEDING AT A RAPID PACE.

A REPORT RELEASED IN WASHINGTON TUESDAY AND QUOTED BY THE WASHINGTON LINE, A STATE DEPARTMENT NEWSLETTER, SAYS THE MOMENTUM IS DUE TO A NEAR UNIVERSAL PUSH TOWARDS TRADE AND CAPITAL MARKET LIBERALISATION AND INTERNATIONAL CORPORATE STRATEGIES AND TECHNOLGICAL CHANGE.

THE REPORT, 'GLOBAL ECONOMIC PROSPECTS AND THE DEVELOPING COUNTRIES', SAYS SUCH INTEGRATION PROVIDES A MAJOR OPPORTUNITY FOR RAISING THE LONG-TERM WELFARE OF BOTH DEVELOPING AND DEVELOPED COUNTRIES. 

IT SAYS THE GLOBAL ECONOMIC ENVIRONMENT HAS BEEN INVIGORATED BY BUOYANT WORLD TRADE THAT PROMISES TO GROW BY MORE THAN SIX PERCENT A YEAR OVER THE NEXT 10 YEARS AND BENEFITTING FROM LOW INFLATION.

THE WORLD BANK NOTES HOWEVER THAT THERE ARE STILL CHALLENGES FOR BOTH DEVELOPED AND DEVELOPING COUNTRIES BEFORE A HARMONIOUS WORLD ECONOMY IS ACHIEVED.

"A KEY ELEMENT OF REFORM WILL BE CONTINUED PROGRESS ON OPENING UP ECONOMIES TO INTERNATIONAL TRADE AND INVESTMENT."

THE REPORT SAYS THAT ECONOMIC GROWTH COULD REACH FIVE PERCENT A YEAR IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES AND 2.8 PERCENT IN INDUSTRIALISED COUNTRIES IN THE NEXT 10 YEARS, PROVIDED SUPPORTIVE POLICIES ARE MAINTAINED.

SOME ECONOMIC GROWTH HAS BEEN FORECAST FOR SUB-SAHARAN AFRICA'S TRANSITION ECONOMIES, BUT THAT THIS WOULD BE WELL BELOW THE OVERALL GROWTH RATE FOR DEVELOPING COUNTRIES.

"OUTWARD-ORIENTED STRUCTURAL REFORM WILL BE AN ESPECIALLY IMPORTANT CHALLENGE IN COUNTRIES IN SUB-SAHARAN AFRICA AND ELSWHERE THAT ARE AT AN EARLY STAGE IN THIS PROCESS," ACCORDING TO THE WORLD BANK.

MOST AFRICAN COUNTRIES HAVE ADOPTED FREE-MARKET ECONOMIES BUT STILL REMAIN APPREHENSIVE ABOUT PERCEIVED PROTECTIONISM IN THE WESTERN MARKETS WHICH THEY SAY DENIES FREE ACCESS FOR THIER GOODS.

PANA MK/DS 18APRIL95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


116 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


ZIMBABWE: ZIMBABWE WORKERS BODY RESCUING RETRENCHEES


LENGTH: 854 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (HARARE)

APRIL 18, 1995

BY CHEMIST MAFUBA, PANA CORRESPONDENT

ZIMBABWE'S SKILLED WORKERS WHO LOSE THEIR JOBS DUE TO THE COUNTRY'S ONGOING ECONOMIC REFORMS CAN NOW TURN TO THE ZIMBABWE CONGRESS OF TRADE UNIONS (ZCTU) FOR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO START THEIR OWN COMPANIES.

WHEN THE ZCTU REALISED THAT ZIMBABWE'S ECONOMIC STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT PROGRAMME (ESAP) INTRODUCED BY THE GOVERNMENT IN 1990 WOULD COST A LOT OF JOBS, IT SET UP A REVOLVING FUND FOR THE EXERCISE.

SO FAR IT HAS RAISED THE "SEED MONEY" TOTALLING ZIMDOLLARS 300,000 (USD 37 500) DONATED BY THE NORWEGIAN PEOPLE'S RELIEF ASSOCIATION.

THE ZCTU HAS DISBURSED ZD 200 000 (USD 25 000) TO FOUR COMPANIES, BENEFITING MORE THAN 60 WORKERS SINCE ITS EMPLOYMENT CREATION UNIT BECAME OPERATIONAL IN 1993. 

ZIMBABWE EMBRACED THE TOUGH DONOR-BACKED ECONOMIC REFORMS IN 1990 WHICH CALLED FOR THE SCALING DOWN OF THE BLOATED CIVIL SERVICE, RESULTING IN MASSIVE UNEMPLOYMENT.

NOW A TOTAL OF 30 532 EMPLOYEES HAVE LOST THEIR JOBS IN BOTH THE PRIVATE AND PUBLIC SECTORS.

IT IS ESTIMATED THAT OF ZIMBABWE'S 10.5 MILLION PEOPLE, A TOTAL OF TWO MILLION ARE UNEMPLOYED.

HARD HIT ARE SOME 300 000 SCHOOL LEAVERS WHO JOIN THE LABOUR MARKET ANNUALLY. ONLY 30 000 OR SO ARE ABSORBED INTO THE NATIONAL WORK FORCE.

ESAP ENTERS ITS SECOND FIVE-YEAR PHASE IN 1995 WITH MORE EMPLOYEES FROM THE CIVIL SERVICE EXPECTED TO LOSE THEIR JOBS IN LINE WITH THE TARGETS SET BY THE WORLD BANK AND THE INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND.

THE REVOLVING FUND, WHOSE IDEA ZCTU MOOTED IN 1991, IS OPEN TO INDIVIDUAL TRADERS, PARTNERSHIP ENTERPRISES AND CO-OPERATIVE VENTURES.

THE INTEREST ON THE LOAN, PAYABLE OVER FOUR YEARS WITH A THREE-MONTH GRACE PERIOD, HAS BEEN SET AT 20 PERCENT.

THE VIABILITY OF THE PROJECT IS TAKEN AS PART OF COLLATERAL, AND THE MACHINERY REMAINS ZCTU PROPERTY UNTIL THE LOAN IS REPAID IN FULL.

THE INSURANCE AGAINST FIRES AND BURGLARIES WILL BE CONSIDERED AS ADDITIONAL SECURITY IN FUTURE.

AS OF NOW, TWO PARTNERS IN A FIRM WHICH MAKES FOLDERS, BUSINESS CARDS, BIBLE COVERS AND BRIEFCASES SECURED A LOAN OF ZD 45 000 (USD 5 625), AND CREATED EMPLOYMENT FOR 15 PEOPLE AT THEIR PREMISES IN WATERFALLS, HARARE.

ALSO IN WATERFALLS, TWO PARTNERS IN A COMPANY WHICH MANUFACTURES SOCCER BALLS, VOLLEY BALLS, RUGBY BALLS, TENNIS BALL NETS AND SATCHELS HAVE CREATED JOBS FOR 15 PEOPLE WITH A LOAN OF ZD 25 000 (USD 3 125).

ONE TRADER IN MUFAKOSE, HARARE, CREATED EMPLOYMENT FOR EIGHT PEOPLE WITH A GRANT OF ZD 60 000 (USD 7 500) TO MANUFACTURE SHOES.

ANOTHER TRADER AT A GOLD MINE NEAR THE SECOND LARGEST CITY OF BULAWAYO HAS CREATED JOBS FOR 19 PEOPLE WITH A GRANT OF ZD 70 000 (USD 8 750).

THIS YEAR THE TRUSTEES HAVE UNDERTAKEN TO FUND 10 PROJECTS FOR WOMEN BECAUSE THEY ARE DISADVANTAGED ON THE MONEY MARKET, YET THEIR LOAN REPAYMENT RECORD OF 75 PERCENT FAR OUTSTRIPS THAT OF MEN.

THE ZCTU, WHICH HAS 29 AFFILLIATES, WILL TRY TO PERSUADE THE GOVERNMENT TO RELEASE SOME OF THE SOCIAL DIMENSIONS FUND (SDF) MONEY TO SPONSOR PROJECTS WHICH IT WILL HAVE APPROVED.

THE SDF HAS FINANCED 1 195 PROJECTS WORTH ZD 89,3 MILLION (USD 11 162 500), CREATING JOBS FOR 5 032 PEOPLE SINCE 1990.

THE LABOUR BODY WILL ALSO GIVE PRIORITY TO FINANCING PROJECTS STARTED BY WORKERS RETRENCHED FROM THE CLOTHING AND TEXTILE INDUSTRY WHICH IS COLLAPSING AS FIERCE COMPETITION FROM CHEAP FOREIGN PRODUCTS TAKES HOLD.

TRAINED OFFICERS WILL BE DEPLOYED COUNTRY-WIDE TO HELP THE BUDDING COME UP WITH VIABLE PROJECT PROPOSALS AS MOST WHICH ARE BEING RECEIVED FALL SHORT OF WHAT IS REQUIRED.

PANA-ZIANA CCM/TGM/DS 18APRIL95
