Africa News


April, 1995


ZAMBIA: ZAMBIAN GOVERNMENT FLOATS CEMENT SHARES


LENGTH: 520 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (LUSAKA)

APRIL 18, 1995

BY MUSENGWA KAYAYA, PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

THE ZAMBIAN GOVERNMENT HAS OFFERED ITS SHARES IN THE COUNTRY'S SOLE CEMENT MANUFACTURING COMPANY, CHILANGA CEMENT, FOR SALE TO THE PUBLIC UNDER THE COUNTRY'S CURRENT PRIVATISATION OF STATE-OWNED COMPANIES.

THE GOVERNMENT HAS TRANSFERRED SOME 54,750,970 ORDINARY SHARES TO THE ZAMBIA PRIVATISATION TRUST FUND (ZPTF) WHICH WILL EFFECT THE SALES TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH THE LUSAKA STOCK EXCHANGE (LUSE) ESTABLISHED LAST YEAR.

CHILANGA CEMENT WAS BOUGHT OFF IN 1994 BY THE COMMONWEALTH DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION (CDC) BUT GOVERNMENT RETAINED SOME SHARES WHICH IT IS NOW DISPOSING OFF. 

ACCORDING TO A PROSPECTUS RELEASED BY THE ZPTF TUESDAY IN LUSAKA TUESDAY, THE OFFER IS OPEN ONLY TO ZAMBIAN CITIZENS AND OTHER PUBLIC INSTITUTIONS TO BE SPECIFIED BY GOVERNMENT.

CHILANGA CEMENT PRODUCES ABOUT 500,000 TONNES OF CEMENT PER YEAR FROM ITS TWO PLANTS IN CHILANGA, SOUTH OF THE CAPITAL LUSAKA, AND NDOLA IN THE NORTHERN COPPERBELT REGION.

ACCORDING TO THE LATEST AVAILABLE DATA, THE COMPANY IS CURRENTLY OPERATING AT 65 PERCENT CAPACITY AND GEOLOGICAL FORECASTS INDICATE THAT LIMESTONE RESERVES, THE MAJOR INPUT, ARE EXPECTED TO LAST FOR THE NEXT 40 YEARS IN THE CHILANGA AND 60 YEARS IN NDOLA AREAS.

THE ZAMBIAN GOVERNMENT EMBARKED ON THE PRIVATISATION PROGRAMME IN 1992 FOLLOWING ADOPTION OF AN IMF-DRIVEN STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT PROGRAMME (SAP).

CHILANGA IS AMONG SOME OF ZAMBIA'S MAJOR FORMER STATE ENTERPRISES BEING TRANSFERRED INTO PRIVATE HANDS.

ZAMBIA BREWERIES, BREWERS OF BOTTLE BEER, WAS TAKEN OVER BY A SOUTH AFRICAN FIRM IN 1994.

THE ZPTF WAS ESTABLISHED THE SAME YEAR BY AN ACT OF PARLIAMENT TO HELP INDEGENOUS ZAMBIANS ACCESS THE NECESSARY FINANCES TO BUY SHARES IN COMPANIES OF THEIR CHOICE.

GOVERNMENT HAS SET ITSELF A TARGET TO SELL OFF SOME 20 STATE FIRMS BY THE END OF THIS YEAR.

PANA MK/DS 18APRIL95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


118 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


MALI: MALI TO BECOME A NEW ELDORADO


LENGTH: 867 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (BAMAKO)

APRIL 18, 1995

BY ABDOULAYE TRAORE, PANA CORRESPONDENT

MINING HAS RECEIVED A MAJOR BOOST IN MALI AS THE COUNTRY'S GOLD INDUSTRY TAKES ON A NEW IMPORTANCE.

IN THE 18TH CENTURY, IN THE HEYDAY OF THE MALI EMPIRE, THE COUNTRY'S GOLD WAS HELD BY THE OF KINGS AND PRINCES OF THE MANDING. IN COLONIAL DAYS, IT TURNED SEVERAL EUROPEANS INTO WEALTHY PEOPLE WHO CAME TO THRIVE IN WHAT WAS THEN FRENCH SUDAN.

AFTER INDEPENDENCE (1960), PRESIDENT MODIBO KEITA, A SOCIALIST, WANTED TO STEM THE OUTFLOW OF GOLD PROFITS TOWARDS THE OUTSIDE WORLD AND ALLOW MALI BENEFIT MORE FROM THE RESOURCE. 

HE SOUGHT AND OBTAINED THE SUPPORT OF THE SOVIET UNION AND PUT IN PLACE A STATE ENTERPRISE, THE 'NATIONAL COMPANY FOR MINING RESEARCH AND EXPLOITATION' (SONAREM) WHICH REPLACED THE (FRENCH) BUREAU OF GEOLOGICAL AND MINING RESEARCH (BRGM) PREVIOUSLY IN CHARGE OF GOLD MINING.

UNFORTUNATELY, THE INITIATIVE DID NOT PRODUCE THE DESIRED RESULT. GOLD PRODUCTION STARTED SUFFERING FROM MISMANAGEMENT AND BUREAUCRATIC RED TAPE, LIKE MANY OTHER STATE ENTERPRISES IN AFRICA.

WITH THE 1968 MILITARY COUP WHICH BROUGHT PRESIDENT MOUSSA TRAORE INTO POWER, MALI FELT OBLIGED TO OPEN UP THE GOLD SECTOR TO PRIVATE ENTERPRISE. THE INDUSTRY HAD FALLEDN INTO DECLINE AND THE ONLY MAJOR PRODUCER WAS KALANA, RUN BY THE STATE AND ITS SOVIET PARTNERS.

BUT EQUIPMENT AT THE MINE HAD BEEN BADLY MAINTAINED WHILE THERE WAS ALSO OVER-EMPLOYMENT WITH SOME 600 WORKERS FOR AN ANNUAL PRODUCTION OF LESS THAN THREE TONNES.

THE CURRENT MALIAN GOVERNMENT, BORN OUT OF DEMOCRATIC ELECTIONS IN 1992, IS DETERMINED TO FACILITATE PRIVATE INVESTMENT IN THE MINING SECTOR, OFFICIAL SOURCES SAY.

THE INITIATIVE SEEMS TO BE BEARING FRUIT AS MAJOR COMPANIES, INLCUDING THE GIANT ANGLO-AMERICA, INVEST IN GOLD EXPLORATION IN THE COUNTRY.

OPTIMISIM IS HIGH, AS THE PRIME MINISTER IBRAHIM BOUBACAR KEITA, IN DESCRIBING ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY IN MALI, SAYS "ALL LIGHTS ARE GREEN".

THE COUNTRY IS ALSO DOING WELL IN OTHER SECTORS. AT 26 PER CENT, INFLATION IS, ACCORDING TO THE FINANCE MINISTER, SOUMAILA CISSE, NOT TOO BAD -- CONSIDERING THE DEVALUATION OF THE CFA IN JANUARY 1994. THE CURRENCY IS USED IN MOST OF FRENCH-SPEAKING AFRICA.

MALIAN EXPORTS ARE DOING WELL. CATTLE EXPORTS, A MAJOR SOURCE OF FOREIGN EXCHANGE, DOUBLED TO 41.6 BILLION F CFA (480 CFA = ONE US DOLLAR) IN 1994 AS AGAINST 20 BILLION IN 1993, AMADOU BA, OF THE MALIAN CATTLE AND MEAT OFFICE (OMBEVI) SAID.

THE HEAD OF STATE, ALPHA OUMAR KONARE, SAID LAST YEAR THAT MALI HAD PAID OVER 70 BILLION F CFA OF ITS EXTERNAL DEBT.

ONE MONTH AGO, THE GOVERNMENT UNDERTOOK TO HONOUR AN INTERNAL DEBT OF ABOUT 41 BILLION F CFA.

CROPS HAVE ALSO DONE WELL THIS YEAR. THE PRODUCTION OF COTTON, THE COUNTRY'S MAIN EXPORT, WILL FOR THE FIRST TIME GO BEYOND THE RECORD 350,000 TONNES.

BUT CROPS AS A WHOLE REMAIN EXPOSED TO THE VAGARIES OF THE WEATHER AND LOCUST INVASIONS. THIS HAS, IN SOME QUARTERS, JUSTIFIED THE SIGNIFICANCE NOW GIVEN TO GOLD.

THE POLICY FOR THE SECTOR IS TO MOVE TOWARDS A POLICY TO MAKE THE MINING INDUSTRY ATTRACTIVE FOR FOREIGN INVESTORS, WHILE LEAVING PART OF THE WEALTH CREATED IN THE COUNTRY, MORY KANE, THE MINING MINISTER SAYS.

GOLD RESERVES IN MALI ARE ESTIMATED AT SOME 353 TONNES. PRODUCTION, AT AROUND THREE TONNES IN 1994, IS EXPECTED TO DOUBLE THIS YEAR TO SIX TONNES.

TWENTY THREE EXPLORATION AND MINING LICENCES WERE GRANTED IN 1994 TO PRIVATE, MALIAN AND FOREIGN OPERATORS. MALI SEEMS CERTAINLY SET FOR SOME GOLD BOOM.

PANA AT/KIB/PAP/DS 18APRIL95

Africa News


April, 1995


ZIMBABWE: ZIMBABWE TRUST INVESTS IN MAJOR EXPLORATION PROJECT


LENGTH: 360 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (BULAWAYO)

APRIL 18, 1995

THE DEVELOPMENT TRUST OF ZIMBABWE HAS SECURED MORE THAN ZIMDOLLARS 134 MILLION (USD 16.8 MILLION) FROM BRITISH SOURCES FOR ITS EXPLORATION ACTIVITIES IN ZIMBABWE.

AN OFFICIAL OF THE TRUST SAID IN AN INTERVIEW THAT NEGOTIATIONS WERE GOING ON AT SENIOR GOVERNMENT LEVEL TO FINALISE THE DEAL. 

"EXPLORATION WOULD HAVE STARTED BUT WE WERE WAITING FOR THE LOAN FROM THE UNITED KINGDOM," THE OFFICIAL SAID.

DTZ, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH A RUSSIAN COMPANY, WAS RECENTLY GRANTED FIVE EXCLUSIVE PROSPECTING ORDERS (EXPLORATION LICENCES) FOR DIAMONDS, GOLD AND PLATINUM IN VARIOUS MINING DISTRICTS OF ZIMBABWE BY THE GOVERNMENT.

BUT, THE DTZ OFFICIAL DISPELLED SPECULATION IN THE MINING INDUSTRY THAT THE TRUST HAD APPLIED FOR THE LICENCES FOR SPECULATIVE REASONS SINCE IT WAS STRAPPED FOR CASH.

"WE ARE RECOVERING FROM THE DROUGHT JUST LIKE EVERYBODY ELSE AND THE SITUATION HAS NOT BEEN THAT GOOD BUT TO SAY WE ARE SPECULATORS IS NOT TRUE," THE OFFICIAL SAID, REFERRING FURTHER QUESTIONS TO THE CHAIRMAN OF DTZ, VICE PRESIDENT JOSHUA NKOMO.

PANA-ZIANA AB/TN/STC/DS 18APRIL95

ZAMBIA: ZAMBIA FAILS TO TAP LOCAL OIL RESOURCES


LENGTH: 374 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (LUSAKA)

APRIL 18, 1995

BY MUSENGWA KAYAYA, PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

ZAMBIA HAS BEEN UNABLE TO TAP LOCAL OIL RESOURCES DUE TO GOVERNMENT FAILURE TO ADVERTISE THE EXISTING DEPOSITS AMONG INTERNATIONAL INVESTORS, ACCORDING TO A PARLIAMENTARY REPORT QUOTED BY THE LOCAL MEDIA HERE TUESDAY.

THE REPORT SAYS THAT THE ZAMBIAN MINISTRY OF FINANCE HAS NEVER PLACED ADVERTISEMENTS IN INTERNATIONAL OIL OR GAS JOURNALS TO MAKE THE ENERGY BUSINESS COMMUNITY AWARE OF THE COUNTRY'S OIL POTENTIAL. 

GOVERNMENT IN 1993 GAVE BROCHURES TO FOUR BRITISH WOULD-BE INVESTORS IN THE ZAMBIAN OIL INDUSTRY BUT THERE HAS BEEN NO FOLLOW-UP SINCE, ACCORDING TO THE REPORT.

THE "NEGATIVE RESPONSE" IS PARTLY ATTRIBUTED TO THE SCRAMBLE BY WESTERN AND OTHER INTERNATIONAL INVESTORS FOR THE "SOVIET-BLOC" OIL INDUSTRY FOLLOWING THE COLLAPSE OF COMMUNIST SOVIET UNION WHICH HAS OPENED UP THE AREA FOR PRIVATE INDUSTRY.

SUBSTANTIAL DEPOSITS OF OIL ARE SAID TO EXIST IN ZAMBIA'S WESTERN ZAMBEZI PLAINS.

CURRENTLY, OIL IMPORTS ACCOUNT FOR ALMOST HALF OF THE COUNTRY'S IMPORT BILL.

PANA MK/PBM 18APRIL95

FROM THE PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (PANA) ECONEWS AND ENVIRONEMENT BULLETIN

ZIMBABWE: SOUTHERN AFRICAN TOURISM ORGAN IN PIPELINE


LENGTH: 854 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (HARARE)

APRIL 18, 1995

PLANS TO SET UP A SINGLE SOUTHERN AFRICA REGIONAL TOURISM ORGANISATION ARE AT AN AN ADVANCED STAGE, ZIMBABWE COUNCIL FOR TOURISM CHAIRMAN DAVID CHAPMAN SAID ON MONDAY.

IN A STATEMENT, CHAPMAN SAID A WORKSHOP TO DISCUSS THE ESTABLISHMENT OF THE ORGANISATION HAD BEEN HELD IN WINDHOEK, NAMIBIA AND A STEERING COMMITTEE SET UP TO ASSIST THE SADC TOURISM CO-ORDINATION (TCU) UNIT AND SOUTHERN AFRICA REGIONAL TOURISM COUNCIL (SARTOC) IN SETTING UP THE NEW REGIONAL BODY.

"THE WORKSHOP DEFINED A STEERING COMMITTEE CONSISTING OF REPRESENTATIVES FROM ALL THE 11 MEMBER COUNTRIES' PRIVATE AND PUBLIC SECTORS. THIS STEERING COMMITTEE WILL ASSIST THE SADC TOURISM CO-ORDINATION UNIT AND SOUTHERN AFRICA REGIONAL TOURISM COUNCIL IN AN INTERIM PHASE TO JOINTLY SET UP THE NEW REGIONAL BODY," SAID CHAPMAN. 

AT PRESENT THERE ARE TWO TOURISM ORGANISATIONS IN THE SADC REGION, THE SADC TOURISM CO-ORDINATION UNIT LOCATED IN MASERU AND THE SOUTHERN AFRICA REGIONAL TOURISM COUNCIL LOCATED IN JOHANNESBURG AND BLANTYRE.

CHAPMAN SAID THE WINDHOEK TECHNICAL WORKSHOP HAD OUTLINED A MODEL FOR A FUTURE NEW REGIONAL ORGANISATION WHICH WOULD HAVE TO BE FURTHER DETAILED BY CONSULTANTS, BEFORE PRESENTATION AT A SECOND WORKSHOP TO BE HELD IN JOHANNESBURG IN MAY.

THE WORKSHOP JOINTLY INITIATED BY THE SADC TCU UNIT AND SARTOC WAS ATTENDED BY 55 PARTICIPANTS FROM 11 SOUTHERN AFRICA DEVELOPMENT COMMUNITY (SADC) MEMBER COUNTRIES AND THE EUROPEAN UNION.

CHAPMAN SAID THE WORKSHOP WAS THE SECOND STAGE IN A PROCESS OF CONSULTATION PLANNING UNDERTAKEN BY SADC CONSULTANTS, HOFF AND OVERGAARD OF DENMARK.

"THE FIRST STAGE CONSISTED OF COUNTRY VISITS TO ALL SADC MEMBER COUNTRIES. IN EACH COUNTRY THE MAJOR STAKEHOLDERS FROM THE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SECTORS WERE INTERVIEWED IN ORDER TO DEFINE THE NEEDS FOR AND SUPPORT OF A NEW SINGLE REGIONAL ORGANISATION," SAID CHAPMAN.

PANA-ZIANA JIM/MP/PBM 18APRIL95

ECONEWS:ZIMBABWE-INVESTMENTS ZIMBABWEAN CORPORATION TO CREATE JOBS

BULAWAYO, ZIMBABWE (PANA) - THE STATE-OWNED ZIMBABWE DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION (ZDC) PLANS TO INVEST OVER 6.3 MILLION US DOLLARS IN NEW JOB CREATION VENTURES IN VARIOUS PARTS OF THE COUNTRY.

ZDC'S ACTING CHIEF EXECUTIVE, NOMUTSA CHIDEYA, SAID ON MONDAY THAT HIS ORGANISATION HOPED TO TEAM UP WITH THE INDIGENOUS COMMUNITY IN NYAMINYAMI TO BUILD A FIVE MILLION US DOLLAR SAFARI LODGE.

CONSTRUCTION OF THE LODGE, EXPECTED TO EMPLOY OVER 80 PEOPLE, WAS SCHEDULED TO START IN JULY, HE SAID.

ZDC ALSO INTENDS TO DEVELOP A HOTEL WORTH 625,000 US DOLLARS IN DETE AND REFURBISH ITS BRICK AND TILE MANUFACTURING PLANT IN THE EASTERN HIGHLANDS.

" WE HAVE ALREADY MADE A SUBMISSION TO THE GOVERNMENT FOR AN ALLOCATION UNDER THE PUBLIC SECTOR INVESTMENT PROGRAMME (PSIP) FOR THE NEXT FISCAL YEAR," CHIDEYA SAID IN AN INTERVIEW.

AT THE START OF THE YEAR, THE ZDC PREPARED A COMPREHENSIVE FIVE-YEAR CORPORATE PLAN SUBMITTED TO GOVERNMENT AND WAS SEEKING A CAPITAL INJECTION OF 25 MILLION US DOLLARS TO CREATE AND SUSTAIN BUSINESS VENTURES.

CHIDEYA SAID THE ZDC WOULD NEXT MONTH START DISCUSSIONS WITH THE COUNTRY'S PROVINCIAL GOVERNORS ON HOW TO TACKLE INDUSTRIALISATION, DECENTRALISATION AND EMPLOYMENT CREATION.

" WE HAVE HAD SOME PRELIMINARY DISCUSSIONS WITH ALL THE EIGHT GOVERNORS AND WE WANT FURTHER TALKS WITH THEM ON HOW PROVINCIAL DEVELEOPMENT COMMITTEES HAVE TACKLED INDUSTRIALISATION," CHIDEYA SAID.

PANA-ZIANA ZST/PBM 18APRIL95

FROM THE PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (PANA) ECONEWS AND ENVIRONEMENT BULLETIN

122 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


AFRICAN PRESS REVIEW - WEEK OF APRIL 14, 1995


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

APRIL 14, 1995

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY

BY OLU SARR, PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

DAKAR, SENEGAL (PANA) - BURUNDI AND RWANDA, TWO COUNTRIES WITH A SIMILAR MIX OF COMBUSTIBLE POLITICAL, SOCIAL AND ETHNIC FACTORS, ARE SEEMINGLY ALWAYS IN THE NEWS THESE DAYS. THEIR WOES AND THOSE BETWEEN SUDAN AND UGANDA WERE PARTLY THE FOCUS OF THE AFRICAN MEDIA THIS WEEK.

THE "KENYA TIMES" BLAMED THE ORGANISATION OF AFRICAN UNITY (OAU) AND AFRICAN LEADERS FOR FAILING TO ACT FORCEFULLY IN BURUNDI AND PREVIOUSLY IN NEIGHBOURING RWANDA.

"IT IS TIME AFRICAN LEADERS PUT THEIR HEADS TOGETHER AND PREVENTED ANOTHER BLOODBATH IN BURUNDI," IT SAID. 

"THE OAU SHOULD SPEARHEAD THE CAMPAIGN FOR RECONCILIATION AND EMPHASISE ON AFRICAN SOLUTIONS INSTEAD OF INVITING FOREIGN PEACEKEEPERS," IT ADDED.

ACKNOWLEDGING THE PRESENCE OF AN OAU PEACE MISSION WHICH ARRIVED IN BURUNDI WEDNESDAY, IT REMINDED THE BODY OF FOREIGN MINISTERS "TO CONSIDER THE PLIGHT OF THOUSANDS OF REFUGEES WHO KEEP MOVING IN SEARCH OF SHELTER."

IT SAID: "THIS TIME ROUND, THE OAU MUST ENDEAVOUR TO RECONCILE THE TUTSI AND THE HUTU (SO THEY WILL) UNDERSTAND THAT KILLING ONE ANOTHER HAS FAILED TO RESOLVE WHATEVER DISPUTE THERE IS BETWEEN THEM, AND MUST JUST LEARN TO LIVE WITH EACH OTHER AND CREATE AN ATMOSPHERE OF TOLERANCE AND CO-EXISTENCE."

ON THE SAME PAGE IS AN ARTIST'S CONCEPTION OF NEVER-ENDING WARS IN AFRICA. IN THE CARTOON, SEGMENTED INTO THREE, THE ARTIST BEGINS WITH KENYA AND RWANDA STANDING TOGETHER. A BELLICOSE KENYA IS SHOWN SHOUTING A THE TOP OF ITS VOICE. SEGMENT TWO HAS RWANDAN'S HEAD CHOPPED OFF AND A VERY SHOCKED KENYA LOOKING ON. THE THIRD PART SHOWS KENYA, APPARENTLY HAVING RECOVERED FROM THE SHOCK, STILL SHOUTING AND POOR RWANDA LYING DEAD NEXT TO HER.

THE ORGANISATION 'REPORTERS SANS FRONTIERES' (REPORTERS WITHOUT BORDERS) ATTRACTED CRITICISM FOR ADVOCATING A BAN ON WHAT IT SAID WERE EXTREMIST NEWSPAPSERS IN BURUNDI, SUCH AS 'L'ETOILE'

"THEY CALL US ASSASSINS OVER ALL RADIO STATIONS AROUND THE WORLD AND COMPARE US TO THE INFAMOUS RADIO AND TELEVISION STATION 'MILLES COLLINES' IN RWANDA AND TO THE 'KANGURA' NEWSPAPER," BUJUMBURA'S 'L'ETOILE' SAID.

PARADOXICALLY, THE PAPER ADDED, "WHEN THOSE TWO MEDIA ORGANISATIONS WERE PREPARING FOR THE RWANDAN HOLOCAUST, 'REPORTERS SANS FRONTIERES' APPLAUDED AND GAVE THEIR BLESSING TO WHAT THEY CALLED THE EMERGENCE OF A FREE PRESS," IT SAID. IT ACCUSED THE ORGANISATION, A MOSTLY WEST EUROPEAN GROUP, OF SEEKING PUBLICITY AND OF "NURTURING CERTAIN PATERNALISTIC ATTITUDES."

THEN, L'ETOILE CHALLENGED "THESE ADVENTURERS" TO FIND A SINGLE ARTICLE WHERE IT CALLED ON HUTUS AND TUTSIS TO KILL EACH OTHER.

"IF THE GOVERNMENT BANS US, WE WILL GO UNDERGROUND. THEN, CRITICISM AGAINST THE GOVERNMENT WILL BE MUCH STRONGER, IF IT IS STILL IN POWER," IT SAID.

AS RWANDA LAST WEEK MARKED THE FIRST ANNIVERSARY OF THE START OF GENOCIDE IN WHICH SOME 500,000 PEOPLE WERE HACKED OR SHOT TO DEATH, THE UGANDAN PRESS CALLED FOR FAIR TRIALS OF THE ALLEGED KILLERS.

"WHAT IS NEEDED IN RWANDA NOW IS FOR ALL THOSE INVOLVED IN THE ADMINISTRATION OF JUSTICE TO EXERCISE MAXIMUM IMPARTIALITY AND PROFESSIONALISM AS A WAY OF BUILDING PUBLIC CONFIDENCE IN THE FRAGILE SYSTEM," STATE-OWNED NEW VISION SAID.

IT ADDED THAT SINCE THE TRIALS WOULD ALSO INTEREST NON-RWANDANS, "IMPARTIALITY WILL NOT ONLY CALM THE ANGER OF THOSE ITCHING FOR REVENGE BUT WILL ALSO REASSURE THOSE MILLIONS OF REFUGEES OUTSIDE TO RETURN HOME AND EXPECT FAIR TRIALS."

TURNING TO UGANDA'S RELATIONS WITH SUDAN, IT FOCUSED ON TALKS IN TRIPOLI, LIBYA, EARLY APRIL IN WHICH AN ACCORD TO SETTLE THE ROW WAS WORKED OUT. THAT DEVELOPED OUT OF MUTUAL ACCUSATIONS OF HELPING REBELS ATTACK THE CENTRAL GOVERNMENT OF EACH COUNTRY.

"THIS IS A WELCOME MOVE THAT SHOULD REMOVE A THORN THAT HAS PERSISTENTLY SOURED RELATIONS BETWEEN THE TWO NEIGHBOURS," IT SAID.

"THE ACCUSATIONS, ACCURATE OR OTHERWISE, HAVE UNDERMINED EFFORTS TO RESTORE REGIONAL HARMONY AND HAVE PRECIPITATED ACTIONS LIKE THE BOMBING OF PARTS OF NORTHERN UGANDA THAT DISRUPT SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC ACTIVITY," IT SAID.

IN VIEW OF CONSTANT BICKERING BETWEEN KENYA AND UGANDA, KAMPALA'S INDEPENDENT TRI-WEEKLY PAPER 'THE MONITOR' APPEALED TO THE UGANDA GOVERNMENT TO OPEN ITS MUCH TALKED ABOUT SEA ROUTE VIA DAR-ES-SALAAM RATHER THAN RELY ON THE KENYAN PORT OF MOMBASA.

"KENYAN LEADERS HAVE NOT, IN THE LEAST, BEEN TAMED BY THE PERENNIAL THREATS. PRECISELY BECAUSE THEY KNOW THAT THEY ARE DEALING WITH A SIDE THAT TALKS A LOT AND DOES LITTLE," IT SAID.

IT NOTED A HOST OF REASONS WHY KENYA MIGHT FEEL DUTY- BOUND TO DO WITH THEIR SEA ROUTE: GOOD NEIGHBOURLINESS, RESPECTING THE ECONOMIC SENSE OF KEEPING THE ROUTE OPEN, AND UGANDA'S INTERNATIONAL RIGHT OF ACCESS TO THE SEA.

"BUT EXPERIENCE HAS SHOWN THOSE NAIROBI CHIEFS CAN AT TIMES BE QUITE UNREASONABLE," IT SAID.

"IT WOULD, THREFORE, BE SILLY FOR UGANDA TO BE BLINDED BY THESE ASPECTS OF THE ARGUMENT AND LOSE SIGHT OF THE SIMPLE LOGIC AND EXPECTATIONS OF POSSIBLE NATURAL DISASTERS AND EVEN WAR. UGANDA AS AN INTERESTED PARTY SHOULD WORK CLOSELY WITH THE TANZANIA GOVERNMENT TO DEVELOP THE DAR-ES-SALAAM OR TANGA ROUTE," IT SAID.

PANA OSS/PBM 15APRIL95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


April, 1995


GABON: SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASES ON THE RISE IN GABON


LENGTH: 374 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (LIBREVILLE)

APRIL 12, 1995

SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASES (STD) OTHER THAN AIDS HAVE ATTAINED ALARMING PROPORTIONS IN GABON, ACCORDING TO A STUDY BY THE NATIONAL AIDS CONTROL PROGRAMME.

ALTHOUGH THESE DISEASES ARE PRACTICALLY IGNORED, THE REPORT SAID, THEIR HIGH PREVALENCE IS GRADULLY BEING DISCOVERED AMONG PREGNANT WOMEN. 

A RECENT STUDY CONDUCTED IN SEVERAL MATERNAL AND CHILD PROTECTION CENTRES DISCOVERED THAT ABOUT 13 PER CENT OF PREGNANT WOMEN HAVE SWELLINGS IN THEIR UTERUS OR 'CHLAMYDIA TRACHEMATIS'.

IT SHOWED THAT 21.9 PER CENT SUFFER FROM 'CANDIDA ALBICANS' OR 'TRICHOMONAS VAGINALIS' AND 5 PER CENT FROM SYPHILIS.

THE REPORT NOTED AN 8 PER CENT AVERAGE INCREASE IN HIV INFECTIONS BETWEEN 1986 AND 1989, AS AGAINST 18 PER CENT FROM 1989 T0 1992. SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASES ARE ARE AN OPEN DOOR FOR HIV INFECTION.

THE FIGHT AGAINST STDS, INCLUDING AIDS, IS ONE OF THE CURRENT PUBLIC HEALTH PRIORITIES IN GABON. CONTROL STRATEGIES FOCUS ON EPIDEMIOLOGICAL MONITORING, RESEARCH, STAFF TRAINING ETC...

THE GABONESE AIDS AND STD CONTROL PROGRAMME IS BEING ASSISTED BY THE FRENCH GOVERNMENT, THE EUROPEAN UNION, THE WORLD HEALTH ORGANISATION AND THE UNITED NATIONS FUND FOR POPULATION ACTIVITIES.

PANA-AGP BT/LMM/KIB/SJD/PBM 12APRIL95

FROM THE PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY SCIENCE & HEALTH BULLETIN

124 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


WOMEN'S HEALTH SITUATION AROUND THE WORLD


LENGTH: 440 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (GENEVA)

APRIL 12, 1995

THE NUMBER OF WOMEN AGED OVER 65 WILL REACH 326 MILLION WITHIN 20 YEARS, THE MAJORITY OF WHOM WILL LIVE IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES, ACCORDING TO ESTIMATES FROM THE WORLD HEALTH ORGANISATION (WHO).

SENIOR WOMEN ARE OFTEN CONFRONTED WITH DISABILITIES, CHRONIC DISEASES, POVERTY, LONELINESS AND ALIENATION, SAID A WHO STUDY MADE PUBLIC MONDAY AT THE WHO HEADQUARTERS IN GENEVA, SWITZERLAND.

FEMALE LIFE EXPECTANCY IN DEVELOPED COUNTRIES IS ON AVERAGE 15 YEARS HIGHER THAN THAT OF WOMEN IN THE SOUTH, AND SOMETIMES 30 YEARS HIGHER THAN THAT OF WOMEN IN POOR COUNTRIES. 

IN THE LATTER STATES, LIFE EXPECTANCY MAY NOT BE MORE THAN 50 YEARS, THE WHO SAYS, ADDING THAT HEART DISEASES AND RELATED ACCIDENTS ARE THE MAIN CAUSES OF DEATH AND DISABILITIES AMONG WOMEN IN OLD AGE.

UP TO 60 PER CENT OF DEATHS AMONG SENIOR WOMEN ARE CAUSED BY SUCH DISEASES IN DEVELOPED COUNTRIES, THE STUDY ADDED.

THE WHO EXPERTS NOTED THAT WOMEN'S HEALTH PROBLEMS ARE NOT GIVEN DUE ATTENTION IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES WHERE WOMEN ARE A VULNERABLE GROUP TO HEART DISEASES, A MAIN CAUSE OF MORTALITY AMONG WOMEN AGED 50 AND OVER.

IN THE COUNTRIES OF THE SOUTH, HIGHER LIFE EXPECTANCY AND LIVING STANDARDS ARE ACCOMPANIED BY A RISE IN MORTALITY AND DISABILITIES FROM HEART DISEASES. THE 460,000 NEW CASES OF CERVICAL CANCER RECORDED EVERY YEAR OCCUR MAINLY IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES, THE STUDY SAID.

HOWEVER, THE DISEASE CAN BE AVOIDED THROUGH PREVENTIVE MEASURES. SYSTEMATIC SCREENING EVERY FIVE YEARS CAN CAUSE AN 85 PER CENT REDUCTION OF MORTALITY DUE TO THE CANCER, THE STUDY EXPLAINED.

PANA KIB/SJD/DS 12APRIL95 ENG017

FROM THE PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY SCIENCE & HEALTH BULLETIN

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


April, 1995


ZAMBIA: ZAMBIA BANS SEX DRUG


LENGTH: 667 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (LUSAKA)

APRIL 12, 1995

BY MILDRED MULENGA, PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

A HIGH POTENCY APHRODISIAC INTRODUCED IN ZAMBIA A FORTHIGHT AGO HAS BEEN BANNED BY THE COUNTRY'S PHARMACY AND POISONS BOARD.

THE DRUG, 'MALE FORMULA', IS WHEN TAKEN OVER THIRTY DAYS WITH A DOSAGE OF TWO TABLETS PER DAY SUPPOSED TO ENABLE MEN PERFORM SEX "ALL NIGHT LONG".

IT IS SAID TO INCREASE SPERM COUNT, ALLEVIATE MALE FERTILITY PROBLEMS AND STIMULATE BOTH MENTAL AND PHYSICAL ENERGY. 

A FEMALE VERSION THE APHRODISIAC, THE 'FEMALE FORMULA', ALSO SAID TO REJUVENATE WOMEN SEXUALLY, WAS ALSO ABOUT TO BE BROUGHT ON THE ZAMBIAN MARKET BY A PRIVATE LUSAKA FIRM, 'NODA INVESTMENTS'.

ZAMBIA'S PHARMACY AND POISONS BOARD, TUESDAY IN LUSAKA ORDERED THE WITHDRAWAL FROM THE MARKET OF 'MALE FORMULA', SAYING ITS CLINICAL CONTENTS HAD NOT BEEN VERIFIED BY PHARMACEUTICAL EXPERTS.

THE DRUG, MANUFACTURED BY A UNITED STATES COMPANY, CALIFORNIA DISTRIBUTORS WAS SUPPLIED THROUGH A SOUTH-AFRICAN-BASED COMPANY.

ACCORDING TO THE SUPPLIERS, THE DRUG CONTAINS VITAMIN B1 (THIAMINE), VITAMIN B2 (RIBOFLOVINE) AND CALCIUM PANLOTHENATE.

UNDER ZAMBIAN LAW, NO MEDICINE CAN BE IMPORTED OR MANUFACTURED UNTIL IT IS PASSED BY THE PHARMACY AND POISONS BOARD.

ACCORDING TO NODA PROPRIETOR, MACDONALD NKABIKA, THE DRUG IS BEST FOR SEXUALLY TIRED AND OVER-WORKED MEN.

"MARRIAGES HAVE BROKEN UP BECAUSE SOME PEOPLE HAVE FAILED TO PERFORM SEXUALLY BUT THOSE WHO WILL TAKE THIS FORMULA WILL BE ASSURED OF A RESTORATION BECAUSE NATURALLY THE MAN WILL BE PHYSICALLY STIMULATED," NKABIKA HAD EARLIER CLAIMED IN HIS ADVERTISEMENTS.

HE CLAIMED THE FEMALE FORMULA STOPS IRRITABLE DISCHARGES FROM WOMEN AND ACTIVATES THEIR SEXUAL DESIRE, REDUCED IN SOME WOMEN AFTER PROLONGED CONSUMPTION OF BIRTH CONTROL PILLS.

NKABIKA HAS PROTESTED THE BAN OF THE DRUG.

HE CLAIMED IN LUSAKA WEDNESDAY THERE HAD BEEN A "TREMENDOUS" DEMAND FOR THE DRUG SOLD AT 15,000 KWACHA (ABOUT 20 UNITED STATES DOLLARS) A COURSE.

HERBAL APHRODISIACS ARE POPULAR AMONG BOTH MEN AND WOMEN IN ZAMBIAN CITIES.

MEDICAL EXPERTS CONSULTED BY PANA IN LUSAKA WEDNESDAY SAID AS FAR AS THEY KNEW, THERE IS STILL NO MEDICINE THAT BOOSTS ONE'S SEXUAL PERFORMANCE.

THEY SAID SEX IS A PHYSIOLOGICAL FUNCTION WHOSE SUCCESFUL PERFORMANCE DEPENDS ON PSYCHOLOGICAL, PHYSICAL, MENTAL, ENVIRONMENTAL AND OTHER FACTORS.

NKABIKA'S 'NODA INVESTMENTS' TRADITIONALLY SELLS HYGIENE AND OTHER HOUSEHOLD GOODS UNDER THE TRADE NAME 'MOTHER OF HYGIENE'.

HIS EXCITED WOULD-BE SEX CLIENTS HAD RECENTLY ADDED ANOTHER TITLE TO HIS BUSINESS -- 'FATHER OF LIBIDO'.

PANA MM/MK/DS 12APRIL95 ENG009

FROM THE PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY SCIENCE & HEALTH BULLETIN

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

CAMEROON: 40 DIE OF MENINGITIS IN EASTERN CAMEROON


LENGTH: 227 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (YAOUNDE)

APRIL 12, 1995

CAMEROON SAYS THAT 40 PEOPLE HAVE DIED OF MENINGITIS IN THE DEPARTMENT OF LOM-ET-DJEREM, THE COUNTRY'S EASTERN PROVINCE.

THE GOVERNMENT SAID TUESDAY IN YAOUNDE, THE CAPITAL, THAT 79 CASES OF THE DISEASE WERE REPORTED. IT ADDED THAT THERE WAS FEAR OF OUTBREAKS IN OTHER AREAS OF THE PROVINCE WHICH IS IN THE TROPICAL RAINFOREST.

GOVERNMENT HAS SENT 40,000 DOSES OF VACCINE TO BETARE-OYA, THE MOST AFFECTED LOCALITY, IN LOM-ET-DJEREM.

IT HAS ALSO STARTED TO IMMUNISE RESIDENTS OF BERTOUA, THE PROVINCIAL CAPITAL.

PANA AC/LMM/SJD/OSS 12APRIL95 ENG008

Africa News


April, 1995


ZIMBABWE: ZIMBABWE INTRODUCES HOME-BASED CARE FOR ORPHANS


LENGTH: 774 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (GWERU)

APRIL 12,1995

BY PAINOS DAKWA, PANA CORRESPONDENT

MARY IS A SEVEN-MONTH-OLD ORPHAN NOW BEING CARED FOR BY FOSTER PARENTS IN THE HIGH DENSITY SUBURB OF MKOBA IN ZIMBABWE'S MIDLANDS CAPITAL, GWERU.

HER PARENTS DIED THREE MONTHS AGO OF ACQUIRED IMMUNO-DEFICIENCY SYNDROME (AIDS) LEAVING THE INFANT WITH NO RELATIVE PREPARED TO TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR HER UPKEEP.

BUT A SINGLE MOTHER WHO KNEW HER PARENTS VOLUNTEERED TO LOOK AFTER THE CHILD, RECEIVING ASSISTANCE FROM A LOCAL HEALTH CENTRE AND A NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANISATION IN THE FORM OF FOOD AND CLOTHING. 

MARY IS NOW AMONG MORE THAN 100 CHILDREN IN AND AROUND GWERU IN CENTRAL ZIMBABWE,BORN TO TERMINALLY-ILL PARENTS WHO EVENTUALLY DIE LEAVING THEIR OFFSPRING HOMELESS DESTITUTES, ALSO BOUND FOR THE GRAVE IN MOST CASES.

SIXTY THOUSAND CHILDREN AGED BELOW 15 YEARS HAD BEEN ORPHANED IN ZIMBABWE BY THE END OF 1993 AS A RESULT OF THE DEATH OF BOTH PARENTS FROM AIDS AND OTHER KILLER DISEASES.

MOST OF THEM WERE LEFT IN THE CARE OF DESTITUTE GRANDPARENTS.

ALTHOUGH STEPS ARE BEING TAKEN BY THE DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL WELFARE AND SOME NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANISATIONS TO GIVE ASSISTANCE, THIS IS NOT ENOUGH.

HOWEVER, A HOME-BASED CARE PROGRAMME JOINTLY LAUNCHED BY THE GWERU CITY COUNCIL AND THE MIDLANDS AIDS SUPPORT ORGANISATION (MASO), COULD BE THE WAY OUT.

THE PROGRAMME, INITIATED IN NOVEMBER 1992, WAS OFFICIALLY LAUNCHED IN JULY 1994 BY A GROUP OF 15 WOMEN IN GWERU WHO OFFERED TO PROVIDE CARE TO TERMINALLY-ILL PATIENTS IN THE COMMUNITIES THEY LIVE IN.

ABOUT 100 WOMEN, MAINLY VOLUNTEERS, WERE TRAINED BY MASO AND THE GWERU CITY COUNCIL BUT ONLY 15 REMAINED WHILE THE REST DROPPED OUT.

THIS FIGURE HAS NOW RISEN TO 35 AS MORE WOMEN VOLUNTEERS ARE NOW TAKING AN ACTIVE INTEREST IN THE PROGRAMME.

HOME-CARE CO-ORDINATOR FOR THE GWERU CITY COUNCIL, NURSING SISTER DIANA MAKWINDI, SAYS NURSES PROVIDE HOME VISITING SERVICES TO THE SICK AND TO THE ORPHANS AS PART OF THEIR RESPONSIBILITIES IN THEIR AREAS OF OPERATION.

"WE ARE TRYING TO SOURCE FUNDS FROM THE CHILD SURVIVAL AND DEVELOPMENT FOUNDATION SO THAT WE CAN ESTABLISH A SOCIAL WELFARE FUND TO ASSIST ORPHANS, TERMINALLY-ILL PATIENTS AND THE POOR," EXPLAINS MAKWINDI.

SHE SAYS 54 TERMINALLY-ILL PATIENTS WERE IDENTIFIED AT GWERU GENERAL HOSPITAL WHILE 39 WERE BEING CARED FOR BY THE COMMUNITY.

BUT AS MORE AND MORE TERMINALLY-ILL PATIENTS DIE IN GWERU, SAYS MAKWINDI, THE PROBLEM OF ORPHANS RISES BY THE DAY BECAUSE THEY NEED FOOD, CLOTHING AND ACCOMMODATION.

JANET MADAMOMBE, WHO HAS ASSISTED FOUR FAMILIES, SAYS SHE IS NO LONGER VIEWED AS A VISITOR IN THE HOMES WHERE SHE IS COUNSELLING PATIENTS.

ONE PATIENT WHO SPOKE ON CONDITION OF ANONYMITY SAID THE HOME-BASED CARE PROGRAMME WAS THE BEST THING WHICH COULD EVER HAPPEN TO TERMINALLY-ILL PATIENTS.

"WE WELCOME IT BECAUSE IT GIVES US A SENSE OF BELONGING AND WE FEEL IT SHOULD BE CONTINUED," SHE SAID.

ANOTHER PATIENT WHO WAS UNABLE TO WALK SAID THE PROGRAMME WAS A BIG RELIEF TO THEM SINCE MOST OF THE RELATIVES SHUNNED THEM BECAUSE OF THEIR ILLNESS.

PANA-ZIANA PED/TGM/PBM 12APRIL95 ENG007

FROM THE PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY SCIENCE & HEALTH BULLETIN

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995

128 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


ZAMBIA: NO FAMILY PLANNING FOR REFUGEES


LENGTH: 720 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (LUSAKA)

APRIL 12, 1995

BY MUSENGWA KAYAYA, PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

THE WORLD'S 18 MILLION REFUGEES ARE AMONG PEOPLE WHO RARELY RECEIVE FAMILY PLANNING SERVICES, ACCORDING TO THE UNITED STATES-BASED "FAMILY HEALTH INTERNATIONAL" (FHI).

THE NON-PROFIT RESEARCH AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE ORGANISATION, SAYS THAT WHILE PROVIDING FOOD, SHELTER AND MEDICAL CARE ARE INITIALLY VITAL IN ASSISTING REFUGEES, REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH SERVICES ARE IMPORTANT AFTER BASIC NEEDS ARE MET.

"EVERN IN CRISIS SITUATIONS, PEOPLE ARE STILL SEXUALLY ACTIVE, AND THUS, MANY ARE STILL EXPOSED TO UNWANTED PREGNANCY OR SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASES," SAYS BEVERLY TUCKER, AN FHI ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR OF FIELD OPERATIONS. 

THE FHI MOSTLY CONCERNS ITSELF WITH FAMILY PLANNING ISSUES AND HIV/AIDS AROUD THE WORLD.

TUCKER IS REPORTED IN THE LATEST FHI QUARTERLY "NETWORK MAGAZINE" AS SAYING THAT SOME REFUGEES LIVE FOR MANY YEARS IN REFUEE CAMPS WHERE YOUNGER PEOPLE ARE LIKELY TO RESORT TO SEXUAL ENCOUNTERS FOR LACK OF RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES.

WOMEN PARTICULARLY ARE MORE VULNERABLE TO BY USING SEXUAL FAVOURS TO OBTAIN FOOD OR OTHER NEEDS FROM OFFICIALS INCHARGE OF REFUGEE CAMPS.

A REPORT FROM THE WOMEN'S COMMISSION FOR REFUGEE WOMEN AND CHILDREN QUOTED BY THE MAGAZINE RECOMMENDS THAT RELIEF AGENCIES STRENGTHEN ALL FACETS OF REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH SERVICES FOR WOMEN, INCLUDING TRAINING OF BIRTH ATTENDANTS.

IT RECOMMENDED THAT WOMEN REFUGEES BE PROVIDED WITH CONTRACEPTIVE SERVICES AND TREATED FOR SEXUALLY TRANSIMITTED DISEASES AND PROTECTED FROM UNSAFE ABORTIONS.

FHI ALSO STRESSED THE IMPORTANCE OF FAMILY PLANNING AND COUNSELLING FOR WOMEN WHO HAVE JUST GIVEN BIRTH OR HAVE LOST A PREGNANCY.

CHILDBIRTH IS AN IDEAL OPPORTUNITY FOR SUCH WOMEN TO OBTAIN FAMILY PLANNING SERVICES AND COUNSELING.

MEANWHILE THE FHI SAYS THAT SCIENTISTS ARE EXPLORING A VARIETY OF WAYS TO GIVE MEN NEW METHODS OF REVERSIBLE CONTRACEPTION, INCLUDING CONTRACEPTIVE INJECTIONS, PILLS AND SKIN IMPLANTS. OTHER METHODS ARE PATCHES OR CREAMS.

IT SAYS HOWEVER THAT DESPITE THE INVESTIGATIONS, IT WILL BE MANY MORE YEARS BEFORE ANY OF THE METHODS ARE PERFECTED FOR GENERAL USE.

FHI CORPORATE MEDICAL DIRECTOR DR WILLIAM GATES SAYS FOR THE TIME BEING MEN SHOULD BE ENCOURAGED TO USE THE EXISTING METHODS OF CONDOMS AND VASECTOMY INCLUDING THE NATURAL METHODS OF PERIODIC ABSTINENCE OR THE "RYTHM METHOD."

"WE NEED TO FIND WAYS TO EDUCATE AND SHOW MEN THAT INVOLVEMENT IN FAMILY PLANNING AND REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH WILL SERVE THEIR INTERESTS AS MEN. ECONOMICALLY, THEY WILL HAVE FEWER CHILDREN TO SUPPORT AND THE LIVES OF THEIR WIVES WILL BE BETTER WITH FEWER CHILDREN," ACCORDING TO DR GATES.

MEN ARE CONSIDERED AS ANOTHER GROUP WHO ARE NOT "TYPICAL" FAMILY PLANNING CLIENTS.

PANA MK/PBM 12APRIL95 ENG003

FROM THE PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY SCIENCE & HEALTH BULLETIN

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

GABON: GABON TO BORROW FROM FOREIGN DONORS


LENGTH: 280 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (LIBREVILLE)

April, 1995

GABONESE MPS HAVE VOTED BILLS AUTHORISING THEIR GOVERNMENT TO BORROW MONEY FROM THE FRENCH DEVELOPMENT FUND (CFD), THE ISLAMIC DEVELOPMENT BANK (IDB), THE INTERNATIONAL FUND FOR AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT (IFAD) AND THE WORLD BANK.

THE LOAN FROM THE FRENCH FUND, 1.1 BILLION CFA (470 CFA = ONE DOLLAR), WILL BE USED TO FINANCE ABOUT FIFTY MIXED FARMS ALONG THE LIBREVILLE-KANGO ROAD AND TO SET UP A STUDY FOR SEVERAL PROJECTS. 

THE 5 BILLION CFA FROM THE IDB WILL BE SPENT ON DEVELOPING THE NDJOLE-LALARA-MITZIC ROAD (187 KM) IN NORTHERN GABON AND TO BUILD 171 PRIMARY SCHOOL CLASSROOMS AND 20 HOUSES FOR TEACHERS.

THE WORLD BANK LOAN, ABOUT 3 BILLION CFA, WILL BE EARMARKED FOR THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMME TO THE TRANSPORT SECTOR, WHILE THE 4.5 BILLION CFA FROM IFAD WILL BE USE TO FINANCE AN AGRICULTURAL SUPPORT PROJECT IN A BID TO PROMOTE RURAL DEVELOPMENT.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995

Africa News


April, 1995


CONGO: ELF-CONGO BUYS UP STATE SHARES


LENGTH: 400 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (BRAZZAVILLE)

April, 1995

BY MBAKOUO, PANA CORRESPONDENT

THE CONGOLESE AFFILIATE OF ELF, THE FRENCH OIL COMPANY, HAS BOUGHT OFF, FOR 50 MILLION US DOLLARS, THE CONGOLESE STATE'S SHARES IN THE COMPANY, OFFICIAL SOURCES SAID IN BRAZZAVILLE.

WITH HALF OF THE PROCEEDS FROM THE SALE OF ITS SHARES TO THE AFFLIATE, CONGO'S LARGEST OIL PRODUCER, THE GOVERNMENT HAS PAID JANUARY SALARIES TO CIVIL SERVANTS AND TRIED TO SOLVE SOME PROBLEMS IN THE EDUCATION SECTOR, SAID PRESIDENT PASCAL LISSOUBA. 

CONGO HAD 25 PER CENT OF THE CAPITAL OF ELF-CONGO WHICH ACCOUNTS FOR ABOUT 80 PER CENT OF OIL PRODUCTION IN THE COUNTRY.

OIL AND TIMBER ARE CONGO'S MAIN FOREIGN EXCHANGE EARNERS.

PARLIAMENT RECENTLY ADOPTED A BILL AUTHORISING THE STATE TO SELL OFF ITS SHARES IN THE COMPANY.

AT A PRESS BRIEFING IN BRAZZAVILLE, PRESIDENT LISSOUBA ANNOUNCED THAT 15 MILLION USD HAD BEEN "PUT IN RESERVE" FOR THE PAYMENT OF OTHER SALARIES.

THE REMAINDER WILL BE INVESTED IN ROADS, STUDENT GRANTS AND REPAYING THE DEBT OWED BY THE NATIONAL ELECTRICITY COMPANY (SNE) TO ITS ZAIREAN COUNTERPART FOR ENERGY SUPPLIES ESTIMATED, BY ZIAREAN AUTHORITIES, TO HAVE COST SOME 12 MILLION US DOLLARS.

THE MONEY PAID BY ELF-CONGO IS BEING MANAGED BY CONGO'S NATIONAL TREASURY COMMITTEE, SET UP BY THE GOVERNMENT TO ENSURE GREATER TRANSPARENCY IN THE MANAGEMENT OF PUBLIC FUNDS. ITS MEMBERS INCLUDE MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT AND TRADE UNIONS.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


131 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


MALI: BIG MINING COMPANIES SCRAMBLE FOR GOLD IN MALI


LENGTH: 627 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (BAMAK0)

APRIL 11, 1995

BY ABDOULAYE TRAORE, PANA CORRESPONDENT

A GROWING NUMBER OF MINING COMPANIES, SOME AMONG THE WORLD'S BIGGEST, ARE SHOWING A GROWING INTEREST IN EXPLORING FOR GOLD IN MALI.

THE LAST ONE TO HAVE ESTABLISHED ITSELF IN MALI, THE BARRICK GOLD CORPORATION COMPANY OF NORTH-AMERICA HAS OBTAINED EXPLORATION LICENCES THAT WILL ALLOW FOR AN INVESTMENT OF OVER 5.2 MILLION DOLLARS.

THE TWO PROJECTS ARE EXPECTED TO GENERATE OVER 100 JOBS IN IN KADIOLA, SOUTHERN MALI, AND KENIEBA IN THE WEST. 

"WE ARE PLANNING TO MAKE SUBSTANTIAL INVESTMENTS AND WE HOPE TO MAKE MALI OUR REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT POLE," THE FORMER CANADIAN PRIME MINISTER, BRIAN MULRONEY, NOW CHAIRMAN AT THE BARRICK GOLD CORPORATION SAID.

IN FEBRUARY, REPORTS FROM THE MALIAN CAPITAL SAID TWO SOUTH AFRICAN COMPANIES HAD RECEIVED EXPLORATION AND EXPLOITATION LICENCES FOR THE COUNTRY'S WESTERN AND SOUTHERN PARTS.

ONE OF THEM, THE RAND GOLD COMPANY WILL, UNDER ITS LICENCE, OPERATE IN THE LOCALITIES OF KEREKOTO I AND II (KENIEBA ZONE). THE OTHER ONE IS THE ANGLO-AMERICAN CORPORATION WHICH, ACCORDING TO INFORMED SOURCES, IS THE LEADING GOLD-PRODUCER IN THE WORLD.

THE SOUTH AFRICAN GIANT WILL OPERATE IN SADIOLA IN THE SOUTH WHERE IT PLANS TO INVEST 1.5 BILLION CFA FRANCS (480 F CFA = 1 US DOLLAR). IT IS EXPECTED TO MINE 116 TONNES OF GOLD IN THE NEXT THREE YEARS, MORY KANE FROM THE MALIAN GOVERNMENT SAID.

THE MINE WILL BE SUNK BY THE SADIOLA GOLD MINES (SEMOS S.A), CREATED LAST OCTOBER BY ANGLO-AMERICAN AND THE CANADIAN COMPANY IAM GOLD. THE MALIAN GOVERNMENT AND THE WORLD BANK'S INTERNATIONAL FINANCE COPORATION (IFC) ARE OTHER SHAREHOLDERS.

ANOTHER MAJOR SOUTH AFRICAN MINING COMPANY, THE CONSOLIDATED INVESTMENT COMPANY LTD, HAS GONE INTO PARTNERSHIP WITH GHANA'S ASHANTI GOLDFEILDS IN TAKING OVER OF THE MANAGEMENT OF KALANA GOLDSMINES, A STATE ENTERRPISE DISSOLVED IN 1992 FOR POOR PERFORMANCE. MEANWHILE, THE LOMILO MINE, WHICH BELONGS TO THE AUSTRO-AMERICAN GROUP BHP-UTAH MINERAL PTY LTD, THE IFC AND THE MALIAN STATE, IS PLANNING ON DOUBLDING GOLD OUTPUT TO SIX TONNES.

A JOINT VENTURE OF THE FRENCH BUREAU OF GEOLOGICAL AND MINING RESEARCH AND OF THE MALIAN STATE HAVE ALSO GONE INTO JOINT EXPLORATION THAT SEEMS PROMISING.

OTHER LARGE-SCALE MINING COMPANIES ARE EXPECTED IN BAMAKO, SOURCES IN MALI'S MINING MINISTRY SAY. "THE MALIAN MINING CODE IS FAVOURABLE TO INVESTORS," THEY ADD.

PANA AT/KIB/PAP/DS 11APRIL95

Africa News


April, 1995


ZIMBABWE: REGIONAL BANK ACCUSED OF IGNORING SMALL BUSINESS


LENGTH: 440 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (BULAWAYO)

APRIL 11, 1995

ZIMBABWE'S NATIONAL EXPORT BODY, ZIMTRADE, HAS BLAMED THE EASTERN AND SOUTHERN AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK OF FAVOURING LARGE EXPORTERS BECAUSE OF ITS HIGH MINIMUM THRESHOLD FOR LOANS.

UNDER ITS OFFSHORE EXPORT CREDIT FINANCE SCHEME,THE MINIMUM AMOUNT AN EXPORTER CAN APPLY FOR IS ZIMDOLLAR 4.25 MILLION (500,000 US DOLLARS), BUT ZIMBABWEAN SMALL AND MEDIUM-SIZE COMPANIES SAY THIS IS UNFAIR AS IT DISCRIMINATES AGAINST THEM. 

"IT SEEMS TO EXCLUDE NEW EXPORTERS WHO BADLY NEED THE RESOURCES. BUT WE FEEL THIS FACILITY SHOULD BE BROADENED BY MAKING IT ACCESSIBLE TO SMALL SCALE EXPORTERS," SAID ZIMTRADE CHIEF EXECUTIVE, MORRISON SIFELANI.

UNDER THE SCHEME, THE FINANCE IS AVAILABLE THROUGH SOME OF THE LOCAL MERCHANT AND COMMERCIAL BANKS. THE FINANCE IS PROVIDED AS WORKING CAPITAL NEEDED TO FULFILL AN EXPORT ORDER.

ALTHOUGH INTEREST RATES (CURRENTLY AROUND 10 PER CENT) FLACTUATE FROM TIME TO TIME, THEY ARE WELL BELOW THOSE ON THE LOCAL MONEY MARKET.

SIFELANI WOULD NOT SAY WHAT ZIMTRADE WANTED AS THE MINIMUM AN EXPORTER COULD APPLY FOR.

"IT SHOULD BE AS LOW AS POSSIBLE BECAUSE WE BELIEVE EACH CASE MUST BE EVALUATED ON ITS MERIT," HE SAID.

ZIMTRADE WAS ALSO PUSHING FOR THE SETTING UP OF A "NON-ORTHODOX" BANK SYMPATHETIC TO THE NEEDS OF ENTREPRENEURS ASPIRING TO BREAK INTO THE EXPORT MARKET.

"WE ARE NOT MAKING THESE RECOMMENDATIONS IN ISOLATION, BUT WITH OTHER INTERESTED GROUPS SUCH AS THE INDIGENOUS BUSINESS, DEVELOPMENT CENTRE, THE CONFEDERATION OF ZIMBABWE INDUSTRIES AND SO ON," SIFELANI SAID.

PANA-ZIANA AB/TN/STC/DS 11APRIL95

Africa News


April, 1995


NIGERIA: NIGERIA'S INSURANCE: AFRICA-RE MOVES INTO SOUTH AFRICA


LENGTH: 880 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (LAGOS)

APRIL 11, 1995

BY DOMINIC ETE-DANIEL, PANA CORRESPONDENT

THE RECENT COMMISSIONING OF A LIAISON OFFICE IN SOUTH AFRICA BY LAGOS-BASED AFRICA RE-INSURANCE CORPORATION (AFRICA-RE) IS BEING SEEN BY INDUSTRY SOURCES AS A MOVE TO PENETRATE AFRICA'S LARGEST INSURANCE MARKET.

THE CORPORATION'S GENERAL MANAGER, BAKARY KAMARA, TOLD PANA IN LAGOS "SOUTH AFRICA CURRENTLY ACCOUNTS FOR 70 PER CENT OF AFRICA'S INSURANCE PREMIUM INCOME."

AFRICAN COUNTRIES BETWEEN THEM GENERATE ABOUT 18 BILLION U.S. DOLLARS IN INSURANCE PREMIUMS. SOUTH AFRICA ALONE ACCOUNTS FOR 15 BILLION DOLLARS. 

KAMARA SAID MOROCCO COMES SECOND WITH 600 MILLION DOLLARS FOLLOWED BY NIGERIA WITH SLIGHTLY OVER 500 MILLION DOLLARS.

HE SAID THE FACT THAT NO AFRICAN REINSURANCE COMPANY CURRENTLY OPERATES IN SOUTH AFRICA, GIVES AFRICA-RE, THE CONTINENT'S LARGEST INSURANCE GROUP AN EDGE.

THE SOUTH AFRICAN INSURANCE MARKET IS CURRENTLY DOMINATED BY FOREIGN INTERESTS.

KAMARA SAID AFRICA-RE, INCORPORATED IN 1976 BY 36 MEMBER STATES OF THE ORGANISATION OF ARICAN UNITY, HAD CARRIED OUT A FEASIBILITY STUDY WHICH SHOWED THAT "THE MARKET (IN SOUTH AFRICA) IS A SOLID ONE, COMPETITIVE AND HIGHLY SOPHISTICATED."

"WE NEED TO BE THERE," HE SAID.

HE SAID THE ADMISSION OF SOUTH AFRICA TO AFRICA-RE WILL IN NO WAY ALTER THE EQUITY STRUCTURE OF THE CORPORATION.

RATHER "IF SOUTH AFRICA JOINS, BEING THE BIGGEST INSURANCE MARKET IN AFRICA, THEY WILL ONLY BE ALLOTTED MAXIMUM SHARE HOLDING STATUS LIKE NIGERIA, EGYPT, MOROCCO AND LIBYA," KAMARA ADDED.

OUT OF THE 15 BILLION DOLLARS PREMIUM GENERATED ANNUALLY BY SOUTH AFRICA, HE SAID 12 BILLION DOLLARS IS ACCUMULATED THROUGH LIFE UNDERWRITING AND THREE BILLION DOLLARS FROM NON-LIFE UNDERTAKINGS.

THE CHAIRMAN SAID LIFE UNDERWRITING POTENTIALS ALSO EXIST IN ZIMBABWE, MORROCCO AND ALGERIA.

HE SAID ANOTHER AFRICA-RE BRANCH OFFICE IS TO BE OPENED IN MAURITIUS. IT WILL ALSO CATER FOR THE COMOROS ISLAND, MAGADASCAR AND SYCHELES.

KAMARA SAID THE LONG TERM PLAN IS TO SET UP NATIONAL OFFICES IN EACH COUNTRY.

AS PART OF THE RESTRUCTURING, HE SAID THE CORPORATION IS SETTING UP A FULL LIFE DEPARTMENT TO UNDERTAKE MORE LIFE UNDERWRITTING.

INSURANCE TRADE WINDOW AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT CONSULTANCIES ARE ALSO PLANNED.

ON THE CORPORATION'S BALANCE SHEET, KAMARA SAID "WE ARE DOING VERY WELL."

HE SAID IN 1992, THE GROUP MADE A PROFIT OF 4.1 MILLION U.S. DOLLARS. THE FIGURE INCREASED TO 4.6 MILLION DOLLARS IN 1993.

ALTHOUGH NOT ALL THE 1994 FIGURES WERE AVAILABLE THE CHAIRMAN SAID THE CORPORATION RECORDED A 21.3 PER CENT OVERALL GROWTH, INCLUDING 40 PER CENT GROWTH RATE IN NIGERIA IN 1994.

HE SAID BETWEEN 1993 AND 1994 THE GROUP RECORDED ONE BILLION U.S. DOLLAR INCOME IN NIGERIA.

AFTER ITS INCORPORATION IN 1976, AT THE INSTANCE OF THE ABIDJAN-BASED AFRICA DEVELOPMENT BANK, AFRICA-RE STARTED OPERATION IN 1978 WITH A PAID UP CAPITAL OF 4.6 MILLION U.S. DOLLARS, WHICH ROSE TO 30 MILLION DOLLARS IN 1990.

IT HAS BEEN CHARGED WITH REVERSING THE "EXCESSIVE FLOW" OF INSURANCE PREMIUMS FROM THE CONTINENT.

AFRICA-RE OPERATES THROUGH THREE REGIONAL OFFICES IN ABIDJAN (COTE D'IVOIRE) FOR THE FRENCH-SPEAKING AFRICAN COUNTRIES, MOROCCO FOR NORTH AFRICA AND NAIROBI (KENYA) FOR THE EAST AND SOUTHERN AFRICAN REGIONAL MARKETS.

ITS 1994 ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING IS TO BE HELD IN CASABLANCA, MOROCCO, IN MAY.

PANA DE/PE/DS 11APRIL95 ENG020

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April, 1995


GABON: PRIVATE SECTOR FRANC ZONE EMPLOYERS MEET IN LIBREVILLE


LENGTH: 267 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (LIBREVILLE)

APRIL, 1995

A WORKSHOP ON 'EMPLOYERS STRATEGIES IN THE FACE OF THE NEW ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL POLICIES OF REGIONAL INTEGRATION' OPENED IN LIBREVILLE TUESDAY.

THE WORKSHOP HAS BROUGHT TOGETHER EMPLOYERS ASSOCIATIONS FROM THE CFA FRANC CURRENCY ZONE AND IS TARGETTTED MAINLY AT THE PRIVATE SECTOR. 

IT IS DESIGNED TO HELP EMPLOYERS DEFINE JOINT STRATEGIES IN THE FACE OF SIMILAR REGULATIONS BEING ADOPTED BY GOVERNMENT'S IN THE CFA ZONE.

THE THREE-DAY MEETING WILL ALSO DISCUSS THEMES AS VARIED AS WORLD COMPETITION, REGIONAL INTEGRATION AND NATIONAL COMPETITIVENESS, THE HARMONIZATION OF LABOUR AND BUSINESS LEGISLATION, DEVALUATION AND ECONOMIC INTEGRATION AS WELL AS DEVELOPMENT OF SUB-REGIONAL COOPERATION AMONG EMPLOYER'S ASSOCIATIONS.

THE WORKSHOP HAS BEEN ORGANIZED BY THE GABONESE EMPLOYERS' CONFEDERATION (CPG) AND THE INTERNATIONAL LABOUR ORGANIZATION.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


135 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


NIGERIA: INVESTMENT OPTIONS IN NIGERIA'S MINING SECTOR


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (LAGOS)

APRIL 11, 1995

BY DOMINIC ETE-DANIEL, PANA CORRESPONDENT

A MAJOR STEP AT DIVERSIFYING NIGERIA'S OIL-DEPENDENT ECONOMY WAS THE RECENT CREATION OF A MINISTRY FOR SOLID MINERALS DEVELOPMENT.

THE NEW MINISTER KALOMA ALI ON ASSUMING DUTY IN MARCH PLEDGED TO EVOLVE A POLICY THAT WILL GIVE DIRECTION TO NIGERIA'S MINING SECTOR AND PROVIDE AN ENABLING INVESTMENT ENVIRONMENT FOR PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SECTOR PARTICIPATION.

THE BIRTH OF THE SOLID MINERAL MINISTRY FOLLOWED A MINING WORKSHOP HELD IN NIGERIA'S CENTRAL MINING CITY OF JOS IN NOVEMBER 1994.

THE WORKSHOP HAD RECOMMENDED THE CREATION OF AN INVESTMENT BANK TO CATER FOR THE NEEDS OF NIGERIA'S MINING COMMUNITY. 

THE CREATION OF THE MINISTRY HAS HEIGHTENED EXPECTATIONS THAT THE REACTIVATION OF NIGERIA'S SOLID MINERALS SECTOR WILL GIVE AN IMMEDIATE BOOST TO THE COUNTRY'S ECONOMIC RECOVERY.

ALREADY MANY INVESTMENT PROPOSALS HAVE BEEN PRESENTED FOR FUNDING.

IN THE COAL INDUSTRY FOR INSTANCE, THE NIGERIAN COAL CORPARATION (NSS) IN 1994 SUBMITTED A THREE-YEAR ROLLING PLAN FOR 1995-1997, TO THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT.

THE 1.3 BILLION-NAIRA PROPOSAL IS FOR THE REHABILITATION AND MODERNISATION OF THE COUNTRY'S EXISTING COAL MINES AND ASSOCIATED INFRASTRUCTURE (22 NAIRA =1USD).

THE MANAGING DIRECTOR OF THE NATIONAL COAL CORPORATION, GREY IWUH SAID IF REACTIVATED, NIGERIA'S EXISTING COAL MINES COULD EARN THE COUNTRY ABOUT 55 MILLION U.S. DOLLARS PER ANNUM.

NIGERIA CURRENTLY HAS 18 UNDEVELOPED COAL FIELDS, WITH COAL RESERVES OF 2.7 BILLION TONNES, HE SAID. SOME 10 OF THESE REQUIRE DETAILED EXPLORATION WORK, CONSTRUCTION OF ACCESS ROADS AND PRE-INVESTMENT STUDIES TO DETERMINE VIABILITY, AND A PROGRAMME OF DEVELOPMENT.

THE NIGERIAN MINING CORPORATION (MMC), WHICH OVERSEES THE COUNTRY'S VAST ARRAY OF SOLID MINERALS APART FROM URANIUM, COAL AND IRON ORE, HAS ALSO SUBMITTED ITS OWN PROPOSAL TO GOVERNMENT.

THE MMC MANAGING DIRECTOR, YOHANAH BOT KWA, TOLD PANA "THERE ARE DIVERSE MINERAL DEPOSITS IN NIGERIA (32 CURRENTLY) WITH VARIED INDUSTRIAL AND DOMESTIC USES AND THEIR EXPLOITATION CAN CONTRIBUTE TREMENDOUSLY TO NIGERIA'S ECONOMIC RECOVERY."

HE SAID WHAT IS NEEDED IS SUSTAINBLE INVESTMENT IN THE SECTOR.

HE SAID IT WAS TO STIMULATE DEVELOPMENT OF THE MINING SECTOR THAT THE NIGERIAN MINING CORPORATION WAS SET UP IN 1972.

BUT KWA SAID "IT IS PARADOXICAL THAT WHILE NIGERIA HAS BEEN SPENDING SUBSTANTIAL FOREIGN EXCHANGE TO IMPORT VITAL MINERAL RAW MATERIALS, THEREBY ASSISTING OTHER COUNTRIES TO RESUSCITATE THEIR ECONOMIES, IT HAS SIMULTANEOUSLY FAILED TO GRASP AND EXPLOIT THE ABUNDANT OPPORTUNITIES AFFORDED BY THE AVAILBILITY OF THESE RAW MATERIALS LOCALLY."

HE SAID NIGERIA SPENDS ABOUT 800 MILLION DOLLARS A YEAR ON THE IMPORTATION OF RAW MATERIALS BECAUSE OF THE INABILITY OF LOCAL INDUSTRIES TO MEET DOMESTIC NEEDS.

AT THE SAME TIME, HE SAID, THE EXPORT POTENTIAL FOR NIGERIAN MINERALS, AS APPRAISED BY THE CORPORATION, IS MORE THAN 800 MILLION DOLLARS PER ANNUM WITH POTENTIAL INCREASE OF 25 PER CENT IN THE LONG TERM.

MEANWHILE, KWA SAID NIGERIA HAS SO FAR INVESTED MORE THAN FIVE BILLION DOLLARS IN ITS IRON AND STEEL INDUSTRY.

A GREATER PART OF THE AMOUNT, HE SAID, WAS SPENT ON IMPORTING INPUTS SUCH AS IRON ORES, COKING COAL, DOLOMITE, LIMESTONE, CLAYS, MAGNESITE, KYANITE, ZIRCON, GRAPHITE, MANGANESE SELICA SAND AND CHROMITE, ALL OF WHICH ARE AVAILABLE IN THE COUNTRY.

IT IS ESTIMATED BY INDUSTRIALISTS THAT IN ORDER TO FULLY HARNESS THE POTENTIALS OF NIGERIA'S SOLID MINERALS, ABOUT 350 MILLION DOLLARS WOULD BE REQUIRED.

THIS WOULD GO INTO EXPLORATION, APPRAISAL, DEVELOPMENT AND EXPLOITATION OF THE DEPOSITS AS WELL AS THE DEVELOPMENT OF INFRASTRUCTURE SUCH AS ROADS, WATER AMD POWER SUPPLY TO MINING OPERATIONS.

IN THE SHORT TERM, THEY RECOMMEND THAT EMPHASIS BE PLACED ON INDUSTRIAL MINERALS TO SATISFY THE DOMESTIC MARKET.

PROCEEDS FROM THE INDUSTRIAL MINERALS, THE INDUSTRIALISTS SAY, COULD BE USED TO SUSTAIN GROWTH AND PROVIDE EQUITY CAPITAL IN THE LONG TERM PROJECTS WITH EFFORTS GEARED TOWARDS DEVELOPING THE COMPLEX METALLIC MINERALS FOR JOINT CONCERNS BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT AND THE PRIVATE SECTOR.

ON PRIVATE SECTOR PARTICIPATION IN THE MINING VENTURES, KWA SAID "DUE TO THE RISK FACTOR" AND THE LONG GESTATION PERIOD PRIVATE INVESTMENT HAS NOT BEEN FULLY ATTRACTED.

HE CALLED FOR SOME INCENTIVES SUCH AS LOWER TARIFFS AND INTEREST RATES AND ADEQUATE FOREIGN EXCHANGE ALLOCATION FOR THE PURCHASE OF THE NECESSARY MINING INPUTS.

INVESTORS SHOULD ALSO BE ALLOWED TO HOLD 100 PER CENT EQUITY IN MINING VENTURES WITH DRASTIC REDUCTION IN RENT AND FEES, HE ADDED.

TO USE SOLID MINERALS AS A LINCHPIN FOR ECONOMIC RECOVERY, MANY INDUSTRIALISTS SAY NIGERIA MUST DO AWAY WITH "NEGATIVE POLICIES THAT HINDER PRIVATE INVESTMENT" IN THE SECTOR, SUCH AS HIGH RENTS AND FEES WHICH TEND TO ENCOURAGE ILLEGAL MINING.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

April, 1995


NIGERIA: THIRTY EIGHT NIGERIAN COMPANIES FOR DAKAR TRADE FAIR


LENGTH: 280 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (DAKAR)

APRIL, 1995

NIGERIA'S EXPORT PROMOTION COUNCIL HAS CHOSEN 38 COMPANIES TO REPRESENT THE COUNTRY AT THE FIRST ECOWAS TRADE FAIR TO BE HELD IN DAKAR, SENEGAL, NEXT MONTH.

LAGOS COUNCIL MANAGER, JOHNSON OLUMEKUN, SAID THE DECISION HAD BEEN TAKEN IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE NATIONAL COMMITEE PROGRAMME. 

THE PROGRAMME CONSIDERS BUSINESS PROSPECTS FOR THE COMPANIES IN WEST AFRICA AND THEIR FINANCIAL STRENGTH AS MAJOR CRITERIA IN THE SELECTION.

FOLLOWING THE DAKAR FAIR, TO BE HELD FROM 25 MAY TO 4 JUNE, THE EVENT SHOULD TAKE PLACE EACH FOUR YEARS, ACCORDING TO THE ECOWAS HEADS OF STATE RECOMMENDATIONS.

CREATED ON 28 MAY 1975, THE COMMUNITY INCLUDES 16 WEST AFRICAN COUNTRIES: BENIN, BURKINA, CAPE VERDE, COTE D'IVOIRE, GAMBIA, GHANA, GUINEA, GUINEA-BISSAU, LIBERIA, MALI, MAUTITANIA, NIGER, NIGERIA, SENEGAL, SIERRA LEONE AND TOGO.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


137 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


CONTINENT: SOUTHERN AFRICA SETS TOURISM TARGETS


LENGTH: 1400 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY

APRIL 11, 1995

BY FAITH ZABA,PANA CORRESPONDENT

HARARE, ZIMBABWE (PANA) - SOUTHERN AFRICAN COUNTRIES, FACED WITH INCREASED COMPETITION FOR TOURISTS FROM DEVELOPED COUNTRIES, HAVE RESOLVED TO PROMOTE REGIONAL CO-OPERATION IN TOURISM, ONE OF THE FASTEST GROWING ECONOMIC SECTORS IN THE REGION.

ACCOUNTING FOR LESS THAN ONE PERCENT OF THE WORLD TOURISM EARNINGS, THE REGION COULD REALISE BILLIONS OF DOLLARS IF TOURISM OPERATORS ADOPT THE AGGRESSIVE BUSINESS ATTITUDES OF THEIR WESTERN COUNTERPARTS.

ACCORDING TO THE WORLD TOURISM ORGANISATION (WTO), PRELIMINARY RESULTS FOR 1994 INDICATE THAT TOURIST ARRIVALS THROUGHOUT THE WORLD WERE 528 MILLION WITH TOTAL EARNINGS OF USD 40,125 BILLION.

THE REST OF THE WORLD ENJOYED A THREE PERCENT INCREASE IN ARRIVALS WHILE THE AFRICAN CONTINENT HAD A MODEST INCREASE OF 1.5 PERCENT. 

THE SOUTHERN AFRICAN REGION, AS A SINGLE TOURIST DESTINATION, HAS A POTENTIAL TO INCREASE INTERNATIONAL ARRIVALS BY MORE THAN 10 PERCENT AFTER THE END OF APARTHEID IN SOUTH AFRICA LAST YEAR, THE END OF THE CIVIL WAR IN MOZAMBIQUE AND IMPROVED PROSPECTS FOR PEACE IN ANGOLA.

HOTELIERS FROM SIX SOUTHERN AFRICAN COUNTRIES MET IN ZIMBABWE RECENTLY TO DISCUSS STRATEGIES OF BOOSTING REGIONAL CO-OPERATION TO MAKE SOUTHERN AFRICA ONE OF THE PREMIER TOURIST DESTINATIONS ON THE CONTINENT.

HOTELIERS FROM BOTSWANA, LESOTHO, MALAWI, NAMIBIA, ZAMBIA AND ZIMBABWE MET IN ZIMBABWE'S NORTHERN LAKE RESORT TOWN OF KARIBA WHERE THE HOTEL AND RESTAURANT ASSOCIATION OF ZIMBABWE (HARAZ) WAS HOLDING ITS ANNUAL CONGRESS.

THE THEME OF THEIR CONGRESS -- BUILDING BRIDGES -- WAS FOCUSING MORE ON THE NEED FOR REGIONAL CO-OPERATION.

OTHER SOUTHERN AFRICAN COUNTRIES STAND TO BENEFIT A SUBSTANTIAL AMOUNT FROM THE NEWLY INDEPENDENT SOUTH AFRICA, WHICH ENJOYED A 12 PERCENT INCREASE OF TOURIST ARRIVALS LAST YEAR.

AS A RESULT OF THE ADVENT OF PEACE IN THAT COUNTRY, TOURISTS FROM THE UNITED KINGDOM, GERMANY, THE UNITED STATES, FRANCE AND THE FAR EAST ARE NOW FOCUSING ON SOUTH AFRICA AS A TOURIST DESTINATION.

IN SOUTH AFRICA, THE TOURISM INDUSTRY EARNED MORE THAN 12 BILLION RANDS (3.34 BILLION US DOLLARS) WHILE ZIMBABWE, WITH THE NEXT LARGEST INDUSTRY, EARNED 800 ZIMDOLLARS MILLION (USD 100 MILLION).

SOUTH AFRICAN TOURISM BOARD CHIEF EXECUTIVE MAVUSO MSIMANG SAID THERE WAS NEED FOR JOINT MARKETING TO ATTRACT MORE INTERNATIONAL VISITORS TO THE REGION.

"THERE IS AMPLE SPACE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF TOURISM IN OUR REGION AND WE MUST JOIN HANDS AND GET ON WITH THE JOB. TOURISM IS ABOUT BUILDING BRIDGES. LET US USE TOURISM AND OUR UNIQUE AFRICAN HOSPITALITY TO THE BENEFIT OF ALL," HE SAID.

ZIMBABWE'S MINISTER OF ENVIRONMENT AND TOURISM, HERBERT MURERWA, SAID SOUTHERN AFRICAN COUNTRIES SHOULD ADOPT THE CONCEPT OF MULTI-DESTINATION TOURISM.

"WE MUST WORK TOGETHER AND SHARE OUR LIMITED RESOURCES TO ENSURE THE MAXIMUM IMPACT IN THE SOURCE MARKET,'' MURERWA SAID.

THE SOUTHERN AFRICAN REGION COULD MORE THAN DOUBLE ITS ANNUAL EARNINGS IF ITS GOVERNMENTS IMMEDIATELY SCRAPPED VISAS FOR ITS REGIONAL NATIONALS AND RESIDENTS.

ZIMBABWE IS SAID TO BE LOSING MORE THAN 100 MILLION ZIMDOLLARS (USD 12.5 MILLION) IN POTENTIAL TOURISTS FROM SOUTH AFRICA WHO ARE REQUIRED TO PAY 90 RAND (25 US DOLLARS) FOR A SINGLE ENTRY. ZIMBABWEANS, ON THE OTHER HAND, GET FREE VISAS TO ENTER SOUTH AFRICA.

THE RECENTLY CREATED SOUTHERN AFRICA HOSPITALITY ASSOCIATION (SAHA) HAS CALLED ON SOUTHERN AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS TO TAKE IMMEDIATE STEPS TO ABOLISH VISA CHARGES FOR PEOPLE TRAVELLING IN THE REGION.

CURRENT MEMBERS OF SAHA INCLUDE BOTSWANA, MOZAMBIQUE, NAMIBIA, SOUTH AFRICA, ZAMBIA AND ZIMBABWE.

SAHA CHAIRMAN ENZIO ROSSI OF ZAMBIA SAID SOUTHERN AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS SHOULD INTRODUCE A SOUTHERN AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT COMMUNITY (SADC) VISA FOR INTERNATIONAL TOURISTS TO FACILITATE INTERNATIONAL TOURISTS' FREE MOVEMENT WITHIN THE REGION.

ROSSI ALSO URGED GOVERNMENTS IN THE REGION TO INTRODUCE A SADC PASSPORT.

"THE ASSOCIATION BELIEVES THAT THE REGION SHOULD BE MARKETED AS A SINGLE TOURIST DESTINATION IN ORDER TO ACHIEVE ECONOMIES OF SCALE BY, AMONG OTHER THINGS, SELLING REGIONAL PACKAGES COMBINING THE MAJOR TOURIST ATTRACTIONS IN THE REGION," HE SAID.

ONE MAJOR CONCERN WHICH AROSE AT THE CONGRESS WAS THE NEED FOR INCREASED PARTICIPATION OF THE INDIGENOUS PEOPLE IN THE TOURISM INDUSTRY.

THE TOURISM INDUSTRY IN THE REGION IS DOMINATED BY THOSE OF WHITE STOCK -- THIS WAS EVIDENT AT THE CONGRESS WHERE THE RATIO WAS ONE BLACK TO THREE WHITE PARTICIPANTS.

MOST INDIGENOUS PEOPLE IN THE INDUSTRY ARE EMPLOYEES RATHER THAN ENTREPRENEURS.

THERE ARE 319 TOUR OPERATORS IN ZIMBABWE, OF WHICH ONLY 19 ARE BLACK ENTREPRENEURS.

OF THE 19, FIVE PULLED OUT AFTER EXPERIENCING PROBLEMS, 10 ARE RUNNING MINIBUSES, TWO SAFARI AND CANOEING OPERATIONS AND ONE HAS EMPLOYED AGENTS TO RUN HIS OPERATIONS.

ZIMBABWE'S TOURISM MINISTER, MURERWA, SAID HOTELIERS SHOULD ENTER INTO JOINT VENTURES WITH INDIGENOUS PEOPLE.

ON THE SAME ISSUE, HOTEL AND RESTAURANT ASSOCIATION OF ZIMBABWE PRESIDENT PAUL MATAMISA REASSURED WHITES THAT EFFORTS BY GOVERNMENT TO INDIGENISE THE ECONOMY WERE NOT A THREAT BUT WOULD MAKE MORE PEOPLE ECONOMICALLY STRONGER.

"IT IS HIGHLY IMPORTANT TO RECOGNISE THAT INDIGENISATION IS NOT A THREAT TO ANY ONE SECTION OF OUR POPULATION.

"APPLIED FAIRLY AND CORRECTLY, IT WILL BENEFIT US ALL, MAKING MANY MORE PEOPLE ECONOMICALLY STRONGER AND HELPING REDUCE SUCH NEGATIVES AS UNEMPLOYMENT AND POVERTY," HE SAID.

MATAMISA SAID GOVERNMENT HAD A MAJOR ROLE TO PLAY IN ASSISTING BLACK ENTREPRENEURS INTO THE INDUSTRY BY PROVIDING START-UP CAPITAL AND CREATING AN ENABLING ENVIRONMENT.

IT IS ONE THING TO TALK ABOUT THE NEED FOR REGIONAL COOPERATION - THE CHALLENGE IS NOW FOR THE REGION TO DEVELOP SOLID FRAMEWORKS FOR EFFECTIVE CO-OPERATION AND CO-ORDINATION OF THE TOURISM INDUSTRY.

PANA-ZIANA FZ/TGM/DS 11APRIL95 ENG008

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


138 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


BURKINA FASO: BURKINA MEETING URGES NEED FOR WATER MANAGEMENT


LENGTH: 467 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (OUAGADOUGOU)

APRIL 10, 1995

BY ISSA SOMA, PANA CORRESPONDENT

OUAGADOUGOU, BURKINA FASO (PANA) - AN INTERNATIONAL WORKSHOP ON TRADITIONAL WATER MANAGEMENT (GTE) ENDED IN OUAGADOUGOU AT THE WEEKEND STRESSING THAT POLICY MAKERS BE COMMITTED TO THE PROTECTION OF THE RESOURCE.

IN ITS RECOMMENDATIONS, THE MEETING URGED POLICY MAKERS TO ADOPT A 'RESEARCH-ACTION' APPROACH TO ENSURE POPULAR COMMITMENT TO INNOVATIONS IN THE MANAGEMENT OF WATER RESOURCES.

EXPERTS FROM 17 AFRICAN, AMERICAN AND ASIAN COUNTRIES ATTENTED THE MEETING SPONSORED BY UNICEF JOINTLY WITH THE INTERNATIONAL OFFICE FOR WATER (SIE), THE INTERNATIONAL UNION FOR NATURE (UICN) AND THE AFRICAN REGIONAL CENTRE FOR DRINKABLE WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION (CREPA). 

GTE'S NEW DEVELOPMENT PLAN SHOULD RELY, ACCORDING TO RIMA SALAH, THE UNICEF REPRESENTATIVE IN BURKINA FASO, ON THE ENHANCEMENT OF KNOWLEDGE AND A PARTICIPATORY APPROACH THAT TAKES INTO ACCOUNT TRADITIONAL PRACTISES OF WATER MANAGEMENT.

"FOR ANY DEVELOPMENT PLAN TO SUCCEED, LOCAL SKILLS AND KNOW-HOW SHOULD BE TAKEN INTO ACCOUNT AND THE ADDED VALUE GENERATED BY EXPERIENCE PUT TO GOOD USE," SAID SEYDOU SOUARE, THE UICN DIRECTOR.

AT THE END OF THE THREE-DAY MEETING UNICEF PLEDGED TO CIRCULATE THE RECOMMENDATIONS IN ALL THE UNITED NATIONS MEMBER COUNTRIES AND TO SUPPORT ANY INNOVATION AND NEW PROJECT AND HELP IMPROVE SOUTH-SOUTH EXCHANGES ON WATER MANAGEMENT.

THE WORKSHOP WAS ATTENDED BY DELEGATES FROM 11 AFRICAN COUNTRIES (BENIN, BURKINA, COTE D'IVOIRE, GHANA, GUINEE, MALI, MAURITANIA, NIGER, NIGERIA, SENEGAL AND TOGO), THREE AMERICAN COUNTRIES (BRAZIL, CANADA AND MEXICO) AND THREE ASIAN COUNTRIES (INDIA, PAKISTAN, AND SRI LANKA).

PANA IS/KIB/FJG/DS 10APRIL95

FROM THE PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY ENVIRONMENT & DEVELOPMENT BULLETIN

EGYPT: CAIRO'S RINGROAD TO BE REROUTED


LENGTH: 547 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (DAKAR)

APRIL 10, 1995

EGYPT HAS ACCEPTED A PROPOSAL BY THE UNITED NATIONS CULTURAL AGENCY, UNESCO, TO ALTER THE ROUTE OF THE EIGHT-LANE CAIRO RINGROAD WHICH WAS CUT ACROSS THE ANCIENT PYRAMIDS LYING SOUTH OF THE CITY.

THE GOVERNMENT AND THE UN EDUCATIONAL SCIENTIFIC AND CULTURAL ORGANISATION AGREED ON AN ALTERNATE ROUTE RUNNINHG FROM THE NORTH OF THE SITE.

THE WORLD FAMOUS PYRAMIDS HAVE BEEN DECLARED A 'WORLD HERITAGE' SITE BY UNESCO. 

EGYPT ASKED UNESCO EXPERTS TO PROPOSE ANOTHER ROUTE TO DECONGEST DOWNTOWN CAIRO FOLLOWING OBJECTIONS TO THE ORIGINAL PLAY LAY THE ROAD CLOSE TO THE PYRAMIDS.

UNESCO AND EGYPTIAN OFFICIALS MET LAST WEEK TO WORK OUT DETAILS OF THE NEW ROUTE. THE OFFICIALS ALSO HAD TO ENSURE THAT THE PROJECT WAS IN CONFORMITY WITH EGYPTIAN LAWS PASSED IN 1983, WHICH PROTECT THE AREA CLOSE TO THE GISEH PYRAMIDS SOME 4,500 YEARS OLD.

DURING ITS FIVE-DAY VISIT, THE MISSION HAD TALKS WITH A COMMITTEE OF EXPERTS FROM THE MINISTRIES OF CULTURE, DEFENCE, LOCAL ADMINISTRATION, RECONSTRUCTION AND NEW COMMUNITIES, AS WELL AS WITH THE GISEH GOVERNNOR'S OFFICE.

IT WAS FEARED THE FOUR-KILOMETRE FREEWAY WOULD BRING A F GROWTH OF AUTO EXHAUT GASES AND UNACCEPTABLE LEVELS OF VIBRATION THAT WOULD DESTROY THE POLLUTION.

THE PYRAMIDS AND THE GISEH SPHINXES HAVE ALREADY SUFFERED DAMAGE FROM UNPLANNED BUILDING CONSTRUCTION AROUND THE ARES, WASTE DISPOSAL AND TRAFFIC. THEY SUFFER FROM AIR AND CLIMATIC EROSION.

A SECTION OF THE ROAD, WHICH PASSES CLOSE TO THE PYRAMIDS, MIGHT BE DESTROYED THIS WEEK THE SECRETARY GENRAL OF THE EGYPTIAN SUPREME COUNCIL OF ANTIQUITIES, ABDEL HALIM NOUREDDIN, SAID.

THE 14-MILLION DOLLAR ROAD WAS CONCEIVED A DECADE AGO BUT CONSTRUCTION WAS SUSPENDED BY EGYPTIAN PRESIDENT HOSNI MUBARAK FOLLOWING A "PROFOUND DISAGREEMENT" WITH UNESCO.

THE COST OF THE DIVERSION HAS NOT BEEN SPECIFIED. HOWEVER, UNESCO AND EGYPTIAN OFFICIALS SAID IT WAS "A REAL PROBLEM."

PANA KIB/PAP/OSS 10APRIL95 ENG025

FROM THE PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY ENVIRONMENT & DEVELOPMENT BULLETIN

April, 1995


ZAMBIA: FEARS OF GLOBAL WARMING SAID TO BE EXAGGERATED


LENGTH: 800 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (LUSAKA)

APRIL 10, 1995

BY MUSENGWA KAYAYA, PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (PANA) CORRESPONDENT

A NEW STUDY ON THE EFFECTS OF FOSSIL FUEL EMISSIONS ON THE ATMOSPHERE HAS REFUTED COMPUTER PREDICTIONS OF DANGEROUS WARMING OF GLOBAL AVERAGE TEMPERATURES AS EXAGGERATED AND SHOULD BE REJECTED.

"THE OVERWHELMING EVIDENCE IS THAT THE COMPUTER MODELS ARE NOT ABLE TO PREDICT CHANGES IN GLOBAL TEMPERATURE BASED ON CARBON-DIOXIDE LEVELS," SAID SALLIE BALIUNUS, A HAVARD ASTROPHYSICIST AND SENIOR SCIENTIST AT THE MARSHALL INSTITUTE.

THE STUDY WAS RELEASED 3 APRIL BY THE GEORGE C.MARSHALL INSTITUTE IN THE UNITED STATES. 

WEDNESDAY'S ISSUE OF THE WASHINGTON LINE," A UNITED STATES' STATE DEPARTMENT PUBLICATION, QUOTED THE STUDY AS SAYING THAT SCIENTIFIC FACTS FAIL TO SUPPORT POLICYMAKERS CALLING FOR IMMEDIATE LIMITS ON CARBON-DIOXIDE EMISSIONS FROM THE BURNING OF COAL AND OIL.

THE REPORT WAS RELEASED TO COINCIDE WITH THE UNITED NATIONS CLIMATE TREATY CONFERENCE IN THE FUTURE GERMANY CAPITAL, BERLIN.

BALIUNUS IS QUOTED AS SAYING THAT POLICY-MAKERS NEED ACCURATE INFORMATION ABOUT MAN-MADE CARBON DIOXIDE AND ITS POTENTIAL IMPACT ON GLOBAL WARMING.

SCIENTISTS HAVE PREDICTED THAT CURRENT RATES OF FOSSIL FUEL USE COULD RESULT IN DOUBLING OF ATMOSPHERIC CARBON BY LATE IN THE NEXT CENTURY.

COMPUTER SIMULATIONS ON EARTH CLIMATE SHOW SUCH DOUBLING WOULD CAUSE AVERAGE GLOBAL TEMPERATURE TO RISE BY AS MUCH AS THREE DEGREES CENTIGRADE, LEADING IN INCREASE IN COASTAL FLOODING, TROPICAL CYCLONES AND DROUGHT.

HOWEVER, THE MARSHALL STUDY SAYS THAT TEMPERATURE CHANGES OBSERVED OVER THE LAST 50 TO 100 YEARS, IN RESPONSE TO INCREASE IN CARBON-DIOXIDE, SUGGEST THAT TEMPERATURE INCREASES FROM A DOUBLING OF GREENHOUSE GASES WILL BE LESS THAN ONE DEGREE CENTIGRADE AND INDISTINGUISHABLE FROM NATURAL CLIMATE FLUCTUATIONS.

"THE PREDICTED WARMING IS EXAGGERATED BY A LARGE FACTOR. ACCORDING TO THE SCCENTIFIC EVIDENCE, THE WARMING SHOULD BE WELL UNDER ONE DEGREE CENTIGRADE. THIS RISE, SPREAD OVER A CENTURY, WOULD LIKELY BE BEGIGN," BALIUNUS SAID IN HER STUDY.

THE UNITED NATIONS HAS DECLARED A WORLD SOLAR ENERGY DECADE FROM 1996 TO 2005. THIS IS DEDICATED TO THE USE OF SOLAR ENERGY GLOBALLY, MORE SUSTAINABLE AND ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY SOURCE OF POWER COMPARED TO COAL AND OIL.

THESE FOSSIL FUELS ARE BLAMED FOR POLLUTING THE EARTH AND THREATENING MAN'S EXISTENCE.

COAL COMBUSTION HAS BEEN PROVED BY SCIENCE TO PRODUCE ACID RAIN WHICH RESULTS IN THE POLLUTION OF LAKES.

THE WORLD BODY HAS FORMED A WORLD SOLAR COMMISSION CHAIRED BY ZIMBABWEAN PRSSIDENT ROBERT MUGABE TO OVERSEE THE GLOBAL TRANSITION TO MORE USE OF THE SUN A SOURCE OF ENERGY FOR THE FUTURE.

"IT IS ...VITAL THAT VITUALLY FREE PRIMARY ENERGY RESOURCES ARE FOUND AND EXPLOITED AND THE MOST PROMISING OF THESE IS SOLAR ENERY," BORIS BERKOVISKI SAID RECENTLY.

BERKOVISKI, THE DIRECTOR OF ENGINEERING AND TECHNOLOGY DIVISION OF UNESCO, WAS SPEAKING AT AN AFRICAN REGIONAL CONFERENCE OF ENERGY EXPERTS MEETING IN THE ZIMBABWEAN CAPITAL, HARARE TO MAP OUT THE REGION'S UNPUT TO THE WORLD SOLAR DECADE.

PANA MK/OSS 10APRIL95 ENG015

FROM THE PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY ENVIRONMENT & DEVELOPMENT BULLETIN

Africa News


April, 1995


ZIMBABWE: FARMING EXPERTS DISCUSS DRYLAND FARMING TECHNIQUES


LENGTH: 520 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (MASVINGO)

APRIL, 1995

LAND AND WATER MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES ARE THE ONLY VIABLE WAY OF ENSURING SUCCESS FOR SMALL-SCALE FARMERS IN THE SEMI-ARID PARTS OF THE COUNTRY, AGRICULTURAL EXPERTS ENDING A WORKSHOP ON SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION HAVE AGREED.

EXPERTS RULED OUT IRRIGATION BECAUSE IT WAS COSTLY. THE OFTEN CASH-STRAPPED FARMERS HAVE TO RELY ON LIMITED, ERRATIC RAINFALL. 

THEY SAID THAT DIFFERENT TILLAGE TECHNIQUES HAD PROVED HIGHLY VARIABLE DEPENDING ON SOIL AND SITE.

"TO ADDRESS THE PROBLEM OF HIGH VARIABILITY OF CONDITIONS, DIFFERENT TECHNIQUES AND SYSTEMS SHOULD BE PROMOTED AS OPTIONS RATHER THAN BLANKET RECOMMENDATIONS," THEY SAID,

FARMERS, THEY ADDED, SHOULD BE ENCOURAGED TO SELECT, TEST AND EXPERIMENT WITH OPTIONS "IN ORDER TO ADAPT TECHNOLOGIES TO THEIR SPECIFIC NEEDS AND CONDITIONS."

THE SPECIALISTS AGREED THAT HIGH WATER LOSSES FROM ARABLE LAND THROUGH SURFACE RUN-OFF AND RAMPANT SOIL LOSS THROUGH SHEET EROSION DIMINISHED THE LOW AGRICULTURAL POTENTIAL OF THESE AREAS, CHARACTERISED BY GENERALLY SANDY AND INFERTILE SOILS.

TRAINING OF FARMERS SHOULD BE BASED ON TEACHING OF PROCESSES AND SHARING OF AVAILABLE FARMER KNOWLEDGE RATHER THAN TEACHING OF TECHNIQUES.

THE FIVE-DAY WORKSHOP WAS CONVENED IN THE WAKE OF RAMPANT LAND DEGRADATION THAT HAS SEEN YIELDS PLUMMET AND FARMER MORALE SINK IN ZIMBABWE'S SEMI-ARID NATURAL REGIONS FOUR AND FIVE.

THE MAJORITY OF COMMUNAL FARMERS IN ZIMBABWE LIVE AND FARM IN THESE REGIONS WITH AN AVERAGE ANNUAL RAINFALL OF 600 MILLIMETRES OR LESS.

ALTHOUGH THE ANNUAL RAINFALL IS LOW, THE INTENSITY OF THE RAINFALL OFTEN EXCEEDS THE INFILTRATION RATE OF THE SOIL. THEREFORE, MUCH RUN-OFF OCCURS EXPOSING THE SOIL TO VARIOUS FORMS OF EROSION.

THE WORKSHOP WAS SPONSORED BY THE GERMAN TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO ZIMBABWE. IT DREW AT LEAST 60 PARTICIPANTS FROM THE FARMING COMMUNITY, RESEARCH INSTITUTIONS AND DEVELOPMENT AGENCIES.

FROM THE PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY ENVIRONMENT & DEVELOPMENT BULLETIN

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


April, 1995


ZIMBABWE: ZIMBABWE GOVT TO EMBARK ON MULTI-BILLION PROGRAMME


LENGTH: 494 words


 

PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (BULAWAYO)

APRIL 10, 1995

ZIMBABWE VICE-PRESIDENT JOSHUA NKOMO HAS UNVEILED A MULTI-BILLION PROGRAMME TO GIVE A FACE LIFT TO CITIES OF HARARE AND BULAWAYO.

HE SAID GOVERNMENT WOULD BEGIN BUILDING SATELLITE TOWNS THIS YEAR IN THE URBAN CENTRES WITH IMPROVED HOUSING DESIGNS. THE PROJECT INCLUDES INDUSTRIAL CENTRES THAT WOULD FURTHER BLACK ADVANCEMENT INTO THE MAINSTREAM OF THE WHITE DOMINATED ECONOMY. 

ALTHOUGH THE LAND FOR THE PROJECTS HAD ALREADY BEEN IDENTIFIED IN BOTH CITIES, WHICH TOGETHER HAVE AN ESTIMATED 1.14 MILLION PEOPLE, MUNICIPALITIES HAD NOT BEEN APPROACHED. HOWEVER, THEY WOULD BE EXPECTED TO TAKE PART.

THE PROGRAMME WILL EMPHASISE PRODUCTION OF MODERN STRUCTURES THAT WILL REMAIN ACCEPTABLE OVER MANY YEARS.

"WHAT THE BULAWAYO CITY COUNCIL DID IN NKETA AND NKULUMANE IS A TRAGEDY THAT WE WILL AVOID IN THE NEW TOWN," NKOMO SAID.

THE SATELLITE TOWN WILL STRETCH FROM MAKOKOBA, BULAWAYO'S OLDEST TOWNSHIP, WHICH WILL BE DEMOLISHED AND REBUILT, TO GREENSPAN THAT IS AT THE MOMENT AN EXPANSE OF MAIZE FIELDS.

UNLIKE PRESENT HOUSING SCHEMES THAT WERE DIVORCED FROM EMPLOYMENT CREATION, THE NEW TOWNS WILL BE PLANNED IN SUCH A MANNER THAT DWELLERS WILL BE GET WORK AND AFFORD RENTS.

THE PRESENT SCHEMES, NKOMO SAID, SOON BECAME A FARCE AFTER STANDS AND HOUSES WERE REPOSSESSED WHEN PEOPLE FAILED TO SERVICE THE MORTGAGES, LEAVING THEM HOMELESS.

ZIMBABWE NEEDS 84,000 NEW HOUSES EVERY YEAR TO MEET URBAN DEMAND OVER THE NEXT 10 YEARS, WHILE OVER 33 PER CENT OF THE POPULATION IS UNEMPLOYED.

NKOMO SAID THE EXISTING TOWNS WERE DOMINATED BY NON-AFRICANS WHOM THE GOVERNMENT DID NOT WANT TO PUSH OUT BUT WAS CREATING COMPETITION FOR THEM.

THE PROGRAMME, HE SAID, WAS A STATE PROJECT THAT HAD NOTHING TO DO WITH THE DEVELOPMENT TRUST OF ZIMBABWE WHICH HE CHAIRS.

PANA-ZIANA SJM/TN/MP/OSS 10APRIL95

FROM THE PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY ENVIRONMENT & DEVELOPMENT BULLETIN

Africa News


April, 1995


CONTINENT: AFRICAN PRESS REVIEW - WEEK OF APRIL 7, 1995


LENGTH: 1520 words


 

BY OLU SARR, PAN AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (PANA) CORRESPONDENT

DAKAR, SENEGAL (PANA) - WHILE THERE MAY BE NOTHING FUNNY ABOUT THE SPATE OF ETHNIC KILLINGS IN BURUNDI, A NEW WEEKLY NEWAPAPER THERE USED A CARTOON TO ILLUSTRATE THE GRAVITY OF THIS PROBLEM.

IN ITS FIRST ISSUE BUJUMBURA'S PRO-TUTSI 'L'OBSERVATEUR' ILLUSTRATED THE SOMEWHAT UNEASY COHABITATION BETWEEN HUTU HEAD OF STATE SYLVESTRE NTIBANTUNGANYA AND HIS TUTSI PRIME MINISTER, ANTOINE NDUWAYO.

UNDER THE TITLE "TWO BULLS IN THE ARENA" THE 12-PAGE TABLOID SHOWED BOTH MEN IN SHORTS, BOXING GLOVES ON AND READY TO DRAW BLOOD. NTIBANTUNGANYA WAS SHOWN CLUTCHING A HAND GRENADE BEHIND HIS BACK PRIMED AND READY TO BE HURLED AT NDUWAYO. 

THEN, SHOWING THEIR VASTLY DIFFERENT VIEWS ON POLICY, IT HAD NDUWAYO SAYING, "I SHOULD HUNT AND DESTROY ALL ARMED HUTU BANDITS."

NTIBANTUNGANYA REPLIES, "I SHOULD OVERHAUL THE TUTSI DOMINATED ARMY."

THE ARMY WAS SUBJECT FOR MORE ANALYSIS IN THE PAPER'S INSIDE PAGES. WHILE EXPLAINING TUTSI PRE-EMINENCE IN THE ARMY, L'OBSERVATEUR SAID IT WAS UNTRUE THAT IT WAS ENTIRELY SO.

THE HEAVY TUTSI PRESENCE IN THE ARMY OVER THE PAST 30 YEARS, IT CLAIMED, WAS BECAUSE THEY SOUGHT PROTECTION FORM EXTERMINATION BY THE HUTU.

"THIS PREDOMINANCE OF TUTSI IN THE ARMY, THEREFORE, PROVOKED FEAR AMONG THE HUTU," IT SAID.

THESE FEARS WERE UNJUSTIFIED, IT SAID, ESPECIALLY SINCE HUTUS HAVE TAKEN TEST THIS YEAR FOR ENTRY INTO DIFFERENT RANKS OF THE ARMY.

CONCLUDING, IT CLAIMED "THE TUTSI DOMINATION IN DIFFERENT ARMY UNITS IS SIMPLY DUE TO THE HUTU'S OWN WISH TO STAY OUT."

IN ANOTHER TROUBLESOME COUNTRY, NIGER, PAPERS COMMENTED ON THE NEGOTIATIONS IN BURKINA FASO BETWEEN GOVERNMENT AND TUAREGS REBELS. SOME HAD SOMETHING TO SAY ABOUT THE CHANGE OF LEADERSHIP OF THE UNITED TUAREG FRONT.

THE WEEKLY 'LE REPUBLICAN' OF NIAMEY NOTED THAT THE REPLACEMENT OF MANO DAYAK BY RHISSA BOULA AS HEAD OF THE TUAREG RESISTANCE HAD NOT STOPPED THE PEACE TALKS.

ANOTHER NIAMEY WEEKLY 'LE DEMOCRATE' EXPLAINED THE LEADERSHIP CHANGE THIS WAY: AS AN AGREEMENT DRAWS INEVITABLY NEARER BOULA, A MAN OF THE PEOPLE, WISHES "TO SHARE SOME OF THE FRUITS" OF PEACE.

IT SAID THAT BOULA MAY WELL DESERVE TO GAIN SOMETHING OUT OF PEACE SINCE HE HAS SACRIFICED MORE THAN DAYAK, WHO PASSES HIS TIME PLAYING THE STAR ON EUROPEAN TELEVISION.

"IT IS RIGHT TO REPLACE THE HEAD OF THE ORGANISATION OF THE ARMED RESISTANCE," IT SAID.

BECAUSE OF HIS POPULARITY AMONG THE PEOPLE, IT SAID, HE IS THE BEST MAN TO ASK FOR AN INTERNATIONAL COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO THE MASSACRES OF TCHINTEBARADEN, THE RELEASE OF TUAREG PRISONERS, DEVELOPMENT FOR TUAREG AREAS AND THE DISARMING OF THE ARAB MILITIA.

FOR ITS PART, TOGOLESE NEWSPAPERS COMMENTED ON BENIN'S LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS WHICH WERE FREE OF ARGUMENT AND VIOLENCE. ONE PAPER NOTED THAT THERE WERE NO SOLDIERS AROUND AND ORDER WAS MAINTAINED BY VILLAGE CHIEFS THROUGHOUT POLLING.

THE PAPER, THE WEEKLY 'MOTION D'INFORMATION', TERMED BENIN'S EXPERIENCE "A LESSON IN DEMOCRACY AND GOOD CITIZENSHIP" FOR TOGO.

"IT WAS ADMIRABLE. IT (EXEMPLIFIED) THE DETERMINATION OF VOTERS FOR CLEAN ELECTIONS," IT SAID.

"IN TOGO, OUR LEADERS HAVE NOT YET ATTAINED THIS LEVEL OF MATURITY," IT SAID.

IN TOGO, IT WENT ON, EVEN TASKS AS SIMPLE AS UPDATING ELECTORAL LISTS TURNS INTO VIOLENCE WHICH EVENTUALLY BRING POLICE, SOLDIERS, GERNDARMES AND EVEN ARMY VETERANS INTO TAKING PART IN ELECTORAL FRAUD.

THE VANGUARD OF LAGOS COMMENTED ON WHAT IT CALLED NIGERIA'S LIBERIAN ADVENTURE.

IT WONDERED IF THE COUNTRY COULD SUSTAIN THE 660,000 NAIRA (30,000 U.S. DOLLARS) DAILY TO FEED ABOUT 6,000 TROOPS IN LIBERIA.

"WHEN OTHER COSTS SUCH AS MILITARY HARDWARE, TRANSPORTATION, COMMUNICATIONS AND SUNDRY EXPENSES ARE CALCULATED FOR ALMOST FIVE YEARS DURING WHICH NIGERIA HAS BEEN PART OF ECOMOG, THE COST MUST BE MIND-BOGGLING," HE SAID.

IT NOTED THAT TANZANIA AND UGANDA WERE PULLING OUT OF THE OPERATION BECAUSE "THE INTRASINGENCE OF THE LIBERIAN WARLORDS CAN NO LONGER BE TOLERATED."

OPTIONS OPEN TO NIGERIA, IT SAID, INCLUDED AN ULTIMATUM TO THE WARLORDS THAT THE PRESENT PEACE PROCESS "WILL BE THE LAST OPPORTUNITY OR WE PULL OUT."

IT CONCLUDED: "WE HAVE TO BE COST-CONSCIOUS AS OUR RESOURCES ARE LIMITED. THIS THE LIBERIANS MUST BE MADE TO UNDERSTAND."

CUTTING COSTS AND AMASSING WEALTH WERE ALSO THE PREOCCUPATION OF DAKAR'S 'LE SOLEIL' WHEN COMMENTING ON SENEGAL'S 35TH INDEPENDENCE ANNIVERSARY OF THE COUNTRY.

"GENERATING WEALTH SHOULD BECOME OUR LEITMOTIF, OUR PERSONAL AND COLLECTIVE OBSESSION, OUR STRONG YEARNING," IT SAID.

"IN THIS RESPECT THE MOST DIFFICULT THING IS TO BEGIN," IT SAID.

TURNING TO JIMMY CARTER'S BATTLE AGAINST THE GUINEA-WORMS, THE VANGUARD NOTED THAT THE INFECTION DROPPED FROM 700,000 TO 36,000 CASES IN ONE YEAR.

THIS RESULT BY CARTER'S GLOBAL 2000, IT SAID, WAS "A MONUMENTAL ACHIEVEMENT."

IT SAID, "WE COMMEND THE DRIVE, DEDICATED AND COMMITMENT WHICH FORMER PRESIDENT CARTER HAS BROUGHT INTO THE PROJECT."

GOVERNMENTS AT VARIOUS LEVELS IN NIGERIA MUST, IT SAID, SUPPORT "THIS WORTHY PROJECT" BY PROVIDING SAFE AND POTABLE DRINKING WATER FOR THE PEOPLE. HEALTH OFFICIALS AT LOCAL LEVELS "MUST ALSO INTENSIFY CAMPAIGNS" TO PREVENT THE DISEASE FROM SPREADING.

"THIS IS THE LEAST WE CAN DO TO SHOW THAT EFFORTS BY MR. CARTER AND HIS ORGANISATION WILL NOT BE IN VAIN," IT SAID.

THE 'DAILY TIMES', A SEMI-OFFICIAL LAGOS PAPER, COMMENTED ON CARTER'S VISIT AND HIS DIPLOMACY ON THE FATE OF CERTAIN POLITICAL DETAINEES AND THE COUNTRY'S DEMOCRATIC PROCESS.

SOME OF CARTER'S CALLS, SUCH AS A 1997 RETURN OF THE MILITARY TO THE BARRACKS, WERE CONTROVERSIAL. BUT THE PAPER SAID "HOWEVER ONE ASSESSES THE PITCH, THRUST AND CONSEQUENCES OF MR. CARTER'S INTERVENTIONS, IT IS DIFFICULT TO DENY THEIR REFRESHINGLY MEEK AND HUMANE TOUCH."

IN ADDITION, IT SAID, "HIS APPROACH ALSO CONSTITUTES A HEALTHY BREAK FROM THE SOMEWHAT UNEASY CONTEXT OF NIGERIA-UNITED STATES RELATIONS IN THE LAST FEW YEARS."

IT NOTED CARTER'S CONCERN FOR WORLD PEACE AND FOR AFRICA, THE ONLY UNITED STATES PRESIDENT TO HAVE VISITED THIS CONTINENT.

"IN THE STRUGGLE TO BUILD A FAIRER WORLD ACTUATED BY NOBLER AND GENTLER INSTINCTS, THE PROMISES OF CARTER'S PEACEMAKING AND CONSTRUCTIVE ETHOS DESERVE DISTINCT APPRECIATION ESPECIALLY GIVEN BOTH HIS WEALTH OF EXPERIENCE AS A FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT AND HIS STATUS AS A GLOBAL DIPLOMAT." IT SAID.

PANA OSS/PBM 7APRIL95
