Africa News


April, 1995


ZAIRE: A Health Insurance Scheme for Zaire


LENGTH: 694 words


 

World Health Magazine (Geneva)

November-December, 1994

by N. Sema Hurugo

A health insurance society has been in existence in Zaire since 1986. It was started by the Bwamanda Centre for Integrated Development to counter the difficulties which the district's rural population faced in having no fixed income to pay for hospital care, and also to compensate for reduced eternal financing.

Membership of the Mutual Society, a true health insurance scheme, is not obligatory. So people have to be made aware of its value and convinced that sickness is a risk inherent in life which they must make provision for so that, when it does occur, they are prepared against the unforeseeable aspects - its gravity, duration, overall cost and economic consequences, and the professional and moral impact. 

The registering of new members took place in March each year, the period when both the Center for Integrated Development and the traders are engaged in buying agricultural produce. The peasants therefore have some income and can afford the annual premium. This premium takes account of local purchasing power and is fixed empirically at a sum equivalent to the price of two to three kilograms of soya per year and per individual.

When an individual signs up with the Society, he or she is also obliged to sign up all the family members, each paying an individual premium. So members are in family units and today include 60% of the population of Bwamanda.

The health centres maintain files on each family and it is they who refer the sick to hospital, with a transfer coupon affirming that they are Mutual Society member. The Society covers all their hospital and some primary care dispensed at the health centres, particularly for tuberculosis, heart diseases, leprosy and childbirth.

The success of Bwamanda's Mutual Society is due principally to three factors: participation of the community and the agencies of the medical service and of rural development in all stages of the process, from conception to organization; the trust existing between the community and the medical service, thanks especially to the quality of health care offered and to such other activities of the Centre for Integrated Development at a farming, digging of wells and rural promotion drives; the investment of the funds collected in the purchase of drugs. The existence of a well run regional pharmacy helps to ensure that the contributions collected are well spent.

Fully accepted and understood by the people of Bwamanda, the Society has already shown good results. It gives people greater access to health care by covering 80% of all outpatient and hospital treatment. It has much improved the finances of the general referral hospital by ensuring that t 70% of the costs are recouped, a remarkable feat considering the social and economic crisis at present facing Zaire. Finally by encouraging those who are well to pay for those who are sick, it represents a real attempt to promote community solidarity.

World Health Magazine is published by World Health Organization, CH-1211 Geneva 27, Switzerland.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


145 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


SUDAN: Human Rights Commission Renews Rapporteur's Mandate


LENGTH: 1774 words


 

Sudan Democratic Gazette (London)

April, 1995

Despite the Khartoum regime's refusal to work with the United Nations Human Rights Commission's Special Rapporteur, Gaspar Biro, throughout the whole of 1994, the commission still found growing evidence of human rights abuses in Sudan and so voted on 8 March to condemn this record and to renew Mr. Biro's mandate for another year. Thirty-three countries out of a total of fifty-three voted to condemn Sudan. Only seven countries voted against, ten abstained and three absented themselves from the vote.

Even more so than in previous years, the Khartoum regime finds itself isolated internationally. Those countries who voted against the resolution were notable for their own poor records on human rights; namely China, Cuba, India, Indonesia, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. The seventh vote was cast by the Khartoum regime itself. 

More African Condemnation

Although it was disappointing that only Mauritius out of all the African countries present joined with the twenty-one European countries, Japan and the USA, to sponsor the resolution, the actual voting record of African countries on the resolution itself was an improvement on last year. Of the fifteen African members of the commission apart from Sudan, seven voted to condemn Sudan. These were: Algeria, Benin, Cameroon, Gabon, Malawi, Mauritius and Zimbabwe. Five countries abstained. These were Angola, Cote d'Ivoire, Egypt, Ethiopia and Togo. Of these, only Ethiopia's position as one of the mediators in the IGADD process had real justification for an abstention.

Egypt acted more responsibly this year than last by abstaining rather than absenting themselves. Egypt's position has always been a difficult one due to its close ties with Sudan. The Khartoum regime regularly tries to blackmail the Cairo administration into supporting its position by trying to bring Egypt's own dubious human rights record before the commission.

Like Egypt, Mauritania has its own reasons for abstaining. The country has been exposed as one of the few states where slavery is still practiced, and so it would have found it difficult to support a resolution which criticises the re-emergence of slavery in Sudan. The abstentions of Cote d'Ivoire, Angola and Togo are less easy to explain. Togo is one of the emerging democracies in Africa and its failure to support human rights issues at the UN casts doubt on its ongoing democratic experiment.

In presenting his report to the commission, Dr. Biro regretted that the Khartoum regime had failed to co-operate with him during 1994. He observed that he was nonetheless able to collect information and data on human rights abuses during field visits to Sudan's neighbours, Egypt, Uganda and Kenya, as well as through talking to Sudanese, UN and international humanitarian agencies. He observed that the human rights situation in Sudan has not improved during 1994. In some areas, it has deteriorated. He gave as an example of this deterioration the regime's aerial bombardment of civilian targets inside Southern Sudan.

The special rapporteur emphasised the plight of the most vulnerable groups: children, women and the elderly. He wrote: "In this introductory statement I want very much to emphasise the sad situation of the most defenceless victims of all sorts of abuses and violations throughout the whole country: the women and the children. Particularly in the North, displaced women and children are affected by the most atrocious practices by government agents. Nubians are perhaps the most prominent within this category of victims: reports on abduction of children fro the Nuba Mountains continued to arrive during the past year. Cruelty, ruthlessness and arbitrariness are the most important characteristics of these actions. On 15 October 1994, for instance, scores of settlers in Omdurman, protesting a new campaign of destruction of houses by bulldozers and the forced resettlement of squatters by the authorities, were disbursed by force by the Sudanese security forces. These forces shot indiscriminately into the unarmed crowd, which included women and children, leaving 5 squatters and seriously injuring more than 25 others. In the South, according to 1994 UNICEF estimates, around 500,000 minors are in danger because of the war. Any shortages due to forced suspension of humanitarian assistance have direct repercussions on women and children firstly. On 8 January 1995 for instance, UN and NGO staff were relocated from Maiwut following the Government's withdrawal of the location from the Operation Lifeline Sudan (OLS) flight clearance list for the month of January. OLS considered that because of this situation approximately 10,900 residents and displaced persons were placed at risk, including over 1,000 unaccompanied minors who were receiving assistance from among others UNICEF and WFP. It is worth mentioning while the number of people in need of emergency food aid in Sudan has dropped from 4.3 million in 1994 to 1.2 million, of which some 720,000 are in Southern Sudan, OLS estimated at the end of January 1995 that an intensification of the fighting in Equatoria, Bahr al Ghazal and Upper Nile provinces may force thousands of people to abandon their harvest and run for safety."

Comprehensive Resolution

This year's resolution condemning human rights abuse in Sudan was more comprehensive than in previous years. The resolution included terms on slavery and support for the IGADD regional peace process amongst its main points. The document:

"Expresses its deep concern at continued serious human rights violations in the Sudan, including summary executions, extrajudicial killings, arbitrary arrests, detentions without due process, violations of the rights of women and children, slavery and slavery -like practices, forced displacement of persons and systematic torture;...

"Urges the Government of the Sudan fully to respect human rights, and calls upon all parties to cooperated in order to ensure such respect;...

"Calls upon the Government of the Sudan to cease immediately the deliberate and indiscriminate aerial bombardment of civilian targets;...

"Noting with deep concern reports of grave human rights violations in the Sudan, particularly summary executions, detentions without trial, forced displacement of persons and torture, as described in, "inter alia", recent reports submitted to the Commission on Human Rights by the Special Rapporteur on the question of torture, the Special Rapporteur on the question of religious intolerance, ...

"Deplores the fact that, following its interference with the Special Rapporteur's visit in 1993, the Government of the Sudan has persisted in its refusal to cooperate with the Special Rapporteur in his efforts to carry out his mandate in full, in particular by denying him the right to visit the Sudan;...

"Urges the Government of the Sudan to release all political detainees and prisoner, cease all acts of torture and cruel, inhuman and degrading punishment and close down all clandestine or unacknowledged detention centres, and to ensure that all accused persons are held in the custody of ordinary police or prison authorities where family members and lawyers can visit them and that such persons receive just and fair trials under internationally recognised standards;..."

Per haps the two new and most striking features of the commission's resolution on Sudan are the clear statement on slavery and the endorsement of the IGADD peace initiative. On slavery, the resolution:

"Urges the Government of the Sudan to terminate policies or activities which support, condone, encourage or foster the sale of or trafficking in children, the separation of children from their families and social backgrounds, or which subject children to forced internment, indoctrination or cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment;

"Calls upon the government of the Sudan to work actively for the eradication of practices which are directed against and particularly violate the human rights of women and girls, and welcomes activities by any local or women's groups towards that end, as reported by the Special Rapporteur;..."

On the IGADD initiative the commission:

"Notes with appreciation the current regional effort of the heads of State of the Intergovernmental Authority on Draught and Development (Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya and Uganda) to assist parties to the conflict in the Sudan to reach a peaceful settlement;

"Urges all parties to the conflict to agree to an immediate cease-fire and to co-operate fully with the present regional initiative of the heads of State of the Intergovernmental Authority on Drought and Development:

Sudan Democratic Gazette is published at PO Box 2295, London w14 ond, U.K.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).

LANGUAGE: English

146 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


PRESIDENT NELSON MANDELA AT SOUTH AFRICAN FREEDOM DAY CELEBRATIONS


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

April 27, 1995

Pretoria

Honourable Ministers; Premier of the Gauteng Province; Councillors of Pretoria and Johannesburg; Friends from abroad and the diplomatic corps; Distinguished Guests;

Fellow South Africans;

As dawn ushered in this day, the 27th of April, 1995, few of us could suppress the welling of emotion, as we were reminded of the terrible past from which we come as a nation; the great possibilities that we now have; and the bright future that beckons us.

And so we assemble here today, and in other parts of the country, to mark a historic day in the life of our nation. Wherever South Africans are across the globe, our hearts beat as one, as we renew our common loyalty to our country and our commitment to its future.

The birth of our South African nation has, like any other, passed through a long and often painful process. The ultimate goal of a better life has yet to be realised. 

But if any one day marked the crossing of the divide from a past of conflict and division to the possibility of unity and peace; from inequality to equality; from a history of oppression to a future of freedom, it is 27 April 1994.

On this day, you, the people, took your destiny into your own hands. You decided that nothing would prevent you from exercising your hard-won right to elect a government of your choice. Your patience, your discipline, your single-minded purposefulness have become a legend throughout the world.

You won this respect because you made the simple but profound statement that the time had come for the people to govern. You turned our diversity from a weakness to be exploited for selfish ends; into a richness to be celebrated for the good of all.

Today, we meet to reaffirm that we are one people with one destiny; a destiny that we can now shape together from the sweat of our brows.

Dear compatriots;

We have learnt over the First Freedom Year that there is no short-cut to making South Africa the country of our dreams. It requires hard work by those entrusted with positions of responsibility in government. It demands that workers and employers work together to produce efficiently and compete with the best in the world, to achieve equity and to help create more jobs. It requires hard work on the part of farmers and farm-workers, to feed the nation and provide raw materials, even in the face of adversity. It requires hard work by students and teachers to build a literate, skilled and learned nation. It requires greater exertion by our sports-persons and artists to always offer the best for the country and its people. It demands of all of us, wherever we may be, to exercise our rights as citizens; and do so without infringing on the rights of others.

South Africa is firmly set on the road to peace and prosperity.

In the spirit of Masakhane, w must, as a nation, strive to do better, and even better, all the time. This is the challenge that we face, as we enter the Second Freedom Year.

The rights that we now enjoy should be improved as we draft the new constitution. And you, and only you, can ensure that the Constitutional Assembly produces what is best for the country. We must ensure that democracy reaches our localities, at work and everywhere we interact. To make the RDP work, we must all register for the November Local Government elections.

On its part, Government is finalising guidelines for next year's budget: to ensure greater spending on education, health, housing and other needs. We are determined that public funds must be spent responsibly and in an open fashion.

The projects we have started in Odi-Moretele, Weenen, Ibhayi, the East Rand, Kutama-Sinthumule, Mogopa and other areas have shown that the people, working together with government, can improve their lives.

The phasing in of free education; free medical care to children under six and pregnant mothers; the school nutrition scheme; land restitution - all these and others are the beginnings of programmes to give freedom real meaning.

In the Second Freedom year, we must speed up these programmes; cut down on bureaucratic red tape; ensure that there are community structures to manage them; and direct more relief to the Fellow South Africans; 27 April bequeathed us the supreme bodies to make laws and guard our democratic rights.

As we move into the Second Freedom Year, our democracy will be strengthened by the welcome role of bodies such as the Constitutional Court, Human Rights Commission and the soon-to-be-established Truth and Reconciliation Commission, not only to correct past wrongs, but also to create a better future. In the same vein, we shall need more systematic work in parliament to complete the legal framework needed for transformation.

But freedom would be meaningless without security in the home and in the streets.

It is for this reason that government has set in motion a plan to deal firmly with crime and violence. Discussions have been completed to allocate more resources for the training of police officers, improving facilities in areas ignored under apartheid, and to facilitate the setting up of more Police Community Forums. These funds will be acquired both from the shifting of priorities in the ministry concerned, and from the RDP Fund.

In the spirit of Masakhane, where communities succeed in co-operating with the police to bring down the levels of crime, and where they ensure that services are paid for, serious consideration will be given to increase the investment of public funds in these localities.

We thank the security forces, whose support for the process of change has been invaluable.

In the spirit of goodwill that accompanies this, our first Freedom Day, I have decided to grant amnesty to the following categories of prisoners: Firstly, a special remission of sentences of one quarter for all prisoners with a maximum remission of six months. This amnesty will not apply to prisoners sentenced for child abuse.

Secondly, a remission of sentences on all persons who were charged solely for the possession, before 6 December 1993, of arms, ammunition, explosives and explosive devices, associated with political conflicts of the past, irrespective of their political affiliation.

These measures will come into effect as soon as the Departments concerned have completed the necessary administrative procedures. We hope that through this act of goodwill, we are sending message to all prisoners that they should mend their ways and make a fresh start. We appeal to society to help them resettle in communities as responsible and law-abiding citizens.

Fellow compatriots; Over the past year we have confounded the prophets of doom; and we shall do so for many, many more years to come. On behalf of the Government of National Unity, I wish to thank all South Africans who have made this, our miracle possible. As a nation, we extend our gratitude to the international community whose force of example, encouragement and support has strengthened us in this difficult task.

I also wish to congratulate Minister Ben Ngubane and his team for the excellent work they have done to make this celebration the success that it promises to be. Theirs has been a lofty example of united action in the national interest.

As our nation did a year ago, let each community take its destiny into its own hands by ensuring that everyone registers as a voter by the 1st of June.

Enriched by the experience of the First Freedom Year, let us work together, with each other and for each other, in the spirit of Masakhane!

Issued by: Office of the President

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).

Africa News


April, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Soccer: Borman bounces back


LENGTH: 1814 words


 

Weekly Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

April 21, 1995

by Clinton Asary

The game of soccer, as it is so often said, is very unpredictable -- though these days in places like Malaysia this trend is changing.

Here at home, however, as in most parts of the world, it is still as unpredictable as ever. Ask Randal Borman (20) the Cape Town Spurs and national U23 striker.

Borman went into last Saturday's Olympic qualifing first leg tie against Burundi at Milpark as the home side's kingpin, having scored in three consecutive games for the Sasol Super Squad. The "hopes of the nation" appeared to have been placed squarely on his shoulders. 

But in an interview shortly before the game, Borman, maybe in foresight, remarked on the ups and downs of the game: "You never know with soccer, one minute you are on top and then suddenly you get a kick," he said.

And how true it proved to be, 90 minutes later Borman went from hero to villain as he first squandered a golden opportunity, driving the ball over the top after he had rounded the goalkeeper, and then, seven minutes from the end, he missed a penalty.

"With the first chance I was off balance and shot with my weaker foot, but the penalty I shot straight at the goalkeeper, hoping he would dive into one of the corners," he said.

But it is unlikely that the disappointment against Burundi will keep the talented Capetonian down.

Borman's uncle Daniel, or "Dot" as he was popularly known, terrorised defences on the Cape Flats as a youngster, then as a professional with Glendene in the old FPL and Randal is looking to do the same but on a much higher level.

An injury to Spurs' star striker Shaun Bartlett has seen Borman slot into the striker's position, and do what he does best, score goals. "I have set myself a target of 15 to 20 goals for the season, if I play regularly I am sure I can achieve it," he said.

Borman feels that Spurs have put last season's disappointment behind them and are aiming to go one better than the two cup semifinals and losing the league by a point. "We have a good team, with players like Zane Alexander and Andre Arendse, who are playing well, we should do well again this season. But we have to play more as a unit and not individuals."

Like any young player Borman also has overseas ambitions, "Before the end of the season I would like to go overseas for trials, just for the experience. If I get a contract though, I will gladly accept it," he said.

But for now Borman is working on achieving his main goal for this season, "I want to make the senior national squad, hopefully by the end of this season ."

Rugby: For the love of the game -- and money by Michael McMurray

They love rugby in Pretoria and as the World Cup approaches many budding entrepreneurs are showing they love money just as much

WITH the same mischievous twinkle that a naughty schoolgirl might have in her eyes, Francina de Kock confesses that she doesn't pay to watch any of the rugby matches played at Loftus Versfeld.

"During half-time I follow the catering van into gate five and nobody ever stops me. They probably feel sorry for me," she admits.

At the ripe old age of 81 Francina surely ranks as one of Pretoria's oldest female rugby supporters, but it's highly unlikely that she will be able to "sneak" through the gates when security measures are tightened at the stadium in preparation for the World Cup in May.

Pretoria is a buzz of excitement as residents eagerly wait in anticipation for the kick-off of one of the world's most hyped and greatest sporting events.

Not only rugby fans are getting caught up in World Cup fever but also those out to make a fast buck from what they are hoping will be a literal flood of foreign currency streaming into the capital.

Says Marie Pretorius, manageress of the Oorkant Loftus guest house, "I will be increasing my rates for the World Cup period but I'm not out to rob anyone blind."

A Sunnyside woman who refused to be named said she was planning to rent out two of the rooms at her house for between R600-R700 a day which would exclude meals. She said two groups of Australians were interested but nothing had yet materialised.

Ingrid Schnetler from Waterkloof Agricultural Holdings will be selling jerseys and pullovers displaying the World Cup logo at between R110-R130.

Other ambitious entrepreneurs from Pretoria will be issuing certificates stating that "I was at the Rugby World Cup 1995" to socks, wooden beverage holders, and plastic bottles.

Rugby World Cup licencee manager Mandy Scalen says a taxidermist from Pretoria had even proposed the idea of a stuffed springbok rump that was actually a liquor dispenser.

She says they couldn't endorse the product as it might have damaged the image of the Rugby World Cup.

But for ordinary fans the only damage they are in danger of is sheer emotional exhaustion as the kick-off day draws closer. Jan Hofmeyr, self-proclaimed Northerns (but now Springbok) rugby fan from Monument Park, says people tend to become overly emotional when it comes to rugby. "People start to think, eat and sleep rugby. For fanatics it's not just a game anymore ... it's a way of life," he says.

A financial and administrative official in charge of suite owners at Loftus Versfeld, Rina Smit, giggles in agreement, "People might not know what the local government elections are but everybody knows about the World Cup" she says.

Keith Glass, an accountant from Sunnyside jokingly puts his fascination for the sport down to the fact that he never played soccer.

"It's the game I grew up with," says Anneline Jonker from Moreletta Park. "Coming from an Afrikaans household it was simply expected of one, male or female to watch rugby."

For the more traditional city folk like 21-year-old barman Shawn Alexander, the love of rugby might have something to do with one's testosterone level. "I love rugby as it's a game played by men for men," he says in macho drawl.

Rugby might still be a game played by men but judging by its large female following in Pretoria it's not just a game exclusively for men anymore.

Women enjoy the game just as much as their beer-guzzling male counterparts, albeit for rather peculiar reasons.

Trudie Eksteen, a thirtysomething accountant in Pretoria, says her love for the game is dominated by all the good looking men on and off the field. "Some of the male spectators are just soooo sexy".

In Pretoria, rugby is still the great white sport but recently the game has succeeded in making some tentative inroads. Nike Phahla admits for instance that "my game is still soccer" but adds that his interest in the white-ruled game was piqued when some of his white friends introduced him to it.

For Phahla, who works for a Johannesburg-based security company comprised of former exiled Apla and MK members, there may be more in the World Cup than his awakening interest in the game.

According to him, the company was approached by New Zealand regarding possible protection for its players during the World Cup but nothing has been finalised.

Of course, even in Pretoria, there are those wishing the game and the tournament would simply go away.

"What skill do grown men need for chasing after a ball, stomping on each other and taking bite sized chunks out of their opponent's ears?" Michelle Bayford, a fiery red haired sub editor at a children's magazine wants to know.

"I loathe rugby but the people here (Pretoria) have almost embraced it as a form of religion," she says.

A final year mechanical engineering student at the University of Pretoria, ML Nel, says rugby supporters are hooligans. "Just look at Loftus after a rugby match -- its a pigsty,"he explains. "The only good thing about the World Cup is that it affords all South Africans the chance to make as much money as possible." -- Digi-News

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Africa News


April, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: Diamond War Looms


LENGTH: 947 words


 

Weekly Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)

April 21, 1995

Russia has threatened to pull out of the De Beers-run diamond buying and selling cartel, reports Jacques Magliolo

The long-awaited battle between diamond giant De Beers and Russia is looming after last week's threats by the Russian government to pull out of the Central Selling Organisation (CSO).

If Russia did leave the CSO, would the world diamond market suffer from a major shake-up and would it have serious implications for world diamond prices? After all, experts believe that last year Russia sold 50 percent of an estimated US$2-billion worth of polished and rough diamonds outside the CSO.

The deputy head of the Russian state precious metals committee, Leonid Gurevich, says the current agreement does not reflect Russia's status as a country which possesses some of the world's richest diamond reserves and they want greater access to world markets. Essentially, it wants to increase its sales outside the CSO from five percent to 20 percent. 

Says Gurevich: "Russia is not just seeking the amendment of some provisions of the deal, it wants the whole strategy of dealing with the cartel to be reviewed."

It appears that the organisation is also not happy. "The current CSO agreement with Russia expires on December 31 1995 and it is possible that De Beers could stop buying diamonds from Russia," says De Beers spokesman Andrew Cumine.

While Russia wants to amend future agreements to allow it to sell greater quantities of diamonds outside the CSO, De Beers is "looking for 100 percent of Russian diamonds to sell through the CSO, plus a sales quota for Russia's existing stockpile, so that it can sell diamonds in an orderly fashion," says Cumine.

"In terms of our agreement with Russia, it is the only country which is permitted to sell any quantity of diamonds outside the CSO," says Cumine. He adds that reasons for this are historic and were "to allow Russia to check CSO prices against other buyers and thus make sure that the CSO was providing them with a fair deal."

At a meeting held in March CSO managing director Gary Ralfe made De Beers position on the issue clear. "If the Russians would like to have a close partnership with the CSO then this should be based on the equitable principle that a 100 percent of their production should be flowing through the CSO."

At present De Beers controls 50 percent of the world's production of diamonds. Russian diamond sales represent 26 percent of CSO sales.

While this may be a substantial stake of the world diamond pie, Cumine believes that Russian production is not increasing. Their mines are old and deep, have to be mined under extremely adverse conditions (they are based in Siberia), no new mines seem to have opened and their seems to be a lack of electrical power to run the mines.

In addition to these problems, De Beers believes that even Russia's stockpile is decreasing. "At present we estimate that the stockpile consists of diamonds which are more difficult to sell, such as the good quality and the smaller range diamonds," says Cumine. "It is only to their advantage to sell these more difficult diamonds through the organisation," he says.

For a new five-year agreement, De Beers would insist on a simplification of the negotiation procedures, it would want to know how diamonds are distributed within Russia and the quantity of diamonds produced and stockpiled in that country.

Analysts agree that Russia will kick up a fuss, but will ultimately agree to these terms. The general consensus is that Russia needs hard currency to fund precious metals mines, social welfare, roads and such and could not afford to set up its own client base, nor do they have the necessary technical expertise to create another CSO.

After all, the present agreement provides Russia with about $1-billion a year "up front payment for diamonds, in cash," says Cumine. For the present Russia is not in a position to dictate terms.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).

LANGUAGE: English

149 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: SA's Nuclear Policy Bombed


LENGTH: 1467 words


 

Weekly Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

April 21, 1995

A barrage of criticism has greeted South Africa's support of the Big five nations at the UN nuclear summit, writes Gaye Davis.

SOUTH AFRICA has been accused of turning its back on the Third World and cosying up to the United States by supporting the Big Five powers in their bid to hold on to their nuclear bombs.

This week Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo backed the Big Five -- the United States, Russia, China, France and the United Kingdom -- at the United Nations nuclear non- proliferation summit.

Foreign policy analyst Peter Vale, professor of Southern African studies at the University of the Western Cape, said South Africa had "buckled under United States' pressure" and warned there would be "a great deal of disquiet within the Non-Aligned Movement (NAM)". 

Director of South Africa's Group for Environmental Monitoring David Fig said the decision called the independence and integrity of South Africa's foreign policy into question.

He slammed foreign policy decision-makers for failing to consult South Africans, saying: "Our new leaders are becoming indistinguishable from the old in their adherence to the foreign policy prescriptions of the rich and privileged countries."

Countries within the NAM wanted the treaty conditionally extended for a fixed period only in order to pressure the Big Five -- to fully implement its provisions.

Particularly, they wanted an end to failures and delays in implementing Non Proliferation Treaty provisions which would see nuclear powers fully committed to disarming, to giving non-nuclear countries proper guarantees for their own security and to enabling the transfer of peaceful nuclear technology.

South Africa was seen as having particular influence on the issue as the world's first country to unilaterally and voluntarily dismantle its own nuclear weapons programme.

Nzo's address this week to 178 nations gathered at the United Nations for the NPT review conference effectively dashed any hopes of South Africa's support for the NAM position.

Nzo acknowledged the NAM countries' criticisms of the treaty were valid. He urged that the NPT be strengthened in order to ensure nuclear powers did more to meet NPT obligations and suggested proposals for doing so. But he said the proposals should not be made conditions for the NPT's extension, saying the treaty itself could be weakened if they were.

He said South Africa was making the proposals in the interests of the greatest possible consensus among treaty states. But critics believe United States threats to withhold nuclear co-operation with South Africa if it went with the NAM countries lie behind the decision.

Vale said: "This foreign policy decision will be seen to be one made by whites in the interests of a world in which white interests are protected and defended. It does not reflect what the majority of people feel about the issue -- South Africa's people have not been consulted at all," he said.

It was ridiculous to defend the decision as necessary in the interests of North-South bridge-building, Vale said. "This is a very privileged club which is now licensed to get more nuclear capacity while those outside it are forced to resort to illicit ways of developing a nuclear capacity.

"In a sense it is an apartheid treaty -- some countries are in and some are out."

Said Fig: "We are submitting to extreme pressure exerted by the United States to conform to its desires."

South Africa had failed to use the moral ground it acquired when it became the world's first country to unilaterally and voluntarily dismantle its own nuclear weapons arsenal.

Fig said the decision contributed to the inherent instability of the NPT by putting certain key countries within the NAM outside the agreement.

He criticised foreign policy decision-makers for failing to submit South Africa's position to public debate. "We need a new approach to decision-making, not a reproduction of the old alienating system."

The decision was "a severe setback for alliances being built between South Africa, its southern African partners and the Non-Aligned Movement. The position plays into the hands of the existing nuclear weapons states, particularly the United States, which knows the extension of the treaty makes no significant demands on the weapons states to reduce their existing arsenals.

"The non-aligned countries need strong evidence of good faith in the nuclear weapons' states' willingness to disarm before they can agree to participate in such an unequal non-proliferation regime."

This was why South African officials proposed a compromise position of a rolling extension at a preparatory conference in January, Fig said. "This compromise would have opened the way for the resolution of the inequalities in the spirit of global non- proliferation."

But ANC MP Rob Davies, a member of the parliamentary portfolio committee on foreign affairs, said: "It's a complicated question. There is an unevenness in the process and some Third World countries were seizing on this in order to be able to create nuclear arsenals themselves.

"I'm not sure that this is the direction we should be going in. We should really be trying to close the loopholes which allow other countries to develop arsenals.

"There are advantages in South Africa, which has abandoned its own nuclear programme, taking a stand against the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

'My only reservation is the indefinite extension (of the NPT) does freeze the status quo as far as existing nuclear powers are concerned."

The Washington Post this week reported that United States ambassador to South Africa Princeton Lyman delivered a demarche to Nzo on March 10 which warned a vote against the unconditional extension by South Africa would undermine "mutual interests" and affect Washington's view of South Africa's non-proliferation credentials.

The newspaper said the demarche also noted the United States had supported South Africa's membership of the Nuclear Suppliers Group -- an exclusive group of nations generating nuclear power controlling technology sales.

Foreign Affairs spokesman Coen Snyman could not confirm the demarche. He said the issue had a long history with "lots of communication between South Africa and the United States. President Clinton wrote to President Mandela about it".

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


150 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


SOUTH AFRICA: The Longest Honeymoon in History: A Report Card On The New Government


LENGTH: 5920 words


 

Weekly Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg)

April 21, 1995

by Anton Harber

After a year in office, South Africa's political leaders are talking defensively. Minister Jay Naidoo speaks, in the language of South Africa's new bureaucrats, about the lack of capacity, the need for rigorous business plans, the demands of fiscal discipline, the absence of effective local government, and other factors that have slowed down implementation of the Reconstruction and Development Programme.

Gauteng Premier Tokyo Sexwale said last week that you cannot turn around 400 years of history in one year.

Housing Minister Sankie Nkondo will tell you about all the preparation she needs to make before starting to build houses. And Health Minister Dr Nkosazana Zuma will tell you about the difficult issues that have to be solved before one can tackle health reform. 

They are being defensive because if you measure the success of the Government of National Unity in strictly numerical terms -- the number of houses built, the number of people who have access to free health care or potable water -- then it scores disturbingly low.

Apart from a few showy (and important) presidential projects, such as the provision of a daily peanut butter sandwich to schoolkids and free health care for infants, all the key ministries such as housing, health and education will tell you that they are still at the stage of policy formulation and structural planning, prior to actual implementation of the RDP. Of course they are. There was never any chance that within a year a whole team of new ministers would come to grips with their new tasks, change their departments, develop the policy positions they need to start with and actually start implementing radically new programmes.

But you don't win elections by saying that in the first year you will write white papers, hire consultants and open matters to public debate. You do it by promising to provide houses, health care and schools. Judged against these pre-election promises, the GNU fails miserably. And that's why it has opened itself up to the crude populist criticism of slow delivery.

But this is a simplistic way to judge, because beyond the simple numbers, the ANC has put in place a broad agenda for social change that has already started to make a fundamental impact on the make-up of the country.

Some of these measures are so far-reaching that they make us world trend-setters in social reform.

For example, before Parliament is a new Labour Relations Bill which is aimed at fundamentally changing workplace relations and breaking the tradition of antagonism and conflict. If has been drawn up at breakneck speed and, if passed, will put us in the forefront of modern industrial relations. The formation of Nedlac, the joint state- business-labour-NGO forum to deal with economic and development issues, puts us ahead of most attempts around the world to create a social contract between these different sectors to overcome the traditional antagonisms of the past.

The health policy proposals due to be handed to the minister by a special committee in the next few weeks is more a case of catching up with the world on basic health care provision -- as is the case with attempts to create equal educational opportunities.

But these moves are a clear indication that this is one country which has routed those conservatives, masquerading as neo-liberals, who are winning campaigns in most Western and many African countries to cut back the state and withdraw government from these kinds of social policy issues in order to leave reform to the market system. Where President Bill Clinton has failed to create a new social agenda, President Nelson Mandela has succeeded. Where the British Labour Party is struggling to articulate a social democracy for the late 20th century, the ANC is bounding ahead.

It is accepted by virtually all South Africans -- even most of the conservative business community -- that the state has a role in redressing the inherited inequalities and creating a better society, as long as it is done within the constraints of fiscal discipline.

There is almost universal agreement -- inherent in the fact that all parties have embraced the RDP -- that progress depends on the pragmatic combination of economic growth and tightly-managed reform and redistribution.

So we see high on the national agenda both the encouragement of foreign investment and such issues as the provision of clean water and equal education opportunities.

And the social reformers driving this, notably Minister Jay Naidoo, have not only accepted the credo of fiscal discipline -- they have embraced it with all the fervour of new converts.

This has introduced a new breed of civil servants, often drawn from the ranks of the strugglistas of the 1980s, filling government policy posts to write new policies and laws in every area from industrial strategy to freedom of information. And their agenda is one of social democratic reform.

The role of the private sector has been to try to create a few extremely wealthy and powerful black individuals who would provide a bulwark against accusations that South Africa's most powerful companies are all-white. So white business is financing and advising a line-up of instant millionaires.

This will undoubtedly have its own, unpredictable, social effects. But much more radical is the reform programme being put in place in almost every government department.

When was the last time in any country that policy on everything ranging from policing to pensions was being rewritten? And rewritten in such a way that, if followed through, will change this society so fundamentally that within a decade it will go from being one of the world's least civilised to one of the most progressive.

This has been combined with a formidable human rights structure. The interim constitution creates a Constitutional Court, a Human Rights Commission, a Public Protector, and a Gender Commission. The first of these to be formed, the Constitutional Court, is packed overwhelmingly with individuals who have a proven commitment to human rights and independence.

The government has faced two tests of its commitment to constitutionalism and human rights. The one came when Mandela himself had to climb down on the dismissal of his own wife from the cabinet. The other was an attack on press freedom from the Defence Ministry. Heavily criticised by his own party, the Defence Minister backed off. The ANC passed both tests. Couple this agenda with the prospects for economic growth, said by all experts to be good for the next few years, and the first year of the GNU seems to end as optimistically as it began. The post- election honeymoon continues.

There are some significant problems that could send things awry: crime is escalating, the police forces are in disarray, the looting of pensions and other coffers by old-guard bureaucrats continues apace, crude affirmative action so far has done as much good as harm, and there is little sign of an end to the endemic corruption that marked the previous government.

The important ministries of welfare, foreign affairs, police and education are weak points -- and President Mandela has not dealt with ineffectual cabinet ministers as toughly as he has dealt with ill-disciplined ones. The policy of openness and accountability is facing a potential backlash from some of those made uncomfortable by aggressive media scrutiny.

But, on a political level, the far-right-wing threat has dissipated, and the Inkatha Freedom Party's ability to disrupt things is much more limited than before. The feel-good factor is high, with the post-inauguration euphoria of national unity proving to be more lasting than expected.

Against this background, the ANC does not have to be overly concerned that it has not met its first-year promises. It has a growing economy, a strong majority, the world's most popular president and the longest- lasting afterglow in recorded history. If serious delivery on the RDP is not under way in two to three years -- prior to the build-up to the next election -- then the ANC will have a headache. It would do well to set more realistic targets for this period.

Meanwhile, the country thrives on the rich and rare combination of economic growth, fundamental social reform and firm steps to establish a human rights culture.

How they scored (out of 10)

Nelson Mandela (President)

Score: 9.5

President Mandela would have scored a full 10-star rating a month ago, before the mishandling of the Winnie Mandela saga, and he may be back up there when he puts this issue behind him. But his star-studded performance has been tarnished a little by the messiness of the last few weeks.

It is easy to talk about Mandela's strengths: his vision, his mixture of strong leadership and a willingness to compromise, his pragmatism, his moral stature, his workaholic habits.

He is not without his weaknesses: he has been slow to flag down the government gravy train and he has not been firm with ministers performing below par.

But none of this does serious damage to the fact that he is -- both at home and internationally -- the world's most popular and most respected politician. The success of the first year of the GNU, and the strongly humanistic ethos of the new government, can be credited largely to his leadership.

Thabo Mbeki (First Deputy President)

Score: 6

Mbeki has been increasingly taking over Mandela's tasks, functioning as a de facto prime minister, bringing his suaveness, his political savvy, and his diplomatic experience to bear. Yet he is criticised for not putting his own stamp of authority on matters of state. Instead he functions as a ubiquitous Mr Fix-it, intervening in day-to-day crises and heading various task groups and committees.

His mishandling of Winnie Mandela's firing raised eyebrows when it became apparent that he was the one who had failed to consult with other party leaders. It seemed to confirm a reputation for inefficiency.

He has also sullied his reputation by being seen to back the "populists" in the ANC. Indeed, he had built a political base on their support and is considerably weakened within the ANC when they are on the defensive, as they are at the moment. It is an irony, because Mbeki is no populist -- he is a pragmatic man who has his eyes firmly fixed on his primary goal: ascending to the presidency.

He is a man never to be underestimated: a skillful political manoeuverer and a man of charm and eloquence, he is a formidable candidate for succession.

FW de Klerk (Deputy President)

Score: 4

The former president has struggled to come to terms with his loss of power. Essentially, he has a difficult position: he has only as much authority as Mandela cares to give him and the chemistry between the two of them is lacking. Without any well-defined area of responsibility, he is limited to a narrow role, which carries its own frustrations. He is not allowed to stand in for the president -- rather than have him do so during the president's parliamentary question-time, the institution was done away with. And the ANC makes sure that if Mandela is overseas, Mbeki is there to stand in for him.

De Klerk has mostly been heard from when he is having a tantrum about something he is accused of -- and is generally guilty of. The only other time he makes a mark is during his frequent overseas trips (five in the last year, costing R370 000), spreading the GNU gospel and promoting foreign investment.

As De Klerk grew into the job of president, so he has shrunk into the lesser post. He would do well to consider retiring to be remembered for his remarkable contribution to history, rather than continue to be beset by anxiety over his status and problems within his own caucus. He is now more important to his own party -- where he is the glue holding it together -- than to the GNU itself.

Kader Asmal (Minister of Water Affairs and Forestry)

Score 8.5

This Groucho Marx lookalike has turned his ministry from an archetype of apartheid bureaucracy into a model of civilian participation. The former law professor has used his intellectual energy and heavyweight status in the ANC to ensure that water and forests now occupy a central role in the RDP.

His style of "participatory governance", which he is trying to develop into an art form, saw dam names neutralised without a backlash.

Asmal does not confine himself to his ministry, speaking out on almost anything else that catches his eye, which is why he is known in parliamentary circles as the Minister of Everything.

Sibusiso Bengu (Minister of Education)

Score: 4

The effects of a stroke suffered shortly after his appointment may still be troubling Bengu; he has not caught up with his late start.

More serious is his reluctance to become involved in confrontation; perhaps why he favours long-range planning over short-term fire fighting. Bengu's response to turmoil in the universities was to set up the National Commission on Higher Education. It will all take time.

There has been some progress in Bengu's year in office; there just hasn't been enough of it. In January, the former 18 education departments were transformed into one national and nine provincial departments and the ministry approved a new (interim) deracialised school syllabus.

Mangosuthu Buthelezi (Minister of Home Affairs)

Score: 5

If he's not in Cape Town he's in Ulundi. Perceived in Pretoria as a largely absent minister, his director-general (who achieved fame as head of the Independent Election Commission department that failed to deliver ballot papers) effectively runs the show.

Buthelezi has guaranteed every South African a passport, and raved a little about illegal immigrants. He brings more skills and experience to the post than most, having served for decades in homeland cabinets -- but is spending most of his time fighting party-political issues. There is little sign that he has come to grips with the biggest headache of his department -- the amount of illegals flowing across South Africa's borders and the hostile, even violent, reception they are receiving.

Dawie de Villiers (Minister of Environment and Tourism)

Score: 5

If there's a motto in the ANC's cabinet caucus it could be "Dump it on Dawie". The Environment and Tourism minister has faced a barrage of criticism from opponents in the GNU. These range from he "wants to turn us into a garbage ground for other countries' toxic waste" to complaints that the former Springbok rugby captain is out watching matches. But it appears that much of it is motivated by the ambition of his rivals, Deputy Minister Bantu Holomisa and parliamentary committee head Peter Mokaba.

Although De Villiers has made some mistakes -- like coming up with a gobbledygook hazardous waste policy -- tourism is booming and he can take some credit for this.

Pallo Jordan (Minister of Posts and Telecommunications)

Score: 4

Jordan is the minister trying to change important institutions by doing as little as possible. He's the hands-off minister, arguing that it is not his role to be too active in running the state -owned corporations that fall within his brief, such as the SABC, Telkom and the Postal Service. A less polite title is the invisible minister.

He's changed the face of the boards of Telkom and the Postal Service by making new appointments, but appears now to be sitting back to allow the new boards to drive the transformation process -- something ANC colleagues feel he should be doing. The integration of broadcasting and posts and telecommunications services in the ex- bantustans is still in limbo. So is the question of whether the state will fund the SABC to become a proper public service broadcaster.

Chris Liebenberg (Minister of Finance)

Score 7

A responsible and quiet student, Liebenberg has done better than expected this term.

Dubbed the Kepler Wessels of finance ministers because of his painstakingly methodical approach, he was expected to be cast as lacking in verve because of his predecessor's flamboyance. But Liebenberg has shown up the flaws in Keys' ministerial style. Keys talked endlessly of scrapping the financial rand: Liebenberg actually did it. Keys also saddled Liebenberg with the problem of the rather ad hoc Secondary Tax on Companies. For the business audience, banker Liebenberg says all the right things, while having a keen social conscience. All are impressed by his attention to detail, and his willingness to grapple with the enormous financial problems -- such as public debt -- the GNU inherited. The only criticism is that the colour of his department is still pinko-grey.

Trevor Manuel (Minister of Trade and Industry)

Score: 7

Manuel has confounded business skeptics with his understanding of the issues facing the country and has quickly gathered around him a core of well-qualified advisers.

His performance in trying to get South African exporters a better deal with Europe in terms of the Lome convention was commendable. He has taken the bull by the horns, signaling an end to protection-on-demand by business, and promising tougher anti-competitive laws. His department was responsible for the Monitor report's scathing criticism of industry.

At the same time, his newfound commitment to competition has less than thrilled the left wing of the party and made some unionists uncomfortable. He has hung tough with both business and unions in beginning the restructuring of the textile and motor industries.

But so far movement on policy has been slow and there has been insufficient movement in framing an over-arching industrial policy and tougher competition policy.

Tito Mboweni (Minister of Labour)

Score: 9

No department has moved as fast and as effectively as Labour to write new policy, draft new Bills and establish new structures -- all of which have received widespread acclaim. Mboweni's Labour Bill, currently before Parliament, promises far-reaching reform of industrial relations. Much the same breadth of thinking lies behind the formation of Nedlac, the forum for the government, business, labour and non-government organisations to seek common ground on major policy issues. He has also announced a five-year plan for a labour market policy which will stress skills development and job creation. Mboweni has also been studiously independent in labour matters, winning the respect of both unions and business.

Roelf Meyer (Minister of Constitutional Development, Provincial Affairs and Local Government)

Score: 6

Able and competent, Meyer has been the most impressive of NP ministers. He has the weightiest portfolio of any Nat minister in the GNU and is very much on top of his department, even though he now finds himself trapped in a vacuum as his tasks are usurped by the Constitutional Assembly.

Meyer's major challenge is to see through the devolution of power to the provinces -- many of which are not yet sufficiently geared for this.

The biggest problems he faces are political, enjoying conspicuous lack of support from his NP colleagues. He is deeply disliked by some who hold him accountable for compromises made during negotiations.

Joe Modise (Minister of Defence)

Score: 3

Not known for his ability to think on his feet, Modise leaves much public work to his deputy minister, Ronnie Kasrils. Modise was chosen becuase he was thought to be the military leader who could bring the old-style generals along into the new order. But often it appears that they are dragging him backwards into the old order. Ironically, the rebellion came not from the old guard, but from the new recruits -- the MK and Apla cadres who were furious with the survival of the old army culture.

Modise has succeeded in bringing in a significant number of new officers and set up the Cameron Commission of inquiry to investigate covert arms deals.

A defence White Paper has yet to appear. His department is also criticised for being less than transparent.

Derek Hanekom (Minister of Land Affairs)

Score: 9

Hanekom likes to say he qualified for his post by keeping a few cows and making the best yoghurt in the Magaliesberg, before being jailed in the 1980s. But anyone who thought Hanekom would run his ministry like a rural commune was wrong. He set in motion sophisticated land reform programmes and has achieved more than any other ministry in dealing with apartheid's legacy.

He promotes himself as the "comrade minister", spending time tramping around rural areas. The only complaints come from colleagues left to carry out "Derek's decrees", frequent and rash promises to rural communities that "you will get your land back within months".

Mac Maharaj Minister of Transport

Score: 5

Maharaj has been uncharacteristically quiet in the Cabinet, perhaps because of his peripheral post. He has moved to defuse taxi conflicts. and has also taken important steps to deal with the airport system, a critical factor for tourism.

Sankie Nkondo (Minister of Housing)

Score: 5

Nkondo's relatively low profile since stepping into Joe Slovo's shoes, points to the extent to which she was initially overwhelmed. However, she is now coming to grips with it. But it is still too early to assess her performance.

Sydney Mufamadi (Minister of Safety and Security)

Score: 6

To be fair to Mufamadi, he has been given one of the hardest tasks of all. The police force is disunited, underpaid, overworked, discontented and barely competent. He has to undertake not just massive restructuring to turn it into a decentralised, civilian force, but teach it new skills and new attitudes. At the heart of his policy is community policing, now being adopted by members of the force around the country.

There is no sign yet of the new Police Bill, though Mufamadi has forced out the truculent old commissioner, made an astute choice for a new one, and appointed nine regional commissioners.

Sipho Mzimela (Minister of Correctional Services)

Score: 6

Mzimela got off to a slow start in terms of transforming Correctional Services. An amendment to the Correctional Services Act prohibits the jailing of awaiting-trial children and he has planned youth development centres for young offenders. Mzimela eased pressure on overcrowded prisons without resorting to the "bursting" process of his predecessor. Prison riots saw him doing a good deal of firefighting.

Jay Naidoo (Minister without portfolio)

Score: 4

Naidoo's greatest achievements have been the crafting of a new language, RDP-speak, and the adoption of a new state religion, fiscal discipline. He uses these to explain why there is so little delivery of the RDP.

Some have called him the Chris Heunis of the new order: he speaks in riddles, is minister of everything and of nothing, and has a propensity for producing organograms.

Ben Ngubane ( Minister of Arts, Culture, Science and Technology)

Score: 6

Ngubane's best friends would probably admit he got off to a bad start, due to his unfamiliarity with cloak-and- dagger cultural politics, and an unworkable relationship with then-Deputy Minister Winnie Mandela. He admitted to having blundered in donating R1-million in state money to a private-sector trust fund. But things have speeded up with a bold restructuring of performing arts councils. The diplomatic and easy-going Ngubane has been the surprise success among IFP ministers.

Alfred Nzo (Minister of Foreign Affairs)

Score: 2

Nzo is lucky that South Africa is riding the wave of international acclaim, hiding the fact that there is no coherent foreign policy beyond recognising the need to send the president and his two deputies on regular trips to raise investment. The policy gap is due largely to the fact that Nzo has woken up only occasionally in the last year: to make the occasional boring speech and to argue for the retention of old-guard Director General Rusty Evans. But give Nzo his due -- he is only there to ensure that others, such as Mbeki and Mandela, can do the real foreign work. He should be allowed to retire soon and stop all this tiring travel.

Dullah Omar (Minister of Justice)

Score: 9

South African justice is not what it used to be. Lay people are sharing the bench with magistrates in court. South Africans will no longer serve time in prison simply because they cannot repay a financial debt. Plain language is replacing legalistic gobbledygook. Justice Ministers from all over Southern Africa are talking about regional co-operation. The truth commission is going to happen.

But the change is deeper than these outward signs. For the first time ever, South Africa has a Justice Ministry concerned with administering justice as opposed to laying down the law. This is due to the tireless efforts of Omar.

Jeff Radebe (Minister of Public Works)

Score:6

Radebe wins his stars for his dramatic and unprecedented confrontation with his most senior official last week. Prior to that, he would have scored low for lack of progress on his ambitious public works programme. This tardiness may now be explained by the behaviour of his bureaucrats -- but he will have to prove it by making up for lost time.

Stella Sigcau (Minister of Public Enterprises)

Score: 4

The best that can be said about Sigcau so far is that she has done no harm -- largely because she hasn't done much at all, except accept the inevitability of some privatisation. If it is to happen, it will need a champion. Sigcau, however, has so far lacked the conviction and status to drive the process.

Zola Skweyiya (Minister of Public Service and Administration)

Score: 5

His is the most difficult portfolio -- changing the face and character of the civil service. Change in every other government department depends on his policies. Skweyiya has come under fire from ANC colleagues for not moving fast or decisively enough. Nonetheless he's managed to come through the year without wide scale disruptions, has employed advisors with strong negotiating skills, and is making progress, albeit slow, on policy issues.

Steve Tshwete (Minister of Sport)

Score: 7

Sport evokes passions among South Africans of every pigment, so the person controlling it has to be a skillful negotiator. Tshwete is such a person: he rescued South Africa's Olympic bid and has guided sports development.

Andre 'Kraai' van Niekerk (Minister of Agriculture)

Score: 4

Any intentions which Van Niekerk might have to transform South African agriculture will have to be realised within the parameters set by Land Affairs and Water Affairs. A major part of his job will be to impart farming skills to those who have recently acquired land and drag the white Agricultural Union into the new era.

Chris Fismer (too early to tell)

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.
