Africa News


April, 1995


SIERRA LEONE: Freedom For Some


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Newswatch April 3, 1995

by Emmanuel Ugwu

The Revolutionary United Front, RUF, a rebel movement in Sierra Leone, appears to be bowing to international pressures to release foreign hostages it is currently holding. Last Tuesday, the RUF freed seven Catholic nuns who had been in its custody since January 25 this year. They were captured along with some Sierra Leoneans in Kambia, west of Freetown, the country's capital. The freed nuns, six Italians and a Brazilian, were among the 17 foreign hostages captured in January. 

Announcing their release in Abidjan, the Ivorien capital last week, the RUF promised that the remaining foreign hostages would be freed in due course. It said, however, that the British nationals still in their custody would regain their freedom when the British government stops military assistance to the government in Freetown. But the foreign and commonwealth office in London said the RUF allegation was unfounded. It said it would be in the movement's own interest to free the British nationals without delay.

While the whereabouts of the British nationals are known, that of Roger Graf, a Swiss national is still unknown. Graf was believed to be one of the 17 foreign nationals abducted by the rebels but the RUF said last week it had no knowledge of his whereabouts. Alimany Sankoh, the political and foreign affairs coordinator of RUF, said the movement had already notified the Swiss ambassador in Accra, Ghana, that Graf was not one of the foreign nationals it has been holding.

Sankoh's statement was silent on the fate of hundreds of Sierra Leoneans held hostage by the RUF. Analysts said the silence might be prompted by the decision of the movement to conscript captured Sierra Leoneans into the RUF army to swell its rank. Before last week, there had been reports that many Sierra Leoneans were either forced to join the RUF army or compelled to undertake sundry duties for the movement. Those who resisted conscription were either killed outright or tortured to death.

Last week's partial release of the foreign hostages and a promise to free the others later was, indeed, a volte- face for the RUF. Before then, it had vowed to hold on to them until their countries stopped giving political, economic and military assistance to the Valentine Strasser-led National Provisional Ruling Council, NPRC. The volte-face has triggered speculations in diplomatic circles of a possible deal between the RUF and the Catholic church to facilitate the release of the nuns.

But Georgio Bikusi, the Catholic bishop of Makeni, who played a major role in securing their release, said there was no deal with the RUF whatsoever. According to him, the rebels attached no strings to the release of the nuns. He was echoing the claim of the Vatican that the nuns were released purely on humanitarian ground.

Hostage-taking was adopted by the RUF as a warfare strategy five months ago. The first victims were two Britons abducted in Kabala, a northern town. The NPRC said the RUF resorted to that strategy because it cold no longer hold on to any territory. But RUF sources said the strategy was designed to cripple the mining sector and ultimately ground the country's economy. Apart from the nuns now freed, most of the remaining hostages were engineers working at the Bauxite Mining Company and the Rutile Company, another mining firm. The effect of the strategy is already telling on the economy as government is overstretching its finances to prosecute the war and keep the administration going.

The RUF said last week that if its plans work out successfully, the capture of Freetown was just a matter of time. Reports have indicated that the RUF militia are already 60 kilometers away from Freetown which is the only city so far spared from the ravages of the war. The presence of Nigerian and Guinean troops in the ECOWAS peace-monitoring group, ECOMOG has halted the advance of the rebels on the Sierra Leonean capital.

Newswatch is published at P.M.B. 21499 Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950 Fax: 962887 Telex:27874

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


152 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


NIGERIA: Endless Conference


LENGTH: 3707 words


 

Newswatch April 3, 1995 by Wale Akin Aina

Adolphus Karibi-Whyte, chairman of the National Constitutional Conference is convinced that the conference is now set to complete its assignment. Last Wednesday, he emphatically told "Newswatch" that all issues before the conference had been concluded. "There is nothing unresolved as of today," he declared.

His conviction is note borne out by developments at the conference which is already five months behind schedule. It was to have wound up at the end of last October. But up-till now the conference has not adopted a definite time-table or a deadline for the completion of its work. On March 29, the conference rejected a motion for the conclusion of debates on the draft constitution and final presentation to the Provisional Ruling Council, PRC. According to a proposal by Olusola Saraki, head of the business committee, the conference was to go on a two-week recess on April 6 and on resumption, April 24, conclude debates and present the draft constitution by May 4. 

Karibi-Whyte disagreed with the motion because he said that he was only aware of the two-week adjournment period last Thursday, the motion was represented and passed. In effect, this means that the conclusion of work by the conference would remain open-ended after the recess.

Last week, conference delegates were still arguing over the constitutional provision for a permanent or transitional rotational presidency. Some burning issues might disrupt the conference and thus prolong it work. One of these is rotational presidency. Karibi-Whyte told "Newswatch" last week that as far as he was concern, the issue had been resolved. According to him, the conference had decided that the presidency shall rotate between the north and south and this has been reflected in Section 227 of the draft constitution. Quoting Order 40, rule five of the guidelines on conference debates which states that whatever is concluded by the conference cannot be re-opened, Karibi-Whyte said: "We are not going back on the decision of the conference. There can be no amendment of Section 227.

His position is quite different from that of Mamman Nasir, his deputy at the conference. Nasir, chairman of the constitution drafting committee, CDC, had said that rotational presidency was still an unresolved issue. This is not the first time Nasir's position would be contrary to that of officials of the conference. At the completion of the work of the CDC last January, Nasir had raised a number of issues which he said was yet to be resolved by the CDC. This includes the question of whether or not the secretary to government should also head the civil service. This had shocked fellow members of the CDC who felt that Nasir was trying to buy time to elongate military rule by unnecessarily delaying conference decision. Karibi-Whyte told "Newswatch" that Nasir was making the issue of rotational presidency a political one. "He was head of the CDC which drafted the report. Why did he not put the transitional clause as the head of the drafting committee?" he queried. He said that even those insisting on an amendment of Section 227 want rotational presidency for a transitional period of 24 years. This, he said, is not workable because the president will serve for a term of five years. "Who will do a four-year term so that we can conclude the 24-year transitional period that is being suggested?" he asked.

Karibi-Whyte said that the issue of a transitional clause in Section 227 is a waste of time adding, "if they want to waste their time adding, "if they want to waste their time they can do so, but we are not going to bring it (Section 227) back." But last Thursday, 17 northern delegates led by Isa Kachako, a retired colonel, held a press conference and threatened they would not endorse the draft constitution if it was not explicitly stated that rotational presidency should be transitional. "Newswatch" learnt that as at the end of last week, some northern delegates had endorsed the presentation of a minority report of the draft constitution to the PRC. Kachako and his group said they had no confidence in Karibi-Whyte. "Newswatch" also learnt that there has been moves to pass a vote of no-confidence on the chairman and possibly impeach him. Karibi-Whyte said that he was not taking such moves seriously. "I have heard talk of this, " he told "Newswatch", "but there is no provision to impeach me. I would simply have ruled such actions out of order."

The position of the northern delegates showed that efforts at resolving the issue of rotational presidency had fallen through. The last of such efforts was the formation of a "working our committee" compromising three delegates each from the north and the south. The committee was jointly header by Abba Kyari, a retired brigadier-general and former governor of North-Central State and Alex Ekwueme, former vice-president "Newswatch" learnt that some southern delegates queried Ekwueme's mandate for speaking for them. They were said to have insisted that there should be no change in the draft constitution that the presidency should rotate between north and south.

Last week, Ismaila Isa, publisher of the "Democrat" newspapers and a conference delegate from Katsina State, said that rotational presidency on a permanent basis was not acceptable to the north. "That is final, " he declared. He told "Newswatch" that the north had accepted rotational presidency on principle and as a show of good faith for delegates from the west who had come to the conference at the risk of their lives and property following the crisis of the annulled presidential elections of June 12, 1993. According to him, "we felt that they should have something to show back home as heroes and not blacklegs. We never foresaw that rotational presidency should come into the constitution as a permanent feature." Isa said that those who are insisting on making rotational presidency permanent in the constitution were out to sabotage the conference.

But Olumuyiwa Oladimeji, a delegate from Osun State, said that the south cannot negotiate rotational presidency. "It is only people that believe that they have a monopoly of political power who are afraid of rotational presidency," he said. According to him, the original position of the south was that there should be rotation among six zones in the country, "but we had to make terrible concessions to agree to these narrow two zones."

Oladimeji said it was surprising that those to whom they made concessions were now trying to jettison rotational presidency. He said "If they are now going to reject it then we go back to our six zones." He said that if there was going to be a minority report on the rotational presidency, then the south would also have to present minority reports on several issues that were conceded. This, he said, include revenue allocation, zone structure and commands for the police, amongst others. "The presidency will have more than enough minority reports if people want to write a minority report on rotational presidency," he said.

Larinde Akinleye, a delegate from Oyo State, also disagreed with Isa's statement that the north acted in good faith in accepting rotational presidency. He said that northern delegates were not helping the conference by making an issue out of rotational presidency. "They should be tolerant enough to accommodate the decisions of the conference," he said.

The section of the draft constitution dealing with rotational presidency is not specific on whether or not it should be permanent or transitional. Subsection 1 of Section 227 simply states that "The election to the office of president shall rotate between the North and the 'South." Subsection 4 of the same section states that states carved our from former Northern region, including the Federal Capital Territory, FTC, Abuja shall represent the North while states carved out from the former Eastern and Western regions, including the Federal Territory of Lagos, shall be deemed to be the south.

When the issue first came up at the power-sharing committee level, it could not be resolved. The committee passed it to the conference. After heated debates, the conference appointed a consensus committee, headed by Saraki to resolve the matter. Last October 8, the consensus committee presented its report which stated that the presidency should rotate alternately between the north and the south. On October 17, J.A. Rowiaye, a delegate from Ogun and a member of the power-sharing committee, proposed that rotation as a transitional measure be deleted from the report of the power-sharing committee. His contention was that when the committee included traditional clause in it report, it did so on the basis that power should rotate among six proposed zones. He said that now that it was to rotate between just two zones, there was no reason why it should remain transitional.

Rowaiye's motion was defeated but the transitional clause was also not included in the draft constitution. So, the issue of whether rotational presidency should be transitional or not became a conundrum. The northern delegates argue that since the move by Rowaiye to delete the transitional clause in the committee report failed, the draft constitution should be amended to reflect that the rotation was transitional and it should also state the period. On the other hand, southern delegates say that the consensus committee between the north and the south should be transitional. They, therefore, argued that any amendment on the draft would be by consensus.

This appears to agree with Karibi-Whyte's view. He told "Newswatch" last week that since the decision of the conference was arrived by consensus, it would also be changed by consensus. He added: "Since there is no consensus we have to discountenance it."

But even with this, some delegates from the north are questioning the composition of the Saraki consensus committee. They, for instance, say that for a consensus committee to be truly constituted, it must be representative of all states and as such must have nominated members from all states. This, they claim, was not done by Karibi-Whyte. Also, they queried the nature of the consensus after observing that Saraki and Chukwuemeka Odumegwu-Ojukwu, who was also a member of the consensus committee, openly disagreed on the floor of the conference on the decision reached by the committee. The northern delegates also claim that no written report was presented to the conference by the consensus committee. According to Isa, the members of the committee did not append their names or signatures to any resolution. He declared: "I challenge them to show us their resolution or any document they have endorsed when they arrived at the decision."

The controversy over rotational presidency raised fears that the conference may be extending the tenure of the government of Sani Abacha, the head of state. Last Tuesday, Paulinus Akpeki, a delegate from Delta State, said at a press conference that the conference had itself worked against the January 1, 1996, date it set for the military last December. Akpeki, one of the opponents of the date, said he felt vindicated because the "January 1, 1996 date was hastily taken and was unrealistic and hence impracticable." He said that the ultimatum to the military was ill-advised and noted that five months after it was supposed to have wound up, the conference was still debating the draft constitution and report of its resolutions.

He said that the earlier date of October 1997, suggested by the conference transition committee and rejected by the conference, should have been ideal considering that the committee headed by Barnabas Gernade listed component parts of the transition which included the establishment of a new electoral commission, formation of political parties, registration of voters and creation of states. This situation apparently favours Akpeki, who has always insisted that the conference has no business setting a terminal date for the military. Though he had last January drawn a transition programme to terminate military rule in had not been taken seriously by other delegates who saw his move as political posturing. His expected motion for the extension of military rule last January never saw the light of day.

Akpeki denied that he was a proponent for an extension of military rule. He told "Newswatch" that even the 1997 date might prove unrealistic. He said it was now uncertain when the draft constitution would be presented to the PRC. He said that up-till now, the conference was yet to draw up a programme of transition for the military and that it shows that it is about to wind up deliberations soon. The present situation tallies with an earlier "Newswatch" report which last January spoke of moves to delay the submission of the draft constitution till June 1995 and thereby make it impossible for a transition programme to be worked out in the remaining months of the year. This conforms with the programme proposed for government by pro-military groups who want 1997 as the exit date.

Are the delegates being teleguided to use delaying tactics to prolong military rule? The frequent adjournments by the conference seems to suggest so. This year alone, the conference has adjourned two times. When it resumed last January 9, it sat for less than 48 hours and went on a two-month recess. By Thursday, it would go on another long recess. Also, opinion are divided over the foot-dragging attitude of delegates. A conference delegate said some delegates were afraid of losing the generous allowances of N25,000 a month and the bonus paid to every member at special religious holidays. Sources close to Aso Rock said that long adjournments would enable the government deliver "welfare packages" to delegates. This can be as much as N75,000 during the recess periods to cover Easter expenses.

Sources close to the presidency also said that many delegates lobbied for ministerial appointments. Eight of them were appointed into Abacha's new cabinet. The source told "Newswatch" that now that there are speculations that the head of state had directed that administrators should dissolve their cabinets and the care-taker committees of local governments, conference members have again been lobbying for political appointments.

Other political commentators, however, feel that those who want to drag the conference back were doing a bidding of the military. There are strong suspicions that this was why the delegates began debates on the second volume of the drafting committee report with suggestions that it should again review all the reports of the various committees, one by one before adopting them.

Some delegates said this was necessary because these were in the second volume of the report that ought to be included in the draft constitution. One of these is the issue of creation of new states and local governments. Although creation of specific states is not a constitutional matter, the constitutional drafting committee seemed to have included additional states and local governments which were not in the original report of the committee for state creation. For instance, the drafting committee report recommended two states to be created out of Benue State. These are Apa with capital at Otukupo and Katsina-Ala with capital at Zaki-Biam. The original report only recommended the creation of Apa State. In Akwa Ibom, they recommended the creation of Atlantic State, comprising of Oron in Akwa Ibom and Calabar in Cross Rivers State. They also recommended the creation of Itai State which will have Ikot-Ekpene as capital. The report of the state creation committee had recommended the creation of Itai state. For local government, the drafting committee report recommended the creation of two new local governments form Oju local government of Benue State. These are Obi and Oyongo. But strangely, it changed the headquarters of Oju local government form Oju to Ichakobe, a development said to be raising tension in the area. Also out of the Nsukka local government area in Enugu State, the committee recommended three new local governments: Ovogovo, Nsukka and Nsukka South.

Last week, indegenes of the Nsukka local government, led by E.A. Obayi, complained to the conference that at no time did they canvass or ask for three local governments. They claimed that the recommendation by the drafting committee was contrary to the one by the conference committee on states and local governments last September.

Also, in its recommendations, the drafting committee did not name the constituent areas of the new states or local governments and, in some cases, did not even list state capitals or local government headquarters. The capital of the recommended Atlantic State was not mentioned.

With these lapses, some conference delegates reason that it might be tempting for the government to delay the handing over of power while it proceeds to reassess the recommendations of the conference. When he visited Nigeria two weeks ago, Jimmy Carter, the former American president, cautioned against implementing all the recommendations of the conference. He said that it might be misinterpreted as excuse by the military to delay handling over to an elected government. Carter specifically said that the creation of states should not constitute a prelude to the transfer of power.

Government has so far left the conference alone with its controversies. Despite the rancour generated by the rotational presidency, government has said nothing. In 1989, when the issue of the sharia was about to derail the constituent assembly, the administration of former President Ibrahim Babangida intervened. Augustus Aikhomu, former vice-president, in a stern speech, called the assembly to order and barred further discussion on the sharia. Also in 1978, under the Olusegun Obanjo regime, when the same issue of the sharia threatened the constituent assembly, the government intervened using a combination of carrot and stick to get back into the assembly the pro-sharia group, led by Shehu Shagari, who had staged a walk-out.

Last week, government officials told "Newswatch" that the government does not want to get involved in the constitutional conference so that its actions might not be misinterpreted. Appointment of eight delegates into the cabinet would suggest that government is not particularly keen on the outcome of its work. Fred Chijuka, brigadier-general and spokesman for the defence headquarters, said that this would in no way affect the constitutional conference. He said that "if one third of the members are still there, then the job of the day is going on."

Chijuka said he does not see this as a strategy by Abacha to stay on, adding that "no military government would want to say put in this country with all these political hawks around."

Olademeji told "Newswatch" all these issues do not have to affect the process of democratisation by government. He said: "I like to hope that the government we have is committed to the democratisation process." he said that although there were some people who do not agree with majority or consensus opinion, "this should not be an excuse for government to delay the political democratisation process."

Newswatch is published at P.M.B. 21499 Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950 Fax: 962887 Telex:27874

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).

LANGUAGE: English

153 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


GHANA: Conflict Resolution and Peacekeeping in Africa: Ghana's Experience


LENGTH: 2547 words


 

by H.E. Flt. Lt. J.J. Rawlings, Speech given at the Carnegie Endowment for Peace, Washington, DC

March, 1995

May I first express my appreciation to the Carnegie Endowment for Peace, the Centre for Strategic and International Studies and the Constituency for Africa for providing this opportunity to share with you Ghana's experience in the field of conflict resolution and peacekeeping.

The end of the Cold War raised high hopes for a new and stable international order which would be characterized by cooperation among and within states, rather than by polarization, rivalry and conflict. However, within a relatively short time these optimistic expectations have been severely jolted by the aggravation of old conflicts and outbreak of new ones, often with frightening intensity.

The spate of conflicts in Afghanistan, Liberia, Somalia, Rwanda, Bosnia, in some of the former states of the former Soviet Union , and along the Peruvian-Ecuadorian border has made it evident that we are not at peace simply because Cold War is over. Indeed we may be facing stark realities which were previously masked by the overpowering images of super power rivalry. 

The search for effective approaches to conflict prevention, resolution and management highlights the importance of understanding the local context of theses conflicts, the underlying social and cultural forces that are tugging away at the heart of nations and communities, which in the past might have been disregarded in favour of global power explanation.

In looking for ways to end such disputes and conflicts, the world has naturally tended to look upon the United Nations as the framework of action by the international community. Despite the imperfections revealed by its operations in Somalia and Bosnia, the united Nations has acquired a wealth of experience through its involvement in efforts to resolve a wide variety of disputes and, therefore may be expected to have the flexibility that is required to deal with different conflict situations. In addition, in places like Nicaragua, El Salvador, Cambodia, South Africa, Namibia, Mozambique and in Angola it has recorded remarkable successes, which often tend to be ignored when strident criticisms are leveled against the organisation.

Ghanaians take pride in our active participation in UN peacekeeping operations. Although we are a relatively small country with limited resources, we have been most willing to commit our forces wherever required in the interest of peace, and to act in concert with other member states to share and shoulder collective international responsibility.

In the early '60s, Ghana participated in its first major UN operation in the newly independent state of Congo (now Zaire). Ghana has since contributed contingents of troops, military observers, police and electoral officials to the following United Nations peacekeeping operations: UN Emergency Force, Egypt, 1973-78; UN Interim Forces in Lebanon, 178-95; UN Good Offices Mission in Afghanistan and Pakistan, 1988-92; UN Iran-Iraq Military Observer Group, 1988-90; UN Iraq-Kuwait Observer Mission, 1990-95; UN Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara, 1992-95; UN Protection Force, ex-Yugoslavia, 1992-95; UN Transitional Authority in Cambodia, 1993-94; and UN Assistance Mission in Rwanda, 1994-95. We sent troops to Rwanda even when most countries still hesitates, and we have maintained a continuous presence to help alleviate the suffering and put an end to the human tragedy in our sister African country.

I have taken the liberty of detailing Ghana's involvement in global peacekeeping in order to highlight Ghana's commitment to the lofty ideals and objectives of the UN, the organisation which is our best hope in for world peace and security. It is indeed, a pleasure to recall the glowing tribute paid to the Ghana Armed Forces in Accra by the US Deputy Secretary of State, Mr. Strobe Talbott, when he said, and I quote, "Ghana has played a very important role in peacekeeping, going back thirty years to when it sent troops to the Congo; and, of course, it distinguished itself both in the multiplicity of missions that Ghanaian armed forces have undertaken over the years and also with the distinction and professionalism, with which the Ghanaian Armed Forces have carried out those missions. All of us were very impressed in those horrible days in April in Rwanda when the Ghanaian unit was the only one on the ground in Rwanda to stand its ground," unquote. There could be no better tribute to the memory of the Ghanaian soldiers who have lost their lives during peacekeeping duties than the thoughts expressed by Deputy Secretary, Mr. Strobe Talbott.

About half of our armed forces are presently engaged in UN peacekeeping activities in one form or another, in fulfillment of our solemn commitment and obligation to the world community.

In the current atmosphere of concern about the efficacy of the UN as a tool for dealing with conflict situations, one aspect often overlooked is the positive contributions that some developing countries have made in UN operations.

Good news from Africa is often lost, especially to those who feel far geographically and mentally from our continent. Africa has been making important contributions to United Nations efforts. More African states are willing to participate in UN peacekeeping activities. Within the framework of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) principle of non-interference in the internal affairs of member states, has still been possible for the OAU to acknowledge the realities on the continent and create its own Conflict Prevention, Resolution and Management mechanism, which is expected to play a more active role in the resolution of conflicts in Africa.

At the sub-regional level, also, concerted efforts have been made to deal with African conflicts

In East Africa, the Inter-Governmental Association on Drought and Development (IGADD), which was originally scheduled to deal with the Sahelian drought as been mediating in the civil war in Sudan.

In Southern Africa, Presidents Nelson Mandela of South Africa, Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe and Quett Masire of Botswana, within the framework of the Southern African Development Community (SADC), undertook joint efforts in helping to resolve the crisis in Lesothos and have also been involved in the search for a peaceful settlement of the Mozambican and Angolan crisis.

In West Africa, in August 1990, the Economic Community of West Africa States (ECOWAS) which embraces 16 states including Ghana, sent its first contingent of troops drawn from Gambia, Guinea, Nigeria and Sierra Leone and Ghana intervene in the Liberian civil war. This marked the first time that an African sub-regional organization had intervened with military forces in one of its member states.

The decision to launch the ECOMOG operation was purely humanitarian- to deal with a situation of the collapse of a nation state that was having face repercussions for the whole region. Thousands of refugees from other countries in the sub-regions were trapped in Liberia, sometimes being used as apes in the conflict. About half a million refugees had pored over the borders into neighboring states. Thousands of West Africans have lost their lives as a result of this conflict. The Liberian civil war constituted a clear threat to peace and stability in the area which hindered efforts to promote regional integration and regional economic development.

Since then ECOWAS has made several efforts at resolving the Liberian civil war. Our efforts have been hampered by our resource constraints, but we have persisted nonetheless.

It is in this regard that ECOWAS is appreciative of the supportive role that the US has played in the search for a solution to the conflict, though many were surprised at the initial distance that the US Government seemed to adopt in the early stages of the Liberian crisis were well summed up by Adlai Stevenson "Making peace is harder than making war", nut making peace is infinitely more regarding for humanity than making war and causing so much suffering.

We have certainly learnt some useful lessons from our involvement in the Liberian conflict. It has become increasingly clear to us that even with the noblest of intentions, it is difficult for a third party or a mediator to play an effective and successful role in the face of intransigence by one or more of the parties. Peace cannot really be imposed or forced, it must be made, molded, often with limited logistics.

The situation is all the more difficult where civil or governmental authority has completely broken down. The involvement of outside powers which may be siding with any of the parties to the conflict is equally a hindrance to peaceful resolution of such conflicts.

Conflicts resolution and peacemaking are further hindered when the multinational peacemaking entity lacks either the resources or the resolve to maintain peace, or where the positions of its member countries on issues are not consonant.

Essentially, the primary responsibility for the resolution of such conflicts resides with the major domestic warring factions and their external supporters, and unless they recognize the need to show accommodation and cooperation, it is difficult for anybody to impose a solution which would be just and lasting. Ultimately what the warring parties aspire to is what Woodrow Wilson described in 1917 as "peace without victory".

Our experience in Liberia has further confirmed the need for the international community to devise a strategy and mechanism not only for prompt and effective delivery of assistance to refugees, and for demobilization and reconstruction, but more so for the prevention of such conflicts.

We are convinced that in the long term it is more cost-effective to institute measures to prevent the outbreak of conflicts than to search for solutions when the conflict has already occurred. Preventive diplomacy has the incalculable benefit of saving lives, often in the hundreds of thousands.

We also recognize that in any global strategy for conflict resolution, regional and sub-regional actors or players should be given a prominent role. It is our view that the geographical realities of a conflict may impact on its resolution. Regional involvement, in tandem with the UN, and bolstered where necessary by additional bilateral assistance may therefore be more effective.

We therefore appreciate the efforts that the US is making under the Africa Resolution Conflict Act passed by Congress last year to assist the OAU improve upon the capacity-building of its conflict resolution mechanism. In the same vein, we welcome recent initiative taken by the Clinton Administration to extend US support for conflict resolution mechanism in Africa to the sub-regional and bilateral levels.

While these efforts at regional sub-regional and bilateral capacity building are in progress, the international community will have to continue to rely on the UN. It is therefore, disheartening to note that at the moment, the UN does not have the capacity to enable it play the effective role envisaged for it under the Charter. The end of the Cold War has provided multilateral cooperation -- that had long been limited by the US-Soviet Union rivalry -- with a golden opportunity to use the UN as a vehicle for effective peacekeeping.

In this regard, we in Ghana commend the Clinton Administration for putting a premium on conflict resolution issues as part of its foreign policy agenda. It is important that the U.S. acts effectively in pre-empting some of these conflict situations and not wait till these degenerate into carnage whose horrific exposure on American TV will so outrage the American population that the US will still eventually get involved, but perhaps with too little and too late to prevent human suffering.

In the connection, we recognize that even with the end of the Cold War, it may not always be possible for the United States to provide men for UN peacekeeping operations.

However, assistance in providing logistic support, supplies, intelligence and communication is vital. Equally important, the leadership of the US must continue to mobilize international interest in the early resolution of regional disputes.

The United Nations, like any human organization, requires sound moral leadership if it is to be effective and successful. Ghana for its part, will play an active role in the UN, the OAU and ECOWAS to prevent conflicts, and when they do occur, to help to resolve them promptly and cost effectively. The United States also should continue to work in partnership with other states in maintaining peace and security.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


154 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


ETHIOPIA: Ethiopia: Accountability Past And Present


LENGTH: 880 words


 

Report Summary by Amnesty International

April, 1995

The Ethiopian authorities are prosecuting officials of the former government for gross human rights violations, but the Transitional Government has not acted with equal determination against abuses by its own forces.

The Transitional Government was established in 1991 after 17 years of brutally repressive rule. The general election scheduled for May 1995 marks the end of the four-year transition period.

The Transitional Government took on the crucial task of bringing to justice officials of the former government responsible for gross human rights violations. The trials have started after long delays and will continue for some years. If they are fair and do not result in executions -- which are themselves violations of human rights -- they will send a message to all perpetrators of human rights violations that they cannot expect impunity and will be held accountable for their actions. 

However, the transitional period has also seen many new abuses of human rights.

Thousands of opponents of the Transitional Government were detained without charge or trial between 1992 and 1994. The majority have now been released but there are still hundreds of political detainees. Some political prisoners have possibly been given unfair trials; as more detainees are being brought to court this is of growing concern. Some detainees are prisoners of conscience, including journalists and members of non-violent opposition parties.

Dozens of government opponents have "disappeared." People have been held in secret detention centres, and torture has been inflicted on suspected members of opposition groups. A number of defenceless civilians have been shot dead by the security forces. Abuses have also been committed by armed opposition groups.

The Transitional Government has not been consistent in its approach to accountability for human rights abuses. It has not done enough to stop and prevent human rights violations, especially in the context of the Oromo Liberation Front's continuing armed opposition. The international community too has paid insufficient attention to continuing reports of violations. The important message of the trials of former officials will be undermined unless decisive action is taken to stop human rights violations perpetrated by those in power now.

This report is about the human rights record of President Meles Zenawi's four-year Transitional Government. It is based on extensive research by Amnesty International and the outcome of Amnesty International's latest talks with the Ethiopian government in February 1995. The meetings discussed a detailed memorandum submitted by Amnesty International to the government three months earlier and the report incorporates the government's response.

The report documents human rights violations in Ethiopia since 1991, including the imprisonment of non-violent critics of the government; detentions without charge or trial of other government opponents, some of whom were involved in violent opposition; "disappearances"; torture; and political killings by the security forces and by opposition groups.

It also describes the first stages of the trials of officials of the former Dergue and Workers Party of Ethiopia governments headed by Lieutenant-Colonel Mengistu Haile-Mariam between 1974 and 1991.

The report concludes with a series of recommendations for urgent action to end and prevent human rights violations. The Ethiopian government should be more open and consistent in its approach to human rights by acknowledging and redressing violations. It should look more closely at its own record and deal with present as well as past abuses.

This summarizes a 58-page document (23,360 words), Ethiopia: Accountability past and present: human rights in transition (AI Index: AFR 25/06/95), issued by Amnesty

International in April, 1995. Anyone wanting further details or to take action on this issue should consult the full document.

INTERNATIONAL SECRETARIAT, 1 EASTON STREET, LONDON WC1X 8DJ, UNITED KINGDOM. Tel: (44) (71) 413 5500. Fax: (44) (71) 956 1157

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


155 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April, 1995


U.S./AFRICA: Document: Peacekeeping, Development Aid - Congressional Actions Expected in May


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1987 words


 

Africa Policy Information Center Update

April 30, 1995

As Congress returns from recess after the Easter vacation, the Republican majority will be continuing its drive to make fundamental changes in national priorities, on both domestic and international issues.

Cuts in the current year's budget (rescissions) voted by the House and Senate before the recess took $60 million from funds previously approved for the International Development Association (the World Bank's soft loan affiliate), $62 million from the African Development Fund (associated with the African Development Bank), $15 million from international peacekeeping, and $12.5 million from bilateral economic assistance. They also mandated an additional $125 million in additional foreign operations cuts to be specified by the administration's Office of Management and Budget. The supplemental bills including these cuts also failed to approve the administration's supplemental request for $672 million for payment of overdue U.S. peacekeeping obligations.

The proposal by Senator Mitch McConnell to remove $110 million from the bilateral Development Fund for Africa (one-eighth of the total $802 million) was, however, defeated by intense lobbying and grass-roots mobilization by a number of Africa advocacy groups, including the Washington Office on Africa, the American Committee on Africa, Bread for the World, Interaction, and others. 

Coming up in May: (1) Both the House and Senate will be considering budget resolutions for Fiscal Year 1996, which begins in October 1995. The roughly $20 billion international affairs "150" account, which includes development aid and peacekeeping as well as operating expenses for the State Department and other agencies, may be cut drastically, by as much as $2.6 billion to $5 billion. Since many items in the account, such as operating expenses and funding for Israel and Egypt, will be protected, a lower "150" limit will put the greatest pressure on the most vulnerable items: peacekeeping and development aid for other regions. Groups including Interaction <ia@interaction.org> and Church World Service <cwslwr@igc.apc.org> are spearheading the effort to keep cuts to this account under $1.5 billion. (2) The House of Representatives has passed H.R. 7, which includes an accounting measure effectively prohibiting most U.S. support for UN Peacekeeping, by counting bilateral costs of U.S. operations approved by the UN (such as the Persian Gulf, the bilateral intervention in Haiti) against U.S. assessed obligations. The Senate will soon take up a similar bill (S. 5). Even if, as some Republicans say, there are loopholes that would still allow some U.S. contributions, the result would be a further drastic reduction in UN peacekeeping capacity. The Council for a Livable World (Tel: 202-543-4100; Fax: 202-543-6297) and the Washington Office on Africa <woa@igc.apc.org> are two of the groups actively opposing S.5. (3) Development assistance will continue under intense pressure to be cut drastically. With aid to Israel, Egypt, Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union enjoying greater political protection, Africa will be a particular target.

Senator McConnell and others are expected to continue their push to eliminate the Development Fund for Africa as an earmarked account, leaving priorities within bilateral assistance contingent on strategic significance and short-term economic prospects for U.S. business. Senator Helms is pressing a proposal to merge USAID, the African Development Foundation, and the InterAmerican Foundation into a new agency which would marginalise sustainable development as a goal and not fund government-to-government programs at all.

Most Africa advocacy groups in the U.S. stress that they are not defenders of the USAID status quo. But they argue that drastic cuts and guidelines specifically excluding the goal of sustainable development will simply work to further marginalise Africa, and be used to justify cuts by other countries and international agencies as well. (Thus the Canadian International Development Agency has also announced cuts, aimed particularly at the strong NGO programs of development education in Canada.) Groups such as Bread for the World <bfw@gmuvax.gmu.edu>, the Washington Office on Africa, and African Americans for Aid to Africa (c/o Washington Office on Africa) have stressed that reform in the direction of sustainable development depends on clearly identifying the goals of promoting self-help development and poverty reduction, and preserving funding levels for the bilateral Development Fund for Africa at the 1995 figure of $802 million.

The attack on funding for international involvement, however, builds on extraordinary levels of public ignorance about the actual sums involved. A new poll on peacekeeping by the Center for the Study of Policy Attitudes, reported by

The New York Times, showed that a majority of 67% of the U.S. public still express strong support for UN peacekeeping in general (down from 84% a year ago). But when the respondents were asked to estimate what percentage of the U.S. budget goes for international peacekeeping, the median response was 22% (the actual figure is equivalent to less than 1% of the U.S. defense budget alone). They also thought on average that the U.S. provides about 40% of UN peacekeeping troops, ten times the actual percentage. (More details of the poll are expected to be available soon.)

A poll earlier this year by the same agency (see summary below) showed parallel results on the issue of foreign aid. Such perceptions, combined with long-standing stereotypes of Africa as a hopeless and undifferentiated morass of violence and poverty, pose formidable obstacles to the many groups working to counter the drive to further marginalise Africa.

Attachment: Poll Reveals Contradictory Views on AID

A new study of American public attitudes on foreign aid was recently conducted by the Program on International Policy Attitudes of the Center for International and Security Studies of the University of Maryland. It included a poll of 801 Americans conducted January 12-15 (margin of error plus or minus 3.5-4%), focus groups, interviews and a review of other polls. It found that:

1. An overwhelming majority of respondents (80%) embrace the principle that the United States should give some aid to help people in foreign countries who are in genuine need. Only 8% want to eliminate foreign aid entirely.

2. A strong majority (75%) says that the United States is spending too much on foreign aid. But this attitude is based on the assumption that the US is spending vastly more than it is, in fact. Asked to estimate how much of the federal budget goes to foreign aid, the median estimate of those responding was 15% -- 15 times actual spending (only about 1% of the budget). (Other polls have found even higher estimates). Asked what an "appropriate" amount would be, the median level proposed was 5%. Asked how much would be too much, the median response was 13%, while 3% was seen as "too little" -- still 3 times present spending.

3. When informed about the actual amount of spending on foreign aid, the number who felt that the amount was too much was 18% -- down from the 75% who had previously felt that the US was spending too much. When informed, a strong majority (62%) favored either maintaining or increasing foreign aid spending.

4. The public wants to change the mix of priorities in foreign aid spending, putting less emphasis on securing US strategic allies and bases around the world and more emphasis on helping the poor and needy.

5. Support for spending on poor countries stems partly from a belief that the world is so interconnected that it is in the economic interest of the US to promote the development of Third World countries (63% agree).

6. Strong support also comes from the attitude that the US has a moral obligation to help nations in need (67% agree), while an overwhelming majority (77%) rejects the idea that the US should only give aid when it promotes the US national interest.

7. A strong majority (67%) supports the principle of giving aid to help countries move toward democracy, including former socialist countries, and 80% are unhappy about the amount of aid that goes to countries that are not democratic or have poor human rights records.

8. Eighty-three percent believe there is widespread waste and corruption in foreign aid programs. A strong majority (58%) would be willing to pay more in taxes if they believed that more aid would get to the people who really need it.

9. To promote self-reliance, the majority (65%) is willing to spend more on aid that emphasizes trade and development and is willing to give poor countries preferential trade treatment.

The study "Americans and Foreign Aid: A Study of American Public Attitudes", was conducted by the Program on International Policy Attitudes, a program of the Center for the Study of Policy Attitudes and the University of Maryland Center for International and Security Studies. An 8-page summary is available free from the Center for the Study of Policy Attitudes (CSPA), 11 Dupont Circle NW, Suite 610, Washington, DC 20036. Phone: (202) 232-7500. Fax: (202)232-1159. Email: cspa@vita.org. Inquire to CSPA for pricing on the full study.

This update was prepared by the Africa Policy Information Center (APIC). The attachment from CSPA is reposted with permission.

For additional information on its content, please contact CSPA directly.

For additional information: Africa Policy Information Center, 110 Maryland Ave. NE, #112, Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. Email: woa@igc.apc.org.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).

Africa News


May, 1995


UN AGENCY HONOURS 27 ENVIRONMENTALISTS


LENGTH: 1387 words


 

NAIROBI, KENYA (PANA) - THE UNITED NATIONS ENVIRONMENT PROGRAMME (UNEP) HAS RECOGNIZED THE COMMITMENT OF 27 INDIVIDUALS AND ORGANISATIONS TO THE CAUSE OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION BY ELECTING THEM TO THE PRESTIGIOUS RANKS OF ITS GLOBAL 500 ROLL OF HONOUR, IT SAID IN A STATEMENT.

THESE ENVIRONMENTALISTS FROM AROUND THE WORLD WILL BE OFFICIALLY HONOURED 5 JUNE AT A SPECIAL AWARD CEREMONY IN PRETORIA, THE SOUTH AFRICAN CAPITAL.

THE EVENT IS BEING HOSTED BY UNEP AND THE SOUTH AFRICAN GOVERNMENT AS PART OF THIS YEAR'S WORLD ENVIRONMENT DAY CELEBRATIONS.

AMONG THE LAUREATES WILL BE SERIGNE SAMB, A SENEGALESE FARMER WHOSE CULTIVATION EXPERIMENTS HAVE STIMULATED OTHER FARMERS TO ADOPT SIMILAR PRACTICIES. OTHERS ARE ROBERT FILMER A CONSERVATIONIST FROM SOUTH AFRICA AND HER MAJESTY QUEEN NOOR OF JORDAN. 

THE LIST INCLUDES SEVEN GLOBAL 500 YOUTH ENVIRONMENT AWARD LAUREATES. THEY HAVE DEMONSTRATED THAT BEING YOUNG IS NO IMPEDIMENT TO BEING ENVIRONMENTALLY ACTIVE. AMONG THEM IS ALWAN-AL-TEIF, A CHILDREN'S MUSIC AND DRAMA TROUPE IN THE SUDAN. THE GROUP HAS HELPED RAISE PUBLIC AWARENESS OF ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES.

AMONG THE WINNERS IS CHINA'S YOUNG PIONEERS ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING STATION OF DAXINGLU PRIMARY SCHOOL. IT HAS CARRIED OUT INVESTIGATIONS ON ACID RAIN; AND ON AIR, DUST AND NOISE POLLUTION AND PROPOSED SOLUTIONS. THE GREEN MACHINE CONSERVATION CLUB OF SOUTH AFRICA FOR UPLIFTING THE IMPROVERISHED AND INFORMAL SETTLEMENTS IN AND AROUND THE KNYSNA DISTRICT IS AMONG THE LAUREATES.

"IN HONOURING THESE ENVIRONMENTALISTS, UNEP SEEKS TO ENCOURAGE AND MOBILIZE THE CREATIVE ENERGIES OF INDIVIDUALS AND ORGANIZATIONS ALIKE IN THE DEFENSE OF THE ENVIRONMENTL," THE UN BODY SAYS.

UNEP EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR ELIZEBETH DOWDESWELL SAID THAT SOME 590 INDIVIDUALS AND ORGANIZATIONS HAD BEEN HONOURED SINCE UNEP LAUNCHED GLOBAL 500 AWARD IN 1987.

AMONG PROMINENT PAST WINNERS ARE FRENCH MARINE EXPLORER JACQUES COUSTEAU; GRO HARLEM BRUNDTLAND, THE PRIME MINISTER OF NORWAY; ANIL AGGARWAL AND THE ENVIRONMENTALIST FROM INDIA. OTEHRS INCLUDE THE LATE CHICO MENDES, THE BRAZILIAN RUBBER TAPPER WHO WAS MURDERED DURING HIS FIGHT TO SAVE THE AMAZON RAIN FOREST, THE GREENBELT MOVEMENT IN KENYA, HIS ROYAL HIGHNESS THE DUKE OF EDINBURGH OF THE WORLD WIDE FUND FOR NATURE AND JIMMY CARTER, A FORMER UNITED STATES PRESIDENT.

GLOBAL 500 AWARDS ARE GIVEN YEARLY TO INDIVIDUALS AND ORGANISATIONS WHICH PROVIDE OUTTSTANDING CONTRIBUTIONS TO PROTECT THE ENVIRONMENT. UNEP LOOKS TO THE WORLD COMMUNITY TO IDENTIFY AND NOMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL ADVOCATES SO THAT THEY TOO CAN BE RECOGNIZED FOR THEIR EFFORT. NOMINATIONS CAN BE OBTAINED FROM UNEP HEADQUARTERS, GLOBAL 500 ROLL OF HOUNOUR, P.O. BOX 30552, NAIROBI, KENYA.

PANA OSS 22MAY95

PROFILES OF WINNERS

BRITISH INVESTIGATIVE JOURNALIST GEORGE MONBIOT HAS BEEN EXPOSING, AND AT TIMES AT HIS OWN PERIL, HIGH RANKING OFFICIALS KNOWINGLY ENGAGING IN ACTIONS THAT DESTROY THE ENVIRONMENT.

NOW, HE IS AMONG 27 INDIVIDUALS AND ORGANISATIONS ELECTED TO THE UNITED NATIONS ENVIRONMENT PROGRAMME (UNEP) GLOBAL 500 HONOUR ROLE FOR PROTECTING THE ENVIRONMENT. THEY WILL RECEIVE THE CITATION 5 JUNE.

IN A STATEMENT FROM ITS NAIROBI HEADQUARTERS, UNEP SAYS MONBIOT'S REPORTS HAS MADE MAJOR NEWS. HE HAS TRACED A CHIMPANZEE SMUGGLING NETWORK TO THE HEAD OF THE CUSTOMS DEPARTMENT OF COTE D'IVOIRE. HE HAS UNCOVERED A TIGER SKIN SMUGGLING NETWORK OPERATING BETWEEN INDONESIA AND SINGAPORE.

HE DENOUNCED THE ILLEGAL TRADE IN MAHOGANY BETWEEN BRAZIL AND GREAT BRITAIN, TRACING FELLING WITHIN INDIGENOUS FOREST RESERVES AND TO THE FURNITURE RESTORATION DEPARTMENT OF BUCKINGHAM PALACE, OFFICIAL RESIDENCE OF THE BRITISH CROWN. AS A CONSEQUENCE, THE ROYAL FAMILY PLEDGED IN 1994 THAT IT WOULD ONLY USE TROPICAL WOOD FROM SUSTAINABLE SOURCES.

WITH HIS BOOK AMAZON WATERSHED, HIS REPORT 'MAHOGANY IS MURDER' AND THE DOCUMENTARY FILM 'YOUR FURNITURE, THEIR LIVES', HE LAUNCHED AN INTERNATIONAL CAMPAIGN AGAINST THE ILLEGAL MAHOGANY TRADE. THIS CRUSADE HAS NOW BEEN ADOPTED BY AT LEAST 120 ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS, LEADING TO A 55 PER CENT REDUCTION OF MAHOGANY SALES IN GREAT BRITAIN.

ERIGNE SAMB, A FARMER IN THE SENEGALESE VILLAGE OF THIAMB'ENE, IS ON THE HONOUR ROLE. HE COMES FROM AN AREA WHICH HAS SEEN A DRASTIC REDUCTION IN TREE COVER DUE TO OVERGRAZING, SHITFING CULTIVATION AND TREE CUTTING.

SAMB RECOGNIZED THE NEGATIVE EFFECT THAT DEFORESTATION WAS HAVING ON HIS LIVESTOCK. SO, IN 1993 HE ESTABLISHED THE FIRST SYLVO-PASTORAL FIELD IN HIS VILLAGE.

HE FENCED IN 14 HECTARES OF HIS FARM USING VARIOUS CUTTINGS IN ORDER TO SAVE THIS AREA AS A FODDER RESERVE IN DROUGHT YEARS. THE NATURAL REGENERATION IN HIS FIELD DEVELOPED EXTREMELY WELL IN CONTRAST TO THE SURROUNDING BARREN LANDS.

AFTER FOUR YEARS OF PROTECTION, THE NUMBER OF TREES PER HECTARE INCREASED FROM 10 TO 1,250. HIS FARM HAS BECOME A MODEL FOR SOIL CONSERVATION AND DEMONSTRATES WHAT INDIVIDUALS CAN DO, USING LOCALLY DEVELOPED TECHNOLOGIES.

THROUGH THE ASSOCIATION WHICH HE FOUNDED, FATHER BALCMANS HAS SPENT A LIFETIME REACHING RURAL COMMUNITIES IN BURKINA FASO TO CARE FOR AND NURTURE THEIR ENVIRONMENT. FROM NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT TO SOUND AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES AND RATIONAL BREEDING METHODS, SCORES OF VILLAGES HAVE LEARNED TO HELP THEMSELVES.

TWENTY-FIVE VILLAGES HAVE SUCCESSFULLY IMPLEMENTED FATHER BALEMANS' SCHEME WHICH WAS RECOGNIZED AS A MODEL BY A GOVERNMENT IN SEPTEMBER 1994.

IN THE YOUTH CATEGORY, ARCHIEVEMENTS OF THE GREEN MACHINE NATURE CONSERVATION CLUB RUN BY THE SUNRIDGE PRIMARY SCHOOL ARE IMPRESSIVE. IT IS MANAGED BY STUDENTS BELONGING TO ONE OF THE MOST DISADVANTAGED SECTIONS OF SOUTH AFRICAN SOCIETY.

GREENING OF THEIR ENVIRONMENT HAS GONE IN TANDEM WITH EFFORTS TO IMPROVE THE LIVING CONDITIONS OF THE POPULATION. THEIR FIRST PROJECT AIMED AT UPLIFTING THE IMPOVERISHED AND INFORMED SETTLEMENTS IN AND AROUND THEIR DISTRICT. CLUB MEMBERS ORGANIZED WORKSHOPS FOR YOUTH ADDICTED TO NARCOTICS AND SET UP SOUP KICHENS FOR THE HUNGRY.

SINCE THE INFORMAL SETTLEMENT IS SITUATED AROUND A TRASH DUMP, A SYSTEM WAS SET IN MOTION TO EXCHANGE FOOD PACKETS FOR RECYCLABLE MATERIALS. THIS NOT ONLY HELPED CLEAN UP THE AREAS, BUT ASSISTED THE COMMUNITY IN SUPPLEMENTING ITS INCOME.

THE CLUB CREATED AN INDIGENOUS PARK IN THE GROUNDS OF THE SCHOOL AND SUPPLIED TREES TO OTHER SCHOOLS IN THE AREA. A THIRD PROJECT WAS A CAMPAIGN AGAINST WASTE, ENCOURAGING RECYCLING, WHICH WAS RUN CONCURRENTLY WITH A CAMPAIGN TO ENHANCE ENVIRONMENTAL AWARENESS.

PANA OSS 22MAY95


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


157 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


SUDAN TURNS TO CANE WASTE INSTEAD OF CHARCOAL


LENGTH: 440 words


 

KHARTOUM, SUDAN (PANA) - SUDAN EARLY THIS MONTH OPENED ITS FIRST FACTORY FOR PROCESSING SUGAR CANE WASTE INTO FUEL.

THE GENEID SUGAR FACTORY HAS STARTED A PROJECT FOR BLENDING MOLASSES AND BAGASSE, THE RESIDUES FROM CANE AFTER THE EXTRACTION OF SUGAR, INTO BLOCKS THAT ARE PROVING TO BE USEFUL AS AN ALTERNATIVE COOKING FUEL TO CHARCOAL OR FIREWOOD. 

THE PROJECT BELONGS TO THE RENEWABLE ENERGY GROUP FOR THE PRODUCTION OF BUGASS BLOCKS,A SUBSIDIARY OF THE STATE-OWNED SUDANESE DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION.

THE GROUP'S GENERAL MANAGER OMAR EL RASHEED SAYS THE LONG TERM GOAL IS TO GRADUALLY STOP THE FELLING OF TREES FOR FUELWOOD AND CHARCOAL.

HE SAID OVER 100 WORKERS ARE EMPLOYED BY THE PROJECT WHICH HAS ALSO PROVIDED CHEAPER FUELS FOR BRICK-MAKING AND LIME MILLING INDUSTRIES.

A BLOCK OF THE FUEL THUS PRODUCED CAN COOK A POT OF BEANS AT A HUMBLE COST OF 200 SUDANESE POUN 200, COMPARED TO 1000 SUDANESE POUNDS FOR CHARCOAL(1$=330.3 SUDANESE POUND).

PRODUCTION COST OF BAGASSE BLOCKS IS LESS BY 75 PER CENT THAN THAT OF CHARCOAL, THE FACTORY'S OWNERS CLAIM.

THEY SAY BAGASSE FUEL DOES NOT REQUIRE IMPORTED DIESEL OIL TO IGNITE A FIRE.

RASHEED EXPECTS HIS FACTORY TO PRODUCE AN ANNUAL SIX MILLION BAGASSE BLOCKS, THE EQUIVALENT OF 8,800 TONNES OF FUEL.

THE FOUR GOVERNMENT-OWNED SUGAR FACTORIES PRODUCE ONE MILLION TONNES ANNUALLY.

BAGASSE BLOCKS ARE PRODUCED BY A SIMPLE HAND OR LEG DRIVEN MACHINE THAT CAN BE MAUNFACTURED LOCALLY.

PANA YH/PBM 22MAY95

May, 1995


SUDAN'S BLUE NILE WATER REACHES LOWEST LEVEL,


LENGTH: 347 words


 

KHARTOUM, SUDAN (PANA) - THE WATER LEVEL IN RIVER BLUE NILE HAS REACHED ITS LOWEST LEVEL IN THIRTY YEARS, AGGRAVATING SUDAN'S ELECTRIC POWER SHORTAGE.

THE GOVERNMENT DAILY 'EL ENGATH EL WANI' ON SUNDAY REPORTED THAT WATER LEVEL AT BLUE NILE'S EDDAIM STATION ON THE BORDER WITH ETHIOPIA WAS ON LAST FRIDAY AT 6.82 METRES, 14 CENTIMETRES LOWER THAN IT WAS THE SAME DAY IN 1994. 

BY SATURDAY, THE LEVEL HAD FALLEN TO 11 CM LOWER THAN IT WAS THE PREVIOUS YEAR, THE LOWEST IN THREE DECADES, THE PAPER ADDED.

ACCORDING TO THE DAILY, THE DROP IN WATER LEVELS MEANS LESS AND LESS POWER GENERATED FROM THE ROSSEIRIS AND SENNAR DAMS ALL OF THEM ON THE BLUE NILE.

FOR THE PAST TWO MONTHS, POWER CUTS AND RATIONING HAVE BECOME COMMON IN SUDANESE URBAN CENTRES.

SUDAN OBTAINS MORE THAN 50 PER CENT OF ITS ELECTRIC POWER FROM THESE HYDRO- ELECTRIC STATIONS.THE REST COMES FROM THERMAL STATIONS.

LATE LAST MONTH, THE GOVERNMENT SIGNED AN AGREEMENT WITH A RUSSIAN FIRM TO BUILD A 50-70 MEAGAWATT POWER STATION AT KAJBAR IN THE EXTREME NORTH. IT ALSO ENVISAGES TO BUILD A 1000 MEAGAWATT DAM AT HAMDAB AREA,ALSO IN THE NORTH.

PANA YH/PBM 22MAY95

May, 1995


BANK CHIEF ENDS TENURE WITH TWO BOOKS


LENGTH: 627 words


 

by FELIX NJOKU -- PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

ABUJA, NIGERIA (PANA) - AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK PRESIDENT BABACAR NDIAYE, WHO WINDS UP HIS 10-YEAR TENURE ON THURSDAY, HAS COME OUT WITH TWO NEW BOOKS ROUNDING UP HIS 30 YEARS EXPERIENCE AT THE ABIDJAN-BASED BANK.

ONE OF THE BOOKS ENTITLED +LA FOI DE BANQUIER. LA BAD D'HIER A DEMAIN+ (THE BANKER'S FAITH. THE ADB FROM PAST TO THE FUTURE) IS A 219-PAGE TREATISE WHICH RECOUNTS NDIAYE'S EXPERIENCE WITH THE BANK. 

NDIAYE IN THE BOOK PROVIDES A THINK-PIECE ON DEVELOPMENT AND HIS OWN VERSION OF THE DETERIORATION OF HIS RELATIONSHIP WITH THE BANK BOARD.

"AFRICA HAS TO BE HONEST WITH ITSELF IF IT IS TO DEVELOP," NDIAYE SAID IN THE BOOK.

THE OTHER, TITLED +LA BAD, L'AFRIQUE ET MOI+ (THE ADB, AFRICA AND I), IS A SERIES OF INTERVIEWS BETWEEN NDIAYE AND CAMEROONIAN JOURNALIST, HONORE DE SUMO.

HERE, ONE OF ITS HIGHLIGHTS IS ON THE PSYCHOPHANCY COMMON IN AFRICA AND CITES A CONVERSATION WITH AN UNAMED TOP AFRICAN GOVERNEMENT OFFICIAL:

"YOU KNOW DEAR FRIEND, WE MUST TELL THE CHIEF WHAT HE WANTS TO HEAR. IT IS THE SECRET OF LONGEVITY AND PROMOTION..."

NDIAYE POINTS TO SUCH ATTITUDES AS SYMPTOMATIC OF "LA POLITIQUE DU VENTRE" (THE POLITICS OF THE BELLY) WHICH HAVE MORTGAGED AFRICA TO THE SHOFT-TERM INTERESTS OF THE PRIVILEGED FEW.

WHAT SHOULD BE IS THAT THE CHIEF MUST BE TOLD THE TRUTH IF AFRICA IS TO PROGRESS, HE SAYS.

NDIAYE HOLDS UP PRESIDENT JERRY RAWLINGS GHANA AS AN EXAMPLE OF HOW TO REFORM AN ECONOMY WITHOUT LOSING POPULAR SUPPORTS. THE BOOK WAS APPARENTLY PRINTED BEFORE THE MASS STREET DEMONSTRATIONS IN THE WEST AFRICAN COUNTRY OVER A NEWLY INTRODUCED VALUE ADDED TAX (VAT) EARLIER THIS MONTH WHICH PUT TO QUESTION THE ENTIRE BUSINESS OF ECONOMIC REFORM AND GHANAIAN WELFARE.

"IS YOUR GREY HAIR THE RESULT OF YOUR HEAVY RESPONSIBILITIES" TO THE CONTINENT AND "HOW DO YOU PROMOTE ECONOMIC GROWTH IN AFRICA AT A TIME OF CONFLICT IN LIBERIA, ANGOLA, SUDAN, RWANDA AND SOMALIA ?"

NDIAYE RESPONDS TO SUCH QUESTIONS WITH THE SAME DIPLOMATIC DELIBERATION TO WHICH THOSE WHO HAVE ATTENDED HIS PRESS BRIEFINGS ARE FAMILAR.

BUT WHILE THE BOOK THROWS SOME LIGHT ON NDIAYE AND THE ADB, THE READER IS NOT LIKELY TO FIND PROFOUND INSIGHT INTO THE PSYCHE OF THE MAN WHO HAS BEEN AT THE HELM OF THE INSTITUTION'S AFFAIRS OVER THE LAST DECADE.

ONE WOULD ALSO HAVE LOVED TO READ HIS PREDICTIONS ON THE BANK'S FUTURE IN THE FACE OF THE CONTINENT'S GROWING MARGINALISATION AND EXTERME POVERTY.

NONETHELESS, THE WORKS MARK A MAJOR CONTRIBUTION TO LITERATURE ON THE AFRICAN FINANCE SCENE.

PANA FON/IS/DS 23MAY95

May, 1995


AFRICAN BANK INTENSIFIES DEBT RECOVERY


LENGTH: 560 words


 

by FELIX NJOKU -- PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

ABUJA, NIGERIA (PANA) - EFFORTS BY THE AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK (ADB) TO RECOVER HUGE DEBTS OWED TO IT BY SOME AFRICAN COUNTRIES HAVE BEGUN TO YIELD RESULTS WITH TOTAL ARREARS CUT DOWN TO SOME ABOUT 553 MILLION U.S. DOLLARS FROM 585 MILLION DOLLARS, ADB VICE PRESIDENT, FERHAT LOUNES HAS SAID.

"SOME COUNTRIES ESPECIALLY IN THE FRANC ZONE AND SUDAN HAVE SETTLED THEIR ARREARS AND THROUGH A BLEND OF STRICT SANCTIONS AND DIALOGUE, WE HAVE IMPLEMENTATED A MORE RIGOUROUS POLICY," LOUNESS TOLD PANA IN ABUJA, NIGERIA, WHERE THE 31ST ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING OF THE ADB STARTS WEDNESDAY.

THE BANK WAS FORCED TO INTRODUCE NEW SANCTIONS AND COERCIVE POLICIES TO FORCE THE SATES TO SETTLE THE BILLS WHICH ARE DEPLETING ITS PURSE AND ABILITY TO PROMOTE ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT IN AFRICA. 

THE SITUATION IS ALSO DISCOURAGING ITS 25 NON-AFRICAN MEMBERS FROM REPLENISHING ITS CONCESSIONAL LENDING AFFILIATE, THE AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT FUND.

MEANWHILE, LOANS AND GRANT APPROVED BY THE BANK LAST YEAR DROPPED BY SOME ONE BILLION DOLLARS TO JUST 1.4 BILLION LARGELY BECAUSE ITS COFFERS WERE DRY.

THE NUMBER OF LOANS ALSO DROPPED TO 30 IN 1994 FROM 103 IN THE PREVIOUS YEAR.

A REPORT BEING PRESENTED TO THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY SAID SOME 100.5 MILLION DOLLARS DEBT WAS COLLECTED IN 1994 WHILE OUTSTANDING ARREAS WERE PROJECTED TO REACH 7180 MILLION DOLLARS AT THE END OF FISCAL 1995.

THE MAIN DEBTORS ARE ZAIRE, LIBERIA AND SOMALIA, THREE AFRICAN COUNTRIES WHICH BEEN IN THE THROES OF CIVIL STRIFE IN THE PAST YEARS. ZAIRE ALONE OWES SOME 366 MILLION DOLLARS.

"ZAIRE IS LOOKING FOR A RADICAL SOLUTION, PERHAPS TO BE PUT INTO PLACE AT THE END OF THIS YEAR...THE BANK IS ALSO LOOKING FOR A DEAL," LOUNES SAID.

BOTH THE IMF AND THE WORLD BANK ARE ALSO PURSUING ZAIRE FOR BIG ARREAS OWED BY THE CENTRAL AFRICAN COUNTRY.

THE ABD ANNUAL REPORT FOR FISCAL 1994 SHOWED THAT 3.7 BILLION DOLLARS OR 37 PER CENT OF APPROVED LOANS WERE YET TO BE DISBURSED.

WHILE THE PROFITABILITY AND RESERVE POSITION OF THE BANK REMAIN INTACT, ITS LIQUIDITY HAS DECLINED.

THE CURRENT RATIO OF LIQUIDITY TO TOTAL DEBT FELL TO 25.1 PER CENT IN 1994.

PANA FON/IS/DS 23MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Africa News


May, 1995


ZIMBABWE TO LOSE 100M U.S. DOLLARS IN EXPORTS


LENGTH: 507 words


 

HARARE, ZIMBABWE (PANA) - ZIMBABWE WILL LOSE ABOUT 840 MILLION ZIMDOLLARS (100 MILLION U.S. DOLLARS) IN EXPORT REVENUE THIS YEAR AS AGRICULTURAL OUTPUT SHRINKS BECAUSE OF DROUGHT, A WORLD BANK OFFICIAL SAID TUESDAY.

BANK SENIOR RESIDENT ECONOMIST IN ZIMBABWE KAPIL KAPOOR TOLD DELEGATES AT A DAYLONG CONFERENCE ON THE WEATHER THAT DROUGHT THIS YEAR HAD CAUSED A 60-PER-CENT DROP -- TO 840,000 TONNES -- IN MAIZE OUTPUT. SUGAR PRODUCTION HAD DECLINED BY 27 PER CENT TO 380,000 TONNES. 

COTTON EXPORTS WOULD ALSO BE LOWER AS PRODUCTION FELL FROM 181,000 TONNES IN 1994 TO SOME 110,000 TONNES.

DUE TO THE DECLINE IN AGRICULTURAL OUTPUT, BETWEEN ZD 630 MILLION (75 MILLION U.S. DOLLARS) AND ZD 840 MILLION (100 MILLION U.S. DOLLARS) WOULD BE ADDED TO THE IMPORT BILL FOR THE IMPORTATION OF MAIZE, WHEAT AND COTTON.

MAIZE IMPORTS, HE SAID, WERE EXPECTED TO BE LIMITED TO BETWEEN 200,000 AND 300,000 TONNES.

THE COMBINED IMPACT OF THE DECLINE IN EXPORTS AND THE INCREASE IN FOOD IMPORTS WAS EXPECTED TO COST THE COUNTRY ABOUT ZD 1.7 BILLION (200 MILLION U.S. DOLLARS).

HOWEVER, TOTAL EXPORTS WERE EXPECTED TO RISE GIVEN FIRMER COMMODITY PRICES FOR TOBACCO, FERRO-CHROME AND GOLD IN THE INTERNATIONAL MARKET.

KAPOOR ESTIMATED THAT TOTAL EXPORT EARNINGS WOULD INCREASE FROM ZD 15.7 BILLION (1.87 BILLION U.S. DOLLARS) IN 1994 TO ZD 16.5 BILLION (1.96 BILLION) THIS YEAR.

THIS WOULD MAINTAIN THE COUNTRY'S BALANCE OF PAYMENTS SITUATION AT A FAVOURABLE POSITION.

KAPOOR SAID THAT BECAUSE OF THE DROUGHT, THE ECONOMY WOULD GROW AT A REDUCED RATE OF BETWEEN 1.5 AND 2 PER CENT THIS YEAR, DOWN FROM PREVIOUS ESTIMATES OF 4 PER CENT.

"THIS REDUCED GROWTH RATE IMPLIES A DECLINE IN REAL PER CAPITA INCOME LEVELS SINCE GDP GROWTH WILL ALMOST CERTAINLY BE BELOW THE POPULATION GROWTH OF 2.8 PER CENT," HE SAID.

PANA ZIANA JM/TM/OSS/DS 23MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). Africa News


May, 1995


ZAMBIA'S INTEREST RATES RISE


LENGTH: 387 words


 

LUSAKA, ZAMBIA (PANA) - ECONOMIC UNCERTAINTIES SINCE THE BEGINING OF 1995 HAVE GREATLY CONTRIBUTED TO THE STEADY RISE IN BANK BASE RATES WHICH HAVE NOW SOARED TO AN AVERAGE 45 PERCENT, IT HAS BEEN REVEALED.

ZAMBIA ASSOCIATION OF CHAMBERS OF COMMERCE AND INDUSTRY (ZACCI) CHIEF EXECUTIVE THEO BULL SAID IN LUSAKA TUESDAY THAT UNCERTAINTY OVER GOVERNMENT'S ABILITY TO OPERATE WITHIN THE BUDGET AND SEAL A DEAL WITH THE INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND (IMF) HAD INFLUENCED THE RISE OF BANK BASE RATES.

BULL SINGLED OUT THE MERIDIEN BIAO BANK UNCERTAINTY AS AN ISSUE THAT HAD BEEN DRAGGING ON SINCE THE BEGINNING OF THE YEAR AND AN AREA WHICH MAY HAVE ATTRACTED UNBUDGETED FOR MONIES FROM GOVERNMENT. 

HE SAID DOUBTS OVER GOVERNMENT'S SIGNING OF AN AID AGREEMENT WHICH WAS EXPECTED TO BE DONE LAST MONTH WITH THE IMF HAVE ALSO PROPELLED THE UPWARD TREND THAT BANK BASE RATES HAVE TAKEN SINCE THE YEAR STARTED.

ZACCI AND THE BUSINESS COMMUNITY WOULD CONTINUE TO SUPPORT GOVERNMENT IN ITS EFFORTS TO STEER THE ECONOMY ON COURSE BUT IT WILL BE REGREATEBLE IF GOVERNMENT FAILS TO OPERATE WITHIN THE BUDGET AND OVERSPENDS, BULL SAID.

IT IS REGREATEBLE THAT THINGS HAVE HAD TO BE LIKE THIS BUT THIS IS THE NORMAL ROUTE BASE RATES WILL TAKE WHEN FACED WITH SUCH UNCERTAINTIES, BULL SAID.

THE IMF IS SAID TO HAVE CENSURED THE ZAMBIAN GOVERNMENT FOR THE ATTEMPTED BAIL OUT OF MERIDIEN BIAO BANK AND GROSS UNJUSTIFIED EXPENDITURE ON DEFENCE.

PANA-ZANA CMM/KL/DS 23MAY95

163 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


AFRICA RISKS ECONOMIC MARGINALISATION, SAYS UN OFFICIAL


LENGTH: 494 words


 

by MUSENGWA KAYAYA -- PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

LUSAKA, ZAMBIA (PANA) - AFRICA RISKS PERMANENT ECONOMIC MARGINALISATION BY THE REST OF THE WORLD UNLESS IMMEDIATE STEPS ARE TAKEN TO STRENGTHEN CONTINENTAL ECONOMIES THROUGH REGIONAL INTEGRATION, A SENIOR UNITED NATIONS OFFICIAL HAS SAID.

UN SENIOR LEGAL OFFICER IN VIENNA, MUNA NDULO, HAS SAID AFRICA HAS BECOME POORER TODAY IN PER CAPITA TERMS THAN IT HAD BEEN 30 YEARS AGO.

"THE CONTINENT ENJOYS THE DUBIOUS DISTINCTION OF BEING AT THE BOTTOM IN ALL INDICES MEASURING HUMAN PROGRESS...AFRICA HAS BEEN RELEGATED TO THE PERIPHERY IN THE WORLD AND RISKS BECOMING PERMANENTLY MARGINALISED," SAYS NDULO IN A PAPER PUBLISHED BY THE LATEST ISSUE OF THE +SOUTHERN AFRICA ECONOMIST MAGAZINE+. 

NDULO SAYS IT IS PARADOXICAL THAT THE CONTINENT SHOULD BE AN ECONOMIC OUTCAST AT A TIME OF INCREASED GLOBISATION AND INTERDEPENDENCE.

"A STRATEGY THAT NEEDS TO BE PURSUED VIGOROUSLY IS ECONOMIC INTEGRATION," SAYS NDULO WHO CITES THE SOUTHERN AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT COMMUNITY (SADC) AS ONE EXAMPLE OF REGIONAL COOPERATION THAT OFFERS THE BEST HOPE OF SUCCESS.

ACCORDING TO NDULO, SADC'S WORK PROGRAMMES SHOULD FOCUS ON BUILDING INSTITUTIONS TO FACILITATE INTEGRATION AND IDENTIFYING AND TACKLING OBSTACLES TO INTEGRATION.

NDULO, A ZAMBIAN NATIONAL, IS FORMER LAW PROFESSOR AT THE UNIVERSITY OF ZAMBIA. HE HAS WRITTEN SEVERAL BOOKS AND OTHER PUBLICATIONS IN LAW AND DEVELOPMENT STRATEGIES.

AFRICA HAS THE LOWEST LIFE EXPECTANCY AT 51 YEARS AND IS SAID TO HAVE ABOUT 168 MILLION MALNOURISHED PEOPLE, DESPITE THE CONTINENT'S POTENTIAL TO PRODUCE ALL ITS FOOD REQUIREMENTS.

ACCORDING TO NDULO, RELIANCE ON PRIMARY COMMODITY EXPORTS, A HEAVY DEDT BURDEN AND HIGH IMPORT BILLS HAVE HAD THE JOINT EFFECTS OF SIDELINING THE CONTINENT FROM THE MAINSTREAM WORLD ECONOMY.

PANA MK/DS 23MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


May, 1995


ZIMBABWE WINE MAKER POSTS EXCELLENT RESULTS


LENGTH: 360 words


 

HARARE, ZIMBABWE (PANA) - A MAJOR ZIMBABWEAN WINE AND SPIRIT PRODUCER, AFRICAN DISTILLERS LTD, POSTED EXCELLENT RESULTS FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 MARCH 1995, BUT WARNED THAT THE FUTURE WAS NOT BRIGHT AS DISPOSABLE INCOMES PLUMMET BECAUSE OF INFLATION.

THE COMPANY SAID IN A STATEMENT EARNINGS ATTRIBUTABLE TO SHAREHOLDERS HAD RISEN A SIGNIFICANT 118 PERCENT TO ZIMDOLLARS 14.135 MILLION (USD 1.7 MILLION) WHILE TURNOVER WAS ALSO UP 35 PERCENT TO ZD 206 MILLION (USD 24.2 MILLION). 

THE COMPANY WAS ABLE TO DECLARE ZD 4.9 MILLION (USD 571 294) IN DIVIDENDS TO SHAREHOLDERS, A 118 PERCENT INCREASE OVER THE PREVIOUS YEAR.

ALTHOUGH THE EARLY PART OF THE YEAR HAD SHOWN A SUSTAINED GROWTH IN ALL WINE CATEGORIES AND SPIRITS, THE GOVERNMENT'S DECISION TO INCREASE EXCISE DUTIES ON FORTIFIED WINES IN AUGUST 1994 AND SPIRITS IN JANUARY THIS YEAR HAD A MARKED ADVERSE EFFECT ON SALES VOLUME PARTICULARLY DURING THE FINAL QUARTER.

ON THE OTHER HAND, POOR RAINS AND HIGH INFLATION, PEGGED AT 21.6 PERCENT AS OF MARCH, HAD PUT DISPOSABLE INCOME UNDER PRESSURE DURING THE FINAL QUARTER.

AS A RESULT OF PRESSURES ON INCOMES, DIFFICULT TRADING CONDITIONS WERE EXPECTED TO PERSIST, ALTHOUGH THE IMPACT WOULD BE MINIMISED BY REASONABLE RAINS IN THE NEXT SEASON AND A REVIEW OF EXCISE DUTY LEVELS.

PANA-ZIANA JS/JM/DS 23MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Africa News


May, 1995


ZAMBIA'S BAIL-OUT OF MERIDIEN BANK CRITICISED BY IMF


LENGTH: 880 words


 

by MILDRED MULENGA -- PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

LUSAKA, ZAMBIA (PANA) - THE INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND (IMF) HAS CRITICISED THE ZAMBIAN GOVERNMENT FOR TRYING TO BAIL OUT THE DEFUNCT MERIDIEN BANK AS AN UNNECESSARY DIVERSION OF MONEY MEANT FOR CAPITAL PROJECTS.

THIS IS ACCORDING AN INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND MISSION THAT VISITED ZAMBIA 28 MARCH- 4 APRIL 95 AND QUOTED BY THE ZAMBIAN PRESS.

POLICE HAVE CONFISCATED A COPY OF THE DOCUMENT FROM ZAMBIA'S FORMER HEALTH MINISTER BONIFACE KAWIMBE AFTER THEY SEARCHED HIS HOUSE IN LUSAKA LAST THURSDAY.

THE SEARCH WAS CONDUCTED A DAY BEFORE GOVERNMENT CLOSED THE TROUBLED "PAN-AFRICAN" BANK. 

IT WAS SHUT LAST FRIDAY AFTER SHAREHOLDERS FAILED TO INJECT FRESH CAPITAL AND LIQUIDITY INTO THE BANK WHICH HAD SUFFERED A RUN AND LOST CUSTOMER CONFIDENCE.

ACCORDING TO THE IMF, THE BAILING OUT OF MERIDIEN BANK BIAO PUT ZAMBIA AT A DISADVANTAGE WHEN THE COUNTRY WAS ABOUT TO QUALIFY FOR ITS ENHANCED STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT FUND (ESAF).

ESAF ALLOWS MEMBER COUNTRIES ACCESS TO LONG-TERM BORROWING AT CONCESSIONARY RATES.

ACCORDING TO THE IMF, ZAMBIA IS LIKELY TO EXPERIENCE AN INCREASE IN FUEL PRICES AND SHORTAGES OF FOOD SUPPLIES IN HOSPITALS AND SCHOOLS BECAUSE OF THE 30 BILLION KWACHA INJECTED INTO THE MERIDIEN BANK.

IT SAYS FUEL PRICES WILL GO UP BY 60 PERCENT. FUEL HAS ALREADY GONE UP BY 14 PERCENT AND A 46 PERCENT RISE IS ALSO EXPECTED.

THE DOCUMENT SAYS MERIDIEN BANK HAS BEEN HOLDING 25 MILLION UNITED STATES DOLLARS FROM THE ZAMBIAN GOVERNMENT WHICH WAS SUPPOSED TO HAVE BEEN PAID LAST YEAR. THIS WAS ABOVE THE K30 BILLION PUMPED INTO THE BANK BY THE GOVERNMENT.

GOVERNMENT LAST MARCH DELINKED MERIDIEN BIAO BANK FROM THE REST OF THE MERIDIEN GLOBAL NETWORK AND TOOK OVER THE RUNNING OF THE BANK FOR AN INITIAL PERIOD OF SIX MONTHS.

THE BANK HAD SUFFERED A MAJOR SETBACK LAST FEBRUARY WHEN CLIENTS AROUND THE COUNTRY CLOSED ACCOUNTS AFTER HEARING OF ITS LIQUIDITY PROBLEMS AMIDST WIDESPREAD RUMOURS OF IMPENDING CLOSURE.

HOWEVER, GOVERNMENT INTERVENED AND BAILED OUT THE BANK BY PUMPING IN 8.4 AN INITIAL BILLION KWACHA.

THE BANK HAD 40,000 ACCOUNTS IN ZAMBIA, MAKING IT THE FOURTH LARGEST COMMERCIAL BANK IN THE COUNTRY.

THE PROBLEMS AT MERIDIEN BANK STEMMED MAINLY FROM ITS DEALINGS WITH OTHER MEMBERS OF THE MERIDIEN GROUP IN OTHER COUNTRIES, ACCORDING TO ZAMBIAN CENTRAL BANK OFFICIALS.

MERIDIEN BIAO INTERNATIONAL SHUT DOWN ITS HEAD OFFICE IN HAMBURG, GERMANY, LAST JANUARY AND SCALED DOWN CORREPONDENT BANKING SERVICES OF ITS LIASON OFFICE IN LONDON AND NEW YORK.

IN KENYA AND SWAZILAND, THE CENTRAL BANKS OF THE TWO COUNTRIES, HAVE TAKEN OVER THE BANK'S OPERATIONS IN AN EFFORT TO CONSOLIDATE PUBLIC CONFIDENCE.

ZAMBIA'S MERIDIEN BANK DEPOSITS HAD DROPPED FROM ABOUT K70 BILLION TO BELOW K30 BILLION.

TWO YEARS AGO CHILUBA'S GOVERNMENT BAILED OUT CAPITAL BANK WHICH HAD FOUND ITSELF IN A SIMILAR POSITION.

THE DEFUNCT MERIDIEN BANK HAS NOW BEEN PLACED UNDER RECEIVERSHIP AND WILL BE MERGED WITH THE ZAMBIA NATIONAL COMMERCIAL BANK (ZNCB) IN THE ZAMBIA BANKING CORPORATION LIMITED (ZAMBANK). THE BANK IS TO BE PRIVATISED.

ZAMBIAN FINANCE MINISTER RONALD PENZA SUNDAY ASSURED MERIDIEN ACCOUNT HOLDERS THAT INTERIM MEASURES HAD BEEN PUT IN PLACE TO SERVICE CUSTOMERS BEFORE THE PROPOSED ZAMBANK COMES INTO OPERATION.

"(THE) PEOPLE'S MONEY IS SAFE AND THEY SHOULD JUST WAIT FOR THESE LITTLE DETAILS TO BE SORTED OUT AND SHOULD NOT PANIC," PENZA SAID.

PANA MM/MK/DS 23MAY1995

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). Africa News


May, 1995


ZIMBABWE BENEFITING FROM STABILITY, SAYS IMF


LENGTH: 467 words


 

HARARE, ZIMBABWE (PANA) - THE INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND HAS DESCRIBED ZIMBABWE AS ONE OF THE SIX SUB-SAHARAN AFRICAN COUNTRIES WITH LOW MACRO-ECONOMIC IMBALANCES, A PREREQUISITE FOR SUSTAINABLE ECONOMIC GROWTH FOR THE COUNTRY.

MACRO-ECONOMIC STABILITY WAS FOUND TO CONTRIBUTE TO SUSTAINABLE GROWTH BY IMPROVING THE EFFICIENCY OF PRIVATE INVESTMENT IN ZIMBABWE - A SECTOR DUBBED THE ENGINE FOR ECONOMIC GROWTH BY WESTERN ANALYSTS.

"PROGRESS TOWARDS IMPLEMENTING STRUCTURAL AND INSTITUTIONAL REFORMS, BY PROVIDING THE NECESSARY ENVIRONMENT FOR PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT, LED TO BETTER ECONOMIC PERFORMANCE," SAID THE IMF. 

IN A 1986-93 STUDY OF 41 SUB-SAHARAN COUNTRIES, THE IMF CLASSIFIED BOTSWANA, MAURITIUS, NAMIBIA, SEYCHELLES, SWAZILAND AND ZIMBABWE AS COUNTRIES THAT HAD BEEN ABLE TO ATTAIN LOW MACRO IMBALANCES, DESPITE SPELLS OF DROUGHT IN THE SOUTHERN AFRICAN REGION.

ZIMBABWE HAD BEEN IMPLEMENTING THE IMF-INSPIRED, AND WESTERN-BACKED FIVE-YEAR ECONOMIC STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT PROGRAMME SINCE 1991, AND SHE INTENDS TO PURSUE THE SECOND PHASE (ESAP) AT THE END OF THE YEAR.

THOUGH ZIMBABWE HAD NOT YET FULLY ATTAINED MACRO-ECONOMIC STABILITY, IT WAS EXPECTED THAT PROGRESS MADE DURING THE FIRST PHASE OF ESAP WOULD SPILL-OVER INTO ESAP II, LEADING TO A PRIVATE SECTOR DRIVEN ECONOMY.

DURING ESAP I, THE COUNTRY HAD DEREGULATED THE FOREIGN EXCHANGE MARKET, PRICES AND THE LABOUR MARKET.

FOREIGNERS WERE NOW ABLE TO REMIT 100 PERCENT OF THEIR DIVIDENDS AND AFTER-TAX PROFITS, AND TRADE ON THE LOCAL EQUITY MARKET, THE ZIMBABWE STOCK EXCHANGE.

THE GOVERNMENT'S FISCAL REFORMS, MARKED BY A HIGH BUDGET DEFICIT PROJECTED AT 6.9 PERCENT OF GDP IN 1994/95 FISCUS, NEEDED TO BE EXPEDITED, IF THE COUNTRY IS TO ATTAIN MACRO-ECONOMIC STABILITY UNDER ESAP II.

PANA-ZIANA ET/NN/DS 23MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.
