May, 1995


ZAMBIAN KWACHA CONTINUES TO TUMBLE


LENGTH: 294 words


 

LUSAKA, ZAMBIA (PANA) - THE EXCHANGE RATE OF THE ZAMBIAN KWACHA AGAINST OTHER CURRENCIES HAS REACHED ITS LOWEST LEVEL IN FOUR YEARS.

THE KWACHA WAS SELLING AT AN AVERAGE OF 890 KWACHA TO THE DOLLARS LAST WEEK, UP FROM 850 KWACHA THE PREVIOUS WEEK, WHILE THE BRITISH POUND STERLING ROSE FROM AN AVERAGE OF 1370 KWACHA TO AN AEVERAGE OF 1400 DURING THE SAME PERIOD. 

EFFORTS TO SUSTAIN THE STABILITY OF THE CURRENCY ACHIEVED LAST YEAR HAS FAILED, DUE TO A SHORTAGE OF FOREIGN EXCHANGE AND GOVERNMENT DIVERSION OF THE RESERVES TO SERVICE THE COUNTRY'S FOREIGN DEBT.

FINANCIAL ANALYSTS SAY THE KWACHA'S DEPRECIATION IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE IN THE NEXT TWO TO THREE MONTHS AND EVEN BEYOND UNLESS STRINGENT MEASURES ARE NOT PUT IN PLACE TO SHORE UP THE TUMBLING CURRECY.

THE RAPID SLUMP OF THE KWACHA IS LIKELY TO HAVE AN INFLATIONARY EFFECT ON THE IMPORT-DEPENDENT ECONOMY, WITH PRICES OF GOODS AND SERVICES EXPECTED TO SHOOT UP.

PANA PM/PBM 23MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Africa News


May, 1995


ZAMBIAN OPPOSITION AGAINST MERIDIEN BANK MERGER


LENGTH: 627 words


 

by MUSENGWA KAYAYA -- PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

LUSAKA, ZAMBIA (PANA) - ZAMBIA'S OPPOSITION +NATIONAL PARTY+ IS LOBBYING MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT TO BLOCK THE PROPOSED MERGER OF THE DEFUNCT MERIDIEN BANK BIAO WITH THE STATE-OWNED NATIONAL COMMERCIAL BANK (ZANACO).

NP PRESIDENT HUMPHREY MULEMBA SAID IN LUSAKA MONDAY THAT HIS PARTY IS TOTALLY OPPOSED TO THE ENVISAGED AMALGAMATION AND CALLED FOR A PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE HOW MUCH STATE FUNDS HAD BEEN CHANNELLED TO THE CLOSED BANK.

HE ADVISED MINORITY SHAREHOLDERS WITH ZANACO TO FILE A COURT INJUCTION TO RESTRAIN GOVERNMENT FROM CARYING OUT THE PROPOSED MERGER, WHICH, HE CLAIMED, APPEARED TO BE MOTIVATED BY PERSONAL INTERESTS AMONG SOME ZAMBIAN GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS. 

SOME FINANCIAL ANALYSTS IN LUSAKA TUESDAY DESCRIBED THE INTENDED MERGER AS ILL-CONCEIVED AND NOT IN THE BEST INTEREST OF THE ZAMBIAN ECONOMY.

GOVERNMENT LAST FRIDAY PLACED THE CASH-STRAPPED MERIDIEN BANK UNDER RECEIVERSHIP AND ANNOUNCED THAT IT WOULD MERGE WITH ZANACO TO FORM A NEW BANK, THE ZAMBIA BANKING CORPORATION.

FINANCE MINISTER RONALD PENZA REVEALED IN LUSAKA MONDAY THAT GOVERNMENT HAD EARLY THIS YEAR SECRETLY PRINTED MONEY IN A FUTILE BID TO BAIL OUT THE ILL-FATED BANK.

PENZA SAID GOVERNMENT WAS FORCED TO CLOSE MERIDIEN BANK AFTER THE INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND OPPOSED ITS DECISION TO BAIL IT OUT WITH STATE FUNDS.

THE IMF IS SAID TO HAVE TOLD ZAMBIA THAT THE ACTION DISQUALIFIED THE COUNTRY FROM ACCESS TO ITS +ENHANCED STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT FACILITY+ (ESAF) ALLOWING MEMBER-COUNTRIES TO BORROW ON LONG-TERM AT CONCESSIONARY RATES.

GOVERNMENT LAST MARCH DE-LINKED MERIDIEN BIAO BANK FROM THE REST OF THE MERIDIEN GLOBAL NETWORK AND TOOK OVER ITS RUNNING.

THE BANK SUFFERED A MAJOR SETBACK IN FEBRUARY WHEN CLIENTS CLOSED THEIR ACCOUNTS AFTER HEARING OF ITS LIQUIDITY PROBLEMS AND IMPENDING CLOSURE.

HOWEVER, GOVERNMENT INTERVENED AND BAILED OUT THE BANK BY PUMPING IN 8.4 BILLION KWACHA (1$ = 855 KWACHA).

THE BANK HAD 40,000 ACCOUNTS IN ZAMBIA AND WAS THE FOURTH LARGEST COMMERCIAL BANK IN THE COUNTRY.

MERIDIEN BIAO INTERNATIONAL SHUT DOWN ITS HEAD OFFICE IN HAMBURG, GERMANY LAST JANUARY AND SCALED DOWN CORRESPONDENT BANKING SERVICES AT ITS LIASON OFFICES IN LONDON AND NEW YORK.

THE CENTRAL BANKS OF KENYA AND SWAZILAND HAVE TAKEN OVER THE BANK'S OPERATIONS TO RETAIN CONFIDENCE.

ZAMBIA'S MERIDIEN BANK DEPOSITS HAD DROPPED FROM ABOUT K70 BILLION TO BELOW K30 BILLION, A FIGURE BELOW ITS LIABILITIES.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

ZAMBIA AIRWAYS-SEVERANCE


LENGTH: 280 words


 

LUSAKA, ZIMBABWE (ZANA) - FORMER EMPLOYEES OF THE LIQUIDATED STATE-OWNED ZAMBIA AIRWAYS ARE TO BE PAID SEVERANCE PACKAGES UNDER THE CONDITIONS OF THE DEFUNCT ZAMBIAN INDUSTRIAL AND MINING CORPORATION.

THIS FOLLOWS AN AGREEMENT FRIDAY BY THE LAWYER OF THE FORMER EMPLOYEES, MUNDIA SIKATANA, AND THE GOVERNMENT. THE FORMER EMPLOYEES HAD REJECTED AN EARLIER OFFER.

A FORMER EMPLOYEE TOLD THE ZAMBIAN NEWS AGENCY THAT THE PACKAGE CONSISTS OF A MONTH'S SALARY FOR EACH YEAR SERVED AND A GRATUITY OF A MONTH'S PAY FOR EACH YEAR SERVED FOR THE FIRST 10 YEARS. THEY WILL ALSO GET A MONTH AND A HALF'S PAY FOR THE NEXT 10 YEARS AND TWO MONTHS PAY FOR THE REST OF THE SERVICE.

THEY HAVE ALSO BEEN OFFERED TO BUY COMPANY HOUSES THEY ARE OCCUPYING AT BOOK VALUE.

SIKATANA COULD NOT BE CONTACTED FOR DETAILS OF THE PACKAGE.

PANA ZANA KL/OSS 26MAY95

Africa News


May, 1995


GAMBIA URGES CLOSER COOPERATION WITH NIGERIA


LENGTH: 467 words


 

by PAUL EJIME -- PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

LAGOS, NIGERIA (PANA) - THE VISITING GAMBIAN FINANCE AND ECONOMIC AFFAIRS MINISTER OUSMAN KORO CESSAY MET HERE FRIDAY WITH NIGERIAN OFFICIALS FOR TALKS ON CLOSER ECONOMIC COOPERATION BETWEEN THE TWO COUNTRIES.

HE TOLD THE NIGERIAN MINISTER IN CHARGE OF PETROELUEM RESOURCES DAN ETETE THAT THE GAMBIA WOULD CONTINUE TO COUNT ON NIGERIA FOR ESPECIALY ECONOMIC SUPPORT BECAUSE BOTH COUNTRIES SHARE A SIMILAR HISTORIAL BACKGROUND.

BOTH FORMER BRITISH COLONIES HAVE LONG-STANDING COOPERATION COVERING AREAS SUCH AS EDUCATION, MILITARY AFFAIRS AND THE JUDICIARY. NIGERIAN MILITARY ADVISERS WERE IN THE GAMBIA, UNTIL SHORTLY AFTER THE JULY 1994 COUP THAT TOPPLED PRESIDENT DAWDA JAWARA. 

CESSAY, IN NIGERIA FOR THE 31ST ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING OF THE AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK, SAID HIS COUNTRY WOULD CONTINUE TO HOLD CONSULTATIONS WITH NIGERIA FOR MUTUAL COOPERATION.

IN HIS RESPONSE, ETETE SAID NIGERIA'S ASSISTANCE TO AFRICAN COUNTRIES WAS NOT LIMITED TO THE GAMBIA.

HE SAID NIGERIA WOULD CONTINUE TO TAKE THE INITIATIVE TO KEEP AFRICA TOGETHER.

THE NIGERIAN MINISTER SAID THE CONTINENT WAS "GOING THROUGH DIFFICULT TIMES" EXACERBATED BY WHAT HE CALLED "INTRUSIONS FROM THE SUPER POWERS WHO TAKE DELIGHT IN SEEING US KILL OURSELVES INSTEAD OF HOLDING DIALOGUE WITH OURSELVES."

HE SAID THE GAMBIA IS CURRENTLY SUPPORTING NIGERIA'S BID FOR THE PRESIDENCY OF THE AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK.

DELEGATES FAILED THURSDAY TO ELECT A NEW PRESIDENT FOR THE BANK TO REPLACE SENEGALESE BABACAR N'DIAYE.

THE ELECTION HAS BEEN PUT FORWARD AND WILL NOW BE HELD AT THE ADB HEADQUARTERS IN ABIDJAN.

PANA PE/DS 26MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English

171 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


NDIAYE MADE HONORARY BANK PRESIDENT


LENGTH: 547 words


 

ABUJA, ZIMBABWE (PANA) - OUTGOING AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK CHIEF EXECUTIVE BABACAR NDIAYE WAS MADE HONORARY PRESIDENT OF THE LENDING INSTITUTION FRIDAY IN RECOGNITION OF HIS 30 YEARS OF SERVICE THERE.

THE RECOGNITION WAS CONFERRED AT THE CLOSING CEREMONY OF THE BANK'S ANNUAL BOARD MEETING OF GOVERNORS AND DIRECTORS IN ABUJA, THE NIGERIAN CAPITAL.

NDIAYE, WHO HAS BEEN ASKED TO CONTINUE AS PRESIDENT UNTIL END AUGUST, TOLD THE DELEGATES THAT HE HAD BEEN "HUMBLED" BY THE HONOUR. HE PLEDGED TO WORK FOR THE GOOD OF THE BANK AND ENSURE THAT "WHEN WE COME BACK IN AUGUST THE BANK WILL HAVE A NEW PRESIDENT." 

THE BOARD OF GOVERNORS AND DIRECTORS ASKED NDIAYE TO REMAIN BECAUSE THE MEETING FAILED TO ELECT A MAN TO SUCCEED HIM FROM THE FIVE CONTESTING CANDIDATES.

IN APPARENT REFERENCE TO THE WRANGLE BETWEEN HIMSELF AND THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS, NDIAYE SAID LIKE ALL HUMAN BEINGS, HE HAD MADE MISTAKES.

"I MUST SAY THERE ARE ASSETS AND LIABILITIES AND IN MY CASE, I AM SORRY IF I HURT SOME PEOPLE, I UNDERSTAND HUMAN FEELINGS," HE SAID TO APPLAUSE.

HE IS REPORTED TO HAVE ACCUSED DIRECTORS OF THE MISUSE OF OFFICE AND ABUSE OF FUNDS. THEY HAVE REFUSED TO MEET HIM UNTIL THEIR TERM OF OFFICE ENDS THIS YEAR.

MEANWHILE THE BOARD OF GOVERNORS RESOLVED THAT THE SHAKE UP WITHIN THE BANK BE CONTINUED. IT ASKED NDIAYE TO STRESS ON MEMBER COUNTRIES THE NEED FOR THEM TO PAY THEIR OUTSTANDING ARREARS.

HE HAS BEEN DIRECTED TO PROMOTE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT IN MEMBER COUNTRIES, AS WELL AS ADDRESS PROBLEMS ASSOCIATED WITH POVERTY.

THE GOVERNORS RESOLVED THAT THE FIELD WAS NOW OPEN FOR CANDIDATES WISHING TO BE CONSIDERED FOR THE PRESIDENCY. NOMINATIONS SHOULD BE WITH THE BANK BEFORE THE END OF JULY.

IT WAS AGREED THAT THE ELECTIONS BE HELD AT AN EXTRAORDINARY SESSION IN ABIDJAN, COTE D'IVOIRE, AUGUST 25. THE PRESIDENT-ELECT SHOULD ASSUME OFFICE NOT LATER THAN SEPTEMBER 4.

MEANWHILE, THE BANK'S NEXT ANNUAL MEETING AND THAT OF THE AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT FUND IS SCHEDULED FOR MAY IN ABIDJAN.

PANA ZIANA STC/TM/OSS 26MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). 172 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


NIGERIA, GHANA IN SOCCER WAR SUNDAY IN U-17 CHAMPIONSHIPS


LENGTH: 494 words


 

by IDRIS ABDULRAHMAN -- PANA CORRESPONDENT

BAMAKO, MALI (PANA) - THE SOCCER BATTLE BETWEEN NIGERIA AND GHANA IN THE FINAL OF THE AFRICAN UNDER-17 CHAMPIONS IN MALI SUNDAY, LOOKS LIKE A RE-ENACTMENT OF THEIR ENCOUNTER IN JAPAN '93.

NIGERIA'S GOLDEN EAGLETS, THE WORLD CHAMPIONS, RAN AWAY WITH A 2-1 VICTORY OVER THE STARLETS IN JAPAN.

WIN OR LOSE SUNDAY, BOTH COUNTRIES HAVE QUALIFIED FOR THE WORLD UNDER-17 CHAMPIONSHIP IN ECUADOR LATER IN THE YEAR. BUT AT STAKE APPEARS TO BE NATIONAL PRIDE RATHER THAN THE TROPHY. 

THE WEST AFRICAN SOCCER RIVALS HAVE PROVED SOCCER PUNDITS RIGHT WHEN THEY SCALED ALL OBSTACLES TO QUALIFY FOR SUNDAY'S BATTLE IN BAMAKO.

FOR NIGERIA, THE JOURNEY FROM THE PRELIMINARY STAGE WAS ROUGH ESPECIALLY IN THEIR 3-1 SEMI-FINAL WIN AGAINST HOSTS MALI.

ALTHOUGH THE FINAL ENCOUNTER MAY BE DICEY AND THRILLING, THE EAGLETS' RECORD IN THE COMPETITION IS FRIGHTENING ENOUGH FOR THE UNBLEMISHED GHANAIANS.

TO SECURE A FINAL BERTH FOR THE WORLD JUNIOR SOCCER CHAMPIONSHIP IN ECUADOR, THE EAGLETS WON FOUR MATCHES SCORING 12 GOALS AND CONCEDED TWO.

ON PAPER, THE STARLETS LOOK SUPERIOR IF YOU TAKE THEIR TOURNAMENT'S 13 UNREPLIED GOALS INTO ACCOUNT.

SOCCER PUNDITS SAY VICTORY COULD GO EITHER SIDE. BUT GHANAIAN COACH NURUDEEN JAWOLA HAS WARNED THAT HIS TEAM IS TECHNICALLY BETTER AND THAT OVER-CONFIDENCE COULD SCUTTLE THE NIGERIAN AMBITION TO TAKE THE TROPHY.

IT IS EXPECTED THAT THE GHANAIANS, WHO WON THE GLOBAL COMPETITION IN ITALY IN 1991, WOULD CONFRONT THE EAGLETS WITH ALL WEAPONS IN THEIR SOCCER ARMOURY.

BUT AS TRADITIONAL SOCCER FOES, THE GOLDEN EAGLETS LOOK WELL EXPERIENCED TO DIM THE STARLETS.

GOING BY AVAILABLE RECORD DEFENDING CHAMPIONS NIGERIA HOLD A ONE-WIN ADVANTAGE OVER THE GHANAIANS, FORMER HOLDER OF THE FIFA/JCV CUP.

BUT SOCCER ANALYSTS WARN THAT SOCCER IS NOT MATHEMATICS.

PANA-NAN IA/VAO/PE/OSS 26MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


May, 1995


WOMEN DEMAND MINISTERS' DISMISSAL


LENGTH: 387 words


 

LUSAKA, ZAMBIA (PANA) - WOMEN FOR CHANGE, A NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANISATION WORKING WITH RURAL COMMUNITIES IN ZAMBIA, HAS URGED THE DISMISSAL OF FINANCE MINISTER RONALD PENZA FOR ALLEGED MISMANAGEMENT OF THE MERIDIEN-BIAO BANK AFFAIR.

THE DEMAND COINCIDES WITH THAT OF FORMER FOREIGN AFFAIRS MINISTER VERNON MWAANGA WHO HAS ALSO APPEALED TO ZAMBIAN PRESIDENT FREDERICK CHILUBA TO DISMISS THE FINANCE MINISTER FOR RECKLESS USE OF PUBLIC FUNDS. 

WOMEN FOR CHANGE INFORMATION OFFICER PRICILLA MUNDILILA SAID IN LUSAKA FRIDAY THAT A CABINET DECISION TO BLOCK A MERIDIEN BIAO-ZAMBIA NATIONAL COMMERCIAL BANK PROPOSED BY THE MINISTER SHOWED THAT PENZA HAD ACTED WRONGLY IN TRYING TO BAIL OUT THE PRIVATELY-OWNED BANK.

PENZA IS ALLEGED TO HAVE UNILATERALLY PUMPED 8.4 BILLION KWACHA (840 KWACHA = ONE US DOLLAR) OF TAX PAYERS' MONEY INTO MERIDEIN-BIAO, A PRIVATE INSTITUTION, IN AN ATTEMPT TO BAIL OUT THE BANK NOW IN RECEIVERSHIP. HE LATER ANNOUNCED THE MERGER OF THE DEFUNCT BANK WITH THE ZAMBIA NATIONAL COMMERCIAL BANK (ZNCB) IN WHICH GOVERNMENT HAS A MAJORITY SHAREHOLDING.

THE ZAMBIAN GOVERNMENT REVERSED THE DECISION ON THE MERGER THURSDAY.

PRIVATE SHAREHOLDERS IN THE ZNCB HAD EARLIER SAID THE MOVE WAS SUSPICIOUS, ILLEGAL AND THAT THEY WOULD FIGHT IT TO THE END.

"WE THE WOMEN OF THIS NATION SHALL NOT LET IRRESPONSIBLE PEOPLE SUCH AS MR PENZA CONTINUE MISGUIDING THIS NATION AND DEMAND HIS IMMEDIATE RESIGNATION," THE STATEMENT SAID.

PANA-ZANA CMM/KL/DS 26PANA95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

ZAMBIA HOSTS INTERPOL CONFERENCE


LENGTH: 187 words


 

LUSAKA, ZAMBIA (PANA) - ZAMBIA WILL STARTING MONDAY HOST THE 13TH AFRICAN INTERPOL REGIONAL CONFERENCE TO BE ATTENDED BY POLICE CHIEFS FROM 15 COUNTRIES AND INTERNATIONAL OBSERVERS.

INSPECTOR GENERAL OF POLICE FRANCIS NDHLOVU SAID IN LUSAKA FRIDAY THAT THE CONFERENCE WILL FOCUS ON DRUGS AND MONEY LAUNDERING. 

IT WILL ALSO ALLOW PARTICIPANTS TO EXCHANGE INTELLIGENCE AND DRAW UP STRATEGIES ON HOW TO COMBAT DRUGS IN AFRICA, HE SAID.

Africa News


May, 1995


AFRICAN BANK MEMBERS DEMAND AUDIT


LENGTH: 520 words


 

ABUJA, NIGERIA (PANA) - FOUR POWERFUL NON-REGIONAL MEMBERS OF THE AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK ON FRIDAY SAID A THOROUGH AUDIT OF THE BANK'S FINANCES AND OPERATIONS WILL BE CARRIED OUT THIS YEAR TO EXPOSE CASES OF FRAUD AND CORRUPTION WHICH ARE BELIEVED TO HAVE OCCURRED DURING THE PAST 10 YEARS.

IN AN INTERVIEW IN ABUJA WHERE THE ANNUAL ADB MEETINGS ARE BEING HELD, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR OF THE BANK REPRESENTING BRITAIN, GERMANY, THE NETHERLANDS, AND PORTUGAL, HANS SCHMID, SAID THE AUDIT WAS NECESSARY FOLLOWING NUMEROUS OTHER AUDIT REPORTS WHICH HAD REVEALED THAT FUNDS IN THE BANK HAD BEEN MISUSED.

ALREADY, FIVE SENIOR BANK OFFICIALS HAVE BEEN FIRED AND ANOTHER 100 OR MORE ARE EXPECTED TO LEAVE AS THE BANK WEEDS OFF STAFF IMPLICATED IN CORRUPT OR FRAUDULENT ACTIVITIES. 

SCHMID SAID THE BANK WOULD SOON ISSUE AN INTERNATIONAL TENDER INVITING REPUTABLE COMPANIES TO BID TO CARRY OUT THE AUDIT, WHICH WAS EXPECTED TO TAKE FOUR MONTHS FROM THE AWARD OF THE CONTRACT.

"WE HAVE DECIDED TO COMMISSION AN AUDIT OF THE BANK IN ORDER TO DETERMINE THE EXTENT OF THE MISUSE AND ABUSE OF RESOURCES DURING THE PAST 10 YEARS. THERE HAVE BEEN NUMEROUS REPORTS THAT POINT TO CASES OF FRAUD AND CORRUPTION, MISMANAGEMENT AND ABUSE OF BANK RESOURCES," SAID SCHMID.

"THIS AUDIT IS PART OF THE CORRECTIVE MEASURES TO MAKE THIS BANK CLEAN AND LEANER AND DEFINITELY SOME HEADS WILL ROLL; ALREADY THEY HAVE STARTED TO ROLL," HE ADDED.

MEANWHILE, HE DESCRIBED AS AN INSULT THE RECENT LETTER WRITTEN BY ADB PRESIDENT, BABACAR NDIAYE, IN WHICH HE WAS SAID TO HAVE CRITICISED THE BANK'S BOARD OF DIRECTORS.

NDIAYE ALLEGED THAT SOME DIRECTORS HAD "TRANSFORMED THEIR OFFICES INTO PERSONAL FIEFDOMS WHOSE WEIGHT THEY BRING TO BEAR WITH CRUSHING WEIGHT ON ANY ATTEMPT TO CHECK THEIR EXCESSES."

"THE ACCUSATIONS WERE AN INSULT AND WE POINTED OUT IN OUR RESPONSE THAT THEY WERE UNNECESSARY AND WERE DESIGNED TO DIVERT ATTENTION FROM NDIAYE'S OWN SHORTCOMINGS DURING THE PAST 10 YEARS," HE SAID.

PANA-ZIANA STC/ET/KTM/DS 26MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

MOZAMBIQUE'S CHISSANO TO VISIT ITALY


LENGTH: 280 words


 

MAPUTO, MOZAMBIQUE (PANA) - MOZAMBIQUE'S PRESIDENT, JOAQUIM CHISSANO, STARTS A FIVE-DAY VISIT TO ITALY SUNDAY, A SOURCE IN HIS OFFCICE SAID FRIDAY.

CHISSANO WILL FROM SUNDAY TO TUESDAY TAKE PART IN A CONFERENCE OF THE 'LEADERS OF TOMORROW' IN THE CITY OF VENEZA. 

THE CONFERENCE IS BEING ORGANISED BY THE ELIE WIESEL FOUNDATION FOR HUMANITIES IN THE UNITED STATES AND ITALY'S GIORGION CINI FOUNDATION.

ISSUES TO BE DISCUSSED BY THE CONFERENCE INCLUDE AFRICA'S FUTURE, PEACE IN THE MIDDLE EAST, AND THE YOUTH IN THE RESOLUTION OF THE IRISH CONFLICT, THE VIOLENCE OF YOUNG CHILDREN IN THE UNITED STATES, AND THE FUTURE OF THE CHILDREN IN BOSNIA-HERZEGOVINA.

AMONG OTHER NOTABLES EXPECTED TO ATTEND ARE THE UNITED STATES' FIRST LADY HILARY CLINTON.

IN ROME CHISSANO WILL HOLD TALKS WITH ITALIAN PRESIDENT OSCAR LUIGI SCALFARO.

PANA-AIM PD/GM/DS 26MAY95

U.S. MILITARY DELEGATION ARRIVES IN HARARE


LENGTH: 294 words


 

HARARE, ZIMBABWE (PANA) - A HIGH-POWERED UNITED STATES MILITARY DELEGATION ARRIVED IN HARARE FRIDAY FOR A FIVE-DAY VISIT. IT WILL HOLD MEETINGS ON AREAS OF JOINT MILITARY INTERESTS WITH ZIMBABWE. 

A ZIMBABWE ARMY SPOKESMAN TOLD THE COUNTRY'S NEWS AGENCY, ZIANA, WEDNESDAY THAT THE VISIT WOULD LEAD TO A COMBINED TRAINING EXERCISES. THESE WILL BE CONDUCTED IN ZIMBABWE THE BEGINNING OF AUGUST. ZIMBABWE AND THE US HAVE CONDUCTED JOINT MILITARY TRAINING EXERCISES BEFORE.

THE 16-MEMBER U.S. CONTINGENT IS LED BY VIETNAM WAR VETERAN GEN. CHARLES G. BOYD. HE IS THE DEPUTY COMMANDER-IN-CHIEF, EUROPEAN COMMAND, STUTTGART IN GERMANY.

DURING HIS CAREER, GEN. BOYD WAS ASSIGNED TO KORAT ROYAL THAI AIR FORCE BASE, WHERE HE ACCUMULATED 105 COMBAT MISSIONS BEFORE BEING SHOT DOWN BY GROUNDFIRE NEAR HANOI, NORTH VIETNAM, APRIL 22, 1966.

HE WAS CAPTURED AND TAKEN INTERNED IN VARIOUS PRISONS THROUGHOUT NORTH VIETNAM UNTIL HIS REPATRIATION FEBRUARY 12, 1973.

PANA ZIANA JIM/NN/NDN/OSS 26MAY95

178 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


ELECTIONS RIGHTS BODY CHARGES BIAS IN ZIMBABWE ELECTIONS


LENGTH: 800 words


 

HARARE, ZIMBABWE (PANA) - A LOCAL HUMAN RIGHTS ORGANISATION, ZIMRIGHTS, HAS SAID ZIMBABWE'S JUST-ENDED PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS COULD NOT BE CALLED FREE AND FAIR BECAUSE OF THE CONSTITUTIONAL ADVANTAGES THE RULING PARTY IN THE COUNTRY ENJOYS.

SOME OF THE ADVANTAGES THAT THE RULING PARTY ENJOYS ARE THEIR ABILITY TO USE THE SOCIAL WELFARE, COMMUNICATION AND TRANSPORT STRUCTURES OF THE STATE TO THEIR OWN POLITICAL GAIN AND A GOVERNMENT-SUPPLIED SUBSIDY OF ZIMDOLLARS 32 MILLION (USD 4 MILLION).

AT THE OFFICIAL LAUNCH OF THE ZIMRIGHTS ELECTIONS MONITORING REPORT ON FRIDAY, ITS CHAIRMAN REGINALD MATCHABA-HOVE SAID THERE WAS URGENT NEED FOR A REVIEW OF THE ZIMBABWE CONSTITUTION, PARTICULARLY THE ELECTORAL ACT. 

MATCHABA-HOVE SAID GOVERNMENT SHOULD CALL FOR A NATIONAL CONSULTATIVE CONFERENCE TO REVIEW THE ELECTORAL LAWS.

WITH THE CURRENT ELECTORAL ACT, MATCHABA-HOVE SAID, ZIMBABWE STILL HAD A VERY LONG WAY TO GO BEFORE IT COULD CONSIDER ITSELF A FULLY-FLEDGED DEMOCRACY.

AREAS NEEDING AMENDMENT INCLUDED THE PRESIDENT'S POWERS TO APPOINT THE ELECTORAL SUPERVISORY COMMISSION, DELIMITATION COMMISSION AND NON-CONSTITUENT MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT.

"THERE ARE UNDERLYING PROBLEMS WITH THE ELECTORAL PROCESS ITSELF AND THE SURROUNDING CONTEXT THAT PREVENT THE ELECTIONS FROM BEING CALLED SUBSTANTIALLY DEMOCRATIC: THE ELECTIONS WERE NEITHER FREE NOR FAIR.

"FOR ITS PART, ZIMRIGHTS CAN ONLY DEMAND THAT THE CONSTITUTION BE REVISED IN THE PUBLIC INTEREST AND EARNESTLY ENTREAT THAT CONTINUAL PROGRESS TOWARDS A DEMOCRATIC SYSTEM WILL NOT BE HINDERED BY ENTRENCHED POLITICIANS," MATCHABA- HOVE SAID.

THE MOST SERIOUS CONSTITUTIONAL DEFICIENCIES, IT SAID, AROSE FROM THE PRESIDENT'S POWER TO APPOINT MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT.

THE PRESIDENT HAS THE POWER TO APPOINT 12 NON-CONSTITUENT MPS AND EIGHT PROVINCIAL GOVERNORS WHO SIT IN PARLIAMENT.

ADDED TO THE 10 CHIEFS, WHO ARE ELECTED BY THE CHIEF'S COUNCIL BUT APPOINTED BY THE PRESIDENT, THE RULING PARTY WITH AN INCUMBENT PRESIDENT NEED ONLY TO WIN 46 OF THE 120 SEATS TO OBTAIN PARLIAMENTARY CONTROL.

THE ADVANTAGES MEAN THAT IN SOME CONSTITUENCIES THERE IS NO CHANCE OF THE RULING PARTY LOSING.

ZANU PF WON 118 OF THE 120 CONTESTED SEATS DURING THE FOURTH LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS SINCE INDEPENDENCE IN 1980, HELD IN APRIL. THE OTHER TWO SEATS WERE WON BY ZANU (NDONGA).

ZIMRIGHTS ALLEGES THAT THE DELIMITATION OF CONSTITUENCIES FOR ZIMBABWE'S 1995 LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS IN SEVERAL CASES SEEMED TO HAVE BEEN DELIBERATELY CHOSEN TO WEAKEN OPPOSITION PARTY STRONGHOLDS.

IN ITS 1995 GENERAL ELECTIONS MONITORING REPORT, ZIMRIGHTS CITED BULAWAYO, ZIMBABWE'S SECOND CITY, AS AN EXAMPLE OF WHERE IT APPEARED THAT CONSTITUENCIES THAT WERE TRADITIONAL STRONGHOLDS OF THE OPPOSITION ZANU (NDONGA) HAD BEEN STRETCHED TO INCLUDE AREAS THAT TRADITIONALLY SUPPORTED THE RULING ZANU PF PARTY.

THE ORGANISATION SAID THE DELIMITATION PROCESS FOR 1995 WAS ARBITRARY AND IRRATIONAL.

THE DELIMITATION COMMISSION'S DECISION ON THE BOUNDARIES OF THE CONSTITUENCIES WAS SUSPICIOUS, THE REPORT SAID.

THE COMMISSION, LED BY JUDGE PRESIDENT JUSTICE WILSON SANDURA, WAS APPOINTED BY THE PRESIDENT AND HAS BEEN CRITICISED FOR BEING DOMINATED BY MEMBERS OF THE RULING PARTY.

PANA-ZIANA FZ/TM/DS 26MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


May, 1995


TUNISIAN OPPOSITION PROTESTS POLL RESULTS


LENGTH: 414 words


 

TUNIS, TUNISIA (PANA) - TUNISIA'S MAIN OPPOSITION PARTY HAS CLAIMED THE MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS HELD LAST SUNDAY WERE MARKED BY IRREGULARITIES.

THE POLLS WERE WON BY PRESIDENT ZINE EL ABIDINE BEN ALI'S RULING CONSTITUTIONAL DEMOCRATIC RALLY (RCD). 

AT A NEWS CONFERENCE HERE THURSDAY, THE CHAIRMAN OF THE OPPOSITION MOVEMENT OF DEMOCRAT SOCIALISTS (MDS), MOHAMED MOADA, DENOUNCED "IRREGULARITIES" WHICH, HE SAID, TOOK VARIOUS FORMS.

HE CLAIMED THAT LOCAL AND REGIONAL OFFICIALS PUT PRESSURE ON VOTERS TO CAST BALLOTS FOR THE RULING PARTY'S CANDIDATES.

HE ADDED THAT SOME MDS SUPPORTERS WERE DENIED ELECTORS' CARDS WHILE THE PARTY'SS OBSERVERS WERE REFUSED ACCESS TO POLLING STATIONS.

THE MDS LEADER SAID HE HAD AIRED THE COMPLAINTS TO THE PRESIDENT DURING AN AUDIENCE THE SAME DAY.

HE REITERATED HIS PARTY'S COMMITMENT TO THE DEMOCRATIC PROCESS IN TUNISIA, SAYING HE WAS SATISFIED WITH THE ASSURANCES HE GOT FROM PRESIDENT BEN ALI.

BEN ALI HAS ASKED ONE OF HIS TOP ADVISERS TO OPEN AN ENQUIRY INTO THE ALLEGED IRREGULARITIES.

THE TUNISIAN OPPOSITION ONLY PRESENTED 32 LISTS OF CANDIDATES IN THE 257 ELECTORAL DISTRICTS.

THE RULING RCD WON 4084 OF THE 4090 MUNICIPAL COUNCIL SEATS IN LAST SUNDAY'S BALLOT. THE OPPOSITION ONLY MANAGED SIX SEATS

THE MDS TOOK TWO COUNCILS WHILE THREE WENT TO THE DEMOCRATIC ALLIANCE, FORMED BY A THREE-PARTY COALITION. ONE COUNCIL WAS WON BY INDEPENDENTS.

PANA BB/SG/SJD/PBM 26MAY95

180 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


WEEKLY PRESS REVIEW FOR MAY 26, 1995


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

by OLU SARR -- PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

DAKAR, SENEGAL (PANA) - THE WEST AFRICAN SUMMIT ON LIBERIA, THE OAU'S 32ND ANNIVERSARY AND ECONOMIC AND HEALTH ISSUES DOMINATE AFRICAN EDITORIALS THIS WEEK.

THE VANGUARD, A PRIVATE PAPER IN NIGERIA, RECOUNTED HOW MUCH THE COUNTRY HAD PAID IN THOUSANDS OF LIVES LOST AND FOUR BILLION U.S. DOLLARS SPENT TO HELP BRING PEACE TO LIBERIA.

ALTHOUGH IT WELCOMED THE SUMMIT, IT SAID, "IT IS VERY SAD, HOWEVER, THAT SOME OF THE COUNTRIES THAT ARE OPENLY CLAMOURING FOR A RETURN TO PEACE TO LIBERIA HAVE BEEN FOUND TO BE GIVING CLANDESTINE SUPPORT OF ALL FORMS TO SOME OF THE WARRING FACTIONS."

KENYA'S OLDEST SELLING NEWSPAPER, THE EAST AFRICAN STANDARD, SAW "A GLITTER OF HOPE" FOR PEACE. 

"THIS IS BECAUSE THE MAIN FACTION LEADER, CHARLES TAYLOR, HAS SAID HE IS READY TO PARTICIPATE IN FRESH TALKS TO END THE FIVE-YEAR CONFLICT," IT SAID.

AN OFFSHOOT OF LIBERIA'S TROUBLES IS SIERRA LEONE'S GUERRILLA WAR. THE SEMI-OFFICIAL 'DAILY TIMES' OF LAGOS SAID WHATEVER PROGRESS MADE IN LIBERIA "MAY TURN OUT TO BE STILLBORN", UNLESS THE CRISIS IN NEIGHBOURING SIERRA LEONE IS ALSO RESOLVED.

"THE CONFLICT IS ALSO TRAGIC BECAUSE SIERRA LEONE, LIKE LIBERIA, IS A SYMBOL OF FREEDOM FOR AFRICAN PEOPLES," IT SAID, NOTING THAT BOTH WERE SETTLEMENTS FOR FREED SLAVES.

IT NOTED THAT NIGERIA AND GUINEA WERE PROVIDING MILITARY ASSISTANCE TO SIERRA LEONE. BUT FOR THESE EFFORTS TO YIELD THE PEACE DIVIDEND, IT SAID, CAPTAIN VALENTINE STRASSER'S ADMINISTRATION "MAY HAVE TO DO MORE."

STRASSER'S NATIONAL PROVISIONAL RULING COUNCIL, IT SAID, SHOULD SEEK CONSENSUS WITH THE OPPOSITION FORCES.

"IN OUR VIEW, THE MOST RESPECTABLE WAY TO DO SO IS TO ACCELERATE THE PROCESS OF MILITARY DISENGAGEMENT FROM POWER," IT SAID.

CONFLICT PREVENTION AND MANAGEMENT ARE SOME OF THE NEW TASKS BEING UNDERTAKEN BY THE ORGANISATION OF AFRICAN UNITY, ALTHOUGH IT HAS BEEN LESS VISIBLY ACTIVE IN SIERRA LEONE'S CASE.

GHANA'S STATE-OWNED 'DAILY GRAPHIC' NEWSPAPER COMMENTED ON THE OAU'S 32ND ANNIVERSARY, ITS ACHIEVEMENTS AND FAILURES.

IT CHRONICLED THE END OF COLONIALISM AS ONE OF THE POSITIVE ACHIEVEMENT BUT ASKS: "LOOKING AT THE CATALOGUE OF THE OVERALL PROBLEMS OF AFRICA, CAN'T IT BE SAFELY SAID THAT THE OAU HAS REMAINED A TALKING SHOP AND, THEREFORE, HAS NOT ACHIVED ANYTHING MUCH TO ITS EXISTENCE?"

IT CONTINUED "AS WE CELEBRATE THIS ANNIVERSARY, IT IS IMPERATIVE FOR ALL MEMBER-STATES TO REDEDICATE THEMSELVES ANEW TO THE CAUSE OF INTEGRATING THE CONTINENT POLITICALLY, ECONOMICALLY AND SOCIALLY" FOR THE BENEFIT OF ITS PEOPLE.

"INFACT THE PRESSING NEED FOR AFRICA IS TO CARVE ITSELF A STRATEGIC ROLE IN THE NEW WORLD ORDER," IT ADDED.

"AND TO BE ABLE TO ACHIEVE THESE LOFTY IDEAS AND IDEALS, IT BEHOVES ALL AND SUNDRY TO REMEMBER THAT NOBODY CAN COME FROM ANYWHERE TO SHAPE OUR DESTINY AS AFRICANS EXCEPT AFRICANS THEMSELVES," IT CONCLUDED.

THIS POSITION WAS BACKED BY LUSAKA'S STATE-OWNED 'TIMES OF ZAMBIA' IN AN EDITORIAL DEVOTED TO THE OAU ANNIVERSSARY, WHICH FELL THURSDAY.

IT VOICED THE OPINION THAT AFRICAN COUNTRIES COULD NOT BE REGARDED AS TOTALLY FREE AS LONG AS THEY PRETENDED TO BE IN CHARGE OF THEIR ECONOMIES, WHICH ARE INFACT RUN BY FOREIGNERS.

"TOTAL FREEDOM FOR AFRICA IS CLEARLY VERY FAR AWAY AND WILL REMAIN SO AS LONG AS AFRICAN COUNTRIES CONTINUE TO BE SATISFIED WITH CLAIMING THAT THE REFORMS (ECONOMIC) ARE THEIR OWN WHEN IN FACT THEY ARE MADE ELSEWHERE," SAID THE DAILY IN AN EDITORIAL MARKING AFRICA FREEDOM DAY WHICH FELL THURSDAY.

"IN MOST OF AFRICA TODAY ANYTHING THAT WORKS IS DONOR-FUNDED. THERE IS VERY LITTLE INDIGENOUS INITIATIVE OR EFFORT," SAID THE TIMES.

BUT, ACCORDING TO THE DAILY, MOST OF THE FOREIGN-TAILORED ECONOMIC PANACEAS ONLY EXCERBATE LOCAL TENSIONS AND INTERNAL CONFLICTS AS THEY TEND TO CREATE A RICH FEW AMONG THE MAJORITY POOR.

KAMPALA'S NEW VISION NEWSPAPWER TOOK A BROADER LOOK AT THE CLASH BETWEEN UNITED STATES CONGRESS AND PRESIDENT BILL CLINTON OVER BILLS TO CUT AMERICAN FOREIGN AID BUDGET.

"THIS MAY LOOK LIKE A DOMESTIC POLITICAL PROBLEM FOR AMERICA BUT THERE ARE WIDER IMPLICATIONS FOR THE WORLD, ESPECIALLY AFRICA," IT SAID.

"AFRICA MUST NOW FACE UP TO THE FACT THAT ITS LOSS OF STRATEGIC IMPORTANCE HAS A PRICE AND THE PRICE RIGHT NOW IS REDUCED AID," IT SAID.

THEREFORE, IT SAID, AFRICA NEEDED "TO STRENGTHEN ITS ECONOMIES THROUGH INTEGRATION, BIGGER MARKETS AND INDUSTRIALISATION TO RELY LESS ON THE WHIMS OF THOSE WHOSE INTERESTS LIE ELSEWHERE."

NIGERIA SEMI-OFFICIAL 'DAILY SKETCH' FOCUSED ON ELEMENTS OF THE ACCRA RIOTS OVER VALUE ADDED TAX, VAT.

"IT IS A MYSTERY WHY THE GOVERNMENT OF MR. RAWLINGS ALLOWED HIS SUPPORTERS TO CONFRONT THE ANTI-VATERS WHOSE INTENTION TO DEMONSTRATE HAD BEEN LONG ADVERTISED AND WHO, IN A MANNER OF SPEAKING, HAD THE RIGHT OF WAY," IT SAID.

IT NOTED THAT FOLLOWING THE DISTURBANCES THE TAX WAS REDUCED BY 2.5 PER CENT FROM THE PROPOSED 17.5 PER CENT.

"THE PROPOSED REDUCTION OF THE CHARGE TO 15 PER CENT IS MEANINGLESS, (IT) WILL NOT BE A SALVE TO THE FINANCIAL PAINS OF MOST GHANAIANS," IT SAID.

IT SUGGESTED THAT GOVERNMENT "SHOULD DO BETTER THAN THAT AND CONVINCE THE PEOPLE THAT THEIR VAT WILL BE SPENT JUDICIOUSLY."

THE KINSHASA WEEKLY 'LE NOUVEAU MONDE' COMMENTED ON THE AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK MEETING IN ABUJA AND FOCUSED THEIR ATTENTION ON THEIR COUNTRY'S DISQUALIFICATION FROM BORROWING FROM THE FACILITY.

IT NOTED THAT ZAIRE'S 500 MILLION DOLLAR DEBT TO THE BANK WAS ONE OF THE MAIN AGENDA ITEMS AT THE MEETING.

"IT IS A SITUATION WHICH HAS EMBARASSED THE ZAIREAN GOVERNMENT WHICH NEVERTHELESS SENT ITS FINANCE MINISTER, MR. PAY-PAY (TO THE MEETING)," IT SAID.

ANOTHER KINSHASA PAPER, LE COMPATRIOTE, COMMENTED ON THE FACT THAT NO RANKING ZAIREAN GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS, EXCEPT PROFESSOR MUYEMBE, HAVE VISITED THE TOWN OF KIKWIT SINCE THE EBOLA VIRUS BECAME ACTIVE THERE.

"NEITHER PRESIDENT MOBUTU SESE SEKO, NOR PRIME MINISTER KENGO WA DONDO...NOBODY HAD THE COURAGE TO GO TO KIKWIT," IT SAID,

"PROFESSOR MUYEMBE LIVED UP TO THE HIGHEST CALLINGS OF HIS PROFESSION AND WITHIN THE FIRST FEW DAYS OF THE OUTBREAK WENT TO KIKWIT WITH HIS TEAM," IT SAID.

"BUT DOES THE ENTIRE WORLD KNOW THAT THIS DOCTOR, LIKE HIS COLLEGUES IN THE PROFESSION, HAVE BEEN ABANDONED BY THE PUBLIC OFFICIALS?" IT SAID.

IT NOTED THAT THE PROFESSOR LIVES ON A MEAGRE SALARY HAS BEEN UNPAID FOR MONTHS, TO THE POINT THAT HE IS HAVING DIFFICULTY FEEDING HIS FAMILY.

MUYEMBE'S MONTHLY TAKE HOME PAY, IT SAID, IS LESS THAT A MAN WHO PUSHES A CART.

LE POTENTIAL, ANOTHER OF THE CITY'S PAPERS, SAID NOW THAT EVERYONE WAS AWARE OF THE VIRULENCE OF THE DISEASE "THE LEAST ZAIREAN AUTHORITIES SHOULD DO IS TO ACKNOWLEDGE THAT THE MEDICAL PROFESSION IS TRUELY ONE OF VERY HIGH RISK."

PANA OSS/PBM 26MAY95

May, 1995


ZAIRE 'EBOLA' VIRUS UPDATE


LENGTH: 227 words


 

KINSHASA, ZAIRE (PANA) - THE ZAIREAN HEALTH MINISTRY HAS SAID THAT THE EBOLA VIRUS HAS NOW KILLED 102 PEOPLE OUT OF 137 REPORTED CASES IN KIKWIT, SOME 400 KM EAST OF KINSHASA.

THE WORLD HEALTH ORGANISATION (WHO), HOWEVER, ESTIMATES THAT 108 PEOPLE HAVE DIED OUT OF 144 CASES REPORTED IN THE TOWN. 

THE WHO JUSTIFIES ITS FIGURES BY TAKING INTO ACCOUNT THE FIRST CASES REPORTED IN JANUARY 1995, WHICH THE ZAIREAN MINISTRY OF HEALTH HAS NOT DONE.

MEANWHILE, MEDICAL SOURCES IN KINSHASA SAID THE VIRUS WAS APPARENTLY BEING BROUGHT UNDER CONTROL AS IT CLAIMS FEWER AND FEWER VICTIMS.

HOWEVER, FEAR OF THE ILLNESS STILL HAUNTS KIKWIT AND ITS ENVIRONS.

PANA LAPS/MBA/LMM/SJD/DS 26MAY95

Africa News


May, 1995


UNICEF LOSES 10 MILLION U.S. DOLLARS IN KENYAN FRAUD


LENGTH: 547 words


 

by SEGUN ADEYEMI -- PANA CORRESPONDENT

UNITED NATIONS, (PANA) - THE UNITED NATIONS CHILDREN'S FUND (UNICEF) SAYS THE LOSS OF ABOUT 10 MILLION U.S. DOLLARS AT ITS OFFICE IN KENYA WAS A "SERIOUS BLOW" TO ITS OPERATIONS.

UNICEF'S EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR COROL BELLAMY SAID HERE THURSDAY THAT THE LOSS OCCURED THROUGH FRAUD AND MISMANAGEMENT OF RESOURCES AT ITS OFFICE IN NAIROBI BETWEEN 1993 AND 1994.

SHE WAS SPEAKING HERE AT A CONFERENCE ON THE OUTCOME OF AN INTERNAL AUDIT ORDERED INTO THE TRANSACTIONS OF THE OFFICE EARLIER THIS YEAR. 

EIGHT OFFICIALS HAVE BEEN FIRED AND ANOTHER 15 CHARGED OVER THE ALLEGED FRAUD.

BELLAMY, WHO ASSUMED DUTY AT THE UN AGENCY ON 1 MAY WARNED THAT "DECISIVE ACTION" WOULD BE TAKEN AGAINST ALL OFFENDERS.

"SUCH BEHAVIOUR IS ENTIRELY UNACCEPTABLE," SHE SAID AND REITERATED HER PLAN TO STRENGTHEN MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTABILITY IN EVERY AREA OF UNICEF'S WORK.

THE INTERNAL AUDIT REPORT SHOWED THAT ONE MILLION U.S DOLLARS WAS LOST TO "PERSONAL FRAUD BY STAFF MEMBERS," WHILE BETWEEN EIGHT AND NINE MILLION DOLLARS WAS LOST TO "GROSS MISMANAGEMENT."

OTHER FINDINGS INCLUDE "GROSS VIOLATION OF UNICEF RULES AND REGULATIONS, LACK OF OPERATIONAL, FINANCIAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE CONTROLS AND WIDESPREAD FRAUD AND WASTAGE THROUGH GROSS MISMANAGEMENT."

THE REPORT SAID THE ENVIRONMENT OF THE INDICTED OFFICE WAS "CORRUPT AND LACKING IN STAFF INTEGRITY." IT ALSO ALLEGED "BIASED RECRUITMENT AND COLLUSION BETWEEN STAFF AND BANKS, SUPPLIERS AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANISATIONS.

THE AUDITORS RECOMMENDED THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A CLEAR POLICY OF ACCOUNTABILITY AT UNICEF.

THEY ALSO URGED THE ORGANISATION TO DEVELOP A SYSTEM THAT MAKES MANAGERS ACCOUNTABLE FOR INTERNAL CONTROLS, TO SYSTEMATICALLY PERFORM NECESSARY VERIFICATION ON PROSPECTIVE EMPLOYEES AND MODIFY THE FINANCIAL SYSTEM TO PREVENT TAMPERING.

THE UNICEF KENYAN OFFICE WITH ABOUT 300 PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY STAFF RECORED TOTAL EXPENDITURE OF 37 MILLION U.S. DOLLARS IN THE 1993/94 PERIOD.

PANA SEG/PE/PBM 26MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

Africa News


May, 1995


RWANDAN GENOCIDE TRIAL COULD START BY YEAR END


LENGTH: 400 words


 

by SEGUN ADEYEMI -- PANA CORRESPONDENT

UNITED NATIONS, (PANA) - THE INTERNATIONAL CRIMINAL TRIBUNAL SET UP TO TRY SUSPECTS FOR THE RWANDAN MASSACRES COULD START TRIALS IN THE NEXT SIX MONTHS, A UNITED NATIONS OFFICIAL HAS SAID.

UN SPOKESMAN AHMAD FAWZI, QUOTING THE COURT'S CHIEF PROSECUTOR SOUTH AFRICAN JUDGE RICHARD GOLDSTONE, SAID HERE THURSDAY HEARINGS COULD START BY THE END OF THIS YEAR. 

THE TRIBUNAL WAS SET 8 NOVEMBER 1994 TO TRY SUSPECTS FOR THE GENOCIDE COMMITTED IN RWANDA IN 1994, WHICH RESULTED IN THE MASSACRE OF SOME 500,000 PEOPLE IN THE CENTRAL AFRICAN COUNTRY.

MEANWHILE ON THURSDAY, THE UN GENERAL ASSEMBLY ELECTED LENNART ASPEGREN OF SWEDEN AS THE SIXTH JUDGE FOR THE INTERNATIONAL TRIBUNAL.

ASPEGREN, A JUSTICE OF THE SUPREME SOCIAL INSURANCE COURT OF SWEDEN, OBTAINED THE REQUIRED MAJORITY ON THE EIGHTH BALLOT IN A SERIES OF VOTING WHICH STARTED ON WEDNESDAY WHEN THE OTHER FIVE JUDGES WERE NAMED AT THE UN HEADQUARTERS IN NEW YORK.

THE FIVE JUDGES ELECTED WEDNESDAY, WERE NAVANETHEM PILLAY OF SOUTH AFRICA, LAITY KAMA OF SENEGAL, T.H. KHAN OF BANGLADESH, YAKOV OSTROVSKY OF THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION AND WILLIAM SEKULE OF TANZANIA.

THE JUDGES WERE ELECTED FROM A LIST OF 12 CANDIDATES NOMINATED BY UN MEMBERS AND NON-MEMBER STATES WITH PERMANENT OBSERVER MISSIONS AT THE UN.

THE JUDGES, WHO ARE TO SERVE FULL-TIME FOR FOUR YEARS EACH, WILL TAKE OFFICE, UPON TWO MONTHS NOTICE, AHEAD OF THE TRIALS.

PANA SEG/PE/PBM 26MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Africa News


May, 1995


UN PEACE KEEPING ASKS AFRICAN HELP


LENGTH: 387 words


 

by SEGUN ADEYEMI -- PANA CORRESPONDENT

UNITED NATIONS (PANA) - THE UNITED NATIONS UNDER-SECRETARY-GENERAL FOR PEACEKEEPING OPERATIONS, KOFI ANNAN, HAS URGED AFRICAN COUNTRIES TO SHOW MORE INTEREST IN THE UN STANDBY FORCES ARRANGEMENT.

ADDRESSING MEMBERS OF THE AFRICAN AMICALE, AN ORGANISATION OF AFRICANS AT THE UN HEADQUARTERS IN NEW YORK THURSDAY, ANNAN SAID THE ARRANGEMENT COULD ENHANCE AFRICA'S PREPAREDNESS FOR PEACEKEEPING OPERATIONS. 

HE SAID SO FAR ONLY FIVE OF THE 41 COUNTRIES WHICH HAVE INDICATED THEIR INTEREST IN THE STANDBY FORCES ARRANGEMENT WERE FROM AFRICA.

ACCORDING TO THE GHANAIAN DIPLOMAT, THE STANDBY ARRANGEMENT WAS PART OF THE UN'S EFFORTS TO ENHANCE ITS PEACEKEEPING OPERATIONS BY GETTING COUNTRIES TO DESIGNATE TROOPS AND EQUIPMENT NEEDED FOR SECURITY COUNCIL-APPROVED NEW UN MISSIONS.

HE SAID IT IS DESIGNED TO PREVENT A REPEAT OF THE SITUATION IN 1994 WHEN IT TOOK MORE THAN THREE MONTHS TO FIND TROOPS AND EQUIPMENT FOR THE UN ASSISTANCE MISSION IN RWANDA (UNAMIR), EVEN AS THOUSANDS WERE BEING MASSACRED IN THE CENTAL AFRICAN COUNTRY.

HOWEVER, ANNAN HAILED AFRICA'S ROLE IN UN PEACEKEEPING, SAYING THAT 6,000 PEACEKEEPERS FROM AFRICAN COUNTRIES WERE CURRENTLY SERVING IN DIFFERENT SUCH MISSIONS AROUND THE WORLD.

HIS SPEECH WAS THE HIGHLIGHT OF THE AFRICAN AMICALE'S CELEBRATION OF THE AFRICA FREEDOM DAY ON 25 MAY.

PANA SEG/PE/DS 26MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. 185 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


DELEGATES REACT TO FAILURE TO ELECT ADB PRESIDENT


LENGTH: 680 words


 

HARARE, ZIMBABWE (PANA) - DELEGATES TO THE 31ST ANNUAL MEETING OF THE AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK (ADB) ON FRIDAY DESCRIBED AS A SHAME THE FAILURE TO ELECT A PRESIDENT FOR THE BANK FOR THE FIRST TIME IN 32 YEARS.

INTERVIEWED BY THE ZIMBABWE INTER-AFRICAN NEWS AGENCY (ZIANA), DELEGATES FROM GERMANY, KENYA, UGANDA, THE UNITED STATES AND SAID AFRICAN BOARD OF GOVERNORS WERE TO BLAME FOR THE IMPASSE REACHED ON THURSDAY, PREFERRING TO USE POLITICS TO STIFLE EFFORTS TO ELECT A SUBSTANTIVE PRESIDENT.

"IT IS A PITY AND ONE WONDER WHERE THE AFRICAN UNITY IS,"SAID A DELEGATE FROM GERMANY. 

ZIMBABWE'S DEPUTY MINISTER OF FINANCE, MISHECK CHINAMASA, TOLD ZIANA THE DECISION TO LET OUTGOING PRESIDENT, BABACAR NDIAYE, TO CONTINUE FOR ANOTHER THREE MONTHS WAS THE BEST THEY COULD DO UNDER THE CIRCUMSTANCES.

HE AGREED, HOWEVER, THAT IT HAD NOT BEEN IN THE BEST INTERESTS OF THE BANK TO CHOOSE A PRESIDENT, PARTICULARLY WHEN THERE WERE THREE CANDIDATES WHO QUALIFIED.

NIGERIA, WITH THE LARGEST SHAREHOLDING IN THE BANK AND WHICH ALSO FIELDED A CANDIDATE, WAS ACCUSED OF CAUSING A CRISIS BY REFUSING TO WITHDRAW THE CONTESTANT, YESUFU ABDULAI, WHEN IT WAS CLEAR HE WOULD NOT GET A CLEAR MAJORITY ON THURSDAY.

CHINAMASA, WHO LED THE ZIMBABWE DELEGATION TO THE MEETING, SAID THE FIELD WAS OPEN AGAIN FOR ASPIRING CANDIDATES TO START LOBBYING FOR SUPPORT FOR THE PRESIDENCY.

HE SAID ELECTIONS TO ELECT THE ADB PRESIDENT WOULD NOW BE HELD AT THE BANK'S HEADQUARTERS IN ABIDJAN, COTE D'IVOIRE, AT WHICH A CONSENSUS WAS EXPECTED TO BE REACHED WITHOUT GOING THROUGH THE DEBACLE EXPERIENCED DURING THE ABUJA MEETING.

SOME BOARD OF GOVERNORS, MEANWHILE, HAD WANTED THE ADB VICE-PRESIDENT FOR CENTRAL OPERATIONS, FERHAT LOUNES, AN ALGERIAN, TO BE MADE INTERIM PRESIDENT.

THIS WAS, HOWEVER, REJECTED ON GROUNDS THAT IT WOULD NOT BE IN THE BEST INTERESTS OF THE BANK, THE SHAREHOLDERS AND THE STAFF.

LOUNES' CANDIDATURE WAS BEING SUPPORTED BY ALGERIA, WHICH ON THURSDAY SURPRISED DELEGATES BY SWITCHING ITS VOTE TO THE NIGERIAN CANDIDATE, AS MANY HAD EXPECTED THE NORTH AFRICAN COUNTRY TO SUPPORT THE MOROCCAN CANDIDATE, OMAR KABBAJ.

ANALYSTS SAID AT THE NEXT ROUND OF ELECTIONS, THE NIGERIANS WERE EXPECTED TO RETURN THE FAVOUR BY USING THEIR LARGE VOTING CLOUT TO BACK LOUNES, SO THAT HE COULD BECOME THE NEW ADB PRESIDENT.

OTHER NAMES MENTIONED FOR THE INTERIM POST OF ADB PRESIDENT INCLUDED FORMER PRESIDENT, ZAMBIA'S WILA MUNGO'MBA, WHO LED THE BANK BETWEEN 1980 AND 1985.

THE RACE IS NOW ON FOR THE NEXT ROUND OF VOTING TO ELECT THE NEW PRESIDENT ON 23 AUGUST, WHO IS EXPECTED TO TAKE OVER WHEN NDIAYE OFFICIALLY LEAVES ON 31 AUGUST. HE HAS HEADED ADB FOR 10 YEARS.

PANA-ZIANA TM/PBM 26MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). GHANA AND NIGERIA FOR AFRICAN UNDER-17 FINAL


LENGTH: 200 words


 

BAMAKO, MALI (PANA) - NATIONAL SOCCER TEAMS FROM GHANA AND NIGERIA WILL CLASH SUNDAY IN BAMAKO IN THE FINAL OF THE FIRST UNDER-17 AFRICAN CUP OF NATIONS.

IN THE SEMI-FINALS THURSDAY, NIGERIA, REIGNING WORLD CHAMPIONS, BEAT MALI 3-1, WHILE GHANA, RUNNERS-UP AT THE LAST WORLD CUP, THRASHED GUINEA 3-0. 

HOSTS MALI WILL NOW PLAY GUINEA SUNDAY FOR THE THIRD PLACE PLAY-OFF.

THE FIRST THREE TEAMS IN THE TOURNAMENT WILL REPRESENT AFRICA IN THE NEXT UNDER-17 WORLD CUP TO BE HELD IN ECUADOR IN AUGUST.

PANA LMM/SJD/PBM 26MAY95

Africa News


May, 1995


GABON POSTPONES CONSTITUTIONAL REFERENDUM


LENGTH: 307 words


 

LIBREVILLE, GABON (PANA) - GABON HAS DECIDED TO POSTPONE A SCHEDULED CONSTITUTIONAL REFERENDUM FROM 25 JUNE TO 23 JULY.

ANNOUNCING THIS ON GABON RADIO AND TELEVISION THURSDAY EVENING, PRIME MINISTER PAULIN OBAME NGUEMA, SAID THAT THE NEW DATE WAS SET TO GIVE THE PREPARATORY COMMISSION ENOUGH TIME TO PREPARE FOR THE POLL. 

THE GOVERNMENT ALSO DECIDED TO SHIFT THE OPENING OF VOTER EDUCATIONAL CAMPAIGNS, INITIALLY SCHEDULED TO START FRIDAY. THESE WILL NOW START 23 JUNE AND END ON 22 JULY, WHILE VOTER REGISTRATIONS ARE SET TO END 22 JUNE.

THE POSTPONEMENT OF THE POLL CAME AMID A WRANGLE BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT AND THE OPPOSITION GROUPED UNDER HIGH RESISTANCE COUNCIL (HCR).

THE OPPOSITION HAS BEEN PRESSING THE GOVERNMENT TO MAKE SURE THAT THE FORTHCOMING REFERENDUM IS FREE AND FAIR.

THE OPPOSITION BLOC IS ALSO DEMANDING CHANGES IN THREE CLAUSES IN THE CONSTITUTION.

THE LACK OF ENTHUSIASM BY POTENTIAL VOTERS TO REGISTER IN LIBREVILLE AND THE OWENDO SUBURB COULD ALSO BE ONE OF THE REASONS FOR THE POSTPONEMENT.

PANA-AGP-GAB MP/JNE/SG/SJD/PBM 26MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. 188 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


ELECTION OF AFRICAN BANK PRESIDENT PUSHED TO AUGUST


LENGTH: 947 words


 

by FELIX NJOKU -- PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

ABUJA, NIGERIA (PANA) - THE BOARD OF GOVERNORS OF THE AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK (ADB) FRIDAY REVERSED LAST NIGHT'S DECISION TO SUSPEND THE ELECTION OF THE INSTITUTION'S PRESIDENT FOR SIX MONTHS.

INSTEAD, THE BOARD ASKED THE BANK'S OUTGOING HEAD, BABACAR NDIAYE OF SENEGAL, TO STAY ON UNTIL THE HOLDING, IN AUGUST,OF FRESH ELECTIONS AT ITS HEADQUARTERS ABDIJAN, COTE D'IVOIRE.

NDIAYE IS LEAVING THE INSTITUTION AFTER 10 YEARS AS ITS PRESIDENT.

THIS APPEARED TO BE THE COMPROMISE AFTER THURSDAY NIGHT'S FAILURE BY THE FIVE CANDIDATES FROM LESOTHO, MAURITANIA, MOROCCO, NIGERIA AND UGANDA TO COLLECT ENOUGH VOTES TO TAKE OVER THE BANK'S PRESIDENCY. 

AFTER FIVE ROUNDS OF POLLING, DELEGATES AT THE 31ST ANNUAL GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF THE ADB HAD DECIDED TO POSTPONE THE ELECTION OF THE INSTITUTION'S PRESIDENT FOR SIX MONTHS AND TO LOOK FOR WHICH AN INTERIM PRESIDENT WOULD MANAGE AFFAIRS AT THE ABIDJAN-BASED BANK.

THE DEADLOCK OCCURED AFTER THE FRONTRUNNERS, TIMOTHY THAHANE OF LESOTHO WHO LED THE POLLS THROUGHOUT AND HIS CLOSEST RIVAL, MOROCCO'S OMAR KABBAJ, FAILED TO SECURE THE REQUIRED VOTES TO WIN.

THE LAST ROUND SCORES WERE: THAHANE 44 PER CENT; KABBAJ 36 PER CENT WHILE THE NIGERIAN CANDIDATE, SEYYIED ABDULAI GOT 19 PER CENT.

THAHANE'S LEAD WAS BASED ON SUPPORT FROM THE NON-REGIONAL MEMBERS. KABBAJ CAME SECOND BUT DID NOT SECURE THE REQUIRED MAJORITY VOTES FROM THE AFRICAN MEMBERS.

THE FOURTH ROUND WITHDRAWAL OF MOHAMED LEKHAL OF MAURITANIA AND RICHARD KAIJUKA OF UGANDA AND THE THE RELEASE OF THEIR VOTES COULD NOT PRODUCE A CLEAR WINNER IN THE LAST BALLOT.

TO BECOME ADB PRESIDENT, AN ASPIRANT HAS TO SECURE A MAJORITY OF VOTES FROM ITS 51 AFRICAN MEMBERS AS WELL AS THOSE FROM THE 25 NON-REGIONALS, UNDER A SYSTEM OF WEIGHTED AVERAGES OF EACH COUNTRY'S SHARE IN THE BANK.

NIGERIA HAS THE LARGEST REGIONAL SHARE OF SOME 10.02 PER CENT AT THE BANK.

THE NIGERIAN CANDIDATE PLACED THIRD BUT FAILED TO GET A SINGLE VOTE FROM THE NON-REGIONALS, A SLAP IN THE FACE FOR THE HOST MILITARY GOVERNMENT OF GEN.SANNI ABACHA.

THE FAILURE TO PROVIDE THE BANK WITH A SUBSTANTIVE CHIEF EXECUTIVE AT A TIME THE CASH-STRAPPED BANK BADLY NEEDS ONE TO BOLSTER ITS INTERNATIONAL CREDIBILITY, COULD FURTHER AGGRAVATE THE INSTITUTION'S BAD FINANCIAL SITUATION.

NIGERIAN OFFICIALS WERE GENERALLY NOT UNHAPPY WITH THE STALEMATE, CLAIMING IT THWARTED, AT LEAST FOR THE TIME BEING, TO ATTEMPTS BY THE WESTERN POWERS TO HIJACK THE CONTINENTAL FINANCE INSTITUTION.

"THIS HAS STOPPED THE NON-REGIONALS FROM STEALING THE BANK", ONE TOP NIGERIAN BANKER TOLD THIS CORRESPONDENT. (MORE)

ANOTHER NIGERIAN DELEGATE SUGGESTED THAT SINCE THE US ALWAYS PROVIDES THE PRESIDENT OF THE WORLD BANK AND JAPAN CHOOSES THE CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF THE ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK, IT WOULD HAVE BEEN PROPER FOR A NIGERIAN TO HEAD THE ADB SINCE IT IS THE BIGGEST SHAREHOLDER.

BUT THE NON-REGIONAL MEMBERS WHO PROVIDE MOST OF THE BANK'S LOANABLE RESOURCES ARE NOT IMPRESSED BY THESE ARGUMENTS.

THEY FEAR THAT A NIGERIAN PRESIDENT OF THE BANK WOULD COME UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF ABACHA'S MILITARY GOVERNMENT AND THIS WOULD IMPACT NEGATIVELY ON ITS ABILITY TO MOBILISE RESOURCE FOR LENDING TO ITS AFRICAN MEMBERS.

SOME ANALYSTS HERE CONTEND THAT THE NON-REGIONALS USED THEIR LEVERAGE AT THE BANK TO PRESS DEMANDS ON THE NIGERIAN MILITARY TO RETURN TO DEMOCRATIC RULE.

NONE OF THESE ARGUMENTS WILL HELP THE ADB, WHICH HAS BEEN VIRTUALLY STARVED OF NEW FUNDS IN THE PAST FIVE YEARS BY NON-REGIONAL MEMBERS.

BOTH THE ADB AND ITS SOFT LOAN AFFILIATE, THE AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT FUND (ADF) ARE DUE FOR REPLENISHMENT BUT THE FOREIGN MEMBERS INSIST THERE HAS TO BE A THOROUGH HOUSE CLEANING OF THE BANK BEFORE THEY COULD PROVIDE NEW FUNDS.

THIS SHOULD HAVE BEGUN WITH THE ELECTION OF A NEW PRESIDENT TO OVERSEE IMPLEMENTATION OF IMPENDING REFORMS TO THE FULLEST.

THESE REFORMS WILL ONLY START TO BE PUT INTO PRACTICE AFTER AUGUST, IF A CONSENSUS CANDIDATE COMES UP TO BREAK THE DEADLOCK THAT EMERGED IN ABUJA.

PANA FON/FT/PBM 26MAY95

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved by the Pan African News Agency (PANA). B.P. 4056, Dakar,Senegal. Tel: (221) 241395. Fax: (221) 241690. E-mail: baam@pana.pana.sn. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org). May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

189 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


KENYA EXPELS RWANDAN DIPLOMAT


LENGTH: 387 words


 

NAIROBI, KENYA (PANA) - KENYA THURSDAY EXPELLED ANOTHER TOP RWANDAN DIPLOMAT, ACTING CHARGE D'AFFAIRES IGIRANEZA THE'ODOMIR.

FOREIGN MINISTRY SOURCES IN NAIROBI CONFIRMED THAT THE'ODOMIR WAS ORDERED TO LEAVE KENYA BY 5PM (LOCAL TIME) (17.00 HRS GMT) THURSDAY. 

HOWEVER, THE PERMANENT SECRETARY IN THE OFFICE OF THE PRESIDENT IN CHARGE OF INTERNAL SECURITY WILFRED KIMALAT COULD NOT DENY OR CONFIRM THE EXPULSION THURSDAY.

THE'ODOMIR BECAME THE SECOND RWANDAN ENVOY TO BE KICKED OUT OF KENYA IN LESS THAN TWO MONTHS. HIS PREDECESSOR MAJ. JACQUES NZIZA WAS GIVEN MARCHING ORDERS ON 19 APRIL.

THE'ODOMIR WAS ON WEDNESDAY SUMMONED TO THE KENYAN FOREIGN MINISTRY OFFICES IN NAIROBI BY A SENIOR OFFICIAL, MAX KAHENDE.

SOURCES SAID HE WAS QUESTIONED AND GIVEN LESS THAN 24 HOURS TO LEAVE BUT WOULD NOT REVEAL WHAT THE RWANDAN DIPLOMAT WAS TOLD.

EARLIER THIS MONTH, ON MAY 2, THE ACTING CHARGE D'AFFAIRES HAD ACCUSED THE KENYA GOVERNMENT OF HAVING A HIDDEN AGENDA AGAINST RWANDA.

HE ALSO REPEATED ALLEGATIONS BY HIS PREDECESSOR THAT KENYA WAS SHELTERING SOME OF THE TOP HUTU OFFICIALS INVOLVED IN THE GENOCIDE IN HIS COUNTRY IN 1994 IN WHICH MORE THAN 500,000 PEOPLE, MAINLY TUTSI WERE KILLED.

THE KENYA GOVERNMENT DID NOT REPLY TO THESE ACCUSATIONS, INCLUDING A CLAIM THAT HE WAS "SURPRISED AT THE WAY KENYA WAS BEHAVING AS IF IT WAS NOT AN AFRICAN STATE."

PANA-KNA RN/SM/PBM 26MAY95

Africa News


May, 1995


ZAMBIAN GOVERNMENT RETREATS ON BANK MERGER


LENGTH: 467 words


 

by MUSENGWA KAYAYA -- PANA STAFF CORRESPONDENT

LUSAKA, ZAMBIA (PANA) - THE ZAMBIAN GOVERNMENT HAS BACKED DOWN ON ITS PLANS TO MERGE COLLAPSED MERIDIEN BANK BIAO WITH THE STATE-OWNED NATIONAL COMMERCIAL BANK (ZANACO), AN OFFICIAL SPOKESMAN SAID HERE THURSDAY.

INFORMATION MINISTER KELI WALUBITA SAID LATE IN THE EVENING THAT THE ZAMBIAN CENTRAL BANK WILL NOW DECIDE THE FUTURE OF THE DEFUNCT BANK AFTER STUDYING ITS CURRENT POSITION.

GOVERNMENT DIRECTED THE CENTRAL BANK, IN LIASON WITH THE RECEIVER TO RECOVER ALL PUBLIC FUNDS ADVANCED TO THE DEFUNCT BANK, WALUBITA SAID IN A STATEMENT. 

ARRANGEMENTS ARE ALSO TO BE MADE TO PAY DEPOSITORS WITH A MINIMUM BALANCE OF 500,000 KWACHA WITH MERIDIEN WITHIN THE NEXT THREE MONTHS. (1 US DOLLAR= K840).

THE INTENDED BANK MERGER WAS ANNOUNCED LAST WEEK BY FINANCE MINISTER RONALD PENZA WHO SAID A NEW BANK 'THE ZAMBIA BANKING CORPORATION' (ZAMBANK) WOULD BE CREATED OUT OF THE TWO BANKS.

BUT WALUBITA SAID THURSDAY THAT THE DECISION WAS WRONG AS THE CASH-STRAPPED MERIDIEN HAD BEEN PUT UNDER RECEIVERSHIP AND COULD NOT LEGALLY BE ALMAGATED WITH THE LOCAL BANK.

THE INTENDED MERGER WAS ROUNDLY CONDEMNED BY THE OPPOSITION, SOME ZANACO MINIORITY SHAREHOLDERS, INCLUDING SOME MEMBERS OF THE CABINET WHO ACCUSED PENZA OF BEING MOTIVATED BY PERSONAL INTERESTS.

FORMER FOREIGN MINISTER AND CHAIRMAN OF THE FOREIGN RELATIONS COMMITTEE OF THE RULING MOVEMENT FOR MULTIPARTY DEMOCRACY VERNON MWAANGA LAST WEDNESDAY DEMANDED PENZA'S SACKING FOR "RECKLESS MISUSE OF PUBLIC FUNDS" BY TRYING TO BAIL OUT THE BANK.

GOVERNMENT LAST FEBRUARY PUMPED 8.4 BILLION KWACHA INTO THE CASH-STRAPPED BANK IN A FUTILE BID TO SAVE IT FROM IMPENDING COLLAPSE.

PANA MK/PM/PBM 26MAY95

191 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


New Opportunities in Zimbabawe


LENGTH: 440 words


 

by President Robert Mugabe

Speach to Dinner in His Honor at Dudley Industries

Kernersville ,North Carolina

May 19, 1995

This is a very great honor, and we look forward to cooperation with this establishment here. Mr. Joe Dudley, who visited us in Zimbabwe a while ago, is a man of real determination who has done so much from such humble circumstances. We can benefit.

In southern Africa, now that South Africa is a democracy, we are working to develop a community that will offer a vast market to the rest of the world, a region of some 100 million people, a supplier of commodities to other markets. 

But in order for us to be really viable, we need investments. And in Zimbabwe, we are putting in place a number of incentives to encourages enterprises to establish themselves and to encourage those already established to expand.

Not long ago, we centrally regulated the economy. We inherited these central mechanisms, and we noticed that the controls tended to discourage the entrepreneur. We removed them and embarked on our economic structural adjustment progrma, called ESAP. We made it possible for companies to remit dividends, no holds.

In regard to investors from then United States, we signed an OPIC agreement in 1990 that protects American companies. Heinz came into our company long ago. Coca Cola, Palmolive-Colgate and a host of other are doing well. And now Dudley will add its name. Let us see a black face that is successful! We are not chasing any whites away, but e are saying, let's be equal.

Thank you for this opportunity. We have discovered your concern about us. We have discovered we are one.May that love, that concern, may that oneness continue to bind us in the future.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


192 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


Science Symposium to Convene in Uganda


LENGTH: 3000 words


 

by Research & Development Forum for Science-Led Development in Africa (RANDFORUM)

The Third Presidential Forum on the Management of Science for Development in Africa is being held on the 24th and 25th July 1995 at the Uganda International Conference Centre in the Capital City of Kampala. The Meeting will be chaired by H.E. President Yoweri K. Museveni.

This Third Session of the Presidential Forum is being held after two other successful summits. RANDFORUM organized the First Presidential Forum on the on 31st October and 1st November 1993 in Gaborone, Botswana. The Forum was chaired by His Excellency Sir Ketumile Masire, President of the Republic of Botswana and Chairman of the Global Coalition for Africa (GCA); and was attended by Heads of State and Government (or their senior representatives), African Elders, Chief Executives of Africanwide, Regional and Multilateral Organizations, as well as about 300 leading representatives of the African scientific community, the major regional development agencies, and the private sector. This historic Meeting was dramatic evidence that there is growing and explicit commitment among African Leaders from all economic and development sectors that they are serious in adopting and operationalizing a 

development paradigm based on S&T for science-led and technology-driven development in Africa. In their Joint Communique, read by Dr. Kenneth Kaunda, former President of Zambia and an eminent African Elder, the Leaders stressed the importance of getting a cross-section of African Leaders sensitized to these issues and having them participate at the next Presidential Forum, to be held in 1994. Countries involved at this inaugural Forum included Botswana, Kenya, Mozambique, Uganda, Nigeria, Egypt, and Zimbabwe. This high-level Meeting was able to discuss and agree to commit itself fully to pursue S&T as a major vehicle for social and economic advancement in Africa on a sustained basis. A major outcome of the First Presidential Forum was the agreement by the Heads of State to the creation of The African Foundation for Research and Development (AFRAND) as a major instrument for the mobilization of financial resources to fund demand-driven research that has direct application to development problems and to commercialization.

The Second Presidential Forum was held on 21st and 22nd July 1994 in Maputo, Mozambique, under the Chairmanship of His Excellency President Joaquim Alberto Chissano. The theme of the Conference was "Mobilization of Africa's Development Oriented Scientific Talents and Management Skills." Sixteen African States were represented at the Heads of State level (10), or Prime Minister level (2), or Deputy Prime Minister level (1), and official Ministerial level (3). These comprised Mozambique (host/chairman), Botswana(the 1993 host/chairman), Angola, Congo, Gabon, Malawi, Mauritius, and Namibia; Senegal, South Africa, and Tanzania; Uganda, Zaire, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. Numerous multilateral and national development institutions attended, including the African Development Bank (ADB), Preferential Trade Area of Eastern and Southern Africa being turned into a Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (PTA/COMESA), African Regional Industrial Property Organization (ARIPO), United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (ECA), and the Association of African Universities (AAU). There were more than 400 participants. A significant proportion of the participants represented the private sector and community-level leadership. The Second Presidential Forum launched AFRAND on 22nd July 1994 after attaining 13 founding signatory member countries and 2 signatories from Africa-based multilateral institutions.

The Third Presidential Forum is devoting its time to discussing "Strategic Framework for Food and Nutritional Security in Africa, 1995-2005"

There is no doubt whatsoever that basic food and nutritional security has become the priority of priorities in Africa. It is not only a question of Africa's self-worth and political prudence. Food and nutritional security has become a major roadblock that must be completely cleared, in order to make way for other priorities essential for sustainable economic growth and social development.

Forty years ago, Africa was self-sufficient in food, and was even a modest exporter of some food commodities, such as palm oil and groundnuts. Two decades later, it had lost its capacity to feed itself; and by 1985, 22 countries in the continent had appealed to the international community for emergency food aid. In the Great African Famine of 1984-85, a record number of 1.0 million people died of hunger, malnutrition, and related diseases in the Sudan, Ethiopia, Somalia, Niger, Chad, Mali, and Mozambique. Since then, recurrent drought, the debt crisis, and civil unrest have combined to further deepen the state of hunger and malnutrition in a large swath of the Sahelian and Sahelian like portions of the continent.

High rates of child and maternal malnutrition has worsened the famine pandemic, and has greatly diminished Africa's human capital. One-third of Africa's population takes energy below the minimum accepted per capita energy daily intake of 2300 kCal. The absolute number of under-nourished Africans has increased by 27% in the last 20 years, from 101 million people in 1969-71 to 168-300 million people in 1988-90. The result has been a greatly increased mortality rate among children under 5 years old, impaired physique in those who survive, and reduced intellectual development in later life. About 2.5 million out of 4.0 million African children who die before they reach age 5, suffer from malnutrition. There were more than 27 million children in 1990 who were underweight; this horrendous figure will increase to 36 million by the year 2005, if present trends continue. About 50-60% of pregnant women and pre-school children suffer from nutritional anaemia due to iron deficiency, seriously depressing the capacity to work; while many more suffer from malaria, leading to considerable loss of working days among the adult population, and to 1-2 million deaths a year among children.

The prevalence of malaria mosquitoes in the continent is ironic, since Africa is, in truth, grossly water-poor, except for the areas adjoining the Gulf of Guinea, the Congo Basin, and Madagascar. While water-rich countries, such as Sweden, have per capita availability of freshwater amounting to 22,110 cu.m. or more per year, water-poor African countries, such as South Africa, have per capita availability of freshwater of only 1,540 cu.m. per year, Kenya only 720 cu.m., and Libya a mere 190 cu.m. Indeed, no African country is regarded as water-rich, except Cameroon. Consequently, Africa, which needs irrigation most, has the lowest potential for it, except along the River Nile. Not only does it show unfavourable topography and unreliable rainfall, its water bodies contained in irrigation reservoirs and channels bear a tremendous load of water-borne diseases. Indeed, one may be forgiven if he concludes that, even if Africa is the second largest continent in the world, it is not particularly suited for agriculture: over 80% of its soils are poor and fragile, and 47% of the continent is too dry for rain-fed agriculture. Yet, 70-80% of its inhabitants depend on agriculture for their livelihoods. This is a challenge that African R& D specialists and entrepreneurs cannot afford to pass over to others. The technological innovations, founded on several millenia of traditional knowledge base, that are required to enhance African agricultural productivity and to put production onto the path of intensification, in response to inherent soil fragility, unreliable rainfall, proness to frequent drought, and shrinking per capita availability of arable land, all demand total concentration. It is a priority that can no longer be set aside.

SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY IN FEEDING AFRICA

More than any other region of the world, food production South of the Sahara is in crisis. High rates of population growth and little application of improved production technology has resulted in declining per capita food production, escalating food deficits, and deteriorating nutritional levels, especially among the rural poor. Unless recent production trends are drastically altered, Africa will only be producing 75% of its food requirements by the year 2000.

One of the fundamental patterns of the African food crisis is the fact that there is no realistic vision and strategic policies to guide the agricultural sector. The African geopolitical leadership is presently working in a fragmented manner, and based on a fragile conceptual framework. Africa is predominantly an agrarian society. This can be exemplified by Kenya, which is one of the few African countries having a significant industrial sector. Kenya has a total of 2.7 million small holdings, representing about 16 million persons (comprising about 64% of the entire population), 80% of whom own less than 2 hectares. Yet, these small holders account for 75% of the value of agricultural and livestock production, 55% of marketed output, and over 85% of agricultural employment. Therefore, whatever future scenario of science-led development is adopted, it must have small holder agricultural production and employment as a contemporary, integral part of that scenario.

The African condition of extreme poverty, human diseases (malaria, river blindness, trypanosomiasis, guinea worm, schistosomiasis, etc), animal diseases, poor soils, uncertain rainfall, increasing population pressures, changing tenure and ownership patterns for land and cattle, agriculturalists, weaknesses in research and technology delivery systems, and political and social turmoil, all make the task of agricultural development extremely difficult. To a considerable extent, the present food crisis is the result of the long-term neglect of agriculture by political leaders both during the colonial and postindependence periods. Even though agriculture provides employment and the livelihood for 70-85% of the people in most African countries, rural and agricultural development have been given - and are still being given - low priority. Investments in primary education, agricultural research and extension education, input distribution and crop marketing systems, are woefully inadequate. Furthermore, many governments have pursued - and continue to pursue - cheap food policies to mollify the politically volatile urban dwellers at the expense of production incentives for farmers.

The impact that science-based agricultural development has had on the well-being of all humankind during this century has been enormous, although it has been partially masked by the rapid increase in human numbers. The benefits from the so-called Green Revolution in cereal production over the past three decades in many developing countries in the Asian and South American regions have been tremendous. It has not, however, solved the problem of chronic undernutrition and mulnutrition for hundreds of millions of lowincome, poverty-stricken people around the world, who are unable to purchase the food they need for adequate nutrition, despite the abundance of food in the world markets.

To reverse Africa's alarming food production trends, her small-scale farmers need access to science-based agricultural technology, just as similar farmers desperately needed it in Asia and South America three decades ago. Even though most of the technological components that are required for a Green Revolution are already available, because of various constraints, e.g. discriminatory economic policies, unavailability at the farmgate of seed of improved varieties and appropriate fertilizers, and inadequate transport, infrastructure, marketing and credit systems. It needs much more commitment and action for a similar revolution to occur in Africa.

There are at least two key problems involved in feeding Africa's - indeed the world's - people. The first is the complex task of producing sufficient quantities and adequate nutritiousness of the desired foods to satisfy basic needs; and to accomplish this Herculean feat in environmentally and economically sustainable ways. The second task, equally or even more daunting, is to distribute food equitably. The impediment to equitable food distribution is poverty - lack of purchasing power - resulting from unemployment or underemployment, which, in turn, is made more severe by rapid population growth and shrinking arable land.

ROUNDTABLE OF TECHNOLOGY-ORIENTED ENTREPRENEURS IN AFRICA

The Third Presidential Forum will be proceeded by the Inaugural Meeting establishing the Roundtable of Technology-Oriented Entrepreneurs in Africa on 22nd23rd July 1995 at the Uganda International Conference Centre. This Roundtable will have the complex task of organically linking mission-oriented R&D efforts to the resolution of the bottlenecks - whether they originate in production, processing, diversification, quality control, timeliness, sustainability, price competitiveness, or the use of natural or agroprocessing and food industries resources or other commodities as starting points - for manufacturing industries using new or upgraded technologies and enhanced management techniques to meet well-researched markets, whether, domestic, or intra-African, or foreign. This would be its first task, in conjunction with the Roundtable of Science Advisors and African Business Roundtable (ABR) in close conjunction to the African Development Banks, the financial sector as a whole, and venture capitalists.

An Inaugural Meeting of the Core Group of the Roundtable of ScienceAdvisors for Science-Led Development in Africa that was established some three years ago, will be held on 23rd July 1995.

During the Third Presidential Forum the Republic of Uganda will exhibit its main achievements in the field of Science and Technology (S&T) and its application in her economic and social development. The exhibition will involve the participation of the industry, R&D institutions, NGOs and Corporations. These will feature industrial development and other major scientific and technological breakthrough in agriculture, mineral resources, environment, construction, telecommunication, electronics as well as other areas of interest.

The Uganda National Council for Science and Technology (UNCST), an institution mandated to oversee the integration of Science and Technology in the SocialEconomic development of Uganda, will have a central role in the staging of the Science and Technology Exhibition. Application of Science and Technology is effectively through the private sector and service institutions. Consequently, the Uganda Manufacturers' Association (UMA) the Northern Uganda Manufactures' Association (NUMA) and the Uganda Small Scale Industries Association (USSIA), will play a significant role in this S&T exhibition. So will other service and research institutions based within Uganda.

The Exhibition will be held at the UMA Showgrounds, Lugogo, Kampala from Sunday 23rd to Tuesday 25th July 1995.

CONFERENCE SECRETARIAT

Mrs Grace M. A. Ochola, Administration and Public Affairs Manager, RANDFORUM Executive Office, P. O. .

30x 49849, NAIROBI, Kenya Tel: 254-2-567787. Fax: 254-2-564376

Dr. Zerubabel M. Nyiira ViceChairman National Organizing Committee and Executive Secretary Uganda National Councilfor Science and Technology (UNCST) 76 Buganda Road P. O. Box 6884 KAMPALA Uganda Tel: 256-41-250431 Fax: 25641-234579

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).

193 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


Uganda's Firms Top Investor's List


LENGTH: 720 words


 

The Monitor

by Nabusayi L. Wambokha

Though foreign investors get the red carpet treatment from Uganda's politicians, local companies and individuals beat them to the top of the investment honours.

According to a just-released local and foreign investors survey done by the Uganda Investment Authority (UIA), "most investors in Uganda re not foreign companies who have been promoted and (given incentives) to come to Uganda but individuals who are citizens, former citizens and residents and companies with previous close business connections to the country.

"There has been rare foreign investment with no previous connection to Uganda," the "Survey of Licensed Investors-1994, which was conducted by Arnold F. Lessard, a Special Investment Policy Advisor with the UIA from the United States Agency for International Development (USAID). 

Of the 405 companies surveyed between 1993 and 1994, 80 percent are under implementation, while 18 percent are inactive or abandoned. The report says the manufacturing sector, which includes large agro-processing, projects is the leading sector with 71 percent of actual investments, creating 28,118 new jobs.

The report says Ugandan-controlled companies dominated the survey sample, with many of them sponsored and self-financed while the joint ventures accounted for 35 percent. The local funding sources exceed foreign sources, but foreign funding is growing rapidly; doubling between 1993 and 1994.

The survey describes a typical investor in Uganda as "currently or previously a resident of the country, has a Ugandan-controlled company, target the domestic market, is in the manufacturing sector and has an investment ranging between US $250,000 and 350,000.

The UIA Operating Summary report for December 1994 and January 1995, for example, cites the case of six foreign investors coming into the country to explore investment opportunities but none was licensed.

The six significant projects which were licensed were all locally owned including Naguru Medcal Laboratory LTD, East African Regional Airline LTD (Joint ownership), G.G. Powers LTD, Sports View Hotel Ltd., Universal matches Ltd., and the Voice of Toro.

The Lessard survey says effective international investment promotion is an expensive undertaking which must be supported over a long period of time. It says the answer for this lies in more pro-active and vigorous international investment promotion of priority sector which have international comparative advantage and marketing such opportunities directly to potential foreign investors.

" The days are over when Uganda can simply wait for foreign investors to present themselves at the doors of the UIA," the survey warns.

It however says aggressive promotional efforts in 1994 and 1995, many personally led by President Yoweri Museveni, are showing results.

The investors are not without their problems. According to the survey, access to project and export finance and to serviced land are the major problems. It estimates that it will take several years to restructure, downsize, restrain and profitable turnround local banks.

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English

194 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


Zimbabwe: Mugabe cracks down on press


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

by Iden Wetherall

Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)

May 19, 1995

Harare -- When Zimbabwe's senior public prosecutor made it clear on Monday that the police had insufficient evidence to proceed with defamation charges against those at the helm of the contry's leading independent newspaper, and that arrests and charges were in any case inappropriate procedures in such a case, a telephone call from the attorney general's office soon put him straight. He was instructed to proceed anyway.

Proprietor Elias Rusike (54), Financial Gazette executive editor Trevor Ncube (33), and deputy editor Simba Makunike (31) were charged with criminal defamation after their arrest and detention over the weekend. The charges followed a complaint from high court judge Paddington Garwe and Cabinet Minister Enos Chikowore about allegations in the newspaper that they had officiated at a state house wedding ceremony for President Robert Mugabe (72) and his former secretary, Grace Marufu (37). All concerned, including Mugabe, have denied that the ceremony took place. 

Legal sources reported that senior public prosecutor Duncan Dingana had ordered criminal charges to be dropped saying the allegations and evidence to date were "not serious enough" to warrant arrest and remand of the journalists. He was overruled by attorney general Patrick Chinamasa who sits in Mugabe's cabinet. Criminal defamation is a rarely- pressed charge that requires proof of "potential disruption to the community".

The prosecution has aroused widespread concern among Zimbabwe's nascent civil society who fears that following its crushing electoral victory, Mugabe's Zanu PF party, which is unashamedly hostile to pluralism and an independent press, will proceed to punish its most prominent critics.

Mugabe has expressed his hostility towards the independent press on previous occasions, referring to it as "the yellow press". He is said to have become enraged when Horizon magazine disclosed details of his present relationship with Marufu last month, even though it had been rumoured in Harare for two years. There has been no attempt to deny that customary marriage exchanges have taken place between the families or that two children have subsequently been born, Robert Junior (6) and Bona (5), named after Mugabe's late mother. Marufu's first husband, an airforce officer, is reportedly claiming that Robert is his son. He has been posted abroad.

Sources in Zimbabwe's diplomatic community suggest that leaks about the couple have emanated from powerful political figures in the ruling party who fear that the emergence of a Mugabe dynasty may one day eclipse their chances of preferment.

The state media, which has remained obediently silent about the President's marriage until the recent disclosures, last week suggested that Mugabe might consider action in the civil courts against those seeking to "damage his reputation" ahead of next year's presidential election.

Althought official newspapers have been quick to suggest that the President's office has nothing to do with the current prosecution, it is difficult to conceive of such high-level action without Mugabe's knowledge.

The well-organised swoop in which a team of over 16 police officers took part betrays a politcial hand, editor Ncube believes. "This is an unambiguous attempt at intimidation," he said, adding that police interrogation focused on his sources in the wedding story.

The three journalists were picked up on Saturday morning and taken by detectives to their offices which were searched. No arrest or search warrants were produced, they said. Defence advocate Erik Morris claimed after Monday's hearing the timing of the arrests was clearly designed to maximise the period of detention.

"It seems to be a return to the glorious old Rhodesian Front days," Morris said, referring to the white monority regime of Ian Smith before 1980. "That is what used to happen then."

Students held placards outside the courtroom saying "Smith's laws again".

The Financial Gazette has been responsible for a series of disclosures highlighting official corruption, the most recent case involving a cellular phone contract.

Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace representative Mike Auret said the arrests were reminiscent of the Smith era and designed to "instill fear in the local media".

President Mugabe is in the United States this week working up investment for Zimbabwe. Commentators note his case for investing in a democratic Zimbabwe will now look threadbare. And stories about his private life are not likely to go away.

The International Federation of Journalists on Wednesday urged Mugabe "to take steps immediately to reassure the international community that Zimbabwe remains steadfast in its commitment to press freedom."

Justice Garwe presided over the trial of anaesthetist Richard McGown last year. On that occasion he declined to institute proceedings against a ruling party newspaper that gave prominence to calls for the "amputation of white limbs" if McGown was not found guilty. In the same case, Attorney-General Chinamasa said in response to defence pleas for action against those inciting violence and contempt of court: "That is the price you pay for a free press."

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025. For e-mail subscriptions, send inquiries to: email-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html. Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.

LANGUAGE: English
