216 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


South Africa's Plan To Get The Nation Working


LENGTH: 3454 words


 

New Nation

May 5, 1995

by Amrit Manga

Tito Mboweni's Labour Ministry this week unwrapped a five-year programme aimed at radically reshaping its priorities within the new political, social and economic framework and which, in the process, will allow it to play a central role in achieving out society's two major objectives-"the extension of democratic gains" and the attainment of economic well-being."

This will involves legislative changes, transformation of existing institutions and the building of new ones. It will also mean the implementation of commissions of investigation, whose finding will lay the basis for new policy and laws.

If the five-year programme is to be effective, it will have to reach our and influence policy in almost every government department-from finance to justice, public works to reconstruction and development, trade and industry to education and training.

Given the framework within which the ministry operated in the apartheid era, the shifts needed to meet the requirements of the new situation are huge. 

It will have to explore previously unworkable links between government and business, examine the possibility of national wage accords and, in that process, challenge traditional taboos that have formed the central pillars of the old macro-economic strategy.

"In formulation the new direction, the Labour Ministry will take its cue from the Reconstruction and Development Programme (RDP)," the document outlining the five-year programme says.

According to the RDP White Paper published late last year, the country needs an integrated economic policy that will " achieve sustainable growth, viable employment creation and a movement towards full employment."

In addition to setting full employment as a target, the White Paper also emphasis the need for "greater participation is the economy leading to reduced income disparities and a labour market characterized by effective collecting bargaining, an equitable system of rights, active policies to address employment patterns and stability."

The document acknowledges the centrality of job creation, which form one of the most important underlying principles of its five-year programme.

The ministry points out that "principally, economic progress is measured by the economy's ability to create jobs and to produce commodities and services capable of meeting the increasingly demanding requirements of the domestic and international markets."

But job creation is also key in the process of deepening democracy. This is recognized in the RDP White Paper, which makes a clear reference to an "equitable system of rights" within the framework that aspires to full employment.

The Labour Ministry makes a similar observation, saying: "Democracy cannot be attained if sectors of the population are denied access to employment at adequate remuneration and in acceptable conditions."

Recent statistics compiled for the RDP Ministry suggest that the task of job creation will require a momentous effort.

Various research finding into unemployment suggest that not a single job has been created in the formal sector in the last decade.

Between 1989 and 1992 alone, 286,000 jobs were said have been lost in the non-agricultural sectors of the economy.

This disastrous record is made worse by the fact that a very small number of new job seekers entering the labour market have actually been able to find employment in the formal sector.

While statistics have been unreliable, economists have stated quite confidently in recent estimates that the gap between the number of people requiring employment and sectors that can provide jobs have been increasing rapidly.

In addition, the capacity of the economy to create new employment has been deteriorating rapidly since the 1980's, with some areas more seriously affected than others.

According to the statistics quoted by the RDP ministry, unemployment ranges as high as 47 percent in the Northern Transvaal province to almost 30 percent in Gauteng.

Except for the Free State and the Western Cape, all other provinces are currently labouring under the burden of unemployment rates higher than 30 percent.

Both long and short-term programmes will be undertaken by the ministry to realize the objectives of employment creation spelt out in the RDP.

To this end, its five-year plan serves to: elaborate short-term programmes designed to draw unemployment workers into meaningful employment; focus close attention on strengthening and refocusing available vocational counseling programmes in the labour department and the private sector; mandate a Comprehensive Labour Market Commission (CLMC) to examine the role of national policy and institutions in the determination of wages and other incomes.

In the short term, the Labour Ministry will have to focus attention on the National Public Works Programme, currently being run by the Department of Public Works, especially in the are of regulating labour standards and training.

One of the tasks the Labour Ministry will undertake in relation to this is to convene a meeting of all stakeholders to discuss issues relating to establishing a regulatory framework.

More direct involvement by the labour ministry could come through other job creation schemes. One scheme which the five-year plan alludes to is a wage subsidy scheme, which it says has to be investigated.

This was tried by the apartheid government when it linked its decentralization incentives to wage subsidies. But the exercise turned out to be extremely costly in view of the corruption that set in with the implementation of the subsidy scheme.

But these short term programmes, the five-year plan says, will have to supplemented with longer term projects, which are rooted in sound macro-economic and labour market policies.

It points out that "sustained economic well-being is rooted in the ability of our producers, be they in mining, manufacturing or service sectors to respond to the demands of both the domestic and international markets."

And at the international level, South Africa's obligations under that Gatt agreement to gradually remove protectionist trade barriers will demand that the country improves its overall performance in the production of goods and services traded on the global market.

The ministry sees an important role for itself in this regard and say the CLMC will have to examine the role of national policy and institutions involved in productivity improvement.

It says in its five-year plan that " the cornerstone of our approach to productivity enhancement is that labour should be viewed not as a cost to be minimized but as an asset whose full potential should be realized."

And it is against the backdrop of this overarching philosophy, which in itself departs radically from that of the past government and even of business, that the five-year programme devotes a considerable amount of emphasis to, among other things, eliminating discrimination in the labour market.

It makes the point, for example, that the South African labour market is highly distorted along racial lines. " The consequence of deliberate and systematic policies of apartheid and other forms of discrimination can be seen at almost every South African workplace."

"Certain sectors of the population have been deliberately excluded from among other things, certain job categories and training opportunities."

The first step in its attempt to correct his imbalance, the ministry hopes to, as part of its five-year programme, produce a discussion paper on affirmative action in a matter of months.

This, says the ministry, will be a product of discussions and workshops involving all the social partners, (government, business and labour) as well as the interest groups, including those representing women and the disabled.

Mboweni's plan also places considerable emphasis on underpinning the capacity of human resources by strengthening and refocusing training and education policies and practices.

It notes with concern that "South Africa currently lacks the necessary skills required to meet effectively the needs of expanding domestic and international markets."

In the context of increasing globalization of the economy, competition hinges on improved productivity, technological advancement, beneficiation of raw materials and skills development.

All of this must be deployed towards developing a human resources capacity to drive the development of a growing and internationally competitive economy.

To this end, the Labour Ministry's five-year plan hopes to implement a training and human resource development policy which should: produce a flexible and skilled workforce, generate capacity for international competitiveness, promote productivity and economic growth, social equity and full employment

Although the five-year plan does not propose a target date, it says it will implement "far-reaching changes" proposed by the multi-partite National Training Strategy Initiative in respect of: an integrated approach to education and training, restructuring of national and industry training boards, developing a national qualifications frame-work and a qualifications authority as well as a skills audit to quantify and assess the skill potential of economically active people.

Critically important to the success or failure of the ministry's programme will be its labour market policy.

The five-year plan says the key pillars on which the government's overall economic, social and political policy rests will also form the basis for its comprehensive labour market policy.

These key pillars, identified in the RDP White Paper, include: worker and union rights; policy formulation; employment creation; productivity enhancement to meet the needs of domestic and international markets.

But before the ministry even attempts to develop a labour market policy, it will have to address a critical shortcoming--and that is the lack of a reliable statistical data base on key aspects of the labour market.

One of the major problems confronting organizations and agencies in South Africa who have tried to assess trends in employment and wages has been the lack of reliable statistical base. This has been a consequence of "a dereliction of duty of state agencies responsible for collecting relevant data" economists researching macro-economic policy options for South Africa said in 1993.

Estimates of employment in the informal sector for example range from anything between 19.9 percent to 28 percent. Employment figures for the formal sector are said to be only marginally more reliable.

There is also no single aggregate wage series available for workers in the formal sector. "Even the data on government sector wages are unreliable," economists say.

Unless the labour ministry and more broadly government as a whole develops a reliable statistical base and sustains it, any attempt at developing a workable labour market policy will fail.

A key instrument in the development of the labour market policy is the CLMC, which the ministry has already appointed.

Its task will not be an easy one given that it well have to develop a policy that meets the requirements of the RDP.

The core of these objectives includes employment creation, rising average living standards, workers and union rights, industrial democracy and the elimination of discrimination in the labour market.

But the ministry is aware that these objectives will not be easy to achieve. It says they could only be realized "in a sustained manner if labour market policy is integrated with the requirements of macro-economic instability and poor performance at the workplace."

It notes at the same time that macro-economic stability cannot be sustained if it is "simply associated with stagnation and declining living standards."

Productivity increases therefore have to be reflected in rising average living standards.

All of this demands achieving a critical balance in the labour market, which up to now has simply eluded the South African economy.

Business consistently argues at wage negotiations that real increases in pay level (above inflation) simply do not contribute to economic stability.

Unions have argued exactly the opposite and consensus remains elusive on this issue.

One of the terms of reference of the commission charged with developing a labour market policy will nevertheless investigate the "development of a institutional framework for integrating the dual requirement of rapid and sustainable economic growth and rising average living standards."

"This will include an investigation of: the potential role of national tripartite institutions in income determination, the appropriate relationship between national income determination and existing wage determination mechanisms, the component elements of a possible national incomes accord."

Any policy that emerges from such an investigation will have to take into account that there is significant lost ground that needs to be made up.

In the apartheid era, those responsible for economic policy, while hailing to halt the dramatic decline in employment levels, also failed to ensure adequate growth in real wages for the majority of workers.

Since 1980, for example, the average rate of growth of real wages for African workers declined dramatically.

This is reflected in the rapid increase in the number of black people living in poverty. this figure increased from 14.6 million in 1986 to 16.3 million in 1990.

But making up this lost ground is not the only difficulty that a new labour market policy will have to address.

There is also the question of introducing new and untested, in the South African context, mechanisms, which have come up against formidable opposition from among business people.

One of these relates to the question of a national minimum wage. Thinking in the democratic trade union, for some time, has supported the view that sustainable economic growth would be impossible if large numbers of workers continue to earn poverty wages.

This view, however, will no find support among employers, who have operated within the paradigm which defines labour as a cost that must be reduced to its minimum in the overall equation.

One of the more challenging tasks that the five-year programme sets out for the CLMC in its search for a workable labour market policy, is examining the possibility of a national incomes accord.

Such an accord necessitates some form of an alliance, first between government and organized labour.

Any income accord will be incomplete unless government undertakes to aggressively deliver on its RDP promises, establish a price surveillance authority to investigate price increases and commit itself to using whatever instruments it has at its disposal to control unjustified price increases.

This will naturally demand co-operation from business, which has traditionally opposed any form of price management.

Without price control mechanisms, an incomes accord will be meaningless.

Although not an easy task the CLMC has been given until the end of this year to report back on a labour market policy. The labour ministry hopes to have a White Paper ready by 1996.

Whatever the difficulties in formulating a universally acceptable labour market policy, one this is certain---it will no t be achieved without challenging some of the traditional taboos held by business and the previous government.

The New Nation is published at Darragh House, 13 Wanders St., Johannesburg, South Africa. Tel: (011)333-2711 or (011)333-2721/2/3/4. Telex: 482226 Fax: (011)889-0630

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


217 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


NIGERIA: Abacha's interview on CNN draws critics


LENGTH: 1840 words


 

Newswatch

May 1, 1995

by Olu Ojewale

General Sani Abacha's first press interview in his eleven years in government is the new news. Since he assumed power in November 1993, Abacha had addressed the press only once. His CNN interview last week made as much news as what he said.

Although, the dead of stated fielded only questions filed ahead by the reporter and did not permit follow-up ones as part of the ground rules for the interview, what he said has introduced new dimensions to the nation's political crisis especially the annulment of the June 12, 1993 presidential election and the politics of the continued detention of Moshood Abiola believed to have won that election. His answers to the questions on alleged human rights abuse and the coup story were no less important in what has been seen as an attempt to set a new agenda for public discourse. 

The most important question was who annulled the election? Abacha said the courts did. Said the head of state: "The issue of the annulment of the 1993 election was a judicial decision. It was the judiciary itself that ruled that the election should not hold. Despite that ruling, the election was held, and still the high court ruled that the processing of the elections should stop and that was when that problem started because there was absolute evidence of electoral malpractices that took place during the election and before the election."

As he put it further: "To say that even there was an election and there was a winner of the election is wrong because I remember in only about 14 states out of 30 states, including Abuja, were election results announced. Before then, a court ordered NEC to stop further processing of the election results."

Abacha denied that his government is repressive. "The issue of repression is completely unfounded. There is nobody that is being held illegally. We have a judiciary system. The rule of law is there and our judiciary is alive to its responsibilities....anybody who is detained is detained through a legal and legitimate means and the due process of law is taking is course," he said. he insisted that Nigerians have been expressing themselves freely without any harassment by the military and advised that "anybody who feels that his right has been infringed can seek legal redress."

Abacha's critics are up in arm. Taiwo Akeju, publicity secretary of NADECO, Oyo State branch, said: "It was an open secret that the military annulled the election," which he said still creates a "serious political and economic tension in the country." Akeju said former President Ibrahim Babangida annulled the election and that Abacha, who was a member of tat regime made last Tuesday's statesmen in a desperate attempt to "seek international support and recognition."

Akeju disagreed with Abacha's claim that the election was marred by malpractices, pointing out that it was adjudged free and fair by Humphrey Nwosu, chairman of the defunct National Electoral Commission NEC, Omo Omoruyi, former director of Centre for Democratic Studies, CDS, as well as international observers who monitored the election.

Chuwuemeka Ezeife, former governor of Anambra State, took a similar view saying the annulment of the June 12 election was not a judicial decision. He blamed the military for the action and wondered why it took the Abacha government almost two years to convince itself of that statement. "Perhaps, they want us to go to court and ask it to de-annul the election or, if possible, appeal against the decision," he said.

Bolanle Gbonigi, the Anglican Bishop of Akure diocese, said it was obvious that the military annulled the election. He warned that "until we go back to June 12, there will be no peace for this country and any peace that we are experiencing will be for some time because it would be an unjust peace."

A former civilian governor in one of the western states, who wanted not to identified, accused Abacha of passing the buck for the political crisis in the country to the courts whose powers to adjudicate on the issue were taken away by decrees with ouster clauses. He cited Decree 50 of 1993 which barred the courts from entertaining any suet challenging the annulment of the June 12 presidential election.

Obi Ogbuitepu, Lagos based lawyer, told "News watch" last week that it was the government which barred the courts from hearing the case when NEC appealed against the decision of an Abuja high court to stop further announcement of the election results. " This was a government and not a court decision," Ogbuitepu argued. He pointed out that a presidential election tribunal was already set up to entertain any complaints arising from the elections but that the executive action annulling the elections aborted this process. He argued that if there were electoral irregularities the candidates and not the government should have complained.

Ben Amanze Omoha, another lawyer said "the head of state's comments were insults to Nigerians."

Another issue in the interview that raised dust was Abacha's claim that there was no human rights abuses. Akeju disagreed saying: "There are indeed terrible and serious human rights abuses in Nigeria today more than we have ever witnessed in the history of the country." he said notable NADECO members like Frank Kokori, Wariebi Agamene, former secretary and president of National Union of Petroleum and Energy Workers, NUPENG, Ademola Adeniji-Adele, former chairman, Lagos Island local government and Ayo Opadokun, national publicity secretary of NADECO, Olu Akerele, Sylvester Odio, Fred Eno who were arrested and detained since last year are still to be released. Akeju said most of them have been in detention for more than nine months without trial.

The Constitutional Rights Project, CPR, a human rights group, was particularly irked by the head of state's claim that there were no human rights abuses in the country saying it had a list of abuses. Babatunde Olugboji, the publicity officer of the CPR, argued that Abacha's statement was not a true reflection of the country's state of affairs. He said the government had rendered the judiciary ineffective by the promulgation of various decrees to oust the jurisdiction of the courts in many cases, especially on issues bordering human rights. Said he: "Today, by virtue of Decree 12 of 1994, Abacha has acquired absolute powers to do as he pleases."

Abacha also took some knocks for his standpoint that Abiola's continued detention was a judicial rather than a political matter. Last week, Anthony Enahoro, an elder statesman, said: "The decision to prosecute in this case is not a matter for the courts". He argued further: "In the Nigerian experience, particularly in what may be broadly referred to as political cases, it is not even a matter for the attorney-general or ministry of justice. It is and has always been a matter for the political executive."

Last Thursday, Tochukwu Onwugbufor, solicitor-general requested the Supreme Court to grant him "enlargement of time", to enable him file his brief of argument on Abiola's bail appeal before it. He argued in a 15-point affidavit that he could not file his brief of argument because he traveled to the United States, US, in the middle of last month, adding that his secretary did not draw his attention to the file on the case until after he returned from America on March 20.

Godwin Ajayi, SAN, Abiola's leading counsel who cited many legal authorities to show that Onwugbufor was wasting time and causing unnecessary delay, described the government lawyer's action as "deliberate and inexplicable." He said the federal government had failed to prosecute the case "with due diligence", urging the court not to grant any more time. He said the affidavit deposed to by the government did not comply with the evidence act, adding that where an affidavit runs counter to the evidence act such an affidavit had failed and must be rejected outright. Ajayi, therefore, called on the Supreme court to throw away the affidavit and proceed with the hearing of the substantive matter of Abiola's appeal before it.

But in their unanimous ruling read by Mohammed Bello, chief justice of the federation on behalf of four other justices, the court granted the prayers of the government counsel to allow an extension of time. The court agreed that there was a delay on the part of the government counsel but blamed it on the junior counsel in the ministry whom Mohammed said did not bring the file on the case to the notice of the solicitor-general to enable government prepare its brief of argument.

It fixed May 18 when Onwugbufor is to argue the preliminary objections raised against the appeal, while June 1 was set aside for the main appeal brought by Abiola against the decision of the appeal court to stay execution of its earlier order, granting him bail.

Newswatch is published at P.M.B. 21499 Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950. Fax:962887. Telex:27874

Copyright 1995. All rights reserved. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast without written authorization.


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


218 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


Nigerian Conference Rverses Onrminal Dte for Mlitary


LENGTH: 3867 words


 

Nwswatch

May 8, 1995

by Mike Akpan

The constitutional conference last Tuesday reversed its last December 6 decision which fixed January 1, 1996, as the terminal date for the Abacha regime. The adoption of last week's motion sponsored by Tony Anenih, former national chairman of the defunct Social Democratic Party, SDP, and 36 others was a major victory for pro-military lobbyists in the constitutional conference who had openly condemned the terminal date as unrealistic.

They had been unrelenting in campaigning for a 1997 deadline. But last week, they got more than what they even bargained for. The conference not only reversed its earlier decision but gave Sani Abacha, head of state, a blank cheque to determine when to go. 

Initially, according to "Newswatch" sources, the plan was for the conference to accept the Gemade committee recommendations. This was later dropped because of a strong argument by the government side that the conference had no mandate to fix an exit date would amount to delegates dictating to the federal government. It was then agreed that the motion should merely seek to reverse the December decision without opposition. This was achieved to the shock of the nation because everyone thought the issue had been closed.

The conference said it came to the conclusion that the Provisional Ruling Council, PRC, would require enough time to consider, study and adopt the draft constitution as well as its reports and recommendations which include the creation of new states and local governments, power-sharing and federal character, decentralization of the responsibilities of the federal ministries of agriculture and education to states as well as return of federal universities and other higher institutions to their catchment areas.

Lifting of ban on politics and formation of political parties, reconstitution of national and state electoral commissions, electioneering and conduct of general elections to all tiers of government were also sited as time-consuming. In the light of these recommendations, the conference noted that it would be unrealistic to expect the military to conclude its assignments before January 1, 1996.

Last February, there was an attempt to bring up a similar motion to reverse the terminal date earlier set by the conference. As "Newswatch" reported in its February 20 edition, pro-military conference delegates met in Abuja February 2, to consider a motion presented to them by two former ministers for their signatures. Those who agreed to sign were to be given N250,000 cash. In addition, they were given promises of continuous government patronage which would help to make them political leaders in the various states. Moves to reconvene the conference in mid-February were dropped after the "Newswatch" story.

Last week's motion and the February one have striking similarities. Both motions argued that the January 1, 1996 terminal date decision had received mixed reactions and outcry from members of the public, majority of whom openly condemned it as "unpracticable, unrealistic and unlikely to have the desired peaceful and purposeful handing over of power to and enduring democracy." Both argued that the January date was arbitrary and irrational and not based on an implementable programme of action reasonably leading to the proposed terminal date.

Both motions listed consideration and adoption of the draft constitution by the PRC, promulgation of the new constitution, creation of states and local governments, installation of democratic structures, formation of political parties and electioneering campaigns as items that required enough time to implement.

But last week's motion dropped the cancellation of the 1991 census figures and institutionalisation of anti-corruption measures adopted by the conference "which started with careful implementation of the finding of all the probe panels set up by the government" contained in the February motion.

Last Tuesday's motion was a big relief to the government which since last December 6 had been campaigning seriously to get the delegates to reverse the January 1, 1996 terminal date. On April 13, Tom Ikimi, the foreign affairs minister, said in his address to the diplomatic community in Lagos that the Abacha regime needed more tome to draw up and successfully implement its transition programme to ensure an enduring democracy in Nigeria. He therefore, saw the January 1, 1996 deadline given to the government to hand over to an elected civilian government as unrealistic.

The adoption of the motion was also a big relief to Adolphus Karibi-Whyte, the chairman, and Olusola Saraki, chairman of the business committee of the conference whom the presidency blamed for mismanaging the December 6 debate and allowing the conference to fix January 1, 1996 as the exit date for the regime. The presidency was to do their home work properly, adding that it was their duty to sell the 24-month transition period proposed by the transition committee to the delegates.

The transition committee headed by Barnabas Gemade, former secretary for works and housing, had argued that a 24-month transition period would enable the tension created by the political crisis of 1993 to die down before elections could be organized successfully. The committee's argument was rejected by the conference. Karibi-Whyte said later that he was embarrassed by the decision although he said as chairman he could not disown it.

But the presidency was of the opinion he could have saved himself and the government the embarrassment if he had adjourned sitting for one day when he knew the direction of the debate. This, the presidency believed, would have helped government to reach out to the delegates and prevail on them to accept the 24-month period recommended by the committee on transition.

As soon as the conference decision was relayed to the government, the presidency stated arm-twisting tactics on December 7. Chairmen of the committees on political transition and business were directed to return the cars attached to them. The excuse was that all the vehicles were due for servicing. But Aso Rock sources said it was government's way of saying "enough is enough."

Even then, it was too late to control the direction of the debate. But on December 7, Paulinus Akpeki, a delegate from Delta State, who had strongly spoken against fixing a terminal date for the military, reopened the debate. He argued that the conference should work out a transition time-table for the military. That suggestion led to yet another round of heated debate on the proposal. Again, it was defeated.

The issue of a terminal date for the military dogged the regime even before it took office. During the planning stages of the coup which ousted Ernest Shonekan as head of state, there was no firm decision by the coup planners. The idea of a national conference was said to have been accepted as a ploy to prolong military rule. David Mark, a brigadier-general, told "Newswatch" April last year that some of the original planners of the Abacha coup "objected to the fact that the conference was to be used by perpetualists as a delay tactics." He said if the military followed the original plan to leave office in one year, there would have been no need for the conference. He said the conference was a ploy to keep Abacha in office till 1999.

Events so far have vindicated Mark. During the sitting of the Gemade committee, government agents constantly hovered around the members in order to influence the committee's recommendations. A member of the committee told "Newswatch" last December that on three occasions, a former minister of state who acted as liaison between Abacha and delegates was giving N30,000 to some members, N20,000 to others while some of the members received nothing from him. Some angry members in the committee went to Aso Rock to complain against government's use of intermediary to reach them.

To win the support of the transition committee members, the government sold to them the idea that they would play a role in the transition programme. The members fell for the idea and recommended that the constitutional conference and a body of other eminent Nigerians should meet once every three months to advise Nigerians on the direction of the transition programme.

The committee arrived at its decision based on three proposals. The first proposal favoured a complete civilian transition government to last for five years, another wanted a military government for between one to four years while the third suggested a diarchy which should last for between one and two years.

The delegates chose a diarchy whose partnership would embrace the military, the constitutional conference and or a body of selected eminent Nigerians. In the partnership, the military was to run the government while the conference and the body of selected eminent Nigerians were to monitor and supervise the transition programme.

Again, the recommendations were rejected by the conference. Anenih who sponsored last week's motion had argued then that the conference delegates would have gone beyond their mandate if they become part of the transition programme.

Worried by the posture of the conference on recommendations of its transition committee, the presidency set up two lobby groups last December to work on the pro-January 1, 1996 exit date delegates at the conference. The lobby groups were unable to penetrate the pro-January 1, 1996 camp owing tot he towering influence of Shehu Musa Yar'Adua, a retired major-general and a delegate from Katsina State.

His arrest and detention in March this year for alleged political activities left the camp without a formidable leader. This made it possible for the lobby groups to penetrate the camp and win over many of his supporters. Those who refused to be won over remained indifferent in order not to risk arrest and detention. The biggest catch the lobby groups made was the conversion as a strong Yar'Adua loyalist. Anenih also succeeded in rallying other Yar'Adua supporters to the side of the government.

It was possible for the motion to get an easy passage at the conference last Tuesday because some ardent proponents of the 1996 terminal date were persuaded to stay away. A s a result, Alex Ekwueme, Chukwuemeka Odumegwu-Ojukwu and others were aviodably absent. Other hardliners like Sam Mbakwe, Ango Abdullahi, Abdulazeez Farouk, Abubakar Atiku, Nduka Umoke and J.C. Ogbonaya, who attended the session appeared indifferent to the motion either out of fear of intimidation or because they yielded to the persuasion of the lobby groups not to do anything to hinder the smooth passage of the motion.

"Newswatch" learnt last week that there were many trade-offs between some delegates and the government to ensure an early passage of the motion. For example, southern delegates were lured into supporting the motion in exchange for government's intervention to stop further debate on rotational presidency.

Another carrot the government dangled before some delegates was the creation of states and local governments. Most of the delegates who supported the motion are from areas asking for new states and more local governments. A promise by government to grant their demands bought their support for the motion.

Part of the deal may have to do with new moves to secure the release of Moshood Abiola, detained for declaring himself president June 11 last year. "Newswatch" learnt some delegates supported the motion after extracting a promise that government would release Abiola. Already the peace brokers have asked Abiola's family and associates not to make any further press statements in order not to jeopardize the new moves. An interview Kudirat, Abiola's wife, granted a magazine due for publication this week had to be pulled out on her request. A presidency source said government may order Abiola's release to appease his supporters as well as the United States and Europe in order to gain their support for the new decision of the conference. Another presidency source dismissed that feeling last week as speculative.

Before last week's decision, the conference had begun to undo the 1996 exit date. Scheduled to have concluded its deliberations since October last year, the conference proceeded on three breaks between October and last week thus delaying debates and recommendations on many issues before it. Even when debates on certain issues started, they were allowed to drag on unnecessarily. One of such was the issue of rotational presidency as a permanent or transitional feature in the constitution which nearly stalled the conference. But the conference last week adopted the draft constitution without further debate.

Last week, Akpeki said the failure of the conference to complete its job within the four months earlier stipulated made the January 1, 1996 date impossible. Ali Sheriff, a delegate from Borno State, welcomed last Tuesday's decision of the conference saying the reversal was "in the best interest of the country." He argued that the military needed time to conclude their yet-to-be announced transition programme.

But other conference delegates insisted that is was dangerous to give the military an open-ended programme. Barnabas Baba from Kaduna State argued that it was proper for the conference to draw up a transition programme for the military. He said the new conference decision could give the military a license to implement its transition for the next 50 years. Uzodinma Nwala from Imo State, said the conference decision was likely to create credibility problems for the delegates. He said the conference should have rather than reversing its earlier decision maintained a dignified silence on the terminal date.

Outside the conference, critics said the manner the motion was handled suggested that the decision was predetermined. Eme Awa, a professor and former chairman of the National Electoral Commission, NEC, said the delegates had proved cynics right that the conference was set up to work for the prolongation of military rule. " I am not surprised by what the delegates had done. It confirms my belief that those who think the military can give us democracy are day-dreaming," he said. The Constitutional Rights Project, CRP, said in a statement last week that the decision had confirmed fears that the conference was set up to be easily manipulated by the military junta to prolong its rule.

Karibi-Whyte, tried hard to defend the volte face of the conference last week. When he met Pierre Gargigue Guyonn Aud, the French ambassador, in Abuja last Wednesday, Karibi-Whyte explained that the reversal of the December 6 decision was to correct an earlier error made by the conference. He said the conference went beyond its mandate last year by fixing a terminal date for the military regime. According to him, the new resolution "does not purport to give the military a blank cheque."

Smarting under last week's victory, the pro-military delegates made another move to push forward the date of the submission of the draft constitution to the government from June 9 proposed by the chairman to June 27 on coincide with the inaugural date of the conference. Justifying the decision, the pro-military lobbyists argued that it was better for the conference to give the agency saddled with the printing of the document more time than for the conference to set a date that may be later be postponed. They had their way when the conference adjourned indefinitely last Thursday.

The move has confirmed an earlier story by "Newswatch" that part of the strategy to give the military an extension of tenure is to delay the submission of the draft constitution till late June when it would therefore make no sense for the government to start its transition programme in mid-year.

Apparently satisfied with its scheming, the federal military government said last Thursday that it would respect the decisions of the conference and consider them in the interest of the nation. Oladipo Diya, a lieutenant-general and chief of general staff, said when he met members of Club Abuja '94 in his office that the government was satisfied with the decisions of the conference which he described as a resounding success especially against the backdrop of the initial skepticism with which some Nigerians viewed its takeoff.

While the government was is a jubilant mood throughout last week, some Nigerians have already stated to nurse their fears on the likely fall-outs of the conference decision to prolong military rule.

There is not doubt that external pressure on the regime would increase. Already, Trans Africa, and Afro-American lobby group in the US, has intensified its campaign to force the Abacha regime to accelerate its democratic process. Randall Robinson, its executive director, said in the CNN interview last Thursday that the Clinton administration was already reviewing its policies on the government.

Last December the administration reinforced its decision to make thing difficult for Nigeria to receive its assistance and any from the World bank and the International Monetary Fund, IMF, by renewing its directives to officials to veto any request made to it or the two bodies. Trans Africa is actively campaigning for economic and diplomatic sanctions against Nigeria and is currently persuading the US not to buy Nigeria's crude oil. The US is a major consumner of Nigerian crude oil. It also want Nigeria's assets in that country to be frozen until the country returns to democracy. If that happens, the national economy will be severely hurt.

Angry with the development in Nigeria, the US is reportedly exerting pressure on members of the European Union, EU, to enforce the sanctions they imposed on Nigeria in 1993. Conscious of the effects of economic and diplomatic sanctions, the government has started its diplomatic offensive by sending emissaries to explain the political situation to its audience in Europe and America.

Two weeks ago, Abacha gave his first ever press interview to the CNN and used that opportunity to dismiss allegations that his regime was deliberately frustrating democratic processes in the country. He told the world that his government was committed to an orderly hand over to a democratically elected government.

The interview was a follow-up to Ikimi's address to the diplomatic community in Lagos. His speech was designed to sell the October 1997 deadline earlier canvassed by the government to the foreign envoys.

After the speech, some of the envoys were quoted as saying their home governments would have no option but support the conference decision and that is the government wanted their support, it must get the conference to change the January 1996 terminal date earlier fixed by it. This assurance spurred the government into intensify its pressure on the conference delegates to re-open the exit date issue. it was not clear last week whether the open ended tenure given to the Abacha regime would still enjoy the support of the foreign envoys going by their earlier assurance to stand by the decision of the conference on the issue.

Newswatch is published at P.M.B. 21499 Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950. Fax:962887. Telex:27874

LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

219 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


CENSORSHIP IN KENYA


LENGTH: 2427 words


 

by the International Centre Against Censorship

Excerpts from Report

Introduction

In a speech to mark the New Year, President Daniel arap Moi announced the opening of a process of debate and amendment of Kenya's Constitution in 1995. The announcements was widely welcomed, including by President Moi's political critics and by human rights activists, who have long argued that the Constitution gives the President excessive powers and needs to brought into line the new multi-party political order.

In fact, the Constitution already guarantees freedom of expression in Section 79: "Except with his own consent, no person shall be hindered in the enjoyment of freedom of expression, that is to say, freedom to hold opinions without interference, freedom to receive ideas and information without interference, freedom to communicate ideas and information without interference (whether the communication be to the public generally or to any person or class of persons) ... .

Unfortunately, as the actions of the Kenyan authorities in the last weeks of 1994 and the early weeks of 1995 show, without urgent institutional and legal reform, constitutional safeguards alone will not protect fundamental rights. Among the attacks on freedom of expression in recent weeks have been the following:

Government denunciations of Kenya's main daily newspaper, " The Nation," including a threat to close it down. This was followed by the dismissal of critical "Nation" journalists. On 1 February 1995, the independent magazine, "Finance," was the victim of an arson attack. Later that month, the government banned all past, present and future issues o f "Inooro," a Kikuyu-language weekly newspaper run by the Catholic Church. 

An announcement by the Minister of Information that the government does not intend to grant licenses for private broadcasting, irrespective of the findings of a government-appointed task force which is currently reviewing a broadcasting company leave to sue the Minister for contempt of court, resulting in the application being withdrawn.

The forced removal, without any public notice, of several thousand people already displaced by political violence in the Rift Valley--violence which is widely alleged to have been orchestrated by the ruling party to disrupt the opposition. This was followed by a new upsurge of violence and the arrest of six opposition party officials and Members of Parliament (MPs) when they tried to attend a church service for the victims, one of whom remains in detention on charges of sedition. In March, the government charged another opposition MP with sedition in relation to remarks he allegedly made at a rally in the Central Province.

Police opened fire at a peaceful event to commemorate the anniversary of the death of opposition leader Jaramogi Oginga Odinga.

The Mwangaza Trust, a body established in 1994 as a policy think-tank on constitutional, human and other issues, was deprived of its legal registration by the Attorney-General in January 1995. Ironically, given the President's New Year speech, the Mwangaza Trust had been one of the main advocates of constitutional reform. In February 1995, another non-governmental group, the Centre for Law and Research International (CLARION) was banned after it released a detailed report on corruption.

Sheikh Khalid Balala, a leading Islamic critic of the government, was deprived of his Kenyan citizenship while he was traveling out of country. I the Islamic Party of Kenya, of which he is a member, continues to have its registration refused by the government.

Koigi wa Wamwere, a former MP and the founder of a human rights organization, and three other people are on trial for their lives in a Nakuru magistrates' court. They are alleged to have launched an armed raid on the police station--charges which appear to have been fabricated. The trial has been in progress since April 1994. If convicted, the four men face a mandatory death sentence. Other people associated with the four accused have also been charged with similar offenses, which carry the death penalty, and some have been tortured in custody. The second half of this report consists of a review of the Koigi wa Wamwere case based upon two trial observation missions conducted by Article 19.

Conclusion and Recommendations:

This report represents a far from complete roll call of suppression of information, harassment, detention, false charges, torture and ill-treatment of government critics by the Kenyan government. Through these actions, the government has severely circumscribed multi-party politics in Kenya. Yet, in a London stopover as part of an investment tour of Western European countries in November 1994, President Moi was anxious to promote the image of a government committed to multi-party politics, stating that "we have embraced the (multi-party) system fully". The following month, the Kenyan government promoted this image to donor countries at the Consultative Group for Kenya meeting in Paris. At that meeting, donor countries pledged US $800 million in aid to Kenya, despite continuing concern about human rights abuses. Since then, there has been a marked shift in the Kenyan government's rhetoric and its use of repressive tactics against those whom it perceives as its opponents.

The government's attitude to the politically motivated violence in the Rift Valley has become ever more entrenched. At the Consultative Group for Kenya meeting in mid-December, many donor governments said that they felt the Kenyan government had improved its handling of the displaced communities and cited this as an important factor in their renewal of aid to Kenya. Since then, however, the government has forcibly dispersed thousands of victims of the political violence, without even consulting the UNDP, its official partner in the resettlement process. On 25 February 1995, the authorities refused to allow an opposition parliamentary team to deliver aid to victims of the violence in the Rift Valley and even detained the US Ambassador, Aurelia Brazeal, on suspicion that she was accompanying the team. A t the same time, the ruling KANU party adopting similar tactics to those used in the Rift Valley in order to divide the Muslim community in the Coastal Province.

President Moi's rhetoric against his critics and opponents has become more pronounced. He has accused unnamed diplomats of interfering in Kenya's internal affairs, apparently in a reference to renewed expressions of concern by foreign diplomats about his government's human rights record, including its failure to reform the country's broadcasting laws. He has openly accused the opposition of planning guerrilla warfare and has warned that he will not tolerate any criticism of the Presidency. In February 1995, yet another opposition MP, Linus Oloch Polo, was arrested and charged with sedition on the basis of remarks he allegedly made about the President.

The government has also revived its use of arbitrary banning powers to silence its critics--a practice it had previously abandoned in favour of more subtle methods. Since January 1995, it has banned "Inooro," the Catholic Church weekly and two non-governmental organizations, the Mwangaza Trust and CLARION. Shortly before, CLARION had published a report on official corruption, funded by the Danish Embassy in Nairobi.

The trial of Koigi wa Wamwere, Charles Kuria Wamwere, James Maigwa and G G Njuguna Ngengi has been marked by a shameful catalogue of abuses; yet the government apparently feels confident that it can ignore international pleas for justice in the case with impunity.

There are some real grounds for concern that some members of the international donor community may have been lulled into a sense of complacency by the move towards a multi-party system in Kenya and that this is being cynically exploited by the Kenyan government to further strengthen its political position. Since 1991, when the withdrawal of foreign aid to Kenya forced the government to concede the introduction of a multi-party system, little has changed either in the government's hostility to freedom of expression or in its disregard for the fundamental rights of its people. Multi-partyism has not been accompanied by the kind of institutional and legal reform which is essential to underpin democratic development. In the absense of reform, as this report demonstrates, temporary improvements in human rights performances are an inadequate measure against which to judge a government's human right record.

Article 19 calls on the international community to renew pressure on the Kenyan government in order to prevent further human rights abuses and to ensure that the necessary reform of the law and practice relating to freedom of expression is urgently undertaken. The international community has a duty to act whenever and wherever fundamental human rights are abused. Now is the time for complacency.

"Recommendations":

Article 19 calls on the Kenyan Governments to implement the following recommendations in order to protect the fundamental right to freedom of expression and information:

"The Media and Political Violence in the Rift Valley":

Allow journalists to carry out their profession free from threats and harassment

Rescind the banning order on "Inooro", which was imposed in February 1995

Ensure that the arson attack on "Finance" magazine in February 1995 is fully investigated and that those responsible are brought to justice

Implement the recommendations contained in Article 19's January 1995 report to the Media Task Force on broadcasting by establishing an independent system to issue broadcasting licenses and ending government control of the publicly-funded Kenya broadcasting Corporation

Ensure that an independent public investigation is held into the cause of violence in the Rift Valley and that those responsible are brought to justice

Ensure that journalists, human rights activists and others can freely visit, investigate and report on the situation in the Rift valley, and cease the harassment of those who speak out about human rights abuses in the region.

Ensure that displaced people and those organizations which work with them are fully informed and consulted about resettlement plans and about the situation in their home areas before resettlement takes place.

"Freedom of Association":

Allow CLARION and the Mwangaza Trust to resume their activities, free from intimidation and amend the law on freedom of association to ensure that organizations cannot be banned because of the peaceful political activity

Allow opposition political party activists and MPs to hold meeting without harassment, and amend legal provisions which require permits for meeting to ensure that these cannot be applied in an arbitrary or discriminatory manner to ban peaceful political gatherings.

Allow the IPK to register as a political party and to operate freely, and return Kenyan citizenship to Sheikh Khalid Balala.

"False charges, prison conditions, and torture":

Immediately release all those who have been detained on false charges, including Koigi wa Wamwere, Charles Kuria Wamwere, James Maigwa and G G Njuguna Ngengi, and cease the practice of bringing false criminal charges against human rights activists and government critics on account of their peaceful activities.

Investigate all allegations of torture an ill-treatment in custody, bring those responsible to justice and compensate the victims.

Ensure that the treatment of prisoners meets the UN Standard Minimum Rules for the treatment of Prisoners.

Review laws governing the conduct of trials in Kenya to ensure that they meet the fair trial requirements of international human rights law.

The International Centre Against Censorship, 33 Islington High Street, London N1 9LH, United Kingdom, tel: (071) 278 9292, fax : (071) 713 1356

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


220 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


Kenya's Human Right Record: A Catalogue of Abuses


LENGTH: 694 words


 

by the International Centre Against Censorship

Press Statement, April 1995

Article 19 calls for renewed international pressure on the Kenyan government to halt flagrant human rights abuses according to "Censorship in Kenya: Government Critics face the Death Sentence", Article 19's new report released today (3 April).

The report concludes that without urgent legal and institutional reform, multi-party politics has little practical impact in Kenya. Opposition politicians are harassed and prevented from holding meeting with their constituents; the government continues its tight control of the most important mass media, radio, and television; and those who speak out against the government face harassment, detention, false charges and even torture. The Islamic Party of Kenya continues to be banned and Article 19 fears that the ruling KANU party, using similar tactics to those used in the Rift Valley, is attempting to sow dissension among the Muslim community in the Coast Province. 

The report also reviews the government's human rights record since Kenya's international aid donors pledged US $800 million to Kenya in December 1994. Article 19 fears that Kenya's aid donors have slackened pressure for real change and substantial human rights reform. In the absence of such reform, human rights violations continue, as the following cases demonstrate:

The forced dispersal of thousands of people displaced by the Rift Valley violence in late December 1994. In response to international criticism, the government stopped this practice and, in March, withdrew security regulations in the Rift Valley area.

Bannings of publications and organizations critical of the government. Since January 1995, the government has banned two non-governmental groups, CLARION and the Mwangaza Trust, as well as a weekly newspaper, "Inooro".

Continuing abuses in the protracted trial of Koigi wa Wamwere and others who face the death penalty on charges of attempted armed robbery. Article 19 concludes that the accused are undergoing an unfair trial on false, politically-motivated charges, based on fabricated evidence.

Alarmingly, violent attacks by unknown assailants have also increased. In February, the offices of the independent "Finance" magazine were set on fire. The following month, the Legal Aid Centre was forced to close after being repeatedly petrol-bombed. In the last attack, the assailants shot two security guards and fired on people who tried to intervene.

Frances D'Souza, Article 19's Executive Director commented:

Article 19 calls for the withdrawal of the charges against Koigi wa Wamwere, Charles Kuria Wamwere, James Maigwa and GG Njuguna Ngengi, whose trial has been marked by a catalogue of abuses. The government has refused to withdraw the ill-founded charges against the four, arguing that this would be an interference in the judicial process. But by pursuing these charges the government has itself undermined the reputation and standing of the judiciary.

The government has shamefully exploited both ethnic divisions and legal mechanisms to undermine multi-party politics in Kenya. The international community must take every opportunity to press the Kenyan government to implement legal and institutional reforms which guarantee freedom of expression and other fundamental rights.

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


221 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


Congressional Letter on Africa Aid


LENGTH: 787 words


 

May 17, 1995

Four members of the House of Representatives have taken the initiative to ask their colleagues to sign a letter in support of aid to Africa, to be sent to the chairpersons of the relevant committees that are considering the budget this month and in June.

The four are Amo Houghton (R-NY), Gary Ackerman (D-NY), Doug Bereuter (R-NE), and Donald Payne (D-NJ). Other members of Congress have recently received an invitation to become co- signers. In communicating with your member of Congress concerning aid to Africa, one concrete measure you can urge on them is to sign on to this letter by contacting the offices of Rep. Houghton or Rep. Ackerman. 

The draft text of the letter as sent out by the four members is as follows.

In this time of diminishing resources, the American people are demanding improved fiscal responsibility and sound spending choices that are consistent with American principles. We are, therefore, concerned that current proposals to cut foreign aid, especially development assistance to Africa, misrepresent the will of the American people.

One sound spending choice would be to maintain the Development Fund for Africa as a separate account at a funding level sufficient to foster sustainable development. Disproportionate or severe cuts will undermine this purpose.

As you know, Africa is a continent in crisis -- conflict, famine, environmental degradation and debt burdens beset many nations. These crises too often overshadow the nations on the continent where progress toward democracy and economic growth have greatly improved the context for and impact of U.S. assistance. But Africa is also facing opportunity. Now is not the time to pull back. Now is the time to shift emphasis, promote self-help development, peaceful resolution of conflicts and debt reduction.

The Development Fund for Africa and the African Development Foundation have contributed to Africa's gains in health care, educational opportunities and small business development. As a result, in our minds, it is in the U.S. national interest to assist African nations. Africa is the last great development frontier, a potentially significant partner in world trade. Investments in Africa's people -- to help them meet their basic needs, increase their incomes, develop their infrastructure, participate in decisions and resolve conflicts -- are essential to creating an environment for the fair trade and investment opportunities that will lead to sustained economic and social progress.

U.S. assistance can also help address war and debt, two major obstacles to development in Africa. By providing resources to African organizations engaged in mediating conflicts, the U.S. can support African solutions to African problems. And by forgiving some of the debt owed to the U.S., we can help African nations devote more resources to education and health care and create a better environment for economic growth.

Maintaining effective aid programs for Africa with a level adequate to meet both the needs and the opportunities is in our national interest. We therefore asks that these programs not be signaled out to carry a severe or disproportionate share of the program cutbacks needed to meet the commitment to reducing the federal budget.

This material is made available by the Washington Office on Africa (WOA)., a not-for-profit church, trade union and civil rights group supported organization that works with Congress on Africa-related legislation.Reposting or reproduction (with acknowledgement) is welcomed. For additional information: Washington Office on Africa 110 Maryland Ave. NE, #112 Washington, DC 20002. Phone: 202-546-7961. Fax: 202-546-1545. Email: woa@igc.apc.org. Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English
