222 of 222 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May, 1995


Peacekeeping: From a Crossroads to the Future


SECTION: NEWS, DOCUMENTS & COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 6054 words


 

International Peace Academy

May 1995

by Olara A. Otunnu

Mr. Chairman, Distinguished Representatives, Ladies and Gentlemen.

As on previous occasions, once again I feel very honored to have been asked to address the United Nations Special Committee on Peacekeeping Operations at its 1995 session. The work of this Committee has always been very important, but never more so than today. The mandate of your Committee has assumed special significance in recent years because, on the one hand, peacekeeping and related activities have become perhaps the most important single area of preoccupation for the United Nations and, on the other, because the evolution of these activities is now caught in the midst of a critical historical crossroads.

I propose to divide my remarks into two parts. In the first part, I will provide a brief overview of recent IPA activities, those with a direct bearing on the work of this Committee. The second part of my remarks will be largely an exercise in stock-taking. I will outline some key issues for consideration by this Committee in the context of improving and strengthening the peaceand-security activities of the United Nations. 

There are five areas of recent IPA program activities on which I should like to update the Committee, namely Policy Training Seminars; Policy Symposia; Research Program; Facilitation of Conflict Resolution; and Africa Program.

IPA organizes and conducts a number of policy training seminars on peacekeeping and conflict resolution. The sessions are generally of one to two weeks' duration. Participants in these seminars are drawn from the senior ranks of diplomats, military officers, members of the UN Secretariat as well as the Secretariats of regional organizations and officials of humanitarian organizations. The seminar program is designed to fulfill three inter-related objectives: first, todeepen the knowledge and expertise of participants on critical policy issues relating to peacekeeping and peacemaking; second, to provide opportunities for comparing various national and regional experiences; and third, to provide a setting for networking amongst participants coming from different parts of the world.

This year marks the 25th anniversary of the Vienna Seminar, the flagship of our seminar program. We are proud to count many of the distinguished representatives on this Committee amongst the alumni of the Vienna Seminar. The Paris Seminar has a particular importance. for us as one of the few French-language international seminars of its kind. I am pleased to announce that plans are now underway to launch two new training seminars. We plan to organize, here in New York, an annual seminar primarily for the benefit of members of the Permanent Missions and the staff of the UN Secretariat; the inaugural session for this seminar is scheduled for later this year. In addition, at the request of the eleven states of Central Africa and pursuant to UN General Assembly Resolution A.49/76C of last year, IPA has accepted to organize a special Frenchlanguage seminar program focusing on trainers and on peacekeeping preparedness for the states of the sub-region.

Over the years, IPA has developed a tradition of organizing policy symposia of two or three days duration, which bring together high-level policy-makers from governments and international organizations, scholars, and independent opinion-makers for in-depth policy discussions on an important topical theme (e.g. "Humanitarian Action in Conflict Situations", Princeton, October 1993; "The Role and Composition ofthe Security Council", February 1994) or a cluster of cutting-edge issues (e.g. "New Dimensions of United Nations Peace-keeping Operations", Tokyo, January 1995) relating to peacekeeping and conflict resolution. The policy symposia have two objectives: on the one hand, to provide an occasion for a deeper reflection on the issues in question, and, on the other, to come up with specific insights and recommendations that can be of practical use to policy-makers.

We have organized two important policy symposia since the beginning of this year. In mid-January, we organized in Tokyo, in collaboration with The United Nations University and with the support of the Government of Japan, a symposium on the theme "New Dimensions of United Nations Peace-keeping Operations." In early March in Vienna, IPA and the Government of Austria jointly sponsored a special high-level symposium on the theme "Peacemaking and Peacekeeping for the Next Century" That symposium was especially organized to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the annual Vienna Seminar and the 50th anniversary of the United Nations. The reports from these two symposia will be ready in May. The discussions in Tokyo and Vienna and their outcomes represent part of IPA's intellectual contribution to the commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the United Nations.

The purpose of IPA's Research Program has been to monitor and assess UN and other multilateral peace operations with a view to drawing lessons from those experiences for the future. In this connection, we have just completed case studies of the peace processes in Cambodia and El

Salvador. An IPA Occasional Paper on Cambodia (UNPeacekeeping in Cambodia: UNTAC's Civil Mandate, by Michael Doyle) has just been published. A similar occasional paper on El Salvador ("Seeking Peace with Justice: UN Strategies in Fl Salvador", by Ian Johnstone) will be coming out shortly. An edited volume containing a comprehensive coverage of both the Cambodia and El Salvador cases will be published in early 1996.

In the next phase of our research program, in addition to continuing with some case studies, we shall focus especially on the question of preventive action. The idea here is to build a body of theoretical and practical knowledge to help us answer the question: Is conflict prevention possible? Can preventive measures work? And if so, how?

IPA plays a facilitating role in efforts to settle particular conflicts by providing a middle ground where options for political settlements may be explored with the parties in conflict. In shaping this role for the future, we intend to place special emphasis "onprevensive action".

Earlier, in the context of our research program, I spoke of the need to build a body of knowledge, to develop a better understanding, to probe more thoroughly the boundaries of preventive action. I believe that there is a parallel need to build a "body of practice" and experience in the field of preventive action. This means that the UN and other organizations interested in preventive activities should identify particular countries in actual or potential conflict, in effect to 'adopt' particular conflict situations, and work with local parties to apply a selection of preventive measures over an extended period of time. Only through such a strategy of "preventive engagement", applied over time, can we hope to build a body of practice and experience that will enable us, down the road, to speak with any confidence about preventive action.

It is in this spirit that IPA has fommulated a project on preventive action in Burundi as part of our Program on Preventive Action. In a similar way, we are now working to identify one or two other conflict situations to 'adopt' for preventive engagement; these will most likely be from East/Central Europe and from Asia.

We at IPA recognize the important role that regional organizations must necessarily come to play in the field of peacemaking and peacekeeping. But for this to come to pass, no efforts should be spared to assist them to develop their capacities for action more fully. It is in this context that over the last four years IPA has worked closely with the Organization of African Unity (OAU) to explore ways in which the pan-Afriean organization can respond more effectively to the drama of conflict on the African continent These efforts have already borne fruit in the adoption, in June 1993, of a new OAU mechanism --- The Mechanism for Conflict Prevention, Management and Resolution.

The tasks ahead, in many ways more formidable than the formulation of the Mechanism itself, are two-fold. The first task is how to translate the OAU's intent, embodied in the Mechanism, into an instrument that can make a difference on the ground. The second challenge, equally important, is how to build a broad constituency of support within Africa for the OAU Mechanism in particular, and more generally for all efforts aimed at managing conflicts more peacefully on the continent.

With these objectives in mind, IPA is currently undertaking two projects in collaboration with the OAU.

i. Task Force on Peace Operations in Africa. The mission of the Task Force is to fommulate a graduated program of practical step-by-step measures for the operationalisation of the OAU Mechanism. This exercise will have to take into account several factors and developments, including recent OAU experience; what the 'political traffic' in Africa can bear at any given moment; the role of the UN; the potential role of sub-regional arrangements in different parts of Africa; and the availability of resources, short and long term within and outside Africa, for this purpose. In this context, in addition to what IPA has built in this area over the last four years, we intend to draw on several very useful initiatives which have been undertaken recently; we welcome, in particular, the report which has just been completed under the joint auspices of the Permanent Missions of the United Kingdom and Nigeria.

ii. IPA/OAU Consultation on Civil Societv and Conflict Management in Africa. This consultation, which will be the fourth in our series of consultations on conflict management in Africa, is scheduled for early next year. It will focus on the role of civil society and other nonofficial actors in conflict management and peace initiatives in Africa, and on how to link these activities to the OAU Mechanism. The consultation is also designed to facilitate networking amongst non-official actors in the field of conflict management in Africa.

I shall be meeting this weekend in Addis Ababa with the OAU Secretary General, Dr. Salim Ahmed Salim, to discuss and plan the next steps in the execution of the projects I have outlined above.

The evolution of UN peacekeeping thus far may be divided into three distinct but closely related phases. During the first phase, the UN developed and practiced what has come to be known as traditional peacekeeping, with its emphasis on consent and cooperation; ceasefire; impartiality; and the non-use of force, except in self-defense. Traditional peacekeeping, which was applied mainly in inter-state conflicts, dominated UN practice for four decades, covering the period from 1948 to about 1988.

In the immediate aftemmath of the Cold War, a broader, more ambitious and intrusive notion of peacekeeping emerged. This evolution marked the second phase which has been characterized, amongst others, by increasing UN engagement in a broad range of intra-state conflicts; involvement in the process of national political reconstruction, including supervision of elections and the resuscitation of collapsed state structures; the growth and transformation of humanitarian action; the 'graying' of the vital zone between peacekeeping and enforcement action; and new questions concerning the issue of impartiality. This second phase gained universal currency with the publication by the UN SecretaryBeneral, Dr. Boutros Boutros-Ghali, of his seminal paper "An Agenda for Peace" in January 1992.

After several years of extensive engagement and experimentation in multidimensional peacekeeping, the UN has successfully conducted several major operations, such as in Namibia, Cambodia, El Salvador and Mozambique. At the same time, the Organization has experienced some tragic failures, as evidenced by Somalia, Rwanda, the earlier setback in Angola and the continuing quagmire in the former Yugoslavia. As we look back, what in fact are the "valid" lessons we can draw from these first two phases of UN peace-and-security activities?

There are signs that the UN may be entering a third phase of peacemaking and peacekeeping, a phase marked by reduced ambition, loss of confidence and a general mood of retrenchment. But the onset of this third phase is still very tentative. It is not yet clear if these signs of retrenchment are a passing phenomenon, an interregnum marking the present period of great uncertainties, or whether we are witnessing an enduring wave of the future.

As this Committee deliberates on the future course of peacekeeping and related activities, I wish to highlight some issues for your consideration in that connection.

We all are agreed about the importance of preventive action, even though we know very little in practice about this particular peace activity. The UN and other international organizations need to invest a lot more in preventive measures; successful preventive action can be highly costeffective, saving lives and sparing general destruction, in addition to being considerably cheaper than a peacekeeping operation.

That being said, however, let me offer some clarifications concerning this question. First, as I indicated earlier in my remarks, it is critical that we work to build a body of both "serious knowledge and serious pracice" through systematic preventive engagement in specific situations of actual or potential conflict. This will require innovation and long-term commitrnent. Unless we do this, I fear that preventive action will simply remain an easy and empty slogan.

Second, while we must probe the boundaries of preventive possibilities to the outer limits, we must not lose sight of some serious constraints inherent in this enterprise. How, for example, shall we overcome the shield of national sovereignty, a country's sense of national pride, the temptation for brinkmanship, asymmetry of response amongst parties in conflict, the tendency to misread a developing situation until it is too late, or the lack of interest or will on the part of international actors?

Third, we must not view conflict prevention as the abolition of all conflicts in society. After all, conflict by which I mean competition for power and resources is entirely natural to society. It is the essence of the political process. The challenge of preventive action is different, it is about how to manage this competition without plunging a society into a spiral of violence. It is about how to build patterns of development, institutions, and political cultures that can mediate such competition peacefully and routinely.

Fourthly, by preventive action I am referring to a broad spectrum of activities, going well beyond the traditional notion of preventive diplomacy or the new mechanism of preventive deployment. Preventive action must encompass a broad palette of political, economic, social and humanitarian measures aimed at preventing or de-escalating-the development of conflict and, because of the often circular rather than linear nature of the evolution of conflict, avoiding its recurrence.

It is clear that the UN is over-extended in terms of resources and capacity to perform well the many tasks it has assumed over the last several years. This situation, which has now reached a critical point, calls for an appropriate division of responsibilities between the UN and other international actors in the spheres of preventive action, peacemaking, peacekeeping, enforcement action and peacebuilding. Such a division of labor could take advantage of the different capabilities and interests of regional organizations, national governments and nongovernmental organizations. A possible division of labor may be developed along the following areas of concentration.

i. The UN. The UN should concentrate its efforts on traditional peacekeeping, mediation, peacebuilding activities, and invest more energy in preventive action.

ii Sub-contracting to outside coalitions. For the foreseeable future, enforcement action will have to be 'farmed out' to what may be called 'coalitions ofthe willing and able.' In such a situation, the Security Council should, however, not simply authorize the action but also be more closely associated with the execution and the conclusion of the operation.

When it is envisaged, as was the case in Somalia and Haiti, that the UN should take over a situation following the completion of enforcement action, then this calls for early and adequate preparation for assuming that responsibility. Particular attention needs to be given, for example, to formulating and organizing clear transition arrangements for this purpose.

iii. Regional Organizations. In time, regional organizations must come to assume greater responsibility for peace and security. Alas, that time is not yet here. Most regional organizations are still far from being able to play the role envisaged for them in Chapter VIII of the Charter, mainly because of their lack of --- relevant tradition, financial resources, political prestige and credibility, impartiality, and operational capacity. This places a particular responsibility on the United Nations, the major powers, traditional peacekeeping countries, and other bilateral and multilateral donors to work in a concerted manner to help build the capacities of regional organizations. Until then, we must guard against exaggerated expectations. For the time being, the areas of concentration for regional organizations should be preventive action and peacemaking, while allowing for the gradual development of peacekeeping capacities.

But the emphasis on the role of regional organizations must not lead to a sort of tribalisation of peacekeeping activities, whereby, for example, conflicts in Europe are viewed as the responsibility of the Europeans or African conflicts as the responsibility of the Africans. This notion goes against the grain of the UN--- its universality and worldwide responsibility for maintaining peace and security. Moreover, the problem is compounded by the uneven spread and varying capacities of regional organizations in different parts of the globe. Clearly member states from a particular region should be encouraged to spearhead international response to conflict situations within their region, but this must not detract from the significance of wider international participation in these efforts. This is important for reasons of broader legitimacy and global solidarity, as well as practical reasons of capacity.

iv. Independent Actors We are witnessing the emergence of independent actors in the general field of peacemaking and peacekeeping. Drawn from the ranks of international civil society, these actors are increasingly making direct contributions to peace processes. On account of its informal and flexible character, this sector can often complement offficial efforts, particularly in the areas of early warning, preventive activities, peacemaking, humanitarian action and peacebuilding. Different independent organizations tend to specialize in various aspects of these activities.

The proliferation of conflicts in many parts of the world, all of which call for some form of UN involvement, stands in sharp contrast to the limited capacity and resources of the Organization. In view of these contradictory pressures, the UN will have to determine more systematically where to get involved, when to get involved and to what degree to get involved. These are questions concerning the "breadth", the "depth" and the "stage" of UN engagement, which are distinct from the issue of functional priorities (i.e. investment in preventive action, mediation, traditional peacekeeping and peacebuilding activities) discussed earlier.

In general, the UN should invest its political and material resources where they are "needed most" and where they are likely to make the "greatest difference". Yet the difficulty of formulating any objective criteria for applying such a policy means that decisions will in reality be made on a case-by-case basis. Is there not a danger then that such an ad hoc method of decision-making could become entirely hostage to the fortunes and vagaries of the political process? The challenge for the Security Council in this regard is to apply, and be seen to apply, similar policies in similar situations.

While selective engagement is perhaps a necessary response to present realities, it also presents a serious moral predicament as a long-term policy. Under selective engagement, conflicts will inevitably fall into two categories: on the one side, those 'adopted' by the UN or other international organizations and, on the other, the ones that are allowed to fall between the cracks of the international system. These latter conflicts would be left to run their own course and would effectively constitute the 'forgotten tragedies' of the world. I wonder, moreover, how long international public opinion could stand by and accept such a spectacle of studied indifference, especially when the international community begins to view media images from the scenes of these tragedies.

Enforcement action is war by another name. Thus, before embarking on such action, at least three prerequisites need to be in place: adequate political will, including the will to bear the human cost of the military operation; the will and capacity to assume the necessary financial cost; and the availability of troops adequately prepared and equipped for the task. This is a tall order. It is for this reason that, for the foreseeable future, it is more practical for the UN to continue to 'farm out' such operations to 'coalitions of the willing and able.' Peacekeeping operations on the other hand must continue to adhere to the traditional principles of consent, impartiality and the non-use of force except in self-defense. Confusion between peacekeeping and enforcement action can be very dangerous. Equally dangerous is the tendency to slide from peacekeeping to enforcement action and then back again to peacekeeping.. This is essentially what unfolded in Somalia and Liberia, with disastrous consequences in both cases. All of this would seem to underscore the need to maintain a clear conceptual and operational separation between enforcement action and peacekeeping operations.

In doing so, however, we must recognize that recent experience demonstrates that on the ground there is a growing 'gray zone' between traditional peacekeeping and massive enforcement action. This is especially true in situations of internal eonfliet, which has now become the dominant categorv of eonflicts worldwide.

Let us consider the following scenarios as illustrations of the problems that can arise in the gray zone:

when an armed faction in a eonfliet unilaterally blocks the way, preventing a relief convoy from gaining access to a population in distress;

when a 'safe area' under the protection of the UN is threatened and then attacked by a party in conflict;

when a peacekeeping contingent comes under a massive attack from a well-armed faction;

Or, the situation in Rwanda in April 1994, following the presidential plane crash, when the massacres started, but before they swelled into a genocidal tide.

Could a rapid and sharp intervention, perhaps an impressive show of force by a crack unit, have made any difference in Rwanda? It is at least conceivable that such a gesture might have stemmed, if not averted altogether, the genocide that subsequently unfolded.

The above scenarios are necessarily rough and somewhat simplified, but they illustrate the variety of situations that can develop in the gray zone. For this reason, UN peacekeeping forces, particularly in internal eonflict situations, should be adequately prepared for the gradual or sudden deterioration of a situation, possibly into worst case scenarios. They need to have the capacity for escalated armed response, should this become absolutely necessary.

But this will require that at least two projects be explored more fully. First, the UN needs to develop clear guidelines regarding the conditions for a more forceful response, including a determination of decision-making responsibilities between the contingent commander on the scene, the overall mission commander, and UN headquarters in New York. Second, the UN needs to examine more seriously the various ideas on creating some sort of a rapid response capability. A rapid response force could be despatched immediately to a conflict theater in order to avert or minimize the deterioration of the situation to crisis proportions. Intervention of this kind would go beyond traditional peacekeeping, but still fall short (by its scope and duration) of a full-scale enforcement action. This may be one possible way to help fill some of the present gap in the 'gray zone'.

Peace operations, including humanitarian emergencies, have increased by leaps and bounds over the last several years. This development is producing some significant imbalances within the international system. On this occasion, I should like to highlight two areas of imbalance in particular that need to be addressed.

The first area of imbalance has to do with the growing tension between peacekeeping operations and development activities. An important disequilibrium is beginning to emerge between resource allocations for peacekeeping and emergency activities, on the one hand, and resources available for long-term peacebuilding on the other. The resources devoted by the UN and by governments to peacekeeping and emergency activities are beginning to outstnp the resources for long-term peacebuilding, in other words resources for development. Indeed, a number of governments and other donor institutions have started to divert resources from their development budgets to peacekeeping operations and humanitarian relief.

This trend needs to be reexamined --- investing in social and economic development is one of the surest ways to build a solid foundation for long-term peace in a society as well as between societies. In this connection, there is also need to consciously build a conflict management component into the design of development projects. This is especially necessary in countries where the potential for conflict escalation is high, or where a pattern of gross imbalance in the allocation of resources can provide a fertile ground for conflict.

The second area of imbalance concerns the preoccupation with humanitarian action in a conflict situation vis -a-vis the need for a political process. It is important that humanitarian action be located within an overall vision of a society in conflict. This means, in particular, that humanitarian action should move in tandem with a political process aimed at addressing the underlying causes of a conflict and achieving a political settlement. Otherwise I fear that the tremendous and admirable efforts being deployed on the humanitarian front will inevitably count for very little. The experiences of Cambodia, El Salvador and Mozambique represent examples where a combined strategy of humanitarian and political actions was successfully employed. In sharp contrast to this, however, stands the current situation in and around Rwanda (and to a lesser extent the situation in Burundi), where a major humanitarian operation is in place but no comparable concerted efforts are underway to find a political settlement to the conflict.

The dramatic growth in peacekeeping activities has simply not kept pace with the flow of financial resources. Present arrangements for national contributions have come under severe stress, and the on-going review exercise may well result in a reconfiguration of national contributions. I believe, however, that the time has now come to think more boldly and innovatively about ways to generate additional revenues for peacekeeping operations. Why not, for example, consider a direct contribution from members of the international community who, through their activities, tend to benefit disproportionately from a more stable and peaceful international situation?

There are those who may be considered "general beneficiaries", like airline travelers or transnational corporations. Why not consider, for example, a contribution to the l)N peacekeeping budget of one dollar per airline ticket this would still be less than the price of a cup of coffee at most airports ! Direct taxation on international financial transactions has been suggested as another possibility in this category. And then there "areparticular beneficiaries", which include countries like Cyprus, Cambodia, Angola, El Salvador and Mozambique, where there are on-going peace operations or where a credible measure of peace has been restored. Why not explore, as a matter of policy, special contributions from such beneficiary countries, especially those which have an actual or potentially strong revenue base?

But to explore these and other options more fully, member states must first be prepared to discard a kind of ideological prejudice surrounding discussion of this matter I refer to the view that contribution to peacekeeping operations should be an exclusive affair of governments. I do not believe that this position can be sustained in the long run.

Finally, a word about the need for an information and media strategy. There is no doubt that the UN has made and continues to make a critical contribution to international security through peacekeeping. Regrettably, this is not widely appreciated outside this house. The practice of peacekeeping as a whole has suffered from the lack of an adequate information and media strategy. A partial and unclear understanding of the nature of peacekeeping, its possibilities and constraints, and of its successes and failures, has resulted in distorted public perceptions. And this in turn is beginning to have a negative impact on national policies towards UN peacekeeping activities. Something must be done to remedy this situation.

A clearer and more aggressive public infornnation and media strategy by the UN is needed --- a better informed public is likely to be more supportive of UN peace-and-security activities.

As I stated at the opening of my remarks, the evolution of the peace-and-security agenda of the United Nations is caught at a historical crossroads today. This is a time for stocktaking; it must also be a time for sketching, however tentatively, the outlines for a future role into the next century. I am concerned that the UN should not swing from one extreme to another, from being committed to too much to undertaking too little. It is very much my hope that from the present crossroads, there should emerge a well-considered, balanced role for the UN in its mission of maintaining international peace and security.

I hope that some of the reflections I have shared with the Committee this morning will be useful in that context. I thank you, Mr. Chairman and distinguished representatives, for giving me this opportunity. I wish you much success in your important deliberations.

International Peace Academy, United Nations, New York. Tel: (212) xxxx

Distributed via Africa News Online by Africa News Service (newsdesk@afnews.org).


LOAD-DATE: July 7, 1995


LANGUAGE: English
